<p>13</p>
<p>10</p>
<p>12
The uses of medical physiology I-P allows</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="protein-transporters-act-as-carriers-pumps-or-ion-channels">Protein transporters (act as carriers, pumps or Ion channels)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#protein-transporters-act-as-carriers-pumps-or-ion-channels" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are highly specialized transmembrane proteins that allow passage of water, ions, glucose, urea and other substances through cell membranes.</p>
<ul>
<li>The carriers change their shape (configuration) when they bind their substances to move them from one side of the cell membrane to the other side, usually down the chemical or electrical gradients (= facts, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>a</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a_{n} \rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5806em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">n</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> diffusion).</li>
<li>The pumps act as ATPase enzymes to catalyze hydrolysis of ATP. The released energy is used in active transport of substances, against their chemical or electrical gradients. Examples include the Na<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^+</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> K<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^+</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ATPase pump, the proton pump and the Ca<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{2+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ATPase pump. (Remember that the active transport is either primary active or secondary active, see above).</li>
<li>The Ion channels allow simple diffusion (down chemical or electrical gradients). They include:</li>
<li>Leak channels</li>
<li>Always open. For example potassium leak channels which are responsible for the resting membrane potentials, these are found in almost all cells in the body.</li>
<li>Voltage gated channels</li>
<li>Have gates that open or close in response to changes in voltage "or potential" in the cell membrane. Examples: voltage gated sodium channels &amp; voltage gated potassium channels which are responsible for the depolarization and the repolarization phases of action potentials respectively; these are only found in excitable tissues (nerve and muscle).</li>
<li>Ligand gated channels</li>
<li>Have gates that open when certain membrane receptors bind to specific neurotransmitters or hormones, and close when these chemicals are released from the receptors.</li>
<li>Mechanic-sensitive channels</li>
<li>Have gates that open in response to direct mechanical stimulation of the cell membrane. Their activation results in generation of action potential. They are involved in movement of some cells.</li>
</ul>
<p>13
The uses of medical physiology I-P allows</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="protein-transporters-act-as-carriers-pumps-or-ion-channels">Protein transporters (act as carriers, pumps or Ion channels)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#protein-transporters-act-as-carriers-pumps-or-ion-channels" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are highly specialized transmembrane proteins that allow passage of water, ions, glucose, urea and other substances through cell membranes.</p>
<ul>
<li>The carriers change their shape (configuration) when they bind their substances to move them from one side of the cell membrane to the other side, usually down the chemical or electrical gradients (= facts, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>a</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a_{n} \rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5806em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">n</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> diffusion).</li>
<li>The pumps act as ATPase enzymes to catalyze hydrolysis of ATP. The released energy is used in active transport of substances, against their chemical or electrical gradients. Examples include the Na<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^+</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> K<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^+</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ATPase pump, the proton pump and the Ca<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{2+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ATPase pump. (Remember that the active transport is either primary active or secondary active, see above).</li>
<li>The Ion channels allow simple diffusion (down chemical or electrical gradients). They include:</li>
<li>Leak channels</li>
<li>Always open. For example potassium leak channels which are responsible for the resting membrane potentials, these are found in almost all cells in the body.</li>
<li>Voltage gated channels</li>
<li>Have gates that open or close in response to changes in voltage "or potential" in the cell membrane. Examples: voltage gated sodium channels &amp; voltage gated potassium channels which are responsible for the depolarization and the repolarization phases of action potentials respectively; these are only found in excitable tissues (nerve and muscle).</li>
<li>Ligand gated channels</li>
<li>Have gates that open when certain membrane receptors bind to specific neurotransmitters or hormones, and close when these chemicals are released from the receptors.</li>
<li>Mechanic-sensitive channels</li>
<li>Have gates that open in response to direct mechanical stimulation of the cell membrane. Their activation results in generation of action potential. They are involved in movement of some cells.</li>
</ul>
<p>14
The uses of medical physiology I-P allows</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="protein-transporters-act-as-carriers-pumps-or-ion-channels">Protein transporters (act as carriers, pumps or Ion channels)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#protein-transporters-act-as-carriers-pumps-or-ion-channels" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are highly specialized transmembrane proteins that allow passage of water, ions, glucose, urea and other substances through cell membranes.</p>
<ul>
<li>The carriers change their shape (configuration) when they bind their substances to move them from one side of the cell membrane to the other side, usually down the chemical or electrical gradients (= facts, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>a</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a_{n} \rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5806em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">n</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> diffusion).</li>
<li>The pumps act as ATPase enzymes to catalyze hydrolysis of ATP. The released energy is used in active transport of substances, against their chemical or electrical gradients. Examples include the Na<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^+</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> K<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^+</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ATPase pump, the proton pump and the Ca<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{2+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ATPase pump. (Remember that the active transport is either primary active or secondary active, see above).</li>
<li>The Ion channels allow simple diffusion (down chemical or electrical gradients). They include:</li>
<li>Leak channels</li>
<li>Always open. For example potassium leak channels which are responsible for the resting membrane potentials, these are found in almost all cells in the body.</li>
<li>Voltage gated channels</li>
<li>Have gates that open or close in response to changes in voltage "or potential" in the cell membrane. Examples: voltage gated sodium channels &amp; voltage gated potassium channels which are responsible for the depolarization and the repolarization phases of action potentials respectively, these are only found in excitable tissues (nerve and muscle).</li>
<li>Ligand gated channels</li>
<li>Have gates that open when certain membrane receptors bind to specific neurotransmitters or hormones, and close when these chemicals are released from the receptors.</li>
<li>Mechanic-sensitive channels</li>
<li>Have gates that open in response to direct mechanical stimulation of the cell membrane. Their activation results in generation of action potential. They are involved in movement of some cells.</li>
</ul>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="questions-for-self-assessment-1-best-of-five">QUESTIONS FOR SELF ASSESSMENT-1 (BEST OF FIVE)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#questions-for-self-assessment-1-best-of-five" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Concerning the cell organelles:
a. mitochondria synthesis proteins
b. endoplasmic reticulum is needed for cell division
c. nuclei are the power houses of cells
d. lysosomes contain hydrolytic enzymes
e. Golgi apparatus translates RNA into proteins</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Water passes through cell membranes by:
a. facilitated diffusion
b. primary active transport
c. osmosis
d. no transport
e. none of the above</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Maintenance of constant internal environment is known as:
a. endocytosis
b. feedback mechanism
c. physiology
d. homeostasis
e. haemostasis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Facilitated diffusion:
a. occurs against the electrical gradient
b. requires energy
c. not influenced by the concentration gradient
d. has no transport maximum capacity
e. mediated by a protein carrier</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Which of the following can cross the cell membrane passively?
a. Proteins
b. carbon dioxide
c. potassium ions
d. calcium ions
e. glucose</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Facilitated diffusion differs from simple diffusion in that it:
a. does not require energy
b. occurs against the electrical gradient
c. is not influenced by the concentration gradient
d. is mediated by a protein carrier
e. has no transport maximum capacity</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Which of the following is a passive type of transport:
a. solvent drag
b. endocytosis
c. exocytosis
d. 2nd transport
e. antipol</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>13
The care of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>

35</p>
<p>B- Concerning transport of ions across cell membranes, which of the following is not true:
a. secondary active transport requires energy
b. simple diffusion occurs down the concentration gradient
c. facilitated diffusion occurs against the electrical gradient
d. active transport is mediated by a protein carrier
e. secondary active transport has a transport maximum capacity</p>
<p>B- Concerning transport across cell membranes, all the following require integral proteins to cross cell membranes except:
a. water
b. glucose
c. oxygen
d. potassium ions
e. calcium ions</p>
<p>10-Look channels:
a. are present in almost all cells in the body
b. have given that open or close in response to changes in potential
c. open when a hormone binds to a nearby membrane receptor
d. are responsible for the depolarization phase of action potentials
e. are activated by mechanical stimulation of cell membranes</p>
<p>11-All of the following substances cross the cell membrane through channels or transporters except:
a. sodium
b. bicarbonate
c. oxygen
d. water
e. potassium</p>
<p>12-Homocissols:
a. arrest of bleeding
b. maintenance of constancy of the external environment
c. formation of a blood clot
d. normal pH
e. represented by control of body temperature</p>

<p>CHAPTER 1</p>
<p>BODY FLUIDS</p>
<p>CHAPTER 1</p>
<p>BODY FLUIDS</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="total-body-water-tbw">TOTAL BODY WATER (TBW)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#total-body-water-tbw" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Body composition in a 70 Kg young adult male:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Water = 80% (of the total weight which is 70 kg)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Proteins = 18%</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fats = 15%</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Minerals = 7%</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Carbohydrates = 1%</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Therefore, water is the most important constituent in the body.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>With total deprivation of water, survival is limited to a few days, whereas total food deprivation is tolerated for at least a month.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Total body water (in a 70 kg young adult male):</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>60% of the total body weight</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>60/100 x 70 = 42 kg = 42 L (density of water = 1; therefore Kg = L)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="variation-in-the-of-tbw-among-different-subjects">Variation in the % of TBW among different subjects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#variation-in-the-of-tbw-among-different-subjects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-of-tbw-varies-according-to">The % of TBW varies according to:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-of-tbw-varies-according-to" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Age</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The percentage of TBW decreases with age (e.g. in an embryo it is almost 100%, in a neonate &gt; 80%, in an adult male = 80% and above the age of 60 years = 62%)</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Sex</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The % of TBW is higher in males when compared to equivalent females. This can be explained by the fact that the female has higher percentage of fat in her body than a male of the same age and weight.</li>
<li>The higher percentage of fat is associated with less percentage of water because fat cells contain less water than other types of cells. For example, water in a fat cell is about 13% whereas in a muscle cell is about 70%.</li>
</ul>
<p>13</p>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="total-body-water-tbw">TOTAL BODY WATER (TBW)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#total-body-water-tbw" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Body composition in a 70 Kg young adult male:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Water = 80% (of the total weight which is 70 kg)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Proteins = 18%</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fats = 15%</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Minerals = 7%</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Carbohydrates = 1%</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Therefore, water is the most important constituent in the body.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>With total deprivation of water, survival is limited to a few days, whereas total food deprivation is tolerated for at least a month.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Total body water (in a 70 kg young adult male):</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>60% of the total body weight</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>60/100 x 70 = 42 kg = 42 L (density of water = 1; therefore Kg = L)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="variation-in-the-of-tbw-among-different-subjects">Variation in the % of TBW among different subjects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#variation-in-the-of-tbw-among-different-subjects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-of-tbw-varies-according-to">The % of TBW varies according to:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-of-tbw-varies-according-to" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Age</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The percentage of TBW decreases with age (e.g. in an embryo it is almost 100%, in a neonate &gt; 80%, in an adult male = 80% and above the age of 60 years = 52%)</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Sex</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The % of TBW is higher in males when compared to equivalent females. This can be explained by the fact that the female has higher percentage of fat in her body than a male of the same age and weight.</li>
<li>The higher percentage of fat is associated with less percentage of water because fat cells contain less water than other types of cells. For example, water in a fat cell is about 13% whereas in a muscle cell is about 70%.</li>
</ul>
<p>13</p>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="total-body-water-tbw">TOTAL BODY WATER (TBW)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#total-body-water-tbw" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Body composition in a 70 Kg young adult male:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Water = 80% (of the total weight which is 70 kg)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Proteins = 18%</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fats = 15%</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Minerals = 7%</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Carbohydrates = 1%</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Therefore, water is the most important constituent in the body.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>With total deprivation of water, survival is limited to a few days, whereas total food deprivation is tolerated for at least a month.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Total body water (in a 70 kg young adult male):</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>60% of the total body weight</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>60/100 x 70 = 42 kg = 42 L (density of water = 1; therefore Kg = L)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="variation-in-the-of-tbw-among-different-subjects">Variation in the % of TBW among different subjects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#variation-in-the-of-tbw-among-different-subjects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-of-tbw-varies-according-to">The % of TBW varies according to:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-of-tbw-varies-according-to" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Age</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The percentage of TBW decreases with age (e.g. in an embryo it is almost 100%, in a neonate &gt; 80%, in an adult male &gt; 80% and above the age of 60 years = 52%)</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Sex</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The % of TBW is higher in males when compared to equivalent females. This can be explained by the fact that the female has higher percentage of fat in her body than a male of the same age and weight.</li>
<li>The higher percentage of fat is associated with less percentage of water because fat cells contain less water than other types of cells. For example, water in a fat cell is about 13% whereas in a muscle cell is about 70%.</li>
</ul>
<p>13</p>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Body size</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The % of TBW is higher in thin-lad subjects than obese-third subjects.</li>
<li>This is also explained by the higher percentage of fat in the obese subject, and therefore less percentage of water.</li>
</ul>
<p>Tablet 1: % of TBW in males and females of different ages</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Age</th><th>% of water in a male</th><th>% of water in a female</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Embryo</td><td>Almost 100%</td><td>Almost 100%</td></tr><tr><td>Neonate</td><td>90%</td><td>90%</td></tr><tr><td>Adult</td><td>90%</td><td>51%</td></tr><tr><td>Elderly</td><td>52%</td><td>46%</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Body Fluid Compartments</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>As mentioned in the introduction of this book, cells of the body do not only contain water, but also surrounded by water.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Therefore, total body water is divided into two compartments:</p>
</li>
<li>
<ol>
<li>Intracellular fluid (ECF) = 2/3 of the total body water or 40% of the total body weight (TBw).</li>
</ol>
</li>
<li>
<ol start="2">
<li>Extracellular fluid (ECF) = 1/3 of the total body water or 20% of the total body weight (TBw).</li>
</ol>
</li>
<li>
<p>ECF is further divided into:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>a) Interstitial fluid = 75% of ECF or 15% of TBw.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>b) Intravascular fluid (plasma) = 25% of ECF or 5% of TBw.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>c) Trans-cellular fluid: Negligible.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Notes about trans-cellular fluid</p>
<ul>
<li>It includes synovial fluid, pleural fluid, pericardial fluid, peritoneal fluid, cerebrospinal fluid.</li>
<li>Its volume is very low, that's why it is not included in calculations of ECF.</li>
<li>In abnormal conditions (line pleural effusion, pericardial effusion and ascites) its volume becomes very high.</li>
</ul>
<p>48</p>
<p>The term of method [A] is changed to "adduct"</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Body size</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The % of TBW is higher in thin-lad subjects than obese-third subjects.</li>
<li>This is also explained by the higher percentage of fat in the obese subject, and therefore less percentage of water.</li>
</ul>
<p>Tablet 1: % of TBW in males and females of different ages</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Age</th><th>% of water in a male</th><th>% of water in a female</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Embryo</td><td>Almost 100%</td><td>Almost 100%</td></tr><tr><td>Neonate</td><td>90%</td><td>90%</td></tr><tr><td>Adult</td><td>90%</td><td>51%</td></tr><tr><td>Elderly</td><td>52%</td><td>46%</td></tr></tbody></table>

<li>
<p>Body Fluid Compartments</p>

</li>
<li>
<p>Therefore, total body water is divided into two compartments:</p>
</li>
<li>
<ol>
<li>Intracellular fluid (ECF) = 2/3 of the total body water or 40% of the total body weight (TBw).</li>
</ol>
</li>
<li>
<ol start="2">
<li>Extracellular fluid (ECF) = 1/3 of the total body water or 20% of the total body weight (TBw).</li>
</ol>
</li>
<li>
<p>ECF is further divided into:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>a) Interstitial fluid = 75% of ECF or 15% of TBw.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>b) Intravascular fluid (plasma) = 25% of ECF or 5% of TBw.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>c) Trans-cellular fluid: Negligible.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Notes about trans-cellular fluid</p>
<ul>
<li>It includes synovial fluid, pleural fluid, pericardial fluid, peritoneal fluid, cerebrospinal fluid.</li>
<li>Its volume is very low, that's why it is not included in calculations of ECF.</li>
<li>In abnormal conditions (line pleural effusion, pericardial effusion and ascites) its volume becomes very high.</li>
</ul>

<li>This is also explained by the higher percentage of fat in the obese subject, and therefore less percentage of water.</li>
</ul>

<table><thead><tr><th>Age</th><th>% of water in a male</th><th>% of water in a female</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Embryo</td><td>Almost 100%</td><td>Almost 100%</td></tr><tr><td>Neonate</td><td>90%</td><td>90%</td></tr><tr><td>Adult</td><td>90%</td><td>51%</td></tr><tr><td>Elderly</td><td>52%</td><td>46%</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul>
<li>

</li>
<li>
<p>As mentioned in the introduction of this book, cells of the body do not only contain water, but also surrounded by water.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Therefore, total body water is divided into two compartments:</p>
</li>
<li>
<ol>
<li>Intracellular fluid (ECF) = 2/3 of the total body water or 40% of the total body weight (TBw).</li>
</ol>
</li>
<li>
<ol start="2">
<li>Extracellular fluid (ECF) = 1/3 of the total body water or 20% of the total body weight (TBw).</li>
</ol>
</li>
<li>
<p>ECF is further divided into:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>a) Interstitial fluid = 75% of ECF or 15% of TBw.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>b) Intravascular fluid (plasma) = 25% of ECF or 5% of TBw.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>c) Trans-cellular fluid: Negligible.</p>

<ul>
<li>It includes synovial fluid, pleural fluid, pericardial fluid, peritoneal fluid, cerebrospinal fluid.</li>
<li>Its volume is very low, that's why it is not included in calculations of ECF.</li>
<li>In abnormal conditions (line pleural effusion, pericardial effusion and ascites) its volume becomes very high.</li>
</ul>
<p>50</p>
<p>The term of method [A] is changed to "adduct"</p>
<p>17
The text of medical physiology 17th edition</p>
<ul>
<li>In a 70 Kg adult male:</li>
<li>Total body water = 42 L (60% of the total body weight)</li>
<li>ICF = 28 L (= 40% of total body weight)</li>
<li>ECF = 14 L (= 20% of total body weight)</li>
<li>IBF = 10.6 L (= 16% of total body weight)</li>
<li>IVF (Plasma) = 3.5 L (= 5% of total body weight)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Question:</strong>
Calculate the expected body fluid compartments in an average 60 kg adult male.</p>
<p><strong>Answer:</strong>
Total body weight = 60 Kg, therefore. Total body water = 60/100 x 60 = 36 L, ICF = 40/100 x 60 = 24 L, ECF = 20/100 x 60 = 12 L, IBF = 10/100 x 60 = 9 L and IVF = 5/100 x 60 = 3 L.</p>
<p><strong>Notes about body fluid compartments in neonatal:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>In a 70 Kg adult male:</li>
<li>Total body water = 42 L (60% of the total body weight)</li>
<li>ICF = 28 L (= 40% of total body weight)</li>
<li>ECF = 14 L (= 20% of total body weight)</li>
<li>IBF = 10.6 L (= 15% of total body weight)</li>
<li>IVF (Plasma) = 3.5 L (= 5% of total body weight)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Question:</strong>
Calculate the expected body fluid compartments in an average 60 kg adult male.</p>
<p><strong>Answer:</strong>
Total body weight = 60 Kg, therefore. Total body water = 60/100 x 60 = 36 L, ICF = 40/100 x 60 = 24 L, ECF = 20/100 x 60 = 12 L, IBF = 10/100 x 60 = 9 L and IVF = 5/100 x 60 = 3 L.</p>
<p><strong>Notes about body fluid compartments in neonatal:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>In a 70 Kg adult male:</li>
<li>Total body water = 42 L (60% of the total body weight)</li>
<li>ICF = 28 L (= 40% of total body weight)</li>
<li>ECF = 14 L (= 20% of total body weight)</li>
<li>IBF = 10.6 L (= 15% of total body weight)</li>
<li>IVF (Plasma) = 3.5 L (= 5% of total body weight)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Question:</strong>
Calculate the expected body fluid compartments in an average 60 kg adult male.</p>
<p><strong>Answer:</strong>
Total body weight = 60 Kg, therefore. Total body water = 60/100 x 60 = 36 L, ICF = 40/100 x 60 = 24 L, ECF = 20/100 x 60 = 12 L, IBF = 10/100 x 60 = 9 L and IVF = 5/100 x 60 = 3 L.</p>
<p><strong>Notes about body fluid compartments in neonatal:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>In a 70 Kg adult male:</li>
<li>Total body water = 42 L (60% of the total body weight)</li>
<li>ICF = 28 L (= 40% of total body weight)</li>
<li>ECF = 14 L (= 20% of total body weight)</li>
<li>IBF = 10.6 L (= 15% of total body weight)</li>
<li>IVF (Plasma) = 3.5 L (= 5% of total body weight)</li>

<p><strong>Question:</strong>
Calculate the expected body fluid compartments in an average 60 kg adult male.</p>
<p><strong>Answer:</strong>
Total body weight = 60 Kg, therefore. Total body water = 60/100 x 60 = 36 L, ICF = 40/100 x 60 = 24 L, ECF = 20/100 x 60 = 12 L, IBF = 10/100 x 60 = 9 L and IVF = 5/100 x 60 = 3 L.</p>
<p>Table 1.2: Differences between ECF and ICF in a 70-kg adult male</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Difference</th><th>Extracellular fluid</th><th>Intracellular fluid</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Volume</td><td>10L</td><td>20L</td></tr><tr><td>Conc. Of Cations:</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Sodium (Na⁺)</td><td>142.0 mmol/L</td><td>10 mmol/L</td></tr><tr><td>Potassium (K⁺)</td><td>4.0 mmol/L</td><td>140 mmol/L</td></tr><tr><td>Calcium (Ca²⁺)</td><td>3.5 mmol/L</td><td>Negligible (0)</td></tr><tr><td>Magnesium (Mg²⁺)</td><td>2.0 mmEq/L</td><td>39 mmEq/L</td></tr><tr><td>Conc. Of Anions:</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Chloride (Cl⁻)</td><td>150.0 mmol/L</td><td>4 mmol/L</td></tr><tr><td>Bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻)</td><td>28.0 mmol/L</td><td>10 mmol/L</td></tr><tr><td>Phosphate (PO₄³⁻)</td><td>2.0 mEq/L</td><td>100 mEq/L</td></tr><tr><td>Protein</td><td>17.0 mEq/L</td><td>93 mEq/L</td></tr><tr><td>pH</td><td>7.4</td><td>7.2</td></tr><tr><td>Temperature</td><td>37 °C</td><td>37 °C</td></tr><tr><td>Sensitivity</td><td>280-300 mOsm/L</td><td>280-300 mOsm/L</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Measurement of body Fluid Compartments</p>
<ul>
<li>Volumes of body fluid compartments can be measured using the indicator (dye) dilution method</li>
<li>In this method, a known quantity of a substance (e.g. a dye) is injected and allowed to distribute in the compartment of interest. After distribution, a sample of fluid is taken from the same compartment to measure the final concentration of the dye. Then the volume of the compartment (known as the volume of distribution of the dye) is calculated using the formula</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Volume&nbsp;of&nbsp;distribution</mtext><mo>=</mo><mi>G</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mfrac><mi>d</mi><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Volume of distribution} = G \cdot a \cdot l \cdot \frac{d}{d t}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Volume&nbsp;of&nbsp;distribution</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">G</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋅</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋅</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.01968em;">l</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋅</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0574em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>Where:</p>
<ul>
<li>G is the quantity of the dye injected</li>
<li>l = the rate of method (dry) change / l</li>
<li>l = the rate of method (dry) change / l</li>
</ul>
<p>Table 1.2: Differences between ECF and ICF in a 70-kg adult male</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Difference</th><th>Extracellular fluid</th><th>Intracellular fluid</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Volume</td><td>10L</td><td>20L</td></tr><tr><td>Conc. Of Cations:</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Sodium (Na⁺)</td><td>142.0 mmol/L</td><td>10 mmol/L</td></tr><tr><td>Potassium (K⁺)</td><td>4.0 mmol/L</td><td>140 mmol/L</td></tr><tr><td>Calcium (Ca²⁺)</td><td>3.5 mmol/L</td><td>Negligible (0)</td></tr><tr><td>Magnesium (Mg²⁺)</td><td>2.0 mmEq/L</td><td>39 mmEq/L</td></tr><tr><td>Conc. Of Anions:</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Chloride (Cl⁻)</td><td>150.0 mmol/L</td><td>4 mmol/L</td></tr><tr><td>Bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻)</td><td>28.0 mmol/L</td><td>10 mmol/L</td></tr><tr><td>Phosphate (PO₄³⁻)</td><td>2.0 mEq/L</td><td>100 mEq/L</td></tr><tr><td>Protein</td><td>17.0 mEq/L</td><td>93 mEq/L</td></tr><tr><td>pH</td><td>7.4</td><td>7.2</td></tr><tr><td>Temperature</td><td>37 °C</td><td>37 °C</td></tr><tr><td>Sensitivity</td><td>280-300 mOsm/L</td><td>280-300 mOsm/L</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Measurement of body fluid compartments</p>
<ul>
<li>Volumes of body fluid compartments can be measured using the indicator (dye) dilution method</li>
<li>In this method, a known quantity of a substance (e.g. a dye) is injected and allowed to distribute in the compartment of interest. After distribution, a sample of fluid is taken from the same compartment to measure the final concentration of the dye. Then the volume of the compartment (known as the volume of distribution of the dye) is calculated using the formula</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Volume&nbsp;of&nbsp;distribution</mtext><mo>=</mo><mi>G</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mfrac><mi>d</mi><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Volume of distribution} = G \cdot a \cdot l \cdot \frac{d}{d t}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Volume&nbsp;of&nbsp;distribution</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">G</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋅</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋅</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.01968em;">l</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋅</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0574em; <p>Where:</p>
<ul>
<li>G is the quantity of the dye injected</li>

<p>Measurement of body fluid compartments</p>
<ul>
<li>Volumes of body fluid compartments can be measured using the indicator (dye) dilution method</li>
<li>In this method, a known quantity of a substance (e.g. a dye) is injected and allowed to distribute in the compartment of interest. After distribution, a sample of fluid is taken from the same compartment to measure the final concentration of the dye. Then the volume of the compartment (known as the volume of distribution of the dye) is calculated using the formula</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Volume&nbsp;of&nbsp;distribution</mtext><mo>=</mo><mi>G</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mfrac><mi>d</mi><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Volume of distribution} = G \cdot a \cdot l \cdot \frac{d}{d t}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Volume&nbsp;of&nbsp;distribution</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">G</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋅</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋅</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.01968em;">l</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋅</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0574em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>Where:</p>
<ul>
<li>G is the quantity of the dye injected</li>
<li>l = the rate of method (dry) change / l</li>
</ul>
<p>14
The use of medical physiology 1st edition</p>
<p>-a is the amount of the dye excreted or metabolized by cells
-C is the concentration of the dye after equilibration</p>
<p>Substances used for measurement of body fluid compartments should have the following characteristics:</p>
<ul>
<li>Non toxic</li>
<li>Easily measured</li>
<li>Their amounts are not altered by the body (not stored, metabolized, excreted or produced by the body) or the altered amount can be calculated easily</li>
<li>Distribute only in the compartment being measured</li>
<li>Do not affect water distribution in other compartments</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Remember that</strong>
a Leakage of a substance into other compartment decreases its final concentration and therefore increases the calculated volume of distribution.</p>
<p><strong>Examples for substances used in measurement of body fluids:</strong>
<strong>Substances used in measurement of total body water:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Glutathion oxide (heavy water)</li>
<li>Tritium oxide (³H₂O + an isotope of water)</li>
<li>Antipyrine</li>
<li>Aminopyridine</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Substances used in measurement of extracellular fluid:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Saccharides (main, mantol &amp; sucrose)</li>
<li>These fail to penetrate the trans-cellular fluid</li>
<li>Therefore sₙₐ, rediss黏膜 to the ECF</li>
<li>Radioactive electrolytes (sodium, chloride &amp; bromide)</li>
<li>These easily penetrate the entire ECF and may escape into cells</li>
<li>Therefore they overestimate the ECF</li>
</ul>
<p><em>Phosulphate &amp; thiocyanate</em></p>
<p>15
The use of medical physiology 1st edition</p>
<p>-a is the amount of the dye excreted or metabolized by cells
-C is the concentration of the dye after equilibration</p>
<p>Substances used for measurement of body fluid compartments should have the following characteristics:</p>
<ul>
<li>Non toxic</li>
<li>Easily measured</li>
<li>Their amounts are not altered by the body (not stored, metabolized, excreted or produced by the body) or the altered amount can be calculated easily</li>
<li>Distribute only in the compartment being measured</li>
<li>Do not affect water distribution in other compartments</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Remember that</strong>
a Leakage of a substance into other compartment decreases its final concentration and therefore increases the calculated volume of distribution.</p>
<p><strong>Examples for substances used in measurement of body fluids:</strong>

<li>Antipyrine</li>

<li>Therefore sₙₐ, rediss黏膜 to the ECF</li>
<li>Radioactive electrolytes (sodium, chloride &amp; bromide)</li>

<li>Therefore they overestimate the ECF</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="substances-used-in-measurement-of-plasma">Substances used in measurement of plasma:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#substances-used-in-measurement-of-plasma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Radioactive iodine used to label serum albumin (RBA)</li>
<li>Event's blue dye (which binds to plasma protein and stay in plasma)</li>
<li>Labeled macroglybulin</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="substances-used-in-measurement-of-blood">Substances used in measurement of blood:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#substances-used-in-measurement-of-blood" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Blood volume can be calculated from plasma and packed cell volume (PCV) by the formula: Blood × Plasma X 100/100-PCV</li>
<li>The PCV is measured by centrifugation of a sample of blood in a capillary tube, and then the percentage of the packed cells at the bottom of the tube is calculated (read about the PCV in chapter 5).</li>
<li>It is also calculated from red blood cell volume and plasma volume by the formula: Blood × plasma × red blood cell volume</li>
<li>The red blood cell volume is obtained from the volume of distribution of re-injected red blood cells labeled with radioactive chromium (¹⁴Cr).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="intracellular-fluid-and-interstitial-fluid">Intracellular fluid and interstitial fluid:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intracellular-fluid-and-interstitial-fluid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Are measured indirectly by two substances, for two compartments. Then ICF or ISF can be subtracted as follows:</li>
<li>ICF × TBW - ECF</li>
<li>ISF × ECF - plasma</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="factors-affecting-body-fluid-compartments">Factors Affecting Body Fluid Compartments<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#factors-affecting-body-fluid-compartments" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Body fluid compartments are affected by:</p>
<ol>
<li>Damosis</li>
<li>Diffusion</li>
<li>Gibbs Doman equilibrium</li>
<li>Sodium-potassium pump</li>
<li>Starling's forces</li>
<li>Abnormalities of water balance</li>
</ol>
<p>The one of station phycology®® plates</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="substances-used-in-measurement-of-plasma">Substances used in measurement of plasma:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#substances-used-in-measurement-of-plasma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Radioactive iodine used to label serum albumin (RBA)</li>
<li>Event's blue dye (which binds to plasma protein and stay in plasma)</li>
<li>Labeled macroglybulin</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="substances-used-in-measurement-of-blood">Substances used in measurement of blood:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#substances-used-in-measurement-of-blood" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Blood volume can be calculated from plasma and packed cell volume (PCV) by the formula: Blood × Plasma X 100/100-PCV</li>
<li>The PCV is measured by centrifugation of a sample of blood in a capillary tube, and then the percentage of the packed cells at the bottom of the tube is calculated (read about the PCV in chapter 5).</li>
<li>It is also calculated from red blood cell volume and plasma volume by the formula: Blood × plasma × red blood cell volume</li>
<li>The red blood cell volume is obtained from the volume of distribution of re-injected red blood cells labeled with radioactive chromium (¹⁴Cr).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="intracellular-fluid-and-interstitial-fluid">Intracellular fluid and interstitial fluid:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intracellular-fluid-and-interstitial-fluid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Are measured indirectly by two substances, for two compartments. Then ICF or ISF can be subtracted as follows:</li>
<li>ICF × TBW - ECF</li>
<li>ISF × ECF - plasma</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="factors-affecting-body-fluid-compartments">Factors Affecting Body Fluid Compartments<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#factors-affecting-body-fluid-compartments" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Body fluid compartments are affected by:</p>
<ol>
<li>Damosis</li>
<li>Diffusion</li>
<li>Gibbs Doman equilibrium</li>
<li>Sodium-potassium pump</li>
<li>Starling's forces</li>
<li>Abnormalities of water balance</li>
</ol>
<p>The one of station phycology®® plates</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="substances-used-in-measurement-of-plasma">Substances used in measurement of plasma:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#substances-used-in-measurement-of-plasma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Radioactive iodine used to label serum albumin (RBA)</li>
<li>Event's blue dye (which binds to plasma protein and stay in plasma)</li>
<li>Labeled macroglybulin</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="substances-used-in-measurement-of-blood">Substances used in measurement of blood:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#substances-used-in-measurement-of-blood" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Blood volume can be calculated from plasma and packed cell volume (PCV) by the formula: Blood × Plasma X 100/100-PCV</li>
<li>The PCV is measured by centrifugation of a sample of blood in a capillary tube, and then the percentage of the packed cells at the bottom of the tube is calculated (read about the PCV in chapter 5).</li>
<li>It is also calculated from red blood cell volume and plasma volume by the formula: Blood × plasma × red blood cell volume</li>
<li>The red blood cell volume is obtained from the volume of distribution of re-injected red blood cells labeled with radioactive chromium (¹⁴Cr).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="intracellular-fluid-and-interstitial-fluid">Intracellular fluid and interstitial fluid:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intracellular-fluid-and-interstitial-fluid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Are measured indirectly by two substances, for two compartments. Then ICF or ISF can be subtracted as follows:</li>
<li>ICF × TBW - ECF</li>
<li>ISF × ECF - plasma</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="factors-affecting-body-fluid-compartments">Factors Affecting Body Fluid Compartments<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#factors-affecting-body-fluid-compartments" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Body fluid compartments are affected by:</p>
<ol>
<li>Damosis</li>
<li>Diffusion</li>
<li>Gibbs Doman equilibrium</li>
<li>Sodium-potassium pump</li>
<li>Starling's forces</li>
<li>Abnormalities of water balance</li>
</ol>
<p>The one of station phycology®® plates</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1-demosis">1. Demosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-demosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Demosis is the movement of water molecules across a semi-permeable membrane, from a region of lower concentration of a solute to a region of higher concentration of the solute (see the introduction).</li>
<li>All cell membranes and capillaries are semi-permeable membranes (permeable to water and generally not permeable to solute).</li>
<li>For demosis to occur there should be a difference in solute concentration between the two sides of the membrane, i.e. difference in osmolarity.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-1-1-demosis">Fig 1.1: Demosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-1-1-demosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>1</th><th>solution A</th><th>solution B</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Solution A has the same concentration as solution B</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• No demosis</td><td>☐ ☐</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>☐ ☐</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>☐ ☐</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>☐ ☐</td><td>☐ ☐</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>☐ ☐</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>☐ ☐</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>☐ ☐</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>2</td><td>solution A</td><td>solution B</td></tr><tr><td>---</td><td>---</td><td>---</td></tr><tr><td>Solution A has higher concentration than solution B</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Demosis from B to A</td><td>☐ ☐</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>☐ ☐</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>☐ ☐</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>☐ ☐</td><td>☐</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>☐</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>☐</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="osmolarity-osmolarity-toxicity">Osmolarity, Osmolarity &amp; Toxicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#osmolarity-osmolarity-toxicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="osmolarity">Osmolarity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#osmolarity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Osmolarity is the number of osmoles of solute per one liter of solution.</li>
<li>It is used to describe concentrations of osmolarity active particles in a solution.</li>
<li>If a solute dissociates into one to form an ideal solution, each liberated ion is an osmolarity active particle.</li>
<li>For example: dissociation of one mole of (NaCl) gives one osmole of sodium and one osmole of chloride (i.e. 2 osmoles).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1-osmosis">1. Osmosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-osmosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Osmosis is the movement of water molecules across a semi-permeable membrane, from a region of lower concentration of a solute to a region of higher concentration of the solute (see the introduction).</li>
<li>All cell membranes and capillaries are semi-permeable membranes (permeable to water and generally not permeable to solute).</li>
<li>For osmosis to occur there should be a difference in solute concentration between the two sides of the membrane, i.e. difference in osmolarity.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-1-1-osmosis">Fig 1.1: Osmosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-1-1-osmosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>1</th><th>solution A</th><th>solution B</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Solution A has the same concentration as solution B</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• No osmosis</td><td>☐ ☐</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>☐ ☐</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>☐ ☐</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>☐ ☐</td><td>☐ ☐</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>☐ ☐</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>☐ ☐</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>☐ ☐</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>2</td><td>solution A</td><td>solution B</td></tr><tr><td>---</td><td>---</td><td>---</td></tr><tr><td>Solution A has higher concentration than solution B</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Osmosis from B to A</td><td>☐ ☐</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>☐ ☐</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>☐ ☐</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>☐ ☐</td><td>☐</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>☐</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>☐</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="osmolarity-osmolarity-toxicity">Osmolarity, Osmolarity &amp; Toxicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#osmolarity-osmolarity-toxicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="osmolarity">Osmolarity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#osmolarity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Osmolarity is the number of osmoles of solute per one liter of solution.</li>
<li>It is used to describe concentrations of osmolarity active particles in a solution.</li>
<li>If a solute dissociates into one to form an ideal solution, each liberated ion is an osmolarity active particle.</li>
<li>For example: dissociation of one mole of (NaCl) gives one osmole of sodium and one osmole of chloride (i.e. 2 osmoles).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1-osmosis">1. Osmosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-osmosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Osmosis is the movement of water molecules across a semi-permeable membrane, from a region of lower concentration of a solute to a region of higher concentration of the solute (see the introduction).</li>
<li>All cell membranes and capillaries are semi-permeable membranes (permeable to water and generally not permeable to solute).</li>
<li>For osmosis to occur there should be a difference in solute concentration between the two sides of the membrane, i.e. difference in osmolarity.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-1-1-osmosis">Fig 1.1: Osmosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-1-1-osmosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
