<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="osmolarity-osmolarity-toxicity">Osmolarity, Osmolarity &amp; Toxicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#osmolarity-osmolarity-toxicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="osmolarity">Osmolarity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#osmolarity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Osmolarity is the number of osmoles of solute per one liter of solution.</li>
<li>It is used to describe concentrations of osmolarity active particles in a solution.</li>
<li>If a solute dissociates into one to form an ideal solution, each liberated ion is an osmolarity active particle.</li>
<li>For example: dissociation of one mole of (NaCl) gives one osmole of sodium and one osmole of chloride (i.e. 2 osmoles).</li>
</ul>
<p>1</p>
<ul>
<li>However, one mole of glucose <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>10</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>8</mn></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{C_{6}H_{10}O_{8}})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">C</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">6</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">10</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">8</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> in a solution gives one osmolar because organic substances like glucose are non-ionizable.</li>
<li>Remember that one mole of a substance contains the same number of molecules that are found in one mole of any other substance (&gt; Avogadro's number = 5.061 x 10<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>20</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{20}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">20</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>).</li>
<li>The osmotically active particles can exert osmotic pressure if they are in contact with another solution, but separated from it by a semi-perme (lie membrane (permeable to the solvent but not to the solute).</li>
<li>Osmotic pressure is defined as the pressure necessary to prevent solvent migration (i.e. prevent osmosis).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-841eb1d9.jpeg" alt="img-23.jpeg">
Fig 1.2: The osmotic pressure</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-0ff89081.jpeg" alt="img-24.jpeg">
Fig 1.3: The osmotic pressure</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-d6771dfe.jpeg" alt="img-25.jpeg">
Fig 1.2: The osmotic pressure</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="osmolarity">Osmolarity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#osmolarity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Osmolarity is the number of osmoles per one kilogram of solvent.</li>
<li>It is more accurate than osmolarity since it depends on mass (which is constant) rather than volume (which is affected by changes in temperature and pressure).</li>
</ul>
<p>33</p>
<p>The area of method [m²/cm²] <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>2</mn><mn>10</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2^{10}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">10</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> m²/cm²</p>
<ul>
<li>However, one mole of glucose <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>10</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>8</mn></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{C_{6}H_{10}O_{8}})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">C</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">6</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">10</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">8</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> in a solution gives one osmolar because organic substances like glucose are non-ionizable.</li>
<li>Remember that one mole of a substance contains the same number of molecules that are found in one mole of any other substance (&gt; Avogadro's number = 5.061 x 10<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>20</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{20}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">20</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>).</li>
<li>The osmotically active particles can exert osmotic pressure if they are in contact with another solution, but separated from it by a semi-perme (lie membrane (permeable to the solvent but not to the solute).</li>
<li>Osmotic pressure is defined as the pressure necessary to prevent solvent migration (i.e. prevent osmosis).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="osmolarity">Osmolarity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#osmolarity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Osmolarity is the number of osmoles per one kilogram of solvent.</li>
<li>It is more accurate than osmolarity since it depends on mass (which is constant) rather than volume (which is affected by changes in temperature and pressure).</li>
</ul>
<p>33</p>
<p>The area of method [m²/cm²] <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>2</mn><mn>10</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2^{10}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">10</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> m²/cm²</p>
<p>In body fluids, where the solvent is water, the concentration of solutes is very low (highly diluted); therefore one liter and one kilogram are equal. Moreover, temperature and pressure are constant under normal physiological conditions; that's why osmolality and osmolarity are equal in body fluids.</p>
<p>Because of this similarity between osmolality and osmolarity, you may find osmolality expressed in (mosmol⁻¹) rather than (mosmol⁻²).</p>
<p>Osmolarity of plasma = (280-300) mosmol⁻¹. Na⁺ and its anions are responsible for most of this value (Na⁺ determines ICF osmolality).</p>
<p>Osmolarity of intracellular fluid = (280-300) mosmol⁻¹. K⁺ and its anions are responsible for most of this value (K⁺ determines ICF osmolality).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="toxicity">Toxicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#toxicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This term is used when describing osmolality of a solution relative to osmolality of the plasma.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Accordingly, solutions may be:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Isotonic (with osmolality similar to plasma)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypotonic (with osmolality lower than plasma)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypertonic (with osmolality higher than plasma)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Intravenous (IV) infusion of each type of these solutions affects volumes and osmolarities of body fluid compartments. These effects can be studied from the following figure and table:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 1.3: The effects of different types of solutions on cells:</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-578f529a.jpeg" alt="img-26.jpeg"></p>
<p>23</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-aaf3e7f4.jpeg" alt="img-27.jpeg"></p>
<p>24</p>
<p>In body fluids, where the solvent is water, the concentration of solutes is very low (highly diluted); therefore one liter and one kilogram are equal. Moreover, temperature and pressure are constant under normal physiological conditions; that's why osmolality and osmolarity are equal in body fluids.</p>
<p>Because of this similarity between osmolality and osmolarity, you may find osmolality expressed in (mosmol⁻¹) rather than (mosmol⁻²).</p>
<p>Osmolarity of plasma = (280-300) mosmol⁻¹. Na⁺ and its anions are responsible for most of this value (Na⁺ determines ICF osmolality).</p>
<p>Osmolarity of intracellular fluid = (280-300) mosmol⁻¹. K⁺ and its anions are responsible for most of this value (K⁺ determines ICF osmolality).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="toxicity">Toxicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#toxicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This term is used when describing osmolality of a solution relative to osmolality of the plasma.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Accordingly, solutions may be:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Isotonic (with osmolality similar to plasma)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypotonic (with osmolality lower than plasma)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypertonic (with osmolality higher than plasma)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Intravenous (IV) infusion of each type of these solutions affects volumes and osmolarities of body fluid compartments. These effects can be studied from the following figure and table:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 1.3: The effects of different types of solutions on cells:</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-df5afb77.jpeg" alt="img-28.jpeg"></p>
<p>25</p>
<p>In body fluids, where the solvent is water, the concentration of solutes is very low (highly diluted); therefore one liter and one kilogram are equal. Moreover, temperature and pressure are constant under normal physiological conditions; that's why osmolality and osmolarity are equal in body fluids.</p>
<p>Because of this similarity between osmolality and osmolarity, you may find osmolality expressed in (mosmol⁻¹) rather than (mosmol⁻²).</p>
<p>Osmolarity of plasma = (280-300) mosmol⁻¹. Na⁺ and its anions are responsible for most of this value (Na⁺ determines ICF osmolality).</p>
<p>Osmolarity of intracellular fluid = (280-300) mosmol⁻¹. K⁺ and its anions are responsible for most of this value (K⁺ determines ICF osmolality).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="toxicity">Toxicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#toxicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This term is used when describing osmolality of a solution relative to osmolality of the plasma.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Accordingly, solutions may be:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Isotonic (with osmolality similar to plasma)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypotonic (with osmolality lower than plasma)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypertonic (with osmolality higher than plasma)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Intravenous (IV) infusion of each type of these solutions affects volumes and osmolarities of body fluid compartments. These effects can be studied from the following figure and table:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 1.3: The effects of different types of solutions on cells:</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-0f77b37b.jpeg" alt="img-29.jpeg"></p>
<p>26</p>
<p>This note of method (p5) is the part of "additive"</p>
<p>24
The text of abstract physiology: 4th edition</p>
<p>Table 1.3: Effects of I.V. solutions on volumes and osmolarities</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Solution</th><th>ECF</th><th></th><th>Osmosis</th><th>ICF</th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td></td><td>Vol.</td><td>Osmol.</td><td></td><td>Vol.</td><td>Osmol.</td></tr><tr><td>Isotonic</td><td>↑</td><td>The same</td><td>×</td><td>The same</td><td>The same</td></tr><tr><td>Hypotonic</td><td>↑</td><td>↓</td><td>—</td><td>↑</td><td>↓</td></tr><tr><td>Hypertonic</td><td>↑</td><td>↑</td><td>—</td><td>↓</td><td>↑</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul>
<li>From the above table:</li>
<li>I.V. infusion of an isotonic solution increases volume of ECF with no effect on its osmolarity, and no effect on volume or osmolarity of ICF (i.e. no effect on cells).</li>
<li>I.V. infusion of a hypotonic solution increases volumes of ECF and ICF and decreases osmolarities of ECF and ICF.</li>
<li>I.V. infusion of a hypertonic solution increases volume and osmolarity of ECF, and decreases volume of ICF while its osmolarity is increased.</li>
</ul>
<p>Calculation of osmolality:</p>
<p>A. From the Freezing Point Depression</p>
<ul>
<li>One osmole depresses the freezing point of a solution by 1.86 °C</li>
<li>One millicomole depresses the freezing point by 0.00196 °C</li>
<li>Number of millicomoles per liter in a solution ×
The freezing point depression 0.00196</li>
</ul>
<p>Example:
Calculate the osmolality of normal human plasma if the freezing point = -0.55 °C
Answer:
Plasma osmolality = 0.55/0.00196 = 295 mosmol.</p>
<p>25
The text of abstract physiology: 4th edition</p>
<p>Table 1.3: Effects of I.V. solutions on volumes and osmolarities</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Solution</th><th>ECF</th><th></th><th>Osmosis</th><th>ICF</th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td></td><td>Vol.</td><td>Osmol.</td><td></td><td>Vol.</td><td>Osmol.</td></tr><tr><td>Isotonic</td><td>↑</td><td>The same</td><td>×</td><td>The same</td><td>The same</td></tr><tr><td>Hypotonic</td><td>↑</td><td>↓</td><td>—</td><td>↑</td><td>↓</td></tr><tr><td>Hypertonic</td><td>↑</td><td>↑</td><td>—</td><td>↓</td><td>↑</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul>
<li>From the above table:</li>
<li>I.V. infusion of an isotonic solution increases volume of ECF with no effect on its osmolarity, and no effect on volume or osmolarity of ICF (i.e. no effect on cells).</li>
<li>I.V. infusion of a hypotonic solution increases volumes of ECF and ICF and decreases osmolarities of ECF and ICF.</li>
<li>I.V. infusion of a hypertonic solution increases volume and osmolarity of ECF, and decreases volume of ICF while its osmolarity is increased.</li>
</ul>
<p>Calculation of osmolality:</p>
<p>A. From the Freezing Point Depression</p>
<ul>
<li>One osmole depresses the freezing point of a solution by 1.86 °C</li>
<li>One millicomole depresses the freezing point by 0.00196 °C</li>
<li>Number of millicomoles per liter in a solution ×
The freezing point depression 0.00196</li>
</ul>
<p>Example:
Calculate the osmolality of normal human plasma if the freezing point = -0.55 °C
Answer:
Plasma osmolality = 0.55/0.00196 = 295 mosmol.</p>

<li>I.V. infusion of an isotonic solution increases volume of ECF with no effect on its osmolarity, and no effect on volume or osmolarity of ICF (i.e. no effect on cells).</li>

<ul>
<li>One osmole depresses the freezing point of a solution by 1.86 °C</li>
<li>One millicomole depresses the freezing point by 0.00196 °C</li>
<li>Number of millicomoles per liter in a solution ×
The freezing point depression 0.00196</li>
</ul>
<p>Example:
Calculate the osmolality of normal human plasma if the freezing point = -0.55 °C
Answer:
Plasma osmolality = 0.55/0.00196 = 295 mosmol.</p>
<p>24
The text of abstract physiology: 4th edition</p>
<p>Example:</p>
<p>Calculate the osmolality of a solution containing 110 mmol NaCl, 25 mmol NaHCO₃, 2.5 mmol CaCl₂, 5 mmol urea &amp; 5 mmol glucose</p>
<p>Answer:</p>
<p>Plasma osmolality = (110s2) + (25s2) + (2.5s3) + (5s1) + (5s1) = 287.5 mosmol⁻¹. (Remember that glucose and urea are non-ionizable).</p>
<p>C. Using a formula</p>
<p>Osmolality of the plasma can be calculated using the following formula: Plasma Osmolality = 2[Na] + [K] + [glucose] + [urea] (All concentrations are in mmol/L)</p>
<p>Example:</p>
<p>Calculate the osmolality of the plasma if [Na] = 140 mmol/L, [K] = 4 mmol/L. [Glucose] = 5 mmol/L and [Urea] = 7 mmol/L.</p>
<p>Answer:</p>
<p>Osmolality = 2(140 + 4) + 5 + 7 = 300 mosmol⁻¹. (Isotonic).</p>
<p>2-Diffusion</p>
<ul>
<li>It is expansion or passage of a substance through a cell membrane down its chemical or electrical gradient, due to continuous random movement of its molecules.</li>
<li>Water follows osmolalarly active particles to inside or to outside the cell, this affects volumes of body fluid compartments.</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 1.4. Diffusion</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-738ef2ba.jpeg" alt="img-30.jpeg">
24 The area of residual physiology of plasma</p>

<p>27
The term of method (phycology) of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mi>a</mi></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6644em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6644em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">a</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> millions</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="3-gibbs-duncan-equilibrium">3- Gibbs Duncan equilibrium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-gibbs-duncan-equilibrium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The presence of non-diffusible anions (protein and organic phosphate) within the cell affects distribution of diffusible ions (both anions and cations); it allows entry of diffusible cations (e.g. Na⁺) into the cell and prevents entry of diffusible anions (e.g. Cl⁻).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-9b0bdbf5.jpeg" alt="img-33.jpeg">
Fig 1.8: Gibbs Duncan equilibrium</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The concept was shown theoretically by Gibbs and confirmed experimentally by Dorman (that is why it is known as Gibbs Dorman equilibrium).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>At equilibrium:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>1- Total cations = total anions (on either side of the membrane)
2- The product of diffusible ions on one side equals the product of diffusible ions on the other side of the membrane (This holds for cations and anions of the same valence).</p>
<ul>
<li>Take this example of two solutions "a" and "b", in which Na⁺ and Cl⁻ are diffusible cations and anions respectively. X indicates non diffusible anions.</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>Solution (a)</th><th>Solution (b)</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Na⁺</td><td>Na⁺</td></tr><tr><td>Cl⁻</td><td>Cl⁻</td></tr><tr><td>K⁻</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>28
The term of method (phycology) of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mi>a</mi></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6644em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6644em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">a</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> millions</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="3-gibbs-duncan-equilibrium">3- Gibbs Duncan equilibrium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-gibbs-duncan-equilibrium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="3-gibbs-duncan-equilibrium">3- Gibbs Duncan equilibrium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-gibbs-duncan-equilibrium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<p>23
The term of abstract physiology: 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="from-the-molarity">From the Molarity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#from-the-molarity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Number of cemoies = Number of moles x number of particles (liberated by a single molecule)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="example">Example:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#example" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Calculate the osmolarity of 0.9% NaCl solution and mention the effect of this solution on volume and osmolarity of ICF after its infusion in the plasma? (Molecular weight of NaCl = 58.5).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="answer">Answer:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>0.9% NaCl = 0.9 g/dL, (x 10) = 9 g/L</p>
<p>Molarity = [lomo. g/L] / MWt of NaCl = 9 / 58.5 mol/L</p>
<p>= 0.154 mol/L, (x 1000) = 154 mmol/L</p>
<p>Osmolarity = 154 x 2 = 308 mosm/L</p>
<p>(Isotonic, has no effect on ICF)</p>
<p>Remember that: This solution is regarded as isotonic solution although its osmolarity is higher than plasma Osmolarity (&gt; 300 mosm/L). This is because the dissociation of NaCl in plasma is not as complete as in true ideal solutions (dissociation is about 93%). Therefore the osmolarity of 0.9% NaCl solution in plasma is actually less than 308 mosm/L, that's why it is isotonic.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="example">Example:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#example" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Calculate the osmolarity of 5% glucose solution. If one liter of this solution is infused intravenously, mention the immediate and the later effects on the cells? (MWt glucose = 180).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="answer">Answer:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>5% glucose = 5g/dL = 50 g/L</p>
<p>Molarity = [Como. g/L]MWt = 50/180 = 0.278 mol/L; (x 1000) = 278 mmol/L</p>
<p>Osmolarity = 278 x 1 = 278 mosm/L (Isotonic)</p>
<p>Immediate effect on cells: no effect because it is isotonic</p>
<p>Later effect on cells: After uptake of glucose by cells the solution becomes hypotonic; water enters cells, it increases volume &amp; decreases osmolarity of ICF.</p>
<p>24
The term of abstract physiology: 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="from-the-molarity">From the Molarity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#from-the-molarity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Number of cemoies = Number of moles x number of particles (liberated by a single molecule)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="example">Example:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#example" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Calculate the osmolarity of 0.9% NaCl solution and mention the effect of this solution on volume and osmolarity of ICF after its infusion in the plasma? (Molecular weight of NaCl = 58.5).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="answer">Answer:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>0.9% NaCl = 0.9 g/dL, (x 10) = 9 g/L</p>
<p>Molarity = [lomo. g/L] / MWt of NaCl = 9 / 58.5 mol/L</p>
<p>= 0.154 mol/L, (x 1000) = 154 mmol/L</p>
<p>Osmolarity = 154 x 2 = 308 mosm/L</p>
<p>(Isotonic, has no effect on ICF)</p>
<p>Remember that: This solution is regarded as isotonic solution although its osmolarity is higher than plasma Osmolarity (&gt; 300 mosm/L). This is because the dissociation of NaCl in plasma is not as complete as in true ideal solutions (dissociation is about 93%). Therefore the osmolarity of 0.9% NaCl solution in plasma is actually less than 308 mosm/L, that's why it is isotonic.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="example">Example:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#example" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Calculate the osmolarity of 5% glucose solution. If one liter of this solution is infused intravenously, mention the immediate and the later effects on the cells? (MWt glucose = 180).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="answer">Answer:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>5% glucose = 5g/dL = 50 g/L</p>
<p>Molarity = [Como. g/L]MWt = 50/180 = 0.278 mol/L; (x 1000) = 278 mmol/L</p>
<p>Osmolarity = 278 x 1 = 278 mosm/L (Isotonic)</p>
<p>Immediate effect on cells: no effect because it is isotonic</p>
<p>Later effect on cells: After uptake of glucose by cells the solution becomes hypotonic; water enters cells, it increases volume &amp; decreases osmolarity of ICF.</p>
<p>25
The term of abstract physiology: 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="from-the-molarity">From the Molarity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#from-the-molarity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Number of cemoies = Number of moles x number of particles (liberated by a single molecule)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="example">Example:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#example" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Calculate the osmolarity of 0.9% NaCl solution and mention the effect of this solution on volume and osmolarity of ICF after its infusion in the plasma? (Molecular weight of NaCl = 58.5).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="answer">Answer:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>0.9% NaCl = 0.9 g/dL, (x 10) = 9 g/L</p>
<p>Molarity = [lomo. g/L] / MWt of NaCl = 9 / 58.5 mol/L</p>
<p>= 0.154 mol/L, (x 1000) = 154 mmol/L</p>
<p>Osmolarity = 154 x 2 = 308 mosm/L</p>
<p>(Isotonic, has no effect on ICF)</p>
<p>Remember that: This solution is regarded as isotonic solution although its osmolarity is higher than plasma Osmolarity (&gt; 300 mosm/L). This is because the dissociation of NaCl in plasma is not as complete as in true ideal solutions (dissociation is about 93%). Therefore the osmolarity of 0.9% NaCl solution in plasma is actually less than 308 mosm/L, that's why it is isotonic.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="example">Example:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#example" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Calculate the osmolarity of 5% glucose solution. If one liter of this solution is infused intravenously, mention the immediate and the later effects on the cells? (MWt glucose = 180).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="answer">Answer:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>5% glucose = 5g/dL = 50 g/L</p>
<p>Molarity = [Como. g/L]MWt = 50/180 = 0.278 mol/L; (x 1000) = 278 mmol/L</p>
<p>Osmolarity = 278 x 1 = 278 mosm/L (Isotonic)</p>
<p>Immediate effect on cells: no effect because it is isotonic</p>
<p>Later effect on cells: After uptake of glucose by cells the solution becomes hypotonic; water enters cells, it increases volume &amp; decreases osmolarity of ICF.</p>
<p>The term of abstract physiology: 4th edition</p>
<p>24
The text of method [Kroninger, 1996]</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-equilibrium">A) equilibrium:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-equilibrium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">[\mathrm{Na}^{+}]_{n} / [\mathrm{Na}^{+}]_{n} + [\mathrm{Cl}^{+}]_{n} / [\mathrm{Cl}^{+}]_{n}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0946em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Na</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">n</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Na</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose"><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">n</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1057em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Cl</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8557em;"><span style="top: -3.1473em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose"><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">n</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
</ul>
<p>(There is greater number of ions on the side of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>X</mi><mo mathvariant="normal" lspace="0em" rspace="0em">′</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X^{\prime}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">′</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  than on the other side).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="remember-that">Remember that:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remember-that" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The greater number of particles in compartment 'V' exerts an osmotic effect resulting in swelling of this compartment.</li>
<li>A similar effect occurs in body fluids, i.e. cells tend to undergo swelling, but this is prevented by the Na+/K+ pump.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="effects-of-german-equilibrium-in-the-body">Effects of German equilibrium in the body:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effects-of-german-equilibrium-in-the-body" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-swelling-of-cells">1- Swelling of cells<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-swelling-of-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The EC contains higher concentration of non diffusible anions than the ECF and therefore more particles. This may result in swelling of the cells and eventually their nature. However, swelling of cells is prevented by the action of the Na <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> /K <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">−</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{-}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> pump and other ion channels. The Na <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> /K <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">−</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{-}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> pump transports 3 sodium ions in outside of the cell and 2 potassium ions in inside; this decreases the total number of ions inside the cell and prevents its swelling (see below).</p>
<p>25
The text of method [Kroninger, 1996]</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-equilibrium">B) equilibrium:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-equilibrium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>

<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">[\mathrm{Na}^{+}]_{n} + [\mathrm{Cl}^{+}]_{n}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0946em; </li>
<li>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">[\mathrm{Na}^{+}]_{n} + [\mathrm{Cl}^{+}]_{n} + [\mathrm{Na}^{+}]_{n} + [\mathrm{Cl}^{+}]_{n}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0946em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Cl</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8557em;"><span style="top: -3.1473em; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">[\mathrm{Na}^{+}]_{n} / [\mathrm{Na}^{+}]_{n} + [\mathrm{Cl}^{+}]_{n} / [\mathrm{Cl}^{+}]_{n}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0946em; <p>(Cations on the side of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>X</mi><mo mathvariant="normal" lspace="0em" rspace="0em">′</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X^{\prime}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">′</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  are greater than anions on the same side)</p>

<p>(Diffusible anions on the side of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>X</mi><mo mathvariant="normal" lspace="0em" rspace="0em">′</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X^{\prime}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">′</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  are less than on the other side)</p>

margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">n</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
</ul>
<p>(Cations on the side of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>X</mi><mo mathvariant="normal" lspace="0em" rspace="0em">′</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X^{\prime}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">′</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  are greater than cations on the other side)</p>
<ul>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">[\mathrm{Na}^{+}]_{n} + [\mathrm{Cl}^{+}]_{n} + [\mathrm{K}^{+}]_{n} / [\mathrm{Na}^{+}]_{n} + [\mathrm{Cl}^{+}]_{n}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0946em; </ul>
<p>(There is greater number of ions on the side of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>X</mi><mo mathvariant="normal" lspace="0em" rspace="0em">′</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X^{\prime}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">′</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  than on the other side).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="remember-that">Remember that:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remember-that" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The greater number of particles in compartment 'V' exerts an osmotic effect resulting in swelling of this compartment.</li>
<li>A similar effect occurs in body fluids, i.e. cells tend to undergo swelling, but this is prevented by the Na+/K+ pump.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="effects-of-german-equilibrium-in-the-body">Effects of German equilibrium in the body:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effects-of-german-equilibrium-in-the-body" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-swelling-of-cells">1- Swelling of cells<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-swelling-of-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The EC contains higher concentration of non diffusible anions than the ECF and therefore more particles. This may result in swelling of the cells and eventually their nature. However, swelling of cells is prevented by the action of the Na <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> /K <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">−</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{-}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> pump and other ion channels. The Na <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> /K <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">−</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{-}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> pump transports 3 sodium ions in outside of the cell and 2 potassium ions in inside; this decreases the total number of ions inside the cell and prevents its swelling (see below).</p>
<p>26
The text of method [Kroninger, 1996]</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-equilibrium">A) equilibrium:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-equilibrium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">[\mathrm{Na}^{+}]_{n} + [\mathrm{Cl}^{+}]_{n} + [\mathrm{K}^{+}]_{n}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0946em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Cl</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8557em;"><span style="top: -3.1473em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose"><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">n</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0213em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose"><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">n</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  (i.e. cations in a = anions in a)
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">[\mathrm{Na}^{+}]_{n} + [\mathrm{Cl}^{+}]_{n}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0946em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Na</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; </li>
<li>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">[\mathrm{Na}^{+}]_{n} + [\mathrm{Cl}^{+}]_{n} + [\mathrm{Na}^{+}]_{n} + [\mathrm{Cl}^{+}]_{n}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0946em;
