<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="from-the-above-relationships">From the above relationships:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#from-the-above-relationships" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">[\mathrm{Na}^{+}]_{n} + [\mathrm{Cl}^{+}]_{n}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0946em; </ul>
<p>(Cations on the side of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>X</mi><mo mathvariant="normal" lspace="0em" rspace="0em">′</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X^{\prime}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">′</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  are greater than anions on the same side)</p>
<ul>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">[\mathrm{Cl}^{+}]_{n} + [\mathrm{Cl}^{+}]_{n}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1057em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Cl</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8557em;"><span style="top: -3.1473em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose"><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">n</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1057em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Cl</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8557em;"><span style="top: -3.1473em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose"><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">n</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
</ul>
<p>(Diffusible anions on the side of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>X</mi><mo mathvariant="normal" lspace="0em" rspace="0em">′</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X^{\prime}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">′</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  are less than on the other side)</p>
<ul>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">[\mathrm{Na}^{+}]_{n} + [\mathrm{Na}^{+}]_{n}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0946em; </ul>
<p>(Cations on the side of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>X</mi><mo mathvariant="normal" lspace="0em" rspace="0em">′</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X^{\prime}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">′</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  are greater than cations on the other side)</p>
<ul>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">[\mathrm{Na}^{+}]_{n} + [\mathrm{Cl}^{+}]_{n} + [\mathrm{K}^{+}]_{n} / [\mathrm{Na}^{+}]_{n} + [\mathrm{Cl}^{+}]_{n}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0946em; </ul>
<p>(There is greater number of ions on the side of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>X</mi><mo mathvariant="normal" lspace="0em" rspace="0em">′</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X^{\prime}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">′</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  than on the other side).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="remember-that">Remember that:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remember-that" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The greater number of particles in compartment 'V' exerts an osmotic effect resulting in swelling of this compartment.</li>
<li>A similar effect occurs in body fluids, i.e. cells tend to undergo swelling, but this is prevented by the Na+/K+ pump.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="effects-of-german-equilibrium-in-the-body">Effects of German equilibrium in the body:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effects-of-german-equilibrium-in-the-body" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-swelling-of-cells">1- Swelling of cells<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-swelling-of-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The EC contains higher concentration of non diffusible anions than the ECF and therefore more particles. This may result in swelling of the cells and eventually their nature. However, swelling of cells is prevented by the action of the Na <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> /K <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">−</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{-}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> pump and other ion channels. The Na <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> /K <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">−</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{-}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> pump transports 3 sodium ions in outside of the cell and 2 potassium ions in inside; this decreases the total number of ions inside the cell and prevents its swelling (see below).</p>
<p>26
The text of method [Kroninger, 1996]</p>
<p>23
The uses of medical physiology 14th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-electrical-difference-across-the-cell-membrane">2. Electrical difference across the cell membrane<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-electrical-difference-across-the-cell-membrane" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The asymmetrical distribution of diffudible ions across the cell membrane generates an electrical difference that can be determined for each ion by the Nernst equation. In addition the asymmetrical distribution of non-diffudible anions participates in genesis of the resting membrane potential (see chapter two).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-slight-difference-in-concentration-of-ions-between-plasma-and-igf-and-also-between-plasma-and-the-glomerular-filtration">3. Slight difference in concentration of ions between plasma and IGF and also between plasma and the glomerular filtration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-slight-difference-in-concentration-of-ions-between-plasma-and-igf-and-also-between-plasma-and-the-glomerular-filtration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Since plasma contains higher concentration of protein than the interstitial fluid (ISF), it contains slightly higher concentration of cations (like sodium and potassium) and lower concentration of anions (like chloride and bicarbonate). Similarly in the kidneys, proteins are not filtered out of the glomerular capillaries. The filtrate is free of plasma protein. Therefore the plasma contains slightly higher concentration of cations (like sodium and potassium) and lower concentration of anions (like chloride and bicarbonate) than in the filtrate.</p>
<p>Table 1.2: Differences between plasma and IGF in an adult male</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Difference</th><th></th><th>Plasma</th><th>Interstitial fluid</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Volume</td><td></td><td>5% of body weight</td><td>10% of weight</td></tr><tr><td>Concentration of Cations:</td><td>Sodium (Na⁺)</td><td>145 mmol/L</td><td>140 mmol/L</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Potassium (K⁺)</td><td>4.1 mmol/L</td><td>4 mmol/L</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Calcium (Ca²⁺)</td><td>2.5 mmol/L</td><td>2.1 mmol/L</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Magnesium (Mg²⁺)</td><td>1 mmol/L</td><td>1 mmol/L</td></tr><tr><td>Total cations</td><td></td><td>152.6 mmol/L</td><td>147.1 mmol/L</td></tr><tr><td>Conc. Of Anions:</td><td>Chloride (Cl⁻)</td><td>105 mmol/L</td><td>110 mmol/L</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻)</td><td>25 mmol/L</td><td>30 mmol/L</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Phosphate (PO₄³⁻)</td><td>1 mmol/L</td><td>1 mmol/L</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Organic acids</td><td>5 mmol/L</td><td>5 mmol/L</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Protein</td><td>10.5 mmol/L</td><td>1.1 mmol/L</td></tr><tr><td>Total anions</td><td></td><td>152.6 mmol/L</td><td>147.1 mmol/L</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>24
The uses of medical physiology 14th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="3-electrical-difference-across-the-cell-membrane">3. Electrical difference across the cell membrane<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-electrical-difference-across-the-cell-membrane" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The asymmetrical distribution of diffudible ions across the cell membrane generates an electrical difference that can be determined for each ion by the Nernst equation. In addition the asymmetrical distribution of non-diffudible anions participates in genesis of the resting membrane potential (see chapter two).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-slight-difference-in-concentration-of-ions-between-plasma-and-igf-and-also-between-plasma-and-the-glomerular-filtration">3. Slight difference in concentration of ions between plasma and IGF and also between plasma and the glomerular filtration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-slight-difference-in-concentration-of-ions-between-plasma-and-igf-and-also-between-plasma-and-the-glomerular-filtration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Since plasma contains higher concentration of protein than the interstitial fluid (ISF), it contains slightly higher concentration of cations (like sodium and potassium) and lower concentration of anions (like chloride and bicarbonate). Similarly in the kidneys, proteins are not filtered out of the glomerular capillaries. The filtrate is free of plasma protein. Therefore the plasma contains slightly higher concentration of cations (like sodium and potassium) and lower concentration of anions (like chloride and bicarbonate) than in the filtrate.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="5-electrical-difference-across-the-cell-membrane">5. Electrical difference across the cell membrane<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-electrical-difference-across-the-cell-membrane" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The asymmetrical distribution of diffudible ions across the cell membrane generates an electrical difference that can be determined for each ion by the Nernst equation. In addition the asymmetrical distribution of non-diffudible anions participates in genesis of the resting membrane potential (see chapter two).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-slight-difference-in-concentration-of-ions-between-plasma-and-igf-and-also-between-plasma-and-the-glomerular-filtration">5. Slight difference in concentration of ions between plasma and IGF and also between plasma and the glomerular filtration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-slight-difference-in-concentration-of-ions-between-plasma-and-igf-and-also-between-plasma-and-the-glomerular-filtration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Since plasma contains higher concentration of protein than the interstitial fluid (ISF), it contains slightly higher concentration of cations (like sodium and potassium) and lower concentration of anions (like chloride and bicarbonate). Similarly in the kidneys, proteins are not filtered out of the glomerular capillaries. The filtrate is free of plasma protein. Therefore the plasma contains slightly higher concentration of cations (like sodium and potassium) and lower concentration of anions (like chloride and bicarbonate) than in the filtrate.</p>

Of Anions:</td><td>Chloride (Cl⁻)</td><td>105 mmol/L</td><td>110 mmol/L</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻)</td><td>25 mmol/L</td><td>30 mmol/L</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Phosphate (PO₄³⁻)</td><td>1 mmol/L</td><td>1 mmol/L</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Organic acids</td><td>5 mmol/L</td><td>5 mmol/L</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Protein</td><td>10.5 mmol/L</td><td>1.1 mmol/L</td></tr><tr><td>Total anions</td><td></td><td>152.6 mmol/L</td><td>147.1 mmol/L</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="4-the-sodium-potassium-pump">4. The Sodium Potassium Pump<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-the-sodium-potassium-pump" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Found in all cells of the body.</li>
<li>Transports sodium and potassium actively against their chemical gradients (1 Na⁺ core to outside and 2 K⁺ core to inside the cell).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-1-6-the-sodium-potassium-pump">Fig 1.6. The sodium potassium pump<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-1-6-the-sodium-potassium-pump" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-fb50cdb7.jpeg" alt="img-36.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>It accounts for 20-45% of the total metabolic energy expended by the cell.</li>
<li>Consists of alpha and beta subunits extending through the cell membrane. The beta subunit is a glycoprotein, whereas the alpha subunit is a protein with extracellular binding sites for K⁺ and intracellular binding sites for Na⁺ and ATP.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-1-7-subunits-of-the-sodium-potassium-pump">Fig 1.7. Subunits of the sodium potassium pump<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-1-7-subunits-of-the-sodium-potassium-pump" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-0d8cecce.jpeg" alt="img-37.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>It is the alpha subunit that transports Na⁺ and K⁺, however, separation of the two subunits inactivates the pump.</li>
<li>The Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase enzyme releases energy from ATP that's used in transport of 3 sodium ions to outside the cell and 2 potassium ions to inside. This results in accumulation of negative charges inside the cell (i.e. it is an electrogenic pump).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-the-sodium-potassium-pump">4. The Sodium Potassium Pump<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-the-sodium-potassium-pump" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Found in all cells of the body.</li>
<li>Transports sodium and potassium actively against their chemical gradients (1 Na⁺ core to outside and 2 K⁺ core to inside the cell).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-1-8-the-sodium-potassium-pump">Fig 1.8. The sodium potassium pump<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-1-8-the-sodium-potassium-pump" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-28d4b296.jpeg" alt="img-38.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>It accounts for 20-45% of the total metabolic energy expended by the cell.</li>
<li>Consists of alpha and beta subunits extending through the cell membrane. The beta subunit is a glycoprotein, whereas the alpha subunit is a protein with extracellular binding sites for K⁺ and intracellular binding sites for Na⁺ and ATP.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-1-9-subunits-of-the-sodium-potassium-pump">Fig 1.9. Subunits of the sodium potassium pump<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-1-9-subunits-of-the-sodium-potassium-pump" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-6842d5e8.jpeg" alt="img-39.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>It is the alpha subunit that transports Na⁺ and K⁺, however, separation of the two subunits inactivates the pump.</li>
<li>The Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase enzyme releases energy from ATP that's used in transport of 3 sodium ions to outside the cell and 2 potassium ions to inside. This results in accumulation of negative charges inside the cell (i.e. it is an electrogenic pump).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-the-sodium-potassium-pump">4. The Sodium-Potassium Pump<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-the-sodium-potassium-pump" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Found in all cells of the body.</li>
<li>Transports sodium and potassium actively against their chemical gradients (1 Na⁺ core to outside and 2 K⁺ core to inside the cell).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-1-6-the-sodium-potassium-pump">Fig 1.6. The sodium potassium pump<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-1-6-the-sodium-potassium-pump" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-8779bfa2.jpeg" alt="img-40.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>It accounts for 20-45% of the total metabolic energy expended by the cell.</li>
<li>Consists of alpha and beta subunits extending through the cell membrane. The beta subunit is a glycoprotein, whereas the alpha subunit is a protein with extracellular binding sites for K⁺ and intracellular binding sites for Na⁺ and ATP.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-1-7-subunits-of-the-sodium-potassium-pump">Fig 1.7. Subunits of the sodium potassium pump<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-1-7-subunits-of-the-sodium-potassium-pump" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-7ada6b9c.jpeg" alt="img-41.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>It is the alpha subunit that transports Na⁺ and K⁺, however, separation of the two subunits inactivates the pump.</li>
<li>The Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase enzyme releases energy from ATP that's used in transport of 3 sodium ions to outside the cell and 2 potassium ions to inside. This results in accumulation of negative charges inside the cell (i.e. it is an electrogenic pump).</li>
</ul>
