The text of the document is illegible</p>
<p>21
22</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-the-the-a-pump">Functions of the the "A" pump<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-the-the-a-pump" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Participates in genesis of the resting membrane potential (i.e. generates negative charges towards the inner side of the cell membrane.</li>
<li>Prevents swelling and rupture of cells by removing excess sodium ions to outside (see Donnan effect).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="regulation-of-the-pump">Regulation of the pump<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#regulation-of-the-pump" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The pump is activated by accumulation of Na⁺ ions intracellularly.</li>
<li>Activity is increased by: Insulin, Aldosterone and thyroid hormones</li>
<li>Activity is inhibited by: Dopamine and digoxin</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-starting-s-forces">6. Starting's forces<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-starting-s-forces" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>As mentioned above, movement of water across cell membranes depends on controls. However, movement of water across the walls of capillaries depends, in addition to that, on 4 primary forces (known as Starting's forces) that control fluid exchange between plasma and interstitium.</p>
<ul>
<li>Although Starting's forces act in all blood vessels, they cause fluid exchange only in capillaries.</li>
<li>This is because the walls of capillaries, unlike arteries and veins, are characterized by pores between the endothelial cells that allow movement of water (for this reason capillaries are called "the exchange vessels").</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="starting-forces-include">Starting forces include:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#starting-forces-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="1-capillary-hydrostatic-pressure-cph">1. Capillary hydrostatic pressure (CPH)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-capillary-hydrostatic-pressure-cph" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ul>
<li>It is the pressure of plasma acting on the lateral wall of the blood vessel</li>
<li>For fixation (from plasma to ISF)
= 55 mmHg at the anterior end of capillaries
= 15 mmHg at the venular end of capillaries</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="2-capillary-smooth-pressure-cph">2. Capillary smooth pressure (CPH)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-capillary-smooth-pressure-cph" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ul>
<li>The osmotic pressure of plasma proteins (also known as colloid osmotic pressure or smooth pressure)</li>
<li>It is exerted mainly by albumin</li>
</ul>
<p>23
24</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-the-the-a-pump">Functions of the the "A" pump<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-the-the-a-pump" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Participates in genesis of the resting membrane potential (i.e. generates negative charges towards the inner side of the cell membrane.</p>
<ul>
<li>Prevents swelling and rupture of cells by removing excess sodium ions to outside (see Donnan effect).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="regulation-of-the-pump">Regulation of the pump<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#regulation-of-the-pump" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The pump is activated by accumulation of Na⁺ ions intracellularly.</li>
<li>Activity is increased by: Insulin, Aldosterone and thyroid hormones</li>
<li>Activity is inhibited by: Dopamine and digoxin</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-starting-s-forces">5. Starting's forces<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-starting-s-forces" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>As mentioned above, movement of water across cell membranes depends on osmosis. However, movement of water across the walls of capillaries depends, in addition to that, on 4 primary forces (known as Starting's forces) that control fluid exchange between plasma and interstitium.</p>
<ul>
<li>Although Starting's forces act in all blood vessels, they cause fluid exchange only in capillaries.</li>
<li>This is because the walls of capillaries, unlike arteries and veins, are characterized by pores between the endothelial cells that allow movement of water (for this reason capillaries are called "the exchange vessels").</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="starting-forces-include">Starting forces include:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#starting-forces-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="1-capillary-hydrostatic-pressure-hpp">1. Capillary hydrostatic pressure (HPP)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-capillary-hydrostatic-pressure-hpp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ul>
<li>It is the pressure of plasma acting on the lateral wall of the blood vessel</li>
<li>For fixation (from plasma to ISF)
= 55 mmHg at the anterior end of capillaries
= 15 mmHg at the venular end of capillaries</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="2-capillary-smooth-pressure-cph">2. Capillary smooth pressure (CPH)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-capillary-smooth-pressure-cph" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ul>
<li>The osmotic pressure of plasma proteins (also known as colloid osmotic pressure or smooth pressure)</li>
<li>It is exerted mainly by albumin</li>
</ul>
<p>21
25</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-the-the-a-pump">Functions of the the "A" pump<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-the-the-a-pump" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Participates in genesis of the resting membrane potential (i.e. generates negative charges towards the inner side of the cell membrane.</li>
<li>Prevents swelling and rupture of cells by removing excess sodium ions to outside (see Donnan effect).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="regulation-of-the-pump">Regulation of the pump<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#regulation-of-the-pump" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The pump is activated by accumulation of Na⁺ ions intracellularly.</li>
<li>Activity is increased by: Insulin, Aldosterone and thyroid hormones</li>
<li>Activity is inhibited by: Dopamine and digoxin</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-starting-s-forces">5. Starting's forces<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-starting-s-forces" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>As mentioned above, movement of water across cell membranes depends on controls. However, movement of water across the walls of capillaries depends, in addition to that, on 4 primary forces (known as Starting's forces) that control fluid exchange between plasma and interstitium.</p>
<ul>
<li>Although Starting's forces act in all blood vessels, they cause fluid exchange only in capillaries.</li>
<li>This is because the walls of capillaries, unlike arteries and veins, are characterized by pores between the endothelial cells that allow movement of water (for this reason capillaries are called "the exchange vessels").</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="starting-forces-include">Starting forces include:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#starting-forces-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="1-capillary-hydrostatic-pressure-hpp">1. Capillary hydrostatic pressure (HPP)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-capillary-hydrostatic-pressure-hpp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ul>
<li>It is the pressure of plasma acting on the lateral wall of the blood vessel</li>
<li>For filtration (from plasma to ISF)
= 20 mmHg at the anterior end of capillaries
= 15 mmHg at the venular end of capillaries</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="2-capillary-smooth-pressure-cph">2. Capillary smooth pressure (CPH)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-capillary-smooth-pressure-cph" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ul>
<li>The osmotic pressure of plasma proteins (also known as colloid osmotic pressure or smooth pressure)</li>
<li>It is exerted mainly by albumin</li>
</ul>
<p>The units of Medline (MicroImage® 4.7 column)</p>
<ul>
<li>For absorption (from ISF to plasma)</li>
<li>25 mmHg throughout the capillaries (proteins are not filtered and therefore their oncotic pressure is not changed)</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>Interstitial fluid hydrostatic pressure (VFp):</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Acts in the opposite side to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>4</mn></msup><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10^4 \mathrm{~L} / \mathrm{s}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0641em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">4</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">L</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathrm">s</span></span></span></span></span> against filtration</li>
</ul>
<ol start="4">
<li>Interstitial fluid oncotic pressure (CIPo):</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Acts in the opposite side to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>4</mn></msup><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10^4 \mathrm{~L} / \mathrm{s}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0641em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">4</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">L</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathrm">s</span></span></span></span></span> against absorption</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="notes-about-osmotic-pressure-of-proteins-oncotic-pressure">Notes about osmotic pressure of proteins (Oncotic pressure)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#notes-about-osmotic-pressure-of-proteins-oncotic-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Oncotic pressure is mainly exerted by albumin because it is the smallest plasma protein and therefore it has the highest number of particles than other types of plasma proteins.</li>
<li>Osmolarity depends on "number" not "size" of particles.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="calculation-of-filtration-pressure">Calculation of filtration pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calculation-of-filtration-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Both hydrostatic pressure of ISF and oncotic pressure of ISF are of the magnitude, they act against each other and therefore they cannot each other. That's why they are not considered in calculation of the filtration pressure.</p>
<p>The filtration pressure is calculated by subtracting the capillary oncotic pressure from the capillary hydrostatic pressure as follows:</p>
<ul>
<li>At the arteriolar endn (35.35) = +10 mmHg (i.e. not filtration)</li>
<li>At the ve-LOW endn (15.05) = -10 mmHg (i.e. not absorption)</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-0d23f1be.jpeg" alt="img-42.jpeg">
Fig 1.8. Signlina's Survey</p>
<ul>
<li>For absorption (from ISF to plasma)</li>
<li>25 mmHg throughout the capillaries (proteins are not filtered and therefore their oncotic pressure is not changed)</li>
</ul>
<ol start="5">
<li>Interstitial fluid hydrostatic pressure (VFp):</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Acts in the opposite side to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>4</mn></msup><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10^4 \mathrm{~L} / \mathrm{s}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0641em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">4</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">L</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathrm">s</span></span></span></span></span> against filtration</li>
</ul>
<ol start="4">
<li>Interstitial fluid oncotic pressure (CIPo):</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Acts in the opposite side to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>4</mn></msup><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10^4 \mathrm{~L} / \mathrm{s}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0641em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">4</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">L</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathrm">s</span></span></span></span></span> against absorption</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="notes-about-osmotic-pressure-of-proteins-oncotic-pressure">Notes about osmotic pressure of proteins (Oncotic pressure)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#notes-about-osmotic-pressure-of-proteins-oncotic-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Oncotic pressure is mainly exerted by albumin because it is the smallest plasma protein and therefore it has the highest number of particles than other types of plasma proteins.</li>
<li>Osmolarity depends on "number" not "size" of particles.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="calculation-of-filtration-pressure">Calculation of filtration pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calculation-of-filtration-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Both hydrostatic pressure of ISF and oncotic pressure of ISF are of the magnitude, they act against each other and therefore they cannot each other. That's why they are not considered in calculation of the filtration pressure.</p>
<p>The filtration pressure is calculated by subtracting the capillary oncotic pressure from the capillary hydrostatic pressure as follows:</p>
<ul>
<li>At the arteriolar endn (35.35) = +10 mmHg (i.e. not filtration)</li>
<li>At the ve-LOW endn (15.35) = -10 mmHg (i.e. not absorption)</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-dca1cf45.jpeg" alt="img-43.jpeg">
Fig 1.9. Signlina's Survey</p>
<ul>
<li>For absorption (from ISF to plasma)</li>
<li>25 mmHg throughout the capillaries (proteins are not filtered and therefore their oncotic pressure is not changed)</li>
</ul>
<ol start="5">
<li>Interstitial fluid hydrostatic pressure (VFp):</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Acts in the opposite side to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>4</mn></msup><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10^4 \mathrm{~L} / \mathrm{s}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0641em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">4</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">L</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathrm">s</span></span></span></span></span> against filtration</li>
</ul>
<ol start="4">
<li>Interstitial fluid oncotic pressure (CIPo):</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Acts in the opposite side to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>4</mn></msup><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10^4 \mathrm{~L} / \mathrm{s}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0641em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">4</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">L</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathrm">s</span></span></span></span></span> against absorption</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="notes-about-osmotic-pressure-of-proteins-oncotic-pressure">Notes about osmotic pressure of proteins (Oncotic pressure)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#notes-about-osmotic-pressure-of-proteins-oncotic-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Oncotic pressure is mainly exerted by albumin because it is the smallest plasma protein and therefore it has the highest number of particles than other types of plasma proteins.</li>
<li>Osmolarity depends on "number" not "size" of particles.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="calculation-of-filtration-pressure">Calculation of filtration pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calculation-of-filtration-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Both hydrostatic pressure of ISF and oncotic pressure of ISF are of the magnitude, they act against each other and therefore they cannot each other. That's why they are not considered in calculation of the filtration pressure.</p>
<p>The filtration pressure is calculated by subtracting the capillary oncotic pressure from the capillary hydrostatic pressure as follows:</p>
<ul>
<li>At the arteriolar endn (35.05) = +10 mmHg (i.e. not filtration)</li>
<li>At the ve-LOW endn (15.25) = -10 mmHg (i.e. not absorption)</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-512fb9a5.jpeg" alt="img-44.jpeg">
Fig 1.8. Signlina's Survey</p>
<p>13
The view of medical physiology of asthma</p>
<ul>
<li>A filtration pressure of + 10 mmHg indicates that filtering's forces cause filtration of plasma at the arteriolar end of capillaries to the interstitium. The filtered plasma carries nutrients to the surrounding cells &amp; then the fluid is absorbed back at the venular end with the waste products.</li>
<li>About 50% of the filtered fluid at the arteriolar end of capillaries is absorbed back to the capillaries at their venular end; the remaining 10% of the filtered fluid is also absorbed but by the lymphatics.</li>
<li>The lymphatic vessels also absorb small amount of protein that may escape out of the plasma to the interstitium.</li>
<li>The lymphatics return this protein together with the 10% of the filtered fluid back to the circulation at the neck where the main lymphatic fluid drains into the jugular vein. This keeps balance between filtration and absorption of fluid at the capillaries.</li>
<li>Disturbance of this balance between filtration and absorption may result in accumulation of fluid in the interstitium causing edema.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="edema">Edema<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#edema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Edema is defined as abnormal accumulation of fluid in the interstitial space. It is caused by many diseases through one or more of the following mechanisms:</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="3-decreased-capillary-hydrostatic-pressure-dph">3. Decreased capillary hydrostatic pressure (DPH)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-decreased-capillary-hydrostatic-pressure-dph" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Some diseases may cause accumulation of blood in veins; thus increasing the DPH at the venular end of capillaries. When the DPH becomes higher than the DPH, the return of the filtered fluid to the capillaries is prevented causing edema. Examples include:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Heart failure: Left sided heart failure results in accumulation of blood in the lung veins causing pulmonary edema whereas right sided heart failure causes accumulation of blood in systemic veins causing generalized edema.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Various obstruction: Results in accumulation of blood proximal to the site of obstruction causing localized edema.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A filtration pressure of + 10 mmHg indicates that filtering's forces cause filtration of plasma at the arteriolar end of capillaries to the interstitium. The filtered plasma carries nutrients to the surrounding cells &amp; then the fluid is absorbed back at the venular end with the waste products.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>About 90% of the filtered fluid at the arteriolar end of capillaries is absorbed back to the capillaries at their venular end; the remaining 10% of the filtered fluid is also absorbed but by the lymphatics.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The lymphatic vessels also absorb small amount of protein that may escape out of the plasma to the interstitium.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The lymphatics return this protein together with the 10% of the filtered fluid back to the circulation at the neck where the main lymphatic fluid drains into the jugular vein. This keeps balance between filtration and absorption of fluid at the capillaries.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Disturbance of this balance between filtration and absorption may result in accumulation of fluid in the interstitium causing edema.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="edema">Edema<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#edema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Edema is defined as abnormal accumulation of fluid in the interstitial space. It is caused by many diseases through one or more of the following mechanisms:</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="3-decreased-capillary-hydrostatic-pressure-dph">3. Decreased capillary hydrostatic pressure (DPH)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-decreased-capillary-hydrostatic-pressure-dph" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Some diseases may cause accumulation of blood in veins; thus increasing the DPH at the venular end of capillaries. When the DPH becomes higher than the DPH, the return of the filtered fluid to the capillaries is prevented causing edema. Examples include:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Heart failure: Left sided heart failure results in accumulation of blood in the lung veins causing pulmonary edema whereas right sided heart failure causes accumulation of blood in systemic veins causing generalized edema.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Various obstruction: Results in accumulation of blood proximal to the site of obstruction causing localized edema.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A filtration pressure of + 10 mmHg indicates that filtering's forces cause duration of plasma at the arteriolar end of capillaries to the interstitium. The filtered plasma carries nutrients to the surrounding cells &amp; then the fluid is absorbed back at the venular end with the waste products.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>About 90% of the filtered fluid at the arteriolar end of capillaries is absorbed back to the capillaries at their venular end; the remaining 10% of the filtered fluid is also absorbed but by the lymphatics.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The lymphatic vessels also absorb small amount of protein that may escape out of the plasma to the interstitium.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The lymphatics return this protein together with the 10% of the filtered fluid back to the circulation at the neck where the main lymphatic fluid drains into the jugular vein. This keeps balance between filtration and absorption of fluid at the capillaries.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Disturbance of this balance between filtration and absorption may result in accumulation of fluid in the interstitium causing edema.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="edema">Edema<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#edema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Edema is defined as abnormal accumulation of fluid in the interstitial space. It is caused by many diseases through one or more of the following mechanisms:</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="3-decreased-capillary-hydrostatic-pressure-dph">3. Decreased capillary hydrostatic pressure (DPH)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-decreased-capillary-hydrostatic-pressure-dph" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Some diseases may cause accumulation of blood in veins; thus increasing the DPH at the venular end of capillaries. When the DPH becomes higher than the DPH, the return of the filtered fluid to the capillaries is prevented causing edema. Examples include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Heart failure: Left sided heart failure results in accumulation of blood in the lung veins causing pulmonary edema whereas right sided heart failure causes accumulation of blood in systemic veins causing generalized edema.</li>
<li>Various obstruction: Results in accumulation of blood proximal to the site of obstruction causing localized edema.</li>
</ul>
<p>14
The view of medical physiology of asthma</p>
<p>12
The text of section 201 is illegible</p>
<p>Remember that</p>
<ul>
<li>Oedema is not caused by hypertension because the hydrostatic pressure of capillaries is not increased at the venular end of capillaries, which is the site of absorption.</li>
<li>Oedema is not caused by arterial obstruction because this decreases blood flow to the capillaries and therefore decreases HF.</li>
</ul>
<p>3-Decreased venular pressure (DP₁)</p>
<ul>
<li>Some diseases may lower the level of proteins in the plasma. This decreases DP₁. The low DP₁ prevents absorption of the filtered fluid back to the intravascular space causing edema. Examples include:</li>
<li>Malnutrition: Decreased protein intake (e.g. Kwashiorkor). It results in generalized edema.</li>
<li>Mastocception: Decreased absorption of protein (e.g. due to chronic pancreatitis). It results in generalized edema.</li>
<li>Liver disease (chronic disease like liver cirrhosis): Causes decreased synthesis of plasma proteins. It results in generalized edema.</li>
<li>Renal disease (nephritis or nephritic syndromes or renal failure): Causes loss of plasma proteins in urine. It results in generalized edema.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>Lymphatic obstruction
Obstruction of lymphatics results in accumulation of the fluid that's supposed to be absorbed by the lymphatics to be removed from the interstitium. Therefore, it accumulates causing edema. The obstruction is caused by:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Fibula (worms that live within the lymphatic vessels): Filariasis results in localized edema (very large swelling proximal to the site of obstruction known as stepharidiasis).</li>
<li>Surgical removal of lymph nodes (which drain a site of cancer): This is done to prevent spread of secondary cells from the cancer. It interrupts the lymph node flow resulting in a localized edema.</li>
</ul>
<p>Remember that</p>
<ul>
<li>Oedema is not caused by hypertension because the hydrostatic pressure of capillaries is not increased at the venular end of capillaries, which is the site of absorption.</li>
<li>Oedema is not caused by arterial obstruction because this decreases blood flow to the capillaries and therefore decreases HF.</li>
</ul>
<p>2-Decreased venular pressure (DP₂)</p>
<ul>
<li>Some diseases may lower the level of proteins in the plasma. This decreases DP₂. The low DP₂ prevents absorption of the filtered fluid back to the intravascular space causing edema. Examples include:</li>
<li>Malnutrition: Decreased protein intake (e.g. Kwashiorkor). It results in generalized edema.</li>
<li>Mastocception: Decreased absorption of protein (e.g. due to chronic pancreatitis). It results in generalized edema.</li>
<li>Liver disease (chronic disease like liver cirrhosis): Causes decreased synthesis of plasma proteins. It results in generalized edema.</li>
<li>Renal disease (nephritis or nephritic syndromes or renal failure): Causes loss of plasma proteins in urine. It results in generalized edema.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Lymphatic obstruction
Obstruction of lymphatics results in accumulation of the fluid that's supposed to be absorbed by the lymphatics to be removed from the interstitium. Therefore, it accumulates causing edema. The obstruction is caused by:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Fibula (worms that live within the lymphatic vessels): Filariasis results in localized edema (very large swelling proximal to the site of obstruction known as stepharidiasis).</li>
<li>Surgical removal of lymph nodes (which drain a site of cancer): This is done to prevent spread of secondary cells from the cancer. It interrupts the lymph node flow resulting in a localized edema.</li>
</ul>
<p>Remember that</p>
<ul>
<li>Oedema is not caused by hypertension because the hydrostatic pressure of capillaries is not increased at the venular end of capillaries, which is the site of absorption.</li>
<li>Oedema is not caused by arterial obstruction because this decreases blood flow to the capillaries and therefore decreases HF.</li>
</ul>
<p>3-Decreased venular pressure (DP₃)</p>
<ul>
<li>Some diseases may lower the level of proteins in the plasma. This decreases DP₃. The low DP₃ prevents absorption of the filtered fluid back to the intravascular space causing edema. Examples include:</li>
<li>Malnutrition: Decreased protein intake (e.g. Kwashiorkor). It results in generalized edema.</li>
<li>Mastocception: Decreased absorption of protein (e.g. due to chronic pancreatitis). It results in generalized edema.</li>
<li>Liver disease (chronic disease like liver cirrhosis): Causes decreased synthesis of plasma proteins. It results in generalized edema.</li>
<li>Renal disease (nephritis or nephritic syndromes or renal failure): Causes loss of plasma proteins in urine. It results in generalized edema.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>Lymphatic obstruction
Obstruction of lymphatics results in accumulation of the fluid that's supposed to be absorbed by the lymphatics to be removed from the interstitium. Therefore, it accumulates causing edema. The obstruction is caused by:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Fibula (worms that live within the lymphatic vessels): Filariasis results in localized edema (very large swelling proximal to the site of obstruction known as stepharidiasis).</li>
<li>Surgical removal of lymph nodes (which drain a site of cancer): This is done to prevent spread of secondary cells from the cancer. It interrupts the lymph node flow resulting in a localized edema.</li>
</ul>
<p>13
The text of section 201 is illegible</p>
<p>22
The case of medical physiology of asthma</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-increased-permeability-of-capillaries">A. Increased permeability of capillaries:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-increased-permeability-of-capillaries" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Some diseases may increase the permeability of capillaries and allow filtration of plasma proteins to the interstitium thus increasing the <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{DP}_{\mathrm{sp}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9694em; vertical-align: -0.2861em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">DP</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">sp</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2861em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> which absorbs fluid to the outside causing edema. The capillary permeability is increased by:</p>
<ul>
<li>Inflammation: The increased permeability is due to mediators of inflammation released by white blood cells and the nearby tissues</li>
<li>Results in localized edema</li>
<li>Burn: The increased permeability is due to the high temperature. It results in localized edema</li>
<li>Allergy: The increased permeability is due to histamine which is released by mast cells and basophils. It results in localized or generalized edema</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-edema">Types of edema:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-edema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Edema can be classified into 2 types (by applying pressure on it in one site using one finger 'the thumb' against bone, for a minute):</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-pitting-edema">1. Pitting edema<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-pitting-edema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The finger leaves a mark (a pit) on the skin (the mark appears because the fluid escapes away from the site of pressure and returns slowly)</li>
<li>Causes of pitting edema include:</li>
<li>All causes of high capillary hydrostatic pressure</li>
<li>All causes of low capillary smooth pressure</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="2-non-pitting-edema">2. Non pitting edema<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-non-pitting-edema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The finger does not leave a mark on the skin because the escaped fluid returns rapidly (this is because it is attracted by proteins that are filtered to the interstitium)</li>
<li>Causes of non pitting edema include:</li>
<li>All causes of increased permeability</li>
<li>All causes of lymphatic obstruction</li>
</ul>
<p>23
The case of medical physiology of asthma</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-increased-permeability-of-capillaries">A. Increased permeability of capillaries:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-increased-permeability-of-capillaries" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Some diseases may increase the permeability of capillaries and allow filtration of plasma proteins to the interstitium thus increasing the <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{DP}_{\mathrm{sp}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9694em; vertical-align: -0.2861em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">DP</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">sp</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2861em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> which absorbs fluid to the outside causing edema. The capillary permeability is increased by:</p>
<ul>
<li>Inflammation: The increased permeability is due to mediators of inflammation released by white blood cells and the nearby tissues</li>
<li>Results in localized edema</li>
<li>Burn: The increased permeability is due to the high temperature. It results in localized edema</li>
<li>Allergy: The increased permeability is due to histamine which is released by mast cells and basophils. It results in localized or generalized edema</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-edema">Types of edema:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-edema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Edema can be classified into 2 types (by applying pressure on it in one site using one finger 'the thumb' against bone, for a minute):</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-pitting-edema">1. Pitting edema<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-pitting-edema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="2-non-pitting-edema">2. Non pitting edema<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-non-pitting-edema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>

<li>All causes of lymphatic obstruction</li>
</ul>
<p>The case of medical physiology of asthma</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-increased-permeability-of-capillaries">A. Increased permeability of capillaries:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-increased-permeability-of-capillaries" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Some diseases may increase the permeability of capillaries and allow filtration of plasma proteins to the interstitium thus increasing the <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{DP}_{\mathrm{sp}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9694em; vertical-align: -0.2861em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">DP</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">sp</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2861em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> which absorbs fluid to the outside causing edema. <div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-edema">Types of edema:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-edema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Edema can be classified into 2 types (by applying pressure on it in one site using one finger 'the thumb' against bone, for a minute):</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-pitting-edema">1. Pitting edema<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-pitting-edema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
