<li>All causes of high capillary hydrostatic pressure</li>
<li>All causes of low capillary smooth pressure</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="2-non-pitting-edema">2. Non pitting edema<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-non-pitting-edema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The finger does not leave a mark on the skin because the escaped fluid returns rapidly (this is because it is attracted by proteins that are filtered to the interstitium)</li>
<li>Causes of non pitting edema include:</li>
<li>All causes of increased permeability</li>
<li>All causes of lymphatic obstruction</li>
</ul>
<p>The case of medical physiology of asthma</p>
<ol start="6">
<li>Abnormalities of water balance</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Water balance</li>
<li>In normal physiological conditions, the body loses water in urine to excess waste products of metabolism and in addition to that, there is irreversible loss of water through the skin and in expired air.</li>
<li>These water losses should continuously be replaced by water intake to maintain normal water content of the body.</li>
<li>On the other hand, if water intake is higher than the daily requirement of the body, the excess water should be excreted.</li>
<li>In summary: water loss should equal water intake (= water balance)</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-8f25c360.jpeg" alt="img-45.jpeg">
Fig 1.9: Water balance</p>
<ul>
<li>Abnormalities of this balance between water intake and output cause disturbances in volumes and osmolarity of body fluid compartments.</li>
</ul>
<p>Normal water intake occurs through:</p>
<ul>
<li>drinking 1.3L/day</li>
<li>solid food 0.9L/day</li>
<li>metabolism 0.3L/day</li>
<li>Net = 2.5L/day</li>
</ul>
<p>7.4 The cost of medical physiology of water</p>
<ol start="8">
<li>Abnormalities of water balance</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Water balance</li>
<li>In normal physiological conditions, the body loses water in urine to excess waste products of metabolism and in addition to that, there is irreversible loss of water through the skin and in expired air.</li>
<li>These water losses should continuously be replaced by water intake to maintain normal water content of the body.</li>
<li>On the other hand, if water intake is higher than the daily requirement of the body, the excess water should be excreted.</li>
<li>In summary: water loss should equal water intake (= water balance)</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-e5a94d83.jpeg" alt="img-46.jpeg">
Fig 1.9: Water balance</p>
<ul>
<li>Abnormalities of this balance between water intake and output cause disturbances in volumes and osmolarity of body fluid compartments.</li>
</ul>
<p>Normal water intake occurs through:</p>
<ul>
<li>drinking 1.3L/day</li>
<li>solid food 0.9L/day</li>
<li>metabolism 0.3L/day</li>
<li>Net = 2.5L/day</li>
</ul>
<ol start="8">
<li>Abnormalities of water balance</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Water balance</li>
<li>In normal physiological conditions, the body loses water in urine to excess waste products of metabolism and in addition to that, there is irreversible loss of water through the skin and in expired air.</li>
<li>These water losses should continuously be replaced by water intake to maintain normal water content of the body.</li>
<li>On the other hand, if water intake is higher than the daily requirement of the body, the excess water should be excreted.</li>
<li>In summary: water loss should equal water intake (= water balance)</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-c1bb2296.jpeg" alt="img-47.jpeg">
Fig 1.9: Water balance</p>
<ul>
<li>Abnormalities of this balance between water intake and output cause disturbances in volumes and osmolarity of body fluid compartments.</li>
</ul>
<p>Normal water intake occurs through:</p>
<ul>
<li>drinking 1.3L/day</li>
<li>solid food 0.9L/day</li>
<li>metabolism 0.3L/day</li>
<li>Net = 2.5L/day</li>
</ul>
<p>20 The cost of medical physiology of water</p>
<p>Normal water output occurs through:</p>
<ul>
<li>urine 1.5 L/day</li>
<li>stool 0.1 L/day</li>
<li>sweating &amp; loperetile loss 0.5 L/day</li>
<li>Nails 2.5 L/day</li>
</ul>
<p>Note</p>
<ul>
<li>The average water intake = the average water loss × 2.5 L/day</li>
<li>The above values vary greatly in different physiological and pathological conditions</li>
</ul>
<p>Examples of the physiological conditions:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Type of work
E.g. heavy work increases sweating = increased water loss</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Exercise
E.g. strenuous exercise increases sweating and causes hyperventilation (increases reversible water loss in expired air) = increased water loss</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Degree of water intake
Effects urine volume as follows:</p>
</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>High water intake increases urine volume</li>
<li>Low water intake decreases urine volume</li>
<li>Remember that the minimum volume of urine required for i-citation of waste products of metabolism is 500 ml/day</li>
</ul>
<ol start="4">
<li>Variation in body temperature and environmental temperature
Both affect the amount of sweating, the rate of metabolism and the rate of respiration (see chapter 4)</li>
</ol>
<p>Examples of the pathological conditions:</p>
<ol>
<li>Abnormal water intake through:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>increased metabolism (fever, hyperthyroidism)</li>
</ul>
<p>Normal water output occurs through:</p>
<ul>
<li>urine 1.5 L/day</li>
<li>stool 0.1 L/day</li>
<li>sweating &amp; loperetile loss 0.5 L/day</li>
<li>Nails 2.5 L/day</li>
</ul>
<p>Note</p>
<ul>
<li>The average water intake = the average water loss × 2.5 L/day</li>
<li>The above values vary greatly in different physiological and pathological conditions</li>
</ul>
<p>Examples of the physiological conditions:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Type of work
E.g. heavy work increases sweating = increased water loss</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Exercise
E.g. strenuous exercise increases sweating and causes hyperventilation (increases reversible water loss in expired air) = increased water loss</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Degree of water intake
Effects urine volume as follows:</p>
</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>High water intake increases urine volume</li>
<li>Low water intake decreases urine volume</li>
<li>Remember that the minimum volume of urine required for i-citation of waste products of metabolism is 500 ml/day</li>
</ul>
<ol start="4">
<li>Variation in body temperature and environmental temperature
Both affect the amount of sweating, the rate of metabolism and the rate of respiration (see chapter 4)</li>
</ol>
<p>Examples of the pathological conditions:</p>
<ol>
<li>Abnormal water intake through:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>increased metabolism (fever, hyperthyroidism)</li>
</ul>
<p>Normal water output occurs through:</p>
<ul>
<li>urine 1.5 L/day</li>
<li>stool 0.1 L/day</li>
<li>sweating &amp; loperetile loss 0.5 L/day</li>
<li>Nails 2.5 L/day</li>
</ul>
<p>Note</p>
<ul>
<li>The average water intake = the average water loss × 2.5 L/day</li>
<li>The above values vary greatly in different physiological and pathological conditions</li>
</ul>
<p>Examples of the physiological conditions:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Type of work
E.g. heavy work increases sweating = increased water loss</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Exercise
E.g. strenuous exercise increases sweating and causes hyperventilation (increases reversible water loss in expired air) = increased water loss</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Degree of water intake
Effects urine volume as follows:</p>
</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>High water intake increases urine volume</li>
<li>Low water intake decreases urine volume</li>
<li>Remember that the minimum volume of urine required for i-citation of waste products of metabolism is 500 ml/day</li>
</ul>
<ol start="4">
<li>Variation in body temperature and environmental temperature
Both affect the amount of sweating, the rate of metabolism and the rate of respiration (see chapter 4)</li>
</ol>
<p>Examples of the pathological conditions:</p>
<ol>
<li>Abnormal water intake through:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>increased metabolism (fever, hyperthyroidism)</li>
</ul>
<p>21</p>
<ul>
<li>increased drinking (psychogenic polydipsia)</li>
<li>excess intravenous fluids (fluid overload)</li>
<li>complete water deprivation</li>
</ul>
<p>2- Abnormal water loss through:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>vomiting</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>diarrhea</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>polyuria (diabetes mellitus, diabetes insipidus)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>excessive sweating (heat exhaustion)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>hyperventilation (metabolic acidosis)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>increased drinking (psychogenic polydipsia)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>excess intravenous fluids (fluid overload)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>complete water deprivation</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>3- Abnormal water loss through:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>vomiting</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>diarrhea</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>polyuria (diabetes mellitus, diabetes insipidus)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>excessive sweating (heat exhaustion)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>hyperventilation (metabolic acidosis)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>increased drinking (psychogenic polydipsia)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>excess intravenous fluids (fluid overload)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>complete water deprivation</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>2- Abnormal water loss through:</p>
<ul>
<li>vomiting</li>
<li>diarrhea</li>
<li>polyuria (diabetes mellitus, diabetes insipidus)</li>
<li>excessive sweating (heat exhaustion)</li>
<li>hyperventilation (metabolic acidosis)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="regulation-of-water-balance">Regulation of water balance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#regulation-of-water-balance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>As mentioned earlier, maintenance of constancy of ECF is the goal of all systems in the body.</li>
<li>Variation in water intake or water loss produces minor changes in extracellular fluid volume and osmolarity. These changes stimulate certain receptors (e.g. volume receptors &amp; osmoscrapions) that activate multiple regulatory mechanisms to restore back the constancy of the ECF.</li>
<li>The regulatory mechanisms include:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Mechanisms for control of water intake</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>act principally through control of thirst</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Mechanisms for control of water loss</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>act principally through control of urine volume</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="control-of-water-intake">Control of water intake<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-water-intake" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Under normal environmental and physiological conditions, the amount of water gained by metabolism or solid food is almost constant whereas the amount gained by drinking may be variable. That's why water intake is generally</p>
<p>16</p>
<p>The extent of water loss is generally not sufficient</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="regulation-of-water-balance">Regulation of water balance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#regulation-of-water-balance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>As mentioned earlier, maintenance of constancy of ECF is the goal of all systems in the body.</li>
<li>Variation in water intake or water loss produces minor changes in extracellular fluid volume and osmolarity. These changes stimulate certain receptors (e.g. volume receptors &amp; osmoscrapions) that activate multiple regulatory mechanisms to restore back the constancy of the ECF.</li>
<li>The regulatory mechanisms include:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Mechanisms for control of water intake</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>act principally through control of thirst</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Mechanisms for control of water loss</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>act principally through control of urine volume</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="control-of-water-intake">Control of water intake<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-water-intake" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Under normal environmental and physiological conditions, the amount of water gained by metabolism or solid food is almost constant whereas the amount gained by drinking may be variable. That's why water intake is generally</li>
</ul>
<p>18</p>
<p>The extent of water loss is generally not sufficient</p>
<p>regulated through regulation of drinking (= regulation of thirst). On the other hand, water intake through solid food and metabolism is a non-regulatory component.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood">Blood<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Defined as the subjective perception that provides the urge for humans and animals to drink fluids.</li>
<li>Also defined as the conscious desire for water.</li>
<li>Regulated by thirst center located in the hypothalamus.</li>
</ul>
<p>There are 4 main stimuli to thirst:</p>
<ul>
<li>Angiotensin III: This is an anti-peptide hormone produced in the plasma following release of renin enzyme from the "Juxta-glomerular apparatus" in the kidney (see below).</li>
<li>It acts directly on specific receptors located in circumventricular organs in the brain (neural organs that lie outside the blood-brain barrier) to stimulate thirst. The neuronal pathway from the circumventricular organs to the hypothalamus also uses angiotensin II as a neurotransmitter.</li>
<li>Hypertonicity: Small increases of 1.2% of the effective osmotic pressure of plasma cause shrinkage of osmoreceptors in the hypothalamus (due to osmosis from the osmoreceptors to the ECF).</li>
<li>Shrinkage of the osmoreceptors results in direct mechanical stimulation of the thirst center because its dendrites which are attached to the osmoreceptors are stretched by the shrinkage.</li>
<li>Hyperostemia: The volume of ECF is sensed via volume-receptor located at the low pressure side of the circulation (i.e. the venous side, at the junction of the right atrium and the vena cava and at the entry of the pulmonary vein into the left atrium).</li>
<li>Hyperostemia stretches these receptors which send inhibitory impulses through the vagus nerve to inhibit thirst. On the other hand, hypostemia</li>
</ul>
<p>regulated through regulation of drinking (= regulation of thirst). On the other hand, water intake through solid food and metabolism is a non-regulatory component.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood">Blood<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Defined as the subjective perception that provides the urge for humans and animals to drink fluids.</li>
<li>Also defined as the conscious desire for water.</li>
<li>Regulated by thirst center located in the hypothalamus.</li>
</ul>
<p>There are 4 major stimuli to thirst:</p>
<ul>
<li>Angiotensin III: This is an anti-peptide hormone produced in the plasma following release of renin enzyme from the "Juxta-glomerular apparatus" in the kidney (see below).</li>
<li>It acts directly on specific receptors located in circumventricular organs in the brain (neural organs that lie outside the blood-brain barrier) to stimulate thirst. The neuronal pathway from the circumventricular organs to the hypothalamus also uses angiotensin II as a neurotransmitter.</li>
<li>Hypertonicity: Small increases of 1.2% of the effective osmotic pressure of plasma cause shrinkage of osmoreceptors in the hypothalamus (due to osmosis from the osmoreceptors to the ECF).</li>
<li>Shrinkage of the osmoreceptors results in direct mechanical stimulation of the thirst center because its dendrites which are attached to the osmoreceptors are stretched by the shrinkage.</li>
<li>Hyperostemia: The volume of ECF is sensed via volume-receptor located at the low pressure side of the circulation (i.e. the venous side, at the junction of the right atrium and the vena cava and at the entry of the pulmonary vein into the left atrium).</li>
<li>Hyperostemia stretches these receptors which send inhibitory impulses through the vagus nerve to inhibit thirst. On the other hand, hypostemia</li>
</ul>
<p>The text of author's permission is illegible</p>
<p>The text of author's permission is illegible</p>
<p>stimulates thirst through reduction of the inhibitory discharge from the volume receptors to the thirst center.</p>
<ul>
<li>Hypotension: The blood pressure is sensed via baroreceptors located at the high pressure side of the circulation (i.e. the arterial side, at the carotid sinus and the aortic sinus which are found at the bifurcation of the common carotid artery and the aortic arch respectively).</li>
<li>Hypertension stretches these receptors which send inhibitory impulses through the vagus and the gloeospharyngeal nerves to inhibit the thirst center. On the other hand, hypotension stimulates thirst through reduction of the inhibitory discharge from these receptors to the thirst center.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="remission-that">Remission that<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remission-that" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Thirst is one of the symptoms of dehydration and shock</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-hormone-atrial-natriuretic-peptide-anp-inhibits-thirst">The hormone atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) inhibits thirst<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-hormone-atrial-natriuretic-peptide-anp-inhibits-thirst" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>ANP is a peptide hormone released by atria in response to hypercalemia. It inhibits the effect of angiotensin II on thirst to decrease ECF volume. It also decreases ECF volume through inhibition of aldosterone action in the kidney. Increasing the rate of glomerular filtration and increasing the rate of sodium excretion in urine (notice that loss of sodium is followed by loss of water).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="important-note">Important note<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#important-note" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Drinking stimulates mechanoreceptors in the L.auri and pharynx which provide input to the hypothalamus to attenuate the sensation of thirst. This occurs before any reduction in plasma toxicity; thus acting as a safeguard against over-ingestion of water.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="control-of-water-loss">Control of water loss<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-water-loss" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Under normal environmental and physiological conditions, the amount of water lost by sweating, respiration and through the skin is almost constant whereas the amount lost by urine is variable.</p>
<p>stimulates thirst through reduction of the inhibitory discharge from the volume receptors to the thirst center.</p>
<ul>
<li>Hypotension: The blood pressure is sensed via baroreceptors located at the high pressure side of the circulation (i.e. the arterial side, at the carotid sinus and the aortic sinus which are found at the bifurcation of the common carotid artery and the aortic arch respectively).</li>
<li>Hypertension stretches these receptors which send inhibitory impulses through the vagus and the gloeospharyngeal nerves to inhibit the thirst center. On the other hand, hypotension stimulates thirst through reduction of the inhibitory discharge from these receptors to the thirst center.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="remission-that">Remission that<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remission-that" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Thirst is one of the symptoms of dehydration and shock</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-hormone-atrial-natriuretic-peptide-anp-inhibits-thirst">The hormone atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) inhibits thirst<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-hormone-atrial-natriuretic-peptide-anp-inhibits-thirst" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>ANP is a peptide hormone released by atria in response to hypercalemia. It inhibits the effect of angiotensin II on thirst to decrease ECF volume. It also decreases ECF volume through inhibition of aldosterone action in the kidney. Increasing the rate of glomerular filtration and increasing the rate of sodium excretion in urine (notice that loss of sodium is followed by loss of water).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="important-note">Important note<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#important-note" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Drinking stimulates mechanoreceptors in the L.auri and pharynx which provide input to the hypothalamus to attenuate the sensation of thirst. This occurs before any reduction in plasma toxicity; thus acting as a safeguard against over-ingestion of water.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="control-of-water-loss">Control of water loss<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-water-loss" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Under normal environmental and physiological conditions, the amount of water lost by sweating, respiration and through the skin is almost constant whereas the amount lost by urine is variable.</p>
<p>stimulates thirst through reduction of the inhibitory discharge from the volume receptors to the thirst center.</p>
<ul>
<li>Hypotension: The blood pressure is sensed via baroreceptors located at the high pressure side of the circulation (i.e. the arterial side, at the carotid sinus and the aortic sinus which are found at the bifurcation of the common carotid artery and the aortic arch respectively).</li>
<li>Hypertension stretches these receptors which send inhibitory impulses through the vagus and the gloeospharyngeal nerves to inhibit the thirst center. On the other hand, hypotension stimulates thirst through reduction of the inhibitory discharge from these receptors to the thirst center.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="remission-that">Remission that<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remission-that" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-hormone-atrial-natriuretic-peptide-anp-inhibits-thirst">The hormone atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) inhibits thirst<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-hormone-atrial-natriuretic-peptide-anp-inhibits-thirst" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>ANP is a peptide hormone released by atria in response to hypercalemia. It inhibits the effect of angiotensin II on thirst to decrease ECF volume. It also decreases ECF volume through inhibition of aldosterone action in the kidney. Increasing the rate of glomerular filtration and increasing the rate of sodium excretion in urine (notice that loss of sodium is followed by loss of water).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="important-note">Important note<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#important-note" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Drinking stimulates mechanoreceptors in the L.auri and pharynx which provide input to the hypothalamus to attenuate the sensation of thirst. This occurs before any reduction in plasma toxicity; thus acting as a safeguard against over-ingestion of water.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="control-of-water-loss">Control of water loss<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-water-loss" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Under normal environmental and physiological conditions, the amount of water lost by sweating, respiration and through the skin is almost constant whereas the amount lost by urine is variable.</p>
<p>10
The Journal of Medical Physiology 17 (2004)
10
The Journal of Medical Physiology 17 (2004)</p>
<ul>
<li>The minimal volume of urine that can be excreted to eliminate the metabolic waste products = 0.5 L/day. The maximal volume depends on water intake.</li>
<li>For this reason water loss is controlled through regulation of urine volume. This involves the kidney and the hormones acting on it.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="renal-function">Renal function<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#renal-function" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The functional unit of the kidney is the "nephron" which consists of: glomerulus, for filtration &amp; tubules, for reabsorption and excretion.</li>
<li>About 180 L of fluid pass through the glomeruli of the kidney each day. However, only 1.5 L is excreted in urine indicating that the renal tubules reabsorb more than 50% of the filtered fluid.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-5b872f25.jpeg" alt="img-48.jpeg">
Fig 1.10: The nephron</p>
<ul>
<li>The minimal volume of urine that can be excreted to eliminate the metabolic waste products = 0.5 L/day. The maximal volume depends on water intake.</li>
<li>For this reason water loss is controlled through regulation of urine volume. This involves the kidney and the hormones acting on it.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="renal-function">Renal function<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#renal-function" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The functional unit of the kidney is the "nephron" which consists of: glomerulus, for filtration &amp; tubules, for reabsorption and excretion.</li>
<li>About 180 L of fluid pass through the glomeruli of the kidney each day. However, only 1.5 L is excreted in urine indicating that the renal tubules reabsorb more than 50% of the filtered fluid.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-1fedda6d.jpeg" alt="img-49.jpeg">
Fig 1.10: The nephron</p>
<ul>
<li>The minimal volume of urine that can be excreted to eliminate the metabolic waste products = 0.5 L/day. The maximal volume depends on water intake.</li>
<li>For this reason water loss is controlled through regulation of urine volume. This involves the kidney and the hormones acting on it.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="renal-function">Renal function<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#renal-function" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The functional unit of the kidney is the "nephron" which consists of: glomerulus, for filtration &amp; tubules, for reabsorption and excretion.</li>
<li>About 180 L of fluid pass through the glomeruli of the kidney each day. However, only 1.5 L is excreted in urine indicating that the renal tubules reabsorb more than 50% of the filtered fluid.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-24293cf2.jpeg" alt="img-50.jpeg">
Fig 1.10: The nephron</p>
<ul>
<li>Reabsorption of water in the renal tubules occurs as follows:</li>
<li>The PCT, reabsorbs 70% of the filtrate following sodium reabsorption. The filtrate remains isotonic.</li>
<li>The loop of hands, water reabsorption occurs in the thin descending limb without sodium reabsorption. The filtrate becomes hypertonic; however it becomes hypotonic at the end of the thick ascending limb because it reabsorbs solutes without water.</li>
<li>The OCT, relatively impermeable to water. About 5% of the filtrate may be reabsorbed. The filtrate remains hypotonic.</li>
<li>The CO₂. Completely impermeable ** water except at the presence of ADH (see ADH below).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hormonal-activity">Hormonal activity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hormonal-activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="adh">ADH<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adh" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Amidurants hormone, also known as vasopressin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is a non-peptide hormone synthesized in the hypothalamus and stored in the posterior pituitary gland</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is released in response to the same major stimuli of thirst, through similar mechanisms</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypersensitivity (detected by chemoreceptors located at the hypothalamus. They cause mechanical stimulation of ADH)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypovolemia (results in less stretch of the volume receptors at the low pressure side of the circulation and therefore less inhibition of ADH release)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypotension (results in less stretch of the baroreceptors at the high pressure side of the circulation and therefore less inhibition of ADH release)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Angiotensin II (stimulates ADH release, see below)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Drugs (drugs that stimulate ADH release include barbiturates, clofibrate, nicotine, acetylcholine and others)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Reabsorption of water in the renal tubules occurs as follows:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The PCT, reabsorbs 70% of the filtrate following sodium reabsorption. The filtrate remains isotonic.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The loop of hands, water reabsorption occurs in the thin descending limb without sodium reabsorption. The filtrate becomes hypertonic; however it becomes hypotonic at the end of the thick ascending limb because it reabsorbs solutes without water.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The OCT, relatively impermeable to water. About 5% of the filtrate may be reabsorbed. The filtrate remains hypotonic.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The CO₂. Completely impermeable ** water except at the presence of ADH (see ADH below).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hormonal-activity">Hormonal activity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hormonal-activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="adh">ADH<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adh" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Amidurants hormone, also known as vasopressin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is a non-peptide hormone synthesized in the hypothalamus and stored in the posterior pituitary gland</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is released in response to the same major stimuli of thirst, through similar mechanisms</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypersensitivity (detected by chemoreceptors located at the hypothalamus. They cause mechanical stimulation of ADH)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypovolemia (results in less stretch of the volume receptors at the low pressure side of the circulation and therefore less inhibition of ADH release)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypotension (results in less stretch of the baroreceptors at the high pressure side of the circulation and therefore less inhibition of ADH release)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Angiotensin II (stimulates ADH release, see below)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Drugs (drugs that stimulate ADH release include barbiturates, clofibrate, nicotine, acetylcholine and others)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Reabsorption of water in the renal tubules occurs as follows:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The PCT, reabsorbs 70% of the filtrate following sodium reabsorption. The filtrate remains isotonic.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The loop of hands, water reabsorption occurs in the thin descending limb without sodium reabsorption. The filtrate becomes hypertonic; however it becomes hypotonic at the end of the thick ascending limb because it reabsorbs solutes without water.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The OCT, relatively impermeable to water. About 5% of the filtrate may be reabsorbed. The filtrate remains hypotonic.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The CO₂. Completely impermeable ** water except at the presence of ADH (see ADH below).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hormonal-activity">Hormonal activity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hormonal-activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="adh">ADH<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adh" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Amidurants hormone, also known as vasopressin</li>
<li>It is a non-peptide hormone synthesized in the hypothalamus and stored in the posterior pituitary gland</li>
<li>It is released in response to the same major stimuli of thirst, through similar mechanisms</li>
<li>Hypersensitivity (detected by chemoreceptors located at the hypothalamus. They cause mechanical stimulation of ADH)</li>
<li>Hypovolemia (results in less stretch of the volume receptors at the low pressure side of the circulation and therefore less inhibition of ADH release)</li>
<li>Hypotension (results in less stretch of the baroreceptors at the high pressure side of the circulation and therefore less inhibition of ADH release)</li>
<li>Angiotensin II (stimulates ADH release, see below)</li>
<li>Drugs (drugs that stimulate ADH release include barbiturates, clofibrate, nicotine, acetylcholine and others)</li>
</ul>
<p>40
The text of Medical Microbiology 19th ed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-adh">Functions of ADH<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-adh" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>ADH acts on the collecting ducts in the kidney causing water retention. It facilitates reabsorption of T-12% of the tissue.</li>
<li>When ADH level in plasma is high, it also causes vasoconstriction resulting in elevation of the blood pressure.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="abnormalities-of-adh">Abnormalities of ADH<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities-of-adh" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Deficiency of ADH causes polyuria and excessive fluid due to hypovolemia. Urine volume may reach up to 23 L/day. This condition is known as diabetes insipidus (DI). It may result from a problem in the hypothalamus (neurogenic DI) or a problem in the renal receptors for ADH (nephrogenic DI).</li>
<li>Excessive ADH secretion causes reduction in urine volume, hypertension and edema due to water retention. This condition is known as syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH). It is caused by many problems; these include head trauma, lung tumors, pneumonia and pancreatitis.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="aldosterone">Aldosterone<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#aldosterone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Steroid hormone synthesized in the adrenal cortex.</li>
<li>It is released in response to the following stimuli:</li>
<li>Hyperkalemia
Directly stimulates aldosterone release from the adrenal cortex.</li>
<li>High level of ACTH
The adrenocorticoltrophic hormone (ACTH) is released by the anterior pituitary gland to stimulate secretion of cortisol (not aldosterone) by the adrenal cortex. But, in high levels (due to endocrine abnormalities) it also stimulates release of aldosterone.</li>
<li>The renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system
In this system, renin enzyme which is produced by the Juxta-glomerular apparatus in the kidney results in formation of angiotensin II. The later stimulates aldosterone secretion from the adrenal cortex.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-adh">Functions of ADH<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-adh" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>ADH acts on the collecting ducts in the kidney causing water retention. It facilitates reabsorption of T-12% of the tissue.</li>
<li>When ADH level in plasma is high, it also causes vasoconstriction resulting in elevation of the blood pressure.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="abnormalities-of-adh">Abnormalities of ADH<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities-of-adh" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Deficiency of ADH causes polyuria and excessive fluid due to hypovolemia. Urine volume may reach up to 23 L/day. This condition is known as diabetes insipidus (DI). It may result from a problem in the hypothalamus (neurogenic DI) or a problem in the renal receptors for ADH (nephrogenic DI).</li>
<li>Excessive ADH secretion causes reduction in urine volume, hypertension and edema due to water retention. This condition is known as syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH). It is caused by many problems; these include head trauma, lung tumors, pneumonia and pancreatitis.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="aldosterone">Aldosterone<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#aldosterone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Steroid hormone synthesized in the adrenal cortex.</li>
<li>It is released in response to the following stimuli:</li>
<li>Hyperkalemia
Directly stimulates aldosterone release from the adrenal cortex.</li>
<li>High level of ACTH
The adrenocorticoltrophic hormone (ACTH) is released by the anterior pituitary gland to stimulate secretion of cortisol (not aldosterone) by the adrenal cortex. But, in high levels (due to endocrine abnormalities) it also stimulates release of aldosterone.</li>
<li>The renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system
In this system, renin enzyme which is produced by the Juxta-glomerular apparatus in the kidney results in formation of angiotensin II. The later stimulates aldosterone secretion from the adrenal cortex.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-adh">Functions of ADH<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-adh" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>ADH acts on the collecting ducts in the kidney causing water retention. It facilitates reabsorption of T-12% of the tissue.</li>
<li>When ADH level in plasma is high, it also causes vasoconstriction resulting in elevation of the blood pressure.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="abnormalities-of-adh">Abnormalities of ADH<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities-of-adh" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Deficiency of ADH causes polyuria and excessive fluid due to hypovolemia. Urine volume may reach up to 23 L/day. This condition is known as diabetes insipidus (DI). It may result from a problem in the hypothalamus (neurogenic DI) or a problem in the renal receptors for ADH (nephrogenic DI).</li>
<li>Excessive ADH secretion causes reduction in urine volume, hypertension and edema due to water retention. This condition is known as syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH). It is caused by many problems; these include head trauma, lung tumors, pneumonia and pancreatitis.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="aldosterone">Aldosterone<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#aldosterone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Steroid hormone synthesized in the adrenal cortex.</li>
<li>It is released in response to the following stimuli:</li>
<li>Hyperkalemia
Directly stimulates aldosterone release from the adrenal cortex.</li>
<li>High level of ACTH
The adrenocorticoltrophic hormone (ACTH) is released by the anterior pituitary gland to stimulate secretion of cortisol (not aldosterone) by the adrenal cortex. But, in high levels (due to endocrine abnormalities) it also stimulates release of aldosterone.</li>
<li>The renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system
In this system, renin enzyme which is produced by the Juxta-glomerular apparatus in the kidney results in formation of angiotensin II. The later stimulates aldosterone secretion from the adrenal cortex.</li>
</ul>
<p>41
The text of Medical Microbiology 19th ed.</p>
<p>The Juda-glomerular apparatus (JGA) is formed by:</p>
<ul>
<li>Cells of the afferent arsenole (juda-glomerular cells)</li>
<li>Cells of the DCT (mabula dense cells)</li>
<li>Lactic cells (= extra-glomerular mesangial cells)</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-f401a354.jpeg" alt="img-51.jpeg">
Fig 1.11: The Juda-glomerular apparatus (JGA)</p>
<ul>
<li>This apparatus (specifically the juda-glomerular cells) secretes renin in response to one of the following stimuli:</li>
<li>Hyponatremia (low [Na])</li>
<li>Renal ischemia (e.g. due to hypotension or hypovolemia)</li>
<li>Sympathetic stimulation</li>
<li>Renin acts on a plasma peptide known as angiotensinogen (14 amino acids) produced by the liver to form angiotensin I (10 aa).</li>
<li>Angiotensin I is converted to angiotensin II (8 aa) by the action of angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE).</li>
</ul>
<p>The Juda-glomerular apparatus (JGA) is formed by:</p>
<ul>
<li>Cells of the afferent arsenole (juda-glomerular cells)</li>
<li>Cells of the DCT (mabula dense cells)</li>
<li>Lactic cells (= extra-glomerular mesangial cells)</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-08e60180.jpeg" alt="img-52.jpeg">
Fig 1.11: The Juda-glomerular apparatus (JGA)</p>

<p>40
The role of medical physiology in 1990's</p>
<ul>
<li>This enzyme is produced by the pulmonary endothelial cells. It is also released to the circulation by lung macrophages.</li>
<li>Angiotensin II increases ECF volume &amp; pressure because it causes:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Vasoconstriction</li>
<li>Stimulation of the sympathetic (this stimulates release of renin and renin forms angiotensin I and then angiotensin II and the cycle repeats itself in a positive feedback mechanism)</li>
<li>Stimulation of thirst</li>
<li>Stimulation of ADH</li>
<li>Stimulation of aldosterone</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Aldosterone acts on the DCT and CDs in the kidney to stimulate retention of sodium and excretion of potassium. Water follows sodium resulting in increased ECF volume and pressure.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Unlike excessive ADH secretion, excessive aldosterone secretion due to adrenal tumors results in hypernatremia and hypertension but it does not cause edema. The explanation involves AMP as follows:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypernatremia caused by sodium and water retention stimulates release of AMP from the atria. AMP acts in the kidney to increase sodium and water excretion. This prevents development of edema. This phenomenon is known as "aldosterone escape phenomenon".</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A peptide hormone released by atria in response to hypernatremia.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It reduces ECF volume through the following effects:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Inhibition of the effect of angiotensin II on thirst</li>
<li>Inhibition of the effect of aldosterone on the kidney</li>
<li>Increasing the rate of glomerular filtration</li>
<li>Increasing excretion of sodium in urine (= natriuretic; notice that loss of sodium is followed by loss of water)</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>This enzyme is produced by the pulmonary endothelial cells. It is also released to the circulation by lung macrophages.</li>
<li>Angiotensin II increases ECF volume &amp; pressure because it causes:</li>
</ul>

<p>QUESTIONS FOR SELF ASSESSMENT-2 (BEST OF FIVE)</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>The percentage of total body water is higher in:
a. females compared to equivalent males
b. old subjects compared to children
c. infants compared to neonates
d. five subjects compared to obese ones
e. male children compared to female children</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Using the indicator dilution method, ECF volume is measured by:
a. heavy water
b. RISA
c. multi
d. heavy water and RISA
e. 2-gram body water</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The volume of distribution of substance A in an average adult male was found to be 3.5 litres. This substance could be:
a. distributed to all body fluid compartments
b. highly exchangeable between plasma and interstitium
c. tightly bound to plasma proteins
d. rapidly metabolised by cells
e. all the above are correct</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The ECF differs from the ICF because it contains:
a. less concentration of sodium
b. lower pH
c. higher temperature
d. osmolarity of about 300 mmol/L
e. higher concentration of chloride</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The interstitial fluid:
a. constitutes about 5% of total body weight in adults
b. temperature is less than that of the plasma
c. osmolarity is determined by Cr concentration
d. volume can be measured by using multi and mantol
e. contains slightly higher concentration of Cr than plasma</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In a twenty years old man, the following volumes of distribution are obtained using the indicator dilution method: (multi = 14L and 2-gram) blue dye = 3L, which of the following is not true:
a. intravesicular fluid volume is about 3L
b. ECF volume is about 14L
c. ICF volume cannot be calculated from this data
d. ISF volume cannot be calculated from this data
e. blood volume cannot be calculated from this data</p>
</li>
</ol>
