<p>CHAPTER 2</p>
<p>EXCITABLE TISSUES</p>
<ul>
<li>Names and muscles are said to be excitable because they are capable of generating electrical signals known as action potentials.</li>
<li>In addition to action potentials, excitable tissues are also characterized by resting membrane potentials. However, unlike action potentials, resting membrane potentials are found in almost all cells of the body.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-resting-membrane-potential-rmp">THE RESTING MEMBRANE POTENTIAL (RMP)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-resting-membrane-potential-rmp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>If a the difference in electrical potential between the interior and the exterior of cell membranes at rest, with the interior being more negative relative to the exterior.</li>
<li>The cell membranes are said to be "polarized", i.e. negative inside and positive outside.</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 2.1: The polarized cell membrane</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-4bd87761.jpeg" alt="img-54.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>The difference in potential across the cell membrane can be measured by special devices (e.g. the Cathode Ray Oscilloscope), using electrodes placed in the two sides of the cell membrane.</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 2.2: Measurement of the resting membrane potential</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-4bd87761.jpeg" alt="img-55.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>The magnitude of the RMP differs in different types of cells, for example:</li>
<li>In a skeletal muscle cell = - 90 mv</li>
<li>In a cardiac muscle cell = - 90 mv</li>
<li>In a nerve cell = - 70 mv</li>
</ul>
<p>48</p>
<p>The most of electrical potential is in units</p>
<p>CHAPTER 3</p>
<p>EXCITABLE TISSUES</p>
<ul>
<li>Names and muscles are said to be excitable because they are capable of generating electrical signals known as action potentials.</li>
<li>In addition to action potentials, excitable tissues are also characterized by resting membrane potentials. However, unlike action potentials, resting membrane potentials are found in almost all cells of the body.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-resting-membrane-potential-rmp">THE RESTING MEMBRANE POTENTIAL (RMP)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-resting-membrane-potential-rmp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>If a the difference in electrical potential between the interior and the exterior of cell membranes at rest, with the interior being more negative relative to the exterior.</li>
<li>The cell membranes are said to be "polarized", i.e. negative inside and positive outside.</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 2.1: The polarized cell membrane</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-c222830b.jpeg" alt="img-56.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>The difference in potential across the cell membrane can be measured by special devices (e.g. the Cathode Ray Oscilloscope), using electrodes placed in the two sides of the cell membrane.</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 2.2: Measurement of the resting membrane potential</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-052580f5.jpeg" alt="img-57.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>The magnitude of the RMP differs in different types of cells, for example:</li>
<li>In a skeletal muscle cell = - 90 mv</li>
<li>In a cardiac muscle cell = - 90 mv</li>
<li>In a nerve cell = - 70 mv</li>
</ul>
<p>49</p>
<p>The most of electrical potential is in units</p>
<p>CHAPTER 2</p>
<p>EXCITABLE TISSUES</p>
<ul>
<li>Names and muscles are said to be excitable because they are capable of generating electrical signals known as action potentials.</li>
<li>In addition to action potentials, excitable tissues are also characterized by resting membrane potentials. However, unlike action potentials, resting membrane potentials are found in almost all cells of the body.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-resting-membrane-potential-rmp">THE RESTING MEMBRANE POTENTIAL (RMP)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-resting-membrane-potential-rmp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>If a the difference in electrical potential between the interior and the exterior of cell membranes at rest, with the interior being more negative relative to the exterior.</li>
<li>The cell membranes are said to be "polarized", i.e. negative inside and positive outside.</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 2.1: The polarized cell membrane</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-052580f5.jpeg" alt="img-58.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>The difference in potential across the cell membrane can be measured by special devices (e.g. the Cathode Ray Oscilloscope), using electrodes placed in the two sides of the cell membrane.</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 2.2: Measurement of the resting membrane potential</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-052580f5.jpeg" alt="img-59.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>The magnitude of the RMP differs in different types of cells, for example:</li>
<li>In a skeletal muscle cell = - 90 mv</li>
<li>In a cardiac muscle cell = - 90 mv</li>
<li>In a nerve cell = - 70 mv</li>
</ul>
<p>49</p>
<p>42
The text of various proceedings' 42' sections</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="causes-of-the-rwp">Causes of the RWP:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-of-the-rwp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>a. Potassium efflux
b. The Sodium- potassium pump
c. ICF non-diffusible anions</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="a-potassium-efflux">a. Potassium efflux<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-potassium-efflux" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>This is the major cause of RWP.</li>
<li>The cell membrane is more permeable to potassium than sodium (because the hydrated atom of potassium is smaller than the hydrated atom of sodium).</li>
<li>Therefore potassium diffuses to the outside down its concentration gradient through potassium leak channels.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fig-2-2-potassium-efflux">Fig 2.2: Potassium efflux<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-2-2-potassium-efflux" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-0ed77750.jpeg" alt="img-60.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>For each atom of potassium that diffuses to the outside, a negative charge is generated inside and a positive charge is generated outside the cell membrane.</li>
<li>The positive charges outside the cell membrane relief the potassium ions, forcing them back to the inside through the leak channels (down their electrical gradient from the positive side to the negative side). However, net potassium efflux continues until the chemical gradient which drives potassium to the outside is equal to the electrical gradient that drives potassium to the inside (= stage of equilibrium).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="b-the-sodium-potassium-pump">b. The Sodium- potassium pump<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-the-sodium-potassium-pump" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>An electrogenic pump that pumps 3 sodium ions to outside a cell and 2 potassium ions to inside, thus generating one negative charge inside the cell (and one positive charge outside the cell) with each activity.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="causes-of-the-rwp">Causes of the RWP:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-of-the-rwp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>a. Potassium efflux
b. The Sodium- potassium pump
c. ICF non-diffusible anions</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="a-potassium-efflux">a. Potassium efflux<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-potassium-efflux" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>This is the major cause of RWP.</li>
<li>The cell membrane is more permeable to potassium than sodium (because the hydrated atom of potassium is smaller than the hydrated atom of sodium).</li>
<li>Therefore potassium diffuses to the outside down its concentration gradient through potassium leak channels.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fig-2-3-potassium-efflux">Fig 2.3: Potassium efflux<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-2-3-potassium-efflux" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-6b44a9e9.jpeg" alt="img-61.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>For each atom of potassium that diffuses to the outside, a negative charge is generated inside and a positive charge is generated outside the cell membrane.</li>
<li>The positive charges outside the cell membrane relief the potassium ions, forcing them back to the inside through the leak channels (down their electrical gradient from the positive side to the negative side). However, net potassium efflux continues until the chemical gradient which drives potassium to the outside is equal to the electrical gradient that drives potassium to the inside (= stage of equilibrium).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="b-the-sodium-potassium-pump">b. The Sodium- potassium pump<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-the-sodium-potassium-pump" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>An electrogenic pump that pumps 3 sodium ions to outside a cell and 2 potassium ions to inside, thus generating one negative charge inside the cell (and one positive charge outside the cell) with each activity.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="causes-of-the-rwp">Causes of the RWP:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-of-the-rwp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>a. Potassium efflux
b. The Sodium- potassium pump
c. ICF non-diffusible anions</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="a-potassium-efflux">a. Potassium efflux<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-potassium-efflux" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>This is the major cause of RWP.</li>
<li>The cell membrane is more permeable to potassium than sodium (because the hydrated atom of potassium is smaller than the hydrated atom of sodium).</li>
<li>Therefore potassium diffuses to the outside down its concentration gradient through potassium leak channels.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fig-2-3-potassium-efflux">Fig 2.3: Potassium efflux<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-2-3-potassium-efflux" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-4263f6ee.jpeg" alt="img-62.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>For each atom of potassium that diffuses to the outside, a negative charge is generated inside and a positive charge is generated outside the cell membrane.</li>
<li>The positive charges outside the cell membrane relief the potassium ions, forcing them back to the inside through the leak channels (down their electrical gradient from the positive side to the negative side). However, net potassium efflux continues until the chemical gradient which drives potassium to the outside is equal to the electrical gradient that drives potassium to the inside (= stage of equilibrium).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="b-the-sodium-potassium-pump">b. The Sodium- potassium pump<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-the-sodium-potassium-pump" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>An electrogenic pump that pumps 3 sodium ions to outside a cell and 2 potassium ions to inside, thus generating one negative charge inside the cell (and one positive charge outside the cell) with each activity.</li>
</ul>
<p>The text of various proceedings' 42' sections</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-d20094d1.jpeg" alt="img-63.jpeg">
Fig 2.4 The sodium potassium pump</p>
<ul>
<li>Sodium and potassium ions are transported actively against their concentration gradients, using energy released by hydrolysis of ATP (see chapter 1).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-kit-non-diffusable-anions">c-KIT non diffusable anions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-kit-non-diffusable-anions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Presence of non diffusable anions inside the cell (protein and organic phosphate) contributes to the genesis of RMP by increasing the number of negative charges inside the cell (+ very low contribution).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-equilibrium-potential">The equilibrium potential:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-equilibrium-potential" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The equilibrium potential (E) for an ion gives an idea about its role in genesis of the resting membrane potential. Here the ion is placed in a medium similar to ECF and allowed to pass into or out of the cell to reach equilibrium, without contribution of other ions. The membrane potential generated due to difference in concentrations of that ion in ECF and ICF is called the equilibrium potential. However, it does not occur normally because of the contribution of other ions.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The equilibrium potential can be measured by the <em>Normal equation</em> as follows:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>for cations: E = 61 log [calor/μg/(calor/μg)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>for anions E = 61 log [anion/μg/(anion/μg)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Examples:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>E for K⁺ = 61 log 4/140 = - 90 mv (close to the RMP, indicating a major role of K⁺ in the genesis of RMP).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-f629e5ae.jpeg" alt="img-64.jpeg">
Fig 2.4 The sodium potassium pump</p>
<ul>
<li>Sodium and potassium ions are transported actively against their concentration gradients, using energy released by hydrolysis of ATP (see chapter 1).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-kit-non-diffusable-anions">c-KIT non diffusable anions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-kit-non-diffusable-anions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Presence of non diffusable anions inside the cell (protein and organic phosphate) contributes to the genesis of RMP by increasing the number of negative charges inside the cell (+ very low contribution).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-equilibrium-potential">The equilibrium potential:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-equilibrium-potential" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The equilibrium potential (E) for an ion gives an idea about its role in genesis of the resting membrane potential. Here the ion is placed in a medium similar to ECF and allowed to pass into or out of the cell to reach equilibrium, without contribution of other ions. The membrane potential generated due to difference in concentrations of that ion in ECF and ICF is called the equilibrium potential. However, it does not occur normally because of the contribution of other ions.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The equilibrium potential can be measured by the <em>Normal equation</em> as follows:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>for cations: E = 61 log [calor/μg/(calor/μg)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>for anions E = 61 log [anion/μg/(anion/μg)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Examples:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>E for K⁺ = 61 log 4/140 = - 90 mv (close to the RMP, indicating a major role of K⁺ in the genesis of RMP).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-0735edee.jpeg" alt="img-65.jpeg">
Fig 2.4 The sodium potassium pump</p>
<ul>
<li>Sodium and potassium ions are transported actively against their concentration gradients, using energy released by hydrolysis of ATP (see chapter 1).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-kit-non-diffusable-anions">c-KIT non diffusable anions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-kit-non-diffusable-anions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Presence of non diffusable anions inside the cell (protein and organic phosphate) contributes to the genesis of RMP by increasing the number of negative charges inside the cell (+ very low contribution).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-equilibrium-potential">The equilibrium potential:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-equilibrium-potential" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The equilibrium potential (E) for an ion gives an idea about its role in genesis of the resting membrane potential. Here the ion is placed in a medium similar to ECF and allowed to pass into or out of the cell to reach equilibrium, without contribution of other ions. The membrane potential generated due to difference in concentrations of that ion in ECF and ICF is called the equilibrium potential. However, it does not occur normally because of the contribution of other ions.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The equilibrium potential can be measured by the <em>Normal equation</em> as follows:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>for cations: E = 61 log [calor/μg/(calor/μg)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>for anions E = 61 log [anion/μg/(anion/μg)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Examples:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>E for K⁺ = 61 log 4/140 = - 90 mv (close to the RMP, indicating a major role of K⁺ in the genesis of RMP).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-25f692ef.jpeg" alt="img-66.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>L for Na⁺ = 61 kg 150/15 = + 61 mn (very far from the RMP, indicating a minor role of Na⁺ in genesis of the RMP).</li>
<li>E for Cl⁻ = 61 kg 110/8 = -72 mn (Inbrecker: there is no evidence that Cl has an active transport similar to Na⁺ and K⁺, so it does not contribute to the RMP).</li>
<li>The <em>Seminum equation</em> can be used for direct calculation of the RMP. It includes the effects of the major ions and their permeabilities (P) across the cell membrane as follows:</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>RMP</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>mn</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>61</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>kg</mtext><mtext> </mtext><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mn>0</mn></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>K</mtext><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mtext>cat</mtext></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>m</mtext></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>Na</mtext><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mtext>cat</mtext></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mn>0</mn></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>Cl</mtext><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mtext>on</mtext></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{RMP} \, (\text{mn}) = 61 \, \text{kg} \, \text{P}_0 \, [\text{K}]_{\text{cat}} + \text{P}_\text{m} \, [\text{Na}]_{\text{cat}} + \text{P}_0 \, [\text{Cl}]_{\text{on}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; <div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mn>0</mn></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>K</mtext><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mtext>on</mtext></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>m</mtext></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>Na</mtext><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mtext>on</mtext></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mn>0</mn></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>Cl</mtext><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mtext>on</mtext></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{P}_0 \, [\text{K}]_{\text{on}} + \text{P}_\text{m} \, [\text{Na}]_{\text{on}} + \text{P}_0 \, [\text{Cl}]_{\text{on}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">P</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">m</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Na</span></span><span class="mclose"><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">P</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">0</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Cl</span></span><span class="mclose"><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">on</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-action-potential-ap">THE ACTION POTENTIAL (AP)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-action-potential-ap" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs only in excitable tissues (me as a muscle).</li>
<li>Involves alterations in the membrane potential (degradation and repolarization) following sufficient mechanical, electrical or chemical stimulation.</li>
<li>The action potential can be recorded by special devices (e.g. the cathode ray oscilloscope).</li>
<li>The <em>general</em> action potential can be: <em>Monophasic</em> in which the recording electrodes are placed on the surface of cell membrane; or <em>Diphasic</em> in which they are placed on the two sides of cell membrane.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="components-of-the-action-potential">Components of the action potential<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#components-of-the-action-potential" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Stimulus <em>action</em>:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Occurs at the time of stimulation (marks the point of stimulation).</li>
<li>Due to current leakage from the stimulus electrode.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Latent <em>period</em>:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The <em>sequential</em> interval from the point of stimulation to the start of action potential.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>E for Na⁺ = 61 kg 150/15 = + 61 mn (very far from the RMP, indicating a minor role of Na⁺ in genesis of the RMP).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>F for Cl⁻ = 61 kg 110/8 = -72 mn (Inbrecker: there is no evidence that Cl has an active transport similar to Na⁺ and K⁺, so it does not contribute to the RMP).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The <em>Seminum equation</em> can be used for direct calculation of the RMP. It includes the effects of the major ions and their permeabilities (P) across the cell membrane as follows:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>RMP</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>mn</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>61</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>kg</mtext><mtext> </mtext><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mn>0</mn></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>K</mtext><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mtext>cat</mtext></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>m</mtext></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>Na</mtext><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mtext>cat</mtext></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mn>0</mn></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>Cl</mtext><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mtext>on</mtext></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{RMP} \, (\text{mn}) = 61 \, \text{kg} \, \text{P}_0 \, [\text{K}]_{\text{cat}} + \text{P}_\text{m} \, [\text{Na}]_{\text{cat}} + \text{P}_0 \, [\text{Cl}]_{\text{on}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">RMP</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">mn</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">61</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">kg</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">P</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">0</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">K</span></span><span class="mclose"><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2806em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">cat</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">P</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">m</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Na</span></span><span class="mclose"><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2806em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">cat</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">P</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">0</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Cl</span></span><span class="mclose"><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">on</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mn>0</mn></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>K</mtext><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mtext>on</mtext></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>m</mtext></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>Na</mtext><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mtext>on</mtext></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mn>0</mn></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>Cl</mtext><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mtext>on</mtext></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{P}_0 \, [\text{K}]_{\text{on}} + \text{P}_\text{m} \, [\text{Na}]_{\text{on}} + \text{P}_0 \, [\text{Cl}]_{\text{on}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">on</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">P</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">m</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Na</span></span><span class="mclose"><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">on</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">P</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">0</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Cl</span></span><span class="mclose"><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">on</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-action-potential-bp">THE ACTION POTENTIAL (BP)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-action-potential-bp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs only in excitable tissues (me as a muscle).</li>
<li>Involves alterations in the membrane potential (degradation and repolarization) following sufficient mechanical, electrical or chemical stimulation.</li>
<li>The action potential can be recorded by special devices (e.g. the cathode ray oscilloscope).</li>
<li>The <em>general</em> action potential can be: <em>Monophasic</em> in which the recording electrodes are placed on the surface of cell membrane; or <em>Diphasic</em> in which they are placed on the two sides of cell membrane.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="components-of-the-action-potential">Components of the action potential<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#components-of-the-action-potential" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Stimulus <em>action</em>:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Occurs at the time of stimulation (marks the point of stimulation).</li>
<li>Due to current leakage from the stimulus electrode.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Latent <em>period</em>:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The <em>sequential</em> interval from the point of stimulation to the start of action potential.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>E for Na⁺ = 61 kg 150/15 = + 61 mn (very far from the RMP, indicating a minor role of Na⁺ in genesis of the RMP).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>K for Cl⁻ = 61 kg 110/8 = -72 mn (Inbrecker: there is no evidence that Cl has an active transport similar to Na⁺ and K⁺, so it does not contribute to the RMP).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>The <em>Seminum equation</em> can be used for direct calculation of the RMP. It includes the effects of the major ions and their permeabilities (P) across the cell membrane as follows:</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>RMP</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>mn</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>61</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>kg</mtext><mtext> </mtext><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mn>0</mn></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>K</mtext><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mtext>cat</mtext></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>m</mtext></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>Na</mtext><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mtext>cat</mtext></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mn>0</mn></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>Cl</mtext><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mtext>on</mtext></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{RMP} \, (\text{mn}) = 61 \, \text{kg} \, \text{P}_0 \, [\text{K}]_{\text{cat}} + \text{P}_\text{m} \, [\text{Na}]_{\text{cat}} + \text{P}_0 \, [\text{Cl}]_{\text{on}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">cat</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">P</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">m</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Na</span></span><span class="mclose"><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2806em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; <div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mn>0</mn></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>K</mtext><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mtext>on</mtext></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>m</mtext></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>Na</mtext><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mtext>on</mtext></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mtext>P</mtext><mn>0</mn></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>Cl</mtext><msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mtext>on</mtext></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{P}_0 \, [\text{K}]_{\text{on}} + \text{P}_\text{m} \, [\text{Na}]_{\text{on}} + \text{P}_0 \, [\text{Cl}]_{\text{on}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">P</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">0</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Cl</span></span><span class="mclose"><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">on</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-action-potential-ap">THE ACTION POTENTIAL (AP)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-action-potential-ap" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs only in excitable tissues (me as a muscle).</li>
<li>Involves alterations in the membrane potential (degradation and repolarization) following sufficient mechanical, electrical or chemical stimulation.</li>
<li>The action potential can be recorded by special devices (e.g. the cathode ray oscilloscope).</li>
<li>The <em>general</em> action potential can be: <em>Monophasic</em> in which the recording electrodes are placed on the surface of cell membrane; or <em>diphasic</em> in which they are placed on the two sides of cell membrane.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="components-of-the-action-potential">Components of the action potential<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#components-of-the-action-potential" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Stimulus <em>action</em>:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Occurs at the time of stimulation (marks the point of stimulation).</li>
<li>Due to current leakage from the stimulus electrode.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Latent <em>period</em>:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The <em>sequential</em> interval from the point of stimulation to the start of action potential.</li>
</ul>
<p>31
32</p>
<p>52
The issue of medical physiology of science</p>
<ul>
<li>Can be used for measurement of the conduction velocity (CV) in an area. Conduction velocity = (the distance between the stimulating and recording electrodes) divided by (the latent period).</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>Threshold</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The voltage at which the "test voltage gated sodium channels" open. If not reached, action potential never occurs.</li>
<li>It is usually about 15 mv less than the resting membrane potential (e.g. -75 mv when the RMP is -90 mv).</li>
</ul>
<ol start="4">
<li>Depolarization</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Due to sodium influx through the "test voltage gated sodium channels".</li>
<li>The membrane potential moves towards the equilibrium potential for sodium (+60 mv) but it does not reach it because opening of the sodium channels is short lived (the channels rapidly become inactivated and will never open again unless the membrane potential returns back to the resting level.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="5">
<li>Repolarization</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Due to potassium efflux through "voltage gated potassium channels".</li>
<li>Opening of the "voltage gated potassium channels" is slower than sodium channels; that's why potassium efflux occurs after sodium influx. Opening is also more prolonged than sodium channels and this explains the occurrence of after-hypopolarization (see below).</li>
<li>Additional factors that facilitate repolarization are the inactivation of the "test voltage gated sodium channels" and the reversal of the membrane potential (becomes positive inside), thus limiting further sodium influx.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="6">
<li>After-depolarization</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The slower fall in the rate of repolarization.</li>
<li>occurs when repolarization is 70% completed.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="7">
<li>After-hypopolarization</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Slight oversteaming in the hyperpolarizing direction, due to excess potassium efflux through the "voltage gated potassium channels", and then restoration of</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Can be used for measurement of the conduction velocity (CV) in an area. Conduction velocity = (the distance between the stimulating and recording electrodes) divided by (the latent period).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>Threshold</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The voltage at which the "test voltage gated sodium channels" open. If not reached, action potential never occurs.</li>
<li>It is usually about 15 mv less than the resting membrane potential (e.g. -75 mv when the RMP is -90 mv).</li>
</ul>
<ol start="4">
<li>Depolarization</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Due to sodium influx through the "test voltage gated sodium channels".</li>
<li>The membrane potential moves towards the equilibrium potential for sodium (+60 mv) but it does not reach it because opening of the sodium channels is short lived (the channels rapidly become inactivated and will never open again unless the membrane potential returns back to the resting level.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="5">
<li>Repolarization</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Due to potassium efflux through "voltage gated potassium channels".</li>
<li>Opening of the "voltage gated potassium channels" is slower than sodium channels, that's why potassium efflux occurs after sodium influx. Opening is also more prolonged than sodium channels and this explains the occurrence of after-hypopolarization (see below).</li>
<li>Additional factors that facilitate repolarization are the inactivation of the "test voltage gated sodium channels" and the reversal of the membrane potential (becomes positive inside), thus limiting further sodium influx.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="6">
<li>After-depolarization</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The slower fall in the rate of repolarization.</li>
<li>occurs when repolarization is 70% completed.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="7">
<li>After-hypopolarization</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Slight oversteaming in the hyperpolarizing direction, due to excess potassium efflux through the "voltage gated potassium channels", and then restoration of</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Can be used for measurement of the conduction velocity (CV) in an area. Conduction velocity = (the distance between the stimulating and recording electrodes) divided by (the latent period).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>Threshold</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The voltage at which the "test voltage gated sodium channels" open. If not reached, action potential never occurs.</li>
<li>It is usually about 15 mv less than the resting membrane potential (e.g. -75 mv when the RMP is -90 mv).</li>
</ul>
<ol start="4">
<li>Depolarization</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Due to sodium influx through the "test voltage gated sodium channels".</li>
<li>The membrane potential moves towards the equilibrium potential for sodium (+60 mv) but it does not reach it because opening of the sodium channels is short lived (the channels rapidly become inactivated and will never open again unless the membrane potential returns back to the resting level.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="5">
<li>Repolarization</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Due to potassium efflux through "voltage gated potassium channels".</li>
<li>Opening of the "voltage gated potassium channels" is slower than sodium channels; that's why potassium efflux occurs after sodium influx. Opening is also more prolonged than sodium channels and this explains the occurrence of after-hypopolarization (see below).</li>
<li>Additional factors that facilitate repolarization are the inactivation of the "test voltage gated sodium channels" and the reversal of the membrane potential (becomes positive inside), thus limiting further sodium influx.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="8">
<li>After-depolarization</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The slower fall in the rate of repolarization.</li>
<li>occurs when repolarization is 70% completed.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="7">
<li>After-hypopolarization</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Slight oversteaming in the hyperpolarizing direction, due to excess potassium efflux through the "voltage gated potassium channels", and then restoration of</li>
</ul>
<p>53
The issue of medical physiology of science</p>
<p>the membrane potential to the resting level (due to the activity of the Na/K pump).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-01cee16b.jpeg" alt="img-67.jpeg">
Fig 2.3: The action Potential</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="characteristics-of-action-potentials">Characteristics of action potentials<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#characteristics-of-action-potentials" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-all-or-none-see">1. All or none (see<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-all-or-none-see" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Sub-threshold stimuli can never generate an action potential whereas threshold and supra threshold stimuli can generate action potentials of the same magnitude (i.e. full action potential).</li>
<li>This indicates that action potentials either occur in a full form or do not occur at all (i.e. all or none).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="2-distraction-period">2. Distraction period<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-distraction-period" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Period of time during which a cell membrane is refractory to excitation, because it is already in a state of excitation.</li>
<li>During this period the "test voltage gated channels" for sodium are inactivated.</li>
<li>The refractory period is divided into: absolute and relative periods.</li>
</ul>
<p>The membrane potential to the resting level (due to the activity of the Na/K pump).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-d39987e1.jpeg" alt="img-68.jpeg">
Fig 2.4: The action Potential</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="characteristics-of-action-potentials">Characteristics of action potentials<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#characteristics-of-action-potentials" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-all-or-none-see">1. All or none (see<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-all-or-none-see" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Sub threshold stimuli can never generate an action potential whereas threshold and supra threshold stimuli can generate action potentials of the same magnitude (i.e. full action potential).</li>
<li>This indicates that action potentials either occur in a full form or do not occur at all (i.e. all or none).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="2-refraction-period">2. Refraction period<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-refraction-period" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Period of time during which a cell membrane is refractory to excitation, because it is already in a state of excitation.</li>
<li>During this period the "test voltage gated channels" for sodium are inactivated.</li>
<li>The refractory period is divided into: absolute and relative periods.</li>
</ul>
<p>The membrane potential to the resting level (due to the activity of the Na/K pump).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-1525a5d0.jpeg" alt="img-69.jpeg">
Fig 2.5: The action Potential</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="characteristics-of-action-potentials">Characteristics of action potentials<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#characteristics-of-action-potentials" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-all-or-none-see">1. All or none (see)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-all-or-none-see" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Sub-threshold stimuli can never generate an action potential whereas threshold and supra threshold stimuli can generate action potentials of the same magnitude (i.e. full action potential).</li>
<li>This indicates that action potentials either occur in a full form or do not occur at all (i.e. all or none).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="2-refraction-period">2. Refraction period<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-refraction-period" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Period of time during which a cell membrane is refractory to excitation, because it is already in a state of excitation.</li>
<li>During this period the "test voltage gated channels" for sodium are inactivated.</li>
<li>The refractory period is divided into: absolute and relative periods.</li>
</ul>
<p>The amount of reaction potential (p) = 1.00000</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Absolute refractory period:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Action potential can never be generated even with supra-firewheat stimulation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Its duration from the firing level to the end of one third of repolarization.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Relative refractory period:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Action potential can not be generated by ordinary stimulation but it can be generated by supra-firewheat stimulation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Its duration from the end of absolute refractory period to the end of repolarization (i.e. to the start of after-depolarization).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-0c3813b6.jpeg" alt="img-70.jpeg">
Fig 2.6 The refractory period</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Absolute refractory period</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Relative refractory period</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Conduction</p>
</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Action potential can be propagated (combated) through axons of neurons.</li>
<li>Conduction is an active, self-propagating process that occurs with no change in amplitude or velocity of the action potential.</li>
</ul>
<p>42</p>

<ul>
<li>
<p>Absolute refractory period</p>

<li>
<p>Action potential can never be generated even with supra-firewheat stimulation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Its duration from the firing level to the end of one third of repolarization.</p>
</li>
<li>

</li>
<li>
<p>Action potential can not be generated by ordinary stimulation but it can be generated by supra-firewheat stimulation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Its duration from the end of absolute refractory period to the end of repolarization (i.e. to the start of after-depolarization).</p>
</li>
</ul>

<p>Action potential can never be generated even with supra-firewheat stimulation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Its duration from the firing level to the end of one third of repolarization.</p>
</li>

<p>Relative refractory period</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Action potential can not be generated by ordinary stimulation but it can be generated by supra-firewheat stimulation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Its duration from the end of absolute refractory period to the end of repolarization (i.e. to the start of after-depolarization).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-be26efab.jpeg" alt="img-72.jpeg">
Fig 2.6 The refractory period</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Absolute refractory period</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Relative refractory period</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Conduction</p>
</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Action potential can be propagated (combated) through axons of neurons.</li>
<li>Conduction is an active, self-propagating process that occurs with no change in amplitude or velocity of the action potential.</li>
</ul>
<p>34</p>
<p>The State of mechanical stimulation</p>
<p>There are two types of conduction:</p>
<ul>
<li>Conduction in unmyelinated nerves (continuous conduction)</li>
<li>Conduction in myelinated nerves (satiatory conduction)
(umping of action potential from a node of flameer to another)</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 2.7: Types of electrical conduction
<img src="assets/images/image-20251216-bfb47853.jpeg" alt="img-73.jpeg">
<img src="assets/images/image-20251216-e5532f56.jpeg" alt="img-74.jpeg"></p>
<p>The velocity of conduction depends on:</p>
<ul>
<li>Degree of myelination:</li>
<li>Faster in thick myelinated + thin myelinated + un-myelinated</li>
<li>Distance between nodes of flameer,</li>
<li>Faster when the distance is increased</li>
<li>Diameter of the axon:</li>
<li>Faster when the diameter is larger</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 2.8
The sum of medical physiology  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>1</mn><mtext>st</mtext></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1^{\text{st}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7936em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7936em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">st</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  edition</p>
<p>There are two types of conduction:</p>
<ul>
<li>Conduction in unmyelinated nerves (continuous conduction)</li>
<li>Conduction in myelinated nerves (satiatory conduction)
(umping of action potential from a node of flameer to another)</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 2.7: Types of electrical conduction
<img src="assets/images/image-20251216-70985d7b.jpeg" alt="img-75.jpeg">
<img src="assets/images/image-20251216-c5d7f5ee.jpeg" alt="img-76.jpeg"></p>
<p>The velocity of conduction depends on:</p>
<ul>
<li>Degree of myelination:</li>
<li>Faster in thick myelinated + thin myelinated + un-myelinated</li>
<li>Distance between nodes of flameer,</li>
<li>Faster when the distance is increased</li>
<li>Diameter of the axon:</li>
<li>Faster when the diameter is larger</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 2.9
The sum of medical physiology  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>1</mn><mtext>st</mtext></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1^{\text{st}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7936em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7936em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">st</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  edition</p>
