<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-compound-action-potential">The compound action potential<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-compound-action-potential" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The above description of action potential refers to action potential that is recorded from a single exon. It differs from an action potential recorded from a peripheral nerve (which contains many axons).</li>
<li>The action potential that's recorded from a peripheral nerve is refers to compound action potential and it is characterized by multiple peaks.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-2-6-the-compound-action-potential">Fig 2.6: The compound action potential<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-2-6-the-compound-action-potential" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-ec1ec81b.jpeg" alt="img-85.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>It represents algebraic summation of action potentials of many axons in its nerve. The multiple peaks appear because a peripheral nerve contains different types of fibers with different sizes, thresholds and peaks.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="f-role-of-ecp-electrolyte-disturbances-on-excitability">F: role of ECP electrolyte disturbances on excitability<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#f-role-of-ecp-electrolyte-disturbances-on-excitability" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d-substances-in-sodium-ions">D. substances in sodium ions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-substances-in-sodium-ions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Have little effect on the resting membrane potential (RMP).</li>
<li>Hyponatremia decreases the amplitude of the action potential.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d-substances-in-potassium-ions">D. substances in potassium ions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-substances-in-potassium-ions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>About the resting membrane potential because potassium efflux is the main cause of the resting membrane potential.</li>
<li>By clustering causes hyperpolarization (because it allows more K efflux and therefore the resting membrane potential gets away from the threshold). [30] decreases excitability.</li>
</ul>
<p>35
The case of medical physiology: 2nd ed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-compound-action-potential">The compound action potential<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-compound-action-potential" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The above description of action potential refers to action potential that is recorded from a single exon. It differs from an action potential recorded from a peripheral nerve (which contains many axons).</li>
<li>The action potential that's recorded from a peripheral nerve is called the compound action potential and it is characterized by multiple peaks.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-2-6-the-compound-action-potential">Fig 2.6: The compound action potential<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-2-6-the-compound-action-potential" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-3cf50a1f.jpeg" alt="img-86.jpeg"></p>

<li>It represents algebraic summation of action potentials of many axons in its nerve. The multiple peaks appear because a peripheral nerve contains different types of fibers with different sizes, thresholds and peaks.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="f-role-of-ecp-electrolyte-disturbances-on-excitability">F: role of ECP electrolyte disturbances on excitability<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#f-role-of-ecp-electrolyte-disturbances-on-excitability" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d-substances-in-sodium-ions">D. substances in sodium ions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-substances-in-sodium-ions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Have little effect on the resting membrane potential (RMP).</li>

<ul>
<li>About the resting membrane potential because potassium efflux is the main cause of the resting membrane potential.</li>
<li>By clustering causes hyperpolarization (because it allows more K efflux and therefore the resting membrane potential gets away from the threshold). [30] decreases excitability.</li>
</ul>

The case of medical physiology: 2nd ed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-compound-action-potential">The compound action potential<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-compound-action-potential" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-2-6-the-compound-action-potential">Fig 2.6: The compound action potential<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-2-6-the-compound-action-potential" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="f-role-of-ecp-electrolyte-disturbances-on-excitability">F: role of ECP electrolyte disturbances on excitability<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#f-role-of-ecp-electrolyte-disturbances-on-excitability" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d-substances-in-sodium-ions">D. substances in sodium ions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-substances-in-sodium-ions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Have little effect on the resting membrane potential (RMP).</li>
<li>Hyponatremia decreases the amplitude of the action potential.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d-substances-in-potassium-ions">D. substances in potassium ions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-substances-in-potassium-ions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>About the resting membrane potential because potassium efflux is the main cause of the resting membrane potential.</li>
<li>By clustering causes hyperpolarization (because it allows more K efflux and therefore the resting membrane potential gets away from the threshold). [30] decreases excitability.</li>
</ul>
<p>36
The case of medical physiology: 2nd</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-684a6d81.jpeg" alt="img-88.jpeg">
FIG 2.9. Humanitarianism caused by excessive K efflux</p>
<ul>
<li>Mild to moderate hyperkalemia limits potassium efflux and therefore the RMP is elevated to become closer to the threshold, this increases excitability. However, severe hyperkalemia elevates the RMP to the level of the threshold and therefore it inhibits excitability (the cell can not respond to stimulation since its RMP is not below the threshold, that's why hyperkalemia prevents excitation of the heart and stops it in diastole).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-f0b96994.jpeg" alt="img-89.jpeg">
FIG 2.10. Effect of hyperkalemia on the RMP</p>
<p><strong>Disturbances in calcium ions</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Calcium ions guard the sodium leak channels, thus preventing sodium influx through these channels during the resting state.</li>
<li>In hyperkalemia sodium ions enter the cells because the leak channels are not guarded, this elevates the RMP and makes the cells more excitable (for this case, it is not possible to add sodium to the cell).</li>
</ul>
<p>Disturbances in calcium ions</p>
<ul>
<li>Calcium ions guard the sodium leak channels, thus preventing sodium influx through these channels during the resting state.</li>
<li>In hyperkalemia sodium ions enter the cells because the leak channels are not guarded, this elevates the RMP and makes the cells more excitable (for this case, it is not possible to add sodium to the cell).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-f5b84e01.jpeg" alt="img-90.jpeg"></p>
<p><strong>Disturbances in calcium ions</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Calcium ions guard the sodium leak channels, thus preventing sodium influx through these channels during the resting state.</li>
<li>In hyperkalemia sodium ions enter the cells because the leak channels are not guarded, this elevates the RMP and makes the cells more excitable (for this case, it is not possible to add sodium to the cell).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-454ab3c5.jpeg" alt="img-91.jpeg"></p>
<p><strong>Disturbances in calcium ions</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Calcium ions guard the sodium leak channels, thus preventing sodium influx through these channels during the resting state.</li>
<li>In hyperkalemia sodium ions enter the cells because the leak channels are not guarded, this elevates the RMP and makes the cells more excitable (for this case, it is not possible to add sodium to the cell).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-47828c3a.jpeg" alt="img-92.jpeg"></p>
<p><strong>Disturbances in calcium ions</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Calcium ions guard the sodium leak channels, thus preventing sodium influx through these channels during the resting state.</li>
<li>In hyperkalemia sodium ions enter the cells because the leak channels are not guarded, this elevates the RMP and makes the cells more excitable (for this case, it is not possible to add sodium to the cell).</li>
</ul>
<p>27</p>
<p>reason hyponatraemia is characterized by high excitability in neuromuscular junctions resulting in involuntary contraction of some muscles (= this is known as tetany).</p>
<ul>
<li>Hyponatraemia has an opposite effect; it prevents influx of sodium ions through their leak channels; therefore, it stabilizes cell membranes and decreases excitability.</li>
<li>Severe hyponatraemia may interfere with the normal function of nerves and may result in coma.</li>
<li>Hypernatremia increases contractility of cardiac muscle but not skeletal muscle; that's because calcium ions in ECF enter cardiac muscle cells and increase contraction (they do not enter skeletal muscle cells). Severe hypernatremia stops the heart in systole.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="action-potential-of-the-cardiac-muscle">Action potential of the cardiac muscle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#action-potential-of-the-cardiac-muscle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Fig.2.11:</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-6169bd9f.jpeg" alt="img-93.jpeg"></p>
<p>There are two types of muscle in the heart:</p>
<ul>
<li>The cardiac muscle proper whose AP is characterized by the plateau phase (due to calcium influx). The plateau prolongs the refractory period.</li>
<li>The conductive system, whose AP is characterized by the prepotential (unstable resting membrane potential, mainly due to slow potassium efflux).</li>
</ul>
<p>The result of cardiac phthisis (Fig.2.11)</p>
<p>reason hyponatraemia is characterized by high excitability in neuromuscular junctions resulting in involuntary contraction of some muscles (= this is known as tetany).</p>
<ul>
<li>Hypernatremia has an opposite effect; it prevents influx of sodium ions through their leak channels; therefore, it stabilizes cell membranes and decreases excitability.</li>
<li>Severe hypernatremia may interfere with the normal function of nerves and may result in coma.</li>
<li>Hypernatremia increases contractility of cardiac muscle but not skeletal muscle; that's because calcium ions in ECF enter cardiac muscle cells and increase contraction (they do not enter skeletal muscle cells). Severe hypernatremia stops the heart in systole.</li>
</ul>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="action-potential-of-the-cardiac-muscle">Action potential of the cardiac muscle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#action-potential-of-the-cardiac-muscle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<p>12
The text of standard photocopies: 1st edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sievve">SIEVVE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sievve" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Review are distributed throughout the body to form the nervous system. The nervous system is subdivided into:</li>
<li>Central nervous system (CNS + the brain and the spinal cord).</li>
<li>Peripheral nervous system (PNS + the spinal and cranial nerves).</li>
<li>Each nerve consists of many nerve cells (neurons).</li>
<li>A neuron is the main functional cell in the nervous system.</li>
<li>It consists of:</li>
<li>Cell body (or soma)</li>
<li>Dendrites</li>
<li>Axon</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-2f6d3a75.jpeg" alt="img-96.jpeg">
Fig 2.12: The neuron</p>
<p>There are about 100 billion neurons in the CNS and about 10-50 times the number glial cell (neuroglia).</p>
<ul>
<li>Neuroglia (in non-excitable cells) are 3 types in the CNS:</li>
<li>Microglia</li>
<li>Phagocytic cells in the brain (resemble tissue macrophages)</li>
<li>Astrocytes (in microglia)</li>
<li>Provide a supportive matrix around the neurons</li>
<li>From part of the blood brain barrier (BBB)</li>
<li>Maintain stable ECF concentration of ions (by taking up K⁺)</li>
<li>Two types: fibrous astrocytes (in the white matter) and protoplasmic astrocytes (in the grey matter)</li>
</ul>
<p>13
The text of standard photocopies: 1st edition</p>

<p>60
The work of medical physiology of upper</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Oligodendrocytes in mesangial:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Form myelin sheath around axons in the CNS</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>There is one type of glia in the peripheral nervous system (PNS):</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Schwann cells</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The only glial cells in peripheral nervous system</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Form myelin sheath around axons in peripheral nervous system</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Each cell wraps its membrane around axons up to 100 times to form a myelin sheath</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-b4c7b5be.jpeg" alt="img-99.jpeg">
Fig.2.12: Myelination</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Oligodendrocytes in mesangial:</p>

<li>
<p>Form myelin sheath around axons in the CNS</p>

<p>There is one type of glia in the peripheral nervous system (PNS):</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Schwann cells</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The only glial cells in peripheral nervous system</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Form myelin sheath around axons in peripheral nervous system</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Each cell wraps its membrane around axons up to 100 times to form a myelin sheath</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-7acade1e.jpeg" alt="img-100.jpeg">
Types of nerve fibers</p>
<ul>
<li>Nerve fibers are divided into 3 groups (A, B and C).</li>
<li>These groups differ in the axon size and degree of myelination.</li>
<li>The A group is subdivided into: (Au, Aβ, Ay and Aδ).</li>
</ul>
<p>Group A</p>
<ul>
<li>Thick myelinated = The fastest (especially the Au type)</li>
<li>Has the largest diameter</li>
<li>Carries touch, proprioception and motor impulses</li>
<li>Most susceptible to pressure</li>
<li>Least susceptible to local anesthetics, that's why touch sensation, which is carried by type Aβ fibers, is not completely depressed by local anesthetics</li>
</ul>
<p>61
The work of medical physiology of upper</p>
<p>41
The core of method play a design of 41 criteria</p>
<ul>
<li>Combustion velocity of type A fibers:</li>
<li>Au = 70-120 m/s</li>
<li>Aβ = 90-70 m/s</li>
<li>Au = 15-50 m/s</li>
<li>Aβ = 12-30 m/s</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Group B</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Thin myelinated</li>
<li>Found in the preganglionic autonomic neurons</li>
<li>Most susceptible to hypoxia than to pressure or local anesthetics</li>
<li>Combustion velocity = 0-15 m/s</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Group C</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Un-myelinated</li>
<li>Mainly carries pain and cold sensations</li>
<li>Also found in the postganglionic sympathetic neurons</li>
<li>Most susceptible to local anesthetics (that's why local anesthetics depress pain sensation which is carried through type C fibers)</li>
<li>Least susceptible to hypoxia and pressure</li>
<li>Combustion velocity = 0.5-2 m/s</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Important note</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>There is another method of nerve fiber classification (i.e., Ib, II, III and IV) However, it is rather confusing.</li>
<li>Here is, Ib, II and III are equivalent to the subdivisions of group A fibers whereas IV is equivalent to type C fibers.</li>
<li>This classification is used to describe afferents of the muscle spindle &amp; the Golgi tendon organ (see the motor system).</li>
</ul>
<p>42
The core of method play a design of 41 criteria</p>

<p>42
The state of Medical Education</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="synaptic-transmission">SYNAPTIC TRANSMISSION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#synaptic-transmission" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-synapse">THE SYNAPSE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-synapse" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>It is a junction between two neurons. It allows transmission of electrical impulses from one neuron to another.</li>
<li>The transmission is called "chemical transmission" because a chemical substance "a neurotransmitter" is released by the first neuron (the pre-synaptic neuron) to bind receptors in the second one (the post-synaptic neuron). However, direct electrical transmission can occur through special synapses.</li>
<li>Unlike electrical transmission through the axons, chemical transmission is an directional (i.e. allows conduction in one way only, from the pre-synaptic neuron to the post-synaptic neuron).</li>
<li>The total number of synapses in the CNS is very large, a single axon may divide to form over 2000 synaptic endings.</li>
<li>Most synapses occur between the axon terminals of the pre-synaptic neuron and the cell body or dendrites of the post-synaptic neuron (extramural and sub-dendritic connections). However, other types of connection may occur (e.g. via axonal).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-a3ad61fb.jpeg" alt="img-101.jpeg">
Fig 2.14: Synapses</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="synaptic-transmission">SYNAPTIC TRANSMISSION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#synaptic-transmission" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-synapse">THE SYNAPSE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-synapse" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is a junction between two neurons. It allows transmission of electrical impulses from one neuron to another.</p>
<ul>
<li>The transmission is called "chemical transmission" because a chemical substance "a neurotransmitter" is released by the first neuron (the pre-synaptic neuron) to bind receptors in the second one (the post-synaptic neuron). However, direct electrical transmission can occur through special synapses.</li>
<li>Unlike electrical transmission through the axons, chemical transmission is an directional (i.e. allows conduction in one way only, from the pre-synaptic neuron to the post-synaptic neuron).</li>
<li>The total number of synapses in the CNS is very large; a single axon may divide to form over 2000 synaptic endings.</li>
<li>Most synapses occur between the axon terminals of the pre-synaptic neuron and the cell body or dendrites of the post-synaptic neuron (extramural and sub-dendritic connections). However, other types of connection may occur (e.g. via axonal).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-eba6f01b.jpeg" alt="img-102.jpeg">
Fig 2.15: Synapses</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="synaptic-transmission">SYNAPTIC TRANSMISSION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#synaptic-transmission" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-synapse">THE SYNAPSE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-synapse" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>It is a junction between two neurons. It allows transmission of electrical impulses from one neuron to another.</li>
<li>The transmission is called "chemical transmission" because a chemical substance "a neurotransmitter" is released by the first neuron (the pre-synaptic neuron) to bind receptors in the second one (the post-synaptic neuron). However, direct electrical transmission can occur through special synapses.</li>
<li>Unlike electrical transmission through the axons, chemical transmission is an directional (i.e. allows conduction in one way only, from the pre-synaptic neuron to the post-synaptic neuron).</li>
<li>The total number of synapses in the CNS is very large; a single axon may divide to form over 7000 synaptic endings.</li>
<li>Most synapses occur between the axon terminals of the pre-synaptic neuron and the cell body or dendrites of the post-synaptic neuron (extramural and sub-dendritic connections). However, other types of connection may occur (e.g. via axonal).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-c99bfcee.jpeg" alt="img-103.jpeg">
Fig 2.14: Synapses</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id=""><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"></span></h1></div>
<p>General structure of the synapse</p>
<p>Fig 2.12:</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-217559c8.jpeg" alt="img-104.jpeg"></p>
<p>The presynaptic neuron:</p>
<ul>
<li>Releases a neurotransmitter (NT) through the presynaptic membrane.</li>
<li>The NT is synthesized in the cell body, packed into vesicles in the Golgi apparatus and then transported through the axon to be stored at the terminal end of the axon.</li>
<li>The terminal end of the axon is slightly dilated for storage of the NT. It is called the synaptic knob or button.</li>
</ul>
<p>The postsynaptic neuron:</p>
<ul>
<li>Contains receptors for the NT.</li>
<li>The receptors are located on the postsynaptic membrane.</li>
</ul>
<p>The synaptic cleft:</p>
<ul>
<li>The area that separates the pre and post synaptic neurons.</li>
<li>It is about 20-40 nm wide.</li>
<li>The NT has to cross this area to bind its receptors on the postsynaptic membrane.</li>
</ul>
<p>43</p>
<p>General structure of the synapse</p>
<p>Fig 2.13:</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-25dfd004.jpeg" alt="img-105.jpeg"></p>
<p>The presynaptic neuron:</p>
<ul>
<li>Releases a neurotransmitter (NT) through the presynaptic membrane.</li>
<li>The NT is synthesized in the cell body, packed into vesicles in the Golgi apparatus and then transported through the axon to be stored at the terminal end of the axon.</li>
<li>The terminal end of the axon is slightly dilated for storage of the NT. It is called the synaptic knob or button.</li>
</ul>
<p>The postsynaptic neuron:</p>
<ul>
<li>Contains receptors for the NT.</li>
<li>The receptors are located on the postsynaptic membrane.</li>
</ul>
<p>The synaptic cleft:</p>
<ul>
<li>The area that separates the pre and post synaptic neurons.</li>
<li>It is about 20-40 nm wide.</li>
<li>The NT has to cross this area to bind its receptors on the postsynaptic membrane.</li>
</ul>
<p>43</p>
<p>General structure of the synapse</p>
<p>Fig 2.13:</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-dc05ed36.jpeg" alt="img-106.jpeg"></p>
<p>The presynaptic neuron:</p>
<ul>
<li>Releases a neurotransmitter (NT) through the presynaptic membrane.</li>
<li>The NT is synthesized in the cell body, packed into vesicles in the Golgi apparatus and then transported through the axon to be stored at the terminal end of the axon.</li>
<li>The terminal end of the axon is slightly dilated for storage of the NT. It is called the synaptic knob or button.</li>
</ul>
<p>The postsynaptic neuron:</p>
<ul>
<li>Contains receptors for the NT.</li>
<li>The receptors are located on the postsynaptic membrane.</li>
</ul>
<p>The synaptic cleft:</p>
<ul>
<li>The area that separates the pre and post synaptic neurons.</li>
<li>It is about 20-40 nm wide.</li>
<li>The NT has to cross this area to bind its receptors on the postsynaptic membrane.</li>
</ul>
<p>43</p>
<p>General structure of the synapse</p>
<p>It may contain an enzyme for hydrolysis of the NT and therefore terminate its action (e.g. acetylcholine esterase enzyme for hydrolysis of acetylcholine).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps-of-neurotransmitter-release-to-the-synaptic-cleft">Steps of neurotransmitter release to the synaptic cleft<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps-of-neurotransmitter-release-to-the-synaptic-cleft" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Arrival of the action potential to the terminal end of the axon</li>
<li>Opening of voltage-gated Ca<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{2+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> channels, allowing Ca<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{2+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> influx</li>
<li>Ca<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{2+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> stimulates release of the neurotransmitter (NT) from the vesicles by exocytosis (it increases movement of the vesicles to fuse with the presynaptic membrane and facilitates the process of exocytosis)</li>
<li>The NT within the vesicles is released to the synaptic cleft</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Note: Ca<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{2+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>/Na<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> antiprot."</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fate-of-the-neurotransmitter-at-the-synaptic-cleft">Fate of the neurotransmitter at the synaptic cleft<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fate-of-the-neurotransmitter-at-the-synaptic-cleft" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="8">
<li>N.untransmitters at the synaptic cleft may</li>
<li>Combine with receptors on the post-synaptic membrane (to exert their effects)</li>
<li>Be hydrolyzed by an enzyme in the synaptic cleft</li>
<li>Return back to the synaptic knob by endocytosis</li>
<li>Diffuse to the plasma (where it is catabolized there or in other tissues)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-2-10-fate-of-neurotransmitters-at-the-synapses">Fig 2.10. Fate of neurotransmitters at the synapses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-2-10-fate-of-neurotransmitters-at-the-synapses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-527d6519.jpeg" alt="img-107.jpeg">
54</p>
<p>It may contain an enzyme for hydrolysis of the NT and therefore terminates its action (e.g. acetylcholine esterase enzyme for hydrolysis of acetylcholine).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps-of-neurotransmitter-release-to-the-synaptic-cleft">Steps of neurotransmitter release to the synaptic cleft<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps-of-neurotransmitter-release-to-the-synaptic-cleft" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Arrival of the action potential to the terminal end of the axon</li>
<li>Opening of voltage-gated Ca<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{2+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> channels, allowing Ca<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{2+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> influx</li>
<li>Ca<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{2+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> stimulates release of the neurotransmitter (NT) from the vesicles by exocytosis (it increases movement of the vesicles to fuse with the presynaptic membrane and facilitates the process of exocytosis)</li>
<li>The NT within the vesicles is released to the synaptic cleft</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Note: Ca<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{2+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; </ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fate-of-the-neurotransmitter-at-the-synaptic-cleft">Fate of the neurotransmitter at the synaptic cleft<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fate-of-the-neurotransmitter-at-the-synaptic-cleft" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="8">
<li>N.untransmitters at the synaptic cleft may</li>
<li>Combine with receptors on the post-synaptic membrane (to exert their effects)</li>
<li>Be hydrolyzed by an enzyme in the synaptic cleft</li>
<li>Return back to the synaptic knob by endocytosis</li>
<li>Diffuse to the plasma (where it is catabolized there or in other tissues)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-2-10-fate-of-neurotransmitters-at-the-synapses">Fig 2.10. Fate of neurotransmitters at the synapses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-2-10-fate-of-neurotransmitters-at-the-synapses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-0bd37de5.jpeg" alt="img-108.jpeg">
51</p>
<p>It may contain an enzyme for hydrolysis of the NT and therefore terminates its action (e.g. acetylcholine esterase enzyme for hydrolysis of acetylcholine).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps-of-neurotransmitter-release-to-the-synaptic-cleft">Steps of neurotransmitter release to the synaptic cleft<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps-of-neurotransmitter-release-to-the-synaptic-cleft" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Arrival of the action potential to the terminal end of the axon</li>
<li>Opening of voltage-gated Ca<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{2+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> channels, allowing Ca<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{2+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> influx</li>
<li>Ca<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{2+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> stimulates release of the neurotransmitter (NT) from the vesicles by exocytosis (it increases movement of the vesicles to fuse with the presynaptic membrane and facilitates the process of exocytosis)</li>
<li>The NT within the vesicles is released to the synaptic cleft</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Note: Ca<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{2+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is then removed from the knob by "Ca<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{2+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>/Na<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> antiprot."</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fate-of-the-neurotransmitter-at-the-synaptic-cleft">Fate of the neurotransmitter at the synaptic cleft<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fate-of-the-neurotransmitter-at-the-synaptic-cleft" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="8">
<li>N.untransmitters at the synaptic cleft may</li>
<li>Combine with receptors on the post-synaptic membrane (to exert their effects)</li>
<li>Be hydrolyzed by an enzyme in the synaptic cleft</li>
<li>Return back to the synaptic knob by endocytosis</li>
<li>Diffuse to the plasma (where it is catabolized there or in other tissues)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-2-10-fate-of-neurotransmitters-at-the-synapses">Fig 2.10. Fate of neurotransmitters at the synapses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-2-10-fate-of-neurotransmitters-at-the-synapses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-d1c82e3a.jpeg" alt="img-109.jpeg">
58</p>
<p>42
The text of contract proceedings' 2nd edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="issues-to-remember">Issues to remember:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#issues-to-remember" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Not all of these options are applicable for all types of neurotransmitters.</li>
<li>For example, acetylcholine is hydrolysed in the cleft by acetylcholine-esterase into acetate and choline. Therefore it does not return back to the synaptic knob by endocytosis; however, its metabolite choline returns back.</li>
<li>Another example: noradrenaline is not hydrolysed in the cleft. Therefore it returns back to the synaptic knob by endocytosis and packed again into vesicles to be released later (recycling).</li>
<li>Because it is not hydrolysed in the cleft, the amount of noradrenaline that diffuses to plasma is higher than that of acetylcholine.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="electrical-events-in-the-postsynaptic-neuron">ELECTRICAL EVENTS IN THE POSTSYNAPTIC NEURON<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#electrical-events-in-the-postsynaptic-neuron" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>When a neurotransmitter combines with its specific receptor, it results in opening or closure of some "figure" gated channels" on the postsynaptic membrane.</li>
<li>This changes the permeability of the postsynaptic membrane to specific ions and results in a postsynaptic potential.</li>
<li>The postsynaptic potential is a local potential that can be excitatory or inhibitory (depending on which type of ion channels is opened).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="excitatory-post-synaptic-potential-epsp">Excitatory post synaptic potential (EPSP):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#excitatory-post-synaptic-potential-epsp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This is a depolarizing potential that increases excitability of the postsynaptic neuron.</li>
<li>It does not cause a response because it does not reach the threshold.</li>
<li>It is caused by an excitatory neurotransmitter that opens:</li>
<li>sodium channels causing sodium influx</li>
<li>or calcium channels causing calcium influx</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inhibitory-post-synaptic-potential-ipsp">Inhibitory post synaptic potential (iPSP):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inhibitory-post-synaptic-potential-ipsp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This is a hyperpolarizing potential that decreases excitability of the postsynaptic neuron.</li>
</ul>
<p>43
The text of contract proceedings' 2nd edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="issues-to-remember">Issues to remember:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#issues-to-remember" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>For example, acetylcholine is hydrolysed in the cleft by acetylcholine-esterase into acetate and choline. Therefore it does not return back to the synaptic knob by endocytosis; however, its metabolite choline returns back.</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="electrical-events-in-the-postsynaptic-neuron">ELECTRICAL EVENTS IN THE POSTSYNAPTIC NEURON<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#electrical-events-in-the-postsynaptic-neuron" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>The postsynaptic potential is a local potential that can be excitatory or inhibitory (depending on which type of ion channels is opened).</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="excitatory-post-synaptic-potential-epsp">Excitatory post synaptic potential (EPSP):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#excitatory-post-synaptic-potential-epsp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<li>sodium channels causing sodium influx</li>
<li>or calcium channels causing calcium influx</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inhibitory-post-synaptic-potential-ipsp">Inhibitory post synaptic potential (iPSP):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inhibitory-post-synaptic-potential-ipsp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="excitatory-post-synaptic-potential-epsp">Excitatory post synaptic potential (EPSP):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#excitatory-post-synaptic-potential-epsp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<li>It is caused by an excitatory neurotransmitter that opens:</li>
<li>sodium channels causing sodium influx</li>
<li>or calcium channels causing calcium influx</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inhibitory-post-synaptic-potential-ipsp">Inhibitory post synaptic potential (iPSP):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inhibitory-post-synaptic-potential-ipsp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This is a hyperpolarizing potential that decreases excitability of the postsynaptic neuron.</li>
</ul>
<p>45
The text of contract proceedings' 2nd edition</p>
<ul>
<li>It is caused by an inhibitory neurotransmitter that suggests, in</li>
<li>chloride channels causing potassium efflux or chloride influx depending</li>
<li>or causes sodium or calcium channels preventing their influx.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="summation-of-local-potentials">Summation of local potentials:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#summation-of-local-potentials" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>For an EPSP to reach a threshold and cause a response, it should sum up</li>
<li>with other EPS potentials.</li>
<li>There are two types of summation: spatial and temporal.</li>
</ul>
<p>Spatial summation: Occurs when multiple EPSPs arrive simultaneously at its
same time, on the post-synaptic neuron. The potentials when added together
reach the threshold and produce an action potential.</p>
<p>Temporal summation: Occurs when a single synaptic knob is simulated
repeatedly to produce successive EPSPs. These when added together reach its
threshold and produce an action potential.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-2-17-summation-of-local-potentials">Fig 2.17: Summation of local potentials<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-2-17-summation-of-local-potentials" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-ebe46990.jpeg" alt="img-110.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="action-potential-in-the-post-synaptic-neuron">Action potential in the post-synaptic neuron<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#action-potential-in-the-post-synaptic-neuron" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Summation of several EPSPs generates an action potential in the post-synaptic
neuron.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The action potential starts in the generator zone which is situated at the origin
of the axon (axon hillock).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is caused by an inhibitory neurotransmitter that suggests</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>chloride channels causing potassium efflux or chloride influx depending</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>or causes sodium or calcium channels preventing their influx.</p>
</li>
</ul>

<p>The use of medical procedures</p>

<p>its threshold is more near to the RMP (-59 mV)</p>
</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inhibition-and-facilitation-at-synapses">Inhibition and facilitation at synapses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inhibition-and-facilitation-at-synapses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="direct-inhibition">Direct inhibition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#direct-inhibition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs directly by releasing an inhibitory NT from a presynaptic neuron into a postsynaptic neuron</li>
<li>This direct inhibition on the postsynaptic neuron is called postsynaptic inhibition.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-d7534aa8.jpeg" alt="img-113.jpeg">
Fig 2.10: Direct inhibition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="indirect-inhibition">Indirect inhibition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#indirect-inhibition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs indirectly on the neuron</li>
<li>Has many forms for example:</li>
<li>it follows a previous discharge on the postsynaptic neuron in here the already excited postsynaptic cell is in a refractory period or in after-hypopolarization (Periods of low excitability)</li>
<li>it occurs in a postsynaptic neuron if the release of the excitatory NT coming from its presynaptic neuron is prevented by direct inhibition from another neuron (this is known as presynaptic inhibition)</li>
</ul>
<p>47</p>
<p>The ratio of electrical phosphates: 10⁻⁴ release</p>
<ul>
<li>It is more excitable than the rest of the soon because:</li>
<li>it contains higher number of voltage-gated Na⁺ channels</li>
<li>its threshold is more near to the RMP (-69 mV)</li>
</ul>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="direct-inhibition">Direct inhibition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#direct-inhibition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="indirect-inhibition">Indirect inhibition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#indirect-inhibition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>

<li>it occurs in a postsynaptic neuron if the release of the excitatory NT coming from its presynaptic neuron is prevented by direct inhibition from another neuron (this is known as presynaptic inhibition)</li>
</ul>

<li>It is more excitable than the rest of the soon because:</li>
<li>it contains higher number of voltage-gated Na⁺ channels</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="direct-inhibition">Direct inhibition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#direct-inhibition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="indirect-inhibition">Indirect inhibition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#indirect-inhibition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
