<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="properties-of-synapses">Properties of synapses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#properties-of-synapses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-transmission-is-uni-directional">a- Transmission is uni-directional<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-transmission-is-uni-directional" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>From the presynaptic neuron to the postsynaptic neuron.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-synaptic-delay">b- Synaptic delay<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-synaptic-delay" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The minimum time required for chemical conduction from a synaptic knob to its postsynaptic neuron is a bout 0.5 ms.</li>
<li>Measurement of synaptic delay within the CNS gives information about the number of synapses in a pathway. For example if the delay is about 1.2 ms, the number of synapses is probably two.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-synaptic-fatigue">c- Synaptic fatigue<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-synaptic-fatigue" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Failure or decrease in frequency of conduction in a synapse following repetitive stimulation.</li>
<li>Due to exhaustion of the NT (release of all vesicles at the synaptic knob) or inactivation of the receptors at the postsynaptic membrane.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d-post-atomic-facilitation">d- Post-atomic facilitation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-post-atomic-facilitation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Increased frequency of conduction in a synapse following repeated stimulation.</li>
<li>Caused by increased availability of calcium in the synaptic knob due to repeated stimulation.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="e-convergence-and-divergence">e- Convergence and divergence<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-convergence-and-divergence" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Most of the inputs to the postsynaptic neurons are multiple (convergence).</li>
<li>Most of the outputs from the presynaptic neurons are multiple (divergence).</li>
</ul>
<p>18</p>
<p>The term of method (d) is a single of a given</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-afab78d5.jpeg" alt="img-117.jpeg">
FIG 2.19: Indirect inhibition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="properties-of-synapses">Properties of synapses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#properties-of-synapses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-transmission-is-uni-directional">a- Transmission is uni-directional<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-transmission-is-uni-directional" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>From the presynaptic neuron to the postsynaptic neuron.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-synaptic-delay">b- Synaptic delay<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-synaptic-delay" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The minimum time required for chemical conduction from a synaptic knob to its postsynaptic neuron is a bout 0.5 ms.</li>
<li>Measurement of synaptic delay within the CNS gives information about the number of synapses in a pathway. For example if the delay is about 1.2 ms, the number of synapses is probably two.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-synaptic-fatigue">c- Synaptic fatigue<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-synaptic-fatigue" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Failure or decrease in frequency of conduction in a synapse following repetitive stimulation.</li>
<li>Due to exhaustion of the NT (release of all vesicles at the synaptic knob) or inactivation of the receptors at the postsynaptic membrane.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d-post-atomic-facilitation">d- Post-atomic facilitation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-post-atomic-facilitation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Increased frequency of conduction in a synapse following repeated stimulation.</li>
<li>Caused by increased availability of calcium in the synaptic knob due to repeated stimulation.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="e-convergence-and-divergence">e- Convergence and divergence<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-convergence-and-divergence" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Most of the inputs to the postsynaptic neurons are multiple (convergence).</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="properties-of-synapses">Properties of synapses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#properties-of-synapses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-synaptic-fatigue">c- Synaptic fatigue<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-synaptic-fatigue" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d-post-atomic-facilitation">d- Post-atomic facilitation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d-post-atomic-facilitation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="e-convergence-and-divergence">e- Convergence and divergence<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e-convergence-and-divergence" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Most of the inputs to the postsynaptic neurons are multiple (convergence).</li>
<li>Most of the outputs from the presynaptic neurons are multiple (divergence).</li>
</ul>
<p>18</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-6c314af8.jpeg" alt="img-119.jpeg">
Fig.2.20: Convergence and divergence</p>
<p>The Neuromuscular junction (NML):</p>
<ul>
<li>Special type of synapse (between a neuron and a muscle cell).</li>
<li>The muscle cell membrane that receives the terminal end of the neuron is known as the motor end plate. It is characterized by multiple integrations (protonal folds) that increase its surface area.</li>
<li>Transmission through the NML is similar to chemical transmission through other synapses.</li>
<li>The neurotransmitter is acetylcholine and the receptors are nicotinic.</li>
<li>The local potential produced by binding of acetylcholine to its nicotinic receptors at the NML is called the end plate potential.</li>
<li>The end plate potential is always excitatory (caused by sodium influx) and it is regularly capable of generating an action potential (the high amount of acetylcholine released in the cell is 10 times sufficient for generation of an action potential).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-24078895.jpeg" alt="img-120.jpeg">
Fig.2.21: The neuromuscular junction</p>
<p>The role of medical physiology 17 (2004)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-e482adb9.jpeg" alt="img-121.jpeg">
Fig.2.20: Convergence and divergence</p>
<p>The Neuromuscular junction (NML):</p>
<ul>
<li>Special type of synapse (between a neuron and a muscle cell).</li>
<li>The muscle cell membrane that receives the terminal end of the neuron is known as the motor end plate. It is characterized by multiple integrations (protonal folds) that increase its surface area.</li>
<li>Transmission through the NML is similar to chemical transmission through other synapses.</li>
<li>The neurotransmitter is acetylcholine and the receptors are nicotinic.</li>
<li>The local potential produced by binding of acetylcholine to its nicotinic receptors at the NML is called the end plate potential.</li>
<li>The end plate potential is always excitatory (caused by sodium influx) and it is regularly capable of generating an action potential (the high amount of acetylcholine released in the cell is 10 times sufficient for generation of an action potential).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-ce8c780a.jpeg" alt="img-122.jpeg">
Fig.2.21: The neuromuscular junction</p>
<p>The role of endoscopy biology 17 (2004)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-f5ff89c4.jpeg" alt="img-123.jpeg">
Fig.2.20: Convergence and divergence</p>
<p>The Neuromuscular junction (NML):</p>
<ul>
<li>Special type of synapse (between a neuron and a muscle cell).</li>
<li>The muscle cell membrane that receives the terminal end of the neuron is known as the motor end plate. It is characterized by multiple integrations (protonal folds) that increase its surface area.</li>
<li>Transmission through the NML is similar to chemical transmission through other synapses.</li>
<li>The neurotransmitter is acetylcholine and the receptors are nicotinic.</li>
<li>The local potential produced by binding of acetylcholine to its nicotinic receptors at the NML is called the end plate potential.</li>
<li>The end plate potential is always excitatory (caused by sodium influx) and it is regularly capable of generating an action potential (the high amount of acetylcholine released in the cell is 10 times sufficient for generation of an action potential).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-d7a9ce3c.jpeg" alt="img-124.jpeg">
Fig.2.21: The neuromuscular junction</p>
<p>70
The issue of medical physiology 17th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="factors-affecting-neuromuscular-transmission">Factors affecting neuromuscular transmission<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#factors-affecting-neuromuscular-transmission" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Autoimmune destruction of acetylcholine receptors at the NMJ (= Myasthenia gravis) characterized by weak skeletal muscles.</li>
<li>Autoimmune destruction of calcium channels at the synaptic knob of the NMJ (= Lambert-Eaton syndrome) similar to Myasthenia but unlike it, the weakness of skeletal muscles is improved by repeated contractions, due to increased Ca++ level in the knob.</li>
<li>Weakness of acetylcholine receptors (e.g. curare and succinylcholine) cause paralysis of skeletal muscles.</li>
<li>Snake venoms: block acetylcholine receptors causing paralysis.</li>
<li>Organophosphorus compounds (OPC e.g. parathion) &amp; nerve agents (e.g. Sarin, Tatum and Viti): inhibit acetylcholinesterase to allow acetylcholine to act for prolonged periods in both nicotinic receptors (causing fasciculations, tachycardia &amp; mythexia) and muscarinic receptors (causing bradycardia, bronchospasm, salivation, lacrimation, diarrhea and vomiting). OPC are used as insecticides whereas nerve agents are military weapons (e.g. nerve gas).</li>
<li>Botulinum toxin released by bacteria (Clostridium botulinum): Prevents release of acetylcholine from neurons causing paralysis.</li>
</ul>
<p>Table 2.1: Diseases/Factors affecting neuromuscular transmission</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Disease/Factor</th><th>Effect</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Myasthenia gravis</td><td>Autoimmune destruction of acetylcholine receptors at the NMJ</td></tr><tr><td>Lambert-Eaton syndrome</td><td>Autoimmune destruction of calcium channels at the synaptic knob of the NMJ</td></tr><tr><td>Curare</td><td>Competitive blocker for nicotinic receptors at NMJ</td></tr><tr><td>Succinylcholine</td><td>Degenerating blocker for nicotinic receptors at NMJ</td></tr><tr><td>Snake venoms</td><td>Block acetylcholine receptors</td></tr><tr><td>Parathion</td><td>inhibit acetylcholinesterase to allow acetylcholine to act for prolonged periods</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>71
The issue of medical physiology 17th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="factors-affecting-neuromuscular-transmission">Factors affecting neuromuscular transmission<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#factors-affecting-neuromuscular-transmission" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Autoimmune destruction of acetylcholine receptors at the NMJ (= Myasthenia gravis) characterized by weak skeletal muscles.</li>
<li>Autoimmune destruction of calcium channels at the synaptic knob of the NMJ (= Lambert-Eaton syndrome) similar to Myasthenia but unlike it, the weakness of skeletal muscles is improved by repeated contractions, due to increased Ca++ level in the knob.</li>
<li>Weakness of acetylcholine receptors (e.g. curare and succinylcholine) cause paralysis of skeletal muscles.</li>
<li>Snake venoms: block acetylcholine receptors causing paralysis.</li>
<li>Organophosphorus compounds (OPC e.g. parathion) &amp; nerve agents (e.g. Sarin, Tatum and Viti): inhibit acetylcholinesterase to allow acetylcholine to act for prolonged periods in both nicotinic receptors (causing fasciculations, tachycardia &amp; mythexia) and muscarinic receptors (causing bradycardia, bronchospasm, salivation, lacrimation, diarrhea and vomiting). OPC are used as insecticides whereas nerve agents are military weapons (e.g. nerve gas).</li>
<li>Botulinum toxin released by bacteria (Clostridium botulinum): Prevents release of acetylcholine from neurons causing paralysis.</li>
</ul>
