<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="muscle">MUSCLE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#muscle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-muscle">Types of muscle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-muscle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>There are 3 types of muscle: skeletal, cardiac and smooth.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Skeletal muscle</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>-Bilateral</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Under voluntary control (somatic nervous system)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Has no anatomical connection between fibers</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Does not contract in the absence of external stimulation</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Fig 5.22:</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-08ba03ea.jpeg" alt="img-125.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Cardiac muscle</strong></li>
<li>-Bilateral</li>
<li>Under involuntary control (autonomic nervous system)</li>
<li>There are connections between fibers (gap junctions and intercalated dies)</li>
<li>Contracts rhythmically in the absence of external stimulation</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Fig 5.23:</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-5c5c7eb6.jpeg" alt="img-126.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Smooth muscle</strong></li>
<li>-Non-skeletal</li>
<li>Under involuntary control (autonomic nervous system)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="muscle">MUSCLE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#muscle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-muscle">Types of muscle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-muscle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>There are 3 types of muscle: skeletal, cardiac and smooth.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Skeletal muscle</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>-Bilateral</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Under voluntary control (somatic nervous system)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Has no anatomical connection between fibers</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Does not contract in the absence of external stimulation</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Fig 5.22:</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-d880ae53.jpeg" alt="img-127.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Cardiac muscle</strong></li>
<li>-Bilateral</li>
<li>Under involuntary control (autonomic nervous system)</li>
<li>There are connections between fibers (gap junctions and intercalated dies)</li>
<li>Contracts rhythmically in the absence of external stimulation</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Fig 5.23:</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-2447133f.jpeg" alt="img-128.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Smooth muscle</strong></li>
<li>Non-skeletal</li>
<li>Under involuntary control (autonomic nervous system)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="muscle">MUSCLE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#muscle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-muscle">Types of muscle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-muscle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>There are 3 types of muscle: skeletal, cardiac and smooth.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Skeletal muscle</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>-Bilateral</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Under voluntary control (somatic nervous system)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Has no anatomical connection between fibers</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Does not contract in the absence of external stimulation</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Fig 5.22:</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-077bad38.jpeg" alt="img-129.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Cardiac muscle</strong></li>
<li>-Bilateral</li>
<li>Under involuntary control (autonomic nervous system)</li>
<li>There are connections between fibers (gap junctions and intercalated dies)</li>
<li>Contracts rhythmically in the absence of external stimulation</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Fig 5.23:</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-dc5aa98d.jpeg" alt="img-130.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Smooth muscle</strong></li>
<li>Non-skeletal</li>
<li>Under involuntary control (autonomic nervous system)</li>
</ul>
<p>The text of the document is too faded to be accurately transcribed.</p>
<ul>
<li>Connections between fibers may be present (e.g. smooth muscle in viscera) or absent (e.g. smooth muscle in the eye).</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig.2.24.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-dce79a06.jpeg" alt="img-131.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="structure-of-skeletal-muscle">Structure of skeletal muscle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure-of-skeletal-muscle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Each muscle consists of bundles of fibers</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig.2.25.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-948cba13.jpeg" alt="img-132.jpeg"></p>
<p>Each fiber is a single cell, composed of myofibrils</p>
<p>Fig.2.26.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-31bbfafb.jpeg" alt="img-133.jpeg"></p>
<p>Each myofibril consists of filaments. No filaments are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Thin filaments: myosin II</li>
<li>Thin filaments: actin, tropomyosin and troponins (I, T &amp; C)</li>
<li>Others: actinin and titin</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig.2.27.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-4a9b785f.jpeg" alt="img-134.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="structure-of-skeletal-muscle">Structure of skeletal muscle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure-of-skeletal-muscle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Each muscle consists of bundles of fibers</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig.2.28.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-87d26245.jpeg" alt="img-135.jpeg"></p>
<p>Each fiber is a single cell, composed of myofibrils</p>
<p>Fig.2.29.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-ea94b2a8.jpeg" alt="img-136.jpeg"></p>
<p>Each myofibril consists of filaments, the filaments are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Thin filaments: myosin II</li>
<li>Thin filaments: actin, tropomyosin and troponins (I, T &amp; C)</li>
<li>Others: actinin and titin</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig.2.30.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-5569513e.jpeg" alt="img-137.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="structure-of-skeletal-muscle">Structure of skeletal muscle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure-of-skeletal-muscle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Each muscle consists of bundles of fibers</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig.2.30.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-b07d20ec.jpeg" alt="img-138.jpeg"></p>
<p>Each fiber is a single cell, composed of myofibrils</p>
<p>Fig.2.30.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-3ad547c7.jpeg" alt="img-139.jpeg"></p>
<p>Each myofibril consists of filaments, the filaments are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Thin filaments: myosin II</li>
<li>Thin filaments: actin, tropomyosin and troponins (I, T &amp; C)</li>
<li>Others: actinin and titin</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig.2.31.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-e7442cfa.jpeg" alt="img-140.jpeg">
Fig.2.27:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="solutions">Solutions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#solutions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Appearance of alternate light and dark bands in skeletal or cardiac muscle fibers when examined under direct polarized light, using the microscope.</li>
<li>Are due to differences in refractive indexes of thick &amp; thin filaments</li>
<li>The light area (I band)</li>
<li>is (without) to polarized light (contains actin only)</li>
<li>divided into two halves by the Z line</li>
<li>The dark area (A band)</li>
<li>is (amblyso) to polarized light (contains myosin + ends of actin)</li>
<li>contains lighter area in the middle (H band) that contains myosin only and divided by the M line</li>
<li>The area between two Z lines is called sarcomere</li>
<li>The sarcomere is the functional unit of muscles. It contains an A band + two halves of I band.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-dc976127.jpeg" alt="img-141.jpeg">
Fig.2.28:</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-0f85edca.jpeg" alt="img-142.jpeg">
Fig.2.27:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="solutions">Solutions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#solutions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Appearance of alternate light and dark bands in skeletal or cardiac muscle fibers when examined under direct polarized light, using the microscope.</li>
<li>Are due to differences in refractive indexes of thick &amp; thin filaments</li>
<li>The light area (I band)</li>
<li>is (without) to polarized light (contains actin only)</li>
<li>divided into two halves by the Z line</li>
<li>The dark area (A band)</li>
<li>is (amblyso) to polarized light (contains myosin + ends of actin)</li>
<li>contains lighter area in the middle (H band) that contains myosin only and divided by the M line</li>
<li>The area between two Z lines is called sarcomere</li>
<li>The sarcomere is the functional unit of muscles. It contains an A band + two halves of I band.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-95162cec.jpeg" alt="img-143.jpeg">
Fig.2.29:</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-87fa8f22.jpeg" alt="img-144.jpeg">
Fig.2.30:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="solutions">Solutions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#solutions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Appearance of alternate light and dark bands in skeletal or cardiac muscle fibers when examined under direct polarized light, using the microscope.</li>
<li>Are due to differences in refractive indexes of thick &amp; thin filaments</li>
<li>The light area (I band)</li>
<li>is (without) to polarized light (contains actin only)</li>
<li>divided into two halves by the Z line</li>
<li>The dark area (A band)</li>
<li>is (amblyso) to polarized light (contains myosin + ends of actin)</li>
<li>contains lighter area in the middle (H band) that contains myosin only and divided by the M line</li>
<li>The area between two Z lines is called sarcomere</li>
<li>The sarcomere is the functional unit of muscles. It contains an A band + two halves of I band.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-a8b2105b.jpeg" alt="img-145.jpeg">
Fig.2.31:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-brick-elements">The Brick Elements:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-brick-elements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="myosin-ii">Myosin II<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#myosin-ii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Each has 7 heavy chains and 4 light chains forming a tail and 2 globular heads.</li>
<li>Each head of myosin has:</li>
<li>Actin binding site</li>
<li>ATPase activity</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Fig 2.28:</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-13fb6ad7.jpeg" alt="img-146.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-8th-elements">The 8th Elements:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-8th-elements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-actin">a-Actin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-actin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Coneses of two chains that form double helix</li>
<li>Has active sites that act as targets for myosin heads</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Fig 2.29:</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-0ea3dce8.jpeg" alt="img-147.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-truponymin">b-Truponymin:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-truponymin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Lie in the groove between the two filaments of actin</li>
<li>Hides the actin active sites during relaxation of muscle</li>
<li>This prevents binding of myosin heads to actin</li>
</ul>
<p>The trick of medical physiology of action</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-brick-elements">The Brick Elements:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-brick-elements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="myosin-ii">Myosin II<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#myosin-ii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Each has 2 heavy chains and 4 light chains forming a tail and 2 globular heads.</li>
<li>Each head of myosin has:</li>
<li>Actin binding site</li>
<li>ATPase activity</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Fig 2.29:</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-2f30d1c1.jpeg" alt="img-148.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-8th-elements">The 8th Elements:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-8th-elements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-actin">a-Actin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-actin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Coneses of two chains that form double helix</li>
<li>Has active sites that act as targets for myosin heads</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Fig 2.30:</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-d2087773.jpeg" alt="img-149.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-truponymin">b-Truponymin:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-truponymin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Lie in the groove between the two filaments of actin</li>
<li>Hides the actin active sites during relaxation of muscle</li>
<li>This prevents binding of myosin heads to actin</li>
</ul>
<p>The trick of medical physiology of action</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-brick-elements">The Brick Elements:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-brick-elements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="myosin-ii">Myosin II<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#myosin-ii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Each has 2 heavy chains and 4 light chains forming a tail and 2 globular heads.</li>
<li>Each head of myosin has:</li>
<li>Actin binding site</li>
<li>ATPase activity</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Fig 2.29:</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-566f609b.jpeg" alt="img-150.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-8th-elements">The 8th Elements:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-8th-elements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-actin">a-Actin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-actin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Coneses of two chains that form double helix</li>
<li>Has active sites that act as targets for myosin heads</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Fig 2.30:</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-3e071e2e.jpeg" alt="img-151.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-truponymin">b-Truponymin:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-truponymin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Lie in the groove between the two filaments of actin</li>
<li>Hides the actin active sites during relaxation of muscle</li>
<li>This prevents binding of myosin heads to actin</li>
</ul>
<p>The trick of medical physiology of action</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-081067de.jpeg" alt="img-152.jpeg">
Fig.2.11:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="a-troponins">a. Troponins:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-troponins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Troponin T: Leucin other troponin units to tropomyosin</li>
<li>Troponin I: Inhibits interaction between actin and myosin</li>
<li>Troponin C: Intron calcium which initiates contraction</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-23662d5e.jpeg" alt="img-153.jpeg">
Fig.2.12:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-neurotubular-system">The neurotubular system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-neurotubular-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Membranous structures in the muscle fiber</li>
<li>Made up of T tubules &amp; sarcoplasmic reticulum</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-f-tubules">The F tubules:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-f-tubules" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Are transverse tubules that arise as integrations from the cell membrane.</li>
<li>Located at the A1 syndrome in skeletal muscles (in two per cell) and at the Z lines in cardiac muscles (in a per cell).</li>
<li>Inside the cell they are perforated by the myofibrils.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-3c52b184.jpeg" alt="img-154.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-4ab27ec5.jpeg" alt="img-155.jpeg">
Fig.2.21:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-neurotubular-system">the neurotubular system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-neurotubular-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Membranous structures in the muscle fiber</li>
<li>Made up of T tubules &amp; sarcoplasmic reticulum</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-f-tubules">The F tubules:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-f-tubules" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Are transverse tubules that arise as integrations from the cell membrane.</li>
<li>Located at the A1 syndrome in skeletal muscles (in two per cell) and at the Z lines in cardiac muscles (in a per cell).</li>
<li>Inside the cell they are perforated by the myofibrils.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-d0aa2827.jpeg" alt="img-156.jpeg">
Fig.2.22:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="a-troponins">a. Troponins:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-troponins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Troponin T: Leucin other troponin units to tropomyosin</li>
<li>Troponin I: Inhibits interaction between actin and myosin</li>
<li>Troponin C: Intron calcium which initiates contraction</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-04dad829.jpeg" alt="img-157.jpeg">
Fig.2.13:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-neurotubular-system">The neurotubular system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-neurotubular-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Membranous structures in the muscle fiber</li>
<li>Made up of T tubules &amp; sarcoplasmic reticulum</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-f-tubules">The F tubules:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-f-tubules" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Are transverse tubules that arise as integrations from the cell membrane.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Located at the A1 syndrome in skeletal muscles (in two per cell) and at the Z lines in cardiac muscles (in a per cell).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Inside the cell they are perforated by the myofibrils.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>They transmit action potentials from the sarcolemma to the interior of the cell.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>The sarcoplasmic reticulum:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Forms irregular curtain around the myofibrils.</li>
<li>Has an enlarged terminal on each side of the T tubule "the sarcoplasmic cisternae". These form with the T tubule a triad (T tubule + 2 cisternae on each side).</li>
<li>It stores calcium to be released to the sarcoplasm when an action potential arrives through the T tubule.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Fig 2.33:</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-e5c9e844.jpeg" alt="img-158.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="molecular-basis-of-contraction-sliding-theory">Molecular basis of contraction (Sliding theory)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#molecular-basis-of-contraction-sliding-theory" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Contraction occurs by sliding of the thin filaments over the thick filaments, thus shortening the sarcomers.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="steps-of-muscle-contraction">Steps of muscle contraction:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps-of-muscle-contraction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Depolarization of the sarcolemma (by an action potential coming from the neuromuscular junction).</li>
<li>Transmission of the action potential to interior of the muscle cell via the T tubules.</li>
<li>The passage of the depolarization wave through the T tubules induces opening of dihydropyridine receptors in the membrane of the T tubules.</li>
</ul>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The dihydropyridine receptors:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>in the cardiac muscle they allow influx of calcium &amp; the triplex release of stored calcium in the terminal cisterna.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>in skeletal muscle fibers they act as sensors that detect arrival of its depolarizing wave &amp; trigger release of stored calcium.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Release of stored calcium from the terminal cisterna to the sarcoplasm occurs via the pyrimidine receptors.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Calcium in the sarcoplasm binds to troponin C.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This results in:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Weakness of the binding of troponin I to actin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Conformational changes in tropomyosin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tropomyosin moves laterally to uncover the actin active sites</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Myosin heads bind the uncovered actin active sites</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>ATP is hydrolyzed and the energy released by hydrolysis causes loss of myosin heads inwards.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This causes sliding of actin on myosin resulting in shortening of its sarcomers (= contraction).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-4ad40c1d.jpeg" alt="img-159.jpeg">
Fig.1.34:</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-7fe15d25.jpeg" alt="img-160.jpeg">
Fig.1.36:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The dihydropyridine receptors:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>in the cardiac muscle they allow influx of calcium &amp; the triplex release of stored calcium in the terminal cisterna.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>in skeletal muscle fibers they act as sensors that detect arrival of its depolarizing wave &amp; trigger release of stored calcium.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Release of stored calcium from the terminal cisterna to the sarcoplasm occurs via the pyrimidine receptors.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Calcium in the sarcoplasm binds to troponin C.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This results in:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Weakness of the binding of troponin I to actin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Conformational changes in tropomyosin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tropomyosin moves laterally to uncover the actin active sites</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Myosin heads bind the uncovered actin active sites</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>ATP is hydrolyzed and the energy released by hydrolysis causes loss of myosin heads inwards.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This causes sliding of actin on myosin resulting in shortening of its sarcomers (= contraction).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-e7a6505f.jpeg" alt="img-161.jpeg">
Fig.1.38:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The dihydropyridine receptors:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>in the cardiac muscle they allow influx of calcium &amp; the triplex release of stored calcium in the terminal cisterna.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>in skeletal muscle fibers they act as sensors that detect arrival of its depolarizing wave &amp; trigger release of stored calcium.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Release of stored calcium from the terminal cisterna to the sarcoplasm occurs via the pyrimidine receptors.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Calcium in the sarcoplasm binds to troponin C.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This results in:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Weakness of the binding of troponin I to actin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Conformational changes in tropomyosin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tropomyosin moves laterally to uncover the actin active sites</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Myosin heads bind the uncovered actin active sites</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>ATP is hydrolyzed and the energy released by hydrolysis causes loss of myosin heads inwards.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This causes sliding of actin on myosin resulting in shortening of its sarcomers (= contraction).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-9fcef23f.jpeg" alt="img-162.jpeg"></p>
<p>78
The case of medical physiology 17 volume</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="important-notes">Important notes:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#important-notes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The process by which depolarization of the muscle cell results in contraction is known as proliferation/correlation coupling.</li>
<li>Seven active sites in actin are uncovered for each molecule of troponin C that binds a calcium ion.</li>
<li>Contraction of skeletal muscle depends on release of stored calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, whereas contraction of cardiac and smooth muscles requires influx of calcium from the RCP.</li>
<li>The calcium binding protein in smooth muscle is known as calmodulin. Unlike troponin, calmodulin initiates contraction immediately. First it activates a kinase enzyme that's needed for phosphorylation of myosin head. This phosphorylation triggers the ATPase activity of the head and this is followed by contraction.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="steps-of-muscle-relaxation">Steps of muscle relaxation:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps-of-muscle-relaxation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Shortly after releasing calcium to the sarcoplasm, the sarcoplasmic reticulum begins to transport it back actively by the Ca-Mg ATPase pump.</li>
<li>When the level of calcium in the sarcoplasm is lowered sufficiently, calcium is released from troponin C.</li>
<li>This causes actin &amp; myosin interaction to stop, tropomyosin returns to its position &amp; the muscle relaxes.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="remember-that">Remember that:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remember-that" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>ATP is consumed for both contraction &amp; relaxation.</li>
<li>If calcium transport back to the sarcoplasmic cisterns is inhibited, relaxation will never occur (= contraction).</li>
<li>If no energy is available for relaxation (no ATP), the muscle becomes rigid (= rigor). A common example is (rigor marks) which occurs after death.</li>
</ul>
<p>79
The case of medical physiology 17 volume</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="important-notes">Important notes:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#important-notes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The process by which depolarization of the muscle cell results in contraction is known as excitation-contraction coupling.</li>
<li>Seven active sites in actin are uncovered for each molecule of troponin C that binds a calcium ion.</li>
<li>Contraction of skeletal muscle depends on release of stored calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum whereas contraction of cardiac and smooth muscles requires influx of calcium from the RCP.</li>
<li>The calcium binding protein in smooth muscle is known as calmodulin. Unlike troponin, calmodulin initiates contraction immediately. First it activates a kinase enzyme that's needed for phosphorylation of myosin head. This phosphorylation triggers the ATPase activity of the head and this is followed by contraction.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="steps-of-muscle-relaxation">Steps of muscle relaxation:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps-of-muscle-relaxation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Shortly after releasing calcium to the sarcoplasm, the sarcoplasmic reticulum begins to transport it back actively by the Ca-Mg ATPase pump.</li>
<li>When the level of calcium in the sarcoplasm is lowered sufficiently, calcium is released from troponin C.</li>
<li>This causes actin &amp; myosin interaction to stop, tropomyosin returns to its position &amp; the muscle relaxes.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="remember-that">Remember that:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remember-that" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>ATP is consumed for both contraction &amp; relaxation.</li>
<li>If calcium transport back to the sarcoplasmic cisterns is inhibited, relaxation will never occur (= contraction).</li>
<li>If no energy is available for relaxation (no ATP), the muscle becomes rigid (= rigor). A common example is (rigor marks) which occurs after death.</li>
</ul>
<p>80
The case of medical physiology 17 volume</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="important-notes">Important notes:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#important-notes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The process by which depolarization of the muscle cell results in contraction is known as excitation-contraction coupling.</li>
<li>Seven active sites in actin are uncovered for each molecule of troponin C that binds a calcium ion.</li>
<li>Contraction of skeletal muscle depends on release of stored calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum whereas contraction of cardiac and smooth muscles requires influx of calcium from the RCP.</li>
<li>The calcium binding protein in smooth muscle is known as calmodulin. Unlike troponin, calmodulin initiates contraction immediately. First it activates a kinase enzyme that's needed for phosphorylation of myosin head. This phosphorylation triggers the ATPase activity of the head and this is followed by contraction.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="steps-of-muscle-relaxation">Steps of muscle relaxation:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steps-of-muscle-relaxation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Shortly after releasing calcium to the sarcoplasm, the sarcoplasmic reticulum begins to transport it back actively by the Ca-Mg ATPase pump.</li>
<li>When the level of calcium in the sarcoplasm is lowered sufficiently, calcium is released from troponin C.</li>
<li>This causes actin &amp; myosin interaction to stop, tropomyosin returns to its position &amp; the muscle relaxes.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="remember-that">Remember that:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remember-that" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>ATP is consumed for both contraction &amp; relaxation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If calcium transport back to the sarcoplasmic cisterns is inhibited, relaxation will never occur (= contraction).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If no energy is available for relaxation (no ATP), the muscle becomes rigid (= rigor). A common example is (rigor marks) which occurs after death.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Relaxation in smooth muscles follows de-phosphorylation of myosin heads by a phosphatase enzyme. However, contraction may continue in spite of that for some time; this is due to the latch bridge mechanism.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In the latch bridge mechanism, myosin remains attached to actin resulting in a sustained contraction with minimal energy expenditure; as in the vascular smooth muscle.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-contraction">Types of contraction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-contraction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="isotonic-contraction">Isotonic contraction:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#isotonic-contraction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Isotonic contraction (the same tension) is contraction against a constant load that results in shortening of a muscle.</li>
<li>The muscle develops a constant tension throughout the range of movement (e.g. when lifting a light object).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="isometric-contraction">Isometric contraction:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#isometric-contraction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Isometric contraction (the same length) is contraction without appreciable shortening of a muscle.</p>
<p>The tension developed by the muscle is not constant, it is increasing (e.g. when trying to lift a very heavy object).</p>
<ul>
<li>Since there is no distance of movement (the same length of muscle); no work is done during the isometric contraction (remember that work = force times distance, which is zero).</li>
<li>Standing involves isometric contraction of muscles whereas walking involves both isometric &amp; isotonic contractions.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="single-muscle-twitch-and-summation-of-contractions">Single muscle twitch and summation of contractions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#single-muscle-twitch-and-summation-of-contractions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A single sufficient stimulation of a muscle fiber results in a single action potential that results in a single contraction followed by relaxation (= single muscle twitch).</li>
<li>The duration of the single muscle twitch is longer than the duration of the action potential.</li>
</ul>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<ul>
<li>Repeated stimulation of a muscle fiber results in repeated action potentials that are followed by successive contractions.</li>
<li>Since there is no refractory period for contractions, each new contraction starts before completion of the previous one. This results in summation of these contractions.</li>
<li>The tension developed by summation of contractions is greater than that's developed by a single contraction.</li>
<li>Summation of contractions into one continuous contraction is called tetanus.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tetanus">Tetanus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tetanus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Tetanus may be complete (with no any relaxation between contractions) or incomplete (with some incomplete relaxations between contractions).</li>
<li>The frequency of stimulation that results in tetanus is determined by the duration of the single muscle twitch.</li>
<li>With a frequency of stimulation just below the frequency of summation, the tension developed is increased by each new stimulus until a uniform tension per contraction is reached. This is called treppe or staircase phenomenon.</li>
<li>Here the increase in tension is not due to summation, it is due to increased availability of calcium to troponin C.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-muscle-fibers">Types of muscle fibers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-muscle-fibers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are two types of muscle fibers:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="type-one-fibers">Type one fibers:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#type-one-fibers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Called red muscles (darker than other types)</li>
<li>Respond slowly to stimulation (i.e. have long latency)</li>
<li>Have high oxidative capacity</li>
<li>Contract to maintain posture</li>
<li>E.g. muscles of the back</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="type-two-fibers">Type two fibers:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#type-two-fibers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Called white muscles</li>
</ul>
<p>The core of medical physiology 4th edition</p>
<ul>
<li>Have short twitch duration</li>
<li>Respond rapidly (i.e. have short latency)</li>
<li>Have high glycolytic capacity</li>
<li>Specialized for fine skilled movement</li>
<li>E.g. muscles of the hand</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-oxygen-debt-mechanism">The oxygen debt mechanism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-oxygen-debt-mechanism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>During severe exercise, the amount of oxygen delivered to skeletal muscle by the circulation is not enough for aerobic metabolism; for this reason skeletal muscle has to find extra oxygen or additional sources of energy; this is achieved as follows:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It takes oxygen from myoglobin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It metabolizes glucose anaerobically to lactic acid to synthesize ATP</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It uses phosphorylcreatine to synthesize ATP</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hyperventilation after exercise provides extra amount of oxygen that can be used to repay oxygen taken from myoglobin, to catabolize lactic acid to carbon dioxide and water, and to replenish phosphorylcreatine.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This extra amount of oxygen consumed after exercise is described as the oxygen debt.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The mechanism of oxygen debt does not occur in the cardiac muscle because it depends exclusively on aerobic metabolism for energy production.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<p>QUESTIONS FOR SELF ASSESSMENT-3 (BEST OF FIVE)</p>
<p>1- The resting membrane potential is generated by:
a. opening and closure of ligand gated channels
b. passage of ions through voltage gated channels
c. selective permeability of the cell membrane to potassium
d. closure of sodium leak channels by calcium
e. the high concentration of phosphates in the cell</p>
<p>2- The following is true about the action potential:
a. an external stimulus is not always needed for its initiation
b. the depolarization phase is always due to Na+ influx
c. its duration is equal in all types of excitable cells
d. after-depolarization phase is due to activity of the Na+/K+ pump
e. it can be summed in skeletal but not in cardiac muscle</p>
<p>3- Concerning myelination, which of the following is not true:
a. synthesized from phospholipids and protein
b. found in preganglionic sympathetic neurons
c. found in postganglionic sympathetic neurons
d. found in the central nervous system
e. formed by oligodendroglial cells</p>
<p>4- If ECF K+ concentration is increased from 3.5 to 5.0 mmol/L:
a. the resting membrane potential becomes less negative
b. the resting membrane potential will not change
c. fast voltage gated sodium channels will open
d. an action potential will occur spontaneously
e. the cell membrane becomes hyperpolarized</p>
<p>5- Leak channels:
a. are present in almost all cells in the body
b. have gates that open or close during action potentials
c. have gates that open when a hormone binds to its receptor
d. are responsible for the depolarization phase of action potentials
e. gates are closed by the end of the action potential</p>
<p>6- Calcium channels in synaptic knob:
a. Allow release of neurotransmitter through them
b. Are voltage gated
c. Are ligand gated
d. Are opened when acetylcholine is released
e. Cause termination of the action potential</p>
<p>7- These proteins are involved in skeletal muscle contraction except:
a. calmodulin
b. actin
c. tropomyosin
d. myosin
e. troponin C</p>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<p>8- The A band in a striated muscle</p>
<p>a. is a light area
b. contains thick filaments only
c. is divided by the M line
d. is longer during relaxation than during contraction
e. appears due to overlapping between actin and myosin</p>
<p>9- Concerning chemical conduction, which of the following is not true:</p>
<p>a. it is unidirectional (one way direction)
b. excitatory neurotransmitters open Na⁺ channels
c. inhibitory neurotransmitters open Ca++ channels
d. GABA opens Cl channels in the postsynaptic neurons
e. the post-synaptic neuron is influenced by many pre-synaptic neurons</p>
<p>10-Ryanodine receptors:</p>
<p>a. allow influx of calcium from ECF to ICF in cardiac muscle
b. allow release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic cisternae to ICF in skeletal muscle
c. are found in skeletal but not cardiac muscle
d. act as sensors for arrival of excitation through the T tubule
e. allow pumping back of calcium to sarcoplasmic cisternae</p>
<p>11-Isometric contraction differs from isotonic contraction in that:</p>
<p>a- it does not occur in cardiac muscle
b- it occurs during walking
c- it does not involve interaction between actin and myosin
d- the muscle tension applied is increased during the contraction
e- the force applied equals zero</p>
