<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter-3">CHAPTER 3<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-3" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-autonomic-nervous-system">THE AUTONOMIC NERVOUS SYSTEM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-autonomic-nervous-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The nervous system can be classified into two physiological divisions: The somatic nervous system (SNS) and the autonomic nervous system (ANS)</li>
</ul>
<p>Table 3.1: Comparison between the SNS and the ANS:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>The somatic nervous system</th><th>The autonomic nervous system</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>- Controls voluntary functions</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>e.g. limb movements</td><td>- Controls involuntary functions</td></tr><tr><td>e.g. cardiac beats</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>- Supplies skeletal muscles</td><td>- Supplies smooth and cardiac muscles</td></tr><tr><td>- One neuron connects the central part with the target muscle</td><td>- Two neurons connect the central part with the target muscle</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul>
<li>The two neurons are: preganglionic &amp; postganglionic neurons connected by a ganglion  |</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-683ee679.jpeg" alt="img-163.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig 3.1 Peripheral neurons of the SNS and the ANS</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="divisions-of-the-autonomic-nervous-system">Divisions of the autonomic nervous system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#divisions-of-the-autonomic-nervous-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The autonomic nervous system (ANS) is divided into:</li>
<li>Sympathetic division</li>
<li>Parasympathetic division</li>
</ul>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<p>54
The view of medical physiology 17 pages</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="differences-between-the-sympathetic-and-the-parasympathetic-divisions">Differences between the sympathetic and the parasympathetic divisions.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differences-between-the-sympathetic-and-the-parasympathetic-divisions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activators"><em>Activators</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activators" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Stressful stimuli (e.g. fear, pain, exercise...) activates the sympathetic and complete physical and mental rest (e.g. sleep) activates the parasympathetic.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="metabolism"><em>Metabolism</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#metabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The sympathetic nervous system causes catabolism for immediate release of energy that's used for fight or flight, whereas the parasympathetic is associated with anabolic reactions that store energy until needed by the body.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="anatomical-points"><em>Anatomical points</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anatomical-points" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The peripheral parts of the ANG are made up of proganglionic (myelinated, type B) and proganglionic (unmyelinated, type C) neurons.</li>
<li>The cell bodies of the proganglionic neurons are located in the lateral front of the spinal cord or the motor nuclei of the cranial nerves 10, 9, 7 and 3 in 1973. Their entire pairs through the ventral horns to the spinal nerves and then they follow the blood vessels to the target organs.</li>
<li>The proganglionic neurons of the sympathetic are short. They leave the spinal nerve through white semi-communicates to synapse in sympathetic ganglia with proganglionic neurons that return back to the spinal nerve via grey semi-communicates to be distributed to their targets. They are longer than the proganglionic neurons.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-4b92dd8e.jpeg" alt="img-164.jpeg">
Fig.3.2. Origin and course of a proganglionic neuron</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="differences-between-the-sympathetic-and-the-parasympathetic-divisions">Differences between the sympathetic and the parasympathetic divisions.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differences-between-the-sympathetic-and-the-parasympathetic-divisions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activators"><em>Activators</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activators" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Stressful stimuli (e.g. fear, pain, exercise...) activates the sympathetic and complete physical and mental rest (e.g. sleep) activates the parasympathetic.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="metabolism"><em>Metabolism</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#metabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The sympathetic nervous system causes catabolism for immediate release of energy that's used for fight or flight, whereas the parasympathetic is associated with anabolic reactions that store energy until needed by the body.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="anatomical-points"><em>Anatomical points</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anatomical-points" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The peripheral parts of the ANG are made up of proganglionic (myelinated, type B) and proganglionic (unmyelinated, type C) neurons.</li>
<li>The cell bodies of the proganglionic neurons are located in the lateral front of the spinal cord or the motor nuclei of the cranial nerves 10, 9, 7 and 3 in 1973. Their entire pairs through the ventral horns to the spinal nerves and then they follow the blood vessels to the target organs.</li>
<li>The proganglionic neurons of the sympathetic are short. They leave the spinal nerve through white semi-communicates to synapse in sympathetic ganglia with proganglionic neurons that return back to the spinal nerve via grey semi-communicates to be distributed to their targets. They are longer than the proganglionic neurons.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-8ed451f7.jpeg" alt="img-165.jpeg">
Fig.3.3: Origin and course of a proganglionic neuron</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="differences-between-the-sympathetic-and-the-parasympathetic-divisions">Differences between the sympathetic and the parasympathetic divisions.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differences-between-the-sympathetic-and-the-parasympathetic-divisions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activators"><em>Activators</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activators" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Stressful stimuli (e.g. fear, pain, exercise...) activates the sympathetic and complete physical and mental rest (e.g. sleep) activates the parasympathetic.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="metabolism"><em>Metabolism</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#metabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The sympathetic nervous system causes catabolism for immediate release of energy that's used for fight or flight, whereas the parasympathetic is associated with anabolic reactions that store energy until needed by the body.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="anatomical-points"><em>Anatomical points</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anatomical-points" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The peripheral parts of the ANG are made up of proganglionic (myelinated, type B) and proganglionic (unmyelinated, type C) neurons.</li>
<li>The cell bodies of the proganglionic neurons are located in the lateral front of the spinal cord or the motor nuclei of the cranial nerves 10, 9, 7 and 3 in 1973. Their entire pairs through the ventral horns to the spinal nerves and then they follow the blood vessels to the target organs.</li>
<li>The proganglionic neurons of the sympathetic are short. They leave the spinal nerve through white semi-communicates to synapse in sympathetic ganglia with proganglionic neurons that return back to the spinal nerve via grey semi-communicates to be distributed to their targets. They are longer than the proganglionic neurons.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-60eb707f.jpeg" alt="img-166.jpeg">
Fig.3.2: Origin and course of a proganglionic neuron</p>
<p>55
The view of medical physiology 17 pages</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The sympathetic ganglia, the site of cell bodies of the postganglionic neurons, are connected together to form the sympathetic trunk that extends parallel to the thoracic and upper lumbar spinal segments. Additional sympathetic ganglia are also found in the neck (superior, middle and stellate ganglia) and in the abdomen (collateral ganglia).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>On the other hand, the preganglionic parasympathetic neurons are longer than the postganglionic. The ganglia are found near or within the wall of the target organs.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 5.2. The output of autonomic neurons</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-cc9a47ac.jpeg" alt="img-167.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="output-from-the-cns">Output from the CNS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#output-from-the-cns" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The central parts of the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems originate from certain autonomic centers at the brain (e.g. the hypothalamus or the brain stem) and then descend through the spinal cord.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The peripheral part of the sympathetic passes out through the spinal nerves that originate from the thoracic and some lumbar segments (from T1 to L2); whereas the peripheral part of the parasympathetic passes out through some cranial nerves (number 10, 9, 7 and 3) and some sacral spinal nerves (S2, S3 and S4).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For this reason the outflow of the sympathetic is described as thoracic-lumbar and that of the parasympathetic as cranio-sacral.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>67</p>
<p>The area of medical physiology of science</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The sympathetic ganglia, the site of cell bodies of the postganglionic neurons, are connected together to form the sympathetic trunk that extends parallel to the thoracic and upper lumbar spinal segments. Additional sympathetic ganglia are also found in the neck (superior, middle and stellate ganglia) and in the abdomen (collateral ganglia).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>On the other hand, the preganglionic parasympathetic neurons are longer than the postganglionic. The ganglia are found near or within the wall of the target organs.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-617e974c.jpeg" alt="img-168.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="output-from-the-cns">Output from the CNS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#output-from-the-cns" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The central parts of the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems originate from certain autonomic centers at the brain (e.g. the hypothalamus or the brain stem) and then descend through the spinal cord.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The peripheral part of the sympathetic passes out through the spinal nerves that originate from the thoracic and some lumbar segments (from T1 to L2); whereas the peripheral part of the parasympathetic passes out through some cranial nerves (number 10, 9, 7 and 3) and some sacral spinal nerves (S2, S3 and S4).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For this reason the outflow of the sympathetic is described as thoracic-lumbar and that of the parasympathetic as cranio-sacral.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>67</p>
<p>The area of medical physiology of science</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The sympathetic ganglia, the site of cell bodies of the postganglionic neurons, are connected together to form the sympathetic trunk that extends parallel to the thoracic and upper lumbar spinal segments. Additional sympathetic ganglia are also found in the neck (superior, middle and stellate ganglia) and in the abdomen (collateral ganglia).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>On the other hand, the preganglionic parasympathetic neurons are longer than the postganglionic. The ganglia are found near or within the wall of the target organs.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-9d37e89c.jpeg" alt="img-169.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="output-from-the-cns">Output from the CNS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#output-from-the-cns" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The central parts of the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems originate from certain autonomic centers at the brain (e.g. the hypothalamus or the brain stem) and then descend through the spinal cord.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The peripheral part of the sympathetic passes out through the spinal nerves that originate from the thoracic and some lumbar segments (from T1 to L2); whereas the peripheral part of the parasympathetic passes out through some cranial nerves (number 10, 9, 7 and 3) and some sacral spinal nerves (S2, S3 and S4).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For this reason the outflow of the sympathetic is described as thoracic-lumbar and that of the parasympathetic as cranio-sacral.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>67</p>
<p>The area of medical physiology of science</p>
<p>44
The care of patient physician</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="effects">Effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The ratio of a preganglionic neuron to postganglionic neurons is about 1:20 for the sympathetic neurons and 1:1 for the parasympathetic neurons. This indicates that the effects of the sympathetic are generalized (because of divergence of a preganglionic neuron) while those of the parasympathetic are localized.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>The neurotransmitters released by the neurons</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>
<p>All preganglionic neurons whether sympathetic or parasympathetic, and all postganglionic parasympathetic neurons release acetylcholine whereas the postganglionic sympathetic neurons release noradrenaline. Others release acetylcholine.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Postganglionic sympathetic neurons that release acetylcholine supply to sweat glands, arterioles of skeletal muscles and pile-wreeder muscles.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Table 1.2: Comparison between the zones, and the parasynes.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Difference</th><th>Sympathetic</th><th>Parasympathetic</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Activator*</td><td>Stress</td><td>Rest</td></tr><tr><td>Metabolism*</td><td>Catabolic to release energy for fight or flight</td><td>Anabolic to store energy until needed</td></tr><tr><td>Fragen neurons</td><td>Short</td><td>Long</td></tr><tr><td>Postga. neurons</td><td>Long</td><td>Short</td></tr><tr><td>Ganglia</td><td>Near the spinal cord (paravertebral)</td><td>Near or within the wall of the organ</td></tr><tr><td>Output from the CNS*</td><td>Thoracolumbar</td><td>Craniosacral</td></tr><tr><td>Effects*</td><td>Generalized</td><td>Localized</td></tr><tr><td>Neurotransmitter released by the neurons</td><td>Preganglionic + Acetylcholine</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Postganglionic + Noradrenaline</td><td>Preganglionic + Acetylcholine</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Postganglionic + Acetylcholine</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>45
The care of patient physician</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="effects">Effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The ratio of a preganglionic neuron to postganglionic neurons is about 1:10 for the sympathetic neurons and 1:1 for the parasympathetic neurons. This indicates that the effects of the sympathetic are generalized (because of divergence of a preganglionic neuron) while those of the parasympathetic are localized.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>The neurotransmitters released by the neurons</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>
<p>All preganglionic neurons whether sympathetic or parasympathetic, and all postganglionic parasympathetic neurons release acetylcholine whereas the postganglionic sympathetic neurons release noradrenaline. Others release acetylcholine.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Postganglionic sympathetic neurons that release acetylcholine supply to sweat glands, arterioles of skeletal muscles and pile-wreeder muscles.</p>
</li>
</ul>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="effects">Effects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The ratio of a preganglionic neuron to postganglionic neurons is about 1:10 for the sympathetic neurons and 1:1 for the parasympathetic neurons. This indicates that the effects of the sympathetic are generalized (because of divergence of a preganglionic neuron) while those of the parasympathetic are localized.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>The neurotransmitters released by the neurons</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>
<p>All preganglionic neurons whether sympathetic or parasympathetic, and all postganglionic parasympathetic neurons release acetylcholine whereas the postganglionic sympathetic neurons release noradrenaline. Others release acetylcholine.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Postganglionic sympathetic neurons that release acetylcholine supply to sweat glands, arterioles of skeletal muscles and pile-wreeder muscles.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Table 1.2: Comparison between the zones, and the parasynes.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Difference</th><th>Sympathetic</th><th>Parasympathetic</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Activator*</td><td>Stress</td><td>Rest</td></tr><tr><td>Metabolism*</td><td>Catabolic to release energy for fight or flight</td><td>Anabolic to store energy until needed</td></tr><tr><td>Fragen neurons</td><td>Short</td><td>Long</td></tr><tr><td>Postga. neurons</td><td>Long</td><td>Short</td></tr><tr><td>Ganglia</td><td>Near the spinal cord (paravertebral)</td><td>Near or within the wall of the organ</td></tr><tr><td>Output from the CNS*</td><td>Thoracolumbar</td><td>Craniosacral</td></tr><tr><td>Effects*</td><td>Generalized</td><td>Localized</td></tr><tr><td>Neurotransmitter released by the neurons</td><td>Preganglionic + Acetylcholine</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Postganglionic + Noradrenaline</td><td>Preganglionic + Acetylcholine</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Postganglionic + Acetylcholine</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>THE NEURO-TRANSFERED</p>
<p>The principal neurotransmitters (N1) in the autonomic nervous system are acetylcholine and noradrenaline.</p>
<p><strong>Anhydrodine:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Synthesized from acetyl co A and choline in the cell body of cholinergic neurons (i.e. neurons that release acetylcholine).</li>
<li>Synthesis is catalyzed by the enzyme choline acetyltransferase.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Acetylcholine is released by:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Al(preganglionic parasympathetic) neurons</li>
<li>Al(postganglionic parasympathetic) neurons</li>
<li>Al(preganglionic sympathetic) neurons</li>
<li>Some postganglionic sympathetic neurons (those supplying sweat glands, arterioles of skeletal muscles and pilo-emotor muscles)</li>
</ul>
<p>When released at the synaptic cleft, acetylcholine acts on its receptors. However, its action is terminated by the acetylcholinesterase enzyme which converts it to acetate and choline. Therefore generally no acetylcholine diffuses to plasma.</p>
<p><strong>Nondetendine (n-norepinephrine):</strong></p>
<p>Synthesized from the amino acid tyrosine in noradrenergic neurons (i.e. neurons that release noradrenaline)</p>
<p><strong>Steps of synthesis:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Tyrosine (from diet or from phenylalanine) is hydroxylated to dope (by tyrosine hydroxylase in the cytoplasm).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Dope is decarboxylated to dopamine (by dope decarboxylase in the cytoplasm).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Dopamine is converted to norepinephrine (by dopamine beta hydroxylase in the vesicles).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Noradrenaline is also synthesized in the adrenal medulla (an endocrine gland regarded as a modified sympathetic ganglion that lost its postganglionic</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>THE NEURO-TRANSFERED</p>
<p>The principal neurotransmitters (N1) in the autonomic nervous system are acetylcholine and noradrenaline.</p>
<p><strong>Anhydroadrenaline:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Synthesized from acetyl co A and choline in the cell body of cholinergic neurons (i.e. neurons that release acetylcholine).</li>
<li>Synthesis is catalyzed by the enzyme choline acetyltransferase.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Acetylcholine is released by:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Al(preganglionic parasympathetic) neurons</li>
<li>Al(postganglionic parasympathetic) neurons</li>
<li>Al(preganglionic sympathetic) neurons</li>
<li>Some postganglionic sympathetic neurons (those supplying sweat glands, arterioles of skeletal muscles and pilo-emotor muscles)</li>
</ul>
<p>When released at the synaptic cleft, acetylcholine acts on its receptors. However, its action is terminated by the acetylcholinesterase enzyme which converts it to acetate and choline. Therefore generally no acetylcholine diffuses to plasma.</p>
<p><strong>Nondetendine (n-norepinephrine):</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Synthesized from the amino acid tyrosine in noradrenergic neurons (i.e. neurons that release noradrenaline)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Steps of synthesis:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Tyrosine (from diet or from phenylalanine) is hydroxylated to dope (by tyrosine hydroxylase in the cytoplasm).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Dope is decarboxylated to dopamine (by dope decarboxylase in the cytoplasm).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Dopamine is converted to norepinephrine (by dopamine beta hydroxylase in the vesicles).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Noradrenaline is also synthesized in the adrenal medulla (an endocrine gland regarded as a modified sympathetic ganglion that lost its postganglionic</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>THE NEURO-TRANSFERED</p>
<p>The principal neurotransmitters (N1) in the autonomic nervous system are acetylcholine and noradrenaline.</p>
<p><strong>Anhydrodione:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Synthesized from acetyl co A and choline in the cell body of cholinergic neurons (i.e. neurons that release acetylcholine).</li>
<li>Synthesis is catalyzed by the enzyme choline acetyltransferase.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Acetylcholine is released by:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Al(preganglionic parasympathetic) neurons</li>
<li>Al(postganglionic parasympathetic) neurons</li>
<li>Al(preganglionic sympathetic) neurons</li>
<li>Some postganglionic sympathetic neurons (those supplying sweat glands, arterioles of skeletal muscles and pilo-emotor muscles)</li>
</ul>
<p>When released at the synaptic cleft, acetylcholine acts on its receptors. However, its action is terminated by the acetylcholinesterase enzyme which converts it to acetate and choline. Therefore generally no acetylcholine diffuses to plasma.</p>
<p><strong>Nondetendine (n-norepinephrine):</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Synthesized from the amino acid tyrosine in noradrenergic neurons (i.e. neurons that release noradrenaline)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Steps of synthesis:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Tyrosine (from diet or from phenylalanine) is hydroxylated to dope (by tyrosine hydroxylase in the cytoplasm).</li>
<li>Dope is decarboxylated to dopamine (by dope decarboxylase in the cytoplasm).</li>
<li>Dopamine is converted to norepinephrine (by dopamine beta hydroxylase in the vesicles).</li>
</ul>
<p>Noradrenaline is also synthesized in the adrenal medulla (an endocrine gland regarded as a modified sympathetic ganglion that lost its postganglionic</p>
<p>The name of neurexpressor (N1) is ___________</p>
<p>30
The case of medical physiology 17 (2007)</p>
<p>accne). However, in this gland most of the synthesized noradrenaline (α-norepinephrine) is converted to adrenaline (= epinephrine) by the enzyme phenylthiocianine-N-methyltransferase (PNMT).</p>
<p>Adrenaline, noradrenaline and dopamine are called catecholamines.</p>
<p>In summary, noradrenaline is released by:</p>
<ul>
<li>Most postganglionic sympathetic neurons (excluding those which release acetylcholine);</li>
<li>The adrenal medulla (releases adrenaline plus some noradrenaline). When released at the synaptic cleft, noradrenaline acts on its receptors. There is no enzyme for its hydrolysis in the cleft. However, after its diffusion into the plasma, it is hydrolyzed by two enzymes:</li>
<li>Monoamine oxidase (MAO)</li>
<li>Catechol-O-methyl-transferase (COMT)</li>
<li>The most important metabolite is veridylnandelic acid (VMA), which is excreted in urine.</li>
</ul>
<p>Excretion of high amount of this metabolite in urine indicates hyperproduction of catecholamines (e.g. by a tumor in the adrenal medulla (= pheochromocytoma)).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-54059cee.jpeg" alt="img-170.jpeg">
Fig 3.4. Cholinergic and noradrenergic neurons</p>
<p>(1) The case of medical physiology 17 (2007)</p>
<p>accne). However, in this gland most of the synthesized noradrenaline (α-norepinephrine) is converted to adrenaline (= epinephrine) by the enzyme phenylthiocianine-N-methyltransferase (PNMT).</p>
<p>Adrenaline, noradrenaline and dopamine are called catecholamines.</p>
<p>In summary, noradrenaline is released by:</p>
<ul>
<li>Most postganglionic sympathetic neurons (excluding those which release acetylcholine);</li>
<li>The adrenal medulla (releases adrenaline plus some noradrenaline). When released at the synaptic cleft, noradrenaline acts on its receptors. There is no enzyme for its hydrolysis in the cleft. However, after its diffusion into the plasma, it is hydrolyzed by two enzymes:</li>
<li>Monoamine oxidase (MAO)</li>
<li>Catechol-O-methyl-transferase (COMT)</li>
<li>The most important metabolite is veridylnandelic acid (VMA), which is excreted in urine.</li>
</ul>
<p>Excretion of high amount of this metabolite in urine indicates hyperproduction of catecholamines (e.g. by a tumor in the adrenal medulla (= pheochromocytoma)).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-cb769c40.jpeg" alt="img-171.jpeg">
Fig 3.4. Cholinergic and noradrenergic neurons</p>
<p>(1) The case of medical physiology 17 (2007)</p>
<p>accne). However, in this gland most of the synthesized noradrenaline (α-norepinephrine) is converted to adrenaline (= epinephrine) by the enzyme phenylthiocianine-N-methyltransferase (PNMT).</p>
<p>Adrenaline, noradrenaline and dopamine are called catecholamines.</p>
<p>In summary, noradrenaline is released by:</p>
<ul>
<li>Most postganglionic sympathetic neurons (excluding those which release acetylcholine);</li>
<li>The adrenal medulla (releases adrenaline plus some noradrenaline). When released at the synaptic cleft, noradrenaline acts on its receptors. There is no enzyme for its hydrolysis in the cleft. However, after its diffusion into the plasma, it is hydrolyzed by two enzymes:</li>
<li>Monoamine oxidase (MAO)</li>
<li>Catechol-O-methyl-transferase (COMT)</li>
<li>The most important metabolite is veridylnandelic acid (VMA), which is excreted in urine.</li>
</ul>
<p>Excretion of high amount of this metabolite in urine indicates hyperproduction of catecholamines (e.g. by a tumor in the adrenal medulla (= pheochromocytoma)).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-681525e5.jpeg" alt="img-172.jpeg">
Fig 3.4. Cholinergic and noradrenergic neurons</p>
<p>40
The issue of medical physics — 4th edition</p>
<p>Other neurotransmitters:</p>
<p><strong>Dopamine:</strong> Released by some interneurons in symp. ganglia</p>
<p><strong>Guflin:</strong> Released by some preganglionic neurons</p>
<p><strong>Cyanostriates:</strong></p>
<p>(1)P): May be found with acetylcholine</p>
<p>(ATF: Neuropeptide Y): may be found with noradrenaline</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="autonomic-receptors">AUTONOMIC RECEPTORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#autonomic-receptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>These are the receptors for the neurotransmitters in the autonomic nervous system (i.e. receptors for acetylcholine and noradrenaline)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="acetylcholine-receptors">Acetylcholine receptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acetylcholine-receptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li><strong>Nicotine receptors (N)</strong></li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Stimulated by small amount of nicotine (a chemical substance found in tobacco)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Found at the following sites:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sympathetic ganglia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Parasympathetic ganglia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Neuromuscular junction</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Adrenal medulla</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The brain</p>
</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li><strong>Muscarinic receptors (M)</strong></li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Stimulated by small amount of muscarine (a chemical substance excreted in urine of taripules)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Found at the following sites:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>All organs supplied by postganglionic cholinergic nerves (these include all organs in the body supplied by autonomic neurons except ventricles of the heart and blood vessels of the skin, abdominal viscera and the kidney which are supplied only by sympathetic, without parasympathetic supply).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The brain</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>41
The issue of medical physics — 4th edition</p>
<p>Other neurotransmitters:</p>
<p><strong>Dopamine:</strong> Released by some interneurons in symp. ganglia</p>
<p><strong>Guflin:</strong> Released by some preganglionic neurons</p>
<p><strong>Cyanostriates:</strong></p>
<p>(1)P): May be found with acetylcholine</p>
<p>(ATF: Neuropeptide Y): may be found with noradrenaline</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="autonomic-receptors">AUTONOMIC RECEPTORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#autonomic-receptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>These are the receptors for the neurotransmitters in the autonomic nervous system (i.e. receptors for acetylcholine and noradrenaline)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="acetylcholine-receptors">Acetylcholine receptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acetylcholine-receptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li><strong>Nicotine receptors (N)</strong></li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Stimulated by small amount of nicotine (a chemical substance found in tobacco)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Found at the following sites:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sympathetic ganglia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Parasympathetic ganglia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Neuromuscular junction</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Adrenal medulla</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The brain</p>
</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li><strong>Muscarinic receptors (M)</strong></li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Stimulated by small amount of muscarine (a chemical substance excreted in urine of taripules)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Found at the following sites:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>All organs supplied by postganglionic cholinergic nerves (these include all organs in the body supplied by autonomic neurons except ventricles of the heart and blood vessels of the skin, abdominal viscera and the kidney which are supplied only by sympathetic, without parasympathetic supply).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The brain</p>
</li>
</ul>

<p>Remember that:</p>

<li>Noradrenaline acts better on a receptors than on β receptors while adrenaline acts better on β receptors than on a receptors.</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="effects-of-symp-and-parasymp-stimulation">EFFECTS OF SYMP. AND PARASYMP. STIMULATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effects-of-symp-and-parasymp-stimulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>At postganglionic parasympathetic neurons are discharged, and at postganglionic sympathetic neurons are nondiverergic.</p>
<p>Therefore sympathetic effects are generally mediated by misadrenaline and parasympathetic effects are generally mediated by acetylcholine.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="examples-of-these-effects-on-various-organs-in-the-body">Examples of these effects on various organs in the body:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples-of-these-effects-on-various-organs-in-the-body" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Organ</th><th>Sympathetic effect</th><th>Parasympathetic effect</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Eye pupil</td><td>Dilation of contrasts the dilator pupilles muscle/ alpha receptors)</td><td>Constipation (2 controls the constrictor pupilles muscle/ muscarinic fix)</td></tr><tr><td>Salivary glands</td><td>Stimulates secretion (small amount, mucus in consistency)</td><td>Stimulated secretion (large amount, watery/o consistency)</td></tr><tr><td>Bronchioles</td><td>Bronchostation/ through beta 2 ifis</td><td>Bronchoconstriction through muscarinic fix</td></tr><tr><td>Heart rate</td><td>Increased (Positive chronotropic)/ beta 1</td><td>Decreased (Negative chronotropic/ Muscarin)</td></tr><tr><td>Contractility of the heart</td><td>Increased Positive inotropic</td><td>No direct effect on contractility (it does no supply the ventricles)</td></tr><tr><td>GIT motility &amp; Secretions</td><td>Decreased (inhibitory contrasts the sphincters and relaxes the walls)</td><td>Increased (excitatory, it relaxes the sphincters and contrasts the walls)</td></tr><tr><td>Midlution &amp; Defecation reflexes</td><td>Art involved in the reflex; i.d. its stimulation inhibits these reflexes</td><td>Excitatory (contracts the walls of the bladder &amp; rectum &amp; relaxes their sphincters)</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>55
The state of mechanical engineering</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blockers">BLOCKERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blockers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Stock the actions of neurotransmitters at their receptors</li>
<li>Two types:</li>
<li>Competitive blockers</li>
<li>Compete with the neurotransmitter (NT) for binding with its receptors.</li>
<li>The affinity of the receptor for the blocker is higher than for the NT.</li>
<li>The blocker occupies the receptor without producing any response.</li>
<li>Depolarizing blockers</li>
<li>Causes prolonged depolarization of the receptor.</li>
<li>The receptor becomes in state of refractory period, therefore it does not respond to the neurotransmitter.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blockers">BLOCKERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blockers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Stock the actions of neurotransmitters at their receptors</li>
<li>Two types:</li>
<li>Competitive blockers</li>
<li>Compete with the neurotransmitter (NT) for binding with its receptors.</li>
<li>The affinity of the receptor for the blocker is higher than for the NT.</li>
<li>The blocker occupies the receptor without producing any response.</li>
<li>Depolarizing blockers</li>
<li>Causes prolonged depolarization of the receptor.</li>
<li>The receptor becomes in state of refractory period, therefore it does not respond to the neurotransmitter.</li>
</ul>
<p>The cost of medical physiology / IT advice</p>

The view of medical psychology 17 years
56
The view of medical psychology 17 years</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blockers-of-acetylcholine">Blockers of Acetylcholine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blockers-of-acetylcholine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Nicotinic blockers:</li>
<li>Blockers of acetylcholine at nicotinic receptors</li>
<li>Competitive blockers:</li>
<li>Curare (at the reuptopuecular junction)</li>
<li>Hexamethonium (at the ganglia)</li>
<li>Depolarizing blocker:</li>
<li>Large amount of nicotine</li>
<li>Mucosemic blockers:</li>
<li>Competitive blockers:</li>
<li>Atropine</li>
<li>Doxycycline (hypocine)</li>
<li>Depolarizing blocker:</li>
<li>Large amount of muscarine</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blockers-of-noradrenaline">Blockers of noradrenaline<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blockers-of-noradrenaline" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Alpha blockers:</li>
<li>Phentolamine</li>
<li>Frazosin (alpha 1)</li>
<li>Volontione (Alpha 2)</li>
<li>Beta blockers:</li>
<li>Propranolol</li>
<li>(non selective blocker; blocks beta 1 &amp; beta 2 receptors)</li>
<li>Atenolol</li>
<li>(selective blocker; blocks beta 1)</li>
<li>Butoxamine</li>
<li>(selective blocker; blocks beta 2)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blockers-of-acetylcholine">Blockers of Acetylcholine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blockers-of-acetylcholine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Nicotinic blockers:</li>
<li>Blockers of acetylcholine at nicotinic receptors</li>
<li>Competitive blockers:</li>
<li>Curare (at the reuptopuecular junction)</li>
<li>Hexamethonium (at the ganglia)</li>
<li>Depolarizing blocker:</li>
<li>Large amount of nicotine</li>
<li>Mucosemic blockers:</li>
<li>Competitive blockers:</li>
<li>Atropine</li>
<li>Doxycycline (hypocine)</li>
<li>Depolarizing blocker:</li>
<li>Large amount of muscarine</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blockers-of-noradrenaline">Blockers of noradrenaline<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blockers-of-noradrenaline" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Alpha blockers:</li>
<li>Phentolamine</li>
<li>Frazosin (alpha 1)</li>
<li>Volontione (Alpha 2)</li>
<li>Beta blockers:</li>
<li>Propranolol</li>
<li>(non selective blocker; blocks beta 1 &amp; beta 2 receptors)</li>
<li>Atenolol</li>
<li>(selective blocker; blocks beta 1)</li>
<li>Butoxamine</li>
<li>(selective blocker; blocks beta 2)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blockers-of-acetylcholine">Blockers of Acetylcholine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blockers-of-acetylcholine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Nicotinic blockers:</li>
<li>Blockers of acetylcholine at nicotinic receptors</li>
<li>Competitive blockers:</li>
<li>Curare (at the reuptopuecular junction)</li>
<li>Hexamethonium (at the ganglia)</li>
<li>Depolarizing blocker:</li>
<li>Large amount of nicotine</li>
<li>Mucosemic blockers:</li>
<li>Competitive blockers:</li>
<li>Atropine</li>
<li>Doxycycline (hypocine)</li>
<li>Depolarizing blocker:</li>
<li>Large amount of muscarine</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blockers-of-noradrenaline">Blockers of noradrenaline<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blockers-of-noradrenaline" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Alpha blockers:</li>
<li>Phentolamine</li>
<li>Frazosin (alpha 1)</li>
<li>Volontione (Alpha 2)</li>
<li>Beta blockers:</li>
<li>Propranolol</li>
<li>(non selective blocker; blocks beta 1 &amp; beta 2 receptors)</li>
<li>Atenolol</li>
<li>(selective blocker; blocks beta 1)</li>
<li>Butoxamine</li>
<li>(selective blocker; blocks beta 2)</li>
</ul>
<p>60
The view of medical physiology 17 volume</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abnormalities">ABNORMALITIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="doctor-s-syndrome">Doctor's Syndrome<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#doctor-s-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Results from damage to sympathetic neurons that supply the face</li>
<li>The damage may occur at any site along the course of sympathetic neurons which originate from the hypothalamus, descend through the brain stem, emerge from the upper thoracic segments, synapse at the superior, middle or inferior cervical ganglia and then pass with blood vessels to supply the face. However, the damage usually occurs at the neck (cervical sympathectomy).</li>
<li>Examples of the causes:</li>
<li>Apical lung tumor</li>
<li>Surgical trauma at the neck</li>
<li>Hypothalamic lesions</li>
<li>The syndrome is characterized by the following signs (on the affected side of the face):</li>
<li>Ptosis (drooping of the upper eye lid)</li>
<li>Meiosis (constriction of the eye pupil)</li>
<li>Arrhythmia (dryness, due to loss of sweating)</li>
<li>Enophthalmos (abnormal recession of the eyeball in the orbit)</li>
<li>Rubor (redness, due to vasodilatation)</li>
<li>Calor (redness, due to vasodilatation)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="myasthenia-gravis">Myasthenia Gravis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#myasthenia-gravis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Results from damage to acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junctions</li>
<li>The damage is caused by auto-antibodies induced by unknown mechanism</li>
<li>Develops in females more than males</li>
<li>It is characterized by:</li>
<li>Muscle weakness (especially after repeated movement)</li>
<li>Ptosis (drooping of the upper eye lid)</li>
</ul>
<p>61
The view of medical physiology 17 volume</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abnormalities">ABNORMALITIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="doctor-s-syndrome">Doctor's Syndrome<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#doctor-s-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Results from damage to sympathetic neurons that supply the face</li>
<li>The damage may occur at any site along the course of sympathetic neurons which originate from the hypothalamus, descend through the brain stem, emerge from the upper thoracic segments, synapse at the superior, middle or inferior cervical ganglia and then pass with blood vessels to supply the face. However, the damage usually occurs at the neck (cervical sympathectomy).</li>

<li>Apical lung tumor</li>
<li>Surgical trauma at the neck</li>
<li>Hypothalamic lesions</li>

<li>Ptosis (drooping of the upper eye lid)</li>
<li>Meiosis (constriction of the eye pupil)</li>
<li>Arrhythmia (dryness, due to loss of sweating)</li>
<li>Enophthalmos (abnormal recession of the eyeball in the orbit)</li>
<li>Rubor (redness, due to vasodilatation)</li>
<li>Calor (redness, due to vasodilatation)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="myasthenia-gravis">Myasthenia Gravis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#myasthenia-gravis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abnormalities">ABNORMALITIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="doctor-s-syndrome">Doctor's Syndrome<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#doctor-s-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Results from damage to sympathetic neurons that supply the face</li>
<li>The damage may occur at any site along the course of sympathetic neurons which originate from the hypothalamus, descend through the brain stem, emerge from the upper thoracic segments, synapse at the superior, middle or inferior cervical ganglia and then pass with blood vessels to supply the face. However, the damage usually occurs at the neck (cervical sympathectomy).</li>
<li>Examples of the causes:</li>
<li>Apical lung tumor</li>
<li>Surgical trauma at the neck</li>
<li>Hypothalamic lesions</li>
<li>The syndrome is characterized by the following signs (on the affected side of the face):</li>
<li>Ptosis (drooping of the upper eye lid)</li>
<li>Meiosis (constriction of the eye pupil)</li>
<li>Arrhythmia (dryness, due to loss of sweating)</li>
<li>Enophthalmos (abnormal recession of the eyeball in the orbit)</li>
<li>Rubor (redness, due to vasodilatation)</li>
<li>Calor (redness, due to vasodilatation)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="myasthenia-gravis">Myasthenia Gravis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#myasthenia-gravis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Results from damage to acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junctions</li>
<li>The damage is caused by auto-antibodies induced by unknown mechanism</li>
<li>Develops in females more than males</li>
<li>It is characterized by:</li>
<li>Muscle weakness (especially after repeated movement)</li>
<li>Ptosis (drooping of the upper eye lid)</li>
</ul>
<p>98
The issue of medical physiology 2009
99
The issue of medicine physiology 2009</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Weakness of respiratory muscles (the patient may die due to respiratory failure).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Treatment:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>By anti- acetylcholine esterase (e.g. neostigmine); to decrease break down of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction and allow it to act on the remaining receptors.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Other modalities of treatment include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Use of steroids to inhibit production of the auto-antibodies by lymphocyte.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Decrease of further breakdown of acetylcholine receptors by plasmapheresis (a machine that eliminates the autoantibodies that plasma).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Table 3.2: Effects of drugs acting on autonomic receptors</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>ATROPHIE</th><th>PROPHANOLOL</th><th>SALBUTANOL</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Mechanism of action</td><td>Muscarinic blocker</td><td>β1 &amp; β2 blocker (antagonist)</td><td>β2 agonist (stimulant)</td></tr><tr><td>Effects</td><td>↑ Heart rate ↓ GIT motility &amp; secretion</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Bronchodilation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Dilatation of the eye pupil</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Drias mouth (↓ saliva) | ↓ Heart rate &amp; contractility
↓ Cardiac output
↓ Blood pressure</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Vasoconstriction</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Broncho-constriction | - Bronchodilation
↑ Heart rate (side-effect, because although it is β2 agonist, it may react with β1 receptors resulting in tachycardia)  |</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Weakness of respiratory muscles (the patient may die due to respiratory failure).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Treatment:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>By anti- acetylcholine esterase (e.g. neostigmine); to decrease break down of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction and allow it to act on the remaining receptors.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Other modalities of treatment include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Use of steroids to inhibit production of the auto-antibodies by lymphocyte.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Decrease of further breakdown of acetylcholine receptors by plasmapheresis (a machine that eliminates the autoantibodies that plasma).</p>
</li>
</ul>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="questions-for-self-association-above-if-not">QUESTIONS FOR SELF-ASSOCIATION ABOVE (IF NOT)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#questions-for-self-association-above-if-not" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>The somatic nervous system differs from the autonomic nervous system because:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>It has sensory and motor neurons</li>
<li>Its neurons release acetylcholine</li>
<li>some of its neurons arise from the spinal cord</li>
<li>It has nicotinic receptors</li>
<li>It causes skeletal muscle contraction</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Effects of the parasympathetic nervous system include all the following except:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Increase</li>
<li>partial erection</li>
<li>increased gastrointestinal motility</li>
<li>decreased airway resistance</li>
<li>bradycardia</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>Stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system results in:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>bradycardia</li>
<li>recruitment in the cardiac muscle</li>
<li>dilatation of skeletal muscle arterioles</li>
<li>excessive salivary secretion</li>
<li>negative inotropic effect</li>
</ul>
<ol start="4">
<li>Acetylcholine:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>is released by all postganglionic sympathetic neurons</li>
<li>is released from the adrenal medulla</li>
<li>causes contraction of skeletal muscles</li>
<li>is blocked by propranolol</li>
<li>has alpha and beta receptors</li>
</ul>
<ol start="5">
<li>The drug that blocks muscarinic receptors results in:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>bradycardia</li>
<li>excessive salivation</li>
<li>elevation of blood pressure</li>
<li>micturition</li>
<li>sweating</li>
</ul>
<ol start="6">
<li>Nicotinic receptors are found in:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>arterioles of skeletal muscle</li>
<li>motor and plates of skeletal muscles</li>
<li>sweat glands in the skin</li>
<li>small intestine</li>
<li>ventricles of the heart</li>
</ul>
<ol start="7">
<li>The nicotinic cholinergic receptors at the autonomic ganglia are:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>blocked by curate</li>
<li>stimulated by salbutamol</li>
</ul>
<p>34
The text of medical physiology 14th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="questions-for-self-association-above-if-not">QUESTIONS FOR SELF-ASSOCIATION ABOVE (IF NOT)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#questions-for-self-association-above-if-not" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>The somatic nervous system differs from the autonomic nervous system because:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>It has sensory and motor neurons</li>
<li>Its neurons release acetylcholine</li>
<li>some of its neurons arise from the spinal cord</li>
<li>It has nicotinic receptors</li>
<li>it causes skeletal muscle contraction</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Effects of the parasympathetic nervous system include all the following except:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>increase</li>
<li>partial erection</li>
<li>increased gastrointestinal motility</li>
<li>decreased airway resistance</li>
<li>bradycardia</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>Stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system results in:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>bradycardia</li>
<li>recruitment in the cardiac muscle</li>
<li>dilatation of skeletal muscle arterioles</li>
<li>excessive salivary secretion</li>
<li>negative inotropic effect</li>
</ul>
<ol start="4">
<li>Acetylcholine:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>is released by all postganglionic sympathetic neurons</li>
<li>is released from the adrenal medulla</li>
<li>causes contraction of skeletal muscles</li>
<li>is blocked by propranolol</li>
<li>has alpha and beta receptors</li>
</ul>
<ol start="5">
<li>The drug that blocks muscarinic receptors results in:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>bradycardia</li>
<li>excessive salivation</li>
<li>elevation of blood pressure</li>
<li>micturition</li>
<li>sweating</li>
</ul>
<ol start="6">
<li>Nicotinic receptors are found in:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>arterioles of skeletal muscle</li>
<li>motor and plates of skeletal muscles</li>
<li>sweat glands in the skin</li>
<li>small intestine</li>
<li>ventricles of the heart</li>
</ul>
<ol start="7">
<li>The nicotinic cholinergic receptors at the autonomic ganglia are:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>blocked by curate</li>
<li>stimulated by salbutamol</li>
</ul>
<p>35
The text of medical physiology 14th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="questions-for-self-association-above-if-not">QUESTIONS FOR SELF-ASSOCIATION ABOVE (IF NOT)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#questions-for-self-association-above-if-not" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>The somatic nervous system differs from the autonomic nervous system because:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>It has sensory and motor neurons</li>
<li>Its neurons release acetylcholine</li>
<li>some of its neurons arise from the spinal cord</li>
<li>It has nicotinic receptors</li>
<li>it causes skeletal muscle contraction</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Effects of the parasympathetic nervous system include all the following except:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>increase</li>
<li>partial erection</li>
<li>increased gastrointestinal motility</li>
<li>decreased airway resistance</li>
<li>bradycardia</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>Stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system results in:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>bradycardia</li>
<li>recruitment in the cardiac muscle</li>
<li>dilatation of skeletal muscle arterioles</li>
<li>excessive salivary secretion</li>
<li>negative inotropic effect</li>
</ul>
<ol start="4">
<li>Acetylcholine:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>is released by all postganglionic sympathetic neurons</li>
<li>is released from the adrenal medulla</li>
<li>causes contraction of skeletal muscles</li>
<li>is blocked by propranolol</li>
<li>has alpha and beta receptors</li>
</ul>
<ol start="5">
<li>The drug that blocks muscarinic receptors results in:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>bradycardia</li>
<li>excessive salivation</li>
<li>elevation of blood pressure</li>
<li>micturition</li>
<li>sweating</li>
</ul>
<ol start="6">
<li>Nicotinic receptors are found in:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>arterioles of skeletal muscle</li>
<li>motor and plates of skeletal muscles</li>
<li>sweat glands in the skin</li>
<li>small intestine</li>
<li>ventricles of the heart</li>
</ul>
<ol start="7">
<li>The nicotinic cholinergic receptors at the autonomic ganglia are:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>blocked by curate</li>
<li>stimulated by salbutamol</li>
</ul>

The cost of medical physiology of adults
139
The cost of general physiology of adults</p>
<p>c. stimulated with noradrenaline
d. blocked by hexamethonium
e. identical to those in skeletal muscles</p>
<ol start="8">
<li>
<p>Stimulation of beta 1 receptors results in all the following except:
a. breakdown of adipose tissue
b. increased cardiac output
c. release of renin from the juice-glomerular cells
d. tachycardia
e. vasoconstriction</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Adrenal medullary cells are stimulated by:
a. dopamine
b. GABA
c. adrenaline
d. acetylcholine
e. nor-adrenaline</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Dopamine is:
a. released by all autonomic ganglia
b. an excitatory neurotransmitter
c. an acetylcholine derivative
d. a noradrenaline precursor
e. the main neurotransmitter released by the adrenal medulla</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sympathetic nerves
a. release noradrenalin from pre-ganglionic fibres
b. release adrenalin from post- ganglionic fibres
c. are stimulated during sleep
d. release of acetylcholine by some postganglionic fibres
e. are mostly myelinated</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system results in:
a. tachycardia through β2 receptors
b. constriction of skin blood vessels through β1
c. violation of the eye pupil through β1 receptors
d. contraction of intestinal wall through alpha receptors
e. sweating through muscarinic receptors</p>
</li>
</ol>
