<p>CHAPTER 4
TEMPERATURE AND METABOLIC RATE</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="temperature">TEMPERATURE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#temperature" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="normal-body-temperature">Normal body temperature<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#normal-body-temperature" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The temperature of the internal structures of the body is called the core body temperature.</li>
<li>It equals 37°C (± 0.5°C) or 98.0°F (± 1.0°F)</li>
<li>The core body temperature differs from the temperature of the skin because:</li>
<li>The temperature of the skin is affected directly by the temperature of the external environment.</li>
<li>The subcutaneous fat layer beneath the skin acts as insulator. It preserves the core body temperature and prevents the effect of the external environment.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="remember-that">Remember that:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remember-that" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Skin vasodilatation (as occurs when the core body temperature rises) allows blood to pass through the subcutaneous fat layer and comes under the skin to facilitate heat loss to the outside. The opposite occurs when the core body temperature falls.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="measurement-of-the-core-body-temperature">Measurement of the core body temperature<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#measurement-of-the-core-body-temperature" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The device used is the clinical thermometer.</li>
<li>The sites used for measurement are:</li>
<li>The rectum</li>
<li>The most accurate site</li>
<li>Not socially acceptable</li>
<li>Used in children and unconscious patients</li>
<li>The mouth (under the tongue)</li>
<li>The most frequently used site (Socially acceptable)</li>
</ul>
<p>101</p>
<p>CHAPTER 4
TEMPERATURE AND METABOLIC RATE</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="temperature">TEMPERATURE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#temperature" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<li>The core body temperature differs from the temperature of the skin because:</li>

<p>101</p>
<p>Section 4.1 of the following (1) pages</p>
<ul>
<li>Offers eighty-four the core body temperature (less by 0.5°C)</li>
<li>Affected by hyperventilation, smoking and recently ingested food or drink.</li>
</ul>
<p>Other less frequently used after:</p>
<ul>
<li>The axilla (less accurate, affected by the external environment)</li>
<li>The ear (less accurate, affected by the external environment)</li>
<li>Freshly passed urine (more accurate "but used for research purposes only")</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="regulation-of-body-temperature">Regulation of body temperature<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#regulation-of-body-temperature" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Maintenance of normal body temperature is an important goal in homeostasis.</li>
<li>This is because disturbance in body temperature affects:</li>
<li>Activity of enzymes</li>
<li>Speed of metabolic reactions within the body</li>
<li>Activity of the various systems in the body. For example:</li>
<li>The nervous system: higher body temperature increases conduction in neurons whereas lower body temperature decreases conduction.</li>
<li>The cardiovascular system: higher body temperature causes tachycardia and increases contractility whereas lower body temperature does the reverse.</li>
<li>The respiratory system: higher body temperature causes hyperventilation whereas lower body temperature causes hypoventilation.</li>
<li>The endocrine system: higher body temperature decreases release of thyroid hormones whereas lower body temperature increases release of thyroid hormones.</li>
</ul>
<p>Regulation of body temperature within narrow limits is not only a characteristic of humans, it is also a characteristic of birds and mammals. For this reason this are described as "warm blooded" or "somewhere's".</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Other vertebrates like reptiles, amphibius and fish are "cold blooded" or "pseudothermic" because the range of their body temperature is rather wide.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Invertebrates, on the other hand, can not regulate their body temperature.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Offers slightly from the core body temperature (less by 0.5°C)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Affected by hyperventilation, smoking and recently ingested food or drink.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Other less frequently used after:</p>
<ul>
<li>The axilla (less accurate, affected by the external environment)</li>
<li>The ear (less accurate, affected by the external environment)</li>
<li>Freshly passed urine (more accurate "but used for research purposes only")</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="regulation-of-body-temperature">Regulation of body temperature<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#regulation-of-body-temperature" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Maintenance of normal body temperature is an important goal in homeostasis.</li>
<li>This is because disturbance in body temperature affects:</li>
<li>Activity of enzymes</li>
<li>Speed of metabolic reactions within the body</li>
<li>Activity of the various systems in the body. For example:</li>
<li>The nervous system: higher body temperature increases conduction in neurons whereas lower body temperature decreases conduction.</li>
<li>The cardiovascular system: higher body temperature causes tachycardia and increases contractility whereas lower body temperature does the reverse.</li>
<li>The respiratory system: higher body temperature causes hyperventilation whereas lower body temperature causes hypoventilation.</li>
<li>The endocrine system: higher body temperature decreases release of thyroid hormones whereas lower body temperature increases release of thyroid hormones.</li>
</ul>
<p>Regulation of body temperature within narrow limits is not only a characteristic of humans, it is also a characteristic of birds and mammals. For this reason this are described as "warm blooded" or "somewhere's".</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Other vertebrates like reptiles, amphibius and fish are "cold blooded" or "pseudothermic" because the range of their body temperature is rather wide.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Invertebrates, on the other hand, can not regulate their body temperature.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Offers slightly from the core body temperature (less by 0.5°C)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Affected by hyperventilation, smoking and recently ingested food or drink.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Other less frequently used after:</p>
<ul>
<li>The axilla (less accurate, affected by the external environment)</li>
<li>The ear (less accurate, affected by the external environment)</li>
<li>Freshly passed urine (more accurate "but used for research purposes only")</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="regulation-of-body-temperature">Regulation of body temperature<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#regulation-of-body-temperature" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Maintenance of normal body temperature is an important goal in homeostasis.</li>
<li>This is because disturbance in body temperature affects:</li>
<li>Activity of enzymes</li>
<li>Speed of metabolic reactions within the body</li>
<li>Activity of the various systems in the body. For example:</li>
<li>The nervous system: higher body temperature increases conduction in neurons whereas lower body temperature decreases conduction.</li>
<li>The cardiovascular system: higher body temperature causes tachycardia and increases contractility whereas lower body temperature does the reverse.</li>
<li>The respiratory system: higher body temperature causes hyperventilation whereas lower body temperature causes hypoventilation.</li>
<li>The endocrine system: higher body temperature decreases release of thyroid hormones whereas lower body temperature increases release of thyroid hormones.</li>
</ul>
<p>Regulation of body temperature within narrow limits is not only a characteristic of humans, it is also a characteristic of birds and mammals. For this reason this are described as "warm blooded" or "somewhere's".</p>
<ul>
<li>Other vertebrates like reptiles, amphibius and fish are "cold blooded" or pseudothermic because the range of their body temperature is rather wide.</li>
<li>Invertebrates, on the other hand, can not regulate their body temperature.</li>
</ul>
<p>102
The role of medical physiology in cancer
103
The role of medical physiology in cancer</p>
<p>132
The temperature regulatory center:</p>
<ul>
<li>There is a center specialized for control of body temperature located in the hypothalamus, known as the temperature regulatory center.</li>
<li>The center controls heat loss &amp; heat gain (the anterior hypothalamus controls heat loss &amp; the posterior hypothalamus controls heat gain.</li>
<li>Notice that to maintain constant body temperature, the degree of heat loss should always be balanced by an equivalent degree of heat gain.</li>
</ul>
<p>Heat loss:
Heat is less from the body by:</p>
<ol>
<li>Conduction</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Transfer of heat between objects in contact with each other (From an object with higher temperature to another with lower temperature).</li>
<li>Conduction occurs for either heat loss or heat gain, depending on the level of body temperature.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Conversion</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Transfer of heat away from a surface by successive currents of air or water (from the object to the air or water currents, if they have temperature lower than that of the object).</li>
<li>Convection occurs for either heat loss or heat gain, depending on the level of body temperature.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>Radiation</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Transfer of heat between objects not in contact with each other (from that of higher temperature to another with lower temperature).</li>
<li>Radiation occurs for either heat loss or heat gain, depending on the level of body temperature, compared to the temperature of the water or air currents.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="4">
<li>Evaporation</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Vaporization of water molecules from a surface, taking heat.</li>
<li>For example, evaporation of sweat from the surface of the body or evaporation of water from the mucus membranes during respiration.</li>
</ul>
<p>133
The term of residual physiological <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">V^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> values</p>

<p>135
The term of residual physiological <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">V^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> values</p>
<ul>
<li>Notice that vaporization of 1g of water removes about 0.6 kcal of heat.</li>
<li>During exercise, sweat secretion may reach 1.6 L/h. Evaporation of the volume results in loss of more than 900 kcal of heat per hour.</li>
<li>Evaporation occurs for heat loss only (heat is always lost, not gained by evaporation).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="heat-gain">Heat gain<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#heat-gain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The body gains heat by:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-metabolism">1- Metabolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-metabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Metabolism of all types of energy substrate, especially brown fat, produces considerable heat.</li>
<li>Brown fat is more abundant in infants than adults: it is found many between scapulae and at the raps of the neck. Unlike the white fat, it has no sympathetic innervation and high metabolic activity.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="2-muscular-activity">2- Muscular activity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-muscular-activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Contraction of muscles is a major source of heat. This may be related voluntarily (e.g. exercise) or involuntarily (e.g. shivering).</li>
<li>Shivering is stimulated when the body temperature reaches 30.5°C.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="3-food-intake-specific-dynamic-action-of-food">3- Food intake (Specific dynamic action of food)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-food-intake-specific-dynamic-action-of-food" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Obligatory energy release that occurs during assimilation of food with its digestive system (i.e. before absorption).</li>
<li>The energy release of specific dynamic action of food is highest for potera than for carbohydrates or fats.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="4-from-the-environment">4- From the environment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-from-the-environment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>By combustion, convection or radiation (notice that these mechanisms are suitable for both heat loss and heat gain).</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Dynamical diet</strong>: In a hot weather, combustion, convection and radiation are all for heat gain; the only way for heat loss is through evaporation if sweating. However, in a very humid environment sweating occurs within evaporation. Therefore the temperature of the body is not decreased.</p>
<p>134</p>
<p>This note of method (dynamical) 135</p>
<ul>
<li>Notice that vaporization of 1g of water removes about 0.6 kcal of heat.</li>
<li>During exercise, sweat secretion may reach 1.6 L/h. Evaporation of the volume results in loss of more than 900 kcal of heat per hour.</li>
<li>Evaporation occurs for heat loss only (heat is always lost, not gained by evaporation).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="heat-gain">Heat gain<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#heat-gain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The body gains heat by:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-metabolism">1- Metabolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-metabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Metabolism of all types of energy substrate, especially brown fat, produces considerable heat.</li>
<li>Brown fat is more abundant in infants than adults: it is found many between scapulae and at the raps of the neck. Unlike the white fat, it has no sympathetic innervation and high metabolic activity.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="2-muscular-activity">2- Muscular activity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-muscular-activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Contraction of muscles is a major source of heat. This may be related voluntarily (e.g. exercise) or involuntarily (e.g. shivering).</li>
<li>Shivering is stimulated when the body temperature reaches 35.5°C.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="3-food-intake-specific-dynamic-action-of-food">3- Food intake (Specific dynamic action of food)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-food-intake-specific-dynamic-action-of-food" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Obligatory energy release that occurs during assimilation of food with its digestive system (i.e. before absorption).</li>
<li>The energy release of specific dynamic action of food is highest for potera than for carbohydrates or fats.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="4-from-the-environment">4- From the environment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-from-the-environment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>By combustion, convection or radiation (notice that these mechanisms are suitable for both heat loss and heat gain).</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Dynamical diet</strong>: In a hot weather, combustion, convection and radiation are all for heat gain; the only way for heat loss is through evaporation if sweating. However, in a very humid environment sweating occurs within evaporation. Therefore the temperature of the body is not decreased.</p>
<p>135</p>
<p>This note of method (dynamical) 136</p>
<ul>
<li>Notice that vaporization of 1g of water removes about 0.6 kcal of heat.</li>
<li>During exercise, sweat secretion may reach 1.6 L/h. Evaporation of the volume results in loss of more than 900 kcal of heat per hour.</li>
<li>Evaporation occurs for heat loss only (heat is always lost, not gained by evaporation).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="heat-gain">Heat gain<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#heat-gain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The body gains heat by:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-metabolism">1- Metabolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-metabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Metabolism of all types of energy substrate, especially brown fat, produces considerable heat.</li>
<li>Brown fat is more abundant in infants than adults: it is found many between scapulae and at the raps of the neck. Unlike the white fat, it has no sympathetic innervation and high metabolic activity.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="2-muscular-activity">2- Muscular activity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-muscular-activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Contraction of muscles is a major source of heat. This may be related voluntarily (e.g. exercise) or involuntarily (e.g. shivering).</li>
<li>Shivering is stimulated when the body temperature reaches 35.5°C.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="3-food-intake-specific-dynamic-action-of-food">3- Food intake (Specific dynamic action of food)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-food-intake-specific-dynamic-action-of-food" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Obligatory energy release that occurs during assimilation of food with its digestive system (i.e. before absorption).</li>
<li>The energy release of specific dynamic action of food is highest for potera than for carbohydrates or fats.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="4-from-the-environment">4- From the environment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-from-the-environment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>By combustion, convection or radiation (notice that these mechanisms are suitable for both heat loss and heat gain).</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Dynamical diet</strong>: In a hot weather, combustion, convection and radiation are all for heat gain; the only way for heat loss is through evaporation if sweating. However, in a very humid environment sweating occurs within evaporation. Therefore the temperature of the body is not decreased.</p>
<p>136</p>
<p>This note of method (dynamical) 137</p>
<p>122
The care of medical physiology 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="body-responses-to-a-hot-environment">Body responses to a hot environment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#body-responses-to-a-hot-environment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Due to the direct effect of a hot environment, the temperature of the body starts to rise.</p>
<p>This rise is detected by thermoreceptors located peripherally in the skin and centrally in the spinal cord and hypothalamus.</p>
<p>The peripheral and central chemoreceptors send their impulses to the temperature regulatory center in the hypothalamus.</p>
<p>The center, to correct the body temperature, increases heat loss (by the anterior hypothalamus) &amp; decreases heat gain (by the posterior hypothalamus).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="heat-loss-is-increased-by">Heat loss is increased by:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#heat-loss-is-increased-by" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Sweating (to increase evaporation from the skin)</li>
<li>Vasodilatation (to increase blood supply to the skin, for radiation)</li>
<li>Increased respiration (to increase evaporation from the mucus membranes)</li>
<li>Behavioral changes to increase heat loss, these include:</li>
<li>Stretching at sleep (to increase surface area for radiation)</li>
<li>Light clothes and cold drinks</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="heat-gain-is-decreased-by">Heat gain is decreased by:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#heat-gain-is-decreased-by" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Decreased metabolism, decreased food intake and decreased muscular activity</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="body-responses-to-a-cold-environment">Body responses to a cold environment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#body-responses-to-a-cold-environment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Due to the direct effect of the cold environment, the temperature of the body starts to drop.</p>
<p>This drop is detected by peripheral and central thermoreceptors.</p>
<p>The thermoreceptors send impulses to activate the temperature regulatory center in the hypothalamus.</p>
<p>123
The care of medical physiology 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="body-responses-to-a-hot-environment">Body responses to a hot environment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#body-responses-to-a-hot-environment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Due to the direct effect of a hot environment, the temperature of the body starts to rise.</p>
<p>This rise is detected by thermoreceptors located peripherally in the skin and centrally in the spinal cord and hypothalamus.</p>
<p>The peripheral and central chemoreceptors send their impulses to the temperature regulatory center in the hypothalamus.</p>
<p>The center, to correct the body temperature, increases heat loss (by the anterior hypothalamus) &amp; decreases heat gain (by the posterior hypothalamus).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="heat-loss-is-increased-by">Heat loss is increased by:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#heat-loss-is-increased-by" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Sweating (to increase evaporation from the skin)</li>
<li>Vasodilatation (to increase blood supply to the skin, for radiation)</li>
<li>Increased respiration (to increase evaporation from the mucus membranes)</li>
<li>Behavioral changes to increase heat loss, these include:</li>
<li>Stretching at sleep (to increase surface area for radiation)</li>
<li>Light clothes and cold drinks</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="heat-gain-is-decreased-by">Heat gain is decreased by:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#heat-gain-is-decreased-by" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Decreased metabolism, decreased food intake and decreased muscular activity</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="body-responses-to-a-cold-environment">Body responses to a cold environment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#body-responses-to-a-cold-environment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Due to the direct effect of the cold environment, the temperature of the body starts to drop.</p>
<p>This drop is detected by peripheral and central thermoreceptors.</p>
<p>The thermoreceptors send impulses to activate the temperature regulatory center in the hypothalamus.</p>
<p>124
The care of medical physiology 4th edition</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The center increases heat gain (by the posterior hypothalamus) &amp; decreases heat loss (by the anterior hypothalamus).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Heat gain is increased by:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Increased metabolism</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Increased food intake (the body temperature rises due to the specific dynamic action of food)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Increased muscular activity (smoothing and exercise)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Heat loss is decreased by:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Decreased sweating (to decrease evaporation from the skin)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Vasoconstriction (to decrease blood flow to the skin)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Decreased respiration (to decrease evaporation through the mucus membranes)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Behavioral changes that include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cutting up at sleep (to reduce the surface area). Other behavior changes like heavy, dark-colored clothes and hot drinks increase heat gain.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physiological-variation-in-body-temperature">Physiological variation in body temperature<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physiological-variation-in-body-temperature" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Body temperature varies physiologically according to:</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="age">Age<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#age" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Higher in neonates &lt; children &gt; adults</li>
<li>The higher temperature in neonates and children is due to heat released by metabolic reactions of the growing tissues</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="gender">Gender<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gender" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Higher in males than females of the same age and weight</li>
<li>Due to presence of higher percentage of inactive tissues (fats) in females</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="at-and-following-ovulation">At and following ovulation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#at-and-following-ovulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Due to release of progesterone which has thermogenic effect</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="frequency">Frequency<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#frequency" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Due to higher rate of metabolism (fatal tissues) &amp; higher level of progesterone</li>
<li>The rate of ovulation (fatal tissues) is higher</li>
</ul>
<p>The center increases heat gain (by the posterior hypothalamus) &amp; decreases heat loss (by the anterior hypothalamus).</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Heat gain is increased by:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Increased metabolism</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Increased food intake (the body temperature rises due to the specific dynamic action of food)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Increased muscular activity (smoothing and exercise)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Heat loss is decreased by:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Decreased sweating (to decrease evaporation from the skin)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Vasoconstriction (to decrease blood flow to the skin)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Decreased respiration (to decrease evaporation through the mucus membranes)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Behavioral changes that include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cutting up at sleep (to reduce the surface area). Other behavior changes like heavy, dark-colored clothes and hot drinks increase heat gain</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physiological-variation-in-body-temperature">Physiological variation in body temperature<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physiological-variation-in-body-temperature" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Body temperature varies physiologically according to:</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="age">Age<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#age" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Higher in neonates &lt; children &gt; adults</li>
<li>The higher temperature in neonates and children is due to heat released by metabolic reactions of the growing tissues</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="gender">Gender<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gender" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Higher in males than females of the same age and weight</li>
<li>Due to presence of higher percentage of inactive tissues (fats) in females</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="at-and-following-ovulation">At and following ovulation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#at-and-following-ovulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Due to release of progesterone which has thermogenic effect</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="frequency">Frequency<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#frequency" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Due to higher rate of metabolism (fatal tissues) &amp; higher level of progesterone</li>
<li>The rate of ovulation (fatal tissues) is higher</li>
</ul>
<p>The center increases heat gain (by the posterior hypothalamus) &amp; decreases heat loss (by the anterior hypothalamus).</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Heat gain is increased by:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Increased metabolism</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Increased food intake (the body temperature rises due to the specific dynamic action of food)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Increased muscular activity (smoothing and exercise)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Heat loss is decreased by:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Decreased sweating (to decrease evaporation from the skin)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Vasoconstriction (to decrease blood flow to the skin)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Decreased respiration (to decrease evaporation through the mucus membranes)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Behavioral changes that include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cutting up at sleep (to reduce the surface area). Other behavior changes like heavy, dark-colored clothes and hot drinks increase heat gain</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physiological-variation-in-body-temperature">Physiological variation in body temperature<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physiological-variation-in-body-temperature" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Body temperature varies physiologically according to:</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="age">Age<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#age" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Higher in neonates &lt; children &gt; adults</li>
<li>The higher temperature in neonates and children is due to heat released by metabolic reactions of the growing tissues</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="gender">Gender<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gender" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Higher in males than females of the same age and weight</li>
<li>Due to presence of higher percentage of inactive tissues (fats) in females</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="at-and-following-ovulation">At and following ovulation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#at-and-following-ovulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Due to release of progesterone which has thermogenic effect</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="frequency">Frequency<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#frequency" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Due to higher rate of metabolism (fatal tissues) &amp; higher level of progesterone</li>
<li>The rate of ovulation (fatal tissues) is higher</li>
</ul>
<p>107
The area of medical physiology 6th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lactation">Lactation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lactation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>

</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="circulation-increases">Circulation Increases<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#circulation-increases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Normal variation in levels of thyroid hormones and catecholamines results in equivalent variation in body temperature</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="circadian-fluctuation">Circadian fluctuation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#circadian-fluctuation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Body temperature fluctuates normally throughout the day of 0.5–0.7 °C. It is lowest early in the morning and highest at the evening.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="emotions">Emotions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#emotions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Due to unconscious tensing of muscles.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sleep-and-exercise">Sleep and exercise<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sleep-and-exercise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Body temperature rises with muscular activity and drops at sleep.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abnormalities-of-temperature-regulation">Abnormalities of temperature regulation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities-of-temperature-regulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fever-pyrexia">Fever (Pyrexia)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fever-pyrexia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>An important sign of disease (e.g. tonsillitis, pneumonia, typhoid, malaria, malignancies ...)</li>
<li>Caused by endogenous pyrogens (e.g. cytokines released by phagocytic cells, such as interleukin-1 (IL-1), IL-6 and tumor necrosis factor (TNF α), which act to increase body temperature).</li>
<li>Release of the endogenous pyrogens is induced, in most times, by exogenous pyrogens (substances not synthesized by the body such as bacterial toxins).</li>
<li>Interleukins, which can not cross the blood brain barrier to reach the preoptic area in the hypothalamus, induce synthesis of a substance (most probably prostaglandin E₂) to reach that area which is the site of temperature setting in the body (= Thamostat).</li>
<li>Prostaglandin E₂ needs the thermostat from 37°C to a higher level (e.g. 40°C). The subject feels cold, and therefore he develops changes that</li>
</ul>
<p>108
The area of medical physiology 6th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lactation">Lactation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lactation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Due to higher rate of metabolism (breast tissue)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="circulating-hormones">Circulating hormones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#circulating-hormones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>Normal variation in levels of thyroid hormones and catecholamines results in equivalent variation in body temperature</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="circadian-fluctuation">Circadian fluctuation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#circadian-fluctuation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>Body temperature fluctuates normally throughout the day of 0.5–0.7 °C. It is lowest early in the morning and highest at the evening.</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="emotions">Emotions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#emotions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Due to unconscious tensing of muscles.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sleep-and-exercise">Sleep and exercise<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sleep-and-exercise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abnormalities-of-temperature-regulation">Abnormalities of temperature regulation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities-of-temperature-regulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fever-pyrexia">Fever (Pyrexia)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fever-pyrexia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>An important sign of disease (e.g. tonsillitis, pneumonia, typhoid, malaria, malignancies ...)</li>
<li>Caused by endogenous pyrogens (e.g. cytokines released by phagocytic cells, such as interleukin-1 (IL-1), IL-6 and tumor necrosis factor (TNF α), which act to increase body temperature)</li>
<li>Release of the endogenous pyrogens is induced, in most times, by exogenous pyrogens (substances not synthesized by the body such as bacterial toxins).</li>
<li>Interleukins, which can not cross the blood brain barrier to reach the preoptic area in the hypothalamus, induce synthesis of a substance (most probably prostaglandin E₂) to reach that area which is the site of temperature setting in the body (= Thamostat).</li>
<li>Prostaglandin E₂ needs the thermostat from 37°C to a higher level (e.g. 40°C). The subject feels cold, and therefore he develops changes that</li>
</ul>
<p>109
The area of medical physiology 6th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lactation">Lactation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lactation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Due to higher rate of metabolism (breast tissue)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="circulating-hormones">Circulating hormones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#circulating-hormones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Normal variation in levels of thyroid hormones and catecholamines results in equivalent variation in body temperature</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="circadian-fluctuation">Circadian fluctuation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#circadian-fluctuation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Body temperature fluctuates normally throughout the day of 0.5–0.7 °C. It is lowest early in the morning and highest at the evening.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="emotions">Emotions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#emotions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Due to unconscious tensing of muscles.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sleep-and-exercise">Sleep and exercise<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sleep-and-exercise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Body temperature rises with muscular activity and drops at sleep.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abnormalities-of-temperature-regulation">Abnormalities of temperature regulation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities-of-temperature-regulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fever-pyrexia">Fever (Pyrexia)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fever-pyrexia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>An important sign of disease (e.g. tonsillitis, pneumonia, typhoid, malaria, malignancies ...)</li>
<li>Caused by endogenous pyrogens (e.g. cytokines released by phagocytic cells, such as interleukin-1 (IL-1), IL-6 and tumor necrosis factor (TNF α), which act to increase body temperature).</li>
<li>Release of the endogenous pyrogens is induced, in most times, by exogenous pyrogens (substances not synthesized by the body such as bacterial toxins).</li>
<li>Interleukins, which can not cross the blood brain barrier to reach the preoptic area in the hypothalamus, induce synthesis of a substance (most probably prostaglandin E₂) to reach that area which is the site of temperature setting in the body (= Thamostat).</li>
<li>Prostaglandin E₂ needs the thermostat from 37°C to a higher level (e.g. 40°C). The subject feels cold, and therefore he develops changes that</li>
</ul>
<p>elevate the body temperature such as shivering, non-shivering, thermogenesis (breakdown of brown fat) and skin vasoconstriction; these result in fever.</p>
<p>Remember that:</p>
<ul>
<li>Immediately following loss of the prostaglandin effect, the temperature before point returns back to 37°C. Since the body temperature is still higher than 37°C, the subject develops changes to decrease the body temperature such as sweating and vasodilatation of skin blood vessels.</li>
<li>Drugs that decrease synthesis of prostaglandins can treat fever (e.g. Aspirin).</li>
</ul>
<p>Heat stroke:</p>
<ul>
<li>In a hot dry environment, the only way to lose heat is through evaporation of sweating.</li>
<li>Therefore, failure of sweating results in abnormal elevation of body temperature to a degree that affects the activity of the nervous system, resulting in convulsions, coma and even death.</li>
<li>In heat stroke, there is damage to the temperature regulatory center caused by the high environmental temperature. This was confirmed at autopsy. However, the exact mechanism of damage is not well understood.</li>
<li>Sometimes, as in severe exercise, heat stroke may result from failure of the temperature regulatory mechanisms to maintain normal body temperature (i.e. inadequate sweating), due to high rate of heat production by the exercising muscles.</li>
<li>Failure to reduce body temperature is followed by complications of high temperature (convulsions, coma and death).</li>
<li>Treatment should start immediately (e.g. electrical beds to reduce the body temperature gradually or if not available, ice water; However, body temperature should not be lowered quickly).</li>
</ul>
<p>elevate the body temperature such as shivering, non-shivering, thermogenesis (breakdown of brown fat) and skin vasoconstriction; these result in fever.</p>
<p>Remember that:</p>
<ul>
<li>Immediately following loss of the prostaglandin effect, the temperature before point returns back to 37°C. Since the body temperature is still higher than 37°C, the subject develops changes to decrease the body temperature such as sweating and vasodilatation of skin blood vessels.</li>
<li>Drugs that decrease synthesis of prostaglandins can treat fever (e.g. Aspirin).</li>
</ul>
<p>Heat stroke:</p>
<ul>
<li>In a hot dry environment, the only way to lose heat is through evaporation of sweating.</li>
<li>Therefore, failure of sweating results in abnormal elevation of body temperature to a degree that affects the activity of the nervous system, resulting in convulsions, coma and even death.</li>
<li>In heat stroke, there is damage to the temperature regulatory center caused by the high environmental temperature. This was confirmed at autopsy. However, the exact mechanism of damage is not well understood.</li>

<p>108 The case of medical pharmacists 10 years</p>
<p>109 The case of medical pharmacists 10 years</p>
<p>108 The case of medical pharmacists 10 years</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="heat-exhaustion">Heat exhaustion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#heat-exhaustion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>In a hot humid environment, even sweating can not reduce body temperature because it fails to evaporate. For this reason subjects should keep themselves in a well ventilated cold area to lose heat.</li>
<li>In heat exhaustion, there is excessive sweating but with no evaporation.</li>
<li>The body temperature becomes elevated, the activity of the nervous system is affected and the patient develops dehydration (due to the excessive sweating).</li>
<li>If not treated, the temperature regulatory mechanisms eventually fail and the heat exhaustion becomes complicated by heat stroke (permanent damage to temperature center).</li>
<li>Therefore it is important to treat this condition immediately (take the patient to a well ventilated, cold room and give him 10 fluids, in form of normal saline).</li>
</ul>
<p>Table 4.7. Differences between heat stroke and heat exhaustion</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Difference</th><th>Heat stroke</th><th>Heat exhaustion</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Classical environment</td><td>Hot dry</td><td>Hot humid</td></tr><tr><td>Temperature center</td><td>Abnormal</td><td>Normal</td></tr><tr><td>Sweating</td><td>Absent</td><td>Excessive</td></tr><tr><td>Skin</td><td>Hot &amp; dry</td><td>Hot &amp; wet</td></tr><tr><td>Dehydration</td><td>Absent</td><td>Present</td></tr><tr><td>Effects of the high temperature,</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Tachycardia, hyperventilation,</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>convulsions &amp; coma</td><td>Present</td><td>Present</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hoesthedness">Hoesthedness<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hoesthedness" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Diagnosed when rectal temperature is &lt; 35°C.</li>
<li>Characterized by loss of consciousness, bradycardia and decreased respiration.</li>
<li>Occurs due to the direct effect of cold environments on:</li>
</ul>
<p>100</p>
<p>The term of medical physiology is "robotic"</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="heat-exhaustion">Heat exhaustion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#heat-exhaustion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hoesthedness">Hoesthedness<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hoesthedness" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
