<p>118
The view of medical physiology of care</p>
<p>d. Radiation
e. Combustion</p>
<ol start="8">
<li>
<p>Concerning regulation of body temperature:
a. Birds and mammals are pollutionemic
b. The temperature regulatory center is located in the medulla
c. Connection never causes heat gain
d. Shivering occurs when body temperature falls below 36.5 °C
e. Damage to the posterior hypothalamus is expected to cause hypothermia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Heat stroke differs from heat exhaustion because it:
a. Usually occurs in both dry and humid environments
b. A associated with elevated core body temperature
c. Causes tachycardia and impaired level of consciousness
d. Is not characterized by dehydration
e. Is not associated with sweating</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Measurement of the basal metabolic rate requires:
a. fasting for two hours
b. ingestion of a heavy meal
c. moderate exercise during measurement
d. normal body temperature
e. suitable environmental temperature</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Basal metabolism is mainly accounted for by:
a. Energy spent by cardio-respiratory functions
b. Excretions in the endocrine system
c. The sodium potassium pump
d. Maintenance of body temperature
e. Renal tubular mechanisms</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In the body the metabolism of 10 grams of protein would produce approximately:
a. 10 kcal
b. 53 kcal
c. 41 kcal
d. 30 kcal
e. 20 cal</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For measurement of the basal metabolic rate all the following conditions are required except:
a. mental rest
b. phasic rest
c. normal body temperature
d. 12 hours fasting prior to measurement
e. comfortable room temperature</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The specific dynamic action of food is due to:
a. an increase in core body temperature
b. amino acid metabolism in the liver
c. energy expenditure during digestion</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>119
The view of medical physiology of care</p>
<p>d. Radiation
e. Combustion</p>
<ol start="9">
<li>
<p>Concerning regulation of body temperature:
a. Birds and mammals are pollutionemic
b. The temperature regulatory center is located in the medulla
c. Connection never causes heat gain
d. Shivering occurs when body temperature falls below 36.5 °C
e. Damage to the posterior hypothalamus is expected to cause hypothermia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Heat stroke differs from heat exhaustion because it:
a. Usually occurs in both dry and humid environments
b. A associated with elevated core body temperature
c. Causes tachycardia and impaired level of consciousness
d. Is not characterized by dehydration
e. Is not associated with sweating</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Measurement of the basal metabolic rate requires:
a. fasting for two hours
b. ingestion of a heavy meal
c. moderate exercise during measurement
d. normal body temperature
e. suitable environmental temperature</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Basal metabolism is mainly accounted for by:
a. Energy spent by cardio-respiratory functions
b. Excretions in the endocrine system
c. The sodium potassium pump
d. Maintenance of body temperature
e. Renal tubular mechanisms</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In the body the metabolism of 10 grams of protein would produce approximately:
a. 10 kcal
b. 53 kcal
c. 41 kcal
d. 30 kcal
e. 20 cal</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For measurement of the basal metabolic rate all the following conditions are required except:
a. mental rest
b. phasic rest
c. normal body temperature
d. 12 hours fasting prior to measurement
e. comfortable room temperature</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The specific dynamic action of food is due to:
a. an increase in core body temperature
b. amino acid metabolism in the liver
c. energy expenditure during digestion</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>120
The view of medical physiology of care</p>

The view of medical physiology of care</p>
<p>d. hypothalamic sympathetic stimulation
e. secretion of insulin</p>
<ol start="10">
<li>
<p>The basal metabolic rate:
a. is about 300 kcal/kg body weight/day
b. is measured during exercise
c. is measured during exposure to cold environment
d. rises during menstruation and lactation
e. is usually measured two hour following a meal</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>All the following conditions are expected to increase the rate of metabolism in a young woman EXCEPT:
a. Fasting
b. Fever
c. Menstruation
d. Second trimester of pregnancy
e. Cold environment</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The respiratory exchange ratio is:
a. The ratio of CO2 production to O2 consumption during steady states
b. Used to calculate the peak equivalent
c. Used to calculate oxygen debt of organs
d. Negative for the stomach during active secretion of HCL
e. Negative for the brain at rest</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The metabolic rate is increased by all of the following except:
a. After a body temperature
b. After a environmental temperature
c. Increased sympathetic outflow
d. Stress
e. Hypothetical of the thyroid gland</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Which of the following is the main consumer of energy under basal conditions?
a. Heart activity
b. Respiratory muscle activity
c. Sodium potassium pump
d. Skeletal muscle activity
e. Liver metabolism</p>
</li>
</ol>

<p>The rest of the page is for research</p>
<p>CHAPTER 5 HENATGLOST</p>
<p>BLOOD</p>
<ul>
<li>Blood is a type of connective tissue. Like other types of connective tissue consists of cells and intercellular substance.</li>
<li>The cells are: Red blood cells (RBCs) or erythrocytes. White blood cells (WBCs) or leukocytes and Platelets or thrombocytes.</li>
<li>The intercellular substance is called plasma.</li>
<li>Volume of blood is about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>16</mn></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{1}{16}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1901em; vertical-align: -0.345em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8451em;"><span style="top: -2.655em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">16</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.394em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.345em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span> in an average adult male (<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>≈</mo><mn>40</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\approx 40\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4831em;"></span><span class="mrel">≈</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">40%</span></span></span></span></span> of total body weight).</li>
<li>Volume of plasma is about 2.5L (<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>≈</mo><mn>15</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\approx 15\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4831em;"></span><span class="mrel">≈</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">15%</span></span></span></span></span> of total body weight).</li>
<li>The cells in blood can be separated from plasma by centrifugation.</li>
<li>The percentage of cells in blood is called the packed cell volume (PCV) or the hematocrit.</li>
</ul>
<p>The PCV</p>
<ul>
<li>PCV is the percentage of blood occupied by cells.</li>
<li>Most of these cells are RBCs (more than 90%).</li>
<li>Normal values = 40-80% in males [average = 45%]
= 37-47% in females [average = 42%]</li>
<li>Low PCV indicates anemia.</li>
<li>High PCV indicates polycythemia.</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 5.1: The packed cell volume</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-93c7f525.jpeg" alt="img-179.jpeg"></p>
<p>120</p>
<p>CHAPTER 5 HENATGLOST</p>
<p>BLOOD</p>
<ul>

<li>The cells are: Red blood cells (RBCs) or erythrocytes. White blood cells (WBCs) or leukocytes and Platelets or thrombocytes.</li>
<li>The intercellular substance is called plasma.</li>

vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">40%</span></span></span></span></span> of total body weight).</li>
<li>Volume of plasma is about 2.5L (<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>≈</mo><mn>15</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\approx 15\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4831em;"></span><span class="mrel">≈</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">15%</span></span></span></span></span> of total body weight).</li>
<li>The cells in blood can be separated from plasma by centrifugation.</li>
<li>The percentage of cells in blood is called the packed cell volume (PCV) or the hematocrit.</li>
</ul>
<p>The PCV</p>
<ul>
<li>PCV is the percentage of blood occupied by cells.</li>
<li>Most of these cells are RBCs (more than 90%).</li>
<li>Normal values = 40-80% in males [average = 45%]
= 37-47% in females [average = 42%]</li>
<li>Low PCV indicates anemia.</li>
<li>High PCV indicates polycythemia.</li>
</ul>

<p>BLOOD</p>
<ul>

<li>The cells are: Red blood cells (RBCs) or erythrocytes. White blood cells (WBCs) or leukocytes and Platelets or thrombocytes.</li>
<li>The intercellular substance is called plasma.</li>
<li>Volume of blood is about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>16</mn></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{1}{16}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1901em; = 37-47% in females [average = 42%]</li>

<p>120</p>
<p>Public Engineering</p>
<p>Public Engineering</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-blood">Functions of blood<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-blood" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Transport of:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Gases (e.g. oxygen and carbon dioxide)</li>
<li>Nutrients (e.g. glucose, amino acids and free fatty acids)</li>
<li>Waste products (e.g. urea and uric acid)</li>
<li>Hormones (e.g. catecholamines, insulin, cortisol and thyroid hormones)</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Defense by WBCs</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Homeostasis (maintenance of the constancy of the internal environment, which is the ECF):</p>
</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Control of temperature (by distribution of heat by the blood)</li>
<li>Control of pH (by buffers in the blood, e.g. HCO₃⁻, proteins and hemoglobin)</li>
</ul>
<ol start="4">
<li>Hemostasis:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Prevention of blood loss &amp; maintenance of blood in the fluid state. Blood loss is prevented by arrest of bleeding (e.g. by platelets and clotting factors) and maintenance of blood in the fluid state occurs by the natural anticoagulants.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="formation-of-blood-hematopoiesis">Formation of blood (hematopoiesis)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#formation-of-blood-hematopoiesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Sites of hematopoiesis</li>
<li>During pregnancy, blood is formed at the following sites:</li>
<li>Trait size:</li>
<li>Forme blood during the intrauterine life, first trimester</li>
<li>Liver &amp; spleen:</li>
<li>Form blood during the intrauterine life, second trimester</li>
<li>After delivery, the liver and spleen may resume their hemopoietic activity in children suffering from chronic anemia [this is known as extramedullary hematopoiesis]</li>
</ul>
<p>The Journal of Medical Microbiology 17th edition</p>
<p>Public Engineering</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-blood">Functions of blood<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-blood" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Transport of:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Gases (e.g. oxygen and carbon dioxide)</li>
<li>Nutrients (e.g. glucose, amino acids and free fatty acids)</li>
<li>Waste products (e.g. urea and uric acid)</li>
<li>Hormones (e.g. catecholamines, insulin, cortisol and thyroid hormones)</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Defense by WBCs</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Homeostasis (maintenance of the constancy of the internal environment, which is the ECF):</p>
</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Control of temperature (by distribution of heat by the blood)</li>
<li>Control of pH (by buffers in the blood, e.g. HCO₃⁻, proteins and hemoglobin)</li>
</ul>
<ol start="4">
<li>Hemostasis:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Prevention of blood loss &amp; maintenance of blood in the fluid state. Blood loss is prevented by arrest of bleeding (e.g. by platelets and clotting factors) and maintenance of blood in the fluid state occurs by the natural anticoagulants.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="formation-of-blood-hematopoiesis">Formation of blood (hematopoiesis)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#formation-of-blood-hematopoiesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Sites of hematopoiesis</li>
<li>During pregnancy, blood is formed at the following sites:</li>
<li>Trait size:</li>
<li>Forme blood during the intrauterine life, first trimester</li>
<li>Liver &amp; spleen:</li>
<li>Form blood during the intrauterine life, second trimester</li>
<li>After delivery, the liver and spleen may resume their hemopoietic activity in children suffering from chronic anemia [this is known as extramedullary hematopoiesis]</li>
</ul>
<p>The Journal of Medical Microbiology 17th edition</p>
<p>Public Engineering</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="done-manual">Done manual:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#done-manual" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Forms blood during the intrauterine life, third trimester (and then 48w delivery); called red marrow (active marrow)</li>
<li>Front in almost all bones during pregnancy</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="after-delivery-blood-is-formed-at-the-following-sites">After delivery, blood is formed at the following sites:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#after-delivery-blood-is-formed-at-the-following-sites" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-red-bone-marrow">The red bone marrow<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-red-bone-marrow" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>After delivery, the red bone marrow starts to be replaced gradually by yellow marrow (inactive marrow)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>At about the age of 20y the red marrow is confined to:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fat bones</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Bical sternum, ribs, scapula, vertebrae &amp; iliac bone</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Ends of long bones "esqulyped" not the shaft "diaphysis"</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Small bones of hands &amp; feet</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>About 75% of the cells in the red bone marrow are WBC precursors and only 25% are RBC precursors; inspite of the fact that RBC count is over 500 times more than the WBC count. This indicates the longer life span of RBCs.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-e848bce3.jpeg" alt="img-182.jpeg">
THE RED BLOOD CELLS</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="characteristics-of-rbcs">Characteristics of RBCs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#characteristics-of-rbcs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Shape: Bicorotave disks</li>
<li>Diameter: 7.5 micrometer</li>
<li>Thickness: 1 micrometer (center), 2 micrometer (edges)</li>
</ul>
<p>122</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="done-manual">Done manual:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#done-manual" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Forms blood during the intrauterine life, third trimester (and then 48w delivery); called red marrow (active marrow)</li>
<li>Found in almost all bones during pregnancy</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="after-delivery-blood-is-formed-at-the-following-sites">After delivery, blood is formed at the following sites:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#after-delivery-blood-is-formed-at-the-following-sites" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-red-bone-marrow">The red bone marrow<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-red-bone-marrow" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>After delivery, the red bone marrow starts to be replaced gradually by yellow marrow (inactive marrow)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>At about the age of 20y the red marrow is confined to:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fat bones</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Bical, sternum, ribs, scapula, vertebrae &amp; iliac bone</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Ends of long bones "esqulyped" not the shaft "diaphysis"</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Small bones of hands &amp; feet</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>About 75% of the cells in the red bone marrow are WBC precursors and only 25% are RBC precursors; inspite of the fact that RBC count is over 500 times more than the WBC count. This indicates the longer life span of RBCs.</p>
</li>
</ul>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="done-manual">Done manual:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#done-manual" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>Found in almost all bones during pregnancy</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="after-delivery-blood-is-formed-at-the-following-sites">After delivery, blood is formed at the following sites:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#after-delivery-blood-is-formed-at-the-following-sites" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-red-bone-marrow">The red bone marrow<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-red-bone-marrow" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>After delivery, the red bone marrow starts to be replaced gradually by yellow marrow (inactive marrow)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>At about the age of 20y the red marrow is confined to:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fat bones</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Bical, sternum, ribs, scapula, vertebrae &amp; iliac bone</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Ends of long bones "esqulyped" not the shaft "diaphysis"</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Small bones of hands &amp; feet</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>About 75% of the cells in the red bone marrow are WBC precursors and only 25% are RBC precursors; inspite of the fact that RBC count is over 500 times more than the WBC count. This indicates the longer life span of RBCs.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-ea584d29.jpeg" alt="img-184.jpeg">
THE RED BLOOD CELLS</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="characteristics-of-rbcs">Characteristics of RBCs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#characteristics-of-rbcs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Shape: Bicorotave disks</li>
<li>Diameter: 7.5 micrometer</li>
<li>Thickness: 1 micrometer (center), 2 micrometer (edges)</li>
</ul>
<p>122</p>
<p>Contents</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>No nucleus</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Therefore no reproduction</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Then life span is about 120 days</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>No organelles</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>e.g. no mitochondria and therefore no aerobic glycolysis. However, they use anaerobic glycolysis to generate small amount of energy for maintenance of the integrity of the cell membrane</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Contain hemoglobin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A red pigment found within RBCs</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Important for transport of oxygen</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The volume of a red blood cell is larger than its contents. This allows it to squeeze itself through the narrow capillaries</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Count of RBCs</p>
<ul>
<li>In males: 4.8-6.8 milligrams³ &amp; in females: 4.5-6.7 milligrams³</li>
</ul>
<p>Functions of RBCs</p>
<ul>
<li>Transport oxygen (bound to iron in hemoglobin)</li>
<li>Transport carbon dioxide (bound to globin in hemoglobin)</li>
<li>Buffer (a function of hemoglobin)</li>
<li>Contain antigens on its surface that determine the type of blood group</li>
</ul>
<p>Stages of erythropoiesis</p>
<p>Can be divided into:</p>
<ul>
<li>Replication phase</li>
<li>The increase in number of RBCs</li>
<li>Maturation phase</li>
<li>The decrease in size of RBC precursors</li>
<li>Loss of contents (nucleus and organelles)</li>
<li>Acquisition of hemoglobin</li>
</ul>
<p>122</p>
<p>Contents</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>No nucleus</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Therefore no reproduction</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Then life span is about 120 days</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>No organelles</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>e.g. no mitochondria and therefore no aerobic glycolysis. However, they use anaerobic glycolysis to generate small amount of energy for maintenance of the integrity of the cell membrane</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Contain hemoglobin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A red pigment found within RBCs</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Important for transport of oxygen</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The volume of a red blood cell is larger than its contents. This allows it to squeeze itself through the narrow capillaries.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Count of RBCs</p>
<ul>
<li>In males: 4.8-6.8 milligrams³ &amp; in females: 4.2-5.2 milligrams³</li>
</ul>
<p>Functions of RBCs</p>
<ul>
<li>Transport oxygen (bound to iron in hemoglobin)</li>
<li>Transport carbon dioxide (bound to globin in hemoglobin)</li>
<li>Buffer (a function of hemoglobin)</li>
<li>Contain antigens on its surface that determine the type of blood group</li>
</ul>
<p>Stages of erythropoiesis</p>
<p>Can be divided into:</p>
<ul>
<li>Replication phase</li>
<li>The increase in number of RBCs</li>
<li>Maturation phase</li>
<li>The decrease in size of RBC precursors</li>
<li>Loss of contents (nucleus and organelles)</li>
<li>Acquisition of hemoglobin</li>
</ul>
<p>123</p>
<p>Contents</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>No nucleus</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Therefore no reproduction</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Then life span is about 120 days</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>No organelles</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>e.g. no mitochondria and therefore no aerobic glycolysis. However, they use anaerobic glycolysis to generate small amount of energy for maintenance of the integrity of the cell membrane</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Contain hemoglobin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A red pigment found within RBCs</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Important for transport of oxygen</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The volume of a red blood cell is larger than its contents. This allows it to squeeze itself through the narrow capillaries.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Count of RBCs</p>
<ul>
<li>In males: 4.0-5.0 milligrams³ &amp; in females: 4.2-6.2 milligrams³</li>
</ul>
<p>Functions of RBCs</p>
<ul>
<li>Transport oxygen (bound to iron in hemoglobin)</li>
<li>Transport carbon dioxide (bound to globin in hemoglobin)</li>
<li>Buffer (a function of hemoglobin)</li>
<li>Contain antigens on its surface that determine the type of blood group</li>
</ul>
<p>Stages of erythropoiesis</p>
<p>Can be divided into:</p>
<ul>
<li>Replication phase</li>
<li>The increase in number of RBCs</li>
<li>Maturation phase</li>
<li>The decrease in size of RBC precursors</li>
<li>Loss of contents (nucleus and organelles)</li>
<li>Acquisition of hemoglobin</li>
</ul>
<p>123</p>
<p>The count of medical pharmacists' 125</p>
<p>124
The issue of medical physiology 17 (2004)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="shapes-in-the-bone-marrow">Shapes in the bone marrow<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#shapes-in-the-bone-marrow" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>Purified/self recommended stem cells</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Nucleated cells that divide to form 2 major types of committed stem cells (prophoid and non-lymphoid (myeloid &amp; erythroid) cells)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Committed stem cells (or progenitor cells)</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Nucleated cells that divide to form only one type of blood cells (e.g. the lymphoid forms lymphocytes and the erythroid forms RBCs, and the nucleus forms other WBCs "granulocytes, monocytes" and precursors of platelets "megakaryocytes")</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Prowythroblasts (or Nematoblasts)</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The erythroid committed stem cells divide to form nucleated cells known as prowythroblasts (or nemroblasts). These divide many times and start to form hemoglobin; that's why they are described as early, intermediate &amp; late in according to the stem as basophilic and polychromatophilic. The nemroblasts lose the nucleus &amp; other organelles to become reticulocytes.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="shapes-in-the-blood">Shapes in the blood<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#shapes-in-the-blood" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>Reticulocytes</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The first non-nucleated red blood cell precursors. They have no organelles except some ribosomes (so they are still able to synthesize hemoglobin from ribosomal RNA). After their formation they stay in the bone marrow for 1-2 days; then they enter the peripheral blood for the first time and stay for another 1-2 days before they become mature erythrocytes. They constitute about 1% of total RBCs. High reticulocyte count (&lt;5% = reticulocytes) indicates hyperactivity in the bone marrow (i.e. rapid synthesis of RBCs to replace the first ones) as occurs in:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hemolytic anemia (reticulocytosis indicates RBC hemolysis)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Recent treatment of anemia (e.g. following vitamin B12 injections)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Erythrocytes</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The mature red blood cells.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>125
The issue of medical physiology 17 (2004)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="shapes-in-the-bone-marrow">Shapes in the bone marrow<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#shapes-in-the-bone-marrow" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>Purified/self recommended stem cells</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Nucleated cells that divide to form 2 major types of committed stem cells (prophoid and non-lymphoid (myeloid &amp; erythroid) cells)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Committed stem cells (or progenitor cells)</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Nucleated cells that divide to form only one type of blood cells (e.g. the lymphoid forms lymphocytes and the erythroid forms RBCs, and the nucleus forms other WBCs "granulocytes, monocytes" and precursors of platelets "megakaryocytes")</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Prowythroblasts (or Nematoblasts)</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The erythroid committed stem cells divide to form nucleated cells known as prowythroblasts (or nemroblasts). These divide many times and start to form hemoglobin; that's why they are described as early, intermediate &amp; late in according to the stem as basophilic and polychromatophilic. The nemroblasts lose the nucleus &amp; other organelles to become reticulocytes.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="shapes-in-the-blood">Shapes in the blood<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#shapes-in-the-blood" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>Reticulocytes</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The first non-nucleated red blood cell precursors. They have no organelles except some ribosomes (so they are still able to synthesize hemoglobin from ribosomal RNA). After their formation they stay in the bone marrow for 1-2 days; then they enter the peripheral blood for the first time and stay for another 1-2 days before they become mature erythrocytes. They constitute about 1% of total RBCs. High reticulocyte count (&lt;5% = reticulocytes) indicates hyperactivity in the bone marrow (i.e. rapid synthesis of RBCs to replace the last ones) as occurs in:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hemolytic anemia (reticulocytosis indicates RBC hemolysis)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Recent treatment of anemia (e.g. following vitamin B12 injections)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Erythrocytes</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The mature red blood cells.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>126
The issue of medical physiology 17 (2004)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="shapes-in-the-bone-marrow">Shapes in the bone marrow<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#shapes-in-the-bone-marrow" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="shapes-in-the-blood">Shapes in the blood<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#shapes-in-the-blood" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="control-of-erythropoesis">CONTROL OF ERYTHROPOESIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-erythropoesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="normal-erythropoiesis-response">Normal erythropoiesis response:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#normal-erythropoiesis-response" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Normal bone marrow</li>
<li>Cytokines and colony stimulating factors</li>
<li>Erythropoietin &amp; other hormones (e.g. thyroid hormones)</li>
<li>Certain nutrients (e.g. iron, vitamin B12 and folic acid)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="normal-bone-marrow">Normal bone marrow<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#normal-bone-marrow" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Normal bone marrow is essential for normal erythropoiesis.</li>
<li>Diseases affecting the bone marrow usually results in abnormal erythropoiesis (see anemia).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cytokines-and-colony-stimulating-factors">Cytokines and colony stimulating factors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cytokines-and-colony-stimulating-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Interleukins: IL-1, TL-3, IL-6 and GM-CSF (Granulocyte: Monocyte Colony Stimulating Factors) stimulate proliferation and conversion of pluripotent stem cells into committed stem cells.</li>
<li>These growth factors are produced by bone marrow stromal cells such as fibroblasts, endothelial cells, activated T cells and macrophages.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="erythropoietin-in-the-principal-regulator-of-erythropoiesis">Erythropoietin (in the principal regulator of erythropoiesis)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#erythropoietin-in-the-principal-regulator-of-erythropoiesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="characterization">Characterization:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#characterization" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Glycoprotein (contains 74% carbohydrate and 76% protein).</li>
<li>Have single chain with 165 amino acids.</li>
<li>MW: 34000</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="site-of-production">Site of production:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#site-of-production" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>In adults: produced mainly in the kidneys (90%) &amp; in the liver (10%).</li>
<li>In fetal life: the liver is the main site of production.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="stimulus">Stimulus:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stimulus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Hypoxia (low oxygen at the tissue level).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="function">Function:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#function" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Stimulates replication of stem cells and formation of erythroblasts.</li>
<li>Erythropoietin does not influence the maturation stages of RBCs.</li>
</ul>
<p>123
The costs of medical physiology 175 years</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="control-of-erythropoesis">CONTROL OF ERYTHROPOESIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-erythropoesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="normal-erythropoiesis-response">Normal erythropoiesis response:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#normal-erythropoiesis-response" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="normal-bone-marrow">Normal bone marrow<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#normal-bone-marrow" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<li>Normal bone marrow is essential for normal erythropoiesis.</li>
<li>Diseases affecting the bone marrow usually results in abnormal erythropoiesis (see anemia).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cytokines-and-colony-stimulating-factors">Cytokines and colony stimulating factors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cytokines-and-colony-stimulating-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<li>Interleukins: IL-1, TL-3, IL-6 and GM-CSF (Granulocyte: Monocyte Colony Stimulating Factors) stimulate proliferation and conversion of pluripotent stem cells into committed stem cells.</li>
<li>These growth factors are produced by bone marrow stromal cells such as fibroblasts, endothelial cells, activated T cells and macrophages.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="erythropoietin-in-the-principal-regulator-of-erythropoiesis">Erythropoietin (in the principal regulator of erythropoiesis)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#erythropoietin-in-the-principal-regulator-of-erythropoiesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="characterization">Characterization:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#characterization" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Glycoprotein (contains 24% carbohydrate and 76% protein).</li>
<li>Have single chain with 165 amino acids.</li>
<li>MW: 34000</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="site-of-production">Site of production:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#site-of-production" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>In adults: produced mainly in the kidneys (90%) &amp; in the liver (10%).</li>
<li>In fetal life: the liver is the main site of production.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="stimulus">Stimulus:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stimulus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Hypoxia (low oxygen at the tissue level).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="function">Function:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#function" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Stimulates replication of stem cells and formation of erythroblasts.</li>
<li>Erythropoietin does not influence the maturation stages of RBCs.</li>
</ul>
<p>124
The costs of medical physiology 175 years</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="control-of-erythropoesis">CONTROL OF ERYTHROPOESIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-erythropoesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="normal-erythropoiesis-response">Normal erythropoiesis response:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#normal-erythropoiesis-response" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Normal bone marrow</li>
<li>Cytokines and colony stimulating factors</li>
<li>Erythropoietin &amp; other hormones (e.g. thyroid hormones)</li>
<li>Certain nutrients (e.g. iron, vitamin B12 and folic acid)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="normal-bone-marrow">Normal bone marrow<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#normal-bone-marrow" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Normal bone marrow is essential for normal erythropoiesis.</li>
<li>Diseases affecting the bone marrow usually results in abnormal erythropoiesis (see anemia).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cytokines-and-colony-stimulating-factors">Cytokines and colony stimulating factors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cytokines-and-colony-stimulating-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Interleukins: IL-1, TL-3, IL-6 and GM-CSF (Granulocyte: Monocyte Colony Stimulating Factors) stimulate proliferation and conversion of pluripotent stem cells into committed stem cells.</li>
<li>These growth factors are produced by bone marrow stromal cells such as fibroblasts, endothelial cells, activated T cells and macrophages.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="erythropoietin-in-the-principal-regulator-of-erythropoiesis">Erythropoietin (in the principal regulator of erythropoiesis)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#erythropoietin-in-the-principal-regulator-of-erythropoiesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="characterization">Characterization:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#characterization" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Glycoprotein (contains 21% carbohydrate and 76% protein).</li>
<li>Have single chain with 165 amino acids.</li>
<li>MW: 34000</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="site-of-production">Site of production:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#site-of-production" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>In adults: produced mainly in the kidneys (90%) &amp; in the liver (10%).</li>
<li>In fetal life: the liver is the main site of production.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="stimulus">Stimulus:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stimulus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Hypoxia (low oxygen at the tissue level).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="function">Function:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#function" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Stimulates replication of stem cells and formation of erythroblasts.</li>
<li>Erythropoietin does not influence the maturation stages of RBCs.</li>
</ul>
<p>128
The costs of medical physiology 17 April</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abnormalities">Abnormalities<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Erythropoietin excess (in results in polycythemia)</li>
<li>Caused by:</li>
<li>High stimulus: people living at high stimulus have physiological polycythemia due to the low oxygen tension at these sites.</li>
<li>Renal problems (e.g. renal tumors or polycystic kidney disease): have pathological problems are characterized by excessive release of erythropoietin causing pathological polycythemia.</li>
<li>Chronic respiratory problems: When these problems cause hypoxia, patients develop polycythemia (e.g. lung fibrosis).</li>
<li>Erythropoietin deficiency (in results in anemia)</li>
<li>Anemia caused by erythropoietin deficiency is characterized by low count of RBCs but with normal shape and color 'normocytic normochromic anemia'. The chief cause is chronic renal failure.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="other-hormones-needed-for-normal-erythropoiesis">Other hormones needed for normal erythropoiesis:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-hormones-needed-for-normal-erythropoiesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Androgens (in male hormones that increase bulk of muscles, e.g. testosterone). Muscles are more active than fats, they consume more oxygen. This stimulates erythropoietin production and therefore RBC formation. That's why RBC count is higher in males than females of the same age (notice that this difference between males and females is absent before puberty!).</li>
<li>Growth hormone</li>
<li>Cortisol</li>
<li>Thyroid hormones</li>
</ul>
<p>129
The costs of medical physiology 17 April</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abnormalities">Abnormalities<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Erythropoietin excess (in results in polycythemia)</li>
<li>Caused by:</li>
<li>High stimulus: people living at high stimulus have physiological polycythemia due to the low oxygen tension at these sites.</li>
<li>Renal problems (e.g. renal tumors or polycystic kidney disease): have pathological problems are characterized by excessive release of erythropoietin causing pathological polycythemia.</li>
<li>Chronic respiratory problems: When these problems cause hypoxia, patients develop polycythemia (e.g. lung fibrosis).</li>
<li>Erythropoietin deficiency (in results in anemia)</li>
<li>Anemia caused by erythropoietin deficiency is characterized by low count of RBCs but with normal shape and color 'normocytic normochromic anemia'. The chief cause is chronic renal failure.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="other-hormones-needed-for-normal-erythropoiesis">Other hormones needed for normal erythropoiesis:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-hormones-needed-for-normal-erythropoiesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Androgens (in male hormones that increase bulk of muscles, e.g. testosterone): Muscles are more active than fats, they consume more oxygen. This stimulates erythropoietin production and therefore RBC formation. That's why RBC count is higher in males than females of the same age (notice that this difference between males and females is absent before puberty!).</li>
<li>Growth hormone</li>
<li>Cortisol</li>
<li>Thyroid hormones</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abnormalities">Abnormalities<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>Caused by:</li>
<li>High stimulus: people living at high stimulus have physiological polycythemia due to the low oxygen tension at these sites.</li>
<li>Renal problems (e.g. renal tumors or polycystic kidney disease): have pathological problems are characterized by excessive release of erythropoietin causing pathological polycythemia.</li>
<li>Chronic respiratory problems: When these problems cause hypoxia, patients develop polycythemia (e.g. lung fibrosis).</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="other-hormones-needed-for-normal-erythropoiesis">Other hormones needed for normal erythropoiesis:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-hormones-needed-for-normal-erythropoiesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>Androgens (in male hormones that increase bulk of muscles, e.g. testosterone): Muscles are more active than fats, they consume more oxygen. This stimulates erythropoietin production and therefore RBC formation. That's why RBC count is higher in males than females of the same age (notice that this difference between males and females is absent before puberty!).</li>
<li>Growth hormone</li>
<li>Cortisol</li>
<li>Thyroid hormones</li>
</ul>
<p>127
For more information please call 1-800-222-1111</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="synthesis-needed-for-erythropoiesis">Synthesis needed for erythropoiesis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#synthesis-needed-for-erythropoiesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Amine acids for formation of globin (Hb)</li>
<li>Iron for formation of heme (Hb). Its deficiency causes microcytic hypothermic anemia.</li>
<li>Vitamin B₁₂ &amp; folic acid for DNA synthesis (cell division). Deficiency causes macrocytic hemodynamic anemia.</li>
<li>Vitamin C for iron absorption (it is a reducing factor that maintains iron in the ferrous state)</li>
<li>Other B vitamins: Ca factors in the metabolic reactions</li>
<li>Vitamin E for maintenance of RBC membrane (an anti-oxidant that protects the cell membrane from oxygen radicals). Deficiency causes hemolytic anemia.</li>
<li>Trace elements:</li>
<li>Copper promotes iron absorption</li>
<li>Cobalt. Needed for vitamin B₁₂ synthesis in animals. It may stimulate erythropoietin production.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iron-metabolism">Iron metabolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iron-metabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Distribution in the body</li>
<li>Total amount in the body is about 3-5 grams. Distributed in:</li>
<li>Heme of hemoglobin (BS-75%)</li>
<li>Cellular enzymes (cellulose, cytochrome oxidase) (3%)</li>
<li>Storage (ferritin, hemosiderin) (&gt;20%)</li>
<li>Plasma (transferrin) (&gt;1%)</li>
<li>Dietary enzymes</li>
<li>Animal products: e.g. liver, meat, egg</li>
<li>Plant products: e.g. vegetables, beans</li>
<li>The average diet provides 10-20 mg/day</li>
<li>Daily requirements:</li>
<li>About 1 mg/day in an adult man, 2 mg/day in an adult woman</li>
</ul>
<p>For more information please call 1-800-222-1111</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="synthesis-needed-for-erythropoiesis">Synthesis needed for erythropoiesis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#synthesis-needed-for-erythropoiesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Amine acids for formation of globin (Hb)</li>
<li>Iron for formation of heme (Hb). Its deficiency causes microcytic hypothermic anemia.</li>
<li>Vitamin B₁₂ &amp; folic acid for DNA synthesis (cell division). Deficiency causes macrocytic hemodynamic anemia.</li>
<li>Vitamin C for iron absorption (it is a reducing factor that maintains iron in the ferrous state)</li>
<li>Other B vitamins: Ca factors in the metabolic reactions</li>
<li>Vitamin E for maintenance of RBC membrane (an anti-oxidant that protects the cell membrane from oxygen radicals). Deficiency causes hemolytic anemia.</li>
<li>Trace elements:</li>
<li>Copper promotes iron absorption</li>
<li>Cobalt. Needed for vitamin B₁₂ synthesis in animals. It may stimulate erythropoietin production.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iron-metabolism">Iron metabolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iron-metabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Distribution in the body</li>
<li>Total amount in the body is about 3-5 grams. Distributed in:</li>
<li>Heme of hemoglobin (BS-75%)</li>
<li>Cellular enzymes (cellulose, cytochrome oxidase) (3%)</li>
<li>Storage (ferritin, hemosiderin) (&gt;20%)</li>
<li>Plasma (transferrin) (&gt;1%)</li>
<li>Dietary enzymes</li>
<li>Animal products: e.g. liver, meat, egg</li>
<li>Plant products: e.g. vegetables, beans</li>
<li>The average diet provides 10-20 mg/day</li>
<li>Daily requirements:</li>
<li>About 1 mg/day in an adult man, 2 mg/day in an adult woman</li>
</ul>
<p>For more information please call 1-800-222-1111</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="synthesis-needed-for-erythropoiesis">Synthesis needed for erythropoiesis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#synthesis-needed-for-erythropoiesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Amine acids for formation of globin (Hb)</li>
<li>Iron for formation of heme (Hb). Its deficiency causes microcytic hypothermic anemia.</li>
<li>Vitamin B₁₂ &amp; folic acid for DNA synthesis (cell division). Deficiency causes microcytic hemodynamic anemia.</li>
<li>Vitamin E for iron absorption (it is a reducing factor that maintains iron in the ferrous state)</li>
<li>Other B vitamins: Ca factors in the metabolic reactions</li>
<li>Vitamin E for maintenance of RBC membrane (an anti-oxidant that protects the cell membrane from oxygen radicals). Deficiency causes hemolytic anemia.</li>
<li>Trace elements:</li>
<li>Copper promotes iron absorption</li>
<li>Cobalt. Needed for vitamin B₁₂ synthesis in animals. It may stimulate erythropoietin production.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iron-metabolism">Iron metabolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iron-metabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Distribution in the body</li>
<li>Total amount in the body is about 3-5 grams. Distributed in:</li>
<li>Heme of hemoglobin (BS-75%)</li>
<li>Cellular enzymes (cellulose, cytochrome oxidase) (3%)</li>
<li>Storage (ferritin, hemosiderin) (&gt;20%)</li>
<li>Plasma (transferrin) (&gt;1%)</li>
<li>Dietary enzymes</li>
<li>Animal products: e.g. liver, meat, egg</li>
<li>Plant products: e.g. vegetables, beans</li>
<li>The average diet provides 10-20 mg/day</li>
<li>Daily requirements:</li>
<li>About 1 mg/day in an adult man, 2 mg/day in an adult woman</li>
</ul>
<p>128
The text of section 2 is illegible</p>
<p>The daily requirements are increased during:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Pregnancy</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Lactation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Manip (the first year of life)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Absorption</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Amount absorbed = 10-15% of ingested iron; however, it is highly increased in patients suffering from iron deficiency anemia.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Site of absorption: upper small intestine (duodenum).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Mechanism of absorption: 2nd active transport (Fe³⁺/H⁺ symport).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factors that increase absorption:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Ferrous state (Fe²⁺)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Gastric acidity (HCl), maintains iron in the ferrous state</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Vitamin C, also maintains iron in the ferrous state</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Iron in heme</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factors that decrease absorption:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Presence of phosphates, oxalates or phytates in diet</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Autoimhydria (low hydrochloric acid due to gastric atrophy)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Diarrhea</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Clay</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fever</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tiotacydine</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Iron in plasma</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Concentration= 100-130 micrograms/L. It is transported in plasma by a late globulin known as transferrin. Transferrin is normally 30-40% saturated with iron.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Storage</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sites of storage: intestinal mucosa, liver, spleen and bone marrow.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Forms of storage: ferritin (brennoxidation).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Ferritin is the main form of storage. It stores 65% of stored iron in a stable form that's easily mobilized whereas hemoxidation stores 33% of stored iron in a insoluble form that's slowly mobilized.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>The daily requirements are increased during:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Pregnancy</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Lactation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Manip (the first year of life)</p>
</li>
