<p>129
The text of section 2 is illegible</p>
<p>128
The view of medical technology / 128 address</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>Function of iron formation of heme in Hb</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Iron found in ferrous (Fe2+) form</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Each Hb molecule contains 4 (Fe2+)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Each atom of iron binds 2 atoms of oxygen (Therefore each Hb molecule carries 3 atoms of oxygen (or four molecules))</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Function</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Total daily loss of iron 1 mg/day in adult men, 2mg/day in adult women (i.e. daily intake = daily loss)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Routes for iron loss: Feces, skin, urine and menstruation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Abnormalities</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Iron deficiency anemia (monocytic hypochromic anemia)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Characterized by Low Hb, small &amp; pale RBCs (monocytic hypochromic anemia), low concentration of iron in plasma, low plasma ferritin and high total iron binding capacity (TB/C)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Iron overload: 1* Hemochromatosis &amp; 2* Hemosiderosis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hemochromatosis is a common hereditary condition characterized by excessive iron absorption resulting in abnormal accumulation of iron in many organs causing damage (e.g. liver cirrhosis, gonadal atrophy, cardiomyopathy, skin pigmentation and diabetes mellitus)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hemosiderosis describes iron overload secondary to certain causes (e.g. repeated blood transfusions and excessive iron therapy)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Vitamin B₁₂</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Cyanocobalamin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Water soluble vitamin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Sources and requirement</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Found in food of animal origin (notice that vitamin B12 is formed by microorganisms that contaminate animal tissues, it is not found in food of plant origin unless it is contaminated by these microorganisms).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Data requirements are very low (about 1-2 micrograms/day)</p>
</li>
</ul>

The view of medical technology / 129 address</p>
<ul>

</li>
<li>

</li>
<li>
<p>Each Hb molecule contains 4 (Fe2+)</p>

</li>

</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="site-of-absorption">Site of absorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#site-of-absorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Terminal ileum</li>
<li>Absorption is assisted by the intrinsic factor (produced by parietal cells in the stomach). This binds iron in the stomach and travels with it to the terminal ileum to be absorbed together by pinozytoxin.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="storage">Storage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#storage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>In the liver, the amount stored is enough for at least 3 years without injury.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="funging">Funging<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#funging" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>DNA synthesis (needed for red blood cell replication)</li>
<li>Mucination of nerves</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="abnormalities">Abnormalities<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Deficiency causes</li>
<li>Macrocytic normochromic anemia (megadoblastic anemia)</li>
<li>Sub-acute combined degeneration of the cord (domyelination)</li>
<li>Causes of deficiency</li>
<li>Low intake (rare cause of deficiency except in strict vegetarians)</li>
<li>Resection of the terminal ileum (decreases absorption)</li>
<li>Gastrectomy (removal of the stomach decreases absorption because there is no intrinsic factor)</li>
<li>Gastric atrophy (caused by auto-antibodies that attack parietal cells or the intrinsic factor); this is known as pernicious anemia.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="folic-acid">Folic acid<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#folic-acid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Water soluble vitamin</li>
<li>Sources and requirement</li>
<li>Found mainly in food of plant origin</li>
<li>Daily requirement is about 100 micrograms/day</li>
<li>Requirements are increased during</li>
<li>Pregnancy</li>
<li>Lactation</li>
</ul>
<p>131
The issue of medical physiology of cancer</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="site-of-absorption">Site of absorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#site-of-absorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Terminal ileum</li>
<li>Absorption is assisted by the intrinsic factor (produced by parietal cells in the stomach). This binds iron in the stomach and travels with it to the terminal ileum to be absorbed together by pinozytoxin.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="storage">Storage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#storage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>In the liver, the amount stored is enough for at least 3 years without injury.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="funging">Funging<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#funging" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>DNA synthesis (needed for red blood cell replication)</li>
<li>Mucination of nerves</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="abnormalities">Abnormalities<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Deficiency causes</li>
<li>Macrocytic normochromic anemia (megadoblastic anemia)</li>
<li>Sub-acute combined degeneration of the cord (domyelination)</li>
<li>Causes of deficiency</li>
<li>Low intake (rare cause of deficiency except in strict vegetarians)</li>
<li>Resection of the terminal ileum (decreases absorption)</li>
<li>Gastrectomy (removal of the stomach decreases absorption because there is no intrinsic factor)</li>
<li>Gastric atrophy (caused by auto-antibodies that attack parietal cells or the intrinsic factor); this is known as pernicious anemia.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="folic-acid">Folic acid<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#folic-acid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Water soluble vitamin</li>
<li>Sources and requirement</li>
<li>Found mainly in food of plant origin</li>
<li>Daily requirement is about 100 micrograms/day</li>
<li>Requirements are increased during</li>
<li>Pregnancy</li>
<li>Lactation</li>
</ul>

The view of medical physiology 1st edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hemoglobin">HEMOGLOBIN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hemoglobin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The red pigment found in RBCs.</li>
<li>Molecular weight is about 65000.</li>
<li>Concentration</li>
<li>14-16 g/dL in adult males</li>
<li>13-15 g/dL in adult females</li>
<li>16-20 g/dL in neonates</li>
<li>Structure</li>
<li>Consists of 4 subunits. Each subunit consists of heme + a polypeptide chain [Hb + 4 heme + 4 polypeptide chains]</li>
<li>Each heme is synthesized from glycine and succinyl-CoA. It has a polyhydroxy-containing iron in the reduced state (Fe³⁺).</li>
<li>Each polypeptide chain is identical to another chain in Hb; therefore the 4 polypeptide chains are 2 pairs; e.g. 2 alpha + 2 beta chains or 2 alpha + 2 gamma chains or 2 alpha + 2 delta chains. The 4 chains are called collectively globin (i.e. Hb + 4 heme + globin).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-69fdddb8.jpeg" alt="img-185.jpeg">
Fig.5.2. The four subunits of hemoglobin</p>
<p>123
The view of medical physiology 1st edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hemoglobin">HEMOGLOBIN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hemoglobin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>The red pigment found in RBCs.</li>
<li>Molecular weight is about 65000.</li>
<li>Concentration</li>
<li>14-16 g/dL in adult males</li>
<li>13-15 g/dL in adult females</li>
<li>16-20 g/dL in neonates</li>

<li>Each polypeptide chain is identical to another chain in Hb; therefore the 4 polypeptide chains are 2 pairs; e.g. 2 alpha + 2 beta chains or 2 alpha + 2 gamma chains or 2 alpha + 2 delta chains. The 4 chains are called collectively globin (i.e. Hb + 4 heme + globin).</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hemoglobin">HEMOGLOBIN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hemoglobin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The red pigment found in RBCs.</li>
<li>Molecular weight is about 65000.</li>
<li>Concentration</li>
<li>14-16 g/dL in adult males</li>
<li>13-15 g/dL in adult females</li>
<li>16-20 g/dL in neonates</li>
<li>Structure</li>
<li>Consists of 4 subunits. Each subunit consists of heme + a polypeptide chain [Hb + 4 heme + 4 polypeptide chains]</li>
<li>Each heme is synthesized from glycine and succinyl-CoA. It has a polyhydroxy-containing iron in the reduced state (Fe³⁺).</li>
<li>Each polypeptide chain is identical to another chain in Hb; therefore the 4 polypeptide chains are 2 pairs; e.g. 2 alpha + 2 beta chains or 2 alpha + 2 gamma chains or 2 alpha + 2 delta chains. The 4 chains are called collectively globin (i.e. Hb + 4 heme + globin).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-66d5a35d.jpeg" alt="img-187.jpeg">
Fig.5.3. The four subunits of hemoglobin</p>
<p>125
The view of medical physiology 1st edition</p>
<p>122
The term of standard phyrometry of 14 hours</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-hb">Functions of Hb<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-hb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Carries 98% of oxygen in the blood</li>
<li>Carries some carbon dioxide</li>
<li>Buffer</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="normal-types-of-hb">Normal types of Hb<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#normal-types-of-hb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="hb-a">Hb A<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hb-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Adult Hb constitutes about 98% of all Hb in adults</li>
<li>Contains 2 alpha &amp; 2 beta chains (α₁B₁)</li>
<li>Each alpha chain contains 141 as (formed by genes on chromosome 16) whereas each beta chain contains 146 as (formed by genes on chromosome 11)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="hb-a2">Hb A2<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hb-a2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Adult Hb constitutes about 2.5% of all Hb in adults</li>
<li>Consists of 2 alpha &amp; 2 delta chains (α₁B₂)</li>
<li>Delta chain is similar to beta chain, but differs in 10 aa. It is also formed by genes on chromosome 11</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="hb-f">Hb F<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hb-f" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Fetal Hb</li>
<li>Starts to be replaced Hb A before birth</li>
<li>At birth, it constitutes about 70% of fetal Hb. This decrease to less than 2% (i.e. replacement is almost complete) by the age of 6 month.</li>
<li>Hb F has higher affinity to oxygen than Hb A.</li>
<li>This is because it binds 2,3 DPG (di-phospho-glycoside) less avidity (in other words: 2,3 DPG does not occupy the sites available for oxygen binding as occurs in Hb A.</li>
<li>This facilitates delivery of oxygen from the mother to her fetus through the placental membranes.</li>
<li>Consists of 2 alpha &amp; 2 gamma chains (α₂α₂)</li>
<li>Gamma chain is similar to beta chain except in 37 aa.</li>
<li>It is also formed by genes on chromosome 11.</li>
</ul>
<p>123
The term of standard phyrometry of 14 hours</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-hb">Functions of Hb<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-hb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Carries 98% of oxygen in the blood</li>
<li>Carries some carbon dioxide</li>
<li>Buffer</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="normal-types-of-hb">Normal types of Hb<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#normal-types-of-hb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="hb-a">Hb A<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hb-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Adult Hb constitutes about 98% of all Hb in adults</li>
<li>Contains 2 alpha &amp; 2 beta chains (α₁B₂)</li>
<li>Each alpha chain contains 141 as (formed by genes on chromosome 16) whereas each beta chain contains 146 as (formed by genes on chromosome 11)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="hb-a2">Hb A2<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hb-a2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Adult Hb constitutes about 2.5% of all Hb in adults</li>
<li>Consists of 2 alpha &amp; 2 delta chains (α₁B₂)</li>
<li>Delta chain is similar to beta chain, but differs in 10 aa. It is also formed by genes on chromosome 11</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="hb-f">Hb F<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hb-f" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Fetal Hb</li>
<li>Starts to be replaced Hb A before birth</li>
<li>At birth, it constitutes about 70% of fetal Hb. This decrease to less than 2% (i.e. replacement is almost complete) by the age of 6 month.</li>
<li>Hb F has higher affinity to oxygen than Hb A.</li>
<li>This is because it binds 2,3 DPG (di-phospho-glycoside) less avidity (in other words: 2,3 DPG does not occupy the sites available for oxygen binding as occurs in Hb A.</li>
<li>This facilitates delivery of oxygen from the mother to her fetus through the placental membranes.</li>
<li>Consists of 2 alpha &amp; 2 gamma chains (α₂α₂)</li>
<li>Gamma chain is similar to beta chain except in 37 aa.</li>
<li>It is also formed by genes on chromosome 11.</li>
</ul>
<p>124
The term of standard phyrometry of 14 hours</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-hb">Functions of Hb<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-hb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Carries 98% of oxygen in the blood</li>
<li>Carries some carbon dioxide</li>
<li>Buffer</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="normal-types-of-hb">Normal types of Hb<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#normal-types-of-hb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="hb-a">Hb A<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hb-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Adult Hb constitutes about 98% of all Hb in adults</li>
<li>Contains 2 alpha &amp; 2 beta chains (α₁B₁)</li>
<li>Each alpha chain contains 141 as (formed by genes on chromosome 16) whereas each beta chain contains 146 as (formed by genes on chromosome 11)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="hb-a2">Hb A2<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hb-a2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Adult Hb constitutes about 2.5% of all Hb in adults</li>
<li>Consists of 2 alpha &amp; 2 delta chains (α₁B₂)</li>
<li>Delta chain is similar to beta chain, but differs in 10 aa. It is also formed by genes on chromosome 11</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="hb-f">Hb F<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hb-f" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Fetal Hb</li>
<li>Starts to be replaced Hb A before birth</li>
<li>At birth, it constitutes about 70% of fetal Hb. This decrease to less than 2% (i.e. replacement is almost complete) by the age of 6 month.</li>
<li>Hb F has higher affinity to oxygen than Hb A.</li>
<li>This is because it binds 2,3 DPG (di-phospho-glycoside) less avidity (in other words: 2,3 DPG does not occupy the sites available for oxygen binding as occurs in Hb A.</li>
<li>This facilitates delivery of oxygen from the mother to her fetus through the placental membranes.</li>
<li>Consists of 2 alpha &amp; 2 gamma chains (α₂α₂)</li>
<li>Gamma chain is similar to beta chain except in 37 aa.</li>
<li>It is also formed by genes on chromosome 11.</li>
</ul>
<p>125
The term of standard phyrometry of 14 hours</p>
<p>114
The area of pacific water</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hb-a1c-clerated-hb">Hb A1c (Clerated Hb)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hb-a1c-clerated-hb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Subtype of Hb A</li>
<li>Its terminal amino acid (valine) can bind glucose</li>
<li>Normally it constitutes about 5% of total Hb</li>
<li>Higher percentage of Hb A1c indicates poorly controlled diabetes mellitus</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="embryonic-hemoglobine">Embryonic hemoglobine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#embryonic-hemoglobine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Types of hemoglobin during the first 8 weeks of pregnancy include:</li>
<li>Gower 1 Hb: consists of 2 cells and 2 epsilon chains (Epc)</li>
<li>Gower 2 Hb: consists of 2 alpha and 2 epsilon chains (Epo)</li>
<li>Portland Hb: consists of 2 beta and 2 gamma chains (Edo)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="abnormal-types-of-hb">Abnormal types of Hb<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormal-types-of-hb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="hb-s">Hb S<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hb-s" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Sickle cell Hb: It is Hb A but the amino acid number 6 in beta chains (glucose, acid) is replaced by (valine)</li>
<li>Hb S precipitates in cases of hypoxia. This changes the shape of RBCs to a sickle shape</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="complications-of-the-sickle-shape">Complications of the sickle shape<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications-of-the-sickle-shape" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Hemolytic crisis: hemolytic anemia known as sickle cell anemia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Jaundice: pre-hepatic jaundice due to the excessive hemolysis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Vasovolvovous crisis: obstruction of small capillaries causing atrophy of organs supplied with these blood vessels</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Symptoms appear after the age of 6 month when HbF is almost totally replaced by Hb A (This is because Hb F prevents sickling of RBCs since it does not contain beta chains)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The disease is less severe in heterozygotes (who have one chromosome affected and therefore 50% of their Hb is Hb S) than homozygotes (who had defect in the two chromosomes that form Hb A and therefore most of their Hb is Hb S).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hb-a1c-clerated-hb">Hb A1c (Clerated Hb)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hb-a1c-clerated-hb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Subtype of Hb A</li>
<li>Its terminal amino acid (valine) can bind glucose</li>
<li>Normally it constitutes about 5% of total Hb</li>
<li>Higher percentage of Hb A1c indicates poorly controlled diabetes mellitus</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="embryonic-hemoglobine">Embryonic hemoglobine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#embryonic-hemoglobine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Types of hemoglobin during the first 8 weeks of pregnancy include:</li>
<li>Gower 1 Hb: consists of 2 cells and 2 epsilon chains (Epc)</li>
<li>Gower 2 Hb: consists of 2 alpha and 2 epsilon chains (Epo)</li>
<li>Portland Hb: consists of 2 beta and 2 gamma chains (Epo)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="abnormal-types-of-hb">Abnormal types of Hb<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormal-types-of-hb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="hb-s">Hb S<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hb-s" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Sickle cell Hb: It is Hb A but the amino acid number 6 in beta chains (glucose, acid) is replaced by (valine)</li>
<li>Hb S precipitates in cases of hypoxia. This changes the shape of RBCs to a sickle shape</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="complications-of-the-sickle-shape">Complications of the sickle shape<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications-of-the-sickle-shape" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Hemolytic crisis: hemolytic anemia known as sickle cell anemia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Jaundice: pre-hepatic jaundice due to the excessive hemolysis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Vasovolvovous crisis: obstruction of small capillaries causing atrophy of organs supplied with these blood vessels</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Symptoms appear after the age of 6 month when HbF is almost totally replaced by Hb A (This is because Hb F prevents sickling of RBCs since it does not contain beta chains)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The disease is less severe in heterozygotes (who have one chromosome affected and therefore 50% of their Hb is Hb S) than homozygotes (who have defect in the two chromosomes that form Hb A and therefore most of their Hb is Hb S)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>115
The area of a patient's blood vessels</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hb-a1c-clerated-hb">Hb A1c (Clerated Hb)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hb-a1c-clerated-hb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Subtype of Hb A</li>
<li>Its terminal amino acid (valine) can bind glucose</li>
<li>Normally it constitutes about 5% of total Hb</li>
<li>Higher percentage of Hb A1c indicates poorly controlled diabetes mellitus</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="embryonic-hemoglobine">Embryonic hemoglobine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#embryonic-hemoglobine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Types of hemoglobin during the first 8 weeks of pregnancy include:</li>
<li>Gower 1 Hb: consists of 2 cells and 2 epsilon chains (Epc)</li>
<li>Gower 2 Hb: consists of 2 alpha and 2 epsilon chains (Epo)</li>
<li>Portland Hb: consists of 2 beta and 2 gamma chains (Epo)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="abnormal-types-of-hb">Abnormal types of Hb<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormal-types-of-hb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="hb-s">Hb S<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hb-s" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Sickle cell Hb: It is Hb A but the amino acid number 6 in beta chains (glucose, acid) is replaced by (valine)</li>
<li>Hb S precipitates in cases of hypoxia. This changes the shape of RBCs to a sickle shape</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="complications-of-the-sickle-shape">Complications of the sickle shape<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications-of-the-sickle-shape" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Hemolytic crisis: hemolytic anemia known as sickle cell anemia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Jaundice: pre-hepatic jaundice due to the excessive hemolysis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Vasovolvovous crisis: obstruction of small capillaries causing atrophy of organs supplied with these blood vessels</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Symptoms appear after the age of 6 month when HbF is almost totally replaced by Hb A (This is because Hb F prevents sickling of RBCs since it does not contain beta chains)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The disease is less severe in heterozygotes (who have one chromosome affected and therefore 50% of their Hb is Hb S) than homozygotes (who have defect in the two chromosomes that form Hb A and therefore most of their Hb is Hb S)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>120
The costs of medical physiology 1st edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="notes-to-remember-about-hb-s-sickle-cell-disease">Notes to remember about Hb S &amp; sickle cell disease:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#notes-to-remember-about-hb-s-sickle-cell-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>In these patients, Hb F persists in high concentrations after the age of 6 month and until adulthood as compensation.</li>
<li>The disease in heterozygotes is known as sickle cell trait whereas in homozygotes as sickle cell disease.</li>
<li>Sickle cell disease is a well known problem in certain tribes in Western Sudan and Western Africa. It exists especially in malaria endemic areas; this is explained by the fact that hemoglobin S cannot be digested by malaria parasites (i.e. Hb S patients "the sicklers" are rarely infected with malaria).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="malassemia">Malassemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#malassemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Decreased production of globin chains; e.g. deficiency of alpha chains (alpha thalassemia) or beta chains (beta thalassemia). It is characterized by excessive hemolysis of RBCs resulting in hemolytic anemia.</li>
<li>The type of anemia is microcytic hypochromic anemia.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="other-abnormal-types-of-hemoglobin">Other abnormal types of hemoglobin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-abnormal-types-of-hemoglobin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Are numerous. They include Hb C, E, D and H.</li>
<li>The abnormal types of Hb can be identified by electrophoresis (use of an electrical current to separate normal and abnormal types of hemoglobin in the blood, because they have different electrical charges and different rates of movement).</li>
</ul>
<p>Remember the following abnormal conditions of Hb:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="methemoglobin">- Methemoglobin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#methemoglobin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Here iron is oxidized (from the ferrous state (Fe³⁺) to a ferric state (Fe³⁺)) by some oxidizing agents (e.g. drugs). Normally this is converted back by NADH-Methemoglobin Reductase System within the RBCs.</li>
<li>Congenital absence of this enzyme causes hereditary methemoglobinemia.</li>
<li>The ferric state can not bind O₂ in a reversible reaction as the ferrous state.</li>
<li>Methemoglobin gives the skin a dark color resembling cyanosis.</li>
</ul>
<p>121
The costs of medical physiology 1st edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="notes-to-remember-about-hb-s-sickle-cell-disease">Notes to remember about Hb S &amp; sickle cell disease:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#notes-to-remember-about-hb-s-sickle-cell-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>In these patients, Hb F persists in high concentrations after the age of 6 month and until adulthood as compensation.</li>
<li>The disease in heterozygotes is known as sickle cell trait whereas in homozygotes as sickle cell disease.</li>
<li>Sickle cell disease is a well known problem in certain tribes in Western Sudan and Western Africa. It exists especially in malaria endemic areas; this is explained by the fact that hemoglobin S cannot be digested by malaria parasites (i.e. Hb S patients "the sicklers" are rarely infected with malaria).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="thalassemia">Thalassemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thalassemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Decreased production of globin chains; e.g. deficiency of alpha chains (alpha thalassemia) or beta chains (beta thalassemia). It is characterized by excessive hemolysis of RBCs resulting in hemolytic anemia.</li>
<li>The type of anemia is microcytic hypochromic anemia.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="other-abnormal-types-of-hemoglobin">Other abnormal types of hemoglobin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-abnormal-types-of-hemoglobin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Are numerous. They include Hb C, E, D and H.</li>
<li>The abnormal types of Hb can be identified by electrophoresis (use of an electrical current to separate normal and abnormal types of hemoglobin in the blood, because they have different electrical charges and different rates of movement).</li>
</ul>
<p>Remember the following abnormal conditions of Hb:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="methemoglobin">- Methemoglobin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#methemoglobin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Here iron is oxidized (from the ferrous state (Fe³⁺) to a ferric state (Fe³⁺)) by some oxidizing agents (e.g. drugs). Normally this is converted back by NADH-Methemoglobin Reductase System within the RBCs.</li>
<li>Congenital absence of this enzyme causes hereditary methemoglobinemia.</li>
<li>The ferric state can not bind O₂ in a reversible reaction as the ferrous state.</li>
<li>Methemoglobin gives the skin a dark color resembling cyanosis.</li>
</ul>
<p>122
The costs of medical physiology 1st edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="notes-to-remember-about-hb-s-sickle-cell-disease">Notes to remember about Hb S &amp; sickle cell disease:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#notes-to-remember-about-hb-s-sickle-cell-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>In these patients, Hb F persists in high concentrations after the age of 6 month and until adulthood as compensation.</li>
<li>The disease in heterozygotes is known as sickle cell trait whereas in homozygotes as sickle cell disease.</li>
<li>Sickle cell disease is a well known problem in certain tribes in Western Sudan and Western Africa. It exists especially in malaria endemic areas; this is explained by the fact that hemoglobin S cannot be digested by malaria parasites (i.e. Hb S patients "the sicklers" are rarely infected with malaria).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="thalassemia">Thalassemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thalassemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Decreased production of globin chains; e.g. deficiency of alpha chains (alpha thalassemia) or beta chains (beta thalassemia). It is characterized by excessive hemolysis of RBCs resulting in hemolytic anemia.</li>
<li>The type of anemia is microcytic hypochromic anemia.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="other-abnormal-types-of-hemoglobin">Other abnormal types of hemoglobin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-abnormal-types-of-hemoglobin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Are numerous. They include Hb C, E, D and H.</li>
<li>The abnormal types of Hb can be identified by electrophoresis (use of an electrical current to separate normal and abnormal types of hemoglobin in the blood, because they have different electrical charges and different rates of movement).</li>
</ul>
<p>Remember the following abnormal conditions of Hb:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="methemoglobin">- Methemoglobin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#methemoglobin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Here iron is oxidized (from the ferrous state (Fe³⁺) to a ferric state (Fe³⁺)) by some oxidizing agents (e.g. drugs). Normally this is converted back by NADH-Methemoglobin Reductase System within the RBCs.</li>
<li>Congenital absence of this enzyme causes hereditary methemoglobinemia.</li>
<li>The ferric state can not bind O₂ in a reversible reaction as the ferrous state.</li>
<li>Methemoglobin gives the skin a dark color resembling cyanosis.</li>
</ul>
<p>123
The costs of medical physiology 1st edition</p>
<p>126
The view of medical care and life of health</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="carboxyhemoglobin">Carboxyhemoglobin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#carboxyhemoglobin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Formed by reaction of hemoglobin with carbon monoxide.</li>
<li>The affinity of Hb for CO is very high. That's why it displaces oxygen from its sites resulting in reduction of oxygen carrying capacity of the blood (in enemy hypoxia).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="red-blood-cell-destruction">Red Blood Cell DESTRUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#red-blood-cell-destruction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="stages-of-destruction">Stages of destruction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stages-of-destruction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Every second, a large number of RBCs are broken down in the blood macrophage system (previously known as the reticuloendothelial system) e.g. the spleen.</li>
<li>At the same time the same number is replaced by new RBCs produced in the bone marrow.</li>
<li>Anemia occurs if breakdown is more than production whereas polyphenia occurs if breakdown is less than production.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="in-the-spleen-the-main-site-of-rbc-destruction">In the spleen (the main site of RBC destruction)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#in-the-spleen-the-main-site-of-rbc-destruction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Old and abnormally shaped RBCs that cannot pass through small capillaries in the spleen are destroyed by macrophages and the main product of destruction is hemoglobin which gives heme and globin.</li>
<li>Globin is hydrolysed into amino acids which are reutilized.</li>
<li>Heme releases iron which is needed by the body for synthesis of new RBCs. The remaining porphyrin ring is converted to biliverdin and then to bilirubin.</li>
<li>Bilirubin, a yellow pigment that's water insoluble, is transported towards the liver carried by albumin.</li>
<li>Carriage of the insoluble bilirubin in the blood by plasma proteins prevents its appearance in urine (can not be filtered).</li>
</ul>
<p>127
The view of medical care and life of health</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="carboxyhemoglobin">Carboxyhemoglobin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#carboxyhemoglobin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Formed by reaction of hemoglobin with carbon monoxide.</li>
<li>The affinity of Hb for CO is very high. That's why it displaces oxygen from its sites resulting in reduction of oxygen carrying capacity of the blood (in enemy hypoxia).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="red-blood-cell-destruction">Red Blood Cell DESTRUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#red-blood-cell-destruction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="stages-of-destruction">Stages of destruction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stages-of-destruction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Every second, a large number of RBCs are broken down in the blood macrophage system (previously known as the reticuloendothelial system) e.g. the spleen.</li>
<li>At the same time the same number is replaced by new RBCs produced in the bone marrow.</li>
<li>Anemia occurs if breakdown is more than production whereas polyphenia occurs if breakdown is less than production.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="in-the-spleen-the-main-site-of-rbc-destruction">In the spleen (the main site of RBC destruction)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#in-the-spleen-the-main-site-of-rbc-destruction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Old and abnormally shaped RBCs that cannot pass through small capillaries in the spleen are destroyed by macrophages and the main product of destruction is hemoglobin which gives heme and globin.</li>
<li>Globin is hydrolysed into amino acids which are reutilized.</li>
<li>Heme releases iron which is needed by the body for synthesis of new RBCs. The remaining porphyrin ring is converted to biliverdin and then to bilirubin.</li>
<li>Bilirubin, a yellow pigment that's water insoluble, is transported towards the liver carried by albumin.</li>
<li>Carriage of the insoluble bilirubin in the blood by plasma proteins prevents its appearance in urine (can not be filtered).</li>
</ul>
<p>128
The view of medical care and life of health</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="carboxyhemoglobin">Carboxyhemoglobin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#carboxyhemoglobin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Formed by reaction of hemoglobin with carbon monoxide.</li>
<li>The affinity of Hb for CO is very high. That's why it displaces oxygen from its sites resulting in reduction of oxygen carrying capacity of the blood (in enemy hypoxia).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="red-blood-cell-destruction">Red Blood Cell DESTRUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#red-blood-cell-destruction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="stages-of-destruction">Stages of destruction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stages-of-destruction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Every second, a large number of RBCs are broken down in the blood macrophage system (previously known as the reticuloendothelial system) e.g. the spleen.</li>
<li>At the same time the same number is replaced by new RBCs produced in the bone marrow.</li>
<li>Anemia occurs if breakdown is more than production whereas polyphenia occurs if breakdown is less than production.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="in-the-spleen-the-main-site-of-rbc-destruction">In the spleen (the main site of RBC destruction)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#in-the-spleen-the-main-site-of-rbc-destruction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Old and abnormally shaped RBCs that cannot pass through small capillaries in the spleen are destroyed by macrophages and the main product of destruction is hemoglobin which gives heme and globin.</li>
<li>Globin is hydrolysed into amino acids which are reutilized.</li>
<li>Heme releases iron which is needed by the body for synthesis of new RBCs. The remaining porphyrin ring is converted to biliverdin and then to bilirubin.</li>
<li>Bilirubin, a yellow pigment that's water insoluble, is transported towards the liver carried by albumin.</li>
<li>Carriage of the insoluble bilirubin in the blood by plasma proteins prevents its appearance in urine (can not be filtered).</li>
</ul>
<p>127
The work of Hebbins [the writing] / 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="in-the-liver-and-bile">In the liver and bile<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#in-the-liver-and-bile" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>In the liver, bilirubin is conjugated to glucuronic acid to be water soluble.</li>
<li>Conjugation is catalyzed by the enzyme glucuronyl transferase.</li>
<li>Conjugated bilirubin is then secreted in bile. It gives bile its yellowish color.</li>
<li>For this reason it is called bile pigment. However, some of it escapes into the systemic circulation and appears normally in urine.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="in-the-intestine">In the Intestine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#in-the-intestine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Intron bile reaches the intestine, bilirubin is converted by bacteria to steroid-biogen &amp; urid-biogen (both called urid-biogens).</li>
<li>Steroid-biogen is secreted in stool, giving it its characteristic color.</li>
<li>Urid-biogen is absorbed to the entero-hepatic circulation. However, some of it escapes into the systemic circulation and appears normally in urine.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fig-8-4-accession-of-bilirubin">Fig 8.4. Accession of bilirubin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-8-4-accession-of-bilirubin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-8a5ff3d3.jpeg" alt="img-188.jpeg"></p>
<p>128
The work of Hebbins [the writing] / 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="in-the-liver-and-bile">In the liver and bile<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#in-the-liver-and-bile" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>In the liver, bilirubin is conjugated to glucuronic acid to be water soluble.</li>
<li>Conjugation is catalyzed by the enzyme glucuronyl transferase.</li>
<li>Conjugated bilirubin is then secreted in bile. It gives bile its yellowish color.</li>
<li>For this reason it is called bile pigment. However, some of it escapes into the systemic circulation and appears normally in urine.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="in-the-intestine">In the Intestine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#in-the-intestine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>When bile reaches the intestine, bilirubin is converted by bacteria to steroid-biogen &amp; urid-biogen (both called urid-biogens).</li>
<li>Steroid-biogen is secreted in stool, giving it its characteristic color.</li>
<li>Urid-biogen is absorbed to the entero-hepatic circulation. However, some of it escapes into the systemic circulation and appears normally in urine.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fig-8-4-accession-of-bilirubin">Fig 8.4. Accession of bilirubin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-8-4-accession-of-bilirubin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="in-the-liver-and-bile">In the liver and bile<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#in-the-liver-and-bile" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>Conjugation is catalyzed by the enzyme glucuronyl transferase.</li>
<li>Conjugated bilirubin is then secreted in bile. It gives bile its yellowish color.</li>
<li>For this reason it is called bile pigment. However, some of it escapes into the systemic circulation and appears normally in urine.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="in-the-intestine">In the Intestine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#in-the-intestine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>When bile reaches the intestine, bilirubin is converted by bacteria to steroid-biogen &amp; urid-biogen (both called urid-biogens).</li>
<li>Steroid-biogen is secreted in stool, giving it its characteristic color.</li>
<li>Urid-biogen is absorbed to the entero-hepatic circulation. However, some of it escapes into the systemic circulation and appears normally in urine.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fig-8-4-accession-of-bilirubin">Fig 8.4. Accession of bilirubin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-8-4-accession-of-bilirubin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
