<p>128
The area of medical physiology of adults</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="jaundice">Jaundice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#jaundice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Yellowish coloration of the skin, sclera &amp; mucus membranes.</li>
<li>Occurs due to high level of bilirubin in the plasma (normal bilirubin level is about 1mg/dL).</li>
<li>Jaundice appears when the concentration is higher than 2mg/dL.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-jaundice">Types of Jaundice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-jaundice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Pre-hepatic (hemolytic)</li>
<li>Hepatic</li>
<li>Post-hepatic jaundice (obstructive)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-pre-hepatic-jaundice">1. Pre-hepatic Jaundice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-pre-hepatic-jaundice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Caused by excessive hemolysis of RBCs resulting in excessive release of unconjugated bilirubin (gives indirect reaction in the van den Bergh test).</li>
<li>The high amount of unconjugated bilirubin exceeds the capacity of the liver to conjugation and excretion into bile. For this reason the unconjugated bilirubin appears in blood causing the yellowish color. However, it does not appear in urine because it is bound to albumin in the blood (autotonic jaundice).</li>
<li>Conjugated bilirubin that's secreted by the liver in bile is higher than normal. Therefore production of undidrograms in the intestine and consequently its excretion in urine are also higher than normal.</li>
<li>Prehepatic jaundice is usually associated with hemolytic anemia.</li>
<li>Causes include:</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="abnormal-rbc-shape">Abnormal RBC shape<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormal-rbc-shape" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Sickle cell anemia (due to Hb S)</li>
<li>Congenital spherocytosis (Due to lack of specchin)</li>
<li>Congenital elliptocytosis (due to lack of specchin)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="lack-of-rbc-enzymes">Lack of RBC enzymes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lack-of-rbc-enzymes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Glucose 6 phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency</li>
<li>Pyruvate kinase deficiency</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="mechanical-destruction-of-rbcs">Mechanical destruction of RBCs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanical-destruction-of-rbcs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Malaria</li>
</ul>
<p>129
The area of medical physiology of adults</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="jaundice">Jaundice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#jaundice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Yellowish coloration of the skin, sclera &amp; mucus membranes.</li>
<li>Occurs due to high level of bilirubin in the plasma (normal bilirubin level is about 1mg/dL).</li>
<li>Jaundice appears when the concentration is higher than 2mg/dL.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-jaundice">Types of Jaundice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-jaundice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Pre-hepatic (hemolytic)</li>
<li>Hepatic</li>
<li>Post-hepatic jaundice (obstructive)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-pre-hepatic-jaundice">1. Pre-hepatic Jaundice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-pre-hepatic-jaundice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Caused by excessive hemolysis of RBCs resulting in excessive release of unconjugated bilirubin (gives indirect reaction in the van den Bergh test).</li>
<li>The high amount of unconjugated bilirubin exceeds the capacity of the liver to conjugation and excretion into bile. For this reason the unconjugated bilirubin appears in blood causing the yellowish color. However, it does not appear in urine because it is bound to albumin in the blood (autotonic jaundice).</li>
<li>Conjugated bilirubin that's secreted by the liver in bile is higher than normal. Therefore production of undidrograms in the intestine and consequently its excretion in urine are also higher than normal.</li>
<li>Prehepatic jaundice is usually associated with hemolytic anemia.</li>
<li>Causes include:</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="abnormal-rbc-shape">Abnormal RBC shape<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormal-rbc-shape" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Sickle cell anemia (due to Hb S)</li>
<li>Congenital spherocytosis (Due to lack of specchin)</li>
<li>Congenital elliptocytosis (due to lack of specchin)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="lack-of-rbc-enzymes">Lack of RBC enzymes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lack-of-rbc-enzymes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Glucose 6 phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency</li>
<li>Pyruvate kinase deficiency</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="mechanical-destruction-of-rbcs">Mechanical destruction of RBCs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanical-destruction-of-rbcs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Malaria</li>
</ul>
<p>130
The area of medical physiology of adults</p>
<p>129
The uses of medical physiology 14th edition</p>
<ul>
<li>Hyperepilemism</li>
<li>Other causes like T</li>
<li>Thalassemia</li>
<li>Autoimmune hemolytic anemia...</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>3. Hepatic Jaundice</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Caused by liver cell damage or lack of enzymes resulting in failure of bilirubin conjugation in liver cells (thus increasing unconjugated bilirubin in the blood) or failure of bilirubin excretion in bile after its conjugation (thus increasing conjugated bilirubin in the blood).</li>
<li>i.e. Bilirubin in hepatic jaundice may be conjugated or unconjugated.</li>
<li>Conjugated bilirubin appears in urine whereas unconjugated bilirubin does not (because it is bound to albumin).</li>
<li>Causes of hepatic jaundice include:</li>
<li>Viral hepatitis (e.g. A, B, C, ...) and alcoholic liver disease; cause cell damage + failure of conjugation + unconjugated jaundice.</li>
<li>Dutch Johnson &amp; Rotor syndromes: due congenital defect in the mechanism of bilirubin secretion in bile + conjugated jaundice.</li>
<li>Crigler-Nagel syndrome (type I &amp; II); due to congenital deficiency of the conjugating enzyme + unconjugated jaundice.</li>
<li>Gilbert's syndrome; due to decreased activity of the conjugating enzyme + one of the co-occurient causes of unconjugated jaundice.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>3. Post-hepatic Jaundice</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Caused by obstruction of the biliary tracts. This prevents conjugated bilirubin from reaching the intestine. Therefore it appears in blood causing the characteristic yellowish color.</li>
<li>The conjugated bilirubin, which is water soluble, appears in urine (Choluric Jaundice).</li>
<li>It gives urine a characteristic dark yellowish color. Undoitrogen is not produced in the intestine and so it is absent from urine.</li>
</ul>
<p>129
The uses of medical physiology 14th edition</p>
<ul>
<li>Hyperepilemism</li>
<li>Other causes like T</li>
<li>Thalassemia</li>
<li>Autoimmune hemolytic anemia...</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>2. Hepatic Jaundice</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Caused by liver cell damage or lack of enzymes resulting in failure of bilirubin conjugation in liver cells (thus increasing unconjugated bilirubin in the blood) or failure of bilirubin excretion in bile after its conjugation (thus increasing conjugated bilirubin in the blood).</li>
<li>i.e. Bilirubin in hepatic jaundice may be conjugated or unconjugated.</li>
<li>Conjugated bilirubin appears in urine whereas unconjugated bilirubin does not (because it is bound to albumin).</li>
<li>Causes of hepatic jaundice include:</li>
<li>Viral hepatitis (e.g. A, B, C, ...) and alcoholic liver disease; cause cell damage + failure of conjugation + unconjugated jaundice.</li>
<li>Dutch Johnson &amp; Rotor syndromes: due congenital defect in the mechanism of bilirubin secretion in bile + conjugated jaundice.</li>
<li>Crigler-Nagel syndrome (type I &amp; II); due to congenital deficiency of the conjugating enzyme + unconjugated jaundice.</li>
<li>Gilbert's syndrome; due to decreased activity of the conjugating enzyme + one of the co-occurient causes of unconjugated jaundice.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>3. Post-hepatic Jaundice</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Caused by obstruction of the biliary tracts. This prevents conjugated bilirubin from reaching the intestine. Therefore it appears in blood causing the characteristic yellowish color.</li>
<li>The conjugated bilirubin, which is water soluble, appears in urine (Choluric Jaundice).</li>
<li>It gives urine a characteristic dark yellowish color. Undoitrogen is not produced in the intestine and so it is absent from urine.</li>
</ul>

The uses of medical physiology 14th edition</p>
<p>140
The view of medical physiology 17 pages
140
The view of medical physiology 17 pages</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Since bile does not reach the intestine, stool becomes pale (due to absent bile pigments like bilirubin) and full of fat (due to absent bile salts which are essential for fat digestion and absorption).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Causes of obstructive jaundice include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Gall stores obstructing the common bile duct</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Parasites obstructing the common bile duct</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tumors obstructing the common bile duct (e.g. carcinoma head of the pancreas)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Since bile does not reach the intestine, stool becomes pale (due to absent bile pigments like bilirubin) and full of fat (due to absent bile salts which are essential for fat digestion and absorption).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Causes of obstructive jaundice include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Gall stores obstructing the common bile duct</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Parasites obstructing the common bile duct</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tumors obstructing the common bile duct (e.g. carcinoma head of the pancreas)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Since bile does not reach the intestine, stool becomes pale (due to absent bile pigments like bilirubin) and full of fat (due to absent bile salts which are essential for fat digestion and absorption).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Causes of obstructive jaundice include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Gall stores obstructing the common bile duct</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Parasites obstructing the common bile duct</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tumors obstructing the common bile duct (e.g. carcinoma head of the pancreas)</p>
</li>
</ul>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="section">Section<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="definition">Definition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>State of reduction in hemoglobin concentration below the normal range (according to age and sex)</li>
<li>This occurs because of low Hb within each RBC (S/hr) low total count of RBCs</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="classification-of-anemia">Classification of anemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#classification-of-anemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Decreased production of RBCs</li>
<li>Increased destination of RBCs</li>
<li>Blood loss</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-anemia-due-to-decreased-rbc-production">1. Anemia due to decreased RBC production<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-anemia-due-to-decreased-rbc-production" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Diseases of the bone marrow</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Examples include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Bone marrow infiltration</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tumors (primary tumors like leukemias or secondary tumors from other sources like the bone or the thyroid)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Myelofibrosis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Bone marrow failure (Aplastic anemia)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Congenital (Famom's anemia)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Drugs (e.g. chloramphenicol)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Lack of nutrients (Nutritional, exercise)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Examples include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Iron deficiency anemia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Vitamin B12 deficiency anemia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Folic acid deficiency anemia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Deficiency of proteins</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Lack of hormones</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Examples include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Erythropoietin deficiency (e.g. chronic renal failure)</p>
</li>
</ul>

The costs of medical proceedings / 2nd edition</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-anemia-due-to-increased-rbc-destruction">2-Anemia due to increased RBC destruction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-anemia-due-to-increased-rbc-destruction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causes-include">Causes include<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Abnormal RBC shape</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sickle cell anemia (due to Hb S)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Congenital spherocytosis (Due to lack of spectrin)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Congenital elliptocytosis (due to lack of spectrin)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Lack of RBC enzymes</p>
</li>
<li>

</li>
<li>

<p>Mechanical destruction of RBCs</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Malaria</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypersplenism</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Other causes</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Thalassemia, Autoimmune hemolytic anemia</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="3-anemia-of-blood-loss">3-Anemia of blood loss<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-anemia-of-blood-loss" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acute-blood-loss">Acute blood loss<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-blood-loss" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Acute bleeding occurs following trauma</li>
<li>The drop in Hb concentration does not occur immediately 8 hours after about 3 days (i.e. after restoration of plasma volume and below restoration of cells). The cells take about 4 weeks to be restored.</li>
<li>Severity of anemia is best assessed by history (information given by the patient or his relatives about the blood loss).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chronic-blood-loss">Chronic blood loss<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chronic-blood-loss" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs due to daily loss of small amount of blood over long period of time. This results in iron deficiency anemia (due to loss of iron with blood, about 0.5 mg iron in each ml of blood).</li>
<li>Examples include: Worms like ankylostoma (the hook worm), chronic peptic ulcer and bleeding from a GIT tumor.</li>
</ul>
<p>143
The care of medical physiology of cancer</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-anemia-due-to-increased-rbc-destruction">2-Anemia due to increased RBC destruction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-anemia-due-to-increased-rbc-destruction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causes-include">Causes include<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Abnormal RBC shape</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sickle cell anemia (due to Hb S)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Congenital spherocytosis (Due to lack of spectrin)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Congenital elliptocytosis (due to lack of spectrin)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Lack of RBC enzymes</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Glucose-6 phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pyruvate kinase deficiency</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Mechanical destruction of RBCs</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Malaria</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypersplenism</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Other causes</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Thalassemia, Autoimmune hemolytic anemia ...</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="3-anemia-of-blood-loss">3-Anemia of blood loss<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-anemia-of-blood-loss" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acute-blood-loss">Acute blood loss<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-blood-loss" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Acute bleeding occurs following trauma</li>
<li>The drop in Hb concentration does not occur immediately 8 hours after about 3 days (i.e. after restoration of plasma volume and below restoration of cells). The cells take about 4 weeks to be restored.</li>
<li>Severity of anemia is best assessed by history (information given by the patient or his relatives about the blood loss).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chronic-blood-loss">Chronic blood loss<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chronic-blood-loss" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs due to daily loss of small amount of blood over long period of time. This results in iron deficiency anemia (due to loss of iron with blood, about 0.5 mg iron in each ml of blood).</li>
<li>Examples include: Worms like ankylostoma (the hook worm), chronic peptic ulcer and bleeding from a GIT tumor.</li>
</ul>
<p>142
The care of medical physiology of cancer</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="3-anemia-due-to-increased-rbc-destruction">3-Anemia due to increased RBC destruction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-anemia-due-to-increased-rbc-destruction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causes-include">Causes include<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Abnormal RBC shape</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sickle cell anemia (due to Hb S)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Congenital spherocytosis (Due to lack of spectrin)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Congenital elliptocytosis (due to lack of spectrin)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Lack of RBC enzymes</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Glucose-6 phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pyruvate kinase deficiency</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Mechanical destruction of RBCs</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Malaria</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypersplenism</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Other causes</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Thalassemia, Autoimmune hemolytic anemia</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="3-anemia-of-blood-loss">3-Anemia of blood loss<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-anemia-of-blood-loss" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acute-blood-loss">Acute blood loss<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-blood-loss" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Acute bleeding occurs following trauma</li>
<li>The drop in Hb concentration does not occur immediately 8 hours after about 3 days (i.e. after restoration of plasma volume and below restoration of cells). The cells take about 4 weeks to be restored.</li>
<li>Severity of anemia is best assessed by history (information given by the patient or his relatives about the blood loss).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chronic-blood-loss">Chronic blood loss<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chronic-blood-loss" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs due to daily loss of small amount of blood over long period of time. This results in iron deficiency anemia (due to loss of iron with blood, about 0.5 mg iron in each ml of blood).</li>
<li>Examples include: Worms like ankylostoma (the hook worm), chronic peptic ulcer and bleeding from a GIT tumor.</li>
</ul>
<p>The rest of the text is provided by a structure that does not include any content.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diagnosis-of-anemia">Diagnosis of anemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diagnosis-of-anemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-1-symptoms">Step 1 (symptoms):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-1-symptoms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Anemia is suspected when patients complain of. Fatigability, palpitations, breathlessness and headache.</p>
<p>Remember that Mild anemia and even severe anemia that's developed gradually over long time may be asymptomatic (= without symptoms) due to compensatory mechanisms.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-2-signs">Step 2 (signs):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-2-signs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Doctors do clinical examination looking for:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pallor of mucus membranes</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tachycardia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>High pulse pressure (increased systolic and decreased diastolic pressure)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Signs of the cause or signs of complications</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>During clinical examination, doctors look for signs of a cause that may be responsible for the anemia (e.g. jaundice indicates hemolytic anemia and severe loss of weight indicates malignancy). At the same time they look for a possible complication of anemia, especially if it is severe. A well known example is anemia heart failure presenting with generalized edema.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-3-investigations">Step 3 (investigations):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-3-investigations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Investigations are required to confirm the diagnosis of anemia. These include: Hb estimation, PCV and RBC count</li>
<li>Investigations are also needed to know the cause of anemia. Examples include:</li>
<li>Peripheral blood picture</li>
<li>The shape and color of RBCs under the microscope may give clue about the cause of anemia, look at this table:</li>
</ul>
<p>The rest of the text is provided by a structure that does not include any content.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diagnosis-of-anemia">Diagnosis of anemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diagnosis-of-anemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-1-symptoms">Step 1 (symptoms):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-1-symptoms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Anemia is suspected when patients complain of. Fatigability, palpitations, breathlessness and headache.</p>
<p>Remember that Mild anemia and even severe anemia that's developed gradually over long time may be asymptomatic (= without symptoms) due to compensatory mechanisms.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-2-signs">Step 2 (signs):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-2-signs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Doctors do clinical examination looking for:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pallor of mucus membranes</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tachycardia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>High pulse pressure (increased systolic and decreased diastolic pressure)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Signs of the cause or signs of complications</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>During clinical examination, doctors look for signs of a cause that may be responsible for the anemia (e.g. jaundice indicates hemolytic anemia and severe loss of weight indicates malignancy). At the same time they look for a possible complication of anemia, especially if it is severe. A well known example is anemia heart failure presenting with generalized edema.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-3-investigations">Step 3 (investigations):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-3-investigations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Investigations are required to confirm the diagnosis of anemia. These include: Hb estimation, PCV and RBC count</li>
<li>Investigations are also needed to know the cause of anemia. Examples include:</li>
<li>Peripheral blood picture</li>
<li>The shape and color of RBCs under the microscope may give clue about the cause of anemia, look at this table:</li>
</ul>
<p>The rest of the text is provided by a structure that does not include any content.</p>
<p>The rest of the text is provided by a structure that does not include any content.</p>
<p>144
The cost of medical physiology of cancer</p>
<p>Table E.1:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Shape of RBCs</th><th>Color of RBCs</th><th>Possible causes</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Microcytic</td><td>Hypochromic</td><td>Iron deficiency</td></tr><tr><td>Thalassemia</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Macrocytic (Megastriastic)</td><td>Normochromic</td><td>Vitamin B12 deficiency</td></tr><tr><td>Folic acid deficiency</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Normocytic</td><td>Normochromic</td><td>Anemia of chronic illness</td></tr><tr><td>Chronic renal failure</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul>
<li>Direct microscopy may give additional information. For example fragments, RBCs indicate hemolysis.</li>
<li>High reticulocyte count and bilirubin level in plasma indicate hemolytic anemia.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rbc-indices">RBC indices<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rbc-indices" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Can be calculated to give similar information as the microscopic peripheral blood picture (i.e. information about the shape and color of RBCs). - they include the following indices:</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>MCV (Mean corpuscular volume)</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>PCV x 10RBC, normally = 80 – 90.5, (may be up to 102.5.)</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>RBCs with higher results are described as macrocytic, lower results are microcytic and normal results are normocytic.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>MCH (Mean corpuscular hemoglobin)</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Hb x 10RBC, normally = 25.02 pg</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>RBCs with lower results are described as hypochromic while normal results are normochromic.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>MCHC (Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration)</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Hb x 100PCV, normally = 34% (or 34 g/dL) range: 32-36 g/dL</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>RBCs with lower results are described as hypochromic while normal results are normochromic.</li>
</ul>
<p>145
The cost of medical physiology of cancer</p>
<p>Table E.1:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Shape of RBCs</th><th>Color of RBCs</th><th>Possible causes</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Microcytic</td><td>Hypochromic</td><td>Iron deficiency</td></tr><tr><td>Thalassemia</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Macrocytic (Megastriastic)</td><td>Normochromic</td><td>Vitamin B12 deficiency</td></tr><tr><td>Folic acid deficiency</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Normocytic</td><td>Normochromic</td><td>Anemia of chronic illness</td></tr><tr><td>Chronic renal failure</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul>
<li>Direct microscopy may give additional information. For example fragments, RBCs indicate hemolysis.</li>
<li>High reticulocyte count and bilirubin level in plasma indicate hemolytic anemia.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rbc-indices">RBC indices<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rbc-indices" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Can be calculated to give similar information as the microscopic peripheral blood picture (i.e. information about the shape and color of RBCs). - they include the following indices:</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>MCV (Mean corpuscular volume)</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>PCV x 10RBC, normally = 80 – 90.5, (may be up to 100.5.)</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>RBCs with higher results are described as macrocytic, lower results are microcytic and normal results are normocytic.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>MCH (Mean corpuscular hemoglobin)</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Hb x 10RBC, normally = 25.02 pg</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>RBCs with lower results are described as hypochromic while normal results are normochromic.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>MCHC (Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration)</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Hb x 100PCV, normally = 34% (or 34 g/dL) range: 32-36 g/dL</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>RBCs with lower results are described as hypochromic while normal results are normochromic.</li>
</ul>

The cost of medical physiology of cancer</p>

<ul>
<li>Direct microscopy may give additional information. For example fragments, RBCs indicate hemolysis.</li>
<li>High reticulocyte count and bilirubin level in plasma indicate hemolytic anemia.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rbc-indices">RBC indices<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rbc-indices" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Can be calculated to give similar information as the microscopic peripheral blood picture (i.e. information about the shape and color of RBCs). - they include the following indices:</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>MCV (Mean corpuscular volume)</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>PCV x 10RBC, normally = 80 – 90.5, (may be up to 100.5.)</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>RBCs with higher results are described as macrocytic, lower results are microcytic and normal results are normocytic.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>MCH (Mean corpuscular hemoglobin)</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Hb x 10RBC, normally = 25.02 pg</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>RBCs with lower results are described as hypochromic while normal results are normochromic.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>MCHC (Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration)</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Hb x 100PCV, normally = 34% (or 34 g/dL) range: 31-35 g/dL</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>RBCs with lower results are described as hypochromic while normal results are normochromic.</li>
</ul>
<p>147
The cost of medical physiology of cancer</p>
<p>142
The issue of medical philosophy / 1st edition
143
The issue of medical philosophy / 1st edition
144
The issue of medical philosophy / 1st edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="additional-investigations-for-specific-causes">Additional investigations for specific causes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#additional-investigations-for-specific-causes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Investigations for iron deficiency like TIBC, iron concentration and ferritin level in plasma (see iron metabolism).</li>
<li>Investigations for chronic renal failure like serum creatinine, urea and electrolytes.</li>
<li>Investigations for leukemia like total WBC count and differential count.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="treatment-of-anemia">Treatment of anemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#treatment-of-anemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Treatment of the cause (e.g. stop the site of bleeding)</li>
<li>Replacement of the deficient nutrient (e.g. iron and/or folic acid)</li>
<li>Correction of the low Hb by blood transfusion (if Hb is very low). This is important to prevent anemic heart failure. However, if heart failure has already developed, it is preferred to transfuse packed cells rather than whole blood, to avoid additional fluid overload.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="additional-investigations-for-specific-causes">Additional investigations for specific causes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#additional-investigations-for-specific-causes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Investigations for iron deficiency like TIBC, iron concentration and ferritin level in plasma (see iron metabolism).</li>
<li>Investigations for chronic renal failure like serum creatinine, urea and electrolytes.</li>
<li>Investigations for leukemia like total WBC count and differential count.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="treatment-of-anemia">Treatment of anemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#treatment-of-anemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Treatment of the cause (e.g. stop the site of bleeding)</li>
<li>Replacement of the deficient nutrient (e.g. iron and/or folic acid)</li>
<li>Correction of the low Hb by blood transfusion (if Hb is very low). This is important to prevent anemic heart failure. However, if heart failure has already developed, it is preferred to transfuse packed cells rather than whole blood, to avoid additional fluid overload.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="additional-investigations-for-specific-causes">Additional investigations for specific causes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#additional-investigations-for-specific-causes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Investigations for iron deficiency like TIBC, iron concentration and ferritin level in plasma (see iron metabolism).</li>
<li>Investigations for chronic renal failure like serum creatinine, urea and electrolytes.</li>
<li>Investigations for leukemia like total WBC count and differential count.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="treatment-of-anemia">Treatment of anemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#treatment-of-anemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Treatment of the cause (e.g. stop the site of bleeding)</li>
<li>Replacement of the deficient nutrient (e.g. iron and/or folic acid)</li>
<li>Correction of the low Hb by blood transfusion (if Hb is very low). This is important to prevent anemic heart failure. However, if heart failure has already developed, it is preferred to transfuse packed cells rather than whole blood, to avoid additional fluid overload.</li>
</ol>
<p>QUESTIONS FOR SELF ASSIGNMENT-6 (BEST OF FIVE)</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>A male fetus during the second trimester of intra-uterine life has:
a. about 50% of the total body weight as water
b. red blood cells synthesized in the liver
c. "Green" type of haemoglobin
d. and A antibodies if he is blood group B
e. and D antibodies if he is mouse negative</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>All the following about haemoglobin s are correct except:
a. 5 consists of two alpha and two beta chains
b. 35 alpha chains are normal
c. 3 is absent in all neonates carrying the genes of sickle cell disease
d. 3 precipitates due to hypoxia causing "sickling" of leucocytes
e. 6 results in sickle cell anemia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Men:
a. is found in high amounts in mother's milk
b. is absorbed mainly in the terminal ileum
c. is transported in plasma with albumin
d. is not stored in the liver
e. deficiency causes reduction in volume and color of red blood cells</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of obstructive jaundice:
a. past fatty stool
b. normal urine color
c. absent underinogen from urine
d. high conjugated bilirubin in blood
e. bleeding tendency</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The principal hormone needed for red blood cell formation is:
a. cortisol
b. thyroid
c. vitamin D
d. erythropoietin
e. parathyroid hormone</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by:
a. high P/C3
b. aplastic bone marrow
c. past fatty stool
d. low ferritin level in the plasma
e. macrocytic normochromic RBCs</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Concerning folic acid, it is:
a. a fat soluble vitamin
b. found in green leafy vegetable
c. absorbed better in presence of reducing factors</p>
</li>
</ol>

a. high concentration of conjugated bilirubin in urine
b. high concentration of unconjugated bilirubin in plasma
c. absence of unabhängigen in urine
d. pale and fatty stool

b. ribs
c. pelvic bones
d. shaft of the femur
e. sternum</p>

a. precursors of white blood cells

c. increased in bacterial infections
d. decreased in haemolytic anemia
e. increased following correction of nutritional anemia</p>

<p>The mature red blood cell is children:
a. is synthesized in the spleen
b. has few mitochondria
c. its arcane increases in folic acid deficiency
d. of males has more hemoglobin than that of females
e. lives for about 6 hours</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Concerning the packed cell volume (PCV), it is:
a. the percentage of RBCs out of total cells in the blood
b. higher in neonates than in infants
c. normally about 57% in the adult male
d. high in patients with haemolytic anemia
e. low in all subjects living at high altitude</p>
</li>
<li>

a. is stimulated by increased oxygen tension.
b. is needed for Hb synthesis
c. reduces maturation time of red blood cells
d. its level is always high in people living at high altitudes
e. its level is always low in patients with chronic kidney failure</p>
</li>

b. is characterized by abnormal alpha chains
c. starts to appear in normal children after the age of 6 months
d. precipitates when there is high Hb
e. is an important protective mechanism against malaria</p>

c. volume of red blood cells is above normal

The view of national psychology 17 (2004)</p>
<ol start="15">
<li>
<p>Regarding iron absorption, it is:
a. horizontally controlled
b. decreased by HCL
c. Increased by intrinsic factor of the stomach
d. decreased by penicillin
e. about 10% of daily ingested iron</p>

<li>
<p>Hyperactivity in the bone marrow is indicated by:
a. jaundice
b. anaemia
c. leucocytosis
d. thrombocytosis
e. microleukemia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Microcytic hypochromic anemia occurs due to:
a. acute renal failure
b. hepatic cirrhosis
c. congestive heart failure
d. chronic peptic ulcer
e. flatraecy</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Vitamin B12:
a. is found in green vegetables
b. is absorbed in the stomach
c. is needed for haemoglobin synthesis
d. deficiency causes nonreolytic normochromic anemia
e. deficiency results in demyelination neuropathy</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hb concentration is a pregnant lady is 9 g/dL, PCV is 39% and RBC count is 3 x 10⁶ cal/well. Which of the following is not true:
a. mean corpuscular hemoglobin is normal
b. iron status is probably normal
c. volume of red blood cells is above normal
d. the lady must probably suffers from vit. B12 deficiency
e. folate deficiency is expected in this patient</p>
</li>
</ol>

<p>140
The costs of medical physiology 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="applicities">APPLICITIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#applicities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="definition">Definition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The mobile units in the blood that protect the body against invaders.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="count">Count<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#count" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>-4000-11000/mm³</p>
<ul>
<li>Higher count (leucocytosis) is caused by leukemia, infections, inflammation.</li>
<li>Lower count (leucopenia) is caused by certain diseases of the bone marrow and certain infections (e.g. typhoid fever).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="formation-of-wbcs">Formation of WBCs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#formation-of-wbcs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Size, bone marrow</li>
<li>Stages: (Proliferation &amp; Maturation)</li>
<li>Like other types of cells, formation starts by differentiation of pluripotent stem cells into committed stem cells (progenitor cells).</li>
<li>There are separate committed stem cells for lymphocytes, basophils and eosinophils, whereas neutrophils and monocytes have a common precursor.</li>
<li>Regulation by certain colony stimulating factors (GM-CSF) and cytokines (IL2, IL4 and IL5).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="classification">Classification<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#classification" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>According to presence or absence of cytoplasmic granules, they are classified into two major types: granulocytes and agranulocytes.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-granulocytes">The granulocytes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-granulocytes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Have granulated cytoplasm</li>
<li>Have polysegmented nucleus</li>
<li>Known as poly-morpho-nuclear leucocytes (PNNL)</li>
<li>Have very short life span (Hours)</li>
<li>Have 3 types (according to reaction of the cytoplasmic granules with acidic or basic dyes): Neutrophiles, Basophiles and Eosinophils</li>
</ul>
<p>141
The costs of medical physiology 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bioactive">BIOACTIVE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bioactive" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="definition">Definition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="count">Count<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#count" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="formation-of-wbcs">Formation of WBCs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#formation-of-wbcs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="classification">Classification<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#classification" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-granulocytes">The granulocytes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-granulocytes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>

<li>Have 3 types (according to reaction of the cytoplasmic granules with acidic or basic dyes): Neutrophiles, Basophiles and Eosinophils.</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="transcript">TRANSCRIPT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transcript" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="definition">Definition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="count">Count<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#count" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="formation-of-wbcs">Formation of WBCs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#formation-of-wbcs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Size, bone marrow</li>
<li>Stages: (Prosthesion &amp; Maturation)</li>
<li>Like other types of cells, formation starts by differentiation of pluripotent stem cells into committed stem cells (progenitor cells).</li>
<li>There are separate committed stem cells for lymphocytes, basophils and eosinophils, whereas neutrophils and monocytes have a common precursor.</li>
<li>Regulation by certain colony stimulating factors (GM-CSF) and cytokines (IL2, IL4 and IL5).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="classification">Classification<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#classification" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>According to presence or absence of cytoplasmic granules, they are classified into two major types: granulocytes and agranulocytes.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-granulocytes">The granulocytes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-granulocytes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Have granulated cytoplasm</li>
<li>Have polysegmented nucleus</li>
<li>Known as poly-morpho-nuclear leucocytes (PNNL)</li>
<li>Have very short life span (Hours)</li>
<li>Have 3 types (according to reaction of the cytoplasmic granules with acidic or basic dyes): Neutrophiles, Basophiles and Eosinophils.</li>
</ul>
<p>The costs of medical physiology 4th edition</p>
<p>112
The role of medical psychology: P. 100</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Tissue macrophages include: Kupffer cells in the liver, Langerhans cells in the skin, Microglia in the brain, Osteoclasts in bone and Alveolar macrophages in the lung (= members of the mononuclear phagocyte system, used to be known as reticulo-endothelial system).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Functions of the tissue macrophages (or the phagocyte system):</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Phagocytosis (activated of phagocytes by T lymphocytes)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Presentation of antigens to lymphocytes</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Release of cytokines and other substances (see immunity).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Lymphocytes</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Correlate 20-40% of total WBCs</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Size: may be small or large</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Nucleus: rounded</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cytoplasm: scanty and not granulated</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Before birth: they are produced in the bone marrow as lymphocyte precursor cells</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Then after birth: some still arise from bone marrow. However, most lymphocytes are formed in the lymph nodes, thymus or spleen, from the original precursor cells that developed in the bone marrow and processed in one of the following sites: Thymus gland or Bacte of Fabricius (in birds) for burrs equivalent tissues for the fetal liver and the bone marrow (in humans)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Accordingly there are 2 types of lymphocytes:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>T Lymphocytes (processed in the thymus gland) &amp;</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>B Lymphocytes (processed in the Bacte equivalent tissues)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The two types circulate between blood and lymph.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>T Lymphocytes:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Correlate about 80% of total lymphocytes</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Mature in the thymus gland</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>113
The role of medical psychology: P. 100</p>
