<li>
<p>Then after birth: some still arise from bone marrow. However, most lymphocytes are formed in the lymph nodes, thymus or spleen, from the original precursor cells that developed in the bone marrow and processed in one of the following sites: Thymus gland or Bacte of Fabricius (in birds) for burrs equivalent tissues for the fetal liver and the bone marrow (in humans)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Accordingly there are 2 types of lymphocytes:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>T Lymphocytes (processed in the thymus gland) &amp;</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>B Lymphocytes (processed in the Bacte equivalent tissues)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The two types circulate between blood and lymph.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>T Lymphocytes:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Correlate about 80% of total lymphocytes</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Mature in the thymus gland</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>123
The aims of medical physiology: 4th edition</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Types: Helper T cells (CD4 cells) &amp; cytotoxic T cells (CD8 cells).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When activated, the T lymphocyte from memory T cells; for future recognition of the invader (= the secondary immune response).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>They are responsible for cell mediated immunity (see below).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>B-Lymphocytes:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Constitute about 20% of total lymphocytes.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Maturate in the bone marrow.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When activated, they differentiate into plasma cells (for production of antibodies) and memory B cells (for future recognition of the invader, = the secondary immune response).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Responsible for humoral immunity. i.e. secretion of antibodies that are mixed with body fluids (see below).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="how-can-white-blood-cells-perform-their-functions">How can white blood cells perform their functions?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#how-can-white-blood-cells-perform-their-functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Chemotaxis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Attraction of neutrophils to the site of infection by certain substances including components of the complement system (C5a), leukotrienes and products of damaged tissues, bacteria or leucocytes.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Diapedesis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Passage of white blood cells from the blood to the tissues through the wall of capillaries (e.g. neutrophils, basophils, eosinophils and monocytes).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Opsonization</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Preparation for eating or making the foreign cell palatable or tasty for phagocytosis. Opsonine that coat foreign cells include IgG and some proteins of the complement system.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Phagocytosis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The process of ingestion of bacteria or any abnormal cell by a phagocytic cell (e.g. neutrophils, Monocytes or macrophages).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Preceded by recognition and followed by intracellular killing.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>124
The aims of medical physiology: 4th edition</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Types: Helper T cells (CD4 cells) &amp; cytotoxic T cells (CD8 cells).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When activated, the T lymphocyte from memory T cells; for future recognition of the invader (= the secondary immune response).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>They are responsible for cell mediated immunity (see below).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>B-Lymphocytes:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Constitute about 20% of total lymphocytes.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Maturate in the bone marrow.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When activated, they differentiate into plasma cells (for production of antibodies) and memory B cells (for future recognition of the invader, = the secondary immune response).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Responsible for humoral immunity. i.e. secretion of antibodies that are mixed with body fluids (see below).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="how-can-white-blood-cells-perform-their-functions">How can white blood cells perform their functions?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#how-can-white-blood-cells-perform-their-functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Chemotaxis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Attraction of neutrophils to the site of infection by certain substances including components of the complement system (C5a), leukotrienes and products of damaged tissues, bacteria or leucocytes.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Diapedesis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Passage of white blood cells from the blood to the tissues through the wall of capillaries (e.g. neutrophils, basophils, eosinophils and monocytes).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Opsonization</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Preparation for eating or making the foreign cell palatable or tasty for phagocytosis. Opsonine that coat foreign cells include IgG and some proteins of the complement system.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Phagocytosis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The process of ingestion of bacteria or any abnormal cell by a phagocytic cell (e.g. neutrophils, Monocytes or macrophages).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Preceded by recognition and followed by intracellular killing.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>125
The aims of medical physiology: 4th edition</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Types: Helper T cells (CD4 cells) &amp; cytotoxic T cells (CD8 cells).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When activated, the T lymphocyte from memory T cells; for future recognition of the invader (= the secondary immune response).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>They are responsible for cell mediated immunity (see below).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>B-Lymphocytes:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Constitute about 20% of total lymphocytes.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Maturate in the bone marrow.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When activated, they differentiate into plasma cells (for production of antibodies) and memory B cells (for future recognition of the invader, = the secondary immune response).</p>
</li>
<li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="how-can-white-blood-cells-perform-their-functions">How can white blood cells perform their functions?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#how-can-white-blood-cells-perform-their-functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Chemotaxis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Attraction of neutrophils to the site of infection by certain substances including components of the complement system (C5a), leukotrienes and products of damaged tissues, bacteria or leucocytes.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Diapedesis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Passage of white blood cells from the blood to the tissues through the wall of capillaries (e.g. neutrophils, basophils, eosinophils and monocytes).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Opsonization</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Preparation for eating or making the foreign cell palatable or tasty for phagocytosis. Opsonine that coat foreign cells include IgG and some proteins of the complement system.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Phagocytosis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The process of ingestion of bacteria or any abnormal cell by a phagocytic cell (e.g. neutrophils, Monocytes or macrophages).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Preceded by recognition and followed by intracellular killing.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>154
The laws of medical physiology 8th edition
155
The laws of medical physiology 8th edition
156
The laws of medical physiology 8th edition</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Intracellular killing</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fusion of cytoplasmic granules in the phagocytic cell with the phagocytic vacuole, then release of the antimicrobial agents found within these granules into the vacuole.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The antimicrobial agents found within the granules of neutrophils include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Deferrions</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Proteases (elastase, metalloproteinases)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Other antimicrobial agents released by neutrophils:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Toxic oxygen metabolites (O₂⁻, H₂O₂)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Oxidants (HOCl, HCBr, ...)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The toxic oxygen metabolites (O₂⁻, H₂O₂) are oxidants formed following activation of a cell membrane bound enzyme (NADPH oxidase).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is associated with a process known as the respiratory burst, characterized by marked increase in oxygen uptake and metabolism in the neutrophil.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Steps of formation:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>NADPH + H⁺ + 2O₂ → NADP⁺ + 2H⁺ + 2O₂⁻</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>O₂⁻ + O₂⁻ + H⁺ + H⁺ + H₂O₂ + O₂⁻</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>(The second step is catalyzed by the enzyme superoxide dismutase (SOD))</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Formation of the other oxidants (HOCl, HCBr) is catalyzed by the enzyme myeloperoxidase.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Notice that certain types of bacteria can resist intracellular killing and remain viable within the WBCs.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Intracellular killing</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fusion of cytoplasmic granules in the phagocytic cell with the phagocytic vacuole, then release of the antimicrobial agents found within these granules into the vacuole.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The antimicrobial agents found within the granules of neutrophils include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Deferrions</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Proteases (elastase, metalloproteinases)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Other antimicrobial agents released by neutrophils:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Toxic oxygen metabolites (O₂⁻, H₂O₂)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Oxidants (HOCl, HCBr, ...)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The toxic oxygen metabolites (O₂⁻, H₂O₂) are oxidants formed following activation of a cell membrane bound enzyme (NADPH oxidase).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is associated with a process known as the respiratory burst, characterized by marked increase in oxygen uptake and metabolism in the neutrophil.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Steps of formation:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>NADPH + H⁺ + 2O₂ → NADP⁺ + 2H⁺ + 2O₂⁻</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>O₂⁻ + O₂⁻ + H⁺ + H⁺ + H₂O₂ + O₂⁻</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>(The second step is catalyzed by the enzyme superoxide dismutase (SOD))</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Formation of the other oxidants (HOCl, HCBr) is catalyzed by the enzyme myeloperoxidase.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Notice that certain types of bacteria can resist intracellular killing and remain viable within the WBCs.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Intracellular killing</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fusion of cytoplasmic granules in the phagocytic cell with the phagocytic vacuole, then release of the antimicrobial agents found within these granules into the vacuole.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The antimicrobial agents found within the granules of neutrophils include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Deferrions</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Proteases (elastase, metalloproteinases)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Other antimicrobial agents released by neutrophils:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Toxic oxygen metabolites (O₂⁻, H₂O₂)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Oxidants (HOCl, HCBr, ...)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The toxic oxygen metabolites (O₂⁻, H₂O₂) are oxidants formed following activation of a cell membrane bound enzyme (NADPH oxidase).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is associated with a process known as the respiratory burst, characterized by marked increase in oxygen uptake and metabolism in the neutrophil.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Steps of formation:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>NADPH + H⁺ + 2O₂ → NADP⁺ + 2H⁺ + 2O₂⁻</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>O₂⁻ + O₂⁻ + H⁺ + H⁺ + H₂O₂ + O₂⁻</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>(The second step is catalyzed by the enzyme superoxide dismutase (SOD))</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Formation of the other oxidants (HOCl, HCBr) is catalyzed by the enzyme myeloperoxidase.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Notice that certain types of bacteria can resist intracellular killing and remain viable within the WBCs.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>132
The area of medical physiology/ 6th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bibliatry">BIBLIATRY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bibliatry" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The physiological process by which the body destroys or neutralizes foreign particles. Includes two types:</p>
<ul>
<li>Non specific immunity (female immunity)
(Does not depend on recognition of the invader (i.e. non specific))</li>
<li>Specific immunity
(Depends on recognition of the invader)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="non-specific-immunity-female-immunity">Non specific immunity (female immunity)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#non-specific-immunity-female-immunity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The first line of defense against invaders. It includes:</p>
<ul>
<li>Natural barriers</li>
<li>Inflammation</li>
<li>Natural killer cells</li>
<li>Complement system</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="natural-barriers">Natural barriers:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#natural-barriers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Prevent invasion of tissues by microorganism. They include:</li>
<li>Anatomical barriers (e.g. skin and mucus membranes)</li>
<li>Biochemical barriers (e.g. saliva, tears and gastric acid)</li>
<li>Mechanical barriers (e.g. cough and vomiting)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inflammation">Inflammation:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inflammation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The response of the body to infection. It acts to localize infection. It involves:</li>
<li>Attraction of WBCs to the site of infection</li>
<li>Release of active substances by WBCs</li>
<li>The active substances destroy the microorganisms. However, they also damage tissues and result in changes in blood vessels (e.g. vasodilation and increased permeability)</li>
<li>Signs of inflammation: redness, swelling, pain &amp; loss of function.</li>
</ul>
<p>133
The area of medical physiology/ 6th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bibliatry">BIBLIATRY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bibliatry" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

(Does not depend on recognition of the invader (i.e. non specific))</li>
<li>Specific immunity
(Depends on recognition of the invader)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="non-specific-immunity-female-immunity">Non specific immunity (female immunity)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#non-specific-immunity-female-immunity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="natural-barriers">Natural barriers:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#natural-barriers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Prevent invasion of tissues by microorganism. They include:</li>
<li>Anatomical barriers (e.g. skin and mucus membranes)</li>
<li>Biochemical barriers (e.g. saliva, tears and gastric acid)</li>
<li>Mechanical barriers (e.g. cough and vomiting)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inflammation">Inflammation:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inflammation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The response of the body to infection. It acts to localize infection. It involves:</li>
<li>Attraction of WBCs to the site of infection</li>
<li>Release of active substances by WBCs</li>
<li>The active substances destroy the microorganisms. However, they also damage tissues and result in changes in blood vessels (e.g. vasodilation and increased permeability)</li>
<li>Signs of inflammation: redness, swelling, pain &amp; loss of function.</li>
</ul>
<p>134
The area of medical physiology/ 6th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bibliatry">BIBLIATRY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bibliatry" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The physiological process by which the body destroys or neutralizes foreign particles. Includes two types:</p>
<ul>
<li>Non specific immunity (female immunity)
(Does not depend on recognition of the invader (i.e. non specific))</li>
<li>Specific immunity
(Depends on recognition of the invader)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="non-specific-immunity-female-immunity">Non specific immunity (female immunity)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#non-specific-immunity-female-immunity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The first line of defense against invaders. It includes:</p>
<ul>
<li>Natural barriers</li>
<li>Inflammation</li>
<li>Natural killer cells</li>
<li>Complement system</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="natural-barriers">Natural barriers:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#natural-barriers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Prevent invasion of tissues by microorganism. They include:</li>
<li>Anatomical barriers (e.g. skin and mucus membranes)</li>
<li>Biochemical barriers (e.g. saliva, tears and gastric acid)</li>
<li>Mechanical barriers (e.g. cough and vomiting)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inflammation">Inflammation:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inflammation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The response of the body to infection. It acts to localize infection. It involves:</li>
<li>Attraction of WBCs to the site of infection</li>
<li>Release of active substances by WBCs</li>
<li>The active substances destroy the microorganisms. However, they also damage tissues and result in changes in blood vessels (e.g. vasodilation and increased permeability)</li>
<li>Signs of inflammation: redness, swelling, pain &amp; loss of function</li>
</ul>
<p>154
The costs of medical physiology 155</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="711ce805">Natural killer cells (≈ NK cells)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#711ce805" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A small fraction of circulating lymphocytes is neither T nor B lymphocytes, most of these are natural killer cells (NK cells).</li>
<li>They resemble cytotoxic lymphocytes in killing their targets by releasing granules containing cytolytic enzymes (perforin). However, they differ from them in that:</li>
<li>They kill naturally (generally they do not need activation, however, they may become activated by interferons α and β).</li>
<li>They attack cells which lack class I MHC antigens on their membranes, these include some virus infected cells (because some viruses inhibit expression of MHC-I antigens) &amp; tumor cells (because these have low α no class I MHC expression).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-complement-system">The complement system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-complement-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Group of proteins (50 or more), activated to produce a cell killing effect.</li>
<li>They include: (C1 (has 3 subunits: q, r and s), C2, C3a, C3b, C4, C5, C6, C7, C8, C9, factor B, factor D, factor H, factor I ...)</li>
<li>Most of these proteins are inactive beta globulins (&gt; 5% of all globulins).</li>
<li>They are activated by:</li>
<li><strong>Classic pathway</strong></li>
<li>Triggered by antigen-antibody complexes.</li>
<li>The first factor to be activated is C1 (see fig 5.10).</li>
<li><strong>Alternative pathway</strong></li>
<li>Triggered by the surface of pathogens like bacteria or viruses.</li>
<li>The first factor to be activated is C3 (see fig 5.10).</li>
<li><strong>Lectin pathway</strong></li>
<li>Triggered by contact of lectin with certain carbohydrate groups (mannose) in bacterial wall (mannose-binding lectin (MBL)).</li>
<li>MBL acts like C1q it activates C2 &amp; C4, then other steps follow.</li>
</ul>
<p>156
The costs of medical physiology 157</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="711ce805">Natural killer cells (≈ NK cells)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#711ce805" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A small fraction of circulating lymphocytes is neither T nor B lymphocytes, most of these are natural killer cells (NK cells).</li>
<li>They resemble cytotoxic lymphocytes in killing their targets by releasing granules containing cytolytic enzymes (perforin). However, they differ from them in that:</li>
<li>They kill naturally (generally they do not need activation, however, they may become activated by interferons α and β.</li>
<li>They attack cells which lack class I MHC antigens on their membranes, these include some virus infected cells (because some viruses inhibit expression of MHC-I antigens) &amp; tumor cells (because these have low α no class I MHC expression).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-complement-system">The complement system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-complement-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Group of proteins (50 or more), activated to produce a cell killing effect.</li>
<li>They include: (C1 (has 3 subunits: q, r and s), C2, C3a, C3b, C4, C5, C6, C7, C8, C9, factor B, factor D, factor H, factor I ...)</li>
<li>Most of these proteins are inactive beta globulins (&gt; 5% of all globulins).</li>
<li>They are activated by:</li>
<li><strong>Classic pathway</strong></li>
<li>Triggered by antigen-antibody complexes.</li>
<li>The first factor to be activated is C1 (see fig 5.10).</li>
<li><strong>Alternative pathway</strong></li>
<li>Triggered by the surface of pathogens like bacteria or viruses.</li>
<li>The first factor to be activated is C3 (see fig 5.10).</li>
<li><strong>Lectin pathway</strong></li>
<li>Triggered by contact of lectin with certain carbohydrate groups (mannose) in bacterial wall (mannose-binding lectin (MBL)).</li>
<li>MBL acts like C1q it activates C2 &amp; C4, then other steps follow.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="711ce805">Natural killer cells (≈ NK cells)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#711ce805" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A small fraction of circulating lymphocytes is neither T nor B lymphocytes, most of these are natural killer cells (NK cells).</li>
<li>They resemble cytotoxic lymphocytes in killing their targets by releasing granules containing cytolytic enzymes (perforin). However, they differ from them in that:</li>
<li>They kill naturally (generally they do not need activation, however, they may become activated by interferons α and β.</li>
<li>They attack cells which lack class I MHC antigens on their membranes, these include some virus infected cells (because some viruses inhibit expression of MHC-I antigens) &amp; tumor cells (because these have low α no class I MHC expression).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-complement-system">The complement system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-complement-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Group of proteins (50 or more), activated to produce a cell killing effect.</li>
<li>They include: (C1 (has 3 subunits: q, r and s), C2, C3a, C3b, C4, C5, C6, C7, C8, C9, factor B, factor D, factor H, factor I ...).</li>
<li>Most of these proteins are inactive beta globulins (&gt; 5% of all globulins).</li>
<li>They are activated by:</li>
<li><strong>Classic pathway</strong></li>
<li>Triggered by antigen-antibody complexes.</li>
<li>The first factor to be activated is C1 (see fig 5.10).</li>
<li><strong>Alternative pathway</strong></li>
<li>Triggered by the surface of pathogens like bacteria or viruses.</li>
<li>The first factor to be activated is C3 (see fig 5.10).</li>
<li><strong>Lectin pathway</strong></li>
<li>Triggered by contact of lectin with certain carbohydrate groups (mannose) in bacterial wall (mannose-binding lectin (MBL)).</li>
<li>MBL acts like C1q it activates C2 &amp; C4, then other steps follow.</li>
</ul>
<p>157</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-df96eb8d.jpeg" alt="img-191.jpeg">
Fig 4.10: Activation of the complement cation</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-73f7a6f4.jpeg" alt="img-192.jpeg">
Fig 4.10: Activation of the complement cation</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-1f2650ea.jpeg" alt="img-193.jpeg">
Fig 4.10: Activation of the complement system</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="mechanism-of-action">Mechanism of action:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanism-of-action" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The cell killing effect of the complement proteins is achieved by:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Optimization (e.g. by C1q and C3b)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Chemotaxis (e.g. by C5a)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cell lysis (by the perforating complex C5b6789)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Degranulation of mast cells to release histamine (e.g. by C5a)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Complement proteins are highly regulated with control proteins that inhibit their damaging effects on normal cells</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Deficiency of some of the complement proteins may predispose to repeated infections (e.g. meningitis)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>127</p>
<p>The role of residual physiologic  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>V</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">V^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  effects</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="mechanism-of-action">Mechanism of action:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanism-of-action" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The cell killing effect of the complement proteins is achieved by:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Optimization (e.g. by C1q and C3b)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Chemotaxis (e.g. by C5a)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cell lysis (by the perforating complex C5b6789)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Degranulation of mast cells to release histamine (e.g. by C5a)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Complement proteins are highly regulated with control proteins that inhibit their damaging effects on normal cells</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Deficiency of some of the complement proteins may predispose to repeated infections (e.g. meningitis)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>127</p>
<p>The role of residual physiologic  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>V</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">V^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  effects</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="specific-immunity">Specific Immunity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#specific-immunity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Depends on the action of lymphocytes which, in addition to their immediate defensive role, form memory cells for future recognition of the invaders.</li>
<li>This explains the fact that a secondary immune response (induced by subsequent exposure to an antigen) is always more rapid and stronger than a primary immune response (induced by first exposure to the antigen).</li>
<li>Antigens are presented to lymphocytes by antigen presenting cells which, after phagocytosis, present some of the invader antigens on their surface, to be recognized by the lymphocytes.</li>
</ul>
<p>The antigen presenting cells are:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Dendritic cells (found in lymph nodes spleen and skin)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Macrophages (in different tissues)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Native B lymphocytes (can bind antigen directly through IgM antibodies expressed on their surface. However, they need T helper cells for full activation (see below))</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>After recognition of the antigen, the lymphocytes proliferate and mediate key types of specific immunity:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cell mediated immunity (mediated through activation and proliferation of T lymphocytes).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Humoral immunity (mediated through activation and proliferation of B lymphocytes).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cell-mediated-immunity">Cell mediated immunity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cell-mediated-immunity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>T helper lymphocytes recognize antigens presented by the antigen presenting cells when these antigens are linked with the major histocompatibility protein type II (MHC-II).</li>
<li>Certain markers on the surface of T helper cells (known as cluster of differentiation 4 or CD4) facilitate this recognition.</li>
<li>The activated T helper cells release cytokines for activation of T cytotoxic lymphocytes, natural killer cells and macrophages. These attack primarily viral.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="specific-immunity">Specific immunity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#specific-immunity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Depends on the action of lymphocytes which, in addition to their immediate defensive role, form memory cells for future recognition of the invaders.</li>
<li>This explains the fact that a secondary immune response (induced by subsequent exposure to an antigen) is always more rapid and stronger than a primary immune response (induced by first exposure to the antigen).</li>
<li>Antigens are presented to lymphocytes by antigen presenting cells which, after phagocytosis, present some of the invader antigens on their surface, to be recognized by the lymphocytes.</li>
</ul>
<p>The antigen presenting cells are:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Dendritic cells (found in lymph nodes spleen and skin)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Macrophages (in different tissues)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Native B lymphocytes (can bind antigen directly through IgM antibodies expressed on their surface. However, they need T helper cells for full activation (see below))</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>After recognition of the antigen, the lymphocytes proliferate and mediate key types of specific immunity:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cell mediated immunity (mediated through activation and proliferation of T lymphocytes).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Humoral immunity (mediated through activation and proliferation of B lymphocytes).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cell-mediated-immunity">Cell mediated immunity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cell-mediated-immunity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>T helper lymphocytes recognize antigens presented by the antigen presenting cells when these antigens are linked with the major histocompatibility protein type II (MHC-II).</li>
<li>Certain markers on the surface of T helper cells (known as cluster of differentiation 4 or CD4) facilitate this recognition.</li>
<li>The activated T helper cells release cytokines for activation of T cytotoxic lymphocytes, natural killer cells and macrophages. These attack primarily viral.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="specific-immunity">Specific immunity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#specific-immunity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Depends on the action of lymphocytes which, in addition to their immediate defensive role, form memory cells for future recognition of the invaders.</li>
<li>This explains the fact that a secondary immune response (induced by subsequent exposure to an antigen) is always more rapid and stronger than a primary immune response (induced by first exposure to the antigen).</li>
<li>Antigens are presented to lymphocytes by antigen presenting cells which, after phagocytosis, present some of the invader antigens on their surface, to be recognized by the lymphocytes.</li>
</ul>
<p>The antigen presenting cells are:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Dendritic cells (found in lymph nodes spleen and skin)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Macrophages (in different tissues)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Native B lymphocytes (can bind antigen directly through IgM antibodies expressed on their surface. However, they need T helper cells for full activation (see below))</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>After recognition of the antigen, the lymphocytes proliferate and mediate key types of specific immunity:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cell mediated immunity (mediated through activation and proliferation of T lymphocytes).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Humoral immunity (mediated through activation and proliferation of B lymphocytes).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cell-mediated-immunity">Cell mediated immunity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cell-mediated-immunity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>T helper lymphocytes recognize antigens presented by the antigen presenting cells when these antigens are linked with the major histocompatibility protein type II (MHC-II).</li>
<li>Certain markers on the surface of T helper cells (known as cluster of differentiation 4 or CD4) facilitate this recognition.</li>
<li>The activated T helper cells release cytokines for activation of T cytotoxic lymphocytes, natural killer cells and macrophages. These attack primarily viral.</li>
</ul>
<p>planted cells, intracellular bacteria, fungi, protozoa and cancer cells. In addition they play an important role in rejection of transplanted organs. The cytokines also activate the B lymphocytes.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-b309cf08.jpeg" alt="img-194.jpeg">
Fig 5.11. Proliferation of T helper cells</p>
<ul>
<li>The Cytotoxic T cells can recognize antigens presented by the virus infected cells when these antigens are linked with the major histocompatibility proteins type I (MHC-I).</li>
<li>Certain markers on the surface of cytotoxic T cells (known as cluster of differentiation 6 (CD6)) facilitate this recognition. They kill their targets by releasing proteins known as "perforins" into them. These make pores into the virus infected cells and initiate apoptosis.</li>
<li>It is important to notice that T helper lymphocytes are two types:</li>
<li>T helper 1 (T+1) the principal cells activated in cellular immunity</li>
<li>T helper 2 (T+2) interacts with B lymphocytes in relation to humeral immunity</li>
</ul>
<p>129</p>
<p>Planted cells, intracellular bacteria, fungi, protozoa and cancer cells. In addition they play an important role in rejection of transplanted organs. The cytokines also activate the B lymphocytes.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-b882de44.jpeg" alt="img-195.jpeg">
Fig 5.11. Proliferation of T helper cells</p>

<p>The role of cellular physiology in response</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Examples of the cytokines released By T_{H1}:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>IL-2 (activates lymphocyte proliferation (autocrine effect), natural killer (NK) cells and macrophages)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Interferon (IFN) activates macrophages and inhibits T_{H2}</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Examples of the cytokines released by T_{M}:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>IL-4 (activates B lymphocytes to produce IgE antibodies)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>IL-5 (stimulates differentiation of eosinophils)</p>
</li>

<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-b2e1bb6e.jpeg" alt="img-197.jpeg">
Fig 8.12: Proliferation of cytotoxic T cells</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Human immune-deficiency virus (HIV) attacks CD4 cells (T helper cells) resulting in failure of cytokine production and therefore failure of activation and proliferation lymphocytes and macrophages.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This causes acquired immune-deficiency syndrome (AIDS) and renders the body susceptible for infection (with even the nonpathogenic bacteria) and cancer.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Examples of the cytokines released By T_{M}:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>IL-2 (activates lymphocyte proliferation (autocrine effect), natural killer (NK) cells and macrophages)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Interferon (IFN) activates macrophages and inhibits T_{H2}</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Examples of the cytokines released by T_{M}:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>IL-4 (activates B lymphocytes to produce IgE antibodies)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>IL-5 (stimulates differentiation of eosinophils)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-24f82287.jpeg" alt="img-198.jpeg">
Fig 8.13: Proliferation of cytotoxic T cells</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="humoral-immunity">Humoral Immunity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#humoral-immunity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Activated B-lymphocytes transform into plasma cells and produce large number of antibodies</li>
<li>The antibodies attack the insaders in different ways (see below).</li>
<li>Unlike cell mediated immunity, humoral immunity is directed mainly against extracellular organisms like bacteria.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="notes">Notes:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#notes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Proteins of the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) are encoded by genes located on the short arm of chromosome 6. These proteins are found on the outer surface of body cells and they are unique for each person. In humans they are known as human leukocyte antigens (HLA).</li>
<li>The MHC genes are classified into 3 classes:</li>
<li>Class I
○ Encodes for MHC-I proteins, which are coupled with antigens formed within the cell (e.g. formed by intracellular virus). These proteins are found on all nucleated cells. They are recognized by CD8 cells.</li>
<li>Class II
○ Encodes for MHC-II proteins, which are coupled with antigens of extracellular organisms like bacteria. The antigens are selected after phagocytosis of bacteria and then presented in association with MHC-II proteins. Therefore these proteins are found on antigen presenting cells. They are recognized by CD4 cells.</li>
<li>Class III
○ Encodes for some immunological proteins (e.g. some cytokines and complement proteins).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="humoral-immunity">Humoral Immunity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#humoral-immunity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Activated B-lymphocytes transform into plasma cells and produce large number of antibodies</li>
<li>The antibodies attack the insaders in different ways (see below).</li>
<li>Unlike cell mediated immunity, humoral immunity is directed mainly against extracellular organisms like bacteria.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="notes">Notes:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#notes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Proteins of the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) are encoded by genes located on the short arm of chromosome 6. These proteins are found on the outer surface of body cells and they are unique for each person. In humans they are known as human leukocyte antigens (HLA).</li>
<li>The MHC genes are classified into 3 classes:</li>
<li>Class I
○ Encodes for MHC-I proteins, which are coupled with antigens formed within the cell (e.g. formed by intracellular virus). These proteins are found on all nucleated cells. They are recognized by CD8 cells.</li>
<li>Class II
○ Encodes for MHC-II proteins, which are coupled with antigens of extracellular organisms like bacteria. The antigens are selected after phagocytosis of bacteria and then presented in association with MHC-II proteins. Therefore these proteins are found on antigen presenting cells. They are recognized by CD4 cells.</li>
<li>Class III
○ Encodes for some immunological proteins (e.g. some cytokines and complement proteins).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="humoral-immunity">Humoral Immunity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#humoral-immunity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Activated B-lymphocytes transform into plasma cells and produce large number of antibodies</li>
<li>The antibodies attack the insaders in different ways (see below).</li>
<li>Unlike cell mediated immunity, humoral immunity is directed mainly against extracellular organisms like bacteria.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="notes">Notes:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#notes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Proteins of the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) are encoded by genes located on the short arm of chromosome 6. These proteins are found on the outer surface of body cells and they are unique for each person. In humans they are known as human leukocyte antigens (HLA).</li>
<li>The MHC genes are classified into 3 classes:</li>
<li>Class I
○ Encodes for MHC-I proteins, which are coupled with antigens formed within the cell (e.g. formed by intracellular virus). These proteins are found on all nucleated cells. They are recognized by CD8 cells.</li>
<li>Class II
○ Encodes for MHC-II proteins, which are coupled with antigens of extracellular organisms like bacteria. The antigens are selected after phagocytosis of bacteria and then presented in association with MHC-II proteins. Therefore these proteins are found on antigen presenting cells. They are recognized by CD4 cells.</li>
<li>Class III
○ Encodes for some immunological proteins (e.g. some cytokines and complement proteins).</li>
</ul>
<p>142
The only of medical personnel</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-cytokines">The cytokines<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-cytokines" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Cytokines are proteins produced by a wide variety of immune and non-immune cell types.</li>
<li>They are involved in regulation of growth, development, and activation of immunity and in the mediation of inflammation.</li>
<li>A single cytokine can be released by different cells and different cytokines may have similar functions and can act on different cells.</li>
<li>Actions of cytokines may be:</li>
<li>Autocrine: the cytokine acts on the same cell that secretes it.</li>
<li>Paracrine: the cytokine acts on a nearby cell.</li>
<li>Endocrine: the cytokine circulates in blood and acts on distant cells.</li>
<li>Cytokines have names that describe their targets or their functions. For example, cytokines acting on leucocytes are interleukins (IL-1, 2, 3, 4 ...), whereas cytokines stimulating hematopoiesis are colony stimulating factors (granulocyte-monocyte colony-stimulating factor). - Chemokines are cytokines that regulate cell movement (e.g. Chemotaxis which is regulated by the chemokines IL-6 &amp; RANTES).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="table-5-2-examples-of-some-cytokines-and-their-functions">Table 5.2: Examples of some cytokines and their functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#table-5-2-examples-of-some-cytokines-and-their-functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Cytokine</th><th>Cell source</th><th>Function</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>IL-1</td><td>Macrophages</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Epithelial cells</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Fibroblasts</td><td>Hematopoiesis</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Fever &amp; hepatic acute phase proteins</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Activation of WBCs</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>IL-2</td><td>T cells</td><td>Activation &amp; proliferation of T cells</td></tr><tr><td>Activation of B cells, NK cells and macrophages</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>IL-3</td><td>T cells</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>NK cells</td><td>Hematopoiesis</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>IL-4</td><td>T cells</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Mast cells</td><td>Stimulation of B cells to secrete anti-bodies</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Stimulation of T_{H} proliferation</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>IL-5</td><td>T cells, mast cells &amp; eosinophils</td><td>Activation of eosinophils</td></tr><tr><td>IL-6</td><td>B cells</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Epithelial cells</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Fibroblasts</td><td>Fever &amp; induction of acute phase proteins from the liver</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>T &amp; B cell differentiation</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>143
The only of medical personnel</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-cytokines">The cytokines<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-cytokines" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Cytokines are proteins produced by a wide variety of immune and non-immune cell types.</li>
<li>They are involved in regulation of growth, development, and activation of immunity and in the mediation of inflammation.</li>
<li>A single cytokine can be released by different cells and different cytokines may have similar functions and can act on different cells.</li>
<li>Actions of cytokines may be:</li>
<li>Autocrine: the cytokine acts on the same cell that secretes it.</li>
<li>Paracrine: the cytokine acts on a nearby cell.</li>
<li>Endocrine: the cytokine circulates in blood and acts on distant cells.</li>
<li>Cytokines have names that describe their targets or their functions. For example, cytokines acting on leucocytes are interleukins (IL-1, 2, 3, 4 ...), whereas cytokines stimulating hematopoiesis are colony stimulating factors (granulocyte-monocyte colony-stimulating factor). - Chemokines are cytokines that regulate cell movement (e.g. Chemotaxis which is regulated by the chemokines IL-6 &amp; RANTES).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="table-5-3-examples-of-some-cytokines-and-their-functions">Table 5.3: Examples of some cytokines and their functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#table-5-3-examples-of-some-cytokines-and-their-functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Cytokine</th><th>Cell source</th><th>Function</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>IL-1</td><td>Macrophages</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Epithelial cells</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Fibroblasts</td><td>Hematopoiesis</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Fever &amp; hepatic acute phase proteins</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Activation of WBCs</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>IL-2</td><td>T cells</td><td>Activation &amp; proliferation of T cells</td></tr><tr><td>Activation of B cells, NK cells and macrophages</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>IL-3</td><td>T cells</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>NK cells</td><td>Hematopoiesis</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>IL-4</td><td>T cells</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Mast cells</td><td>Stimulation of B cells to secrete anti-bodies</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Stimulation of T_{H} proliferation</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>IL-5</td><td>T cells, mast cells &amp; eosinophils</td><td>Activation of eosinophils</td></tr><tr><td>IL-6</td><td>B cells</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Epithelial cells</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Fibroblasts</td><td>Fever &amp; induction of acute phase proteins from the liver</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>T &amp; B cell differentiation</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-antibodies">The antibodies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-antibodies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Gamma globulins, called immuno-globulins or (Ig), produced by activated (L) lymphocytes (known as plasma cells).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="structure-of-the-basic-unit-of-antibodies">Structure of the basic unit of antibodies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure-of-the-basic-unit-of-antibodies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>2 heavy chains &amp; 2 light chains connected by disulfide bridges.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Each chain consists of both variable (V) and constant (C) regions.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The C regions form the "Fc portion" for cell binding whereas the V regions form the "Fab portion" for antigen binding.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The variable regions have variable sequences of amino-acids; this makes the Fab portion in each immunoglobulin molecule differs from Fab portions in other molecules. That's why antibodies secreted against specific antigen do not attack other antigens.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Remember that: Each antibody attacks only one specific antigen by its antigen binding site (Fab portion).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-4f9aba0a.jpeg" alt="img-200.jpeg">
Fig 2.13: The basic structure of antibodies</p>
<p>104</p>
<p>The use of natural physiology 17</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-antibodies">The antibodies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-antibodies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Gamma globulins, called immuno-globulins or (Ig), produced by activated (L) lymphocytes (known as plasma cells).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="structure-of-the-basic-unit-of-antibodies">Structure of the basic unit of antibodies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure-of-the-basic-unit-of-antibodies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>2 heavy chains &amp; 2 light chains connected by disulfide bridges.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Each chain consists of both variable (V) and constant (C) regions.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The C regions form the "Fc portion" for cell binding whereas the V regions form the "Fab portion" for antigen binding.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The variable regions have variable sequences of amino-acids; this makes the Fab portion in each immunoglobulin molecule differs from Fab portions in other molecules. That's why antibodies secreted against specific antigen do not attack other antigens.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Remember that: Each antibody attacks only one specific antigen by its antigen binding site (Fab portion).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-d6844003.jpeg" alt="img-201.jpeg">
Fig 2.13: The basic structure of antibodies</p>
<p>104</p>
<p>The use of natural physiology 17</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-antibodies">The antibodies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-antibodies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Gamma globulins, called immuno-globulins or (Ig), produced by activated (L) lymphocytes (known as plasma cells).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="structure-of-the-basic-unit-of-antibodies">Structure of the basic unit of antibodies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure-of-the-basic-unit-of-antibodies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>2 heavy chains &amp; 2 light chains connected by disulfide bridges.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Each chain consists of both variable (V) and constant (C) regions.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The C regions form the "Fc portion" for cell binding whereas the V regions form the "Fab portion" for antigen binding.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The variable regions have variable sequences of amino-acids; this makes the Fab portion in each immunoglobulin molecule differs from Fab portions in other molecules. That's why antibodies secreted against specific antigen do not attack other antigens.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Remember that: Each antibody attacks only one specific antigen by its antigen binding site (Fab portion).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-56f7d5d8.jpeg" alt="img-202.jpeg">
Fig 2.13: The basic structure of antibodies</p>
<p>104</p>
<p>100
The view of medical physiology 17 (2004)</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The immunoglobulins (Ig) are classified according to the types of heavy chains (eg) 5 types: G, M, A, E and D; therefore they are described as IgG, IgM, IgA, IgE and IgD.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>IgG:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The most abundant (constitutes more than 75% of total immunoglobulins in plasma).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The smallest type (monomer: has two sites for binding antigens).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The only type that can cross the placenta from the mother to the fetus to protect him from micro-organisms (= passive immunity).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>IgG is the main antibody in the secondary immune response (i.e. the immune response following exposure to an antigen for the second time or more).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>IgM:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The largest type.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Peritomer (5 of the basic units connected together).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is the main antibody in the primary immune response (i.e. the immune response following exposure to an antigen for the first time).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The secondary immune response is more faster and stronger than the primary immune response due to presence of memory cells formed during the primary response. They immediately react with the antigen and result in secretion of adequate amounts of IgG antibodies against the antigen.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>IgA:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Monomer, dimer or trimer.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In addition to plasma, it is also found on the mucosal surfaces (e.g. mucosa of the GIT, genitor-urinary and respiratory systems), and in body secretions like saliva, milk and tears. For this reason it is called the secretory immunoglobulin.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Plays an important defensive role at these sites against colonization of mucosa by pathogens.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>101
The view of medical physiology 17 (2004)</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The immunoglobulins (Ig) are classified according to the types of heavy chains (eg) 5 types: G, M, A, E and D; therefore they are described as IgG, IgM, IgA, IgE and IgD.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>IgG:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The most abundant (constitutes more than 75% of total immunoglobulins in plasma).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The smallest type (monomer: has two sites for binding antigens).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The only type that can cross the placenta from the mother to the fetus to protect him from micro-organisms (= passive immunity).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>IgG is the main antibody in the secondary immune response (i.e. the immune response following exposure to an antigen for the second time or more).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>IgM:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The largest type.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Peritomer (5 of the basic units connected together).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is the main antibody in the primary immune response (i.e. the immune response following exposure to an antigen for the first time).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The secondary immune response is more faster and stronger than the primary immune response due to presence of memory cells formed during the primary response. They immediately react with the antigen and result in secretion of adequate amounts of IgG antibodies against the antigen.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>IgA:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Monomer, dimer or trimer.</p>
</li>
<li>
