</li>
<li>
<p>Plays an important defensive role at these sites against colonization of mucosa by pathogens.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>102
The view of medical physiology 17 (2004)</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The immunoglobulins (Ig) are classified according to the types of heavy chains (eg) 5 types: G, M, A, E and D; therefore they are described as IgG, IgM, IgA, IgE and IgD.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>IgG:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The most abundant (constitutes more than 75% of total immunoglobulins in plasma).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The smallest type (monomer: has two sites for binding antigens).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The only type that can cross the placenta from the mother to the fetus to protect him from micro-organisms (= passive immunity).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>IgG is the main antibody in the secondary immune response (i.e. the immune response following exposure to an antigen for the second time or more).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>IgM:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The largest type.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Peritomer (5 of the basic units connected together).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is the main antibody in the primary immune response (i.e. the immune response following exposure to an antigen for the first time).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The secondary immune response is more faster and stronger than the primary immune response due to presence of memory cells formed during the primary response. They immediately react with the antigen and result in secretion of adequate amounts of IgG antibodies against the antigen.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>IgA:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Monomer, dimer or trimer.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In addition to plasma, it is also found on the mucosal surfaces (e.g. mucosa of the GIT, genitor-urinary and respiratory systems), and in body secretions like saliva, milk and tears. For this reason it is called the secretory immunoglobulin.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Plays an important defensive role at these sites against colonization of mucosa by pathogens.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>&gt; <strong>left:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>After its formation during a primary immune response induced by certain allergens, it becomes attached to membranes of mast cells &amp; basophils through the Fc portion. Then during a subsequent exposure to the same allergen, it binds the allergen through the Fab portion. This induces release of histamine from these cells causing symptoms and signs of immediate hypersensitivity reaction and sometimes a severe anaphylactic shock due to profound vasodilation.</li>
<li>In addition to its role in allergic reactions, it also offers protection against parasites (e.g. worms).</li>
</ul>
<p>&gt; <strong>left:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Has unknown function; may be antigen antibody recognition (may act as antigen binding receptor on B lymphocytes).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanisms-of-action-of-the-immunoglobulins">Mechanisms of action of the Immunoglobulins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanisms-of-action-of-the-immunoglobulins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Opsonization of bacteria to facilitate phagocytosis (e.g. IgG)</li>
<li>Neutralization of some toxins</li>
<li>Blocking attachment of some viruses and bacteria to cells</li>
<li>Activation of the complement system (IgG and IgM antibodies)</li>
<li>Agglutination of group of cells or substances together to prevent their spread; to be captured by phagocytes in one action</li>
<li>Precipitation of some antigen-antibody complexes</li>
<li>Degranulation of mast cells and basophils (release of histamine)</li>
</ul>
<p>&gt; <strong>left:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>After its formation during a primary immune response induced by certain allergens, it becomes attached to membranes of mast cells &amp; basophils through the Fc portion. Then during a subsequent exposure to the same allergen, it binds the allergen through the Fab portion. This induces release of histamine from these cells causing symptoms and signs of immediate hypersensitivity reaction and sometimes a severe anaphylactic shock due to profound vasodilation.</li>
<li>In addition to its role in allergic reactions, it also offers protection against parasites (e.g. worms).</li>
</ul>
<p>&gt; <strong>left:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Has unknown function; may be antigen antibody recognition (may act as antigen binding receptor on B lymphocytes).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanisms-of-action-of-the-immunoglobulins">Mechanisms of action of the Immunoglobulins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanisms-of-action-of-the-immunoglobulins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Opsonization of bacteria to facilitate phagocytosis (e.g. IgG)</li>
<li>Neutralization of some toxins</li>
<li>Blocking attachment of some viruses and bacteria to cells</li>
<li>Activation of the complement system (IgG and IgM antibodies)</li>
<li>Agglutination of group of cells or substances together to prevent their spread; to be captured by phagocytes in one action</li>
<li>Precipitation of some antigen-antibody complexes</li>
<li>Degranulation of mast cells and basophils (release of histamine)</li>
</ul>
<p>&gt; <strong>left:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>After its formation during a primary immune response induced by certain allergens, it becomes attached to membranes of mast cells &amp; basophils through the Fc portion. Then during a subsequent exposure to the same allergen, it binds the allergen through the Fab portion. This induces release of histamine from these cells causing symptoms and signs of immediate hypersensitivity reaction and sometimes a severe anaphylactic shock due to profound vasodilation.</li>
<li>In addition to its role in allergic reactions, it also offers protection against parasites (e.g. worms).</li>
</ul>
<p>&gt; <strong>left:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Has unknown function; may be antigen antibody recognition (may act as antigen binding receptor on B lymphocytes).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanisms-of-action-of-the-immunoglobulins">Mechanisms of action of the Immunoglobulins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanisms-of-action-of-the-immunoglobulins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Opsonization of bacteria to facilitate phagocytosis (e.g. IgG)</li>
<li>Neutralization of some toxins</li>
<li>Blocking attachment of some viruses and bacteria to cells</li>
<li>Activation of the complement system (IgG and IgM antibodies)</li>
<li>Agglutination of group of cells or substances together to prevent their spread; to be captured by phagocytes in one action</li>
<li>Precipitation of some antigen-antibody complexes</li>
<li>Degranulation of mast cells and basophils (release of histamine)</li>
</ul>
<p>The role of bacterial physiology in cancer</p>
<p>498</p>
<p>The role of bacterial physiology in cancer</p>
<p>199</p>
<p>The role of bacterial physiology in cancer</p>
<p>12</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="12-2-1-10-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11">12.2.1.10.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-2-1-10-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-2-1-10-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11">1.2.1.10.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-2-1-10-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11-11" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>1.1.1.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11</p>
<p>1.1.1.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11</p>
<p>1.1.1.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11</p>
<p>1.1.1.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.11.</p>
<p>108
The uses of barometer, number of units</p>
<ol start="8">
<li>
<p>Regarding T-Lymphocytes, which of the following is correct:
a. helper cells recognize antigens when presented in association with blood clots 1
b. cytotoxic cells expose CD4 molecules on their membranes
c. major cytokines are released by the CD8 cells
d. TNFα is immediately released by T helper cells after their activation
e. T lymphocytes constitute the majority of lymphocytes in circulation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Acute bacterial infections are characterized by high counts of:
a. neutrophils
b. basophils
c. monocytes
d. lymphocytes
e. both a &amp; c</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A stained normal blood film shows:
a. 20% neutrophils
b. 4% basophils
c. 8% lymphocytes
d. 4% monocytes
e. 11% eosinophils</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>"T Lymphocytes" differ from "neutrophils" in all the following assays:
a. their cytoplasm is not granulated
b. they are not markedly increased in bacterial infections
c. they are attacked by the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV)
d. they cannot produce antibodies
e. their nuclei are not segmented</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Neutrophils:
a. have granules containing heparin
b. are produced in the thymus gland
c. can leave the blood and enter tissues
d. low up to three days
e. are increased in viral infections</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Immunoglobulin:
a. D has the largest size
b. E is found in milk
c. G is found mainly in primary immune response
d. M is the only type that activates complement proteins
e. A is found in the mucosa of the respiratory tract</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Immunoglobulin III (IgIII) is:
a. described as the secretory immunoglobulin
b. most abundant in the secondary immune response
c. the untreated type of immunoglobulin in plasma
d. the antibody type directed against antigens of the ABO system
e. found on surface of mast cells</p>
</li>

</li>

<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<p>BLOOD GROUPS AND BLOOD TRANSFUSION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-groups">BLOOD GROUPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-groups" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>= Antigens found on the surface of red blood cells</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="importance">Importance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#importance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Blood transfusion</li>
<li>Exclusion of paternity (paternity can be excluded by blood groups; however, its confirmation requires DNA fingerprinting).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types">Types<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>There is large number of these antigens.</li>
<li>The most important are: ABO system &amp; rhesus system.</li>
<li>Others (of less importance): MNS, Lutheran, Kell, Kidd, Duffy ...</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-abo-system">The ABO System<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-abo-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="antigens-agglutinogens-a-b">Antigens (Agglutinogens): A &amp; B<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antigens-agglutinogens-a-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Two antigens on surface of RBCs: A &amp; B.</li>
<li>Accordingly there are 4 blood groups:</li>
<li>Blood group A has antigen A</li>
<li>Blood group B has antigen B</li>
<li>Blood group AB has both antigens A &amp; B</li>
<li>Blood group O has neither antigen A nor B.</li>
<li>These antigens are also found in other tissues (salivary glands, kidney, liver, lung, pancreas, testes and amniotic fluid).</li>
<li>They are glycosphingolipids in RBCs but glycoproteins in the other tissues.</li>
<li>Basically, all groups have H antigens. In individuals with blood group O, all the H antigens persist without conversion into antigen A or B.</li>
<li>In individuals with blood group A or B, the H antigens are converted into antigens A or B respectively. This is achieved by adding N-acetylgalactosamine</li>
</ul>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<p>17
The text of medical publications 17th edition</p>
<p>to H antigens in blood group A, or adding galactose to H antigens in blood group B</p>
<ul>
<li>A and B glycoproteins are secreted by tissue cells into the circulation. Some individuals are "non-secretors". They are susceptible to a variety of infections because the glycoproteins may bind to polysaccharides on cells and block attachment of bacteria to these polysaccharides.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="antibodies-agalykinase-and-a-anti-b">Antibodies (Agalykinase) and A &amp; anti B<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antibodies-agalykinase-and-a-anti-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Anti A and anti B antibodies (of IgM type) are acquired naturally after birth by unknown mechanism.</li>
<li>Suggested mechanisms for their formation in neonates after birth:</li>
<li>Food contains antigens similar to A &amp; B antigens. Ingestion and absorption of these antigens induce the immune system to attack them by antibodies that circulate in the blood as anti A &amp; anti B antibodies.</li>
<li>Certain intestinal bacteria contain antigens similar to A &amp; B antigens; if these bacteria infect the neonate, the immune system will form antibodies against the bacterial antigens. These antibodies circulate as anti A and anti B antibodies.</li>
<li>The most interesting fact is that, the body forms antibodies against the ABO antigens not present on surface of red blood cells. For example a subject with group A has antigen A on RBC membranes, so his body forms antibodies against B antigen (anti B antibodies).</li>
<li>Accordingly, plasma contains the following types of antibodies:</li>
<li>Anti A antibodies in subjects with blood group B</li>
<li>Anti B antibodies in subjects with blood group A</li>
<li>Anti A &amp; anti B antibodies in subjects with blood group O</li>
<li>No antibodies in subjects with blood group AB</li>
</ul>
<p>18
The text of medical publications 18th edition</p>
<p>to H antigens in blood group A, or adding galactose to H antigens in blood group B</p>
<ul>
<li>A and B glycoproteins are secreted by tissue cells into the circulation. Some individuals are "non-secretors". They are susceptible to a variety of infections because the glycoproteins may bind to polysaccharides on cells and block attachment of bacteria to these polysaccharides.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="antibodies-agalykinase-and-a-anti-b">Antibodies (Agalykinase) and A &amp; anti B<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antibodies-agalykinase-and-a-anti-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Anti A and anti B antibodies (of IgM type) are acquired naturally after birth by unknown mechanism.</li>
<li>Suggested mechanisms for their formation in neonates after birth:</li>
<li>Food contains antigens similar to A &amp; B antigens. Ingestion and absorption of these antigens induce the immune system to attack them by antibodies that circulate in the blood as anti A &amp; anti B antibodies.</li>
<li>Certain intestinal bacteria contain antigens similar to A &amp; B antigens. If these bacteria infect the neonate, the immune system will form antibodies against the bacterial antigens. These antibodies circulate as anti A and anti B antibodies.</li>
<li>The most interesting fact is that: The body forms antibodies against the ABO antigens not present on surface of red blood cells. For example a subject with group A has antigen A on RBC membranes, so his body forms antibodies against B antigen (anti B antibodies).</li>
<li>Accordingly, plasma contains the following types of antibodies:</li>
<li>Anti A antibodies in subjects with blood group B</li>
<li>Anti B antibodies in subjects with blood group A</li>
<li>Anti A &amp; anti B antibodies in subjects with blood group O</li>
<li>No antibodies in subjects with blood group AB</li>
</ul>
<p>19
The text of medical publications 19th edition</p>
<p>to H antigens in blood group A, or adding galactose to H antigens in blood group B</p>
<ul>
<li>A and B glycoproteins are secreted by tissue cells into the circulation. Some individuals are "non-secretors". They are susceptible to a variety of infections because the glycoproteins may bind to polysaccharides on cells and block attachment of bacteria to these polysaccharides.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="antibodies-agalykinase-and-a-anti-b">Antibodies (Agalykinase) and A &amp; anti B<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antibodies-agalykinase-and-a-anti-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Anti A and anti B antibodies (of IgM type) are acquired naturally after birth by unknown mechanism.</li>
<li>Suggested mechanisms for their formation in neonates after birth:</li>
<li>Food contains antigens similar to A &amp; B antigens. Ingestion and absorption of these antigens induce the immune system to attack them by antibodies that circulate in the blood as anti A &amp; anti B antibodies.</li>
<li>Certain intestinal bacteria contain antigens similar to A &amp; B antigens. If these bacteria infect the neonate, the immune system will form antibodies against the bacterial antigens. These antibodies circulate as anti A and anti B antibodies.</li>
<li>The most interesting fact is that, the body forms antibodies against the ABO antigens not present on surface of red blood cells. For example a subject with group A has antigen A on RBC membranes, so his body forms antibodies against B antigen (anti B antibodies).</li>
<li>Accordingly, plasma contains the following types of antibodies:</li>
<li>Anti A antibodies in subjects with blood group B</li>
<li>Anti B antibodies in subjects with blood group A</li>
<li>Anti A &amp; anti B antibodies in subjects with blood group O</li>
<li>No antibodies in subjects with blood group AB</li>
</ul>
<p>172
The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Donors (In blood transfusion)</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Selection of a donor depends on absence of antigens on RBCs of the donor that may react with antibodies in plasma of the recipient (i.e. reactions between donor’s cells &amp; recipient’s plasma “or serum”).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>On the other hand, reaction between the donor’s plasma and recipient’s cells is neglected. This is because the volume of blood collected from the donor is about 500 ml and therefore the amount of antibodies in the plasma of this blood is very small. In addition to that, it will become diluted in the plasma of the recipient.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Accordingly, donors are selected for each blood group as follows:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Donors for blood group (A) are those with blood groups A &amp; O</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Donors for blood group (B) are those with blood groups B &amp; O</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Donors for group (AB) are those with blood groups A, B, AB, O</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Donors for blood group (O) are those with blood group O</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Notes to remember about the donors:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Subjects with blood group AB can receive blood from every blood group (they are described universal recipients)</li>
<li>Subjects with blood group O can give blood to every blood group (they are described as universal donors).</li>
</ul>
<p>&gt; <strong>Inheritance: Autosomal dominant</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Blood group antigens are inherited from each parent as autosomal dominant characters in chromosome 9p (i.e. A &amp; B antigens are inherited in the two copies of chr 9, from the father and the mother).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Therefore, the genotype for each blood group will be as follows:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Blood group A: the genotype is [AA] or [AO]</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Blood group B: the genotype is [BB] or [BO]</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Blood group AB: the genotype is [AB]</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Blood group O: the genotype is [OO]</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>17
The cost of medical physiology: IT values</p>
<p>If a father and his wife have blood groups A and B respectively, their children may have any type of blood groups (A, B, AB or O). But, if they are A and A, their children may have either A or O only.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="distribution">Distribution (%)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#distribution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The ABO blood groups are distributed as follows:</li>
<li>Blood group A is found in about 40% of population</li>
<li>Blood group B is found in about 8% of population</li>
<li>Blood group AB is found in about 2% of population</li>
<li>Blood group O is found in about 40% of population</li>
</ul>
<p>Types to remember about distribution of blood groups:</p>
<ul>
<li>The most dominant blood group is O (blood group of the universal donors) and the least dominant is AB (blood group of the universal recipients).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-rhesus-system">The Rhesus System<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-rhesus-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Area studied in the rhesus monkeys.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="antigens-d">Antigens: D<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antigens-d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Include antigens C, c, D, E, e.</li>
<li>Utilize the ABO antigens. These proteins are only found on RBCs (not found in other tissues).</li>
<li>The most important of these antigens is antigen D (has the highest antigenicity).</li>
<li>Accordingly, there are (2) types of rhesus groups:</li>
<li>Rh+ve (antigen D is present on RBC surface)</li>
<li>Rh-ve (antigen D is absent from RBC surface)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="antibodies-anti-d">Antibodies: anti D<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antibodies-anti-d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Utilize the anti A &amp; anti B antibodies, antibodies of the rhesus system (anti D antibodies) are of the IgG type (i.e. the smallest type that can cross the placenta from maternal blood to fetal blood).</li>
</ul>
<p>18
The cost of medical physiology: IT values</p>
<p>If a father and his wife have blood groups A and B respectively, their children may have any type of blood groups (A, B, AB or O). But, if they are A and A, their children may have either A or O only.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="distribution">Distribution (%)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#distribution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The ABO blood groups are distributed as follows:</li>
<li>Blood group A is found in about 40% of population</li>
<li>Blood group B is found in about 8% of population</li>
<li>Blood group AB is found in about 2% of population</li>
<li>Blood group O is found in about 40% of population</li>
</ul>
<p>Types to remember about distribution of blood groups:</p>
<ul>
<li>The most dominant blood group is O (blood group of the universal donors) and the least dominant is AB (blood group of the universal recipients).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-rhesus-system">The Rhesus System<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-rhesus-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Area studied in the rhesus monkeys.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="antigens-d">Antigens: D<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antigens-d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Include antigens C, c, D, F, e.</li>
<li>Utilize the ABO antigens. These proteins are only found on RBCs (not found in other tissues).</li>
<li>The most important of these antigens is antigen D (has the highest antigenicity).</li>
<li>Accordingly, there are (2) types of rhesus groups:</li>
<li>Rh+ve (antigen D is present on RBC surface)</li>
<li>Rh-ve (antigen D is absent from RBC surface)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="antibodies-anti-d">Antibodies: anti D<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antibodies-anti-d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Utilize the anti A &amp; anti B antibodies, antibodies of the rhesus system (anti D antibodies) are of the IgG type (i.e. the smallest type that can cross the placenta from maternal blood to fetal blood).</li>
</ul>
<p>19
The cost of medical physiology: IT values</p>
<p>If a father and his wife have blood groups A and B respectively, their children may have any type of blood groups (A, B, AB or O). But, if they are A and A, their children may have either A or O only.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="distribution">Distribution (%)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#distribution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<li>Blood group A is found in about 40% of population</li>
<li>Blood group B is found in about 8% of population</li>
<li>Blood group AB is found in about 2% of population</li>
<li>Blood group O is found in about 40% of population</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-rhesus-system">The Rhesus System<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-rhesus-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Area studied in the rhesus monkeys.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="antigens-d">Antigens: D<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antigens-d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Include antigens C, c, D, b, o.</li>
<li>Utilize the ABO antigens. These proteins are only found on RBCs (not found in other tissues).</li>
<li>The most important of these antigens is antigen D (has the highest antigenicity).</li>
<li>Accordingly, there are (2) types of rhesus groups:</li>
<li>Rh+ve (antigen D is present on RBC surface)</li>
<li>Rh-ve (antigen D is absent from RBC surface)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="antibodies-anti-d">Antibodies: anti D<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antibodies-anti-d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Utilize the anti A &amp; anti B antibodies, antibodies of the rhesus system (anti D antibodies) are of the IgG type (i.e. the smallest type that can cross the placenta from maternal blood to fetal blood).</li>
</ul>
<p>20
The cost of medical physiology: IT values</p>
<p>174
The text of medical practice</p>
<ul>
<li>Also unlike anti A and anti B antibodies, anti D antibodies are not readily acquired after birth.</li>
<li>They develop only in (Rh →s) subjects (never in Rh →s subjects).</li>
<li>Causes of their development in rhesus →s subjects.</li>
<li>Blood transfusion of Rh →s blood to Rh →s subjects.</li>
<li>Delivery of (Rh →s) baby by Rh →s mothers (During labor, the plasma separates from the uterus resulting in bleeding and entrance of some key blood in maternal circulation.</li>
</ul>
<p>&gt; Donors</p>
<ul>
<li>Rh →s subjects do not have anti D antibodies. They can receive blood from Rh →s &amp; Rh →s subjects.</li>
<li>Rh →s subjects do not have anti D antibodies unless they receive Rh →s blood. Therefore, they should receive Rh →s blood only.</li>
<li>During emergencies, Rh →s blood is not always available; that’s why rhesus →s subjects may receive Rh →s blood for the first time. This includes formation of anti D antibodies in his plasma within 3 days after the transfusion.</li>
<li>Therefore, any future transfusion of Rh →s blood is contra-indicated because it will be associated with severe reaction.</li>
</ul>
<p>&gt; Inheritance</p>
<ul>
<li>Autosomal dominant character in chromosome 1.</li>
<li>Chromosome 1 carries E or e plus D or without D (absence of D is indicated in d) plus C or c. For example: Cde or cDe or CdE...</li>
<li>Since antigen D determines the rhesus group, genotype for each group (chromosomes from father and mother) will be as follows:</li>
<li>Rh →s genotypes: DD or Dd</li>
<li>Rh →s genotype: dd</li>
</ul>
<p>175
The text of medical practice</p>
<ul>
<li>Also unlike anti A and anti B antibodies, anti D antibodies are not readily acquired after birth.</li>
<li>They develop only in (Rh →s) subjects (never in Rh →s subjects).</li>
<li>Causes of their development in rhesus →s subjects.</li>
<li>Blood transfusion of Rh →s blood to Rh →s subjects.</li>
<li>Delivery of (Rh →s) baby by Rh →s mothers (During labor, the plasma separates from the uterus resulting in bleeding and entrance of some key blood in maternal circulation.</li>
</ul>
<p>&gt; Donors</p>
<ul>
<li>Rh →s subjects do not have anti D antibodies. They can receive blood from Rh →s &amp; Rh →s subjects.</li>
<li>Rh →s subjects do not have anti D antibodies unless they receive Rh →s blood. Therefore, they should receive Rh →s blood only.</li>
<li>During emergencies, Rh →s blood is not always available; that’s why rhesus →s subjects may receive Rh →s blood for the first time. This includes formation of anti D antibodies in his plasma within 3 days after the transfusion.</li>
<li>Therefore, any future transfusion of Rh →s blood is contra-indicated because it will be associated with severe reaction.</li>
</ul>
<p>&gt; Inheritance</p>
<ul>
<li>Autosomal dominant character in chromosome 1.</li>
<li>Chromosome 1 carries E or e plus D or without D (absence of D is indicated in d) plus C or c. For example: Cde or cDe or CdE...</li>
<li>Since antigen D determines the rhesus group, genotype for each group (chromosomes from father and mother) will be as follows:</li>
<li>Rh →s genotypes: DD or Dd</li>
<li>Rh →s genotype: dd</li>
</ul>
<p>176
The text of medical practice</p>
<p>174
The work of Harkness (Phy. 1994: 4) * Volume 175
The work of Harkness (Phy. 1994: 4) * Volume 176
The work of Harkness (Phy. 1994: 4) * Volume 177</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="recommend-text">Recommend Text<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#recommend-text" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>A child of a mecca +ve father &amp; mecca +ve mother can be either Rh +ve or a Rh −ve (if the genotype of both father and mother is "D4").</li>
<li>A child of a mecca −ve father &amp; mecca −ve mother should be Rh −ve.</li>
</ul>
<p>&gt; <strong>Distribution (%):</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Percentage of subjects with Rh +ve blood group, in all populations, is far higher than that of Rh −ve subjects.</li>
<li>For example: 55% are Rh +ve &amp; only 1% are Rh −ve in Europe. In other communities, the percentage of mecca positive subjects is about 85% and 15% for Rh −ve subjects.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="remember-text">Remember Text<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remember-text" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>In the ABO system of blood grouping, transfusion of a mismatched blood (e.g. group A subject receiving blood group B) is always associated with severe reaction.</li>
<li>In the Rhesus system, blood transfusion reactions are:</li>
<li>Never expected for Rh +ve subject receiving Rh −ve blood</li>
<li>Not expected in the first blood transfusion for Rh −ve subject receiving Rh +ve blood</li>
<li>Always expected in subsequent transfusions for Rh −ve subject receiving Rh +ve blood</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="remember-text">Remember Text<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remember-text" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>A child of a mecca +ve father &amp; mecca +ve mother can be either Rh +ve or a Rh −ve (if the genotype of both father and mother is "D4").</li>
<li>A child of a mecca −ve father &amp; mecca −ve mother should be Rh −ve.</li>
</ul>

<ul>
<li>Percentage of subjects with Rh +ve blood group, in all populations, is far higher than that of Rh −ve subjects.</li>
<li>For example: 55% are Rh +ve &amp; only 1% are Rh −ve in Europe. In other communities, the percentage of mecca positive subjects is about 85% and 15% for Rh −ve subjects.</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="remember-text">Remember Text<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remember-text" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="remember-text">Remember Text<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remember-text" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<p>170
The cost of product packaging</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hemolytic-disease-of-the-newborn">Hemolytic disease of the newborn<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hemolytic-disease-of-the-newborn" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Also known as erythroblastosis fetalis because the early stages of RBCs (erythroblasts) appear in fetal blood together with reticulocytes as compensation to the excessive hemolysis.</li>
<li>It occurs in Rh +ve neonates of Rh -ve mothers.</li>
<li>During delivery of the first Rh +ve neonate, some of his blood enters maternal circulation. The delivered neonate is normal, but the mother forms and is antibodies of IgG type to get rid of the baby's RBCs (i.e. she becomes immunized).</li>
<li>When she becomes pregnant again with a Rh +ve fetus, these antibodies cross the placenta, enter the fetal circulation and attach RBCs of the fetus and develop hemolytic anemia and jaundice.</li>
<li>The hemolytic anemia is associated with hyperactive bone marrow to replace the lost RBCs. This results in appearance of the early stages of RBC in fetal blood (erythroblastosis &amp; reticulocytosis).</li>
<li>Anemia may become complicated by heart failure associated with generalized edema (hydrops fetalis) and the fetus may die in utero.</li>
<li>The jaundice is caused by unconjugated bilirubin which is insoluble in water. It may precipitate in the basal ganglia in the brain causing Kerinoleus (charakterized by motor problems and may be associated with mental retardation).</li>
<li>If the newborn is delivered with jaundice, he can be treated with:</li>
<li>Phototherapy converts the insoluble bilirubin to a water soluble substance, Laminin, that's soluble (do not precipitate in the brain) and can be counted easily in urine.</li>
<li>Exchange transfusion taking Rh +ve blood from the neonate and giving him Rh -ve blood.</li>
<li>Plasmapheresis usage of a machine that extracts the antibodies from blood of the neonate.</li>
</ul>
<p>171
The cost of product packaging</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hemolytic-disease-of-the-newborn">Hemolytic disease of the newborn<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hemolytic-disease-of-the-newborn" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Also known as erythroblastosis fetalis because the early stages of RBCs (erythroblasts) appear in fetal blood together with reticulocytes as compensation to the excessive hemolysis.</li>
<li>It occurs in Rh +ve neonates of Rh -ve mothers.</li>
<li>During delivery of the first Rh +ve neonate, some of his blood enters maternal circulation. The delivered neonate is normal, but the mother forms and is antibodies of IgG type to get rid of the baby's RBCs (i.e. she becomes immunized).</li>
<li>When she becomes pregnant again with a Rh +ve fetus, these antibodies cross the placenta, enter the fetal circulation and attach RBCs of the fetus and develop hemolytic anemia and jaundice.</li>
<li>The hemolytic anemia is associated with hyperactive bone marrow to replace the lost RBCs. This results in appearance of the early stages of RBC in fetal blood (erythroblastosis &amp; reticulocytosis).</li>
<li>Anemia may become complicated by heart failure associated with generalized edema (hydrops fetalis) and the fetus may die in utero.</li>
<li>The jaundice is caused by unconjugated bilirubin which is insoluble in water. It may precipitate in the basal ganglia in the brain causing Kerinoleus (characterized by motor problems and may be associated with mental retardation).</li>
<li>If the newborn is delivered with jaundice, he can be treated with:</li>
<li>Phototherapy converts the insoluble bilirubin to a water soluble substance, Laminin, that's soluble (do not precipitate in the brain) and can be counted easily in urine.</li>
<li>Exchange transfusion taking Rh +ve blood from the neonate and giving him Rh -ve blood.</li>
<li>Plasmapheresis usage of a machine that extracts the antibodies from blood of the neonate.</li>
</ul>
<p>172
The cost of product packaging</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hemolytic-disease-of-the-newborn">Hemolytic disease of the newborn<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hemolytic-disease-of-the-newborn" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Also known as erythroblastosis fetalis because the early stages of RBCs (erythroblasts) appear in fetal blood together with reticulocytes as compensation to the excessive hemolysis.</li>
<li>It occurs in Rh +ve neonates of Rh -ve mothers.</li>
<li>During delivery of the first Rh +ve neonate, some of his blood enters maternal circulation. The delivered neonate is normal, but the mother forms and is antibodies of IgG type to get rid of the baby's RBCs (i.e. she becomes immunized).</li>
<li>When she becomes pregnant again with a Rh +ve fetus, these antibodies cross the placenta, enter the fetal circulation and attach RBCs of the fetus and develop hemolytic anemia and jaundice.</li>
<li>The hemolytic anemia is associated with hyperactive bone marrow to replace the lost RBCs. This results in appearance of the early stages of RBC in fetal blood (erythroblastosis &amp; reticulocytosis).</li>
<li>Anemia may become complicated by heart failure associated with generalized edema (hydrops fetalis) and the fetus may die in utero.</li>
<li>The jaundice is caused by unconjugated bilirubin which is insoluble in water. It may precipitate in the basal ganglia in the brain causing Kerinoleus (characterized by motor problems and may be associated with mental retardation).</li>
<li>If the newborn is delivered with jaundice, he can be treated with:</li>
<li>Phototherapy converts the insoluble bilirubin to a water soluble substance, Laminin, that's soluble (do not precipitate in the brain) and can be counted easily in urine.</li>
<li>Exchange transfusion taking Rh +ve blood from the neonate and giving him Rh -ve blood.</li>
<li>Plasmapheresis usage of a machine that extracts the antibodies from blood of the neonate.</li>
</ul>
<p>177
The Journal of Medical Microbiology 177</p>
<ul>
<li>Prevention is better than cure. Here an injection of anti D antibodies given to the mother immediately following labor and not more than 72 hours after it will attack fetal RBCs that carry the mucus antigen and therefore prevent formation of anti D antibodies by the mother himself.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Remember that</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Antibodies injected to a subject stay in the circulation for short time and then disappears completely.</li>
<li>Antibodies formed by a subject himself stay in the circulation for very long time because memory cells continue to secrete the antibodies for life.</li>
</ul>
<p>Sometimes, ABO incompatibility between the mother and the neonate offers some natural protection against the hemolytic disease. For example when the mother is blood group A and the neonate is blood group B, here the naturally occurring anti B antibodies in maternal blood attack RBCs of the neonate as soon as they enter maternal circulation and therefore prevent formation of anti D antibodies.</p>
<ul>
<li>Prevention is better than cure. Here an injection of anti D antibodies given to the mother immediately following labor and not more than 72 hours after it will attack fetal RBCs that carry the mucus antigen and therefore prevent formation of anti D antibodies by the mother himself.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Remember that</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Antibodies injected to a subject stay in the circulation for short time and then disappears completely.</li>
<li>Antibodies formed by a subject himself stay in the circulation for very long time because memory cells continue to secrete the antibodies for life.</li>
</ul>
<p>Sometimes, ABO incompatibility between the mother and the neonate offers some natural protection against the hemolytic disease. For example when the mother is blood group A and the neonate is blood group B, here the naturally occurring anti B antibodies in maternal blood attack RBCs of the neonate as soon as they enter maternal circulation and therefore prevent formation of anti D antibodies.</p>
<ul>
<li>Prevention is better than cure. Here an injection of anti D antibodies given to the mother immediately following labor and not more than 72 hours after it will attack fetal RBCs that carry the mucus antigen and therefore prevent formation of anti D antibodies by the mother himself.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Remember that</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Antibodies injected to a subject stay in the circulation for short time and then disappears completely.</li>
<li>Antibodies formed by a subject himself stay in the circulation for very long time because memory cells continue to secrete the antibodies for life.</li>
</ul>
<p>Sometimes, ABO incompatibility between the mother and the neonate offers some natural protection against the hemolytic disease. For example when the mother is blood group A and the neonate is blood group B, here the naturally occurring anti B antibodies in maternal blood attack RBCs of the neonate as soon as they enter maternal circulation and therefore prevent formation of anti D antibodies.</p>
<p>177
The Journal of Medical Microbiology 177</p>
<p>176
The area of medical physiology 17</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="blood-transfusion">Blood transfusion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-transfusion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="precautions">Precautions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#precautions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>When blood is infused intravenously into patients, plasma of the patients should not contain antibodies that may react with blood group antigens on RBCs of the donor. To achieve this, suitable donors should be selected for each blood group, and this is further confirmed by cross matching test.</li>
<li>In cross matching test the plasma of the recipient (containing antibodies) is mixed with the donor's blood and then examined under the microscope for evidence of agglutination of the RBCs. Agglutination indicates that the blood of the donor is not suitable for the recipient.</li>
<li>In spite of this, errors may occur and unfortunate patients may receive mismatched blood by accident. For this reason, blood transfusion should always be taken seriously, with certain precautions, including release of a few drops at first to make sure that there is no reaction and close follow up of the process, putting life-saving drugs at reach beside the patient.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="complications-of-mismatched-blood-transfusion">Complications of mismatched blood transfusion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications-of-mismatched-blood-transfusion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>&gt; Agglutination of RBCs, followed by hemolysis:
&gt; - In mild cases, agglutination of RBCs may be complicated by post-transfusion jaundice.
&gt; - In severe reaction, a few ml of blood are sufficient to cause severe pain in the neck or in other sites and tightness in the chest (due to block of capillaries by the agglutinated RBCs). This is also followed by hemolysis of the RBCs and release of hemoglobin in plasma.</p>
<p>&gt; Acute renal failure:
&gt; - Some of the intravascular hemoglobin is filtered at the glomeruli and excreted in urine (hemoglobinuria).
&gt; - Some precipitates in the renal tubule resulting, in addition to the low blood pressure, in acute renal failure.</p>
<p>177
Blood transfusion</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="precautions">Precautions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#precautions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>When blood is infused intravenously into patients, plasma of the patients should not contain antibodies that may react with blood group antigens on RBCs of the donor. To achieve this, suitable donors should be selected for each blood group, and this is further confirmed by cross matching test.</li>
<li>In cross matching test the plasma of the recipient (containing antibodies) is mixed with the donor's blood and then examined under the microscope for evidence of agglutination of the RBCs. Agglutination indicates that the blood of the donor is not suitable for the recipient.</li>
<li>In spite of this, errors may occur and unfortunate patients may receive mismatched blood by accident. For this reason, blood transfusion should always be taken seriously, with certain precautions, including release of a few drops at first to make sure that there is no reaction and close follow up of the process, putting life-saving drugs at reach beside the patient.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="complications-of-mismatched-blood-transfusion">Complications of mismatched blood transfusion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications-of-mismatched-blood-transfusion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>&gt; Agglutination of RBCs, followed by hemolysis:
&gt; - In mild cases, agglutination of RBCs may be complicated by post-transfusion jaundice.
&gt; - In severe reaction, a few ml of blood are sufficient to cause severe pain in the neck or in other sites and tightness in the chest (due to block of capillaries by the agglutinated RBCs). This is also followed by hemolysis of the RBCs and release of hemoglobin in plasma.</p>
<p>&gt; Acute renal failure:
&gt; - Some of the intravascular hemoglobin is filtered at the glomeruli and excreted in urine (hemoglobinuria).
&gt; - Some precipitates in the renal tubule resulting, in addition to the low blood pressure, in acute renal failure.</p>
<p>178
Blood transfusion</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="precautions">Precautions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#precautions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>When blood is infused intravenously into patients, plasma of the patients should not contain antibodies that may react with blood group antigens on RBCs of the donor. To achieve this, suitable donors should be selected for each blood group, and this is further confirmed by cross matching test.</li>
<li>In cross matching test the plasma of the recipient (containing antibodies) is mixed with the donor's blood and then examined under the microscope for evidence of agglutination of the RBCs. Agglutination indicates that the blood of the donor is not suitable for the recipient.</li>
<li>In spite of this, errors may occur and unfortunate patients may receive mismatched blood by accident. For this reason, blood transfusion should always be taken seriously, with certain precautions, including release of a few drops at first to make sure that there is no reaction and close follow up of the process, putting life-saving drugs at reach beside the patient.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="complications-of-mismatched-blood-transfusion">Complications of mismatched blood transfusion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications-of-mismatched-blood-transfusion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>&gt; Agglutination of RBCs, followed by hemolysis:
&gt; - In mild cases, agglutination of RBCs may be complicated by post-transfusion jaundice.
&gt; - In severe reaction, a few ml of blood are sufficient to cause severe pain in the neck or in other sites and tightness in the chest (due to block of capillaries by the agglutinated RBCs). This is also followed by hemolysis of the RBCs and release of hemoglobin in plasma.</p>
<p>&gt; Acute renal failure:
&gt; - Some of the intravascular hemoglobin is filtered at the glomeruli and excreted in urine (hemoglobinuria).
&gt; - Some precipitates in the renal tubule resulting, in addition to the low blood pressure, in acute renal failure.</p>
<p>The area of medical physiology 17</p>
<p>176
The issue of medical technology: IT solution
177
The issue of medical technology: IT solution</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Acute renal failure is characterized by low urine output, high urea and high potassium ions. Death may occur in few days.
&gt; Unstimulated intravascular coagulation (IVC)
&gt; In severe cases, antigen-antibody reactions may result in activation of coagulation causing DIC and therefore fatal bleeding due consumption of the clotting factors.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Complications of compatible blood transfusion
Hypertelorism due to potassium released from hemolysed RBCs during storage of blood</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypocalcemia due to excess anticoagulant (e.g. citrate, which is a calcium chelating agent)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fever (feeder reaction) due to pyrogenic and/or cytokines in the donor's blood</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Allergy (allergic reaction) due to allergens in the donor's blood; sometimes severe anaphylaxis may occur</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Transmission of infection due to transfusion of infected blood (e.g. HIV, Hepatitis B, malaria ...)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Air embolism</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Thrombophlebitis at the injection site</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fluid overload especially in patients with heart failure</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Iron overload due to repeated blood transfusions (hemosiderosis)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Acute renal failure is characterized by low urine output, high urea and high potassium ions. Death may occur in few days.
&gt; Unstimulated intravascular coagulation (IVC)
&gt; In severe cases, antigen-antibody reactions may result in activation of coagulation causing DIC and therefore fatal bleeding due consumption of the clotting factors.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Complications of compatible blood transfusion
Hypertelorism due to potassium released from hemolysed RBCs during storage of blood</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypocalcemia due to excess anticoagulant (e.g. citrate, which is a calcium chelating agent)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fever (feeder reaction) due to pyrogenic and/or cytokines in the donor's blood</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Allergy (allergic reaction) due to allergens in the donor's blood, sometimes severe anaphylaxis may occur</p>
</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hemostasis">HEMOSTASIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hemostasis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="definition">Definition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Prevention of blood loss by arrest of bleeding and maintenance of blood in the fluid state.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanisms-or-steps-of-hemostasis-following-injury">Mechanisms (or steps) of hemostasis following injury<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanisms-or-steps-of-hemostasis-following-injury" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Vasospasm</li>
<li>Formation of platelet plug</li>
<li>Formation of blood clot (Coagulation)</li>
<li>Fibrinolysis or fibrous tissue formation</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vasospasm">Vasospasm<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vasospasm" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Occurs immediately following injury due to:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Myogenic response (the vascular smooth muscle responds to trauma by spasm)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Humoral factors (serotonin &amp; catecholamines like epinephrine and norepinephrine cause vasoconstriction)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Neural factors (neural reflex involving the sympathetic neurons)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The vasospasm is expected to be weak in cases of:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypoxia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Metabolic acidosis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Small surface area (spasm caused by a knife is weaker than that caused by a stone, because the surface area of blood vessels injured by the knife is smaller than by the stone)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="formation-of-platelet-plug">Formation of platelet plug<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#formation-of-platelet-plug" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Aggregation of platelets to close a hole in the blood vessel</li>
<li>Enough to close small holes in blood vessels</li>
<li>Large holes need the third step: blood coagulation</li>
</ul>
<p>180
The view of medical physiology of adults</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hemostasis">HEMOSTASIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hemostasis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="definition">Definition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Prevention of blood loss by arrest of bleeding and maintenance of blood in the fluid state.</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanisms-or-steps-of-hemostasis-following-injury">Mechanisms (or steps) of hemostasis following injury<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanisms-or-steps-of-hemostasis-following-injury" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<li>Vasospasm</li>
<li>Formation of platelet plug</li>
<li>Formation of blood clot (Coagulation)</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vasospasm">Vasospasm<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vasospasm" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Occurs immediately following injury due to:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Myogenic response (the vascular smooth muscle responds to trauma by spasm)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Humoral factors (serotonin &amp; catecholamines like epinephrine and norepinephrine cause vasoconstriction)</p>
</li>

<p>Hypoxia</p>

<li>
<p>Metabolic acidosis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Small surface area (spasm caused by a knife is weaker than that caused by a stone, because the surface area of blood vessels injured by the knife is smaller than by the stone)</p>
</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="formation-of-platelet-plug">Formation of platelet plug<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#formation-of-platelet-plug" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="definition">Definition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanisms-or-steps-of-hemostasis-following-injury">Mechanisms (or steps) of hemostasis following injury<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanisms-or-steps-of-hemostasis-following-injury" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vasospasm">Vasospasm<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vasospasm" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

</li>
<li>
<p>Myogenic response (the vascular smooth muscle responds to trauma by spasm)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Humoral factors (serotonin &amp; catecholamines like epinephrine and norepinephrine cause vasoconstriction)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Neural factors (neural reflex involving the sympathetic neurons)</p>
