</li>
<li>
<p>Hypoxia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Metabolic acidosis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Small surface area (spasm caused by a knife is weaker than that caused by a stone, because the surface area of blood vessels injured by the knife is smaller than by the stone)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="formation-of-platelet-plug">Formation of platelet plug<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#formation-of-platelet-plug" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Aggregation of platelets to close a hole in the blood vessel</li>
<li>Enough to close small holes in blood vessels</li>
<li>Large holes need the third step: blood coagulation</li>
</ul>
<p>180
The costs of medical pharmacology / P. adams</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="platelets-thrombocytes">Platelets (Thrombocytes)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#platelets-thrombocytes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Small cells (2-4μm in diameter)</li>
<li>Count (200,000 – 400,000/mm³)</li>
<li>Life span: about 5 days (up to 10 days)</li>
<li>Acne from stem cells &amp; then megakaryocytes in the bone marrow.</li>
<li>The cytoplasm of each megakaryocyte breaks down into large number of platelets (i.e. 7 by are non-nucleated).</li>
<li>Formation is regulated by colony stimulating factors and a hormone known as thrombopoietin, a protein released by the liver and kidneys.</li>
<li>About one third are stored in the spleen. That's why splenectomy (removal of the spleen) is sometimes used for treatment of thrombocytopenia to increase platelet count.</li>
<li>The r membranes contain receptors for collagen and von Willebrand factor (vWF) both are important for attachment of platelets to collagen at sites of blood ver - d injury. Also they have receptors for ADP and fibrinogen.</li>
<li>Platelets contain two types of granules:</li>
<li>Alpha granules (contain protein substances like the clotting factor number 13, platelet derived growth factor (PDGF) which is a potent stimulus for wound healing &amp; vWF which is synthesized by megakaryocytes and also by endothelial cells)</li>
<li>Dense granules (contain non-protein substances like serotonin and ADP)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-platelets">Functions of platelets<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-platelets" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Participates in the various mechanisms of hemostasis as follows:</li>
<li>Vasospasm: they release a vasoconstrictor (serotonin);</li>
<li>Platelet plug formation: major function of platelets (see below);</li>
<li>Blood coagulation (platelets release some clotting factors (e.g. factor 13 and platelet factor 3 "phospholipids")).</li>
<li>Clot retraction: after formation of a blood clot and incubation of blood for half an hour or so, platelets contract because they contain actin and myosin fibers.</li>
</ul>
<p>181
The costs of medical pharmacology / P. adams</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="platelets-thrombocytes">Platelets (Thrombocytes)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#platelets-thrombocytes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Small cells (2-4μm in diameter)</li>
<li>Count (200,000 – 400,000/mm³)</li>
<li>Life span: about 5 days (up to 10 days)</li>
<li>Acne from stem cells &amp; then megakaryocytes in the bone marrow.</li>
<li>The cytoplasm of each megakaryocyte breaks down into large number of platelets (i.e. 7 by are non-nucleated).</li>
<li>Formation is regulated by colony stimulating factors and a hormone known as thrombopoietin, a protein released by the liver and kidneys.</li>
<li>About one third are stored in the spleen. That's why splenectomy (removal of the spleen) is sometimes used for treatment of thrombocytopenia to increase platelet count.</li>
<li>The r membranes contain receptors for collagen and von Willebrand factor (vWF) both are important for attachment of platelets to collagen at sites of blood ver - d injury. Also they have receptors for ADP and fibrinogen.</li>
<li>Platelets contain two types of granules:</li>
<li>Alpha granules (contain protein substances like the clotting factor number 13, platelet derived growth factor (PDGF) which is a potent stimulus for wound healing &amp; vWF which is synthesized by megakaryocytes and also by endothelial cells)</li>
<li>Dense granules (contain non-protein substances like serotonin and ADP)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-platelets">Functions of platelets<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-platelets" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Participates in the various mechanisms of hemostasis as follows:</li>
<li>Vasospasm: they release a vasoconstrictor (serotonin);</li>
<li>Platelet plug formation: major function of platelets (see below);</li>
<li>Blood coagulation (platelets release some clotting factors (e.g. factor 13 and platelet factor 3 "phospholipids")).</li>
<li>Clot retraction: after formation of a blood clot and incubation of blood for half an hour or so, platelets contract because they contain actin and myosin fibers.</li>
</ul>
<p>182
The costs of medical pharmacology / P. adams</p>
<p>In their cytoplasm. This decreases the size of the clot (to about 10% of its original size), and expresses serum (read table 5.2).</p>
<ul>
<li>Platelet deficiency (thrombocytopenia) results in increased bleeding tendency. A count less than 50,000 cells/L is associated with hemorrhage after many injuries and possibly multiple petechial hemorrhages under the skin and mucus membranes "thrombocytopenic purpura"; however, purpura is very common when the platelet count is less than 20,000 cells/L.</li>
<li>On the other hand, high count of platelets (thrombocytosis) predisposes to thrombotic problems.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanism-of-platelet-plus-formation">Mechanism of platelet plus formation:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanism-of-platelet-plus-formation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Platelets attach to collagen fibers (this step is facilitated by collagen receptors on platelets &amp; vWF)</li>
<li>Activation of platelets (attachment to collagen fibers activates platelets to swell, become irregular in surface and become sticky)</li>
<li>Release of contents (serotonin, thromboxane A₂-TXA₂, ADP ...)</li>
<li>Aggregation of platelets (serotonin causes vasospasm whereas TXA₂ &amp; ADP activate nearby platelets to swell and stick to the previous ones and release the same contents, then TXA₂ &amp; ADP activate other platelets and the cycle repeats itself in a form of "positive feedback mechanism" until the small hole in the blood vessel is sealed by the plug (large holes need coagulation).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="table-5-2-comparison-between-serum-and-plasma">Table 5.2: Comparison between serum and plasma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#table-5-2-comparison-between-serum-and-plasma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Difference</th><th>Plasma</th><th>Serum</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Formation</td><td>By centrifugation of blood</td><td>By incubating a clothed sample for sometime</td></tr><tr><td>Clotting proteins (e.g. fibrinogen)</td><td>Present</td><td>Absent (consumed)</td></tr><tr><td>Serotonin</td><td>Low</td><td>High (released by activated platelets)</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>In their cytoplasm. This decreases the size of the clot (to about 10% of its original size), and expresses serum (read table 5.2).</p>
<ul>
<li>Platelet deficiency (thrombocytopenia) results in increased bleeding tendency. A count less than 50,000 cells/L is associated with hemorrhage after many injuries and possibly multiple petechial hemorrhages under the skin and mucus membranes "thrombocytopenic purpura"; however, purpura is very common when the platelet count is less than 20,000 cells/L.</li>
<li>On the other hand, high count of platelets (thrombocytosis) predisposes to thrombotic problems.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanism-of-platelet-plus-formation">Mechanism of platelet plus formation:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanism-of-platelet-plus-formation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Platelets attach to collagen fibers (this step is facilitated by collagen receptors on platelets &amp; vWF)</li>
<li>Activation of platelets (attachment to collagen fibers activates platelets to swell, become irregular in surface and become sticky)</li>
<li>Release of contents (serotonin, thromboxane A₂-TXA₂, ADP ...)</li>
<li>Aggregation of platelets (serotonin causes vasospasm whereas TXA₂ &amp; ADP activate nearby platelets to swell and stick to the previous ones and release the same contents, then TXA₂ &amp; ADP activate other platelets and the cycle repeats itself in a form of "positive feedback mechanism" until the small hole in the blood vessel is sealed by the plug (large holes need coagulation).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="table-5-2-comparison-between-serum-and-plasma">Table 5.2: Comparison between serum and plasma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#table-5-2-comparison-between-serum-and-plasma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Difference</th><th>Plasma</th><th>Serum</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Formation</td><td>By centrifugation of blood</td><td>By incubating a clothed sample for sometime</td></tr><tr><td>Clotting proteins (e.g. fibrinogen)</td><td>Present</td><td>Absent (consumed)</td></tr><tr><td>Serotonin</td><td>Low</td><td>High (released by activated platelets)</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>In their cytoplasm. This decreases the size of the clot (to about 10% of its original size), and expresses serum (read table 5.2).</p>
<ul>
<li>Platelet deficiency (thrombocytopenia) results in increased bleeding tendency. A count less than 50,000 cells/L is associated with hemorrhage after many injuries and possibly multiple petechial hemorrhages under the skin and mucus membranes "thrombocytopenic purpura"; however, purpura is very common when the platelet count is less than 20,000 cells/L.</li>
<li>On the other hand, high count of platelets (thrombocytosis) predisposes to thrombotic problems.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanism-of-platelet-plus-formation">Mechanism of platelet plus formation:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanism-of-platelet-plus-formation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Platelets attach to collagen fibers (this step is facilitated by collagen receptors on platelets &amp; vWF)</li>
<li>Activation of platelets (attachment to collagen fibers activates platelets to swell, become irregular in surface and become sticky)</li>
<li>Release of contents (serotonin, thromboxane A₂-TXA₂, ADP ...)</li>
<li>Aggregation of platelets (serotonin causes vasospasm whereas TXA₂ &amp; ADP activate nearby platelets to swell and stick to the previous ones and release the same contents, then TXA₂ &amp; ADP activate other platelets and the cycle repeats itself in a form of "positive feedback mechanism" until the small hole in the blood vessel is sealed by the plug (large holes need coagulation).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="table-5-2-comparison-between-serum-and-plasma">Table 5.2: Comparison between serum and plasma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#table-5-2-comparison-between-serum-and-plasma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Difference</th><th>Plasma</th><th>Serum</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Formation</td><td>By centrifugation of blood</td><td>By incubating a clothed sample for sometime</td></tr><tr><td>Clotting proteins (e.g. fibrinogen)</td><td>Present</td><td>Absent (consumed)</td></tr><tr><td>Serotonin</td><td>Low</td><td>High (released by activated platelets)</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>182
The role of medical physiology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hood-coagulation">Hood coagulation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hood-coagulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Biochemical reactions that involve activation of clotting factors (present in blood or reactive form) in a cascade way to form a blood clot.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The clotting factors are indicated by roman numbers from I to XIII or by names; for example:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fibrinogen Factor I</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Prothrombin Factor II</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tissue factor Factor III or tissue thromboplastin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Calcium Factor IV</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factor V Proaccelerin or labile factor</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factor VII Serum prothrombin conversion accelerator (SPCA) or stable factor</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factor VIII Anti-hemophilic factor A</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factor IX Christmas factor or antihemophilic factor B</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factor X Stuart factor</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factor XI Antihemophilic factor C</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factor XII Hageman factor</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factor XIII Fibrin-stabilizing factor</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Most of these factors are produced by the liver (exceptions include factors II, IV and XIII).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Remember that there is no clotting factor known as factor VI.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Activation of the clotting factors occurs through two pathways:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Intrinsic pathway</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Extrinsic pathway</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-intrinsic-pathway">The intrinsic pathway<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-intrinsic-pathway" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>All factors involved are present in the blood (i.e. there is no need for an intrinsic factor from the tissues).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hood-coagulation">Hood coagulation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hood-coagulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Biochemical reactions that involve activation of clotting factors (present in blood or reactive form) in a cascade way to form a blood clot.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The clotting factors are indicated by roman numbers from I to XIII or by names; for example:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fibrinogen Factor I</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Prothrombin Factor II</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tissue factor Factor III or tissue thromboplastin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Calcium Factor IV</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factor V Proaccelerin or labile factor</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factor VII Serum prothrombin conversion accelerator (SPCA) or stable factor</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factor VIII Anti-hemophilic factor A</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factor IX Christmas factor or antihemophilic factor B</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factor X Stuart factor</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factor XI Antihemophilic factor C</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factor XII Hageman factor</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factor XIII Fibrin-stabilizing factor</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Most of these factors are produced by the liver (exceptions include factors II, IV and XIII).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Remember that there is no clotting factor known as factor VI.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Activation of the clotting factors occurs through two pathways:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Intrinsic pathway</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Extrinsic pathway</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-intrinsic-pathway">The intrinsic pathway<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-intrinsic-pathway" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>All factors involved are present in the blood (i.e. there is no need for an intrinsic factor from the tissues).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hood-coagulation">Hood coagulation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hood-coagulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Biochemical reactions that involve activation of clotting factors (present in blood or reactive form) in a cascade way to form a blood clot.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The clotting factors are indicated by roman numbers from I to XIII or by names; for example:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fibrinogen Factor I</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Prothrombin Factor II</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tissue factor Factor III or tissue thromboplastin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Calcium Factor IV</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factor V Proaccelerin or labile factor</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factor VII Serum prothrombin conversion accelerator (SPCA) or stable factor</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factor VIII Anti-hemophilic factor A</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factor IX Christmas factor or antihemophilic factor B</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factor X Stuart factor</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factor XI Antihemophilic factor C</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factor XII Hageman factor</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factor XIII Fibrin-stabilizing factor</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Most of these factors are produced by the liver (exceptions include factors II, IV and XIII).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Remember that there is no clotting factor known as factor VI.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Activation of the clotting factors occurs through two pathways:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Intrinsic pathway</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Extrinsic pathway</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-intrinsic-pathway">The intrinsic pathway<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-intrinsic-pathway" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>All factors involved are present in the blood (i.e. there is no need for an intrinsic factor from the tissues).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-case-of-residual-physiology-r2r-2r2-values">The case of residual physiology: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">R^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> values<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-case-of-residual-physiology-r2r-2r2-values" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-case-of-normal-physiology-r2r-2r2-values">The case of normal physiology: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">R^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> values<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-case-of-normal-physiology-r2r-2r2-values" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Factors activated through this pathway include: X8, XI, IX, VIII, X, V, 1 and 2 plus calcium ions (factor IV) &amp; phospholipids (provided by plateaus as plasma factor 2).</li>
<li>The first factor to be activated is factor X8. It is activated when blood comes in contact with collagen or wereable negative surface like glass. See the other steps in figure 5.14.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-161b8320.jpeg" alt="img-203.jpeg">
Fig 5.14: Pathways of coagulation</p>
<ul>
<li>Factors activated through this pathway include: X8, XI, IX, VIII, X, V, 1 and 2 plus calcium ions (factor IV) &amp; phospholipids (provided by plateaus as plasma factor 2).</li>
<li>The first factor to be activated is factor X8. It is activated when blood comes in contact with collagen or wereable negative surface like glass. See the other steps in figure 5.14.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-b11d1da5.jpeg" alt="img-204.jpeg">
Fig 5.14: Pathways of coagulation</p>
<ul>
<li>Factors activated through this pathway include: X8, XI, IX, VIII, X, V, 1 and 2 plus calcium ions (factor IV) &amp; phospholipids (provided by plateaus as plasma factor 2).</li>
<li>The first factor to be activated is factor X8. It is activated when blood comes in contact with collagen or wereable negative surface like glass. See the other steps in figure 5.14.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-791f906f.jpeg" alt="img-205.jpeg">
Fig 5.14: Pathways of coagulation</p>
<p>184
The text of the National Library of Medicine</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-extrinsic-pathway">The extrinsic pathway<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-extrinsic-pathway" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>It is called extrinsic because a tissue factor (known as thromboplastin or factor II) is needed for its activation. This factor consists of phospholipids and protein.</li>
<li>Factors activated through this pathway include: VII, X, V, II and I plus calcium ions (factor IV). It phospholipids (provided by the tissue factor).</li>
<li>This pathway is faster than the intrinsic pathway.</li>
<li>The first factor to be activated is factor VII. It is activated by the tissue factor. See the other steps in figure 5.14.</li>
<li>Factor X, II, I and V are activated through both intrinsic and extrinsic pathways, that's why they are described as factors of the common pathway.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="important-notes-about-coagulation">Important notes about coagulation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#important-notes-about-coagulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Calcium ions are needed in all steps of coagulation except the first two steps of the intrinsic pathway which need high molecular weight kininogen (HMWK) and Prokallinium (PK).</li>
<li>Phospholipids are needed in many steps (e.g. activation of factor X and II).</li>
<li>Phospholipids in the intrinsic pathway are provided by platelets and in the extrinsic pathway are provided by the tissue factor.</li>
<li>Factor V and VIII are cofactors, their activation by thrombin results in amplification and repetition of the reactions through a positive feedback mechanism.</li>
<li>Thrombin, the active form of factor II, is an alpha globulin synthesized in the liver as prothrombin. Its activation requires many factors: aX, aV, calcium and phospholipids. All these factors are known collectively as prothrombin activator complex or thrombokinase.</li>
<li>Activation of prothrombin to thrombin is the most important step in coagulation. Actions of thrombin include:</li>
<li>Activation of fibrinogen (factor I)</li>
<li>Activation of factor V</li>
<li>Activation of factor VII</li>
</ul>
<p>185
The text of the National Library of Medicine</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-extrinsic-pathway">The extrinsic pathway<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-extrinsic-pathway" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>It is called extrinsic because a tissue factor (known as thromboplastin or factor II) is needed for its activation. This factor consists of phospholipids and protein.</li>
<li>Factors activated through this pathway include: VII, X, V, II and I plus calcium ions (factor IV). It phospholipids (provided by the tissue factor).</li>
<li>This pathway is faster than the intrinsic pathway.</li>
<li>The first factor to be activated is factor VII. It is activated by the tissue factor. See the other steps in figure 5.14.</li>
<li>Factor X, II, I and V are activated through both intrinsic and extrinsic pathways, that's why they are described as factors of the common pathway.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="important-notes-about-coagulation">Important notes about coagulation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#important-notes-about-coagulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Calcium ions are needed in all steps of coagulation except the first two steps of the intrinsic pathway which need high molecular weight kininogen (HMWK) and Prokallinium (PK).</li>
<li>Phospholipids are needed in many steps (e.g. activation of factor X and II).</li>
<li>Phospholipids in the intrinsic pathway are provided by platelets and in the extrinsic pathway are provided by the tissue factor.</li>
<li>Factor V and VIII are cofactors, their activation by thrombin results in amplification and repetition of the reactions through a positive feedback mechanism.</li>
<li>Thrombin, the active form of factor II, is an alpha globulin synthesized in the liver as prothrombin. Its activation requires many factors: aX, aV, calcium and phospholipids. All these factors are known collectively as prothrombin activator complex or thrombokinase.</li>
<li>Activation of prothrombin to thrombin is the most important step in coagulation. Actions of thrombin include:</li>
<li>Activation of fibrinogen (factor I)</li>
<li>Activation of factor V</li>
<li>Activation of factor VII</li>
</ul>
<p>186
The text of the National Library of Medicine</p>
<ul>
<li>Activation of plasminogen (see below)</li>
<li>Activation of platelets</li>
<li>Activation of protein C (through thrombomodulin, see below)</li>
<li>Thrombin activates fibrinogen to form fibrin strands. These combine together to form a net at the site of injury. The net catches cells and protein until it is completely sealed as clot.</li>
<li>The blood clot is stabilized by factor XIII (fibrin stabilizing factor) and Ca²⁺. Factor XIII is released by platelets. It forms covalent bonds between fibrin strands.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-fd3edc1e.jpeg" alt="img-206.jpeg">
Fig. 8.10. The blood clot</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fibrinolysis">Fibrinolysis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fibrinolysis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>After formation of the blood clot, bleeding stops, but the clot causes partial obstruction within the blood vessel. Therefore, it should be removed by the process of fibrinolysis; however, some clots may become invaded by fibroblasts (invited by platelet derived growth factors). These cells convert the clot into a permanent fibrous tissue.</li>
<li>Fibrinolysis involves enzymatic degradation of fibrin by the enzyme plasmin resulting in formation of fibrin degradation products.</li>
<li>Plasmin is produced by the liver as an inactive protein (Plasminogen).</li>
<li>Plasminogen is activated by factors called (Plasminogen activation).</li>
<li>These factors can be obtained from: Blood, tissues, urine and bacteria.</li>
</ul>
<p>185</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fibrinolysis">Fibrinolysis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fibrinolysis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>After formation of the blood clot, bleeding stops, but the clot causes partial obstruction within the blood vessel. Therefore, it should be removed by the process of fibrinolysis; however, some clots may become invaded by fibroblasts (invited by platelet derived growth factors). These cells convert the clot into a permanent fibrous tissue.</li>
<li>Fibrinolysis involves enzymatic degradation of fibrin by the enzyme plasmin resulting in formation of fibrin degradation products.</li>
<li>Plasmin is produced by the liver as an inactive protein (Plasminogen).</li>
<li>Plasminogen is activated by factors called (Plasminogen activation).</li>
<li>These factors can be obtained from Blood, tissues, urine and bacteria.</li>
</ul>
<p>186</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fibrinolysis">Fibrinolysis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fibrinolysis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<li>After formation of the blood clot, bleeding stops, but the clot causes partial obstruction within the blood vessel. Therefore, it should be removed by the process of fibrinolysis; however, some clots may become invaded by fibroblasts (invited by platelet derived growth factors). These cells convert the clot into a permanent fibrous tissue.</li>

<p>187</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fibrinolysis">Fibrinolysis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fibrinolysis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>After formation of the blood clot, bleeding stops, but the clot causes partial obstruction within the blood vessel. Therefore, it should be removed by the process of fibrinolysis; however, some clots may become invaded by fibroblasts (invited by platelet derived growth factors). These cells convert the clot into a permanent fibrous tissue.</li>
<li>Fibrinolysis involves enzymatic degradation of fibrin by the enzyme plasmin resulting in formation of fibrin degradation products.</li>
<li>Plasmin is produced by the liver as an inactive protein (Plasminogen).</li>
<li>Plasminogen is activated by factors called (Plasminogen activation).</li>
<li>These factors can be obtained from Blood, tissues, urine and bacteria.</li>
</ul>
<p>188</p>
<p>127
The text of Medical Laboratory: 2nd edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="plasminogen-activation-in-blood">Plasminogen activation in blood<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#plasminogen-activation-in-blood" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>These are: a/01 and thrombin.</li>
<li>Although they are responsible for formation of the blood clot, they participate in its lysis by activating plasminogen into plasmin. However, lysis does not occur immediately following blood clot formation because plasmin is inhibited by a plasma protein known as α₁ anti-plasmin. The level of plasmin has to increase gradually until it becomes sufficient to cause lysis of the clot, this usually occurs after 48 hours. During this time regeneration occurs and the hole in the blood vessel is closed.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="plasminogen-activator-in-the-tissues">Plasminogen activator in the tissues<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#plasminogen-activator-in-the-tissues" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>This is the IFA (Inlase Plasminogen activator). It is released by the tissues, e.g. vascular endothelium, to cause lysis of the clot.</li>
<li>It can be synthesized by recombinant DNA from melanoma cells for medical purposes (to be used for treatment of acute myocardial infarction). However, it is very expensive to be used in the developing countries.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="plasminogen-activator-in-urine">Plasminogen activator in urine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#plasminogen-activator-in-urine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>This is urokinase which is synthesized by the transitional epithelium of the urinary tract and released in urine.</li>
<li>Its physiological significance in urine is unknown, may be to cause immediate lysis for clots that may obstruct the renal tubules.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="plasminogen-activator-from-bacteria">Plasminogen activator from bacteria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#plasminogen-activator-from-bacteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>This is streptokinase, a toxin produced and released by streptococci to break clots formed by the body to bind its spread.</li>
<li>The bacteria are cultured and streptokinase is extracted for treatment of acute myocardial infarction. It is rather cheaper than IFA. However, since it is extracted from bacteria, its IV infusion induces formation of antibodies against it. Therefore, its future use in the same patient requires certain precautions.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-normal-endothelium-can-activate-plasminogen">The normal endothelium can activate plasminogen<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-normal-endothelium-can-activate-plasminogen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The endothelial cells have Plasminogen receptors on their surface. These activate Plasminogen when it binds them.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="plasminogen-activators-in-blood">Plasminogen activators in blood<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#plasminogen-activators-in-blood" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>These are: a/01 and thrombin.</li>
<li>Although they are responsible for formation of the blood clot, they participate in its lysis by activating plasminogen into plasmin. However, lysis does not occur immediately following blood clot formation because plasmin is inhibited by a plasma protein known as α₁ anti-plasmin. The level of plasmin has to increase gradually until it becomes sufficient to cause lysis of the clot, this usually occurs after 48 hours. During this time regeneration occurs and the hole in the blood vessel is closed.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="plasminogen-activator-in-the-tissues">Plasminogen activator in the tissues<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#plasminogen-activator-in-the-tissues" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="plasminogen-activator-in-urine">Plasminogen activator in urine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#plasminogen-activator-in-urine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="plasminogen-activator-from-bacteria">Plasminogen activator from bacteria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#plasminogen-activator-from-bacteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="plasminogen-activator-in-urine">Plasminogen activator in urine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#plasminogen-activator-in-urine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>This is urokinase which is synthesized by the transitional epithelium of the urinary tract and released in urine.</li>
<li>Its physiological significance in urine is unknown, may be to cause immediate lysis for clots that may obstruct the renal tubules.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="plasminogen-activator-from-bacteria">Plasminogen activator from bacteria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#plasminogen-activator-from-bacteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>This is streptokinase, a toxin produced and released by streptococci to break clots formed by the body to bind its spread.</li>
<li>The bacteria are cultured and streptokinase is extracted for treatment of acute myocardial infarction. It is rather cheaper than IFA. However, since it is extracted from bacteria, its IV infusion induces formation of antibodies against it. Therefore, its future use in the same patient requires certain precautions.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-normal-endothelium-can-activate-plasminogen">The normal endothelium can activate plasminogen<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-normal-endothelium-can-activate-plasminogen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The endothelial cells have Plasminogen receptors on their surface. These activate Plasminogen when it binds them.</li>
</ul>
<p>128
The text of Medical Laboratory: 2nd edition</p>
<p>158
The care of medical physiology of cancer</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="anticoagulants">ANTICOAGULANTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anticoagulants" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="natural-anticoagulants">Natural anticoagulants<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#natural-anticoagulants" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are present naturally within the body. They prevent clotting within the circulation. Abnormalities associated with a defect or absence of one or more of these factors are usually associated with intravascular clotting. They include:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-normal-endothelium">The normal endothelium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-normal-endothelium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Prevents clotting by the following:</li>
<li>Smooth surface prevents activation of the clotting factors</li>
<li>Release of prostacycline &amp; nitric oxide (these cause vasodilatation and inhibit platelet aggregation)</li>
<li>Have plasminogen receptors on their surface that activates plasmin when it binds them</li>
<li>Thrombomodulin (see below)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-blood-flow">The blood flow<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-blood-flow" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Rapid blood flow inhibits coagulation whereas stasis of blood favors coagulation. Stasis may occur due to:</li>
<li>Mechanical obstruction of a blood vessel</li>
<li>Prolonged sitting (e.g. during prolonged flight or bus journey)</li>
<li>Prolonged lying down (e.g. comatose patients or those with fractures)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="anti-thrombin-iii">Anti-thrombin III<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anti-thrombin-iii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>An alpha globulin synthesized by the liver.</li>
<li>Bacillaster III, X, XI and XII</li>
<li>Its activity is increased about 1000 times by heparin. For this reason it is called the heparin cofactor</li>
<li>Hemoglobin may also facilitate the activity of antithrombin III.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="anticoagulants">ANTICOAGULANTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anticoagulants" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="natural-anticoagulants">Natural anticoagulants<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#natural-anticoagulants" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="natural-anticoagulants">Natural anticoagulants<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#natural-anticoagulants" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-normal-endothelium">The normal endothelium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-normal-endothelium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="anti-thrombin-iii">Anti-thrombin III<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anti-thrombin-iii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>An alpha globulin synthesized by the liver.</li>
<li>Bacillaster III, X, XI and XII</li>
<li>Its activity is increased about 1000 times by heparin. For this reason it is called the heparin cofactor</li>
<li>Hemoglobin may also facilitate the activity of antithrombin III.</li>
</ul>
<p>189
The text of medical physiology of science</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Hazards</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sulfated polysaccharide (MWr. 15,000-18,000)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Found in the granules of most cells and basophils</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Auto through activation of anti-thrombin B</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Its low level in plasma indicates that it is not very important as a natural anticoagulant at normal conditions</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is very important for prevention of coagulation in containers used for blood collection and when given intravenously in therapeutic doses (e.g. in cases of deep vein thrombosis (DVT))</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When given accidentally in toxic doses, protamine sulphate is used to neutralize it (= antidote).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Alpha-2-macroglobulin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Similar to anti-thrombin B</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Inactivates some clotting factors.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Thromboendulins</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A protein expressed on surface of most endothelial cells (except those in cerebral capillaries)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Binds thrombin to form a complex that activates protein C.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Protein C and its cofactor: protein S</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Produced by the liver</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Require vitamin K for their synthesis.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Replicate the following:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factor V</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factor VII</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Inhibitor of tissue Plasminogen activator (i.e. activates tPA and therefore increases plasmin)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>188
The text of medical physiology of science</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Hepatitis</p>
</li>

<li>
<p>Found in the granules of most cells and basophils</p>

<p>130
The role of natural physiology in cancer</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Fibrin, plasmin and FDFs</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fibrin adsorbs some clotting factors and this prevents propagation of the clq within the blood vessel.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Plasmin breaks down fibrin resulting in dissolution of clots.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fibrin degradation products (FDFs) also inhibit coagulation (by inhibiting thrombin).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Synthetic anticoagulants</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Vitamin K antagonists</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For example warfarin (Coumarin derivative)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This interferes with the action of vitamin K that's needed for synthesis of the following clotting factors in the liver (1972): Factor II (prothrombin) (2), factor Vβ (7), factor IX (9) and factor X (10).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Warfarin is the only anticoagulant that can be taken orally. It is used for prevention of thrombosis and embolism.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Warfarin interacts with many drugs that may potentiate or inhibit its effects (e.g. aspirin) that's why drugs taken with it should be revised.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Warfarin therapy should be monitored by testing the INR (International Normalized Ratio). This is calculated from prothrombin time (PT) as follows:
INR = (PT lossPT control)²⁵, (where ID is the international sensitivity index. ID equals 1 when the tissue factor used in the laboratory compares well with the international reference tissue factor).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Very important notes to remember:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Effects of warfarin start to appear 3 days after initiating therapy. That's because warfarin acts through inhibiting synthesis of vitamin K dependent clotting factors in the liver, but factors already present in blood continue to act during the first few days.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In addition to this delay in action, coagulation tendency is sometimes increased when starting warfarin therapy, rather than decreased! That's</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fibrin, plasmin and FDFs</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fibrin adsorbs some clotting factors and this prevents propagation of the clq within the blood vessel.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Plasmin breaks down fibrin resulting in dissolution of clots.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fibrin degradation products (FDFs) also inhibit coagulation (by inhibiting thrombin).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Synthetic anticoagulants</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Vitamin K antagonists</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For example warfarin (Coumarin derivative)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This interferes with the action of vitamin K that's needed for synthesis of the following clotting factors in the liver (1972): Factor II (prothrombin) (2), factor Vβ (7), factor IX (9) and factor X (10).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Warfarin is the only anticoagulant that can be taken orally. It is used for prevention of thrombosis and embolism.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Warfarin interacts with many drugs that may potentiate or inhibit its effects (e.g. aspirin) that's why drugs taken with it should be revised.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Warfarin therapy should be monitored by testing the INR (International Normalized Ratio). This is calculated from prothrombin time (PT) as follows:
INR = (PT lossPT control)²⁵, (where ID is the international sensitivity index. ID equals 1 when the tissue factor used in the laboratory compares well with the international reference tissue factor).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Very important notes to remember:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Effects of warfarin start to appear 3 days after initiating therapy. That's because warfarin acts through inhibiting synthesis of vitamin K dependent clotting factors in the liver, but factors already present in blood continue to act during the first few days.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In addition to this delay in action, coagulation tendency is sometimes increased when starting warfarin therapy, rather than decreased! That's</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fibrin, plasmin and FDFs</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fibrin adsorbs some clotting factors and this prevents propagation of the clq within the blood vessel.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Plasmin breaks down fibrin resulting in dissolution of clots.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fibrin degradation products (FDFs) also inhibit coagulation (by inhibiting thrombin).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Synthetic anticoagulants</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Vitamin K antagonists</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For example warfarin (Coumarin derivative)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This interferes with the action of vitamin K that's needed for synthesis of the following clotting factors in the liver (1972): Factor II (prothrombin) (2), factor Vβ (7), factor IX (9) and factor X (10).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Warfarin is the only anticoagulant that can be taken orally. It is used for prevention of thrombosis and embolism.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Warfarin interacts with many drugs that may potentiate or inhibit its effects (e.g. aspirin) that's why drugs taken with it should be revised.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Warfarin therapy should be monitored by testing the INR (International Normalized Ratio). This is calculated from prothrombin time (PT) as follows:
INR = (PT lossPT control)²⁵, (where ID is the international sensitivity index. ID equals 1 when the tissue factor used in the laboratory compares well with the international reference tissue factor).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Very important notes to remember:</p>
<ul>
<li>Effects of warfarin start to appear 3 days after initiating therapy. That's because warfarin acts through inhibiting synthesis of vitamin K dependent clotting factors in the liver, but factors already present in blood continue to act during the first few days.</li>
<li>In addition to this delay in action, coagulation tendency is sometimes increased when starting warfarin therapy, rather than decreased! That's</li>
</ul>
<p>131
The role of natural physiology in cancer</p>
<p>because warfarin inhibits activity of protein C &amp; protein S (anticoagulants) which are also vitamin K dependent factors.</p>
<p>Therefore, the best way to anti-coagulate the patient during this period is to give heparin together with warfarin when starting treatment and to monitor warfarin effects with INR, then stop heparin and continue with warfarin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="calcium-chelating-agents">Calcium chelating agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calcium-chelating-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These include: oxalate, citrate and EDTA.</p>
<p>They bind calcium and make it unavailable for coagulation.</p>
<p>Not used in vivo because they may decrease calcium concentration in the plasma and cause tetany.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="remember-that">Remember that<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remember-that" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Anticoagulants used only in vitro: Calcium chelating agents</li>
<li>Anticoagulants used only in vivo: Vitamin K antagonists</li>
<li>Anticoagulants used in vitro and in vivo: Heparin</li>
</ul>
<p>because warfarin inhibits activity of protein C &amp; protein S (anticoagulants) which are also vitamin K dependent factors.</p>
<p>Therefore, the best way to anti-coagulate the patient during this period is to give heparin together with warfarin when starting treatment and to monitor warfarin effects with INR, then stop heparin and continue with warfarin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="calcium-chelating-agents">Calcium chelating agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calcium-chelating-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<p>They bind calcium and make it unavailable for coagulation.</p>
<p>Not used in vivo because they may decrease calcium concentration in the plasma and cause tetany.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="tests-for-hebos1975-0">TESTS FOR HEBOS1975/0<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tests-for-hebos1975-0" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bleeding-time-bt">Bleeding time (BT)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bleeding-time-bt" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A test for platelets because it is done by causing small hole in a blood vessel (a pinprick at the lobe of the ear or the anterior surface of the forearm, using a tensor).</li>
<li>Normally takes 1-7 minutes.</li>
<li>It is prolonged in the following conditions:</li>
<li>Thrombocytopenia</li>
<li>Thromboasthenia</li>
<li>Von Willebrand disease</li>
<li>Vitamin C deficiency</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clotting-time">Clotting time<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clotting-time" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A test for the clotting factors of the intrinsic pathway or common pathway (because it involves collection of blood in a test tube and then initiation of coagulation by contact of blood with glass).</li>
<li>Normally takes less than 10 minutes.</li>
<li>It is prolonged in the following conditions:</li>
<li>Hemophilia</li>
<li>von Willebrand disease</li>
<li>Vitamin K deficiency</li>
<li>Chronic liver disease</li>
<li>Alterinogenaemia</li>
<li>Obstructive jaundice</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="prothrombin-time-pt">Prothrombin time (PT)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#prothrombin-time-pt" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A test for the clotting factors of the extrinsic pathway because blood is collected in a tube containing citrate to remove Ca²⁺, then Ca²⁺ &amp; thromboplastin are added to allow blood to clot (in extrinsic pathway).</li>
<li>Normally takes 12-15 seconds.</li>
<li>It is prolonged in the following conditions:</li>
</ul>
<p>143
The text of medical physiology 4th edition</p>
