The view of medical psychology of science</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="examples-of-bleeding-tendencies">EXAMPLES OF BLEEDING TENDENCIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples-of-bleeding-tendencies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="dermatitis">Dermatitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dermatitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs due to deficiency of:</li>
<li>Factor VIII (hemophilia A, classical, 85% of cases)</li>
<li>Factor IX (hemophilia B, less common, 15% of cases, also known as Christmas disease)</li>
<li>Inherited as X-linked recessive (therefore it is more common in males)</li>
<li>Characterized by normal BT and prolonged clotting time and aPTT.</li>
<li>Treatment: factor VIII injections or fresh frozen plasma or blood.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="von-willebrand-disease">Von Willebrand disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#von-willebrand-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>cMIF is a glycoprotein produced by endothelial cells and megakaryocytes.</li>
<li>It is needed for stabilization of factor VIII and for attachment of platelets to collagen.</li>
<li>Congenital deficiency of this factor causes bleeding tendency with prolonged bleeding time and clotting time.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="afforringements">Afforringements<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#afforringements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Deficiency of fibrinogen may be congenital (since birth), or acquired later in life by a disease (e.g. placental abruption during pregnancy results in clotting of blood behind the placenta. This consumes fibrinogen and causes its deficiency).</li>
<li>Characterized by prolonged clotting time and prothrombin time, however, the base test is thrombin time (TT) which gives information about availability of fibrinogen.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chronic-liver-diseases">Chronic liver diseases<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chronic-liver-diseases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Impairs synthesis of the clotting factors which are synthesized in the liver.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="obstructive-jaundice">Obstructive jaundice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#obstructive-jaundice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>175
The view of medical psychology of science</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="examples-of-bleeding-tendencies">EXAMPLES OF BLEEDING TENDENCIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples-of-bleeding-tendencies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="dermatitis">Dermatitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dermatitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs due to deficiency of:</li>
<li>Factor VIII (hemophilia A, classical, 85% of cases)</li>
<li>Factor IX (hemophilia B, less common, 15% of cases, also known as Christmas disease)</li>
<li>Inherited as X-linked recessive (therefore it is more common in males)</li>
<li>Characterized by normal BT and prolonged clotting time and aPTT.</li>
<li>Treatment: factor VIII injections or fresh frozen plasma or blood.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="von-willebrand-disease">Von Willebrand disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#von-willebrand-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>cMIF is a glycoprotein produced by endothelial cells and megakaryocytes.</li>
<li>It is needed for stabilization of factor VIII and for attachment of platelets to collagen.</li>
<li>Congenital deficiency of this factor causes bleeding tendency with prolonged bleeding time and clotting time.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="afforringements">Afforringements<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#afforringements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Deficiency of fibrinogen may be congenital (since birth), or acquired later in life by a disease (e.g. placental abruption during pregnancy results in clotting of blood behind the placenta. This consumes fibrinogen and causes its deficiency).</li>
<li>Characterized by prolonged clotting time and prothrombin time; however, the base test is thrombin time (TT) which gives information about availability of fibrinogen.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chronic-liver-diseases">Chronic liver diseases<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chronic-liver-diseases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Impairs synthesis of the clotting factors which are synthesized in the liver.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="obstructive-jaundice">Obstructive jaundice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#obstructive-jaundice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>176
The view of medical psychology of science</p>
<ul>
<li>Impairs absorption of vitamin K, which is a fat soluble vitamin that needs bile for its absorption from the intestine.</li>
<li>Vitamin K is needed for synthesis of clotting factors the E, Vit, W and X (1972). Therefore obstructive jaundice causes deficiency of these factors. For this reason, patients with obstructive jaundice should receive vitamin K injections daily for 5 days before surgery.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="examples-of-clotting-tendencies-thrombosis">Examples of clotting tendencies (thrombosis):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples-of-clotting-tendencies-thrombosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="due-to-congenital-problems">- Due to congenital problems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#due-to-congenital-problems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Deficiency of protein C, protein S or antithrombin III</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="due-to-atherosclerotic-blood-vessels">- Due to atherosclerotic blood vessels<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#due-to-atherosclerotic-blood-vessels" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Atherosclerosis may be complicated by complete occlusion of a blood vessel.</li>
<li>It is predisposed by systemic diseases like diabetes and hypertension.</li>
<li>Most dangerous at the coronary, renal and cerebral arteries</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="due-to-abugglish-blood-flow">- Due to abugglish blood flow<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#due-to-abugglish-blood-flow" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Follows prolonged periods of bed ridden (e.g. due to operations, delivery or fractures).</li>
<li>May be complicated by detachment of the clots (embolization).</li>
<li>A large embolus detached from a lower limb vein that obstructs the pulmonary artery usually causes immediate death.</li>
<li>This is known as pulmonary embolism.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="due-to-wide-spread-deposition-of-fibrin-in-the-circulation">- Due to wide spread deposition of fibrin in the circulation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#due-to-wide-spread-deposition-of-fibrin-in-the-circulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>This is known as disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is caused by septicemia, disseminated cancers or massive tissue injuries. These stimulate formation of multiple clots within the intravascular space.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The clots consume the clotting factors and therefore patients bleed from the skin, GIT and respiratory tract ... (usually fatal).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Impairs absorption of vitamin K, which is a fat soluble vitamin that needs bile for its absorption from the intestine.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Vitamin K is needed for synthesis of clotting factors the E, Vit, W and X (1972). Therefore obstructive jaundice causes deficiency of these factors. For this reason, patients with obstructive jaundice should receive vitamin K injections daily for 5 days before surgery.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="examples-of-clotting-tendencies-thrombosis">Examples of clotting tendencies (thrombosis):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples-of-clotting-tendencies-thrombosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="due-to-congenital-problems">- Due to congenital problems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#due-to-congenital-problems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Deficiency of protein C, protein S or antithrombin III</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="due-to-atherosclerotic-blood-vessels">- Due to atherosclerotic blood vessels<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#due-to-atherosclerotic-blood-vessels" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Atherosclerosis may be complicated by complete occlusion of a blood vessel.</li>
<li>It is predisposed by systemic diseases like diabetes and hypertension.</li>
<li>Most dangerous at the coronary, renal and cerebral arteries</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="due-to-abugglish-blood-flow">- Due to abugglish blood flow<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#due-to-abugglish-blood-flow" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Follows prolonged periods of bed ridden (e.g. due to operations, delivery or fractures).</li>
<li>May be complicated by detachment of the clots (embolization).</li>
<li>A large embolus detached from a lower limb vein that obstructs the pulmonary artery usually causes immediate death.</li>
<li>This is known as pulmonary embolism.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="due-to-wide-spread-deposition-of-fibrin-in-the-circulation">- Due to wide spread deposition of fibrin in the circulation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#due-to-wide-spread-deposition-of-fibrin-in-the-circulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>This is known as disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is caused by septicemia, disseminated cancers or massive tissue injuries. These stimulate formation of multiple clots within the intravascular space.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The clots consume the clotting factors and therefore patients bleed from the skin, GIT and respiratory tract ... (usually fatal).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Impairs absorption of vitamin K, which is a fat soluble vitamin that needs bile for its absorption from the intestine.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Vitamin K is needed for synthesis of clotting factors the E, Vit, W and X (1972). Therefore obstructive jaundice causes deficiency of these factors. For this reason, patients with obstructive jaundice should receive vitamin K injections daily for 5 days before surgery.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="examples-of-clotting-tendencies-thrombosis">Examples of clotting tendencies (thrombosis):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples-of-clotting-tendencies-thrombosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="due-to-congenital-problems">- Due to congenital problems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#due-to-congenital-problems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Deficiency of protein C, protein S or antithrombin III</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="due-to-atherosclerotic-blood-vessels">- Due to atherosclerotic blood vessels<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#due-to-atherosclerotic-blood-vessels" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Atherosclerosis may be complicated by complete occlusion of a blood vessel.</li>
<li>It is predisposed by systemic diseases like diabetes and hypertension.</li>
<li>Most dangerous at the coronary, renal and cerebral arteries</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="due-to-abugglish-blood-flow">- Due to abugglish blood flow<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#due-to-abugglish-blood-flow" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Follows prolonged periods of bed ridden (e.g. due to operations, delivery or fractures).</li>
<li>May be complicated by detachment of the clots (embolization).</li>
<li>A large embolus detached from a lower limb vein that obstructs the pulmonary artery usually causes immediate death.</li>
<li>This is known as pulmonary embolism.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="due-to-wide-spread-deposition-of-fibrin-in-the-circulation">- Due to wide spread deposition of fibrin in the circulation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#due-to-wide-spread-deposition-of-fibrin-in-the-circulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>This is known as disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).</li>
<li>It is caused by septicemia, disseminated cancers or massive tissue injuries. These stimulate formation of multiple clots within the intravascular space.</li>
<li>The clots consume the clotting factors and therefore patients bleed from the skin, GIT and respiratory tract ... (usually fatal).</li>
</ul>
<p>The work of medical physiology of medicine</p>
<p>The work of medical physiology of medicine</p>
<p>PLASMA</p>
<ul>
<li>The fluid part of the blood</li>
<li>Volume</li>
<li>About 5% of total body weight in a 70 kg adult male (&lt; 3.5 L)</li>
<li>Contents</li>
<li>Water (&lt; 90%)</li>
<li>Inorganic substances (minerals, electrolytes ...)</li>
<li>Organic substances (proteins, glucose, fats, bilirubin, urea ...)</li>
<li>Plasma proteins</li>
<li>Types:</li>
<li>Albumin</li>
<li>Globuline (α, β and γ)</li>
<li>Fibrinogen</li>
<li>Synthesis</li>
<li>The liver (synthesizes most plasma proteins)</li>
<li>Plasma cells (Synthesizes gamma globuline which are not synthesized by the liver (also known as immunoglobulins or antibodies)</li>
<li>Concentration:</li>
<li>Total = 6.6 g/dL</li>
<li>Albumin: 3.5-6 g/dL</li>
<li>Globuline (α, β and γ): 2.3 g/dL</li>
<li>Fibrinogen: 0.3 g/dL</li>
<li>Functions:</li>
<li>Directly pressure (albumin because its particles are smaller and larger in number than other types of plasma proteins)</li>
<li>Viscosity of blood (globuline and fibrinogens because of the asymmetrical shape and large size of their particles)</li>
<li>Clotting (fibrinogen and some globulins- most clotting factors are beta globulins but prothrombin is an alpha globulin)</li>
</ul>
<p>The text of medical physiology is "where</p>

<p>QUESTIONS FOR SELF ASSASSINANT A (SEAT OF FIVE)</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>The intrinsic pathway of blood coagulation:
a. Is triggered by contact of factor X with collagen
b. Is faster than the extrinsic pathway
c. utilizes 50% of the clotting factors present in the blood
d. requires tissue thromboplasm for its activation
e. is never completed in the absence of Ca++</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Platelets:
a. are non nucleated bicornavie cells
b. arise from megakaryocytes in the bone marrow
c. always stop bleeding
d. their count is higher than red blood cells
e. their size is larger than white blood cells</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A child whose both father &amp; mother are group B-positive may be:
a. blood group A positive
b. blood group A negative
c. blood group AB positive
d. blood group C negative
e. blood group AB negative</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Vitamin K deficiency causes low production of factor:
a. 1
b. 1/2
c. 1/2
d. 21
e. 22</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Prolonged clotting time is found in all the following except:
a. heparin therapy
b. vitamin K re-positive
c. congenital athero-gyneemia
d. thrombo-plasmia
e. chronic liver disease</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The following is not a function of thrombin:
a. breakdown of fibrinogen
b. activation of protein C
c. activation of factor VIII
d. activation of plasminogen
e. activation of factor XI</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The following is not a primary function of globulins:
a. blood coagulation
b. transport of iron
c. immunity
d. critical osmotic pressure
e. blood viscosity</p>
</li>
</ol>

Document of Medical Miscarriages of Taiwan</p>
<ol start="8">
<li>
<p>A woman who is blood group O 6b -ve:
a. has no any antigens on surface of RBCs
b. has anti-A, anti-B and anti-D antibodies in plasma
c. acts as a universal donor
d. can never have a Fescar +ve child
e. usually gives birth to a pro-ribose baby</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The following statement about the extrinsic pathway is not true:
a. it is triggered by tissue trauma
b. it involves factor II
c. it requires calcium ions
d. it is prolonged in haemophilia
e. it is normal in non-bifidermal disease</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The following anticoagulant acts "in vitro" and "in vivo":
a. heparin
b. warfarin
c. thrombomodulin
d. EDTA
e. citrate</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Blinding tendency commonly occurs due to all the following except:
a. warfarin therapy
b. otorhinolide, prindase
c. hyponatraemia
d. thrombotrauma
e. chronic liver disease</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The following is not transported by plasma proteins
a. iron
b. oxygen
c. carbon dioxide
d. bilirubin
e. thyroxine</p>
</li>

<p>This factor is not activated through the intrinsic pathway?
a. I
b. II
c. III
d. IVE
e. VIE</p>
</li>

a. Unknown
b. Streptokinase
c. Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA)
d. thromboplastin
e. thrombos</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>All the following are natural anticoagulant except:
a. thrombosoma A2</p>
</li>

<p><strong>16. Hemophilia is:</strong>
a. more common in males than females
b. due to congenital deficiency of Hageman factor
c. characterized by normal bleeding time
d. characterized by low level of vWF
e. diagnosed when the INR is higher than normal</p>
<p><strong>17. Anti-thrombin III:</strong>
a. is a beta globulin
b. activity is inhibited by heparin
c. is similar in structure to alpha 2 macroglobulin
d. deficiency causes bleeding tendency
e. level in plasma is decreased by warfarin</p>

<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<p>CHAPTER 1</p>
<p>THE CARDIOVASCULAR SYSTEM</p>
<p>THE CARDIAC MUSCLE</p>
<p>Fig 8.1. The heart</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-f88156ec.jpeg" alt="img-207.jpeg"></p>
<p>Human heart consists of:</p>
<ul>
<li>4 chambers</li>
<li>2 area (thin walled, receive blood from major veins and allow it to fill the ventricles)</li>
<li>2 ventricles (thick walled, pump blood to pulmonary and systemic circulation)</li>
<li>4 valves</li>
<li>2 Atrio-ventricular valves (AV valves)</li>
<li>Mitral (left) and Tricuspid (right)</li>
<li>2 Semilunar valves</li>
<li>Aortic (left) and Pulmonary (right)</li>
</ul>
<p>301</p>
<p>The heart of medical physiology 4th edition</p>
<p>CHAPTER 1</p>
<p>THE CARDIOVASCULAR SYSTEM</p>
<p>THE CARDIAC MUSCLE</p>
<p>Fig 8.1. The heart</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-018bc663.jpeg" alt="img-208.jpeg"></p>
<p>Human heart consists of:</p>
<ul>
<li>4 chambers</li>
<li>2 area (thin walled, receive blood from major veins and allow it to fill the ventricles)</li>
<li>2 ventricles (thick walled, pump blood to pulmonary and systemic circulation)</li>
<li>4 valves</li>
<li>2 Atrio-ventricular valves (AV valves)</li>
<li>Mitral (left) and Tricuspid (right)</li>
<li>2 Semilunar valves</li>
<li>Aortic (left) and Pulmonary (right)</li>
</ul>
<p>302</p>
<p>The heart of medical physiology 4th edition</p>
<p>CHAPTER 1</p>
<p>THE CARDIOVASCULAR SYSTEM</p>
<p>THE CARDIAC MUSCLE</p>
<p>Fig 8.1. The heart</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-4f4de772.jpeg" alt="img-209.jpeg"></p>
<p>Human heart consists of:</p>
<ul>
<li>4 chambers</li>
<li>2 area (thin walled, receive blood from major veins and allow it to fill the ventricles)</li>
<li>2 ventricles (thick walled, pump blood to pulmonary and systemic circulation)</li>
<li>4 valves</li>
<li>2 Atrio-ventricular valves (AV valves)</li>
<li>Mitral (left) and Tricuspid (right)</li>
<li>2 Semilunar valves</li>
<li>Aortic (left) and Pulmonary (right)</li>
</ul>
<p>342
The costs of medical jobs ecologic / 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="properties-of-the-cardiac-muscle">Properties of the cardiac muscle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#properties-of-the-cardiac-muscle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The cardiac muscle contains ten types of muscle fiber:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Cardiac muscle proper</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Conclusive system</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If two special properties that characterize it from other types of muscles, these properties include:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>The histology of the cardiac muscle</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Unlike skeletal muscle, there are anatomical connections between the myocardial fibers (intercalated discs and gap junctions) and unlike smooth muscle, the cardiac muscle is situated.</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 6.2: The muscle differences in histology</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>SkeletalMuscle</th><th>Cardiac Muscle</th><th>Smooth Muscle</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td></tr><tr><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td></tr><tr><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td></tr><tr><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td></tr><tr><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="2">
<li>Functional syncytium</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Stimulation of one cardiac muscle cell results in stimulation of all the cells. This occurs due to presence of gap junctions &amp; intercalated discs between the fibers (which are areas of low electrical resistance that allow movement of ions and therefore transmission of action potential easily between cells).</li>
<li>Therefore, the heart contracts as one unit (as a syncytium which is multiple cells grouped together as one unit within a common cell membrane forming a single multi-nucleated cell).</li>
<li>Remember that the heart is not an anatomical syncytium but it is a functional syncytium.</li>
</ul>
<p>343
The costs of medical jobs ecologic / 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="properties-of-the-cardiac-muscle">Properties of the cardiac muscle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#properties-of-the-cardiac-muscle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The cardiac muscle contains two types of muscle fiber:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Cardiac muscle proper</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Conclusive system</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If two special properties that characterize it from other types of muscles, these properties include:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>The histology of the cardiac muscle</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Unlike skeletal muscle, there are anatomical connections between the myocardial fibers (intercalated discs and gap junctions) and unlike smooth muscle, the cardiac muscle is situated.</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 6.2: The muscle differences in histology</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>SkeletalMuscle</th><th>Cardiac Muscle</th><th>Smooth Muscle</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td></tr><tr><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td></tr><tr><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td></tr><tr><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td></tr><tr><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="2">
<li>Functional syncytium</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Stimulation of one cardiac muscle cell results in stimulation of all the cells. This occurs due to presence of gap junctions &amp; intercalated discs between the fibers (which are areas of low electrical resistance that allow movement of ions and therefore transmission of action potential easily between cells).</li>
<li>Therefore, the heart contracts as one unit (as a syncytium which is multiple cells grouped together as one unit within a common cell membrane forming a single multi-nucleated cell).</li>
<li>Remember that the heart is not an anatomical syncytium but it is a functional syncytium.</li>
</ul>
<p>342
The costs of medical jobs ecologic / 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="properties-of-the-cardiac-muscle">Properties of the cardiac muscle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#properties-of-the-cardiac-muscle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The cardiac muscle contains two types of muscle fiber:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Cardiac muscle proper</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Conclusive system</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If two special properties that characterize it from other types of muscles, these properties include:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>The histology of the cardiac muscle</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Unlike skeletal muscle, there are anatomical connections between the myocardial fibers (intercalated discs and gap junctions) and unlike smooth muscle, the cardiac muscle is situated.</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 6.2: The muscle differences in histology</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>SkeletalMuscle</th><th>Cardiac Muscle</th><th>Smooth Muscle</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>3</td></tr><tr><td>2</td><td>3</td><td>4</td></tr><tr><td>3</td><td>4</td><td>5</td></tr><tr><td>4</td><td>5</td><td>6</td></tr><tr><td>5</td><td>6</td><td>7</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Fig 6.2: The cardiac muscle histology</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-81d74bba.jpeg" alt="img-210.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="3-the-main-source-of-energy">3. The main source of energy.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-the-main-source-of-energy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The cardiac muscle consumes fat as the main source of energy. Under basal conditions, 60% of the caloric needs are provided by free fatty acids, 35% by carbohydrates and 5% by ketones and amino acids.</p>
<ul>
<li>On the other hand, skeletal muscles utilize carbohydrates as the main source of energy, especially during exercise.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="4-blood-flow-supply">4. Blood flow (supply)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-blood-flow-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The cardiac muscle receives its blood supply nearly during diastole (unlike skeletal muscles which receive their blood supply nearly during systole).</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The left ventricle receives its blood supply during the diastolic phase only whereas the right ventricle receives its blood supply during both systole &amp; diastole.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This is explained by many physiological &amp; anatomical mechanisms.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Physiological explanation: During systole, aortic pressure—120 mmHg, left ventricular pressure—120 mmHg and right ventricular pressure—25 mmHg; therefore blood flows from the aorta through the right coronary artery but not the left one. On the other hand, during diastole, aortic pressure—80 mmHg, left ventricular pressure—0 mmHg and right ventricular pressure—0 mmHg; therefore blood flows from the aorta through both right and left coronary arteries.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Anatomical explanation: during systole, leaflets of the aortic valve obstruct openings (sinuses) of coronary arteries.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 6.2: The cardiac muscle histology</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-4ec2ffb6.jpeg" alt="img-211.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="3-the-main-source-of-energy">3. The main source of energy.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-the-main-source-of-energy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The cardiac muscle consumes fat as the main source of energy. Under basal conditions, 60% of the caloric needs are provided by free fatty acids, 35% by carbohydrates and 5% by ketones and amino acids.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>On the other hand, skeletal muscles utilize carbohydrates as the main source of energy, especially during exercise.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="4-blood-flow-supply">4. Blood flow (supply)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-blood-flow-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The cardiac muscle receives its blood supply nearly during diastole (unlike skeletal muscles which receive their blood supply nearly during systole).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The left ventricle receives its blood supply during the diastolic phase only whereas the right ventricle receives its blood supply during both systole &amp; diastole.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This is explained by many physiological &amp; anatomical mechanisms.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Physiological explanation: During systole, aortic pressure—120 mmHg, left ventricular pressure—120 mmHg and right ventricular pressure—25 mmHg; therefore blood flows from the aorta through the right coronary artery but not the left one. On the other hand, during diastole, aortic pressure—80 mmHg, left ventricular pressure—0 mmHg and right ventricular pressure—0 mmHg; therefore blood flows from the aorta through both right and left coronary arteries.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Anatomical explanation: during systole, leaflets of the aortic valve obstruct openings (sinuses) of coronary arteries.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 6.3: The cardiac muscle histology</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-4a5ead5c.jpeg" alt="img-212.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="3-the-main-source-of-energy">3. The main source of energy.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-the-main-source-of-energy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The cardiac muscle consumes fat as the main source of energy. Under basal conditions, 60% of the caloric needs are provided by free fatty acids, 35% by carbohydrates and 5% by ketones and amino acids.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>On the other hand, skeletal muscles utilize carbohydrates as the main source of energy, especially during exercise.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="4-blood-flow-supply">4. Blood flow (supply)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-blood-flow-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The cardiac muscle receives its blood supply nearly during diastole (unlike skeletal muscles which receive their blood supply nearly during systole).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The left ventricle receives its blood supply during the diastolic phase only whereas the right ventricle receives its blood supply during both systole &amp; diastole.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This is explained by many physiological &amp; anatomical mechanisms.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Physiological explanation: During systole, aortic pressure—120 mmHg, left ventricular pressure—120 mmHg and right ventricular pressure—25 mmHg; therefore blood flows from the aorta through the right coronary artery but not the left one. On the other hand, during diastole, aortic pressure—80 mmHg, left ventricular pressure—0 mmHg and right ventricular pressure—0 mmHg; therefore blood flows from the aorta through both right and left coronary arteries.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Anatomical explanation: during systole, leaflets of the aortic valve obstruct openings (sinuses) of coronary arteries.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>301</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="5-oxygen-extraction">5. Oxygen extraction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-oxygen-extraction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>At basal conditions, the cardiac muscle extracts higher amount of oxygen than skeletal muscle. It consumes about 9 mL CO₂ 100 g (tossachinide). This is approximately about 70-80% of the oxygen delivered by each unit of blood.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="6-metabolism">6. Metabolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-metabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The cardiac muscle depends on aerobic metabolism for generation of energy. Anaerobic metabolism provides less than 1% of the total energy. This figure may increase slightly during hypoxic states; however, there is no oxygen debt mechanism (obstruction of the coronary artery reduces oxygen delivery to the cardiac muscle and results in its necrosis and death). On the other hand, skeletal muscle depends on both aerobic &amp; anaerobic metabolism for generation of energy, and there is oxygen debt mechanism (oxygen debt is the extra amount of oxygen consumed after exercise to repay oxygen taken from myoglobin &amp; to get rid of lactate accumulating in muscle.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="7-electrical-activity-action-potential">7. Electrical activity (action potential)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-electrical-activity-action-potential" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Action potential of the cardiac muscle proper is characterized by the plateau phase (due to calcium influx), and that of the conductive system is characterized by the prepotential (see below). Theses phases are not found in action potentials of other types of muscles.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-3ccb4a37.jpeg" alt="img-213.jpeg">
Fig 5.4. Actions potentials in the cardiac muscle</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="6-oxygen-extraction">6. Oxygen extraction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-oxygen-extraction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>At basal conditions, the cardiac muscle extracts higher amount of oxygen than skeletal muscle. It consumes about 9 mL CO₂ 100 g (tossachinide). This is approximately about 70-80% of the oxygen delivered by each unit of blood.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="6-metabolism">6. Metabolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-metabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The cardiac muscle depends on aerobic metabolism for generation of energy. Anaerobic metabolism provides less than 1% of the total energy. This figure may increase slightly during hypoxic states; however, there is no oxygen debt mechanism (obstruction of the coronary artery reduces oxygen delivery to the cardiac muscle and results in its necrosis and death). On the other hand, skeletal muscle depends on both aerobic &amp; anaerobic metabolism for generation of energy, and there is oxygen debt mechanism (oxygen debt is the extra amount of oxygen consumed after exercise to repay oxygen taken from myoglobin &amp; to get rid of lactate accumulating in muscle.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="7-electrical-activity-action-potential">7. Electrical activity (action potential)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-electrical-activity-action-potential" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Action potential of the cardiac muscle proper is characterized by the plateau phase (due to calcium influx), and that of the conductive system is characterized by the prepotential (see below). Theses phases are not found in action potentials of other types of muscles.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-901c4de5.jpeg" alt="img-214.jpeg">
Fig 5.4. Actions potentials in the cardiac muscle</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="8-oxygen-extraction">8. Oxygen extraction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8-oxygen-extraction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>At basal conditions, the cardiac muscle extracts higher amount of oxygen than skeletal muscle. It consumes about 9 mL CO₂ 100 g (tossachinide). This is approximately about 70-80% of the oxygen delivered by each unit of blood.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="8-metabolism">8. Metabolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8-metabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The cardiac muscle depends on aerobic metabolism for generation of energy. Anaerobic metabolism provides less than 1% of the total energy. This figure may increase slightly during hypoxic states; however, there is no oxygen debt mechanism (obstruction of the coronary artery reduces oxygen delivery to the cardiac muscle and results in its necrosis and death). On the other hand, skeletal muscle depends on both aerobic &amp; anaerobic metabolism for generation of energy, and there is oxygen debt mechanism (oxygen debt is the extra amount of oxygen consumed after exercise to repay oxygen taken from myoglobin &amp; to get rid of lactate accumulating in muscle.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="7-electrical-activity-action-potential">7. Electrical activity (action potential)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-electrical-activity-action-potential" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Action potential of the cardiac muscle proper is characterized by the plateau phase (due to calcium influx), and that of the conductive system is characterized by the prepotential (see below). Theses phases are not found in action potentials of other types of muscles.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-63e4a22c.jpeg" alt="img-215.jpeg">
Fig 6.4. Actions potentials in the cardiac muscle</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="6-the-refractory-period">6 The refractory period<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-the-refractory-period" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>is prolonged in cardiac muscle (200-400 ms) due to presence of the plateau phase. This protects the heart from tetanus (summation of contractions during successive stimulation) and therefore allows the cardiac muscle to relax, because relaxation is essential for ventricular filling. The refractory period in platelet muscles is about 5-20 ms.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-6-2-the-refractory-periods-in-muscles">Fig 6.2: the refractory periods in muscles<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-6-2-the-refractory-periods-in-muscles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-94d6f2e9.jpeg" alt="img-216.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="6-ccf-calcium">6 CCF calcium:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-ccf-calcium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Contraction of the cardiac muscle depends on both ICF &amp; ECF calcium, whereas contraction of skeletal muscle depends on ICF calcium only. The T tubules in the cardiac muscle allow influx of calcium during action potentials to stimulate contraction. Therefore, increasing ECF calcium increases contractility in cardiac muscle and may stop the heart in systole.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="16-4-1-recruitment-in-cardiac-muscle">16.4.1: Recruitment in cardiac muscle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#16-4-1-recruitment-in-cardiac-muscle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Increasing strength of stimulation of skeletal muscles results in recruitment (i.e. it increases number of stimulated fibers) whereas in the cardiac muscle there is no recruitment (no increase in the number of stimulated fibers). That's because stimulation of one fiber in cardiac muscle results in stimulation of all the fibers.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="11-automobility">11. Automobility<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#11-automobility" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The various parts of the conductive system can discharge action potential spontaneously. This is explained by the prepotential phases that characterize</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-dca6bf6e.jpeg" alt="img-217.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="6-the-refractory-period">6 The refractory period<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-the-refractory-period" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>is prolonged in cardiac muscle (200-400 ms) due to presence of the plateau phase. This protects the heart from tetanus (summation of contractions during successive stimulation) and therefore allows the cardiac muscle to relax, because relaxation is essential for ventricular filling. The refractory period in platelet muscles is about 5-20 ms.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-6-2-the-refractory-periods-in-muscles">Fig 6.2: the refractory periods in muscles<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-6-2-the-refractory-periods-in-muscles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-c83a5da9.jpeg" alt="img-218.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="6-ccf-calcium">6 CCF calcium:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-ccf-calcium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Contraction of the cardiac muscle depends on both ICF &amp; ECF calcium, whereas contraction of skeletal muscle depends on ICF calcium only. The T tubules in the cardiac muscle allow influx of calcium during action potentials to stimulate contraction. Therefore, increasing ECF calcium increases contractility in cardiac muscle and may stop the heart in systole.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="16-4-1-recruitment-in-cardiac-muscle">16.4.1: Recruitment in cardiac muscle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#16-4-1-recruitment-in-cardiac-muscle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Increasing strength of stimulation of skeletal muscles results in recruitment (i.e. it increases number of stimulated fibers) whereas in the cardiac muscle there is no recruitment (no increase in the number of stimulated fibers). That's because stimulation of one fiber in cardiac muscle results in stimulation of all the fibers.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="11-automobility">11. Automobility<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#11-automobility" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The various parts of the conductive system can discharge action potential spontaneously. This is explained by the prepotential phases that characterize</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-c83a5da9.jpeg" alt="img-219.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="6-the-refractory-period">6 The refractory period<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-the-refractory-period" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>is prolonged in cardiac muscle (200-400 ms) due to presence of the plateau phase. This protects the heart from tetanus (summation of contractions during successive stimulation) and therefore allows the cardiac muscle to relax, because relaxation is essential for ventricular filling. The refractory period in platelet muscles is about 5-20 ms.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-6-2-the-refractory-periods-in-muscles">Fig 6.2: the refractory periods in muscles<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-6-2-the-refractory-periods-in-muscles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-c83a5da9.jpeg" alt="img-220.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="6-ccf-calcium">6. CCF calcium:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-ccf-calcium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Contraction of the cardiac muscle depends on both ICF &amp; ECF calcium, whereas contraction of skeletal muscle depends on ICF calcium only. The T tubules in the cardiac muscle allow influx of calcium during action potentials to stimulate contraction. Therefore, increasing ECF calcium increases contractility in cardiac muscle and may stop the heart in systole.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="16-4-1-recruitment-in-cardiac-muscle">16.4.1: Recruitment in cardiac muscle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#16-4-1-recruitment-in-cardiac-muscle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Increasing strength of stimulation of skeletal muscles results in recruitment (i.e. it increases number of stimulated fibers) whereas in the cardiac muscle there is no recruitment (no increase in the number of stimulated fibers). That's because stimulation of one fiber in cardiac muscle results in stimulation of all the fibers.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="11-automobility">11. Automobility<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#11-automobility" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The various parts of the conductive system can discharge action potential spontaneously. This is explained by the prepotential phases that characterize</li>
</ul>
<p>action potentials of the different structures of the conductive system. The conductive system has no resting membrane potential but gradual elevation of prepotential towards the threshold, see below). This results in spontaneous generation of action potentials by the conductive system (especially the first-atrial node). However, the cardiac muscle proper, which has no prepotential, has discharge action potentials spontaneously, but in abnormal conditions (e.g. ischemia). This is known as kilo-ventricular rhythm.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-rhythmicity">12-Rhythmicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-rhythmicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The cardiac muscle undergoes regular rhythmic contractions due to presence of the conductive system, which controls these rhythmic contractions whereas skeletal muscle cannot contract rhythmically.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="13-conductivity">13-Conductivity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#13-conductivity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This is again a characteristic of the conductive system, which generates rhythmic action potentials and conducts it to the whole parts of the cardiac muscle (see below).</li>
</ul>
<p>action potentials of the different structures of the conductive system. The conductive system has no resting membrane potential but gradual elevation of prepotential towards the threshold, see below). This results in spontaneous generation of action potentials by the conductive system (especially the first-atrial node). However, the cardiac muscle proper, which has no prepotential, has discharge action potentials spontaneously, but in abnormal conditions (e.g. ischemia). This is known as kilo-ventricular rhythm.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="13-rhythmicity">13-Rhythmicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#13-rhythmicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The cardiac muscle undergoes regular rhythmic contractions due to presence of the conductive system, which controls these rhythmic contractions whereas skeletal muscle cannot contract rhythmically.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="13-conductivity">13-Conductivity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#13-conductivity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This is again a characteristic of the conductive system, which generates rhythmic action potentials and conducts it to the whole parts of the cardiac muscle (see below).</li>
</ul>
<p>action potentials of the different structures of the conductive system. The conductive system has no resting membrane potential but gradual elevation of prepotential towards the threshold, see below). This results in spontaneous generation of action potentials by the conductive system (especially the first-atrial node). However, the cardiac muscle proper, which has no prepotential, has discharge action potentials spontaneously, but in abnormal conditions (e.g. ischemia). This is known as kilo-ventricular rhythm.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="13-rhythmicity">13-Rhythmicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#13-rhythmicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The cardiac muscle undergoes regular rhythmic contractions due to presence of the conductive system, which controls these rhythmic contractions whereas skeletal muscle cannot contract rhythmically.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="13-conductivity">13-Conductivity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#13-conductivity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This is again a characteristic of the conductive system, which generates rhythmic action potentials and conducts it to the whole parts of the cardiac muscle (see below).</li>
</ul>
<p>206 The Journal of Medical Physiology 1979</p>
<p>206 The Journal of Medical Physiology 1979</p>
<p>206 The Journal of Medical Physiology 1979</p>
<p>The conductive system</p>
<p>The conductive system is formed of cardiac muscle fibers that are less striated and lack definitive boundaries.</p>
<ul>
<li>4 consists of the following structures:</li>
<li>Sino-atrial node (SA node)</li>
<li>Atrio-ventricular node (AV node)</li>
<li>Intermodal atrial pathways</li>
<li>Bundle of His</li>
<li>2 Bundle branches (BB)</li>
<li>(1) Bundle branch (HNR)</li>
<li>(2) Bundle branch (LBR)</li>
<li>The left BB is divided into anterior &amp; posterior fascicles</li>
<li>Purkinje fibers</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-9aa8ad79.jpeg" alt="img-221.jpeg">
Fig 6.6: the conductive system</p>
<p>The conductive system</p>
<p>The conductive system is formed of cardiac muscle fibers that are less striated and lack definitive boundaries.</p>
<ul>
<li>4 consists of the following structures:</li>
<li>Sino-atrial node (SA node)</li>
<li>Atrio-ventricular node (AV node)</li>
<li>Intermodal atrial pathways</li>
<li>Bundle of His</li>
<li>2 Bundle branches (BB)</li>
<li>(1) Bundle branch (HBB)</li>
<li>(2) Bundle branch (LBB)</li>
<li>The left BB is divided into anterior &amp; posterior fascicles</li>
<li>Purkinje fibers</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-c9cf9818.jpeg" alt="img-222.jpeg">
Fig 6.6: the conductive system</p>

</ul>
