<p>108
The costs of electrical job changes - 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-also-atrial-node-sa-node">The also-atrial node (SA Node)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-also-atrial-node-sa-node" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The SA node is found in the right atrium, at the opening of the SVC.</li>
<li>It can discharge action potential spontaneously (the discharge probably originates from small rounded coils in the SA node called P coils).</li>
<li>It is supplied by sympathetic neurons from the right side (because it is developed from structures in the right side of the embryo). The sympathetic neurons increase its rate of discharge.</li>
<li>Similarly, it is supplied by parasympathetic neurons from the right vagus. The parasympathetic neurons decrease its rate of discharge.</li>
<li>Without innervation, its rate of discharge = 100/min, with innervation (symp &amp; parasymp) = 70/min. This indicates that the parasympathetic effect is more dominant than the sympathetic effect on the SA node.</li>
<li>The rate of discharge of the SA node is faster than other parts in the heart, e.g.: AV node (45 mm²) and Ventricles (15-28 mm²). That's why the SA node determines the heart rate (because it is the fastest). For this reason it is regarded as the cardiac pacemaker.</li>
<li>In action potential is characterized by the prepotential (gradual elevation of the membrane potential towards the threshold) due to low K⁺ efflux through the K⁺ leak channels (remember that potassium efflux generates the resting membrane potential). In addition to that, the prepotential is completed by some Ca²⁺ influx (through transient Ca²⁺ channels (1 channels)).</li>
<li>The depolarization phase is due to Ca²⁺ influx (through long lasting calcium channels (L channels)), with some sodium influx, whereas the repolarization phase is due to potassium efflux through the K⁺ voltage gated channels.</li>
<li>The sympathetic makes the prepotential more vertical and therefore increases heart rate whereas the parasympathetic makes the prepotential more horizontal and therefore decreases the heart rate.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-also-atrial-node-sa-node">The also-atrial node (SA Node)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-also-atrial-node-sa-node" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The SA node is found in the right atrium, at the opening of the SVC.</li>
<li>It can discharge action potential spontaneously (the discharge probably originates from small rounded coils in the SA node called P coils).</li>
<li>It is supplied by sympathetic neurons from the right side (because it is developed from structures in the right side of the embryo). The sympathetic neurons increase its rate of discharge.</li>
<li>Similarly, it is supplied by parasympathetic neurons from the right vagus. The parasympathetic neurons decrease its rate of discharge.</li>
<li>Without innervation, its rate of discharge = 100/min, with innervation (symp &amp; parasymp) = 70/min. This indicates that the parasympathetic effect is more dominant than the sympathetic effect on the SA node.</li>
<li>The rate of discharge of the SA node is faster than other parts in the heart, e.g.: AV node (45 mm²) and Ventricles (15-28 mm²). That's why the SA node determines the heart rate (because it is the fastest). For this reason it is regarded as the cardiac pacemaker.</li>
<li>In action potential is characterized by the prepotential (gradual elevation of the membrane potential towards the threshold) due to low K⁺ efflux through the K⁺ leak channels (remember that potassium efflux generates the resting membrane potential). In addition to that, the prepotential is completed by some Ca²⁺ influx (through transient Ca²⁺ channels (7 channels)).</li>
<li>The depolarization phase is due to Ca²⁺ influx (through long lasting calcium channels (L channels)), with some sodium influx; whereas the repolarization phase is due to potassium efflux through the K⁺ voltage gated channels.</li>
<li>The sympathetic makes the prepotential more vertical and therefore increases heart rate whereas the parasympathetic makes the prepotential more horizontal and therefore decreases the heart rate.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-also-atrial-node-sa-node">The also-atrial node (SA Node)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-also-atrial-node-sa-node" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The SA node is found in the right atrium, at the opening of the SVC.</li>
<li>It can discharge action potential spontaneously (the discharge probably originates from small rounded coils in the SA node called P coils).</li>
<li>It is supplied by sympathetic neurons from the right side (because it is developed from structures in the right side of the embryo). The sympathetic neurons increase its rate of discharge.</li>
<li>Similarly, it is supplied by parasympathetic neurons from the right vagus. The parasympathetic neurons decrease its rate of discharge.</li>
<li>Without innervation, its rate of discharge = 100/min, with innervation (symp &amp; parasymp) = 70/min. This indicates that the parasympathetic effect is more dominant than the sympathetic effect on the SA node.</li>
<li>The rate of discharge of the SA node is faster than other parts in the heart, e.g.: AV node (45 mm²) and Ventricles (15-28 mm²). That's why the SA node determines the heart rate (because it is the fastest). For this reason it is regarded as the cardiac pacemaker.</li>
<li>In action potential is characterized by the prepotential (gradual elevation of the membrane potential towards the threshold) due to low K⁺ efflux through the K⁺ leak channels (remember that potassium efflux generates the resting membrane potential). In addition to that, the prepotential is completed by some Ca²⁺ influx (through transient Ca²⁺ channels (1 channels)).</li>
<li>The depolarization phase is due to Ca²⁺ influx (through long lasting calcium channels (L channels)), with some sodium influx; whereas the repolarization phase is due to potassium efflux through the K⁺ voltage gated channels.</li>
<li>The sympathetic makes the prepotential more vertical and therefore increases heart rate whereas the parasympathetic makes the prepotential more horizontal and therefore decreases the heart rate.</li>
</ul>
<p>109
The costs of electrical job changes - 4th edition</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-3d48e768.jpeg" alt="img-224.jpeg">
Fig 6.7: Effects of neurons on the preprandial</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-8e4a81ec.jpeg" alt="img-225.jpeg">
Fig 6.7: Effects of neurons on the postprandial</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-av-node">The AV Node<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-av-node" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The AV node is found in the Rt atrium on the right side of inter-atrial septum, above the fibrous ring that separates atria from ventricles.</li>
<li>It delays conduction from atria to ventricles (because its muscle fibers have lower number of pas junctions and smaller diameter than the SA node).</li>
<li>This delay allows atrial contraction to precede ventricular contraction and therefore completes ventricular filling with blood.</li>
<li>When the SA node is diseased as in fibrosis of the SA node in old subjects (known as sick sinus syndrome), the AV node becomes the cardiac pacemaker. Here the heart rate decreases to about 45 beats/min.</li>
<li>When the AV node is damaged, ventricular rate becomes 15-20/min</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-e40e83a8.jpeg" alt="img-226.jpeg">
Fig 6.7: Effects of neurons on the preprandial</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-av-node">The AV Node<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-av-node" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The AV node is found in the Rt atrium on the right side of inter-atrial septum, above the fibrous ring that separates atria from ventricles.</li>
<li>It delays conduction from atria to ventricles (because its muscle fibers have lower number of pas junctions and smaller diameter than the SA node).</li>
<li>This delay allows atrial contraction to precede ventricular contraction and therefore completes ventricular filling with blood.</li>
<li>When the SA node is diseased as in fibrosis of the SA node in old subjects (known as sick sinus syndrome), the AV node becomes the cardiac pacemaker. Here the heart rate decreases to about 45 beats/min.</li>
<li>When the AV node is damaged, ventricular rate becomes 15-20/min</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-av-node">The AV Node<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-av-node" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The AV node is found in the Rt atrium on the right side of inter-atrial septum, above the fibrous ring that separates atria from ventricles.</li>
<li>It delays conduction from atria to ventricles (because its muscle fibers have lower number of pas junctions and smaller diameter than the SA node).</li>
<li>This delay allows atrial contraction to precede ventricular contraction and therefore comprises ventricular filling with blood.</li>
<li>When the SA node is diseased as in fibrosis of the SA node in old subjects (known as sick sinus syndrome), the AV node becomes the cardiac pacemaker. Here the heart rate decreases to about 45 beats/min.</li>
<li>When the AV node is damaged, ventricular rate becomes 15-20/min</li>
</ul>
<p>The Journal of Medical Physiology 10th edition</p>
<p>The Journal of Medical Physiology 10th edition</p>
<p>THE ELECTROCHEMICAL GROUP (ECG)</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>It is a record of the electrical activity of the head from the surface of the body using electrodes.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The record represents the sum of all action potentials of myocardial fibers at the time of recording as follows:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The sum of all atrial representations</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The sum of all atrial representations</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The sum of all ventricular representations</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The sum of all ventricular representations</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>All these events appear in the ECG as waves and intervals</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The waves are indicated by the letters p, q, r, s, t and sometimes u</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Methods of Recording</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The ECG is recorded by two types of recording:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>One active electrode = an inactive electrode (= unipolar recording)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Two active electrodes = an inactive electrode (= bipolar recording)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The inactive electrode is the reference electrode that gives the iso-electric line in the ECG; it is usually attached to the right foot</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The isoelectric line determines whether a wave is positive or negative.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A positive wave is that recorded above the isoelectric line whereas a negative wave is that recorded below it</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A current of depolarization or repolarization coming towards an active electrode produces a positive ECG wave whereas a current passing a way from an active electrode produces a negative wave.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The active electrodes are placed on the forearms, legs and chest, at different locations to detect abnormalities in different sites of the heart.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Abnormalities appear as changes in the normal configuration of the different waves and intervals in the ECG.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>THE ELECTROCHEMICAL GROUP</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>It is a record of the electrical activity of the heart from the surface of the body using electrodes.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The record represents the sum of all action potentials of myocardial fibers at the time of recording as follows:</p>
</li>

</li>
<li>

</li>

<p>The isoelectric line determines whether a wave is positive or negative.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A positive wave is that recorded above the isoelectric line whereas a negative wave is that recorded below it</p>

The rules of national processing / 1st edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-unipolar-leads">The unipolar leads<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-unipolar-leads" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>These are readings obtained by unipolar recording (i.e. each reading is recorded by one active electrode). They include:</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="limit-leads-recorded-by-electrodes-placed-on-the-linear">Limit leads (recorded by electrodes placed on the linear):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#limit-leads-recorded-by-electrodes-placed-on-the-linear" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>aWR (augmented vector of the right arm)</li>
<li>aWL (augmented vector of the left arm)</li>
<li>aWF (augmented vector of the left foot, remember that the reference electrode is placed on the right foot)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chest-leads-recorded-by-electrodes-placed-on-the-chest">Chest leads (recorded by electrodes placed on the chest):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chest-leads-recorded-by-electrodes-placed-on-the-chest" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>V1 (Vector of electrode placed on the 4th intercostal space to the right of the sternum)</li>
<li>V2 (Vector of electrode placed on the 4th intercostal space to the left of the sternum)</li>
<li>V3 (Vector of electrode placed midway between V3 &amp; V4)</li>
<li>V4 (Vector of electrode placed on the 5th intercostal space at the mid-cleander line)</li>
<li>V5 (Vector of electrode placed on the 5th intercostal space at the anterior axillary line)</li>
<li>V6 (Vector of electrode placed on the 5th intercostal space at the mid-axillary line)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-bipolar-leads">The bipolar leads<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-bipolar-leads" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Readings obtained by bipolar recording (2 active electrodes)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Include three limb leads (I, II &amp; III):</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Lead 'T' is recorded by two active electrodes placed on the right and left arms</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Lead 'If' is recorded by two active electrodes placed on the right arm &amp; the left foot</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Lead 'If' is recorded by two active electrodes placed on the left arm &amp; the left foot</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>212
The rules of national processing / 1st edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-unipolar-leads">The unipolar leads<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-unipolar-leads" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>These are readings obtained by unipolar recording (i.e. each reading is recorded by one active electrode). They include:</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="limit-leads-recorded-by-electrodes-placed-on-the-limbs">Limit leads (recorded by electrodes placed on the limbs):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#limit-leads-recorded-by-electrodes-placed-on-the-limbs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
