<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="part-12">Part 12<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#part-12" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-11a4f2fb.jpeg" alt="img-242.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="arrhythmias">Arrhythmias<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#arrhythmias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Abnormal rhythm of the heart that may be determined by a new pacemaker.
<strong>Causes include:</strong></li>
<li>Damage to the normal pacemaker</li>
<li>Appearance of a new, abnormal pacemaker, with a faster discharge (this occurs in atria or ventricles due to ischemia)</li>
<li>Block in the transmission through the conductive system</li>
<li>Abnormal pathways for transmission (e.g. the bundle of Kent in Wolf Parkinson White Syndrome)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-arrhythmias">Types of arrhythmias<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-arrhythmias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="atrial-arrhythmias">Atrial arrhythmias<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#atrial-arrhythmias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="atrial-extrasystole">Atrial extrasystole<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#atrial-extrasystole" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ul>
<li>Premature discharge from an atrial focus (an ECG cycle that appears before completion of a previous one).</li>
<li>Characterized by abnormally shaped P wave (because atrial degeneration is initiated in an abnormal site, not the SA node).</li>
<li>The premature beat occurs once and it is followed by a delay in the new discharge from the SA node (known as compensatory pause).</li>
</ul>
<p>215
The rest of the text is missing. If missing.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="part-13">Part 13<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#part-13" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-9d2255e9.jpeg" alt="img-243.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="arrhythmias">Arrhythmias<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#arrhythmias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Abnormal rhythm of the heart that may be determined by a new pacemaker.
<strong>Causes include:</strong></li>
<li>Damage to the normal pacemaker</li>
<li>Appearance of a new, abnormal pacemaker, with a faster discharge (this occurs in atria or ventricles due to ischemia)</li>
<li>Block in the transmission through the conductive system</li>
<li>Abnormal pathways for transmission (e.g. the bundle of Kent in Wolf Parkinson White Syndrome)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-arrhythmias">Types of arrhythmias<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-arrhythmias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="atrial-arrhythmias">Atrial arrhythmias<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#atrial-arrhythmias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="atrial-extrasystole">Atrial extrasystole<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#atrial-extrasystole" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ul>
<li>Premature discharge from an atrial focus (an ECG cycle that appears before completion of a previous one).</li>
<li>Characterized by abnormally shaped P wave (because atrial degeneration is initiated in an abnormal site, not the SA node).</li>
<li>The premature beat occurs once and it is followed by a delay in the new discharge from the SA node (known as compensatory pause).</li>
</ul>
<p>216
The rest of the text is missing. If missing.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="part-14">Part 14<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#part-14" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-d292c679.jpeg" alt="img-244.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="arrhythmias">Arrhythmias<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#arrhythmias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Abnormal rhythm of the heart that may be determined by a new pacemaker.
<strong>Causes include:</strong></li>
<li>Damage to the normal pacemaker</li>
<li>Appearance of a new, abnormal pacemaker, with a faster discharge (this occurs in atria or ventricles due to ischemia)</li>
<li>Block in the transmission through the conductive system</li>
<li>Abnormal pathways for transmission (e.g. the bundle of Kent in Wolf Parkinson White Syndrome)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-arrhythmias">Types of arrhythmias<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-arrhythmias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="atrial-arrhythmias">Atrial arrhythmias<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#atrial-arrhythmias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="atrial-extrasystole">Atrial extrasystole<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#atrial-extrasystole" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ul>
<li>Premature discharge from an atrial focus (an ECG cycle that appears before completion of a previous one).</li>
<li>Characterized by abnormally shaped P wave (because atrial degeneration is initiated in an abnormal site, not the SA node).</li>
<li>The premature beat occurs once and it is followed by a delay in the new discharge from the SA node (known as compensatory pause).</li>
</ul>
<p>217
The rest of the text is missing. If missing.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-d441474e.jpeg" alt="img-245.jpeg">
Fig 8.14: Axial extrasystole showing the abnormal P wave</p>
<ul>
<li>Axial tachycardia</li>
<li>Regular rapid discharge with narrow QRS complexes (the narrow complexes generally indicate that there is no problem in ventricles).</li>
<li>The heart rate from the ECG= the radial pulse and may reach about 200 beats/min.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-1beaf90f.jpeg" alt="img-246.jpeg">
Fig 8.15: Axial tachycardia</p>
<ul>
<li>Axial flutter</li>
<li>Regular rapid discharge with narrow complexes.</li>
<li>The rate of atrial discharge (rate of P waves in the ECG) is about (200-350/min) whereas the radial pulse (= rate of QRS complexes) is less than that.</li>
<li>This is because of the delay in the AV node (every discharge from the SA node is not necessarily conducted to the ventricles; therefore number of P waves is higher than number of QRS complexes).</li>
<li>P waves give a characteristic appearance in atrial flutter (the saw-toothed appearance).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-afa011c3.jpeg" alt="img-247.jpeg">
Fig 8.16: Atrial extrasystole showing the abnormal P wave</p>
<ul>
<li>Atrial tachycardia</li>
<li>Regular rapid discharge with narrow QRS complexes (the narrow complexes generally indicate that there is no problem in ventricles).</li>
<li>The heart rate from the ECG= the radial pulse and may reach about 230 beats/min.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-dedb61db.jpeg" alt="img-248.jpeg">
Fig 8.17: Atrial tachycardia</p>
<ul>
<li>Atrial flutter</li>
<li>Regular rapid discharge with narrow complexes.</li>
<li>The rate of atrial discharge (rate of P waves in the ECG) is about (200-350/min) whereas the radial pulse (= rate of QRS complexes) is less than that.</li>
<li>This is because of the delay in the AV node (every discharge from the SA node is not necessarily conducted to the ventricles; therefore number of P waves is higher than number of QRS complexes).</li>
<li>P waves give a characteristic appearance in atrial flutter (the saw-toothed appearance).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-3d0ae971.jpeg" alt="img-249.jpeg">
Fig 8.18: Atrial extrasystole showing the abnormal P wave</p>
<ul>
<li>Atrial tachycardia</li>
<li>Regular rapid discharge with narrow QRS complexes (the narrow complexes generally indicate that there is no problem in ventricles).</li>
<li>The heart rate from the ECG= the radial pulse and may reach about 200 beats/min.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-6e993726.jpeg" alt="img-250.jpeg">
Fig 8.19: Atrial tachycardia</p>
<ul>
<li>Atrial flutter</li>
<li>Regular rapid discharge with narrow complexes.</li>
<li>The rate of atrial discharge (rate of P waves in the ECG) is about (200-350/min) whereas the radial pulse (= rate of QRS complexes) is less than that.</li>
<li>This is because of the delay in the AV node (every discharge from the SA node is not necessarily conducted to the ventricles; therefore number of P waves is higher than number of QRS complexes).</li>
<li>P waves give a characteristic appearance in atrial flutter (the saw-toothed appearance).</li>
</ul>
<p>The work of Medical Microbiology® 2009</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-7cbe13c8.jpeg" alt="img-251.jpeg">
Fig 6.10: Atrial flutter showing the pre-docked appearance</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="atrial-fibrillation">Atrial fibrillation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#atrial-fibrillation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Irregular rapid discharge with narrow complexes.</li>
<li>The rate of discharge in atria is expected to be (300-600/min) however, its calculation from the ECG is impossible because P waves are completely absent.</li>
<li>The ventricular rate (i.e. rate of QRS complexes) is slower because of the delay in the AV node.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-5f011f61.jpeg" alt="img-252.jpeg">
Fig 6.11: Atrial flutter showing the non-docked appearance</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="consequences-of-atrial-arrhythmias">Consequences of atrial arrhythmias:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#consequences-of-atrial-arrhythmias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Occasional extrasystoles have no ill effects and do not need treatment; however, other atrial arrhythmias decrease time of the cardiac cycle (because of the tachycardia). It's decreases the diastolic time which is necessary for ventricular filling and therefore decreases the stroke volume and the cardiac output. The reduction in cardiac output may cause heart failure.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="treatment-of-atrial-arrhythmias">Treatment of atrial arrhythmias:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#treatment-of-atrial-arrhythmias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>According to severity of arrhythmia and patient condition, atrial arrhythmias may be treated with simple maneuvers that increase vagal discharge (like carotid sinus massage at the angle of the jaw, eyeball pressure or induction of vomiting) or by anti-arrhythmic drugs (like digitalis, beta blockers ...) or by using the defibrillator.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-e40e9858.jpeg" alt="img-253.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="atrial-fibrillation">Atrial fibrillation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#atrial-fibrillation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Irregular rapid discharge with narrow complexes.</li>
<li>The rate of discharge in atria is expected to be (300-500/min) however, its calculation from the ECG is impossible because P waves are completely absent.</li>
<li>The ventricular rate (i.e. rate of QRS complexes) is slower because of the delay in the AV node.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-e6427714.jpeg" alt="img-254.jpeg">
Fig 6.12: Atrial flutter showing the non-docked appearance</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="consequences-of-atrial-arrhythmias">Consequences of atrial arrhythmias:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#consequences-of-atrial-arrhythmias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Occasional extrasystoles have no ill effects and do not need treatment; however, other atrial arrhythmias decrease time of the cardiac cycle (because of the tachycardia). It's decreases the diastolic time which is necessary for ventricular filling and therefore decreases the stroke volume and the cardiac output. The reduction in cardiac output may cause heart failure.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="treatment-of-atrial-arrhythmias">Treatment of atrial arrhythmias:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#treatment-of-atrial-arrhythmias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>According to severity of arrhythmia and patient condition, atrial arrhythmias may be treated with simple maneuvers that increase vagal discharge (like carotid sinus massage at the angle of the jaw, eyeball pressure or induction of vomiting) or by anti-arrhythmic drugs (like digitalis, beta blockers ...) or by using the defibrillator.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-9a3f8b3d.jpeg" alt="img-255.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="atrial-fibrillation">Atrial fibrillation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#atrial-fibrillation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Irregular rapid discharge with narrow complexes.</li>
<li>The rate of discharge in atria is expected to be (500-900/min) however, its calculation from the ECG is impossible because P waves are completely absent.</li>
<li>The ventricular rate (i.e. rate of QRS complexes) is slower because of the delay in the AV node.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-424d9fbf.jpeg" alt="img-256.jpeg">
Fig 6.13: Atrial flutter showing the non-docked appearance</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="consequences-of-atrial-arrhythmias">Consequences of atrial arrhythmias:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#consequences-of-atrial-arrhythmias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Occasional extrasystoles have no ill effects and do not need treatment; however, other atrial arrhythmias decrease time of the cardiac cycle (because of the tachycardia). It's decreases the diastolic time which is necessary for ventricular filling and therefore decreases the stroke volume and the cardiac output. The reduction in cardiac output may cause heart failure.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="treatment-of-atrial-arrhythmias">Treatment of atrial arrhythmias:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#treatment-of-atrial-arrhythmias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>According to severity of arrhythmia and patient condition, atrial arrhythmias may be treated with simple maneuvers that increase vagal discharge (like carotid sinus massage at the angle of the jaw, eyeball pressure or induction of vomiting) or by anti-arrhythmic drugs (like digitalis, beta blockers ...) or by using the defibrillator.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-93b64394.jpeg" alt="img-257.jpeg"></p>
<p>214
The case of medical physiology of asthma</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ventricular-arrhythmias">Ventricular arrhythmias<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ventricular-arrhythmias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ventricular-tachycardia">Ventricular tachycardia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ventricular-tachycardia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Premature discharge from a ventricular focus (an ECG cycle that appears before completion of a previous one).</li>
<li>Characterized by abnormally shaped QRS complex (because ventricular depolarization is initiated in an abnormal site, not the normal site which is the septum).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-15fd8ea6.jpeg" alt="img-258.jpeg">
Fig.6.10</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ventricular-tachycardia">Ventricular tachycardia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ventricular-tachycardia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Regular rapid discharge with broad QRS complexes (the broad complexes indicate that there is a problem in ventricles).</li>
<li>Other ECG waves may be hidden by the broad complexes.</li>
<li>The heart rate is very fast.</li>
<li>The commonest cause is ischemic heart disease.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-e8526d5a.jpeg" alt="img-259.jpeg">
Fig.6.10</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ventricular-arrhythmias">Ventricular arrhythmias<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ventricular-arrhythmias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ventricular-tachycardia">Ventricular tachycardia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ventricular-tachycardia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Premature discharge from a ventricular focus (an ECG cycle that appears before completion of a previous one).</li>
<li>Characterized by abnormally shaped QRS complex (because ventricular depolarization is initiated in an abnormal site, not the normal site which is the septum).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-8b612d02.jpeg" alt="img-260.jpeg">
Fig.6.10</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ventricular-tachycardia">Ventricular tachycardia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ventricular-tachycardia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Regular rapid discharge with broad QRS complexes (the broad complexes indicate that there is a problem in ventricles).</li>
<li>Other ECG waves may be hidden by the broad complexes.</li>
<li>The heart rate is very fast.</li>
<li>The commonest cause is ischemic heart disease.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-b5ff16b4.jpeg" alt="img-261.jpeg">
Fig.6.10</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ventricular-arrhythmias">Ventricular arrhythmias<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ventricular-arrhythmias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ventricular-tachycardia">Ventricular tachycardia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ventricular-tachycardia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Premature discharge from a ventricular focus (an ECG cycle that appears before completion of a previous one).</li>
<li>Characterized by abnormally shaped QRS complex (because ventricular depolarization is initiated in an abnormal site, not the normal site which is the septum).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-059c0f66.jpeg" alt="img-262.jpeg">
Fig.6.10</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ventricular-arrhythmias">Ventricular arrhythmias<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ventricular-arrhythmias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="regular-rapid-discharge-with-broad-qrs-complexes-the-broad-complexes-indicate-that-there-is-a-problem-in-ventricles">Regular rapid discharge with broad QRS complexes (the broad complexes indicate that there is a problem in ventricles).<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#regular-rapid-discharge-with-broad-qrs-complexes-the-broad-complexes-indicate-that-there-is-a-problem-in-ventricles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Other ECG waves may be hidden by the broad complexes.</li>
<li>The heart rate is very fast.</li>
<li>The commonest cause is ischemic heart disease.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-1035f5ce.jpeg" alt="img-263.jpeg">
Fig.6.10</p>
<p>320
The cost of medical physiology 1st edition</p>
<ul>
<li>Ventricular fibrillation</li>
<li>Very rapid discharge of multiple ventricular foci.</li>
<li>Results in appearance of an abnormal bizarre shaped ECG.</li>
<li>ECG waves are not clear.</li>
<li>It is a cause of death in patients with myocardial infarction.</li>
</ul>
<p>Part 20</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-068e170b.jpeg" alt="img-264.jpeg"></p>
<p>Consequences of ventricular arrhythmias:</p>
<ul>
<li>Occasional endocarditis have no serious effects and do not need treatment.</li>
<li>Ventricular tachycardia decreases cardiac output because the time available for ventricular filling is decreased and therefore the stroke volume and cardiac output are decreased. This causes heart failure.</li>
<li>In addition to that, ventricular tachycardia may be complicated by ventricular fibrillation.</li>
<li>Ventricular fibrillation is the most dangerous type of arrhythmia. It causes death in minutes because the heart fibrillation without opening blood is supply the brain.</li>
</ul>
<p>Treatment:</p>
<ul>
<li>According to severity of arrhythmia &amp; patient condition, ventricular arrhythmias can be treated with anti-arrhythmic drugs or defibrillators (+ electric shock).</li>
</ul>
<p>321
The cost of medical physiology 1st edition</p>
<ul>
<li>Ventricular fibrillation</li>
<li>Very rapid discharge of multiple ventricular foci.</li>
<li>Results in appearance of an abnormal bizarre shaped ECG.</li>
<li>ECG waves are not clear.</li>
<li>It is a cause of death in patients with myocardial infarction.</li>
</ul>
<p>Part 20</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-4b491eff.jpeg" alt="img-265.jpeg"></p>
<p>Consequences of ventricular arrhythmias:</p>
<ul>
<li>Occasional endocarditis have no serious effects and do not need treatment.</li>
<li>Ventricular tachycardia decreases cardiac output because the time available for ventricular filling is decreased and therefore the stroke volume and cardiac output are decreased. This causes heart failure.</li>
<li>In addition to that, ventricular tachycardia may be complicated by ventricular fibrillation.</li>
<li>Ventricular fibrillation is the most dangerous type of arrhythmia. It causes death in minutes because the heart fibrillation without opening blood is supply the brain.</li>
</ul>
<p>Treatment:</p>
<ul>
<li>According to severity of arrhythmia &amp; patient condition, ventricular arrhythmias can be treated with anti-arrhythmic drugs or defibrillators (+ electric shock).</li>
</ul>
<p>322
The cost of medical physiology 1st edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="heart-block">Heart Block<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#heart-block" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Block of conduction from atria to ventricles</li>
<li>May be:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Incomplete heart block. Sial or second degree</li>
<li>Complete heart block: third degree</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li><strong>First degree:</strong></li>
<li>Prolonged PR interval (&gt; 0.2s)</li>
<li>Causes include: IHD &amp; hypokalaemia</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-6-21">Fig 6.21<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-6-21" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-569811db.jpeg" alt="img-266.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Second degree:</strong></li>
<li>Conduction from atria to the ventricles is blocked (e.g. due to IHD).</li>
<li>This results in generation of P wave two or three times before appearance of the QRS complex (2:1 or 3:1 conduction).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-6-22">Fig 6.22<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-6-22" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-5d734082.jpeg" alt="img-267.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Third degree:</strong></li>
<li>Complete block of conduction from atria to ventricles (due to IHD).</li>
<li>Atria continue to contract by the SA node whereas ventricles continue to contract by a ventricular focus (idioventricular rhythm).</li>
</ul>
<p>222</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="heart-block">Heart Block<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#heart-block" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>Block of conduction from atria to ventricles</li>
<li>May be:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Incomplete heart block. Sial or second degree</li>
<li>Complete heart block: third degree</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li><strong>First degree:</strong></li>
<li>Prolonged PR interval (&gt; 0.2s)</li>
<li>Causes include: IHD &amp; hypokalaemia</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-6-21">Fig 6.21<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-6-21" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<li>Conduction from atria to the ventricles is blocked (e.g. due to IHD).</li>
<li>This results in generation of P wave two or three times before appearance of the QRS complex (2:1 or 3:1 conduction).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-6-22">Fig 6.22<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-6-22" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-dc6c0813.jpeg" alt="img-269.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Third degree:</strong></li>
<li>Complete block of conduction from atria to ventricles (due to IHD).</li>
<li>Atria continue to contract by the SA node whereas ventricles continue to contract by a ventricular focus (idioventricular rhythm).</li>
</ul>
<p>222</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="heart-block">Heart Block<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#heart-block" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Block of conduction from atria to ventricles</li>
<li>May be:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Incomplete heart block. Sial or second degree</li>
<li>Complete heart block: third degree</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li><strong>First degree:</strong></li>
<li>Prolonged PR interval (&gt; 0.2s)</li>
<li>Causes include: IHD &amp; hypokalaemia</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-6-21">Fig 6.21<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-6-21" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-9b520788.jpeg" alt="img-270.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Second degree:</strong></li>
<li>Conduction from atria to the ventricles is blocked (e.g. due to IHD).</li>
<li>This results in generation of P wave two or three times before appearance of the QRS complex (2:1 or 3:1 conduction).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-6-22">Fig 6.22<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-6-22" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-826fb873.jpeg" alt="img-271.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Third degree:</strong></li>
<li>Complete block of conduction from atria to ventricles (due to IHD).</li>
<li>Atria continue to contract by the SA node whereas ventricles continue to contract by a ventricular focus (idioventricular rhythm).</li>
</ul>
<p>222</p>
<p>P waves appear at regular intervals with a normal rate (60-100/min)</p>
<p>QRS complexes are not related to the P waves. They appear independently with an abnormal shape and a slow rate (15-20/min).</p>
<p>Fig.5.23</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-5b846241.jpeg" alt="img-272.jpeg"></p>
<p>Patients with complete heart block develop Stokes Adams attacks (become immediately unconscious and collapse with a minimal degree of exercise). That's because the low cerebral blood flow is further decreased with exercise due to shifting of blood towards muscles.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="myocardial-infarction-mi">Myocardial infarction (MI)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#myocardial-infarction-mi" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Death of myocardial fibers due to interruption of the blood supply (block in the coronary artery or some of its branches).</p>
<ul>
<li>This produces characteristic changes in the ECG.</li>
<li>The changes are explained by the findings that the infarcted area develops rapid repolarization (due to accelerated opening of K+ channels) followed by reduction in the resting membrane potential (RMP) and then delayed depolarization.</li>
<li>The reduction in the RMP makes the normal area more negative relative to the infarcted area (in the extracellular surface of cells not the intracellular). Therefore the electrical currents flow from inside the infarcted area to the normal area (from</li>
</ul>
<p>523</p>
<p>The case of medical physiology: P values</p>
<p>P waves appear at regular intervals with a normal rate (60-100/min)</p>
<p>QRS complexes are not related to the P waves. They appear independently with an abnormal shape and a slow rate (15-20/min).</p>
<p>Fig.5.23</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-60b32e14.jpeg" alt="img-273.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>Patients with complete heart block develop Stokes Adams attacks (become immediately unconscious and collapse with a minimal degree of exercise). That's because the low cerebral blood flow is further decreased with exercise due to shifting of blood towards muscles.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="myocardial-infarction-mi">Myocardial infarction (MI)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#myocardial-infarction-mi" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Death of myocardial fibers due to interruption of the blood supply (block in the coronary artery or some of its branches).</li>
<li>This produces characteristic changes in the ECG.</li>
<li>The changes are explained by the findings that the infarcted area develops rapid repolarization (due to accelerated opening of K+ channels) followed by reduction in the resting membrane potential (RMP) and then delayed depolarization.</li>
<li>The reduction in the RMP makes the normal area more negative relative to the infarcted area (in the extracellular surface of cells not the intracellular). Therefore the electrical currents flow from inside the infarcted area to the normal area (from</li>
</ul>
<p>524</p>
<p>The case of medical physiology: P values</p>
<p>P waves appear at regular intervals with a normal rate (60-100/min)</p>
<p>QRS complexes are not related to the P waves. They appear independently with an abnormal shape and a slow rate (15-20/min).</p>
<p>Fig.5.23</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-4ff3b536.jpeg" alt="img-274.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>Patients with complete heart block develop Stokes Adams attacks (become immediately unconscious and collapse with a minimal degree of exercise). That's because the low cerebral blood flow is further decreased with exercise due to shifting of blood towards muscles.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="myocardial-infarction-mi">Myocardial infarction (MI)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#myocardial-infarction-mi" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Death of myocardial fibers due to interruption of the blood supply (block in the coronary artery or some of its branches).</p>
<ul>
<li>This produces characteristic changes in the ECG.</li>
<li>The changes are explained by the findings that the infarcted area develops rapid repolarization (due to accelerated opening of K+ channels) followed by reduction in the resting membrane potential (RMP) and then delayed depolarization.</li>
<li>The reduction in the RMP makes the normal area more negative relative to the infarcted area (in the extracellular surface of cells not the intracellular). Therefore the electrical currents flow from inside the infarcted area to the normal area (from</li>
</ul>
<p>525</p>
<p>The case of medical physiology: P values</p>
<p>positive to negative). This means that the currents are flowing towards the ECG electrodes overlying the infected area.</p>
<ul>
<li>The electrodes develop upward deflection. This appears as ST elevation in the ECG (Note: the currents are flowing away from the electrodes opposite to the infected area. This appears as ST depression in other ECG leads).</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Fig 6.24</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-c43bd328.jpeg" alt="img-275.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>Some days later, the dead muscle becomes electrically silent (after development of scar tissue). Here the infected area becomes more negative relative to the normal area (extracellularly). This results in disappearance of the ST elevation and appearance of abnormal Q waves).</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Fig 6.25</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-b86e75f0.jpeg" alt="img-276.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>Some days later, the dead muscle becomes electrically silent (after development of scar tissue). Here the infected area becomes more negative relative to the normal area (extracellularly). This results in disappearance of the ST elevation and appearance of abnormal Q waves).</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Fig 6.26</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-5aa5ad37.jpeg" alt="img-277.jpeg"></p>
<p>positive to negative). This means that the currents are flowing towards the ECG electrodes overlying the infected area.</p>
<ul>
<li>The electrodes develop upward deflection. This appears as ST elevation in the ECG (Note: the currents are flowing away from the electrodes opposite to the infected area. This appears as ST depression in other ECG leads).</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Fig 6.24</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-411e53ff.jpeg" alt="img-278.jpeg"></p>
<p>positive to negative). This means that the currents are flowing towards the ECG electrodes overlying the infected area.</p>
<ul>
<li>The electrodes develop upward deflection. This appears as ST elevation in the ECG (Note: the currents are flowing away from the electrodes opposite to the infected area. This appears as ST depression in other ECG leads).</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Fig 6.24</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-1d753f41.jpeg" alt="img-279.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>Some days later, the dead muscle becomes electrically silent (after development of scar tissue). Here the infected area becomes more negative relative to the normal area (extracellularly). This results in disappearance of the ST elevation and appearance of abnormal Q waves).</li>

<p><strong>Fig 6.25</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-dde55fec.jpeg" alt="img-280.jpeg"></p>
<p>224
The cost of medical physiology I P edition
225
The cost of medical physiology I P edition
226
The cost of medical physiology I P edition</p>
<ul>
<li>the ECG does not only diagnose MI but also localizes its site (according to which lead develops ECG changes). For example:</li>
<li>ST elevation in II, III and aVF indicates inferior MI</li>
<li>ST elevation in V1, V2, V3 and V4 indicates anteroseptal MI</li>
<li>ST elevation in V2, V3, V4, I and aVI indicates anterolateral MI</li>
<li>Tell R wave and ST depression in V1 and V2 indicates posterior MI</li>
</ul>
<p>Remember that</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Acute MI is a life threatening problem. It may cause immediate death due to:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Arrhythmia (e.g. ventricular fibrillation)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Severe heart failure</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Rupture of the infarcted area.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The risk of these complications is highest during the first week following the infarction. That's why these patients should be treated appropriately (e.g. by thrombolytic therapy) in special wards (Coronary Care Units "CCU") for close follow up and monitoring during the acute phase.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The ECG does not only diagnose MI but also localizes its site (according to which lead develops ECG changes). For example:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>ST elevation in II, III and aVF indicates inferior MI</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>ST elevation in V1, V2, V3 and V4 indicates anteroseptal MI</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>ST elevation in V2, V3, V4, I and aVI indicates anterolateral MI</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tell R wave and ST depression in V1 and V2 indicates posterior MI</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Remember that</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Acute MI is a life threatening problem. It may cause immediate death due to:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Arrhythmia (e.g. ventricular fibrillation)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Severe heart failure</p>

<p>Remember that</p>
<ul>
<li>Acute MI is a life threatening problem. It may cause immediate death due to:</li>
<li>Arrhythmia (e.g. ventricular fibrillation)</li>
<li>Severe heart failure</li>
<li>Rupture of the infarcted area.</li>
<li>The risk of these complications is highest during the first week following the infarction. That's why these patients should be treated appropriately (e.g. by thrombolytic therapy) in special wards (Coronary Care Units "CCU") for close follow up and monitoring during the acute phase.</li>
</ul>

<p>227
The area of medical physiology / 1st edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="important-notes">Important notes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#important-notes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Hypocalcemia causes low voltage ECG.</li>
<li>Hyperkalemia decreases the resting membrane potential (RMP) towards the threshold, making the cells more excitable (causing arrhythmias) and eventually the RMP reaches the threshold, making the cells non excitable. Here the heart stops in diastole.</li>
<li>Hypomakemia increases contractility in the heart because ECF calcium enters the cells to cause contraction.</li>
<li>Severe hypomakemia stops the heart in systole. For this reason IV injection of calcium in patients with hypocalcemia should be slow to avoid injection of large amount of calcium.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-cardiac-cycle">THE CARDIAC CYCLE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-cardiac-cycle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="duration">Duration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#duration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The normal heart rate is about 75 beats/min (i.e. 75 beats in 60 seconds). Therefore, each beat takes 60/75 = 0.6 second.</li>
<li>Each beat is regarded as one cardiac cycle that involves phases of contraction &amp; relaxation for both atrial and ventricles.</li>
<li>Therefore, each cardiac cycle (0.6s) can be studied in 3 phases:</li>
<li>Atrial systole (takes 0.1 s)</li>
<li>Ventricular systole (takes 0.3 s)</li>
<li>Atrial diastole (takes 0.7 s) &amp; ventricular diastole (takes 0.5 s)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="atrial-systole">Atrial Systole<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#atrial-systole" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>During the phase of atrial systole, the ventricles are in state of diastole. Therefore, atrial contraction ejects blood to fill the ventricles through the atrio-ventricular (AV) values.</p>
<p>228
The area of medical physiology / 1st edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="important-notes">Important notes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#important-notes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Hypocalcemia causes low voltage ECG.</li>
<li>Hyperkalemia decreases the resting membrane potential (RMP) towards the threshold, making the cells more excitable (causing arrhythmias) and eventually the RMP reaches the threshold, making the cells non excitable. Here the heart stops in diastole.</li>
<li>Hypercalcemia increases contractility in the heart because ECF calcium enters the cells to cause contraction.</li>
<li>Severe hypercalcemia stops the heart in systole. For this reason IV injection of calcium in patients with hypocalcemia should be slow to avoid injection of large amount of calcium.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-cardiac-cycle">THE CARDIAC CYCLE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-cardiac-cycle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="duration">Duration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#duration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The normal heart rate is about 75 beats/min (i.e. 75 beats in 60 seconds). Therefore, each beat takes 60/75 = 0.6 second.</li>
<li>Each beat is regarded as one cardiac cycle that involves phases of contraction &amp; relaxation for both atrial and ventricles.</li>
<li>Therefore, each cardiac cycle (0.6s) can be studied in 3 phases:</li>
<li>Atrial systole (takes 0.1 s)</li>
<li>Ventricular systole (takes 0.3 s)</li>
<li>Atrial diastole (takes 0.7 s) &amp; ventricular diastole (takes 0.5 s)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="atrial-systole">Atrial Systole<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#atrial-systole" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>During the phase of atrial systole, the ventricles are in state of diastole. Therefore, atrial contraction ejects blood to fill the ventricles through the atrio-ventricular (AV) values.</p>
<p>229
The area of medical physiology / 1st edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="important-notes">Important notes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#important-notes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Hypocalcemia causes low voltage ECG.</li>
<li>Hyperkalemia decreases the resting membrane potential (RMP) towards the threshold, making the cells more excitable (causing arrhythmias) and eventually the RMP reaches the threshold, making the cells non excitable. Here the heart stops in diastole.</li>
<li>Hypercalcemia increases contractility in the heart because ECF calcium enters the cells to cause contraction.</li>
<li>Severe hypercalcemia stops the heart in systole. For this reason IV injection of calcium in patients with hypocalcemia should be slow to avoid injection of large amount of calcium.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-cardiac-cycle">THE CARDIAC CYCLE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-cardiac-cycle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="duration">Duration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#duration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The normal heart rate is about 75 beats/min (i.e. 75 beats in 60 seconds). Therefore, each beat takes 60/75 = 0.6 second.</li>
<li>Each beat is regarded as one cardiac cycle that involves phases of contraction &amp; relaxation for both atrial and ventricles.</li>
<li>Therefore, each cardiac cycle (0.6s) can be studied in 3 phases:</li>
<li>Atrial systole (takes 0.1 s)</li>
<li>Ventricular systole (takes 0.3 s)</li>
<li>Atrial diastole (takes 0.7 s) &amp; ventricular diastole (takes 0.5 s)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="atrial-systole">Atrial Systole<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#atrial-systole" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>During the phase of atrial systole, the ventricles are in state of diastole. Therefore, atrial contraction ejects blood to fill the ventricles through the atrio-ventricular (AV) values.</p>
<p>228
The state of medical physiology of asthma</p>
<ul>
<li>Ventricular filling occurs by two ways. Passive filling (blood flows passively from atria to ventricles) &amp; active filling (BY atrial systolic).</li>
<li>About 70% of ventricular filling occurs passively. Then atrial systolic completes ventricular filling (provides the 30%).</li>
<li>Atrial contraction increases atrial pressure and causes reflux of blood through the superior vena cava, causing a characteristic "a" wave ("a" for atrial systolic) in both atrial pressure curve and internal jugular venous pressure "JVP" curve (see figure 8.29).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ventricular-systole">Ventricular Systole<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ventricular-systole" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs immediately after atrial systolic because of the delay in the AV node (i.e. ventricles contract while atria relax).</li>
<li>When the ventricles start to contract, the pressures inside them start to rise, then contraction continues until ventricular pressure exceeds atrial pressure, have the AV valves close to prevent reflux of blood back to the atria.</li>
<li>Closure of the AV valves results in the first heart sound "S1" (the sound is caused by turbulence of blood due to closure of valves).</li>
<li>Then the ventricles continue to contract &amp; their pressures continue to rise, while all valves are closed. This is the isovolumetric contraction phase. It occurs immediately after S1.</li>
<li>When pressure in the left ventricle reaches 80 mmHg and in the right ventricle reaches 10 mmHg, the semilunar valves open &amp; blood starts to be ejected into the aortic and pulmonary artery (remember that inspite of the difference in pressure, the two valves open almost in the same time).</li>
<li>The ventricles continue to contract &amp; the pressures continue to rise to maintain ejection which starts rapidly at first (rapid ejection phase) and then slows down (slow ejection phase).</li>
<li>The maximum pressure reached in the left ventricle is 120 mmHg &amp; in the right ventricle ~ 25 mmHg (= systolic pressure).</li>
</ul>
<p>229
The state of medical physiology of asthma</p>
<ul>
<li>Ventricular filling occurs by two ways. Passive filling (blood flows passively from atria to ventricles) &amp; active filling (BY atrial systolic).</li>
<li>About 70% of ventricular filling occurs passively. Then atrial systolic completes ventricular filling (provides the 30%).</li>
<li>Atrial contraction increases atrial pressure and causes reflux of blood through the superior vena cava, causing a characteristic "a" wave ("a" for atrial systolic) in both atrial pressure curve and internal jugular venous pressure "JVP" curve (see figure 8.29).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ventricular-systole">Ventricular Systole<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ventricular-systole" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs immediately after atrial systolic because of the delay in the AV node (i.e. ventricles contract while atria relax).</li>
<li>When the ventricles start to contract, the pressures inside them start to rise, then contraction continues until ventricular pressure exceeds atrial pressure, have the AV valves close to prevent reflux of blood back to the atria.</li>
<li>Closure of the AV valves results in the first heart sound "S1" (the sound is caused by turbulence of blood due to closure of valves).</li>
<li>Then the ventricles continue to contract &amp; their pressures continue to rise, while all valves are closed. This is the isovolumetric contraction phase. It occurs immediately after S1.</li>
<li>When pressure in the left ventricle reaches 80 mmHg and in the right ventricle reaches 10 mmHg, the semilunar valves open &amp; blood starts to be ejected into the aorta and pulmonary artery (remember that inspite of the difference in pressure, the two valves open almost in the same time).</li>
<li>The ventricles continue to contract &amp; the pressures continue to rise to maintain ejection which starts rapidly at first (rapid ejection phase) and then slows down (slow ejection phase).</li>
<li>The maximum pressure reached in the left ventricle is 120 mmHg &amp; in the right ventricle ~ 25 mmHg (= systolic pressure).</li>
</ul>
<p>230
The state of medical physiology of asthma</p>
<ul>
<li>Ventricular filling occurs by two ways. Passive filling (blood flows passively from atria to ventricles) &amp; active filling (BY atrial systolic).</li>
<li>About 70% of ventricular filling occurs passively. Then atrial systolic completes ventricular filling (provides the 30%).</li>
<li>Atrial contraction increases atrial pressure and causes reflux of blood through the superior vena cava, causing a characteristic "a" wave ("a" for atrial systolic) in both atrial pressure curve and internal jugular venous pressure "JVP" curve (see figure 8.29).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ventricular-systole">Ventricular Systole<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ventricular-systole" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Occurs immediately after atrial systolic because of the delay in the AV node (i.e. ventricles contract while atria relax).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When the ventricles start to contract, the pressures inside them start to rise, then contraction continues until ventricular pressure exceeds atrial pressure, have the AV valves close to prevent reflux of blood back to the atria.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Closure of the AV valves results in the first heart sound "S1" (the sound is caused by turbulence of blood due to closure of valves).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Then the ventricles continue to contract &amp; their pressures continue to rise, while all valves are closed. This is the isovolumetric contraction phase. It occurs immediately after S1.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When pressure in the left ventricle reaches 80 mmHg and in the right ventricle reaches 10 mmHg, the semilunar valves open &amp; blood starts to be ejected into the aorta and pulmonary artery (remember that inspite of the difference in pressure, the two valves open almost in the same time).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The ventricles continue to contract &amp; the pressures continue to rise to maintain ejection which starts rapidly at first (rapid ejection phase) and then slows down (slow ejection phase).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The maximum pressure reached in the left ventricle is 120 mmHg &amp; in the right ventricle ~ 25 mmHg (= systolic pressure).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>About 70 ml of blood is ejected from each ventricle. It is known as stroke volume "SV" and it is defined as volume of blood ejected from each ventricle per beat.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>About 50 ml of blood remains in each ventricle at the end of systole. It is known as end systolic volume "ESV".</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>About 120 ml of blood is found in each ventricle before ejection.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This 120 ml is known as the end diastolic volume "EDV". It is defined as volume of blood that remains in each ventricle at the end of diastole.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Remember that contraction of ventricles pushes cusps of the AV valves backwards towards the atria. This causes a characteristic wave in atrial pressure curve &amp; JVP curve known as "C" wave ("C" for cusp shooting). Look at the following figure.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-d9cad454.jpeg" alt="img-290.jpeg">
Fig.8.29: The cardiac cycle</p>
<ul>
<li>About 70 ml of blood is ejected from each ventricle. It is known as stroke volume "SV" and it is defined as volume of blood ejected from each ventricle per beat.</li>
<li>About 50 ml of blood remains in each ventricle at the end of systole. It is known as end systolic volume "ESV".</li>
<li>About 120 ml of blood is found in each ventricle before ejection.</li>
<li>This 120 ml is known as the end diastolic volume "EDV". It is defined as volume of blood that remains in each ventricle at the end of diastole.</li>
<li>Remember that contraction of ventricles pushes cusps of the AV valves backwards towards the atria. This causes a characteristic wave in atrial pressure curve &amp; JVP curve known as "C" wave ("C" for cusp shooting). Look at the following figure.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-d0f245e6.jpeg" alt="img-291.jpeg">
Fig.8.28: The cardiac cycle</p>
<ul>
<li>About 70 ml of blood is ejected from each ventricle. It is known as stroke volume "SV" and it is defined as volume of blood ejected from each ventricle at the end of diastole.</li>
<li>About 50 ml of blood remains in each ventricle at the end of systole. It is known as end systolic volume "ESV".</li>
<li>About 120 ml of blood is found in each ventricle before ejection.</li>
<li>This 120 ml is known as the end diastolic volume "EDV". It is defined as volume of blood that remains in each ventricle at the end of diastole.</li>
<li>Remember that contraction of ventricles pushes cusps of the AV valves backwards towards the atria. This causes a characteristic wave in atrial pressure curve &amp; JVP curve known as "C" wave ("C" for cusp shooting). Look at the following figure.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-49894b17.jpeg" alt="img-292.jpeg">
Fig.8.29: The cardiac cycle</p>
<p>230
The issue of medical psychology 12th edition
231
