The issue of medical psychology 12th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="aptal-ventricular-diastole">Aptal &amp; Ventricular Diastole<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#aptal-ventricular-diastole" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="atral-diastole">Atral diastole<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#atral-diastole" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Precedes ventricular diastolic and continues throughout most of the cycle (because it takes 0.7 s and the whole cycle is 0.6 s).</li>
<li>During this phase blood enters the atrial (versus return).</li>
<li>Accumulation of blood in atrial values aptal &amp; jugular venous pressures and produces "V" wave in atrial pressure curve and JVP curve ("V" for venous return).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ventricular-diastole">Ventricular diastole<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ventricular-diastole" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Ventricular diastole starts during atrial diastolic and filling of atrial with blood.</li>
<li>When the ventricles start to relax, the pressures inside them start to drop. When the ventricular pressures become lower than the pressures in aortic &amp; pulmonary arteries, the semilunar valves are closed to prevent return of blood back to the ventricles.</li>
<li>Closure of the semilunar valves results in the second heart sound "S2" (the sound is caused by turbulence of blood due to closure of the valves).</li>
<li>Then the ventricles continue to relax &amp; the pressures inside them continue to drop, while all valves are closed. This is the isovolumetric relaxation phase. It occurs immediately after S2.</li>
<li>When the pressures inside the ventricles become lower than the pressures in atria, the AV valves open. This allows passive filling of ventricles with blood that already filled atria during this period.</li>
<li>Then the atria contract to complete ventricular filling and to start a new cycle.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="aptal-ventricular-diastole">Aptal &amp; Ventricular Diastole<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#aptal-ventricular-diastole" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="atrial-diastole">Atrial diastole<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#atrial-diastole" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Precedes ventricular diastolic and continues throughout most of the cycle (because it takes 0.7 s and the whole cycle is 0.6 s).</li>
<li>During this phase blood enters the atrial (versus return).</li>
<li>Accumulation of blood in atrial values atrial &amp; jugular venous pressures and produces "V" wave in atrial pressure curve and JVP curve ("V" for venous return).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ventricular-diastole">Ventricular diastole<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ventricular-diastole" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Ventricular diastole starts during atrial diastolic and filling of atrial with blood.</li>
<li>When the ventricles start to relax, the pressures inside them start to drop. When the ventricular pressures become lower than the pressures in aortic &amp; pulmonary arteries, the semilunar valves are closed to prevent return of blood back to the ventricles.</li>
<li>Closure of the semilunar valves results in the second heart sound "S2" (the sound is caused by turbulence of blood due to closure of the valves).</li>
<li>Then the ventricles continue to relax &amp; the pressures inside them continue to drop, while all valves are closed. This is the isovolumetric relaxation phase. It occurs immediately after S2.</li>
<li>When the pressures inside the ventricles become lower than the pressures in atria, the AV valves open. This allows passive filling of ventricles with blood that already filled atria during this period.</li>
<li>Then the atria contract to complete ventricular filling and to start a new cycle.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="aptal-ventricular-diastole">Aptal &amp; Ventricular Diastole<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#aptal-ventricular-diastole" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="atrial-diastole">Atrial diastole<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#atrial-diastole" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Precedes ventricular diastolic and continues throughout most of the cycle (because it takes 0.7 s and the whole cycle is 0.6 s).</li>
<li>During this phase blood enters the atrial (versus return).</li>
<li>Accumulation of blood in atrial values atrial &amp; jugular venous pressures and produces "V" wave in atrial pressure curve and JVP curve ("V" for venous return).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ventricular-diastole">Ventricular diastole<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ventricular-diastole" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Ventricular diastole starts during atrial diastolic and filling of atrial with blood.</li>
<li>When the ventricles start to relax, the pressures inside them start to drop. When the ventricular pressures become lower than the pressures in aortic &amp; pulmonary arteries, the semilunar valves are closed to prevent return of blood back to the ventricles.</li>
<li>Closure of the semilunar valves results in the second heart sound "S2" (the sound is caused by turbulence of blood due to closure of the valves).</li>
<li>Then the ventricles continue to relax &amp; the pressures inside them continue to drop, while all valves are closed. This is the isovolumetric relaxation phase. It occurs immediately after S2.</li>
<li>When the pressures inside the ventricles become lower than the pressures in atria, the AV valves open. This allows passive filling of ventricles with blood that already filled atria during this period.</li>
<li>Then the atria contract to complete ventricular filling and to start a new cycle.</li>
</ul>
<p>200</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-heart-sounds">The Heart sounds<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-heart-sounds" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>These sounds are 4 sounds that result from refixation of blood flow within the heart during closure of the valves or rapid filling of the ventricles.</li>
<li>The fold two sounds are normal sounds, the third is normal in children and young adults and abnormal in older ages (indicates heart failure). The fourth sound is always abnormal (hypertension).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-first-heart-sound-s1">The first heart sound (S1)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-first-heart-sound-s1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Cleared by closure of the AV valves.</li>
<li>Closure at the beginning of ventricular systolic (i.e. at start of the isovolumetric contraction phase).</li>
<li>It is low pitched and more prolonged than S2.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-second-heart-sound-s2">The second heart sound (S2)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-second-heart-sound-s2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Cleared by closure of the semilunar valves.</li>
<li>Closure at the start of ventricular diastolic (i.e. at the start of the isovolumetric relaxation phase).</li>
<li>It is high pitched and takes less time than S1.</li>
<li>It may split into two components (aortic S2 and pulmonary S2).</li>
<li>In normal states, closure of aortic valve precedes closure of the pulmonary valve (i.e. aortic S2 precedes pulmonary S2).</li>
<li>Wide splitting of S2 occurs during deep inspiration, when closure of the pulmonary valve is delayed because the stroke volume is increased by the extra volume of blood delivered to the heart during deep inspiration (inspiration causes chest expansion, this decreases intra-thoracic pressure and increases venous return and therefore stroke volume).</li>
<li>Splitting of S2 decreases in expiration and pulmonary hypertension.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-third-heart-sound-s3">The third heart sound (S3)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-third-heart-sound-s3" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Cleared by rapid ventricular filling (turbulence of blood during passive filling of ventricles). It is normal in children and young adults (filling causes turbulence because the size of ventricles is small).</li>
</ul>
<p>201</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-heart-sounds">The heart sounds<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-heart-sounds" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Heart sounds are 4 sounds that result from turbulence of blood flow within the heart during closure of the valves or rapid filling of the ventricles.</li>
<li>The fold two sounds are normal sounds, the third is normal in children and young adults and abnormal in older ages (indicates heart failure). The fourth sound is always abnormal (hypertension).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-first-heart-sound-s1">The first heart sound (S1)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-first-heart-sound-s1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Cleared by closure of the AV valves.</li>
<li>Closure at the beginning of ventricular systolic (i.e. at start of the isovolumetric contraction phase).</li>
<li>It is low pitched and more prolonged than S2.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-second-heart-sound-s2">The second heart sound (S2)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-second-heart-sound-s2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Cleared by closure of the semilunar valves.</li>
<li>Closure at the start of ventricular diastolic (i.e. at the start of the isovolumetric relaxation phase).</li>
<li>It is high pitched and takes less time than S1.</li>
<li>It may split into two components (aortic S2 and pulmonary S2).</li>
<li>In normal states, closure of aortic valve precedes closure of the pulmonary valve (i.e. aortic S2 precedes pulmonary S2).</li>
<li>Wide splitting of S2 occurs during deep inspiration, when closure of the pulmonary valve is delayed because the stroke volume is increased by the extra volume of blood delivered to the heart during deep inspiration (inspiration causes chest expansion, this decreases intra-thoracic pressure and increases venous return and therefore stroke volume).</li>
<li>Splitting of S2 decreases in expiration and pulmonary hypertension.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-third-heart-sound-s3">The third heart sound (S3)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-third-heart-sound-s3" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Cleared by rapid ventricular filling (turbulence of blood during passive filling of ventricles). It is normal in children and young adults (filling causes turbulence because the size of ventricles is small).</li>
</ul>
<p>202</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-heart-sounds">The heart sounds<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-heart-sounds" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Heart sounds are 4 sounds that result from turbulence of blood flow within the heart during closure of the valves or rapid filling of the ventricles.</li>
<li>The fold two sounds are normal sounds, the third is normal in children and young adults and abnormal in older ages (indicates heart failure). The fourth sound is always abnormal (hypertension).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-first-heart-sound-s1">The first heart sound (S1)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-first-heart-sound-s1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Cleared by closure of the AV valves.</li>
<li>Closure at the beginning of ventricular systolic (i.e. at start of the isovolumetric contraction phase).</li>
<li>It is low pitched and more prolonged than S2.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-second-heart-sound-s2">The second heart sound (S2)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-second-heart-sound-s2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Cleared by closure of the semilunar valves.</li>
<li>Closure at the start of ventricular diastolic (i.e. at the start of the isovolumetric relaxation phase).</li>
<li>It is high pitched and takes less time than S1.</li>
<li>It may split into two components (aortic S2 and pulmonary S2).</li>
<li>In normal states, closure of aortic valve precedes closure of the pulmonary valve (i.e. aortic S2 precedes pulmonary S2).</li>
<li>Wide splitting of S2 occurs during deep inspiration, when closure of the pulmonary valve is delayed because the stroke volume is increased by the extra volume of blood delivered to the heart during deep inspiration (inspiration causes chest expansion, this decreases intra-thoracic pressure and increases venous return and therefore stroke volume).</li>
<li>Splitting of S2 decreases in expiration and pulmonary hypertension.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-third-heart-sound-s3">The third heart sound (S3)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-third-heart-sound-s3" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Cleared by rapid ventricular filling (turbulence of blood during passive filling of ventricles). It is normal in children and young adults (filling causes turbulence because the size of ventricles is small).</li>
</ul>
<p>203</p>
<p>The term of medical physiology*</p>
<ul>
<li>If indicates heart failure in adults because blood volume of passive thing is added to high and systolic volume in patients with heart failure (the end epeps volume is high in heart failure because of the weak ventricular contractions).</li>
<li>On auscultation, presence of 53 plus 61 &amp; 52 gives a characteristic sound described as "Galloping rhythm".</li>
<li>Galloping rhythm is an important sign of heart failure in adults.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-fourth-heart-sound-64">The fourth heart sound (64)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-fourth-heart-sound-64" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>54 is an abnormal sound. It is also known as atrial sound.</li>
<li>It is caused by atrial systole in patients suffering from hypertension.</li>
<li>In normal states, atrial systole does not cause a sound because ventricles expand to receive blood ejected by atrial systole; however, in a hypertensive patient, ventricular wall becomes stiff due to hypertrophy (because they act against resistance). That's why atrial systole results in turbulence of blood and generation of 54.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="abnormal-sounds">Abnormal sounds<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormal-sounds" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Abnormal musical sounds heard over the heart are known as murmurs. They are generated by turbulence of blood flow within the heart due to velvter lesions.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Abnormal sound heard over arteries is known as bruit (e.g. renal bruit due to renal artery stenosis (narrowing).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Abnormal sound heard over veins is known as venous hum.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Murmurs are either systolic or diastolic.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Systolic murmurs are caused by:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stenosis (narrowing) of semilunar valves</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Regurgitation (reflux or dilatation) of atrio-ventricular valves</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Diastolic murmurs are caused by:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stenosis (narrowing) of atrio-ventricular valves</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Regurgitation (reflux or dilatation) of semilunar valves</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For example mitral (or tricuspid) stenosis causes mid diastolic murmur and aortic (or pulmonary) regurgitation causes early diastolic murmur whereas mitral (or pulmonary) regurgitation causes early diastolic murmur.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If indicates heart failure in adults because blood volume of passive thing is added to high and systolic volume in patients with heart failure (the end epeps volume is high in heart failure because of the weak ventricular contractions).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>On auscultation, presence of 53 plus 61 &amp; 52 gives a characteristic sound described as "Galloping rhythm".</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Galloping rhythm is an important sign of heart failure in adults.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-fourth-heart-sound-64">The fourth heart sound (64)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-fourth-heart-sound-64" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>54 is an abnormal sound. It is also known as atrial sound.</li>
<li>It is caused by atrial systole in patients suffering from hypertension.</li>
<li>In normal states, atrial systole does not cause a sound because ventricles expand to receive blood ejected by atrial systole; however, in a hypertensive patient, ventricular wall becomes stiff due to hypertrophy (because they act against resistance). That's why atrial systole results in turbulence of blood and generation of 54.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="abnormal-sounds">Abnormal sounds<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormal-sounds" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Abnormal musical sounds heard over the heart are known as murmurs. They are generated by turbulence of blood flow within the heart due to velvter lesions.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Abnormal sound heard over arteries is known as bruit (e.g. renal bruit due to renal artery stenosis (narrowing).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Abnormal sound heard over veins is known as venous hum.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Murmurs are either systolic or diastolic.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Systolic murmurs are caused by:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stenosis (narrowing) of semilunar valves</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Regurgitation (reflux or dilatation) of atrio-ventricular valves</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Diastolic murmurs are caused by:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stenosis (narrowing) of atrio-ventricular valves</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Regurgitation (reflux or dilatation) of semilunar valves</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For example mitral (or tricuspid) stenosis causes mid diastolic murmur and aortic (or pulmonary) regurgitation causes early diastolic murmur whereas mitral (or pulmonary) regurgitation causes early diastolic murmur</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If indicates heart failure in adults because blood volume of passive thing is added to high and systolic volume in patients with heart failure (the end epeps volume is high in heart failure because of the weak ventricular contractions).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>On auscultation, presence of 53 plus 61 &amp; 52 gives a characteristic sound described as "Galloping rhythm".</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Galloping rhythm is an important sign of heart failure in adults.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-fourth-heart-sound-64">The fourth heart sound (64)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-fourth-heart-sound-64" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>54 is an abnormal sound. It is also known as atrial sound.</li>
<li>It is caused by atrial systole in patients suffering from hypertension.</li>
<li>In normal states, atrial systole does not cause a sound because ventricles expand to receive blood ejected by atrial systole; however, in a hypertensive patient, ventricular wall becomes stiff due to hypertrophy (because they act against resistance). That's why atrial systole results in turbulence of blood and generation of 54.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="abnormal-sounds">Abnormal sounds<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormal-sounds" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Abnormal musical sounds heard over the heart are known as murmurs. They are generated by turbulence of blood flow within the heart due to velvter lesions.</li>
<li>Abnormal sound heard over arteries is known as bruit (e.g. renal bruit due to renal artery stenosis (narrowing).</li>
<li>Abnormal sound heard over veins is known as venous hum.</li>
<li>Murmurs are either systolic or diastolic.</li>
<li>Systolic murmurs are caused by:</li>
<li>Stenosis (narrowing) of semilunar valves</li>
<li>Regurgitation (reflux or dilatation) of atrio-ventricular valves</li>
<li>Diastolic murmurs are caused by:</li>
<li>Stenosis (narrowing) of atrio-ventricular valves</li>
<li>Regurgitation (reflux or dilatation) of semilunar valves</li>
<li>For example mitral (or tricuspid) stenosis causes mid diastolic murmur and aortic (or pulmonary) regurgitation causes early diastolic murmur whereas mitral (or pulmonary) regurgitation causes early diastolic murmur</li>
</ul>
<p>(or tricuspid) regurgitation causes pan-systolic murmur and aortic (or pulmonary) stenosis causes ejection systolic murmur.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pressure-volume-curves-of-the-ventricles">Pressure volume curves of the ventricles<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pressure-volume-curves-of-the-ventricles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This curve summarizes various events in the cardiac cycle. The Y axis represents pressure whereas X axis represents volume. The following figure describes the curve of the left ventricle.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Fig 6.90: The pressure volume curve of the left ventricle</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-bfbd7a32.jpeg" alt="img-293.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>In the above curve:</li>
<li>A represents: passive ventricular filling</li>
<li>B represents: atrial systole</li>
<li>C represents: isovolumetric contraction</li>
<li>D represents: rapid ejection phase</li>
<li>E represents: isovolumetric relaxation</li>
<li>Gp1 represents: opening of AV valves</li>
<li>Gp2 represents: opening of semilunar valves</li>
<li>S1-4 represents: sites of heart sounds</li>
<li>50 ml = End systolic volume</li>
<li>120 ml = End diastolic volume</li>
</ul>
<p>(or tricuspid) regurgitation causes pan-systolic murmur and aortic (or pulmonary) stenosis causes ejection systolic murmur.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pressure-volume-curves-of-the-ventricles">Pressure volume curves of the ventricles<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pressure-volume-curves-of-the-ventricles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This curve summarizes various events in the cardiac cycle. The Y axis represents pressure whereas X axis represents volume. The following figure describes the curve of the left ventricle.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Fig 6.90: The pressure volume curve of the left ventricle</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-3d0133ee.jpeg" alt="img-294.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>In the above curve:</li>
<li>A represents: passive ventricular filling</li>
<li>B represents: atrial systole</li>
<li>C represents: isovolumetric contraction</li>
<li>D represents: rapid ejection phase</li>
<li>E represents: isovolumetric relaxation</li>
<li>Gp1 represents: opening of AV valves</li>
<li>Gp2 represents: opening of semilunar valves</li>
<li>S1-4 represents: sites of heart sounds</li>
<li>50 ml = End systolic volume</li>
<li>120 ml = End diastolic volume</li>
</ul>
<p>(or tricuspid) regurgitation causes pan-systolic murmur and aortic (or pulmonary) stenosis causes ejection systolic murmur.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pressure-volume-curves-of-the-ventricles">Pressure volume curves of the ventricles<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pressure-volume-curves-of-the-ventricles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This curve summarizes various events in the cardiac cycle. The Y axis represents pressure whereas X axis represents volume. The following figure describes the curve of the left ventricle.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Fig 6.90: The pressure volume curve of the left ventricle</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-47296fe5.jpeg" alt="img-295.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>In the above curve:</li>
<li>A represents: passive ventricular filling</li>
<li>B represents: atrial systole</li>
<li>C represents: isovolumetric contraction</li>
<li>D represents: rapid ejection phase</li>
<li>E represents: isovolumetric relaxation</li>
<li>Gp1 represents: opening of AV valves</li>
<li>Gp2 represents: opening of semilunar valves</li>
<li>S1-4 represents: sites of heart sounds</li>
<li>50 ml = End systolic volume</li>
<li>120 ml = End diastolic volume</li>
</ul>
<p>The work of Marshall and Schirmer is published.</p>
<p>234
The <a href="http://www.cif-calidad.edu/ecs/agc/27/edition" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.cif-calidad.edu/ecs/agc/27/edition</a></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-cardiac-output">THE CARDIAC OUTPUT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-cardiac-output" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="definition">Definition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Volume of blood ejected by each ventricle each minute (not both ventricles). It is about 5 L/min in an average adult male, at rest (less in females and more during exercise).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The cardiac index (CI) is sometimes calculated to compare between subjects. It equals (COP/surface area) e.g. Cardiac index in adults = 5 / 1.0 = 3.1 L/m². CI in children is higher because surface area is smaller.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="measurement">Measurement<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#measurement" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Many methods can be used for measurement of the cardiac output. - These include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Indirect methods (like indicator dilution technique, Fick principle and thermodilution method)</li>
<li>Direct methods (using electromagnetic or ultrasonic flow-meter devices).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="indicator-dilution-technique-or-hamilton-dye-method">Indicator dilution technique or Hamilton dye method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#indicator-dilution-technique-or-hamilton-dye-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>In this method, Q amount of a dye is injected in an arm vein; then serial arterial samples are obtained from a peripheral artery to measure the concentration of the dye as it is ejected from the heart to the systemic arteries.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The concentrations are plotted in a graph paper against time.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The resulting curve shows that the concentrations increase to a maximum, and then they start to decrease and then increase again because of recirculation of the dye (look at figure 9.31).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The descending limb at point (x) is extrapolated to the X axis to obtain the time of one circulation (t). The area under the curve is used to calculate the average concentration (C).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Then the COP can be obtained in (L/min) as follows:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>COP</mtext><mo>=</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>Q</mtext><mo>×</mo><mtext>SD</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>C</mtext><mo>×</mo><mtext>t</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{COP} = (\text{Q} \times \text{SD}) / (\text{C} \times \text{t})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">COP</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Q</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">SD</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">C</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">t</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>235
The <a href="http://www.cif-calidad.edu/ecs/agc/27/edition" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.cif-calidad.edu/ecs/agc/27/edition</a></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-cardiac-output">THE CARDIAC OUTPUT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-cardiac-output" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="definition">Definition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Volume of blood ejected by each ventricle each minute (not both ventricles). It is about 5 L/min in an average adult male, at rest (less in females and more during exercise).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The cardiac index (CI) is sometimes calculated to compare between subjects. It equals (COP/surface area) e.g. Cardiac index in adults = 5 / 1.0 = 3.1 L/m². CI in children is higher because surface area is smaller.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="measurement">Measurement<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#measurement" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Many methods can be used for measurement of the cardiac output. - These include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Indirect methods (like indicator dilution technique, Fick principle and thermodilution method)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Direct methods (using electromagnetic or ultrasonic flow-meter devices).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="indicator-dilution-technique-or-hamilton-dye-method">Indicator dilution technique or Hamilton dye method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#indicator-dilution-technique-or-hamilton-dye-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>In this method, Q amount of a dye is injected in an arm vein; then serial arterial samples are obtained from a peripheral artery to measure the concentration of the dye as it is ejected from the heart to the systemic arteries.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The concentrations are plotted in a graph paper against time.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The resulting curve shows that the concentrations increase to a maximum, and then they start to decrease and then increase again because of recirculation of the dye (look at figure 9.31).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The descending limb at point (x) is extrapolated to the X axis to obtain the time of one circulation (t). The area under the curve is used to calculate the average concentration (C).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Then the COP can be obtained in (L/min) as follows:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>COP</mtext><mo>=</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>Q</mtext><mo>×</mo><mtext>SD</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>C</mtext><mo>×</mo><mtext>t</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{COP} = (\text{Q} \times \text{SD}) / (\text{C} \times \text{t})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">COP</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Q</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">SD</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">C</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">t</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>236
The <a href="http://www.cif-calidad.edu/ecs/agc/27/edition" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.cif-calidad.edu/ecs/agc/27/edition</a></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-cardiac-output">THE CARDIAC OUTPUT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-cardiac-output" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="definition">Definition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Volume of blood ejected by each ventricle each minute (not both ventricles). It is about 5 L/min in an average adult male, at rest (less in females and more during exercise).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The cardiac index (CI) is sometimes calculated to compare between subjects. It equals (COP/surface area) e.g. Cardiac index in adults = 5 / 1.0 = 3.1 L/m². CI in children is higher because surface area is smaller.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="measurement">Measurement<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#measurement" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Many methods can be used for measurement of the cardiac output. - These include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Indirect methods (like indicator dilution technique, Fick principle and thermodilution method)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Direct methods (using electromagnetic or ultrasonic flow-meter devices).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="indicator-dilution-technique-or-hamilton-dye-method">Indicator dilution technique or Hamilton dye method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#indicator-dilution-technique-or-hamilton-dye-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>In this method, Q amount of a dye is injected in an arm vein; then serial arterial samples are obtained from a peripheral artery to measure the concentration of the dye as it is ejected from the heart to the systemic arteries.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The concentrations are plotted in a graph paper against time.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The resulting curve shows that the concentrations increase to a maximum, and then they start to decrease and then increase again because of recirculation of the dye (look at figure 9.31).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The descending limb at point (x) is extrapolated to the X axis to obtain the time of one circulation (t). The area under the curve is used to calculate the average concentration (C).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Then the COP can be obtained in (L/min) as follows:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>COP</mtext><mo>=</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>Q</mtext><mo>×</mo><mtext>SD</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>C</mtext><mo>×</mo><mtext>t</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{COP} = (\text{Q} \times \text{SD}) / (\text{C} \times \text{t})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">COP</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Q</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">SD</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">C</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">t</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>237
The <a href="http://www.cif-calidad.edu/ecs/agc/27/edition" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.cif-calidad.edu/ecs/agc/27/edition</a></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-a3003ed6.jpeg" alt="img-296.jpeg">
Fig 4.31: Hamilton dye dilution method</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pick-principle">Pick principle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pick-principle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Pick principle is commonly used for measurement of blood flow to organs (e.g. renal blood flow, cerebral blood flow, liver blood flow ...).</li>
<li>It states that "the amount of a substance consumed (or added) by an organ in a given time equals the arterial-versus difference in concentration times the blood flow to the organ.</li>
<li>Is summary: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mo>=</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>A</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mo>−</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>V</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">Q = [A] - [V] \times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">Q</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span> Blood flow to the organ (where <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">Q =</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">Q</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span></span></span></span></span> the quantity of a substance consumed by the organ, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>A</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">[A]</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span><span class="mclose">]</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>V</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">[V]</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="mclose">]</span></span></span></span></span> are the concentrations of the substance in the artery supplying and the vein draining the organ respectively and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>A</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mo>−</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>V</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">[A] - [V]</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="mclose">]</span></span></span></span></span> is the arterial-versus difference in concentration.</li>
<li>From the above principle the blood flow can be calculated as follows: Blood flow = <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>A</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mo>−</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>V</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">Q / [A] - [V]</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">Q</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="mclose">]</span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li>If the lungs are taken as an organ, then blood flow = the cardiac output from the right ventricle + the cardiac output (melse definition of COP). Therefore COP = <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>A</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mo>−</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>V</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">Q / [A] - [V]</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">Q</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="mclose">]</span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li>The substance consumed (actually added) by the lungs is oxygen.</li>
<li>Oxygen added by the lungs = 250 ml oxygen/min, measured by spirometer.</li>
</ul>
<p>213</p>
<p>The ratio of different group settings is 4:7, unknown.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-02820abe.jpeg" alt="img-297.jpeg">
Fig 4.31: Hamilton dye dilution method</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pick-principle">Pick principle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pick-principle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Pick principle is commonly used for measurement of blood flow to organs (e.g. renal blood flow, cerebral blood flow, liver blood flow ...).</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pick-principle">Pick principle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pick-principle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>Pick principle is commonly used for measurement of blood flow to organs (e.g. renal blood flow, cerebral blood flow, liver blood flow ...).</li>

vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="mclose">]</span></span></span></span></span> are the concentrations of the substance in the artery supplying and the vein draining the organ respectively and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>A</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mo>−</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>V</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">[A] - [V]</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="mclose">]</span></span></span></span></span> is the arterial-versus difference in concentration.</li>
<li>From the above principle the blood flow can be calculated as follows: Blood flow = <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>A</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mo>−</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>V</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">Q / [A] - [V]</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">Q</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="mclose">]</span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li>If the lungs are taken as an organ, then blood flow = the cardiac output from the right ventricle + the cardiac output (melse definition of COP). Therefore COP = <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>A</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mo>−</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>V</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">Q / [A] - [V]</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">Q</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="mclose">]</span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li>The substance consumed (actually added) by the lungs is oxygen.</li>
<li>Oxygen added by the lungs = 250 ml oxygen/min, measured by spirometer.</li>
</ul>
<p>221</p>
<p>The ratio of different group settings is 4:7, unknown.</p>
<ul>
<li>Oxygen concentration in the pulmonary artery (carrying deoxygenated blood) = 150 ml oxygen/L blood (measured using a catheter introduced into the pulmonary artery).</li>
<li>Oxygen concentration in the pulmonary vein (carrying oxygenated blood) = 200 ml oxygen/L blood (measured from any peripheral artery because all arteries have the same concentration of oxygen).</li>
<li>Remember that oxygen concentration in the deoxygenated blood of the pulmonary artery is not taken from peripheral veins.</li>
<li>By applying the above values to the formula</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>COP</mtext><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>N</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mo>−</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>V</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mi>V</mi></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{COP} = \frac{Q \cdot [N] - [V]}{V}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">COP</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.113em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.427em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">Q</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋅</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="mclose">]</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>COP = 200 ml oxygen/min / [50 ml oxygen/L]</p>
<p>(Where 50 is the arterial-venous difference between 150 and 200 ml oxygen/L; therefore the COP = 5 L/min.)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="thermo-dilution-techniques">Thermo-dilution techniques<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thermo-dilution-techniques" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This is similar to the dilution method.</li>
<li>A cold saline is injected as an indicator in the right atrium and the change in blood temperature within the pulmonary artery is used for calculation of the COP.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="direct-methods">Direct methods<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#direct-methods" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Used mainly in experimental animals.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Here surgery is needed to enter the heart through great arteries or veins and measure the cardiac output directly using a flow-meter device (electromagnetic or ultrasonic flow-meter device).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Oxygen concentration in the pulmonary artery (carrying deoxygenated blood) = 150 ml oxygen/L blood (measured using a catheter introduced into the pulmonary artery).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Oxygen concentration in the pulmonary vein (carrying oxygenated blood) = 200 ml oxygen/L blood (measured from any peripheral artery because all arteries have the same concentration of oxygen).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Remember that oxygen concentration in the deoxygenated blood of the pulmonary artery is not taken from peripheral veins.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>By applying the above values to the formula</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>COP</mtext><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>N</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mo>−</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>V</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mi>V</mi></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{COP} = \frac{Q \cdot [N] - [V]}{V}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">COP</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.113em; <p>COP = 250 ml oxygen/min / [50 ml oxygen/L]</p>
<p>(Where 50 is the arterial-venous difference between 150 and 200 ml oxygen/L; therefore the COP = 5 L/min.)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="thermo-dilution-techniques">Thermo-dilution techniques<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thermo-dilution-techniques" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="direct-methods">Direct methods<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#direct-methods" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
