<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>COP</mtext><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>N</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mo>−</mo><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>V</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mi>V</mi></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{COP} = \frac{Q \cdot [N] - [V]}{V}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">COP</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.113em; <div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="thermo-dilution-techniques">Thermo-dilution techniques<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thermo-dilution-techniques" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<li>A cold saline is injected as an indicator in the right atrium and the change in blood temperature within the pulmonary artery is used for calculation of the COP.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="direct-methods">Direct methods<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#direct-methods" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Used mainly in experimental animals.</li>
<li>Here surgery is needed to enter the heart through great arteries or veins and measure the cardiac output directly using a flow-meter device (electromagnetic or ultrasonic flow-meter device).</li>
</ul>
<p>270
The cost of medical physiology of others
271
The cost of medical physiology of others</p>
<p>226</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="card-of-the-cop">CARD OF THE COP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#card-of-the-cop" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The COP = heart rate x stroke volume.</p>
<ul>
<li>0 L/min = 72 beat/min x 70 ml/beat.</li>
<li>Therefore, the two factors that control the COP are the heart rate &amp; stroke volume.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="control-of-the-heart-rate-hr">Control of the heart rate (HR)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-the-heart-rate-hr" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The heart rate is the number of cardiac beats per minute.</li>
<li>It ranges between 60 &amp; 100 beats per min; the average is about 72 beat/min at rest; however, normal heart rate differs according to age (in neonates+infants+children+adults).</li>
<li>In normal adults, a value less than 60 beat/min is described as bradycardia whereas a value more than 100 beat/min is described as tachycardia.</li>
<li>The term positive chronotropic effect is used to describe increase in heart rate whereas negative chronotropic effect describes the reverse.</li>
<li>Remember that, when the heart rate is increased, the time for ventricular filling is decreased and therefore the stroke volume is decreased, this occurs if contractility of the heart is not affected; however, when contractility is also increased, the stroke volume is increased (i.e. factors that increase the heart rate &amp; contractility increase the stroke volume; whereas factors that increase the heart rate alone: decrease the stroke volume).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="factors-affecting-the-hr-are">Factors affecting the HR are:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#factors-affecting-the-hr-are" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="neural-factors">Neural factors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#neural-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Sympathetic neurons</li>
<li>Release noradrenaline to act on beta 1 receptors</li>
<li>Activated by stress (fear, pain, emotions...)</li>
<li>Increase heart rate (positive chronotropic effect)</li>
<li>Chemoreceptors</li>
</ul>
<p>227</p>
<p>The use of medical physiology 1st edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="card-of-the-cop">CARD OF THE COP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#card-of-the-cop" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The COP = heart rate x stroke volume.</p>
<ul>
<li>0 L/min = 72 beat/min x 70 ml/beat.</li>
<li>Therefore, the two factors that control the COP are the heart rate &amp; stroke volume.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="control-of-the-heart-rate-hr">Control of the heart rate (HR)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-the-heart-rate-hr" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The heart rate is the number of cardiac beats per minute.</li>
<li>It ranges between 60 &amp; 100 beats per min; the average is about 72 beat/min at rest; however, normal heart rate differs according to age (in neonates+infants+children+adults).</li>
<li>In normal adults, a value less than 60 beat/min is described as bradycardia whereas a value more than 100 beat/min is described as tachycardia.</li>
<li>The term positive chronotropic effect is used to describe increase in heart rate whereas negative chronotropic effect describes the reverse.</li>
<li>Remember that, when the heart rate is increased, the time for ventricular filling is decreased and therefore the stroke volume is decreased, this occurs if contractility of the heart is not affected; however, when contractility is also increased, the stroke volume is increased (i.e. factors that increase the heart rate &amp; contractility increase the stroke volume; whereas factors that increase the heart rate alone: decrease the stroke volume).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="factors-affecting-the-hr-are">Factors affecting the HR are:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#factors-affecting-the-hr-are" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="neural-factors">Neural factors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#neural-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Sympathetic neurons</li>
<li>Release noradrenaline to act on beta 1 receptors</li>
<li>Activated by stress (fear, pain, emotions...)</li>
<li>Increase heart rate (positive chronotropic effect)</li>
<li>Chemoreceptors</li>
</ul>
<p>228</p>
<p>The use of medical physiology 1st edition</p>
<ul>
<li>Chemical receptors found in aortic bodies (in aortic arch) &amp; carotid bodies (in carotid bifurcation).</li>
<li>Stimulated by hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis</li>
<li>Increase heart rate (positive chronotropic effect)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Bainbridge effect or reflex</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Increase in heart rate (positive chronotropic effect) due to increase in venous return that initiates a reflex or effect as follows:</li>
<li>The reflex is initiated in receptors in the right atrium and integrated in the medulla. It results in stimulation of the SA node to increase its rate of discharge (Bainbridge reflex)</li>
<li>The effect is a direct mechanical effect of the blood on the SA node to increase its rate of discharge (Bainbridge effect)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Parasympathetic neurons</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Reduces acetylcholine to act on muscarinic receptors.</li>
<li>Activated by rest and sleep</li>
<li>Decrease heart rate (negative chronotropic effect)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Bifurcocapter reflexes</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Stretch receptors found in aortic sinus (in aortic arch) &amp; carotid sinus (in carotid bifurcation).</li>
<li>Stimulated by elevation in blood pressure.</li>
<li>Decrease heart rate (negative chronotropic effect)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Hormonal factors:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Many hormones have positive chronotropic effect</li>
<li>Examples include catecholamines &amp; thyroid hormones.</li>
<li>Thyroid hormones act indirectly by increasing number and affinity of beta1 receptors in the heart to catecholamines.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Physiological factors</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>HR is increased by exercise (which is associated with sympathetic stimulation due to physical stress or excitement "emotions")</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If the during sleep (which is associated with parasympathetic stimulation)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Chemical receptors found in aortic bodies (in aortic arch) &amp; carotid bodies (in carotid bifurcation).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stimulated by hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Increase heart rate (positive chronotropic effect)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Bainbridge effect or reflex</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Increase in heart rate (positive chronotropic effect) due to increase in venous return that initiates a reflex or effect as follows:</li>
<li>The reflex is initiated in receptors in the right atrium and integrated in the medulla. It results in stimulation of the SA node to increase its rate of discharge (Bainbridge reflex)</li>
<li>The effect is a direct mechanical effect of the blood on the SA node to increase its rate of discharge (Bainbridge effect)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Parasympathetic neurons</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Reduces acetylcholine to act on muscarinic receptors.</li>
<li>Activated by rest and sleep</li>
<li>Decrease heart rate (negative chronotropic effect)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Bifurcocapter reflexes</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Stretch receptors found in aortic sinus (in aortic arch) &amp; carotid sinus (in carotid bifurcation).</li>
<li>Stimulated by elevation in blood pressure.</li>
<li>Decrease heart rate (negative chronotropic effect)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Hormonal factors:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Many hormones have positive chronotropic effect.</li>
<li>Examples include catecholamines &amp; thyroid hormones.</li>
<li>Thyroid hormones act indirectly by increasing number and affinity of beta1 receptors in the heart to catecholamines.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Physiological factors</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>HR is increased by exercise (which is associated with sympathetic stimulation due to physical stress or excitement "emotions")</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If the during sleep (which is associated with parasympathetic stimulation)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Chemical receptors found in aortic bodies (in aortic arch) &amp; carotid bodies (in carotid bifurcation).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stimulated by hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Increase heart rate (positive chronotropic effect)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Bainbridge effect or reflex</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Increase in heart rate (positive chronotropic effect) due to increase in venous return that initiates a reflex or effect as follows:</li>
<li>The reflex is initiated in receptors in the right atrium and integrated in the medulla. It results in stimulation of the SA node to increase its rate of discharge (Bainbridge reflex)</li>
<li>The effect is a direct mechanical effect of the blood on the SA node to increase its rate of discharge (Bainbridge effect)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Parasympathetic neurons</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Reduces acetylcholine to act on muscarinic receptors.</li>
<li>Activated by rest and sleep</li>
<li>Decrease heart rate (negative chronotropic effect)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Bifurcocapter reflexes</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Stretch receptors found in aortic sinus (in aortic arch) &amp; carotid sinus (in carotid bifurcation).</li>
<li>Stimulated by elevation in blood pressure.</li>
<li>Decrease heart rate (negative chronotropic effect)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Hormonal factors:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Many hormones have positive chronotropic effect.</li>
<li>Examples include catecholamines &amp; thyroid hormones.</li>
<li>Thyroid hormones act indirectly by increasing number and affinity of beta1 receptors in the heart to catecholamines.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Physiological factors</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>HR is increased by exercise (which is associated with sympathetic stimulation due to physical stress or excitement "emotions")</li>
<li>If the during sleep (which is associated with parasympathetic stimulation)</li>
</ul>
<p>1/3</p>
<p>224
The view of medical pharmacology: 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="physical-factors">Physical factors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Changes in body temperature due to hot or cold environment or due to fever or hypothermia; effect heart rate.</li>
<li>Elevation in body temperature by one degree centigrade increases heart rate by about 15 beat/min whereas reduction in body temperature does the reverse.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="drugs">Drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Atropine (muscarinic blocker):</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Blocks the parasympathetic, that's why it increases the heart rate.</li>
<li>It is used in cases of cardiac asystole.</li>
<li>Atenolol &amp; propranolol (beta blockers).</li>
<li>Both drugs decrease HR by blocking beta 1 receptors in SA node. - Atenolol is selective beta blocker (blocks beta1) whereas propranolol is non-selective beta blocker (blocks both beta 1&amp;2).</li>
<li>Salbutamol is a commonly used drug for treatment of asthma. It is a beta 2 agonist. Therefore, it should not increase the heart rate; however, the drug has some effect on beta1 receptors, that's why it increases the heart rate as a side effect.</li>
<li>Cisplatin (anti arrhythmic drug that slows conduction).</li>
<li>Decreases the heart rate because it slows the conductive system.</li>
<li>It increases entry of calcium in cardiac muscle (through a mechanism that involves inhibition of the Na⁺/K⁺ pump). That's why it increases contractility of the heart.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="control-of-the-stroke-volume-sv">Control of the stroke volume (SV)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-the-stroke-volume-sv" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Defined as the volume of blood ejected by each ventricle each beat.</li>
<li>Normal value is about 70 ml (in an average adult male, at rest); however, it differs according to age, sex and physiological state.</li>
<li>It is smaller in neonates &lt; infants &lt; older children &lt; adults due to gradual increase in the size of the heart with normal development.</li>
</ul>
<p>225
The view of medical pharmacology: 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="physical-factors">Physical factors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Changes in body temperature due to hot or cold environment or due to fever or hypothermia; effect heart rate.</li>
<li>Elevation in body temperature by one degree centigrade increases heart rate by about 15 beat/min whereas reduction in body temperature does the reverse.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="drugs">Drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Atropine (muscarinic blocker):</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Blocks the parasympathetic, that's why it increases the heart rate.</li>
<li>It is used in cases of cardiac asystole.</li>
<li>Atenolol &amp; propranolol (beta blockers).</li>
<li>Both drugs decrease HR by blocking beta 1 receptors in SA node. - Atenolol is selective beta blocker (blocks beta1) whereas propranolol is non-selective beta blocker (blocks both beta 1&amp;2).</li>
<li>Salbutamol is a commonly used drug for treatment of asthma. It is a beta 2 agonist. Therefore, it should not increase the heart rate; however, the drug has some effect on beta1 receptors, that's why it increases the heart rate as a side effect.</li>
<li>Cisplatin (anti arrhythmic drug that slows conduction).</li>
<li>Decreases the heart rate because it slows the conductive system.</li>
<li>It increases entry of calcium in cardiac muscle (through a mechanism that involves inhibition of the Na⁺/K⁺ pump). That's why it increases contractility of the heart.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="control-of-the-stroke-volume-sv">Control of the stroke volume (SV)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-the-stroke-volume-sv" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Defined as the volume of blood ejected by each ventricle each beat.</li>
<li>Normal value is about 70 ml (in an average adult male, at rest); however, it differs according to age, sex and physiological state.</li>
<li>It is smaller in neonates &lt; infants &lt; older children &lt; adults due to gradual increase in the size of the heart with normal development.</li>
</ul>
<p>226
The view of medical pharmacology: 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="physical-factors">Physical factors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Changes in body temperature (due to hot or cold environment or due to fever or hypothermia) effect heart rate.</li>
<li>Elevation in body temperature by one degree centigrade increases heart rate by about 15 beat/min whereas reduction in body temperature does the reverse.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="drugs">Drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Atropine (muscarinic blocker):</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Blocks the parasympathetic, that's why it increases the heart rate.</li>
<li>It is used in cases of cardiac asystole.</li>
<li>Atenolol &amp; propranolol (beta blockers).</li>
<li>Both drugs decrease HR by blocking beta 1 receptors in SA node. - Atenolol is selective beta blocker (blocks beta1) whereas propranolol is non-selective beta blocker (blocks both beta 1&amp;2).</li>
<li>Salbutamol is a commonly used drug for treatment of asthma. It is a beta 2 agonist. Therefore, it should not increase the heart rate; however, the drug has some effect on beta1 receptors, that's why it increases the heart rate as a side effect.</li>
<li>Cisplatin (anti arrhythmic drug that slows conduction).</li>
<li>Decreases the heart rate because it slows the conductive system.</li>
<li>It increases entry of calcium in cardiac muscle (through a mechanism that involves inhibition of the Na⁺/K⁺ pump). That's why it increases contractility of the heart.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="control-of-the-stroke-volume-sv">Control of the stroke volume (SV)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-the-stroke-volume-sv" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Defined as the volume of blood ejected by each ventricle each beat.</li>
<li>Normal value is about 70 ml (in an average adult male, at rest); however, it differs according to age, sex and physiological state.</li>
<li>It is smaller in neonates &lt; infants &lt; older children &lt; adults due to gradual increase in the size of the heart with normal development.</li>
</ul>
<p>240
The case of medical physiology of science</p>
<ul>
<li>The stroke volume is larger in males compared to equivalent female of the same age and body size because the heart is adapted to eject more blood to more active tissues in males (muscles) compared to more inactive tissues in females (fals).</li>
<li>During stress (syndrome, pain, hypoglycemia &amp; exercise), the sympathetic nervous system is activated resulting in increased contractility of the heart, this increases stroke volume. At rest, the stroke volume returns to its normal value 70 ml.</li>
<li>The term positive inotropic effect is used to describe increase in contractility of the heart whereas negative inotropic effect describes the reverse.</li>
<li>When contractility of the heart is increased, subjects become aware of the heart beating, this is described as 'preposition'.</li>
<li>Remember that when contractility of the heart is increased, the stroke volume is increased whereas the end systolic volume is decreased.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="factors-affecting-sv-are">Factors affecting SV are:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#factors-affecting-sv-are" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="neural-factors">Neural factors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#neural-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Sympathetic neurons</li>
<li>Increase the stroke volume (positive inotropic effect).</li>
<li>Chemoreceptors</li>
<li>Increase the stroke volume (positive inotropic effect).</li>
<li>Parasympathetic neurons</li>
<li>Do not supply ventricles of the heart. Therefore they have no direct effect on contractility of the heart or stroke volume.</li>
<li>Baroreceptor reflexes</li>
<li>Decrease the stroke volume (negative inotropic effect).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="hormonal-factors">Hormonal factors:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hormonal-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Many hormones have positive inotropic effect.</li>
<li>Examples include catecholamines &amp; thyroid hormones.</li>
</ul>
<p>241
The case of medical physiology of science</p>
<ul>
<li>The stroke volume is larger in males compared to equivalent female of the same age and body size because the heart is adapted to eject more blood to more active tissues in males (muscles) compared to more inactive tissues in females (fals).</li>
<li>During stress (syndrome, pain, hypoglycemia &amp; exercise), the sympathetic nervous system is activated resulting in increased contractility of the heart, this increases stroke volume. At rest, the stroke volume returns to its normal value 70 ml.</li>
<li>The term positive inotropic effect is used to describe increase in contractility of the heart whereas negative inotropic effect describes the reverse.</li>
<li>When contractility of the heart is increased, subjects become aware of the heart beating, this is described as 'preposition'.</li>
<li>Remember that when contractility of the heart is increased, the stroke volume is increased whereas the end systolic volume is decreased.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="factors-affecting-sv-are">Factors affecting SV are:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#factors-affecting-sv-are" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="neural-factors">Neural factors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#neural-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Sympathetic neurons</li>
<li>Increase the stroke volume (positive inotropic effect).</li>
<li>Chemoreceptors</li>
<li>Increase the stroke volume (positive inotropic effect).</li>
<li>Parasympathetic neurons</li>
<li>Do not supply ventricles of the heart. Therefore they have no direct effect on contractility of the heart or stroke volume.</li>
<li>Baroreceptor reflexes</li>
<li>Decrease the stroke volume (negative inotropic effect).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="hormonal-factors">Hormonal factors:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hormonal-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Many hormones have positive inotropic effect.</li>
<li>Examples include catecholamines &amp; thyroid hormones.</li>
</ul>
<p>242
The case of medical physiology of science</p>
<ul>
<li>Thyroid hormones act indirectly by increasing number and affinity of beta1 receptors in the ventricles to catecholamines.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physiological-factors">Physiological factors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physiological-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>SV is increased by exercise (positive inotropic effect).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physical-factors">Physical factors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Changes in body temperature (due to hot or cold environment or due to fever or hypothermia) have direct effect on contractility.</li>
<li>High temperature increases the stroke volume (positive inotropic effect); whereas low temperature does the reverse.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="drugs">Drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Atropine (muscarinic blocker)</li>
<li>Blocks the parasympathetic that's why it has no direct effect on contractility and stroke volume.</li>
<li>Atenolol &amp; propranolol (beta blockers)</li>
<li>Both drugs decrease SV by blocking beta 1 receptors in ventricles. They are commonly prescribed for patients with IHD because they decrease cardiac contractility and therefore decrease the need for oxygen by cardiac muscle.</li>
<li>Digitalis (anti arrhythmic drug that allows conductance)</li>
<li>Increases entry of calcium in cardiac muscle (it inhibits the Na/K ATPase pump resulting in accumulation of sodium in cells. This increases a sodium calcium antiprot pump which takes calcium to outside in exchange to sodium. Calcium increases contractility and therefore SV</li>
<li>Digitalis also decreases heart rate and gives ventricles extra time for filling. This increases the end diastolic volume and therefore the SV is increased (by Frank-Eberling law described below).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="calcium-ions">Calcium ions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calcium-ions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>SV is increased by calcium ions (positive inotropic effect)</li>
<li>Severe hypercalcemia is fatal. It stops the heart in systole.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="preload-after-load">Preload &amp; after load<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preload-after-load" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="preload">Preload<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preload" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>512</p>
<p>Ear over 45 (without precoating) 14" column</p>
<ul>
<li>Thyroid hormones act indirectly by increasing number and affinity of beta1 receptors in the ventricles to catecholamines.</li>
</ul>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="drugs">Drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="calcium-ions">Calcium ions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calcium-ions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="preload-after-load">Preload &amp; after load<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preload-after-load" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="drugs">Drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<li>Blocks the parasympathetic that's why it has no direct effect on contractility and stroke volume.</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="calcium-ions">Calcium ions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calcium-ions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="preload-after-load">Preload &amp; after load<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preload-after-load" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="preload">Preload<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preload" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>545</p>
<p>The area of preload (pH) is a factor of 1000000</p>
<p>240
The view of medical physiology: 4th edition</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>It is the lead on a ventricle before contraction (or the degree of stretch before contraction).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is equivalent to the end diastolic volume (EDV), which depends on venous return. Therefore, when the preload is increased, the SV is increased (direct relationship). The increase in SV occurs according to the Frank-starling Law (see below).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>After load</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>It is the resistance in arteries against ejection.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When increased, the stroke volume is decreased (reverse relationship).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>After load is increased by aortic stenosis, pulmonary stenosis, systemic hypertension, pulmonary hypertension or vasoconstriction.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="frank-starling-law">Frank-Starling Law<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#frank-starling-law" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Described first by Frank and confirmed experimentally later by Starling. It states that "Within certain limits, the energy of contraction is directly proportional to the initial length of muscle fibers".</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The length of cardiac muscle fibers depends on the EDV, which also depends on venous return. Therefore, higher venous return increases EDV, this increases contractility &amp; so increases the SV.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is the lead on a ventricle before contraction (or the degree of stretch before contraction).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is equivalent to the end diastolic volume (EDV), which depends on venous return. Therefore, when the preload is increased, the SV is increased (direct relationship). The increase in SV occurs according to the Frank-starling Law (see below).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>After load</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>It is the resistance in arteries against ejection.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When increased, the stroke volume is decreased (reverse relationship).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>After load is increased by aortic stenosis, pulmonary stenosis, systemic hypertension, pulmonary hypertension or vasoconstriction.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="frank-starling-law">Frank-Starling Law<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#frank-starling-law" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Described first by Frank and confirmed experimentally later by Starling. It states that "Within certain limits, the energy of contraction is directly proportional to the initial length of muscle fibers".</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The length of cardiac muscle fibers depends on the EDV, which also depends on venous return. Therefore, higher venous return increases EDV, this increases contractility &amp; so increases the SV.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is the lead on a ventricle before contraction (or the degree of stretch before contraction).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is equivalent to the end diastolic volume (EDV), which depends on venous return. Therefore, when the preload is increased, the SV is increased (direct relationship). The increase in SV occurs according to the Frank-starling Law (see below).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>After load</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>It is the resistance in arteries against ejection.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When increased, the stroke volume is decreased (reverse relationship).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>After load is increased by aortic stenosis, pulmonary stenosis, systemic hypertension, pulmonary hypertension or vasoconstriction.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="frank-starling-law">Frank-Starling Law<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#frank-starling-law" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Described first by Frank and confirmed experimentally later by Starling. It states that "Within certain limits, the energy of contraction is directly proportional to the initial length of muscle fibers".</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The length of cardiac muscle fibers depends on the EDV, which also depends on venous return. Therefore, higher venous return increases EDV, this increases contractility &amp; so increases the SV.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>241
The view of medical physiology: 4th edition</p>
<p>51</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-vehcous-returns">The Vehcous Returns<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-vehcous-returns" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>4 x the blood that returns blood to the heart through veins.</li>
<li>4 x 9 sets the cardiac output (= 5 L/min in a resting adult male.</li>
<li>4 is affected by the following factors:</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pressure-gradient">Pressure gradient<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pressure-gradient" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Pressure in arteries is higher than vein, higher than right atrium.</li>
<li>Therefore, blood passes down the pressure gradient from arteries to veins to right atrium in the heart.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="respiratory-pump">Respiratory pump<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#respiratory-pump" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Inspiration increases venous return (inspiration increases chest volume and therefore decreases intra-thoracic pressure, that's why venous return is increased). Expiration decreases venous return especially expiration against closed glottis (valvative maneuver) which is done during defecation, labor or lifting heavy weights.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="muscle-pump">Muscle pump<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#muscle-pump" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Contraction of the lower limb muscles separates blood in the veins upwards towards the heart (the venous blood does not pass down during muscle contraction because of the one way valves in veins.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gravity">Gravity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gravity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Standing decreases venous return due to gravity whereas lying down increases venous return.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-volume">Blood volume<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-volume" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Bleeding decreases venous return by decreasing the total blood volume whereas fluid overload increases venous return.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ventilation-vasoconstriction">Ventilation &amp; vasoconstriction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ventilation-vasoconstriction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Ventilation decreases venous return because it increases diameters of these capacitance vessels to store blood.</li>
<li>Vasoconstriction increases venous return (by adding some of the stored blood to the circulation). This is very important in shock.</li>
</ul>
<p>52</p>
<p>The view of medical physiology | 47</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-vehcous-returns">The Vehcous Returns<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-vehcous-returns" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pressure-gradient">Pressure gradient<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pressure-gradient" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="respiratory-pump">Respiratory pump<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#respiratory-pump" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="muscle-pump">Muscle pump<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#muscle-pump" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gravity">Gravity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gravity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-volume">Blood volume<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-volume" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ventilation-vasoconstriction">Ventilation &amp; vasoconstriction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ventilation-vasoconstriction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-vehcous-returns">The Vehcous Returns<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-vehcous-returns" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="muscle-pump">Muscle pump<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#muscle-pump" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gravity">Gravity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gravity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-volume">Blood volume<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-volume" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Bleeding decreases venous return by decreasing the total blood volume whereas fluid overload increases venous return.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ventilation-vasoconstriction">Ventilation &amp; vasoconstriction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ventilation-vasoconstriction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Ventilation decreases venous return because it increases diameters of these capacitance vessels to store blood.</li>
<li>Vasoconstriction increases venous return (by adding some of the stored blood to the circulation). This is very important in shock.</li>
</ul>
<p>54</p>
<p>244
The role of medical physiology in cancer
245
The role of medical physiology in cancer
246
The role of medical physiology in cancer</p>
<p><strong>State of heart valves</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Elements or regurgitation of any of the heart valves decreases the venous return and results in heart failure.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Pericardial pressure</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Pericardial effusion increases pressure within the pericardial sac and therefore decreases venous return.</li>
<li>It is caused by inflammation (pericarditis) due to viral or bacterial infection or due to hypothyroidism or connective tissue diseases.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>State of heart valves</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Elements or regurgitation of any of the heart valves decreases the venous return and results in heart failure.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Pericardial pressure</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Pericardial effusion increases pressure within the pericardial sac and therefore decreases venous return.</li>
<li>It is caused by inflammation (pericarditis) due to viral or bacterial infection or due to hypothyroidism or connective tissue diseases.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>State of heart valves</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Elements or regurgitation of any of the heart valves decreases the venous return and results in heart failure.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Pericardial pressure</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Pericardial effusion increases pressure within the pericardial sac and therefore decreases venous return.</li>
<li>It is caused by inflammation (pericarditis) due to viral or bacterial infection or due to hypothyroidism or connective tissue diseases.</li>
</ul>

<p>The need of artificial physiological pressure</p>
<p>146</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chemical-of-arterial-blood-pressure">CHEMICAL OF ARTERIAL BLOOD PRESSURE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chemical-of-arterial-blood-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="substance">Substance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#substance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="blood-pressure">Blood pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The pressure of blood on walls of blood vessels.</p>
<ul>
<li>Remember that: hydrostatic pressure is the pressure of water (i.e. plasma) on walls of blood vessels.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="systolic-pressure">Systolic pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#systolic-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The maximum pressure in a vessel during systolic of the heart.</li>
<li>Normal value is less than 120 mmHg in adults. Values of 120 mmHg or more and less than 140 have been regarded as normal; however, according to recent studies, these values indicate pre-hypertension state. Systolic blood pressure of 140 mmHg or more is hypertension.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="diastolic-pressure">Diastolic pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diastolic-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The minimum pressure in a vessel during diastolic of the heart.</li>
<li>Normal value is less than 80 mmHg in adults. Values of 80 mmHg or more and less than 90 have been regarded as normal; however, according to recent studies, these values indicate pre-hypertension state. Diastolic blood pressure of 80 mmHg or more is hypertension.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="pulse-pressure">Pulse pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pulse-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The difference between the systolic and the diastolic pressures.</p>
<ul>
<li>Normal pulse pressure is less than 60 mmHg.</li>
<li>When the systolic pressure is increased and the diastolic is decreased, the pulse pressure becomes "wide".</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="causes-of-wide-pulse-pressure-include">Causes of wide pulse pressure include:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-of-wide-pulse-pressure-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Hypothyroidism</li>
<li>Aortic regurgitation</li>
<li>High body temperature</li>
<li>Hard exercise</li>
<li>Severe anemia</li>
</ul>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="causes-of-wide-pulse-pressure-include">Causes of wide pulse pressure include:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-of-wide-pulse-pressure-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
