<p>The need of artificial physiological pressure</p>
<p>270
The state of medical physiology of 1994</p>
<ul>
<li>Pregnancy</li>
<li>Arterio-venous fistula</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mean-arterial-pressure">Mean arterial pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mean-arterial-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The mean pressure during the cardiac cycle</li>
<li>If is calculated as follows:</li>
</ul>
<p>The mean arterial pressure = The diastolic × 1/3 pulse pressure</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Its value is more than or the diastolic than the systolic because the diastolic phase takes longer (one than the systolic in the cardiac cycle).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Example: If a blood pressure of a subject = 120/80</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The systolic = 100 mmHg</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The diastolic = 90 mmHg</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The pulse pressure = 100 - 90 = 40 mmHg</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The mean arterial pressure = 80 + (100 x 40) = 55 mmHg</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="control-of-the-arterial-blood-pressure">Control of the arterial blood pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-the-arterial-blood-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Blood pressure = Cardiac output + Peripheral resistance.</li>
<li>Therefore the blood pressure is controlled by controlling the cardiac output and the peripheral resistance.</li>
<li>The cardiac output is controlled by controlling both the heart rate and the stroke volume (see above). It determines the systolic pressure (i.e. the increase in COP increases systolic pressure).</li>
<li>The peripheral resistance is determined by blood viscosity, length of arteries and radius of arteries as follows:</li>
</ul>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>P</mi><mi>R</mi><mo>=</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>I</mi><mi>U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi>L</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>⋅</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">PR = (IU/L) \cdot D</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">PR</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">I</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">U</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathnormal">L</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋅</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">D</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>Where V is the blood viscosity, L is the length of arteries and r is the radius of blood vessels.</p>
<ul>
<li>The peripheral resistance determines the diastolic blood pressure.</li>
</ul>
<p>Viscosity of the blood</p>
<ul>
<li>Depends on</li>
</ul>
<p>270
The state of medical physiology of 1994</p>
<ul>
<li>Pregnancy</li>
<li>Arterio-venous fistula</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mean-arterial-pressure">Mean arterial pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mean-arterial-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The mean pressure during the cardiac cycle</li>
<li>If is calculated as follows:</li>
</ul>
<p>The mean arterial pressure = The diastolic × 1/3 pulse pressure</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Its value is more than or the diastolic than the systolic because the diastolic phase takes longer (one than the systolic in the cardiac cycle).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Example: If a blood pressure of a subject = 120/80</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The systolic = 120 mmHg</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The diastolic = 90 mmHg</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The pulse pressure = 120 - 90 = 40 mmHg</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The mean arterial pressure = 80 + (100 x 40) = 93 mmHg</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="control-of-the-arterial-blood-pressure">Control of the arterial blood pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-the-arterial-blood-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Blood pressure = Cardiac output + Peripheral resistance.</li>
<li>Therefore the blood pressure is controlled by controlling the cardiac output and the peripheral resistance.</li>
<li>The cardiac output is controlled by controlling both the heart rate and the stroke volume (see above). It determines the systolic pressure (i.e. the increase in COP increases systolic pressure).</li>
<li>The peripheral resistance is determined by blood viscosity, length of arteries and radius of arteries as follows:</li>
</ul>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>P</mi><mi>R</mi><mo>=</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>I</mi><mi>U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi>L</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>⋅</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">PR = (IU/L) \cdot D</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">PR</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">I</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">U</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathnormal">L</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋅</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">D</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>Where V is the blood viscosity, L is the length of arteries and r is the radius of blood vessels.</p>
<ul>
<li>The peripheral resistance determines the diastolic blood pressure.</li>
</ul>
<p>Viscosity of the blood</p>
<ul>
<li>Depends on</li>
</ul>
<p>270
The state of medical physiology of 1994</p>
<ul>
<li>Pregnancy</li>
<li>Arterio-venous fistula</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mean-arterial-pressure">Mean arterial pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mean-arterial-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The mean pressure during the cardiac cycle</li>
<li>If is calculated as follows:</li>
</ul>
<p>The mean arterial pressure = The diastolic × 1/3 pulse pressure</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Its value is more than or the diastolic than the systolic because the diastolic phase takes longer (one than the systolic in the cardiac cycle).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Example: If a blood pressure of a subject = 120/80</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The systolic = 120 mmHg</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The diastolic = 90 mmHg</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The pulse pressure = 120 - 90 = 40 mmHg</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The mean arterial pressure = 80 + (100 x 40) = 95 mmHg</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="control-of-the-arterial-blood-pressure">Control of the arterial blood pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-the-arterial-blood-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Blood pressure = Cardiac output + Peripheral resistance.</li>
<li>Therefore the blood pressure is controlled by controlling the cardiac output and the peripheral resistance.</li>
<li>The cardiac output is controlled by controlling both the heart rate and the stroke volume (see above). It determines the systolic pressure (i.e. the increase in COP increases systolic pressure).</li>
<li>The peripheral resistance is determined by blood viscosity, length of arteries and radius of arteries as follows:</li>
</ul>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>P</mi><mi>R</mi><mo>=</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>I</mi><mi>U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi>L</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>⋅</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">PR = (IU/L) \cdot D</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">PR</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">I</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">U</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathnormal">L</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋅</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">D</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>Where V is the blood viscosity, L is the length of arteries and r is the radius of blood vessels.</p>
<ul>
<li>The peripheral resistance determines the diastolic blood pressure.</li>
</ul>
<p>Viscosity of the blood</p>
<ul>
<li>Depends on</li>
</ul>
<p>270
The state of medical physiology of 1994</p>
<p>12
The case of medical physiology: 4th edition</p>
<ul>
<li>The packed cell volume (PCV)</li>
<li>Plasma proteins especially globulins and fibrinogen (because of the large size of their particles)</li>
<li>Body temperature (this is quite constant in the normal physiological conditions)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="length-of-blood-vessels">Length of blood vessels<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#length-of-blood-vessels" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="constant-in-adults">Constant in adults<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#constant-in-adults" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="rating-of-blood-vessels">Rating of blood vessels<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rating-of-blood-vessels" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>The most important factor in determining the peripheral resistance.</p>
<p>Nutrify proportional with the peripheral resistance. For example, vasoconstriction decreases radius of arteries &amp; increases the peripheral resistance and therefore increases the blood pressure whereas vasodilatation increases the radius &amp; decreases the peripheral resistance and therefore decreases the blood pressure.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="remember-that">Remember that<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remember-that" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ul>
<li>Blood pressure in children is less than that in adults.</li>
<li>The systolic is less because the COP in children is less (child's heart is small) stroke volume is smaller - COP is lower, in spite of the faster heart rate.</li>
<li>The diastolic is less because the length of arteries is less, therefore, peripheral resistance is less (in spite of other factors).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-mechanisms-that-control-the-blood-pressure">The mechanisms that control the blood pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-mechanisms-that-control-the-blood-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Very rapid mechanism (act in seconds)</li>
<li>Baroreceptors</li>
<li>Chemoreceptors</li>
<li>CNS ischemic response</li>
<li>Less rapid mechanisms (act in minutes to hours)</li>
<li>Hormonal vasoconstriction by</li>
</ul>
<p>13
The case of medical physiology: 4th edition</p>
<ul>
<li>The packed cell volume (PCV)</li>
<li>Plasma proteins especially globulins and fibrinogen (because of the large size of their particles)</li>
<li>Body temperature (this is quite constant in the normal physiological conditions)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="length-of-blood-vessels">Length of blood vessels<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#length-of-blood-vessels" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="constant-in-adults">Constant in adults<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#constant-in-adults" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="rating-of-blood-vessels">Rating of blood vessels<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rating-of-blood-vessels" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>The most important factor in determining the peripheral resistance.</p>
<p>Nutrify proportional with the peripheral resistance. For example, vasoconstriction decreases radius of arteries &amp; increases the peripheral resistance and therefore increases the blood pressure whereas vasodilatation increases the radius &amp; decreases the peripheral resistance and therefore decreases the blood pressure.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="remember-that">Remember that<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remember-that" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ul>
<li>Blood pressure in children is less than that in adults.</li>
<li>The systolic is less because the COP in children is less (child's heart is small) stroke volume is smaller - COP is lower, in spite of the faster heart rate.</li>
<li>The diastolic is less because the length of arteries is less, therefore, peripheral resistance is less (in spite of other factors).</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-mechanisms-that-control-the-blood-pressure">The mechanisms that control the blood pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-mechanisms-that-control-the-blood-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="constant-in-adults">Constant in adults<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#constant-in-adults" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="rating-of-blood-vessels">Rating of blood vessels<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rating-of-blood-vessels" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>The most important factor in determining the peripheral resistance.</p>
<p>Nutrify proportional with the peripheral resistance. For example, vasoconstriction decreases radius of arteries &amp; increases the peripheral resistance and therefore increases the blood pressure whereas vasodilatation increases the radius &amp; decreases the peripheral resistance and therefore decreases the blood pressure.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="remember-that">Remember that<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remember-that" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ul>
<li>Blood pressure in children is less than that in adults.</li>
<li>The systolic is less because the COP in children is less (child's heart is small) stroke volume is smaller - COP is lower, in spite of the faster heart rate.</li>
<li>The diastolic is less because the length of arteries is less, therefore, peripheral resistance is less (in spite of other factors).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-mechanisms-that-control-the-blood-pressure">The mechanisms that control the blood pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-mechanisms-that-control-the-blood-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Very rapid mechanism (act in seconds)</li>
<li>Baroreceptors</li>
<li>Chemoreceptors</li>
<li>CNS ischemic response</li>
<li>Less rapid mechanisms (act in minutes to hours)</li>
<li>Hormonal vasoconstriction by</li>
</ul>
<p>15
The case of medical physiology: 4th edition</p>
<p>c. Renin-Angiotensin system
o. Antidiuretic hormone (ADH)
o. Catecholamines</p>
<ul>
<li>Stress relaxation and inverse stress relaxation</li>
<li>Capillary fluid shift
♦ Long term mechanisms (act in days)
♦ Renin-Angiotensin-Aldosterone system
♦ ADH
♦ Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP)
♦ Third mechanism
♦ Other hormones that may affect the blood pressure
♦ Local regulation of blood pressure</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="very-rapid-mechanisms">VERY RAPID MECHANISMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#very-rapid-mechanisms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="baroreceptors">Baroreceptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#baroreceptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Systolic receptors found in high pressure areas of the circulation (aortic sinus in aortic arch and carotid sinus in carotid bifurcation).</li>
<li>They are stimulated by stretch caused by high blood pressure.</li>
<li>They send impulses through the vagus &amp; glossopharyngeal nerves to the medulla oblongata.</li>
<li>The impulses reach the nucleus of tractus solitarius (NTS) and from there inhibitory impulses pass to the vasomotor center (VMC) &amp; cardiac center (CC) in the medulla causing reduction in sympathetic discharge from these centers to the heart and blood vessels.</li>
<li>Excitatory impulses pass to the cardio-inhibitory center in the medulla causing increased parasympathetic discharge from this center to the heart.</li>
</ul>
<p>248</p>
<p>The term of medical technology is "cythe"</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="very-rapid-mechanisms">VERY RAPID MECHANISMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#very-rapid-mechanisms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="baroreceptors">Baroreceptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#baroreceptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Systolic receptors found in high pressure areas of the circulation (aortic sinus in aortic arch and carotid sinus in carotid bifurcation).</li>
<li>They are stimulated by stretch caused by high blood pressure.</li>
<li>They send impulses through the vagus &amp; glossopharyngeal nerves to the medulla oblongata.</li>
<li>The impulses reach the nucleus of tractus solitarius (NTS) and from there inhibitory impulses pass to the vasomotor center (VMC) &amp; cardiac center (CC) in the medulla causing reduction in sympathetic discharge from these centers to the heart and blood vessels.</li>
<li>Excitatory impulses pass to the cardio-inhibitory center in the medulla causing increased parasympathetic discharge from this center to the heart.</li>
</ul>
<p>249</p>
<p>The term of mechanical physiology is "cythe"</p>
<p>o. Renin-Angiotensin system
o. Antidiuretic hormone (ADH)
o. Catecholamines</p>
<ul>
<li>Stress relaxation and inverse stress relaxation</li>
<li>Capillary fluid shift
♦ Long term mechanisms (act in days)
♦ Renin-Angiotensin-Aldosterone system
♦ ADH
♦ Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP)
♦ Third mechanism
♦ Other hormones that may affect the blood pressure
♦ Local regulation of blood pressure</li>
