<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="very-rapid-mechanisms">VERY RAPID MECHANISMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#very-rapid-mechanisms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="baroreceptors">Baroreceptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#baroreceptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Systolic receptors found in high pressure areas of the circulation (aortic sinus in aortic arch and carotid sinus in carotid bifurcation).</li>
<li>They are stimulated by stretch caused by high blood pressure.</li>
<li>They send impulses through the vagus &amp; glossopharyngeal nerves to the medulla oblongata.</li>
<li>The impulses reach the nucleus of tractus solitarius (NTS) and from there inhibitory impulses pass to the vasomotor center (VMC) &amp; cardiac center (CC) in the medulla causing reduction in sympathetic discharge from these centers to the heart and blood vessels.</li>
<li>Excitatory impulses pass to the cardio-inhibitory center in the medulla causing increased parasympathetic discharge from this center to the heart.</li>
</ul>
<p>250</p>
<p>The term of mechanical physiology is "cythe"</p>
<p>249
248</p>
<ul>
<li>Both decreased sympathetic &amp; increased parasympathetic result in:</li>
<li>Reduction in heart rate &amp; stroke volume (i.e. lower COP and therefore lower systolic blood pressure)</li>
<li>Vasodilation (i.e. decreased peripheral resistance and therefore lower diastolic blood pressure)</li>
<li>Consequently the S.P is reduced back to normal within a second.</li>
</ul>
<p>The opposite occurs when there is reduction in S.P. hypotension* less stretchless stimulation of baroreceptors* less inhibitory discharge to the medulla* more sympathetic and less parasympathetic* increased HR &amp; SV* higher COP* increased blood pressure back to normal within a second (systolic &amp; diastolic).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inverted-notes">Inverted notes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inverted-notes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>When the blood pressure is normal, the baroreceptors send <em>basis</em> discharge through the buffer nerves (9 and 10) causing continuous reduction in activity of the VMC and the CC.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Denervation of the baroreceptors (cutting the buffer nerves) causes elevation in blood pressure.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Baroreceptors adapt to new pressures (this is known as resetting). For example when the BP is chronically elevated, the baroreceptors increase the rate of their <em>basis</em> discharge to correct the pressure; however, if the BP remains elevated, the rate of discharge will decrease gradually over time until it reaches the earlier rate. The resetting phenomenon is reversible.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>There are other types of baroreceptors found at the venous side (low pressure areas). These include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Type A atrial baroreceptors: discharge during systole</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Type B atrial baroreceptors: discharge during diastole</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stimulation of these venous baroreceptors results in reflex vasodilation like the arterial baroreceptors; however, the heart rate increases.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>249
247
246</p>
<ul>
<li>Both decreased sympathetic &amp; increased parasympathetic result in:</li>
<li>Reduction in heart rate &amp; stroke volume (i.e. lower COP and therefore lower systolic blood pressure)</li>
<li>Vasodilation (i.e. decreased peripheral resistance and therefore lower diastolic blood pressure)</li>
<li>Consequently the S.P is reduced back to normal within a second.</li>
</ul>
<p>The opposite occurs when there is reduction in S.P. hypotension* less stretchless stimulation of baroreceptors* less inhibitory discharge to the medulla* more sympathetic and less parasympathetic* increased HR &amp; SV* higher COP* increased blood pressure back to normal within a second (systolic &amp; diastolic).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="precipitated-notes">Precipitated notes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#precipitated-notes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>When the blood pressure is normal, the baroreceptors send <em>basis</em> discharge through the buffer nerves (9 and 10) causing continuous reduction in activity of the VMC and the CC.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Denervation of the baroreceptors (cutting the buffer nerves) causes elevation in blood pressure.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Baroreceptors adapt to new pressures (this is known as resetting). For example when the BP is chronically elevated, the baroreceptors increase the rate of their <em>basis</em> discharge to correct the pressure; however, if the BP remains elevated, the rate of discharge will decrease gradually over time until it reaches the earlier rate. The resetting phenomenon is reversible.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>There are other types of baroreceptors found at the venous side (low pressure areas). These include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Type A atrial baroreceptors: discharge during systole</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Type B atrial baroreceptors: discharge during diastole</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stimulation of these venous baroreceptors results in reflex vasodilation like the arterial baroreceptors; however, the heart rate increases.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>248
245</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chemoreceptors">Chemoreceptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chemoreceptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The peripheral chemoreceptors are found in the carotid body in carotid bifurcation and aortic body in aortic arch.</li>
<li>They are stimulated by hypoxia (low O₂ in tissues), hypercapnia (high CO₂) and acidosis (high H⁺). These stimuli are associated with hypotension because of the low tissue perfusion.</li>
<li>They send excitatory impulses through the vagus and gliosisopharyngeal nerves to the respiratory center to increase respiration.</li>
<li>The impulses also stimulate the vasomotor and the cardiac centers (due to radiation of impulses in the medulla).</li>
<li>This increases the blood pressure by increasing sympathetic discharge from these centers to the heart and blood vessels causing increased heart rate, higher stroke volume and vasoconstriction.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cns-ischemic-response">CNS Ischemic response<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cns-ischemic-response" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Reduction of the blood supply to the brain (ischemia), is caused by hypotension. This results in accumulation of CO₂.</li>
<li>The vasomotor center is very sensitive to CO₂. It is stimulated to release by sympathetic discharge to the blood vessels. This increases the blood pressure and therefore improves the blood supply to the brain.</li>
<li>A high intracranial pressure (e.g. caused by a brain tumor) impairs cerebral circulation and results in brain ischemia. This induces similar CNS ischemic response resulting in elevation of the blood pressure to high levels (hypertension).</li>
<li>The high blood pressure stimulates the baroreceptors to inhibit the heart through the cardiac center and the cardiorrhizotory center, but they can not inhibit the vasomotor center which is stimulated by the CO₂; this results in bradycardia.</li>
<li>This sign (hypertension with bradycardia) is an important sign of raised intracranial pressure (known as Cushing’s sign).</li>
</ul>
<p>The role of radical physiology in stroke</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chemoreceptors">Chemoreceptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chemoreceptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The peripheral chemoreceptors are found in the carotid body in carotid bifurcation and aortic body in aortic arch.</li>
<li>They are stimulated by hypoxia (low O₂ in tissues), hypercapnia (high CO₂) and acidosis (high H⁺). These stimuli are associated with hypotension because of the low tissue perfusion.</li>
<li>They send excitatory impulses through the vagus and gliosisopharyngeal nerves to the respiratory center to increase respiration.</li>
<li>This impulses also stimulate the vasomotor and the cardiac centers (due to radiation of impulses in the medulla).</li>
<li>This increases the blood pressure by increasing sympathetic discharge from these centers to the heart and blood vessels causing increased heart rate, higher stroke volume and vasoconstriction.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cns-ischemic-response">CNS Ischemic response<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cns-ischemic-response" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Reduction of the blood supply to the brain (ischemia), is caused by hypotension. This results in accumulation of CO₂.</li>
<li>The vasomotor center is very sensitive to CO₂. It is stimulated to release by sympathetic discharge to the blood vessels. This increases the blood pressure and therefore improves the blood supply to the brain.</li>
<li>A high intracranial pressure (e.g. caused by a brain tumor) impairs cerebral circulation and results in brain ischemia. This induces similar CNS ischemic response resulting in elevation of the blood pressure to high levels (hypertension).</li>
<li>The high blood pressure stimulates the baroreceptors to inhibit the heart through the cardiac center and the cardiorrhizotory center, but they can not inhibit the vasomotor center which is stimulated by the CO₂; this results in bradycardia.</li>
<li>This sign (hypertension with bradycardia) is an important sign of raised intracranial pressure (known as Cushing’s sign).</li>
</ul>
<p>The role of residual physiology in stroke</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chemoreceptors">Chemoreceptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chemoreceptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The peripheral chemoreceptors are found in the carotid body in carotid bifurcation and aortic body in aortic arch.</li>
<li>They are stimulated by hypoxia (low O₂ in tissues), hypercapnia (high CO₂) and acidosis (high H⁺). These stimuli are associated with hypotension because of the low tissue perfusion.</li>
<li>They send excitatory impulses through the vagus and gliosisopharyngeal nerves to the respiratory center to increase respiration.</li>
<li>This impulses also stimulate the vasomotor and the cardiac centers (due to radiation of impulses in the medulla).</li>
<li>This increases the blood pressure by increasing sympathetic discharge from these centers to the heart and blood vessels causing increased heart rate, higher stroke volume and vasoconstriction.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cns-ischemic-response">CNS Ischemic response<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cns-ischemic-response" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Reduction of the blood supply to the brain (ischemia), is caused by hypotension. This results in accumulation of CO₂.</li>
<li>The vasomotor center is very sensitive to CO₂. It is stimulated to release by sympathetic discharge to the blood vessels. This increases the blood pressure and therefore improves the blood supply to the brain.</li>
<li>A high intracranial pressure (e.g. caused by a brain tumor) impairs cerebral circulation and results in brain ischemia. This induces similar CNS ischemic response resulting in elevation of the blood pressure to high levels (hypertension).</li>
<li>The high blood pressure stimulates the baroreceptors to inhibit the heart through the cardiac center and the cardiorrhizotory center, but they can not inhibit the vasomotor center which is stimulated by the CO₂; this results in bradycardia.</li>
<li>This sign (hypertension with bradycardia) is an important sign of raised intracranial pressure (known as Cushing’s sign).</li>
</ul>
<p>The role of radical physiology in stroke</p>
<p>201</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="leis-rapid-mechanisms">LEIS RAPID MECHANISMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#leis-rapid-mechanisms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="operating-recommendations">Operating recommendations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#operating-recommendations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="aod">AOD<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#aod" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Release of this none-peptide hormone from the posterior pituitary gland is stimulated, among other stimuli, by hypotension.</li>
<li>It acts on V1 receptors in the blood vessels causing vasoconstriction. This elevates the blood pressure.</li>
<li>It also elevates the B.P. by acting on V2 receptors in the kidney; however, this action is grouped with the long term mechanisms.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="catecholamines">Catecholamines<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#catecholamines" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Adrenaline and noradrenaline are released in response to hypotension (which is a form of stress).</li>
<li>They act on α receptors in blood vessels causing vasoconstriction. This elevates the blood pressure.</li>
<li>Remember that noradrenaline acts on alpha receptors better than beta whereas adrenaline acts on beta receptors better than alpha.</li>
<li>That's why noradrenaline increases the diastolic (by increasing the peripheral resistance) whereas adrenaline increases the systolic (by increasing the cardiac output).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="renin-angiotensin-ii">Renin-Angiotensin II<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#renin-angiotensin-ii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Renin enzyme is released by the Juzeglomerular cells in the kidney. It is stimulated by renal ischemia, hyponatremia &amp; sympathetic stimulation (all these are associated with hypotension).</li>
<li>It acts on angiotensinogen (plasma protein from the liver) converting it to angiotensin I.</li>
<li>Angiotensin I is converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) which is produced by endothelial cells (especially of pulmonary capillaries).</li>
</ul>
<p>202</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="leis-rapid-mechanisms">LEIS RAPID MECHANISMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#leis-rapid-mechanisms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="operating-recommendations">Operating recommendations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#operating-recommendations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="adh">ADH<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adh" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Release of this none-peptide hormone from the posterior pituitary gland is stimulated, among other stimuli, by hypotension.</li>
<li>It acts on V1 receptors in the blood vessels causing vasoconstriction. This elevates the blood pressure.</li>
<li>It also elevates the B.P. by acting on V2 receptors in the kidney; however, this action is grouped with the long term mechanisms.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="catecholamines">Catecholamines<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#catecholamines" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Adrenaline and noradrenaline are released in response to hypotension (which is a form of stress).</li>
<li>They act on α receptors in blood vessels causing vasoconstriction. This elevates the blood pressure.</li>
<li>Remember that noradrenaline acts on alpha receptors better than beta whereas adrenaline acts on beta receptors better than alpha.</li>
<li>That's why noradrenaline increases the diastolic (by increasing the peripheral resistance) whereas adrenaline increases the systolic (by increasing the cardiac output).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="renin-angiotensin-ii">Renin-Angiotensin II<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#renin-angiotensin-ii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Renin enzyme is released by the Juzeglomerular cells in the kidney. It is stimulated by renal ischemia, hyponatremia &amp; sympathetic stimulation (all these are associated with hypotension).</li>
<li>It acts on angiotensinogen (plasma protein from the liver) converting it to angiotensin I.</li>
<li>Angiotensin I is converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) which is produced by endothelial cells (especially of pulmonary capillaries).</li>
</ul>
<p>203</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="leis-rapid-mechanisms">LEIS RAPID MECHANISMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#leis-rapid-mechanisms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="operating-recommendations">Operating recommendations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#operating-recommendations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="aot">AOT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#aot" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Release of this none-peptide hormone from the posterior pituitary gland is stimulated, among other stimuli, by hypotension.</li>
<li>It acts on V1 receptors in the blood vessels causing vasoconstriction. This elevates the blood pressure.</li>
<li>It also elevates the B.P. by acting on V2 receptors in the kidney; however, this action is grouped with the long term mechanisms.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="catecholamines">Catecholamines<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#catecholamines" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Adrenaline and noradrenaline are released in response to hypotension (which is a form of stress).</li>
<li>They act on α receptors in blood vessels causing vasoconstriction. This elevates the blood pressure.</li>
<li>Remember that noradrenaline acts on alpha receptors better than beta whereas adrenaline acts on beta receptors better than alpha.</li>
<li>That's why noradrenaline increases the diastolic (by increasing the peripheral resistance) whereas adrenaline increases the systolic (by increasing the cardiac output).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="renin-angiotensin-ii">Renin-Angiotensin II<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#renin-angiotensin-ii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Renin enzyme is released by the Juzeglomerular cells in the kidney. It is stimulated by renal ischemia, hyponatremia &amp; sympathetic stimulation (all these are associated with hypotension).</li>
<li>It acts on angiotensinogen (plasma protein from the liver) converting it to angiotensin I.</li>
<li>Angiotensin I is converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) which is produced by endothelial cells (especially of pulmonary capillaries).</li>
</ul>
<p>204</p>
<ul>
<li>Angiotensin II causes vasoconstriction.</li>
<li>It also activates the sympathetic to release renin, then renin converts angiotensinogen to angiotensin I and the cycle repeats itself (positive feedback mechanism).</li>
<li>Other actions of angiotensin II are long term effects (see below).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="stress-relaxation-and-inverse-stress-relaxation">Stress relaxation and inverse stress relaxation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stress-relaxation-and-inverse-stress-relaxation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The stress on walls of blood vessels, caused by high blood pressure, leads to relaxation of smooth muscles in the walls and reduction in the blood pressure in minutes (stress relaxation).</li>
<li>Conversely, reduction in the blood pressure leads to less stress on the walls of blood vessels and therefore constriction of the blood vessels leading to elevation in the blood pressure (inverse stress relaxation).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="capillary-fluid-shift">Capillary fluid shift<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#capillary-fluid-shift" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs due to hypotension because there is reduction in the hydrostatic pressure (which is responsible for filtration).</li>
<li>It becomes lower than the oncotic pressure in capillaries (which is responsible for absorption).</li>
<li>This shifts fluid from the interstitium to the intravascular space. The blood volume is increased and therefore the blood pressure is slightly increased.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="long-term-mechanisms">LONG TERM MECHANISMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#long-term-mechanisms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ranks-angiotensin-aldosterone-system">Ranks Angiotensin Aldosterone system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ranks-angiotensin-aldosterone-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>As mentioned above, angiotensin II rapidly elevates the blood pressure by causing vasoconstriction.</li>
<li>In addition it has other long term effects. Stress include stimulation of aldosterone, stimulation of ADH and stimulation of the third center.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="angiotensin-ii-causes-vasoconstriction">Angiotensin II causes vasoconstriction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#angiotensin-ii-causes-vasoconstriction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>It also activates the sympathetic to release renin, then renin converts angiotensinogen to angiotensin I and the cycle repeats itself (positive feedback mechanism).</li>
<li>Other actions of angiotensin II are long term effects (see below).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="stress-relaxation-and-inverse-stress-relaxation">Stress relaxation and inverse stress relaxation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stress-relaxation-and-inverse-stress-relaxation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The stress on walls of blood vessels, caused by high blood pressure, leads to relaxation of smooth muscles in the walls and reduction in the blood pressure in minutes (stress relaxation).</li>
<li>Conversely, reduction in the blood pressure leads to less stress on the walls of blood vessels and therefore constriction of the blood vessels leading to elevation in the blood pressure (inverse stress relaxation).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="capillary-fluid-shift">Capillary fluid shift<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#capillary-fluid-shift" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs due to hypotension because there is reduction in the hydrostatic pressure (which is responsible for filtration).</li>
<li>It becomes lower than the oncotic pressure in capillaries (which is responsible for absorption).</li>
<li>This shifts fluid from the interstitium to the intravascular space. The blood volume is increased and therefore the blood pressure is slightly increased.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="long-term-mechanisms">LONG TERM MECHANISMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#long-term-mechanisms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ranks-angiotensin-aldosterone-system">Ranks Angiotensin Aldosterone system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ranks-angiotensin-aldosterone-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>As mentioned above, angiotensin II rapidly elevates the blood pressure by causing vasoconstriction.</li>
<li>In addition it has other long term effects. Stress include stimulation of aldosterone, stimulation of ADH and stimulation of the third center.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="angiotensin-ii-causes-vasoconstriction">Angiotensin II causes vasoconstriction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#angiotensin-ii-causes-vasoconstriction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>It also activates the sympathetic to release renin, then renin converts angiotensinogen to angiotensin I and the cycle repeats itself (positive feedback mechanism).</li>
<li>Other actions of angiotensin II are long term effects (see below).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="stress-relaxation-and-inverse-stress-relaxation">Stress relaxation and inverse stress relaxation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stress-relaxation-and-inverse-stress-relaxation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The stress on walls of blood vessels, caused by high blood pressure, leads to relaxation of smooth muscles in the walls and reduction in the blood pressure in minutes (stress relaxation).</li>
<li>Conversely, reduction in the blood pressure leads to less stress on the walls of blood vessels and therefore constriction of the blood vessels leading to elevation in the blood pressure (inverse stress relaxation).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="capillary-fluid-shift">Capillary fluid shift<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#capillary-fluid-shift" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs due to hypotension because there is reduction in the hydrostatic pressure (which is responsible for filtration).</li>
<li>It becomes lower than the oncotic pressure in capillaries (which is responsible for absorption).</li>
<li>This shifts fluid from the interstitium to the intravascular space. The blood volume is increased and therefore the blood pressure is slightly increased.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="long-term-mechanisms">LONG TERM MECHANISMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#long-term-mechanisms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ranks-angiotensin-aldosterone-system">Ranks Angiotensin Aldosterone system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ranks-angiotensin-aldosterone-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>As mentioned above, angiotensin II rapidly elevates the blood pressure by causing vasoconstriction.</li>
<li>In addition it has other long term effects. Stress include stimulation of aldosterone, stimulation of ADH and stimulation of the third center.</li>
</ul>
<p>210
The work of the blood group is part of the project</p>
<ul>
<li>There are many stimuli of aldosterone. However its stimulation by angiotensin II correlates activation of the renin angiotensin aldosterone system.</li>
<li>Aldosterone Acts on the distal convoluted tubules and collecting ducts in kidney causing reabsorption of sodium and secretion of potassium. Water follows sodium in the intravascular space.</li>
<li>This increases blood volume &amp; therefore the blood pressure.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="adh">ADH<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adh" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>As mentioned above, in addition to vasoconstriction, ADH has another long term effect to elevate the blood pressure. It acts on V2 receptors in the collecting ducts of the kidney causing reabsorption of water to the intravascular space.</li>
<li>This increases blood volume &amp; therefore the blood pressure.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="thirst">Thirst<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thirst" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Controlled by a thirst center in the hypothalamus.</li>
<li>It is stimulated by hypotension and other stimuli (hypovolemia, hypersensitivity &amp; angiotensin II). The subject drinks water in response to thirst.</li>
<li>This increases the blood volume &amp; therefore the blood pressure.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="atrial-natriuretic-peptide-anp">Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#atrial-natriuretic-peptide-anp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Atrial natriuretic peptide is a hormone released by atria in response to stretch by hypovolemia (hypovolemia is associated with higher blood pressure).</li>
<li>ANP acts in the kidney to decrease sodium reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubules and antagonizes aldosterone in the distal convoluted tubules and collecting ducts of the kidney. Sodium is lost in urine followed by water.</li>
<li>This decreases the blood volume &amp; therefore the blood pressure.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="other-hormones-that-may-affect-the-blood-pressure">Other hormones that may affect the blood pressure:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-hormones-that-may-affect-the-blood-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Kinins (vasodilators: decreases the B.P.)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Adrenomedulin &amp; pro-adrenomedulin (vasodilators: decrease I)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>224</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>There are many stimuli of aldosterone. However its stimulation by angiotensin II correlates activation of the renin angiotensin aldosterone system.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Aldosterone Acts on the distal convoluted tubules and collecting ducts in kidney causing reabsorption of sodium and secretion of potassium. Water follows sodium in the intravascular space.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This increases blood volume &amp; therefore the blood pressure.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="thirst">Thirst<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thirst" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="other-hormones-that-may-affect-the-blood-pressure">Other hormones that may affect the blood pressure:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-hormones-that-may-affect-the-blood-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>226</li>
</ul>
<p>VP (vessellator - decreases the B.P.)
V (Veteran) (vessellator - increases the B.P.)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="local-regulation">LOCAL REGULATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#local-regulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Aim of Local regulation of blood pressure</li>
<li>To maintain adequate perfusion and therefore adequate supply of O₂ and nutrients to the tissues.</li>
<li>To adjust the perfusion to tissues according to their needs; which vary from time to time according to variation in activities.</li>
<li>Local regulation occurs by the following:</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-autoregulation">1: Autoregulation:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-autoregulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>It is the intrinsic capacity of tissues to regulate their own blood flow.</li>
<li>Found in many tissues like skeletal muscles, cardiac muscle, brain, liver...</li>
<li>Can be explained by:</li>
<li>The myogenic theory of autoregulation</li>
<li>High perfusion pressure results in local vasoconstriction (in organs) to prevent their rupture (according to Law of Laplace, see below) and to adjust blood flow to organs. This mechanism is not expected to occur in response to very low or very high perfusion pressures.</li>
<li>Metabolic theory of autoregulation</li>
<li>Active tissues produce metabolites that can cause vasodilatation. When the blood flow decreases, they accumulate and when the blood flow increases, they are washed away.</li>
<li>Metabolites that can cause vasodilatation include: CO₂, H⁺ and K⁺, ATP, ADP, adenosine, pyruvate, lactate</li>
<li>Localized vasoconstriction can be caused by serotonin and cold.</li>
</ul>
<p>274</p>
<p>The ratio of skeletal muscle to H⁺</p>
<ul>
<li>VP (vessellator - decreases the B.P.)</li>
<li>V (Veteran) (vessellator - increases the B.P.)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="local-regulation">LOCAL REGULATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#local-regulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Aim of Local regulation of blood pressure</li>
<li>To maintain adequate perfusion and therefore adequate supply of O₂ and nutrients to the tissues.</li>
<li>To adjust the perfusion to tissues according to their needs; which vary from time to time according to variation in activities.</li>
<li>Local regulation occurs by the following:</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-autoregulation">1: Autoregulation:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-autoregulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>It is the intrinsic capacity of tissues to regulate their own blood flow.</li>
<li>Found in many tissues like skeletal muscles, cardiac muscle, brain, liver...</li>
<li>Can be explained by:</li>
<li>The myogenic theory of autoregulation</li>
<li>High perfusion pressure results in local vasoconstriction (in organs) to prevent their rupture (according to Law of Laplace, see below) and to adjust blood flow to organs. This mechanism is not expected to occur in response to very low or very high perfusion pressures.</li>
<li>Metabolic theory of autoregulation</li>
<li>Active tissues produce metabolites that can cause vasodilatation. When the blood flow decreases, they accumulate and when the blood flow increases, they are washed away.</li>
<li>Metabolites that can cause vasodilatation include: CO₂, H⁺ and K⁺, ATP, ADP, adenosine, pyruvate, lactate</li>
<li>Localized vasoconstriction can be caused by serotonin and cold.</li>
</ul>
<p>275</p>
<p>The ratio of skeletal muscle to H⁺</p>
<ul>
<li>VP (vessellator - decreases the B.P.)</li>
<li>V (Veteran) (vessellator - increases the B.P.)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="local-regulation">LOCAL REGULATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#local-regulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Aim of Local regulation of blood pressure</li>
<li>To maintain adequate perfusion and therefore adequate supply of O₂ and nutrients to the tissues.</li>
<li>To adjust the perfusion to tissues according to their needs; which vary from time to time according to variation in activities.</li>
<li>Local regulation occurs by the following:</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-autoregulation">1: Autoregulation:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-autoregulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>It is the intrinsic capacity of tissues to regulate their own blood flow.</li>
<li>Found in many tissues like skeletal muscles, cardiac muscle, brain, liver...</li>
<li>Can be explained by:</li>
<li>The myogenic theory of autoregulation</li>
<li>High perfusion pressure results in local vasoconstriction (in organs) to prevent their rupture (according to Law of Laplace, see below) and to adjust blood flow to organs. This mechanism is not expected to occur in response to very low or very high perfusion pressures.</li>
<li>Metabolic theory of autoregulation</li>
<li>Active tissues produce metabolites that can cause vasodilatation. When the blood flow decreases, they accumulate and when the blood flow increases, they are washed away.</li>
<li>Metabolites that can cause vasodilatation include: CO₂, H⁺ and K⁺, ATP, ADP, adenosine, pyruvate, lactate</li>
<li>Localized vasoconstriction can be caused by serotonin and cold.</li>
</ul>
<p>276</p>
<p>The ratio of skeletal muscle to H⁺</p>
<ol>
<li>Substances secreted by the endothelium:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Prothrombin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Casein vasodilatation &amp; inhibits platelet aggregation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Prothrombin is balanced by throbizane AZ (TRAZ) which is released from platelets (TRAZ causes vasoconstriction and stimulates platelet aggregation). The balance is shifted towards prothrombin by low dose aspirin; that's why low dose of aspirin is commonly prescribed to patients at risk of thrombosis (e.g. diabetics and hypertensive patients).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Nitric oxide (NO)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is the endothelial derived relaxation factor (EDRF)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is synthesized from arginine by the enzyme "NO synthase"</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is an important vasodilator in many organs (e.g. causes erection in males); however, it has many other functions in other organs.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Prothromin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Polypeptides (21 aa)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>They are potent vasoconstrictors</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>They have many other functions.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>IMPORTANT NOTES ABOUT BLOOD VESSELS</p>
<p>Arteries and arterioles</p>
<ul>
<li>The walls of large arteries contain high amount of elastic fibers whereas the walls of the arterioles contain less amount of elastic fibers, but more smooth muscle.</li>
<li>The arterioles are the major site of resistance to blood flow (resistance vessels).</li>
</ul>
<p>Calcifacies</p>
<ul>
<li>These are the major site of fluid exchange between plasma and interstitium (exchange vessels).</li>
</ul>
<p>The state of medical physiology of asthma</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Substances secreted by the endothelium:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Prothrombin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Casein vasodilatation &amp; inhibits platelet aggregation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Prothrombin is balanced by throbizane AZ (TRAZ) which is released from platelets (TRAZ causes vasoconstriction and stimulates platelet aggregation). The balance is shifted towards prothrombin by low dose aspirin; that's why low dose of aspirin is commonly prescribed to patients at risk of thrombosis (e.g. diabetics and hypertensive patients).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Nitric oxide (NO)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is the endothelial derived relaxation factor (EDRF)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is synthesized from arginine by the enzyme "NO synthase"</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is an important vasodilator in many organs (e.g. causes erection in males); however, it has many other functions in other organs.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Prothromin</p>

<li>
<p>They are potent vasoconstrictors</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>They have many other functions.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>IMPORTANT NOTES ABOUT BLOOD VESSELS</p>
<p>Arteries and arterioles</p>
<ul>
<li>The walls of large arteries contain high amount of elastic fibers whereas the walls of the arterioles contain less amount of elastic fibers, but more smooth muscle.</li>
<li>The arterioles are the major site of resistance to blood flow (resistance vessels).</li>
</ul>
<p>Calcifacies</p>
<ul>
<li>These are the major site of fluid exchange between plasma and interstitium (exchange vessels).</li>
</ul>
<p>The state of medical physiology of asthma</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Substances secreted by the endothelium:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Prothrombin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Casein vasodilatation &amp; inhibits platelet aggregation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Prothrombin is balanced by throbizane AZ (TRAZ) which is released from platelets (TRAZ causes vasoconstriction and stimulates platelet aggregation). The balance is shifted towards prothrombin by low dose aspirin; that's why low dose of aspirin is commonly prescribed to patients at risk of thrombosis (e.g. diabetics and hypertensive patients).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Nitric oxide (NO)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is the endothelial derived relaxation factor (EDRF)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is synthesized from arginine by the enzyme "NO synthase"</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is an important vasodilator in many organs (e.g. causes erection in males); however, it has many other functions in other organs.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Prothromin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Polypeptides (21 aa)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>They are potent vasoconstrictors</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>They have many other functions.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>IMPORTANT NOTES ABOUT BLOOD VESSELS</p>
<p>Arteries and arterioles</p>
<ul>
<li>The walls of large arteries contain high amount of elastic fibers whereas the walls of the arterioles contain less amount of elastic fibers, but more smooth muscle.</li>
<li>The arterioles are the major site of resistance to blood flow (resistance vessels).</li>
</ul>
<p>Calcifacies</p>
<ul>
<li>These are the major site of fluid exchange between plasma and interstitium (exchange vessels).</li>
</ul>
<p>The state of medical physiology of asthma</p>
<ul>
<li>The junctions between endothelial cells in capillaries may be very light (e.g. in brain capillaries and to a lesser extent in muscles), or fenestrated (e.g. in liver sinusoids and to a lesser extent in glomerular capillaries).</li>
<li>Blood capillaries have the highest surface area (surface area exceeds <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>6300</mn><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">6300\mathrm{m}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">6300</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">m</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> in adults) and the lowest velocity of blood flow.</li>
<li>In spite of the thin wall of capillaries, they do not rupture because of their small diameter. Similarly, arterioles constrict to resist rupture when the perfusion pressure is high (explained by "Law of Laplace").</li>
<li>The law states that: the tension (T) in the wall of a cylinder is equal to the product of the transmural pressure (P) and the radius (r), divided by the wall thickness (w).</li>
</ul>
<p>FIG. 52</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-6e91ed6a.jpeg" alt="img-299.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>As mentioned above: T = Pn/w</li>
<li>The transmural pressure (P) = pressure inside the cylinder - pressure in tissue which is negligible. Therefore (P) = the pressure inside the cylinder (= the distending pressure)</li>
<li>The wall thickness of capillaries (w) is negligible</li>
</ul>
<p>Therefore the equation becomes: T = (r)</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mi>P</mi><mi>P</mi></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><mtext>in&nbsp;blood&nbsp;vessels</mtext><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{P}{P} = \frac{1}{2} \left( \text{in blood vessels} \right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0463em;
