vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">in&nbsp;blood&nbsp;vessels</span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>w</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><mtext>in&nbsp;spheres</mtext><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">w = \frac{1}{2} \left( \text{in spheres} \right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02691em;">w</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">in&nbsp;spheres</span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>274</p>
<ul>
<li>The junctions between endothelial cells in capillaries may be very light (e.g. in brain capillaries and to a lesser extent in muscles), or fenestrated (e.g. in liver sinusoids and to a lesser extent in glomerular capillaries).</li>
<li>Blood capillaries have the highest surface area (surface area exceeds <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>6300</mn><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">6300\mathrm{m}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">6300</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">m</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> in adults) and the lowest velocity of blood flow.</li>
<li>In spite of the thin wall of capillaries, they do not rupture because of their small diameter. Similarly, arterioles constrict to resist rupture when the perfusion pressure is high (explained by "Law of Laplace").</li>
<li>The law states that: the tension (T) in the wall of a cylinder is equal to the product of the transmural pressure (P) and the radius (r), divided by the wall thickness (w).</li>
</ul>
<p>FIG. 53</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-2978fa1f.jpeg" alt="img-300.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>As mentioned above: T = Pn/w</li>
<li>The transmural pressure (P) = pressure inside the cylinder - pressure in tissue which is negligible. Therefore (P) = the pressure inside the cylinder (= the distending pressure)</li>
<li>The wall thickness of capillaries (w) is negligible</li>
</ul>
<p>Therefore the equation becomes: T = P</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mi>P</mi><mi>P</mi></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><mtext>in&nbsp;blood&nbsp;vessels</mtext><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{P}{P} = \frac{1}{2} \left( \text{in blood vessels} \right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0463em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3603em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">P</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">P</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">in&nbsp;blood&nbsp;vessels</span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>w</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><mtext>in&nbsp;spheres</mtext><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">w = \frac{1}{2} \left( \text{in spheres} \right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02691em;">w</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">in&nbsp;spheres</span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>275</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The lines of section 265, column 1, column 2</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The junctions between endothelial cells in capillaries may be very light (e.g. in brain capillaries and to a lesser extent in muscles), or fenestrated (e.g. in liver sinusoids and to a lesser extent in glomerular capillaries).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Blood capillaries have the highest surface area (surface area exceeds <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>6300</mn><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">6300\mathrm{m}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">6300</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">m</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> in adults) and the lowest velocity of blood flow.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In spite of the thin wall of capillaries, they do not rupture because of their small diameter. Similarly, arterioles constrict to resist rupture when the perfusion pressure is high (explained by "Law of Laplace").</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The law states that: the tension (T) in the wall of a cylinder is equal to the product of the transmural pressure (P) and the radius (r), divided by the wall thickness (w).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>FIG. 53</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-73aa0831.jpeg" alt="img-301.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>As mentioned above: T = Pn/w</li>
<li>The transmural pressure (P) = pressure inside the cylinder - pressure in tissue which is negligible. Therefore (P) = the pressure inside the cylinder (= the distending pressure)</li>
<li>The wall thickness of capillaries (w) is negligible</li>
</ul>
<p>Therefore the equation becomes: T = P</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mi>P</mi><mi>P</mi></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><mtext>in&nbsp;blood&nbsp;vessels</mtext><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{P}{P} = \frac{1}{2} \left( \text{in blood vessels} \right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0463em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3603em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">P</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">P</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">in&nbsp;blood&nbsp;vessels</span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>w</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><mtext>in&nbsp;spheres</mtext><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">w = \frac{1}{2} \left( \text{in spheres} \right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02691em;">w</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">in&nbsp;spheres</span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>276</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The lines of section 265, column 1, column 2</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>From the above law, the smaller the radius of a blood vessel, the lower the tension that's needed to balance the distending pressure that's why vessels with smaller radius resist rupture.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>On the other hand, the pressure needed to inflate a sphere should be higher than the pressure inside (i.e. higher than P). Since P is inversely related to the radius, the smaller the radius, the higher the distending pressure needed for inflation.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vencies-and-ratios">Vencies and ratios<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vencies-and-ratios" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Their walls are relatively thin and easily distended. Therefore they can accommodate large volume of blood (capacitance vessels), for example they accommodate 50% of circulating blood at rest.</li>
<li>Venoconstitution occurring during hypotension (e.g. shock) adds large amount of this stored blood into the circulation.</li>
<li>The inner layer (intima) of the limb veins is folded into valves. These are absent from the veins in the abdomen, chest, head and neck.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lymphatics">Lymphatics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lymphatics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The excess interstitial fluid is collected by diffusion into lymphatic capillaries.</li>
<li>These start in the interstitium of the whole body, joined progressively together and traverse lymph nodes to drain eventually in the right and left subclavian veins, at the neck.</li>
<li>Once within the lymphatics, the fluid is called lymph. The lymph is similar to interstitial fluid; however, it circulates lymphocytes and transports lipids (chylomicrons) absorbed in the small intestine. It also carries small amount of protein-filtered from capillaries.</li>
<li>Lymphatic vessels contain valves, and there are no visible forestations in their walls.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-pulse-wave">The pulse wave<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-pulse-wave" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Is a pressure wave that travels along the blood vessels and expands them on its way. The expansion is palpable as pulse.</li>
</ul>
<p>227</p>
<p>The case of medical physiology: 17 values</p>
<ul>
<li>From the above law, the smaller the radius of a blood vessel, the lower the tension that's needed to balance the distending pressure, that's why vessels with smaller radius resist rupture.</li>
<li>On the other hand, the pressure needed to inflate a sphere should be higher than the pressure inside (i.e. higher than P). Since P is inversely related to the radius, the smaller the radius, the higher the distending pressure needed for inflation.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vencies-and-ratios">Vencies and ratios<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vencies-and-ratios" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Their walls are relatively thin and easily distended. Therefore they can accommodate large volume of blood (capacitance vessels), for example they accommodate 50% of circulating blood at rest.</li>
<li>Venoconstitution occurring during hypotension (e.g. shock) adds large amount of this stored blood into the circulation.</li>
<li>The inner layer (intima) of the limb veins is folded into valves. These are absent from the veins in the abdomen, chest, head and neck.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lymphatics">Lymphatics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lymphatics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The excess interstitial fluid is collected by diffusion into lymphatic capillaries.</li>
<li>These start in the interstitium of the whole body, joined progressively together and traverse lymph nodes to drain eventually in the right and left subclavian veins, at the neck.</li>
<li>Once within the lymphatics, the fluid is called lymph. The lymph is similar to interstitial fluid; however, it circulates lymphocytes and transports lipids (chylomicrons) absorbed in the small intestine. It also carries small amount of protein-filtered from capillaries.</li>
<li>Lymphatic vessels contain valves, and there are no visible forestations in their walls.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-pulse-wave">The pulse wave<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-pulse-wave" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Is a pressure wave that travels along the blood vessels and expands them on its way. The expansion is palpable as pulse.</li>
</ul>
<p>227</p>
<p>The case of medical physiology: 17 values</p>
<ul>
<li>From the above law, the smaller the radius of a blood vessel, the lower the tension that's needed to balance the distending pressure; that's why vessels with smaller radius resist rupture.</li>
<li>On the other hand, the pressure needed to inflate a sphere should be higher than the pressure inside (i.e. higher than P). Since P is inversely related to the radius, the smaller the radius, the higher the distending pressure needed for inflation.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vencies-and-ratios">Vencies and ratios<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vencies-and-ratios" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Their walls are relatively thin and easily distended. Therefore they can accommodate large volume of blood (capacitance vessels) for example they accommodate 50% of circulating blood at rest.</li>
<li>Venoconstitution occurring during hypotension (e.g. shock) adds large amount of this stored blood into the circulation.</li>
<li>The inner layer (intima) of the limb veins is folded into valves. These are absent from the veins in the abdomen, chest, head and neck.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lymphatics">Lymphatics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lymphatics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The excess interstitial fluid is collected by diffusion into lymphatic capillaries.</li>
<li>These start in the interstitium of the whole body, joined progressively together and traverse lymph nodes to drain eventually in the right and left subclavian veins, at the neck.</li>
<li>Once within the lymphatics, the fluid is called lymph. The lymph is similar to interstitial fluid; however, it circulates lymphocytes and transports lipids (chylomicrons) absorbed in the small intestine. It also carries small amount of protein-filtered from capillaries.</li>
<li>Lymphatic vessels contain valves, and there are no visible forestations in their walls.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-pulse-wave">The pulse wave<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-pulse-wave" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Is a pressure wave that travels along the blood vessels and expands them on its way. The expansion is palpable as pulse.</li>
</ul>
<p>227</p>
<p>The case of medical physiology: 17 values</p>
<p>278
The Journal of Medical Microbiology 17 (2004)</p>
<ul>
<li>In the arteries it is known as the arterial pulse. The pulse wave moves faster than the blood flow, especially with increased age (i.e. when the arteries lose their elastic fibers and become rigid).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-blood-flow">The blood flow<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-blood-flow" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The blood flow through a blood vessel = pressure/resistance.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is calculated directly by the Fick principle using special substances consumed by the organs to which the blood flow is being measured (revise measurement of the cardiac output). Examples include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>H₂O for cerebral blood flow (H₂O = nitrous oxide)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>PAH for renal blood flow (PAH = Paris-amino-hippuric acid)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Oxygen for blood flow in the lung (i.e. the cardiac output)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The aorta has the highest velocity of blood flow, then the velocity decreases gradually to be lowest in the capillaries and then it increases slightly in veins.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The blood flow through straight blood vessels is laminar. However, there is certain critical velocity above which the blood flow becomes turbulent.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This critical velocity may be exceeded at sites of constriction within a blood vessel, producing turbulence beyond the constriction, or in the heart due to rapid blood flow or closure of the valves.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Turbulent blood flow produces noise that is absent as brist over arteries or a murmur over the heart whereas laminar blood flow is silent.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="circulation-through-special-organs">CIRCULATION THROUGH SPECIAL ORGANS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#circulation-through-special-organs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-coronary-circulation">THE CORONARY CIRCULATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-coronary-circulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The cardiac muscle is supplied by the right and left coronary arteries that originate from coronary sinuses at the root of the aorta, behind two cusps of the aortic valves.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The venous blood is drained to the right atrium through the coronary sinus and anterior cardiac veins, however, small cardiac veins (e.g. thebesian veins) drain.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In the arteries it is known as the arterial pulse. The pulse wave moves faster than the blood flow, especially with increased age (i.e. when the arteries lose their elastic fibers and become rigid).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-blood-flow">The blood flow<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-blood-flow" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The blood flow through a blood vessel = pressure/resistance.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is calculated directly by the Fick principle using special substances consumed by the organs to which the blood flow is being measured (revise measurement of the cardiac output). Examples include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>H₂O for cerebral blood flow (H₂O = nitrous oxide)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>PAH for renal blood flow (PAH = Paris-amino-hippuric acid)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Oxygen for blood flow in the lung (i.e. the cardiac output)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The aorta has the highest velocity of blood flow, then the velocity decreases gradually to be lowest in the capillaries and then it increases slightly in veins.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The blood flow through straight blood vessels is laminar. However, there is certain critical velocity above which the blood flow becomes turbulent.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This critical velocity may be exceeded at sites of constriction within a blood vessel, producing turbulence beyond the constriction, or in the heart due to rapid blood flow or closure of the valves.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Turbulent blood flow produces noise that is absent as brist over arteries or a murmur over the heart whereas laminar blood flow is silent.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="circulation-through-special-organs">CIRCULATION THROUGH SPECIAL ORGANS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#circulation-through-special-organs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-coronary-circulation">THE CORONARY CIRCULATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-coronary-circulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The cardiac muscle is supplied by the right and left coronary arteries that originate from coronary sinuses at the root of the aorta, behind two cusps of the aortic valves.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The venous blood is drained to the right atrium through the coronary sinus and anterior cardiac veins, however, small cardiac veins (e.g. thebesian veins) drain.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In the arteries it is known as the arterial pulse. The pulse wave moves faster than the blood flow, especially with increased age (i.e. when the arteries lose their elastic fibers and become rigid).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-blood-flow">The blood flow<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-blood-flow" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The blood flow through a blood vessel = pressure/resistance.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is calculated directly by the Fick principle using special substances consumed by the organs to which the blood flow is being measured (revise measurement of the cardiac output). Examples include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>H₂O for cerebral blood flow (H₂O = nitrous oxide)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>PAH for renal blood flow (PAH = Paris-amino-hippuric acid)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Oxygen for blood flow in the lung (i.e. the cardiac output)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The aorta has the highest velocity of blood flow, then the velocity decreases gradually to be lowest in the capillaries and then it increases slightly in veins.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The blood flow through straight blood vessels is laminar. However, there is certain critical velocity above which the blood flow becomes turbulent.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This critical velocity may be exceeded at sites of constriction within a blood vessel, producing turbulence beyond the constriction, or in the heart due to rapid blood flow or closure of the valves.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Turbulent blood flow produces noise that is absent as brist over arteries or a murmur over the heart whereas laminar blood flow is silent.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="circulation-through-special-organs">CIRCULATION THROUGH SPECIAL ORGANS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#circulation-through-special-organs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-coronary-circulation">THE CORONARY CIRCULATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-coronary-circulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The cardiac muscle is supplied by the right and left coronary arteries that originate from coronary sinuses at the root of the aorta, behind two cusps of the aortic valves.</li>
<li>The venous blood is drained to the right atrium through the coronary sinus and anterior cardiac veins, however, small cardiac veins (e.g. thebesian veins) drain.</li>
</ul>
<p>279
The Journal of Medical Microbiology 17 (2004)</p>
<p>pile other chambers, resulting in reduction of the PC2 in arterial blood physiological shunt).</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Coronary blood flow to the left ventricle occurs during diastole and to the atria and the right ventricle occurs during both systole and diastole. This is explained by the pressure gradient between the aortic and thorax chambers during the cardiac cycle (see above).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The coronary blood flow = 250 mL/min (= 5% of the cardiac output). It is controlled by:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Metabolites (high CO₂, H⁺, lactate, K⁺, prostaglandins and adenosine): These are the primary dilators of the coronary artery. Among these metabolites adenosine is the most important dilator.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sympathetic stimulation: Both alpha and beta 2 receptors are found in the coronary artery but the direct sympathetic effect is vasoconstriction through alpha receptors; however, the sympathetic increases contractility and therefore increases metabolites. Through metabolites it causes vasodilatation and increases the coronary blood flow (i.e. the indirect effect is more dominant).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Parasympathetic stimulation: causes dilatation of the coronaries.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factors affecting the coronary blood flow (CBF) include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tachycardia (decreases diastole and therefore decreases coronary blood flow "CBF").</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Aortic stenosis (associated with severe compression of the coronary artery during systole of the left ventricle= decreases CBF).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypotension (= decreases pressure in aorta and therefore decreases CBF).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Reduction in the coronary blood flow (ischemia) decreases oxygen supply to the cardiac muscle. This produces severe chest pain that's aggravated by exercise and relieved by rest (engine packing).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Prolonged or severe ischemia (due to complete obstruction of the coronary artery) results in necrosis and death of the cardiac muscle (Myocardial Infarction). Here the pain is not relieved by rest.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>pile other chambers, resulting in reduction of the PC2 in arterial blood physiological shunt).</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Coronary blood flow to the left ventricle occurs during diastole and to the atria and the right ventricle occurs during both systole and diastole. This is explained by the pressure gradient between the aorta and thorax chambers during the cardiac cycle (see above).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The coronary blood flow = 250 mL/min (= 5% of the cardiac output). It is controlled by:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Metabolites (high CO₂, H⁺, lactate, K⁺, prostaglandins and adenosine): These are the primary dilators of the coronary artery. Among these metabolites adenosine is the most important dilator.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sympathetic stimulation: Both alpha and beta 2 receptors are found in the coronary artery but the direct sympathetic effect is vasoconstriction through alpha receptors; however, the sympathetic increases contractility and therefore increases metabolites. Through metabolites it causes vasodilatation and increases the coronary blood flow (i.e. the indirect effect is more dominant).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Parasympathetic stimulation: causes dilatation of the coronaries.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factors affecting the coronary blood flow (CBF) include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tachycardia (decreases diastole and therefore decreases coronary blood flow "CBF").</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Aortic stenosis (associated with severe compression of the coronary artery during systole of the left ventricle= decreases CBF).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypotension (= decreases pressure in aorta and therefore decreases CBF).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Reduction in the coronary blood flow (ischemia) decreases oxygen supply to the cardiac muscle. This produces severe chest pain that's aggravated by exercise and relieved by rest (engine packing).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Prolonged or severe ischemia (due to complete obstruction of the coronary artery) results in necrosis and death of the cardiac muscle (Myocardial Infarction). Here the pain is not relieved by rest.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>pile other chambers, resulting in reduction of the PC2 in arterial blood physiological shunt).</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Coronary blood flow to the left ventricle occurs during diastole and to the atria and the right ventricle occurs during both systole and diastole. This is explained by the pressure gradient between the aorta and thorax chambers during the cardiac cycle (see above).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The coronary blood flow = 200 mL/min (= 5% of the cardiac output). It is controlled by:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Metabolites (high CO₂, H⁺, lactate, K⁺, prostaglandins and adenosine): These are the primary dilators of the coronary artery. Among these metabolites adenosine is the most important dilator.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sympathetic stimulation: Both alpha and beta 2 receptors are found in the coronary artery but the direct sympathetic effect is vasoconstriction through alpha receptors; however, the sympathetic increases contractility and therefore increases metabolites. Through metabolites it causes vasodilatation and increases the coronary blood flow (i.e. the indirect effect is more dominant).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Parasympathetic stimulation: causes dilatation of the coronaries.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factors affecting the coronary blood flow (CBF) include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tachycardia (decreases diastole and therefore decreases coronary blood flow "CBF").</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Aortic stenosis (associated with severe compression of the coronary artery during systole of the left ventricle= decreases CBF).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypotension (= decreases pressure in aorta and therefore decreases CBF).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Reduction in the coronary blood flow (ischemia) decreases oxygen supply to the cardiac muscle. This produces severe chest pain that's aggravated by exercise and relieved by rest (engine packing).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Prolonged or severe ischemia (due to complete obstruction of the coronary artery) results in necrosis and death of the cardiac muscle (Myocardial Infarction). Here the pain is not relieved by rest.</p>
</li>
</ul>

<p>The notes of medical physiology / 4th edition</p>
<p>260
The cost of barbed wire savings of $100.00</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cerebral-circulation">CEREBRAL CIRCULATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cerebral-circulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>0.75 L/min (measured by the Fick principle using inhaled N₂O).</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>
<p>In addition to the sympathetic and parasympathetic innervation, cerebral blood vessels are supplied by sensory nerves. These nerves carry pain sensation triggered by traction or injury of these vessels.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The brain is very sensitive to hypoxia, occlusion of its blood supply causes unconsciousness in about 10 seconds.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Chronic hypoxia produces intellectual deficits and affects the basal ganglia, the thalamus and the inferior colliculus; however, the vegetative structures in the brain stem are more resistant to hypoxia.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="splanching-circulation">SPLANCHING CIRCULATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#splanching-circulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The liver receives 1.5 L/min of blood (0.5 L/min by the hepatic artery and 1.0 L/min by the portal vein).</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Other abdominal viscera receive about 1.0 L of blood per minute.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This indicates that the liver and viscera receive about 1.5 L of arterial blood per minute (in about 30% of the cardiac output).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>However, the blood flow to the small intestine increases after a meal for up to 3 hours and therefore shifts some of the blood supply to the brain. That's why subjects become sleepy after a meal.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The pressure in the portal vein has a clinical importance (&gt; 10 mmHg). It is high in patients with portal hypertension (e.g. due to biflunziasis).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cutaneous-circulation">CUTANEOUS CIRCULATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cutaneous-circulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>less than 0.5 L/min but varies with environmental temperature. It is controlled by sympathetic neurons (no parasympathetic supply).</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>Skin blood vessels develop the following reactions:</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>White reaction</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Follows light skin trauma by a pointed object.</li>
</ul>
<p>261
The cost of barbed wire savings of $100.00</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cerebral-circulation">CEREBRAL CIRCULATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cerebral-circulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>0.75 L/min (measured by the Fick principle using inhaled N₂O).</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>
<p>In addition to the sympathetic and parasympathetic innervation, cerebral blood vessels are supplied by sensory nerves. These nerves carry pain sensation triggered by traction or injury of these vessels.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The brain is very sensitive to hypoxia, occlusion of its blood supply causes unconsciousness in about 10 seconds.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Chronic hypoxia produces intellectual deficits and affects the basal ganglia, the thalamus and the inferior colliculus; however, the vegetative structures in the brain stem are more resistant to hypoxia.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="splanching-circulation">SPLANCHING CIRCULATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#splanching-circulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The liver receives 1.5 L/min of blood (0.5 L/min by the hepatic artery and 1.0 L/min by the portal vein).</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Other abdominal viscera receive about 1.0 L of blood per minute.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This indicates that the liver and viscera receive about 1.5 L of arterial blood per minute (in about 30% of the cardiac output).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>However, the blood flow to the small intestine increases after a meal for up to 3 hours and therefore shifts some of the blood supply to the brain. That's why subjects become sleepy after a meal.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The pressure in the portal vein has a clinical importance (&gt; 10 mmHg). It is high in patients with portal hypertension (e.g. due to biflunziasis).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cutaneous-circulation">CUTANEOUS CIRCULATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cutaneous-circulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>less than 0.5 L/min but varies with environmental temperature. It is controlled by sympathetic neurons (no parasympathetic supply).</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>Skin blood vessels develop the following reactions:</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>White reaction</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Follows light skin trauma by a pointed object.</li>
</ul>
<p>262
The cost of barbed wire savings of $100.00</p>
<p>The reaction is caused by reduction in capillary blood flow following contraction of the precapillary sphincter.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="therapymien">THERAPYMIEN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#therapymien" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Follows two skin trauma by a pointed object. It involves three changes in the skin:</li>
<li>Red reaction: (due to capillary dilatation by the pressure)</li>
<li>Local swelling (wheal): (due to increased capillary permeability)</li>
<li>Diffuse reddening (flave): (due to arteriolar dilatation)</li>
<li>The capillary changes appear to be due to local release of substance P.</li>
<li>The triple response is an example of axon reflex (in which afferent impulses exist antistromically through axons of sensory nerves).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="residual-hyperemia">Residual hyperemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#residual-hyperemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Increased blood flow to an area after a transient occlusion of its blood supply due to vasodilatation caused by hypoxia and metabolites.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cardenascular-responses-to-exercise">CARDENASCULAR RESPONSES TO EXERCISE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cardenascular-responses-to-exercise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The cardiovascular responses to exercise differ according to the type and level of exercise and according to the age and degree of training. Most of the responses involve changes in the cardiovascular and reparatory systems. The following is a brief account about some of the cardiovascular responses:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="increased-heart-rate-due-to">Increased heart rate due to:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#increased-heart-rate-due-to" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Increased sympathetic stimulation (due to stress)</li>
<li>Withdrawal of the parasympathetic effect on the heart (more important than the increased sympathetic)</li>
<li>Circulating catecholamines (from adrenal medulla &amp; sympathetic)</li>
<li>Propriocceptors (sand excitatory impulses to the medullary centers)</li>
<li>Temperature (stimulates the SA node directly)</li>
</ul>
<p>The reaction is caused by reduction in capillary blood flow following contraction of the precapillary sphincter.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="therapymien">THERAPYMIEN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#therapymien" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Follows two skin trauma by a pointed object. It involves three changes in the skin:</li>
<li>Red reaction: (due to capillary dilatation by the pressure)</li>
<li>Local swelling (wheal): (due to increased capillary permeability)</li>
<li>Diffuse reddening (flave): (due to arteriolar dilatation)</li>

</ul>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cardenascular-responses-to-exercise">CARDENASCULAR RESPONSES TO EXERCISE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cardenascular-responses-to-exercise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The cardiovascular responses to exercise differ according to the type and level of exercise and according to the age and degree of training. Most of the responses involve changes in the cardiovascular and reparatory systems. The following is a brief account about some of the cardiovascular responses:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="increased-heart-rate-due-to">Increased heart rate due to:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#increased-heart-rate-due-to" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Increased sympathetic stimulation (due to stress)</li>
<li>Withdrawal of the parasympathetic effect on the heart (more important than the increased sympathetic)</li>
<li>Circulating catecholamines (from adrenal medulla &amp; sympathetic)</li>
<li>Propriocceptors (sand excitatory impulses to the medullary centers)</li>
<li>Temperature (stimulates the SA node directly)</li>
</ul>
<p>The reaction is caused by reduction in capillary blood flow following contraction of the precapillary sphincter.</p>
<p>340
The view of medical psychology 2nd edition</p>
<ul>
<li>Backbridge effect (due to increased venous return by the muscle pump &amp; respiratory pump)</li>
<li>Stimulation of chemoreceptors (due to hypoxia and acidosis)</li>
<li>Stretch receptors in the lung (when the lung is inflated, impulses peak through the vagus to inhibit the cardio-inhibitory center)</li>
<li>The maximum heart rate (MHR) achieved during exercise decreases with age.</li>
<li>The easiest method to calculate it is by the formula:</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>MHR</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>220</mn><mo>⋅</mo><mtext>age</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{MHR} = 220 \cdot \text{age}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">MHR</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">220</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋅</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">age</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>However, there are many alternative formulas suggested by researchers (e.g. MHR = 200.9 - (0.97 x age))</p>
<ul>
<li>The best adverse start with lower heart rate because their resting heart rate is low (they have physiological bradycardia)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Increased stroke volume due to:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Increased sympathetic stimulation (due to stress)</li>
<li>Circulating catecholamines (from adrenal medulla &amp; sympathetic)</li>
<li>Temperature (stimulates the SA node directly)</li>
<li>Stimulation of chemoreceptors (due to hypoxia and acidosis)</li>
<li>Increased venous return + increases PTV (Frank-Starling's low)</li>
<li>Exercise with isotonic contractions produce marked increase in stroke volume whereas exercise with isometric contraction produces little change in it.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Increased venous return due to:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Muscle pump</li>
<li>Respiratory pump (hyperventilation)</li>
<li>Ventrolumination (by the sympathetic and catecholamines)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Increased cardiac output due to:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Increased HR &amp; SV</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Backbridge effect (due to increased venous return by the muscle pump &amp; respiratory pump)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stimulation of chemoreceptors (due to hypoxia and acidosis)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stretch receptors in the lung (when the lung is inflated, impulses peak through the vagus to inhibit the cardio-inhibitory center)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The maximum heart rate (MHR) achieved during exercise decreases with age.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The easiest method to calculate it is by the formula:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>MHR</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>220</mn><mo>⋅</mo><mtext>age</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{MHR} = 220 \cdot \text{age}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">MHR</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">220</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋅</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">age</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>However, there are many alternative formulas suggested by researchers (e.g. MHR = 200.9 - (0.97 x age))</p>
<ul>
<li>Trained athletes start with lower heart rate because their resting heart rate is low (they have physiological bradycardia)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Increased stroke volume due to:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Increased sympathetic stimulation (due to stress)</li>
<li>Circulating catecholamines (from adrenal medulla &amp; sympathetic)</li>
<li>Temperature (stimulates the SA node directly)</li>
<li>Stimulation of chemoreceptors (due to hypoxia and acidosis)</li>
<li>Increased venous return + increases LSV (Frank-Starling's low)</li>
<li>Exercise with isotonic contractions produce marked increase in stroke volume whereas exercise with isometric contraction produces little change in it.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Increased venous return due to:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Muscle pump</li>
<li>Respiratory pump (hyperventilation)</li>
<li>Ventrolumination (by the sympathetic and catecholamines)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Increased cardiac output due to:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Increased HR &amp; SV</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Backbridge effect (due to increased venous return by the muscle pump &amp; respiratory pump)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stimulation of chemoreceptors (due to hypoxia and acidosis)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stretch receptors in the lung (when the lung is inflated, impulses peak through the vagus to inhibit the cardio-inhibitory center)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The maximum heart rate (MHR) achieved during exercise decreases with age.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The easiest method to calculate it is by the formula:</p>
</li>

<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>MHR</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>220</mn><mo>⋅</mo><mtext>age</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{MHR} = 220 \cdot \text{age}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">MHR</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">220</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋅</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">age</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>

<ul>
<li>The best adverse start with lower heart rate because their resting heart rate is low (they have physiological bradycardia)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Increased stroke volume due to:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Increased sympathetic stimulation (due to stress)</li>
<li>Circulating catecholamines (from adrenal medulla &amp; sympathetic)</li>
<li>Temperature (stimulates the SA node directly)</li>
<li>Stimulation of chemoreceptors (due to hypoxia and acidosis)</li>
<li>Increased venous return + increases ESV (Frank-Starling's low)</li>
<li>Exercise with isotonic contractions produce marked increase in stroke volume whereas exercise with isometric contraction produces little change in it.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Increased venous return due to:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Muscle pump</li>
<li>Respiratory pump (hyperventilation)</li>
<li>Ventrolumination (by the sympathetic and catecholamines)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Increased cardiac output due to:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Increased HR &amp; SV</li>
</ul>
<p>341
The view of medical psychology 2nd edition</p>
<ul>
<li>Depends on degree of training and level of exercise</li>
<li>May reach more than 30L/min in athletes</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="increased-or-decreased-peripheral-resistance-pr-due-to">Increased or decreased peripheral resistance (PR) due to:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#increased-or-decreased-peripheral-resistance-pr-due-to" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Compression of blood vessels during isometric contractions (= increased peripheral resistance "PR")</li>
<li>Distortion of skeletal muscle arterioles during isotonic contractions (= decreased peripheral resistance). This dilatation occurs due to:</li>
<li>Sympathetic cholinergic discharge acting on M receptors</li>
<li>Circulating catecholamines acting on B1 receptors</li>
<li>Metabolites</li>
<li>Remember that the level of exercise determines the net effect on peripheral resistance. Hard exercise decreases PR.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-pressure-changes">Blood pressure changes:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-pressure-changes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Changes in systolic blood pressure are determined by the cardiac output whereas changes in the diastolic blood pressure are determined by the peripheral resistance.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Generally, isometric contraction increases both systolic and diastolic pressures whereas isotonic contraction increases the systolic and decreases the diastolic. However, these effects depend, to a large extent, on the level of exercise.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A statistical exercise the systolic is increased, the diastolic is decreased and therefore the pulse pressure is increased.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Depends on degree of training and level of exercise</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>May reach more than 30L/min in athletes</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="increased-or-decreased-peripheral-resistance-pr-due-to">Increased or decreased peripheral resistance (PR) due to:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#increased-or-decreased-peripheral-resistance-pr-due-to" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Compression of blood vessels during isometric contractions (= increased peripheral resistance "PR")</li>
<li>Distortion of skeletal muscle arterioles during isotonic contractions (= decreased peripheral resistance). This dilatation occurs due to:</li>
<li>Sympathetic cholinergic discharge acting on M receptors</li>
<li>Circulating catecholamines acting on B1 receptors</li>
<li>Metabolites</li>
<li>Remember that the level of exercise determines the net effect on peripheral resistance. Hard exercise decreases PR.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-pressure-changes">Blood pressure changes:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-pressure-changes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Changes in systolic blood pressure are determined by the cardiac output whereas changes in the diastolic blood pressure are determined by the peripheral resistance.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Generally, isometric contraction increases both systolic and diastolic pressures whereas isotonic contraction increases the systolic and decreases the diastolic. However, these effects depend, to a large extent, on the level of exercise.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A statistical exercise the systolic is increased, the diastolic is decreased and therefore the pulse pressure is increased.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Depends on degree of training and level of exercise</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>May reach more than 30L/min in athletes</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="increased-or-decreased-peripheral-resistance-pr-due-to">Increased or decreased peripheral resistance (PR) due to:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#increased-or-decreased-peripheral-resistance-pr-due-to" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Compression of blood vessels during isometric contractions (= increased peripheral resistance "PR")</li>
<li>Distortion of skeletal muscle arterioles during isotonic contractions (= decreased peripheral resistance). This dilatation occurs due to:</li>
<li>Sympathetic cholinergic discharge acting on M receptors</li>
<li>Circulating catecholamines acting on B1 receptors</li>
<li>Metabolites</li>
<li>Remember that the level of exercise determines the net effect on peripheral resistance. Hard exercise decreases PR.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-pressure-changes">Blood pressure changes:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-pressure-changes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Changes in systolic blood pressure are determined by the cardiac output whereas changes in the diastolic blood pressure are determined by the peripheral resistance.</li>
<li>Generally, isometric contraction increases both systolic and diastolic pressures whereas isotonic contraction increases the systolic and decreases the diastolic. However, these effects depend, to a large extent, on the level of exercise.</li>
<li>A statistical exercise the systolic is increased, the diastolic is decreased and therefore the pulse pressure is increased.</li>
</ul>
<p>The state of medical physiology of medicine
10
The state of medical physiology of medicine
10
The state of medical physiology of medicine</p>
<p>HEART FAILURE &amp; SHOCK</p>
<p>HEART FAILURE</p>
<ul>
<li>Defined as failure of the heart to meet the metabolic demands of tissues.</li>
<li>Causes include: Severe anemia, severe hypertension, arrhythmia, myocardial infarction, valvular disease and thyrotoxicosis.</li>
<li>Heart failure can be classified as:</li>
<li>Left sided HF (LHF): failure of the left side of the heart</li>
<li>Right sided HF (RHF): failure of the right side of the heart</li>
<li>Congestive HF (CHF): failure of the left &amp; right sides of the heart</li>
<li>Other terms may be used for example "high output heart failure" Here the cardiac output is increased; however, the high COP is still not enough to meet the metabolic demands of tissues which are highly increased (e.g. in thyrotoxicosis).</li>
</ul>
<p>Physiological mechanisms in heart failure</p>
<ul>
<li>All the mechanisms in heart failure are stimulated by hypotension and tissue hypoxia.</li>
<li>These include activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system because of the low blood supply to the kidney. This results in retention of sodium and water and therefore contributes to edema formation (see control of blood pressure).</li>
<li>When the left ventricle fails to eject blood (LHF), blood accumulates in the lung causing pulmonary edema whereas when the right ventricle fails (RHF), blood accumulates in the venous side causing raised JVP, hepatomegaly, ascites and lower limb edema.</li>
<li>When the two ventricles fail (CHF), blood accumulates in the lung and the venous side, therefore, all symptoms and signs of LHF and RHF are found in CHF.</li>
</ul>
<p>Symptoms of heart failure include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Due to blood accumulation in the lung &amp; pulmonary edema</li>
</ul>
<p>354</p>
<p>The case of medical physiology of values</p>
<p>HEART FAILURE &amp; SHOCK</p>
<p>HEART FAILURE</p>
