<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="somtheres-cours-in-lhf-chf">SOMTHERES: COURS IN LHF &amp; CHF<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#somtheres-cours-in-lhf-chf" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Cough occurs in LHF &amp; CHF</li>
<li>Sputum with blood: occurs in LHF &amp; CHF</li>
<li>Due to blood accumulation in venous side</li>
<li>LL swelling: occurs in RHF &amp; CHF</li>
<li>Venous pulsations in the neck: occur in RHF &amp; CHF</li>
<li>Due to low blood supply to muscles:</li>
<li>Fatigability &amp; weakness: may occur in all types of HF</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="other-symptoms">Other symptoms:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-symptoms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Palpitation: may occur in all types of HF</li>
<li>Cyanosis: may occur in all types of HF (especially LHF &amp; CHF)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="signs-of-lhf-include">Signs of LHF include:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#signs-of-lhf-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Tired heart sound (galloping rhythm)</li>
<li>Signs of pulmonary edema (basal crepitations)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="signs-of-rhf-include">Signs of RHF include:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#signs-of-rhf-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Tired heart sound (galloping rhythm)</li>
<li>Generalized edema</li>
<li>Engorged neck veins (raised JVP)</li>
<li>Hepatomegaly and sometimes splenomegaly</li>
<li>Ascites</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="signs-of-chf-include">Signs of CHF include:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#signs-of-chf-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Signs of both LHF &amp; RHF</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="signs-that-may-give-due-to-the-possible-cause-of-hf-include">Signs that may give due to the possible cause of HF include:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#signs-that-may-give-due-to-the-possible-cause-of-hf-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Displaced apex beat: LI ventricular hypertrophy (hypertension)</li>
<li>Pale mucus membranes: Anemia (or vasoconstriction)</li>
<li>Murnus: Valvular lesion</li>
<li>Irregular pulse: Arrhythmia (atrial fibrillation)</li>
<li>Goiter (thyroid enlargement): Thyrotoxicosis</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="investigations">Investigations:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#investigations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>To assess the heart: ECG, chest X ray and echocardiography.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="somtheres-cours-in-lhf-chf">SOMTHERES: COURS IN LHF &amp; CHF<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#somtheres-cours-in-lhf-chf" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>Cough occurs in LHF &amp; CHF</li>

<li>LL swelling: occurs in RHF &amp; CHF</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="other-symptoms">Other symptoms:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-symptoms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>Palpitation: may occur in all types of HF</li>
<li>Cyanosis: may occur in all types of HF (especially LHF &amp; CHF)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="signs-of-lhf-include">Signs of LHF include:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#signs-of-lhf-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Tired heart sound (galloping rhythm)</li>
<li>Signs of pulmonary edema (basal crepitations)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="signs-of-rhf-include">Signs of RHF include:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#signs-of-rhf-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Tired heart sound (galloping rhythm)</li>
<li>Generalized edema</li>
<li>Engorged neck veins (raised JVP)</li>
<li>Hepatomegaly and sometimes splenomegaly</li>
<li>Ascites</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="signs-of-chf-include">Signs of CHF include:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#signs-of-chf-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Signs of both LHF &amp; RHF</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="signs-that-may-give-due-to-the-possible-cause-of-hf-include">Signs that may give due to the possible cause of HF include:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#signs-that-may-give-due-to-the-possible-cause-of-hf-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Displaced apex beat: LI ventricular hypertrophy (hypertension)</li>
<li>Pale mucus membranes: Anemia (or vasoconstriction)</li>
<li>Murnus: Valvular lesion</li>
<li>Irregular pulse: Arrhythmia (atrial fibrillation)</li>
<li>Goiter (thyroid enlargement): Thyrotoxicosis</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="investigations">Investigations:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#investigations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>To assess the heart: ECG, chest X ray and echocardiography.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="somtheres-cours-in-lhf-chf">SOMTHERES: COURS IN LHF &amp; CHF<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#somtheres-cours-in-lhf-chf" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Cough occurs in LHF &amp; CHF</li>
<li>Sputum with blood: occurs in LHF &amp; CHF</li>
<li>Due to blood accumulation in venous side:</li>
<li>LL swelling: occurs in RHF &amp; CHF</li>
<li>Venous pulsations in the neck: occur in RHF &amp; CHF</li>
<li>Due to low blood supply to muscles:</li>
<li>Fatigability &amp; weakness: may occur in all types of HF</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="other-symptoms">Other symptoms:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-symptoms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Palpitation: may occur in all types of HF</li>
<li>Cyanosis: may occur in all types of HF (especially LHF &amp; CHF)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="signs-of-lhf-include">Signs of LHF include:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#signs-of-lhf-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Tired heart sound (galloping rhythm)</li>
<li>Signs of pulmonary edema (basal crepitations)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="signs-of-rhf-include">Signs of RHF include:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#signs-of-rhf-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Tired heart sound (galloping rhythm)</li>
<li>Generalized edema</li>
<li>Engorged neck veins (raised JVP)</li>
<li>Hepatomegaly and sometimes splenomegaly</li>
<li>Ascites</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="signs-of-chf-include">Signs of CHF include:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#signs-of-chf-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Signs of both LHF &amp; RHF</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="signs-that-may-give-due-to-the-possible-cause-of-hf-include">Signs that may give due to the possible cause of HF include:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#signs-that-may-give-due-to-the-possible-cause-of-hf-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Displaced apex beat: LI ventricular hypertrophy (hypertension)</li>
<li>Pale mucus membranes: Anemia (or vasoconstriction)</li>
<li>Murnus: Valvular lesion</li>
<li>Irregular pulse: Arrhythmia (atrial fibrillation)</li>
<li>Goiter (thyroid enlargement): Thyrotoxicosis</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="investigations">Investigations:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#investigations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>To assess the heart: ECG, chest X ray and echocardiography.</li>
</ul>
<p>302
303</p>
<p>For a possible cause: Hb and PCV, level of thyroid hormones in the plasma.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="treatment">Treatment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#treatment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Correction of the cause (e.g. blood transfusion for anemia)</li>
<li>Diuretics like 'Lasix' (for the fluid overload)</li>
<li>Angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEI) (to inhibit formation of angiotensin II and to decrease aldosterone)</li>
<li>Others (e.g. oxygen, morphine ...)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="shock">SHOCK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#shock" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Defined as state of the circulation in which there is inadequate tissue perfusion resulting in disturbance of functions.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="types">Types<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Hypovolemic shock (due to decreased blood volume)</li>
<li>Diastriative or low resistance shock (due to vasodilatation)</li>
<li>Cardiogenic shock (due to cardiac lesion causing low COP)</li>
<li>Obstructive shock (due to obstruction of blood flow in the chest)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="symptoms">Symptoms<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#symptoms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Irritability (due to low blood supply to the brain)</li>
<li>Chest (due to hypovolemia)</li>
<li>Palpitation (due to increased contractility of the heart for compensation)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="signs-not-in-all-types-of-shock">Signs (Not in all types of shock)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#signs-not-in-all-types-of-shock" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Pallor and cold clammy skin (due to vasoconstriction)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sweating (due to sympathetic activation)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tachycardia (due to sympathetic activation)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypotension (due to hypovolemia, vasodilatation, cardiac lesion or kinking of the aorta ...)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Low urine output (due to low renal blood flow and high release of ADH)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>For a possible cause: Hb and PCV, level of thyroid hormones in the plasma...</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="treatment">Treatment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#treatment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Correction of the cause (e.g. blood transfusion for anemia)</li>
<li>Diuretics like 'Lasix' (for the fluid overload)</li>
<li>Angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEI) (to inhibit formation of angiotensin II and to decrease aldosterone)</li>
<li>Others (e.g. oxygen, morphine ...)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="shock">SHOCK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#shock" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Defined as state of the circulation in which there is inadequate tissue perfusion resulting in disturbance of functions.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="types">Types<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Hypovolemic shock (due to decreased blood volume)</li>
<li>Diastriative or low resistance shock (due to vasodilatation)</li>
<li>Cardiogenic shock (due to cardiac lesion causing low COP)</li>
<li>Obstructive shock (due to obstruction of blood flow in the chest)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="symptoms">Symptoms<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#symptoms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Irritability (due to low blood supply to the brain)</li>
<li>Chest (due to hypovolemia)</li>
<li>Palpitation (due to increased contractility of the heart for compensation)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="signs-not-in-all-types-of-shock">Signs (Not in all types of shock)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#signs-not-in-all-types-of-shock" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Pallor and cold clammy skin (due to vasoconstriction)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sweating (due to sympathetic activation)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tachycardia (due to sympathetic activation)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypotension (due to hypovolemia, vasodilatation, cardiac lesion or kinking of the aorta ...)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Low urine output (due to low renal blood flow and high release of ADH)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>For a possible cause: Hb and PCV, level of thyroid hormones in the plasma...</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="treatment">Treatment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#treatment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Correction of the cause (e.g. blood transfusion for anemia)</li>
<li>Diuretics like 'Lasix' (for the fluid overload)</li>
<li>Angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEI) (to inhibit formation of angiotensin II and to decrease aldosterone)</li>
<li>Others (e.g. oxygen, morphine ...)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="shock">SHOCK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#shock" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Defined as state of the circulation in which there is inadequate tissue perfusion resulting in disturbance of functions.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="types">Types<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Hypovolemic shock (due to decreased blood volume)</li>
<li>Diastriative or low resistance shock (due to vasodilatation)</li>
<li>Cardiogenic shock (due to cardiac lesion causing low COP)</li>
<li>Obstructive shock (due to obstruction of blood flow in the chest)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="symptoms">Symptoms<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#symptoms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Irritability (due to low blood supply to the brain)</li>
<li>Chest (due to hypovolemia)</li>
<li>Palpitation (due to increased contractility of the heart for compensation)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="signs-not-in-all-types-of-shock">Signs (Not in all types of shock)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#signs-not-in-all-types-of-shock" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Pallor and cold clammy skin (due to vasoconstriction)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sweating (due to sympathetic activation)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tachycardia (due to sympathetic activation)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypotension (due to hypovolemia, vasodilatation, cardiac lesion or kinking of the aorta ...)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Low urine output (due to low renal blood flow and high release of ADH)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>For a possible cause:</p>
<p>307
The case of medical physiology / 1st edition</p>
<ul>
<li>Hyperventilation (due to chemoreceptor stimulation by hypoxia or acidosis)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Body responses to shock</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Revise the mechanisms that control the blood pressure (very rapid, less rapid and long term mechanisms)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Complications of shock</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Failure to treat shock leads to refractory or irreversible state. Here a positive feedback mechanism is initiated (low COP+ low blood pressure+ low venous return low COP+ low blood pressure and so on) which leads eventually to death.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Hypovolemic shock</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Subdivided according to the cause of hypovolemia into:</li>
<li>Hemorrhagic shock</li>
<li>Surgical shock</li>
<li>Traumatic shock</li>
<li>Burn shock</li>
<li>Shock of fluid loss (e.g. by vomiting or diarrhea)</li>
<li>The compensatory reactions to shock are rapid and long term (see control of blood pressure).</li>
<li>In hemorrhagic shock, plasma is restored in about 3 days whereas red blood cells are restored in 4-8 weeks.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Distributive shock</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Subdivided according to the cause of vasodilation into:</li>
<li>Anaphylactic shock (caused by histamine released by allergic reactions)</li>
<li>Septic shock (caused by endotoxins released by bacteria)</li>
<li>Neurogenic shock (caused by vasovagal attacks caused by severe traumatic pain in certain sites; e.g. testicular trauma)</li>
</ul>
<p>308
The case of medical physiology / 1st edition</p>
<ul>
<li>Hyperventilation (due to chemoreceptor stimulation by hypoxia or acidosis)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Body responses to shock</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Revise the mechanisms that control the blood pressure (very rapid, less rapid and long term mechanisms)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Complications of shock</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Failure to treat shock leads to refractory or irreversible state. Here a positive feedback mechanism is initiated (low COP+ low blood pressure+ low venous return low COP+ low blood pressure and so on) which leads eventually to death.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Hypovolemic shock</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Subdivided according to the cause of hypovolemia into:</li>
<li>Hemorrhagic shock</li>
<li>Surgical shock</li>
<li>Traumatic shock</li>
<li>Burn shock</li>
<li>Shock of fluid loss (e.g. by vomiting or diarrhea)</li>
<li>The compensatory reactions to shock are rapid and long term (see control of blood pressure).</li>
<li>In hemorrhagic shock, plasma is restored in about 3 days whereas red blood cells are restored in 4-8 weeks.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Distributive shock</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Subdivided according to the cause of vasodilation into:</li>
<li>Anaphylactic shock (caused by histamine released by allergic reactions)</li>
<li>Septic shock (caused by endotoxins released by bacteria)</li>
<li>Neurogenic shock (caused by vasovagal attacks caused by severe traumatic pain in certain sites, e.g. testicular trauma)</li>
</ul>
<p>309
The case of medical physiology / 1st edition</p>
<ul>
<li>Hyperventilation (due to chemoreceptor stimulation by hypoxia or acidosis)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Body responses to shock</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Revise the mechanisms that control the blood pressure (very rapid, less rapid and long term mechanisms)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Complications of shock</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Failure to treat shock leads to refractory or irreversible state. Here a positive feedback mechanism is initiated (low COP+ low blood pressure+ low venous return low COP+ low blood pressure and so on) which leads eventually to death.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Hypovolemic shock</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Subdivided according to the cause of hypovolemia into:</li>
<li>Hemorrhagic shock</li>
<li>Surgical shock</li>
<li>Traumatic shock</li>
<li>Burn shock</li>
<li>Shock of fluid loss (e.g. by vomiting or diarrhea)</li>
<li>The compensatory reactions to shock are rapid and long term (see control of blood pressure).</li>
<li>In hemorrhagic shock, plasma is restored in about 3 days whereas red blood cells are restored in 4-8 weeks.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Distributive shock</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Subdivided according to the cause of vasodilation into:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Anaphylactic shock (caused by histamine released by allergic reactions)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Septic shock (caused by endotoxins released by bacteria)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Neurogenic shock (caused by vasovagal attacks caused by severe traumatic pain in certain sites, e.g. testicular trauma)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Due to the vasodilatation, the skin is usually warm (this differentiates hypovolemic shock, in which the skin is cold, from distributive shock (like septic shock), in which the skin is warm.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cardiogenic-shock">Cardiogenic shock<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cardiogenic-shock" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Caused by diseases of the heart which impair the cardiac output</li>
<li>Examples include</li>
<li>Myocardial infarction</li>
<li>Arrhythmias</li>
<li>Congestive heart failure</li>
<li>In addition to the symptoms and signs of shock, there are usually symptoms and signs of pulmonary congestion.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="obstructive-shock">Obstructive shock<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#obstructive-shock" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Occurs due to obstruction of blood flow within the chest (looking of the aorta or interruption of pulmonary blood flow)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Examples include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tension pneumothorax</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cardiac tamponade</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cardiac tumor</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pulmonary embolism</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Due to the vasodilatation, the skin is usually warm (this differentiates hypovolemic shock, in which the skin is cold, from distributive shock (like septic shock), in which the skin is warm.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cardiogenic-shock">Cardiogenic shock<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cardiogenic-shock" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Caused by diseases of the heart which impair the cardiac output</li>
<li>Examples include:</li>
<li>Myocardial infarction</li>
<li>Arrhythmias</li>
<li>Congestive heart failure</li>
<li>In addition to the symptoms and signs of shock, there are usually symptoms and signs of pulmonary congestion.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="obstructive-shock">Obstructive shock<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#obstructive-shock" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Occurs due to obstruction of blood flow within the chest (looking of the aorta or interruption of pulmonary blood flow)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Examples include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tension pneumothorax</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cardiac tamponade</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cardiac tumor</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pulmonary embolism</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Due to the vasodilatation, the skin is usually warm (this differentiates hypovolemic shock, in which the skin is cold, from distributive shock (like septic shock), in which the skin is warm.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cardiogenic-shock">Cardiogenic shock<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cardiogenic-shock" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Caused by diseases of the heart which impair the cardiac output</li>
<li>Examples include:</li>
<li>Myocardial infarction</li>
<li>Arrhythmias</li>
<li>Congestive heart failure</li>
<li>In addition to the symptoms and signs of shock, there are usually symptoms and signs of pulmonary congestion.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="obstructive-shock">Obstructive shock<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#obstructive-shock" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs due to obstruction of blood flow within the chest (looking of the aorta or interruption of pulmonary blood flow)</li>
<li>Examples include:</li>
<li>Tension pneumothorax</li>
<li>Cardiac tamponade</li>
<li>Cardiac tumor</li>
<li>Pulmonary embolism</li>
</ul>
<p>The Journal of Medical Microbiology® 27 (2004)</p>
<p>The Journal of Medical Microbiology® 28 (2005)</p>
<p>The Journal of Medical Microbiology® 29 (2006)</p>
<p>QUESTIONS FOR SELF ASSESSMENT-8 (BEST OF FIVE)</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>The cardiac muscle differs from skeletal muscle because it is:
a. Striated muscle
b. Supplied by the autonomic nervous system
c. Inactive in the absence of external stimulation
d. Vasorelast after repeated stimulation
e. Active in the absence of oxygen</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The stroke volume is directly proportional to:
a. Parasympathetic stimulation
b. The chlorotropic effect of sympathetic stimulation
c. Bearing's forces
d. The initial length of muscle fibers
e. All of the above</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>During the cardiac cycle, closure of the aortic valve occurs at the:
a. End of isometric contraction
b. Beginning of rapid ejection phase
c. Beginning of ventricular relaxation
d. End of ventricular contraction
e. End of rapid firing phase</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Normal P wave in the ECG indicates:
a. Increased size of area
b. Normal atrial contraction
c. Ventricular depolarization
d. Normal cardiac pacemaker
e. Papillary muscle repolarization</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Which of the following about the ECG is not true:
a. Can detect the size of the heart
b. Is useful in detecting reduction in the coronary blood flow
c. It is recorded from limb leads and chest leads
d. It can detect some electrolyte disturbances
e. Is used for measurement of the cardiac output</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Measurement of cardiac output using Fick principle depends on:
a. Measurement of circulation time
b. Frequent arterial blood sampling
c. Use of a dye injected into an arm vein
d. Calculation of blood flow using the formula (blood flow= Q x 60/Ct)
e. None of the above</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Left ventricular heart failure leads to:
a. Increased pulmonary capillary hydrostatic pressure
b. Engorged neck veins
c. Bradycardia
d. Increased myocardial contractility
e. Ascites</p>
</li>
</ol>

<p>J09</p>
<p>The action of electrical (fibromyalgia - 4th edition)</p>
<p>270
The view of medical psychology 17 years</p>
<ol start="8">
<li>
<p>Coronary blood flow:
a. Is mainly regulated by sympathetic supply
b. Increases due to beta blockers
c. Is highest during systolic because of myocardial activity
d. Increases when myocardial metabolism increases
e. Is regulated by myogenic autoregulation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If the radius of an artery is halved (divided by 2) its resistance will increase:
a. 2 times
b. 4 times
c. 8 times
d. 10 times
e. 32 times</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>End diastolic volume may not increase in which of the following:
a. An increase in preload
b. Sympathetic stimulation
c. Reduction in the ejection fraction
d. An increase in venous return
e. An increase in afterload</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The pressure in the left ventricle:
a. Varies between 0 am 120 mmHg
b. Rises rapidly during ventricular filling
c. Shows a maximum of 60 mmHg
d. Falls rapidly during the initial phase of diastole
e. Remains constant during the rapid ejection phase</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Venous return:
a. Is increased on standing
b. Increases during inspiration
c. Is decreased by venoconstriction
d. When decreased, it activates barotrigine reflex
e. When increased, it increases both heart rate &amp; stroke volume</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Which of the following is a vasodilator:
a. Sarolanib
b. Erotolhibin
c. Nitric oxide (NO)
d. Thromboxane A2
e. Norasirophene</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When viscosity of blood is increased, which of the following is increased:
a. Systolic blood pressure
b. Diastolic blood pressure
c. Central venous pressure
d. Venous return
e. PCV</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>271
The view of medical psychology 17 years</p>
<ol start="8">
<li>
<p>Coronary blood flow:
a. Is mainly regulated by sympathetic supply
b. Increases due to beta blockers
c. Is highest during systolic because of myocardial activity
d. Increases when myocardial metabolism increases
e. Is regulated by myogenic autoregulation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If the radius of an artery is halved (divided by 2) its resistance will increase:
a. 2 times
b. 4 times
c. 8 times
d. 10 times
e. 32 times</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>End diastolic volume may not increase in which of the following:
a. An increase in preload
b. Sympathetic stimulation
c. Reduction in the ejection fraction
d. An increase in venous return
e. An increase in afterload</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The pressure in the left ventricle:
a. Varies between 0 am 120 mmHg
b. Rises rapidly during ventricular filling
c. Shows a maximum of 60 mmHg
d. Falls rapidly during the initial phase of diastole
e. Remains constant during the rapid ejection phase</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Venous return:
a. Is increased on standing
b. Increases during inspiration
c. Is decreased by venoconstriction
d. When decreased, it activates barotrigine reflex
e. When increased, it increases both heart rate &amp; stroke volume</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Which of the following is a vasodilator:
a. Sarolanib
b. Erotolhibin
c. Nitric oxide (NO)
d. Thromboxane A2
e. Norasirophene</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When viscosity of blood is increased, which of the following is increased:
a. Systolic blood pressure
b. Diastolic blood pressure
c. Central venous pressure
d. Venous return
e. PCV</p>
</li>
</ol>

b. Increases due to beta blockers
c. Is highest during systolic because of myocardial activity
d. Increases when myocardial metabolism increases
e. Is regulated by myogenic autoregulation</p>

a. 2 times
b. 4 times
c. 8 times
d. 10 times
e. 32 times</p>

a. An increase in preload
b. Sympathetic stimulation
c. Reduction in the ejection fraction
d. An increase in venous return
e. An increase in afterload</p>
</li>

a. Varies between 0 am 120 mmHg
b. Rises rapidly during ventricular filling
c. Shows a maximum of 60 mmHg
d. Falls rapidly during the initial phase of diastole
e. Remains constant during the rapid ejection phase</p>
</li>

a. Is increased on standing
b. Increases during inspiration
c. Is decreased by venoconstriction
d. When decreased, it activates barotrigine reflex
e. When increased, it increases both heart rate &amp; stroke volume</p>
</li>

c. Increased peripheral resistance
d. Edema

c. Characterized by tail peaked T wave in hypokalemia
d. Characterized by absent P wave in fast atrial fibrillation

d. Denervation of the S4 node</p>

b. QRS complex is due to ventricular recolarization
c. ST segment represents conduction in all the conductive system
d. No first heart sound follows the P wave
e. No third heart sound occurs at the same time as the P wave</p>
</li>

b. Depends on anaerobic metabolism for generation of energy

d. Osteogenic myemic contractions
e. Is not protected from tetanus</p>

</li>

a. Is about 2 L/min at rest in adults
b. Is always increased by increasing the heart rate</p>

<p>277</p>
<p>The use of aetio (p) (1)</p>
<p>CHAPTER 7</p>
<p>THE RESPIRATORY SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="structure-and-function">STRUCTURE AND FUNCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure-and-function" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="divisions">Divisions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#divisions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The respiratory system is divided anatomically into:</li>
<li>Upper respiratory tract (URT)</li>
<li>includes all structures outside the thoracic cavity (the chest). These are the nasal cavity, pharynx, larynx and upper part of the trachea.</li>
<li>Lower respiratory tract (LRT)</li>
<li>includes all structures inside the thoracic cavity. These are the lower part of the trachea, bronchi, bronchioles, alveolar sacs (including alveolar ducts and alveoli).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="fig-7-1-the-respiratory-system">Fig 7.1: The respiratory system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-7-1-the-respiratory-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-43d61c9d.jpeg" alt="img-302.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>The URT is characterized by presence of hair (within the nose), ciliated epithelium, mucus secreting cells and rich blood supply.</li>
<li>Evaporation of water from surface of the respiratory mucosa moisture and equilibrates temperature of inspired air with that of the body, thus making the inspired air suitable for gas exchange in the distal parts of the lung.</li>
</ul>
<p>274</p>
<p>The work of J. J. K. L. and R. J. S. P. is based on the following</p>
<p>CHAPTER 7</p>
<p>THE RESPIRATORY SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="structure-and-function">STRUCTURE AND FUNCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure-and-function" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="divisions">Divisions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#divisions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The respiratory system is divided anatomically into:</li>
<li>Upper respiratory tract (URT)</li>
<li>includes all structures outside the thoracic cavity (the chest). These are the nasal cavity, pharynx, larynx and upper part of the trachea.</li>
<li>Lower respiratory tract (LRT)</li>
<li>includes all structures inside the thoracic cavity. These are the lower part of the trachea, bronchi, bronchioles, alveolar sacs (including alveolar ducts and alveoli).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="fig-7-1-the-respiratory-system">Fig 7.1: The respiratory system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-7-1-the-respiratory-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-e6df8e7e.jpeg" alt="img-303.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>The URT is characterized by presence of hair (within the nose), ciliated epithelium, mucus secreting cells and rich blood supply.</li>
<li>Evaporation of water from surface of the respiratory mucosa moisture and equilibrates temperature of inspired air with that of the body, thus making the inspired air suitable for gas exchange in the distal parts of the lung.</li>
</ul>
<p>274</p>
<p>The work of J. J. K. L. and R. J. S. P. is based on the following</p>
<p>CHAPTER 7</p>
<p>THE RESPIRATORY SYSTEM</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="structure-and-function">STRUCTURE AND FUNCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure-and-function" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="divisions">Divisions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#divisions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The respiratory system is divided anatomically into:</li>
<li>Upper respiratory tract (URT)</li>
<li>includes all structures outside the thoracic cavity (the chest). These are the nasal cavity, pharynx, larynx and upper part of the trachea.</li>
<li>Lower respiratory tract (LRT)</li>
<li>includes all structures inside the thoracic cavity. These are the lower part of the trachea, bronchi, bronchioles, alveolar sacs (including alveolar ducts and alveoli).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="fig-7-1-the-respiratory-system">Fig 7.1: The respiratory system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-7-1-the-respiratory-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-a32439ad.jpeg" alt="img-304.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>The URT is characterized by presence of hair (within the nose), ciliated epithelium, mucus secreting cells and rich blood supply.</li>
<li>Evaporation of water from surface of the respiratory mucosa moisture and equilibrates temperature of inspired air with that of the body, thus making the inspired air suitable for gas exchange in the distal parts of the lung.</li>
</ul>
<p>274</p>
<ul>
<li>The respiratory system is divided according to major function:</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Conduction zone:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>For conduction of air to the lower zone, includes the nasal cavity, pharynx, larynx, trachea, bronchi and bronchioles (up to the terminal bronchioles).</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Respiratory zone:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>For gas exchange, includes the respiratory bronchioles and alveolar sacs (placate ducts and alveoli).</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Fig 7.2: Physiological divisions of the respiratory system</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-dbdb872c.jpeg" alt="img-305.jpeg"></p>
<p><strong>Important anatomical points</strong></p>
<p><strong>The trachea-bronchial tree</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Is formed by about 20 divisions. The first 10 divisions (starting from the trachea to the terminal bronchioles) form the conducting zone whereas the other divisions (starting from the respiratory bronchioles to the alveoli) form the respiratory zone.</li>
<li>The trachea and bronchi have cartilage in their walls but little smooth muscle while the bronchioles have smooth muscle in their walls but no cartilage.</li>
<li>The cartilage supports walls of the trachea and large bronchi and prevents their collapse when the pressure inside them is decreased (as occurs during inspiration).</li>
</ul>
<p>The respiratory system is divided according to major function:</p>
<p><strong>Conduction zone:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>For conduction of air to the lower zone, includes the nasal cavity, pharynx, larynx, trachea, bronchi and bronchioles (up to the terminal bronchioles).</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Respiratory zone:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>For gas exchange, includes the respiratory bronchioles and alveolar sacs (placate ducts and alveoli).</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Fig 7.2: Physiological divisions of the respiratory system</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-4dd289c8.jpeg" alt="img-306.jpeg"></p>
<p><strong>Important anatomical points</strong></p>
<p><strong>The trachea-bronchial tree</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Is formed by about 25 divisions. The first 10 divisions (starting from the trachea to the terminal bronchioles) form the conducting zone whereas the other divisions (starting from the respiratory bronchioles to the alveoli) form the respiratory zone.</li>
<li>The trachea and bronchi have cartilage in their walls but little smooth muscle while the bronchioles have smooth muscle in their walls but no cartilage.</li>
<li>The cartilage supports walls of the trachea and large bronchi and prevents their collapse when the pressure inside them is decreased (as occurs during inspiration).</li>
</ul>
<p>The respiratory system is divided according to major function:</p>
<p><strong>Conduction zone:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>For conduction of air to the lower zone, includes the nasal cavity, pharynx, larynx, trachea, bronchi and bronchioles (up to the terminal bronchioles).</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Respiratory zone:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>For gas exchange, includes the respiratory bronchioles and alveolar sacs (placate ducts and alveoli).</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Fig 7.2: Physiological divisions of the respiratory system</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-00def28a.jpeg" alt="img-307.jpeg"></p>
<p><strong>Important anatomical points</strong></p>
<p><strong>The trachea-bronchial tree</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Is formed by about 20 divisions. The first 10 divisions (starting from the trachea to the terminal bronchioles) form the conducting zone whereas the other divisions (starting from the respiratory bronchioles to the alveoli) form the respiratory zone.</li>
<li>The trachea and bronchi have cartilage in their walls but little smooth muscle while the bronchioles have smooth muscle in their walls but no cartilage.</li>
<li>The cartilage supports walls of the trachea and large bronchi and prevents their collapse when the pressure inside them is decreased (as occurs during inspiration).</li>
</ul>
<p>The respiratory system is divided according to major function:</p>
<p>276
The view of medical physiology 1st edition</p>
<ul>
<li>This support is lost in cases of bacheomatosis; that's why patients suffer from an inspiratory sound due to URT obstruction (strobr).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-lungs">The lungs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-lungs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The lungs (the right and the left lungs) are found within the thoracic cavity, protected by the rib cage. Each lung consists of parenchymal tissue supporting airways, blood vessels, nerves and lymphatics.</li>
<li>Each lung is divided, by horizontal and oblique fissures, into lobes. The right lung (consisting of 3 lobes) is larger than the left lung (consisting of 2 lobes due to presence of the heart). Both lungs provide a surface for gas exchange.</li>
<li>LRT diseases mainly affect the lungs. They include: inflammation of the lung (pneumonia), acute airway obstruction (asthma), chronic airway obstruction "COPD" (emphysema), lung fibrosis...</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-pleural-cavity">The Pleural cavity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-pleural-cavity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Each lung is covered by a membrane that's attached tightly to its outer surface (the visceral pleura). The membrane continues to line the inner surface of the chest wall (the parietal pleura).</li>
<li>The potential space which is formed between the visceral and parietal pleuras is called the pleural cavity.</li>
<li>The pleural cavity contains a few millimeters of fluid that acts as a lubricant. It allows easy expansion of the lungs and resists separation of the two membranes, therefore normally, no cavity is actually present.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-5fd908f8.jpeg" alt="img-308.jpeg">
Fig 7.3: The pleural cavity</p>
<ul>
<li>This support is lost in cases of tracheomatosis; that's why patients suffer from an inspiratory sound due to URT obstruction (strobr).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-lungs">The lungs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-lungs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The lungs (the right and the left lungs) are found within the thoracic cavity, protected by the rib cage. Each lung consists of parenchymal tissue supporting airways, blood vessels, nerves and lymphatics.</li>
<li>Each lung is divided, by horizontal and oblique fissures, into lobes. The right lung (consisting of 3 lobes) is larger than the left lung (consisting of 2 lobes due to presence of the heart). Both lungs provide a surface for gas exchange.</li>
<li>LRT diseases mainly affect the lungs. They include: inflammation of the lung (pneumonia), acute airway obstruction (asthma), chronic airway obstruction "COPD" (emphysema), lung fibrosis...</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-pleural-cavity">The Pleural cavity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-pleural-cavity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Each lung is covered by a membrane that's attached tightly to its outer surface (the visceral pleura). The membrane continues to line the inner surface of the chest wall (the parietal pleura).</li>
<li>The potential space which is formed between the visceral and parietal pleuras is called the pleural cavity.</li>
<li>The pleural cavity contains a few millimeters of fluid that acts as a lubricant. It allows easy expansion of the lungs and resists separation of the two membranes, therefore normally, no cavity is actually present.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-e61af8c3.jpeg" alt="img-309.jpeg">
Fig 7.3: The pleural cavity</p>
<ul>
<li>This support is lost in cases of tracheomatosis; that's why patients suffer from an inspiratory sound due to URT obstruction (strobr).</li>
