<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-lungs">The lungs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-lungs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The lungs (the right and the left lungs) are found within the thoracic cavity, protected by the rib cage. Each lung consists of parenchymal tissue supporting airways, blood vessels, nerves and lymphatics.</li>
<li>Each lung is divided, by horizontal and oblique fissures, into lobes. The right lung (consisting of 3 lobes) is larger than the left lung (consisting of 2 lobes due to presence of the heart). Both lungs provide a surface for gas exchange.</li>
<li>LRT diseases mainly affect the lungs. They include: inflammation of the lung (pneumonia), acute airway obstruction (asthma), chronic airway obstruction "COPD" (emphysema), lung fibrosis...</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-pleural-cavity">The Pleural cavity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-pleural-cavity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Each lung is covered by a membrane that's attached tightly to its outer surface (the visceral pleura). The membrane continues to line the inner surface of the chest wall (the parietal pleura).</li>
<li>The potential space which is formed between the visceral and parietal pleuras is called the pleural cavity.</li>
<li>The pleural cavity contains a few millimeters of fluid that acts as a lubricant. It allows easy expansion of the lungs and resists separation of the two membranes, therefore normally, no cavity is actually present.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-8529b996.jpeg" alt="img-310.jpeg">
Fig 7.3: The pleural cavity</p>
<p>277
The view of medical physiology 1st edition</p>
<p>210
The care of medical physiology of asthma</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-the-respiratory-system">FUNCTIONS OF THE RESPIRATORY SYSTEM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-the-respiratory-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Provides oxygen to the tissues</li>
<li>Eliminates carbon dioxide from the tissues</li>
<li>Participates in regulation of pH of the blood</li>
<li>These are the major functions of the respiratory system; however, participation of other systems is essential to perform these functions, especially the blood, cardiovascular system and the renal system.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="other-functions-of-the-respiratory-system">Other functions of the respiratory system:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-functions-of-the-respiratory-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Participates in regulation of body temperature. Hyperventilation increases heat loss by evaporation from the mucus membranes. This is especially important in animals like dogs "parking".</li>
<li>Has some important metabolic functions. Thesanotulate:</li>
<li>Conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II (by angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) which is produced by the pulmonary endothelium).</li>
<li>Restriction of certain vasoactive substances like bradykinin (also by ACE).</li>
<li>Breakdown of arachidonic acid metabolites like prostaglandins and isoborners.</li>
<li>Synthesis of surfactant (see below).</li>
<li>Has many important defense mechanisms.</li>
<li>Hairs within the nose for filtration of air (removes particles &gt; 10 µm in diameter).</li>
<li>Mucus on the surface of respiratory epithelium for trapping smaller particles (2-10 µm in diameter). It is found mainly in the upper respiratory tract.</li>
<li>Cilia on cells for transporting the trapped particles upwards towards the nasopharynx to be swallowed or coughed out (= This is known as mucociliary clearance). They are present up to the respiratory bronchioles.</li>
<li>Cough or sneezing reflexes for ejection of unwanted substances through the mouth to the outside.</li>
</ul>
<p>211
The care of medical physiology of asthma</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-the-respiratory-system">FUNCTIONS OF THE RESPIRATORY SYSTEM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-the-respiratory-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Provides oxygen to the tissues</li>
<li>Eliminates carbon dioxide from the tissues</li>
<li>Participates in regulation of pH of the blood</li>
<li>These are the major functions of the respiratory system; however, participation of other systems is essential to perform these functions, especially the blood, cardiovascular system and the renal system.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="other-functions-of-the-respiratory-system">Other functions of the respiratory system:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-functions-of-the-respiratory-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Participates in regulation of body temperature. Hyperventilation increases heat loss by evaporation from the mucus membranes. This is especially important in animals like dogs "parking".</li>
<li>Has some important metabolic functions. Thesanotulate:</li>
<li>Conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II (by angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) which is produced by the pulmonary endothelium).</li>
<li>Restriction of certain vasoactive substances like bradykinin (also by ACE).</li>
<li>Breakdown of arachidonic acid metabolites like prostaglandins and isoborners.</li>
<li>Synthesis of surfactant (see below).</li>
<li>Has many important defense mechanisms.</li>
<li>Hairs within the nose for filtration of air (removes particles &gt; 10 µm in diameter).</li>
<li>Mucus on the surface of respiratory epithelium for trapping smaller particles (2-10 µm in diameter). It is found mainly in the upper respiratory tract.</li>
<li>Cilia on cells for transporting the trapped particles upwards towards the nasopharynx to be swallowed or coughed out (= This is known as mucociliary clearance). They are present up to the respiratory bronchioles.</li>
<li>Cough or sneezing reflexes for ejection of unwanted substances through the mouth to the outside.</li>
</ul>
<p>212
The care of medical physiology of asthma</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-the-respiratory-system">FUNCTIONS OF THE RESPIRATORY SYSTEM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-the-respiratory-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Provides oxygen to the tissues</li>
<li>Eliminates carbon dioxide from the tissues</li>
<li>Participates in regulation of pH of the blood</li>
<li>These are the major functions of the respiratory system; however, participation of other systems is essential to perform these functions, especially the blood, cardiovascular system and the renal system.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="other-functions-of-the-respiratory-system">Other functions of the respiratory system:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-functions-of-the-respiratory-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Participates in regulation of body temperature. Hyperventilation increases heat loss by evaporation from the mucus membranes. This is especially important in animals like dogs "parking".</li>
<li>Has some important metabolic functions. Thesanotulate:</li>
<li>Conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II (by angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) which is produced by the pulmonary endothelium).</li>
<li>Restriction of certain vasoactive substances like bradykinin (also by ACE).</li>
<li>Breakdown of arachidonic acid metabolites like prostaglandins and isoborners.</li>
<li>Synthesis of surfactant (see below).</li>
<li>Has many important defense mechanisms.</li>
<li>Hairs within the nose for filtration of air (removes particles &gt; 10 µm in diameter).</li>
<li>Mucus on the surface of respiratory epithelium for trapping smaller particles (2-10 µm in diameter). It is found mainly in the upper respiratory tract.</li>
<li>Cilia on cells for transporting the trapped particles upwards towards the nasopharynx to be swallowed or coughed out (= This is known as mucociliary clearance). They are present up to the respiratory bronchioles.</li>
<li>Cough or sneezing reflexes for ejection of unwanted substances through the mouth to the outside.</li>
</ul>
<p>213
The care of medical physiology of asthma</p>
<p>274
The view of medical physiology 17th edition
275
The view of medical physiology 17th edition</p>
<ul>
<li>IgA antibodies and complement proteins within the respiratory secretions for certain antigens.</li>
<li>Antiproteases (e.g. alpha 1-antitrypsin) for proteases released from dead bacteria or WBCs.</li>
<li>Alveolar macrophages for ingestion of bacteria, debris and foreign particles that reach the alveoli (usually less than 2 μm in diameter).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="remember-these-clinical-notes">Remember these clinical notes:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remember-these-clinical-notes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>ACE inhibitors are used for treatment of hypertension. They block the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II however, they also block the breakdown of bradykinin by the angiotensin converting enzyme. This results in many side effects caused by the bradykinin, including angioedema and irritating cough. For this reason, shifting to angiotensin receptor blockers instead of ACE inhibitors is very important for patients who suffer from these side effects. The receptor blockers block effects of angiotensin II without affecting the converting enzyme, therefore the enzyme inactivates bradykinin.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Congenital or acquired deficiency of one or more of the above defense mechanisms results in certain respiratory problems, for example: deficiency of IgA antibodies causes repeated respiratory infections, deficiency of alpha 1-antitrypsin causes destruction of the lung tissue by proteases (as occurs in emphysema) and impaired muscociliary clearance due to immobile cilia causes repeated respiratory infections (as occurs in primary ciliary dyskinesia, also known as Kartagener's syndrome).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>IgA antibodies and complement proteins within the respiratory secretions for certain antigens.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Antiproteases (e.g. alpha 1-antitrypsin) for proteases released from dead bacteria or WBCs.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Alveolar macrophages for ingestion of bacteria, debris and foreign particles that reach the alveoli (usually less than 2 μm in diameter).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="remember-these-clinical-notes">Remember these clinical notes:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remember-these-clinical-notes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>ACE inhibitors are used for treatment of hypertension. They block the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II however, they also block the breakdown of bradykinin by the angiotensin converting enzyme. This results in many side effects caused by the bradykinin, including angioedema and irritating cough. For this reason, shifting to angiotensin receptor blockers instead of ACE inhibitors is very important for patients who suffer from these side effects. The receptor blockers block effects of angiotensin II without affecting the converting enzyme, therefore the enzyme inactivates bradykinin.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Congenital or acquired deficiency of one or more of the above defense mechanisms results in certain respiratory problems, for example: deficiency of IgA antibodies causes repeated respiratory infections, deficiency of alpha 1-antitrypsin causes destruction of the lung tissue by proteases (as occurs in emphysema) and impaired muscociliary clearance due to immobile cilia causes repeated respiratory infections (as occurs in primary ciliary dyskinesia, also known as Kartagener's syndrome).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>IgA antibodies and complement proteins within the respiratory secretions for certain antigens.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Antiproteases (e.g. alpha 1-antitrypsin) for proteases released from dead bacteria or WBCs.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Alveolar macrophages for ingestion of bacteria, debris and foreign particles that reach the alveoli (usually less than 2 μm in diameter).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="remember-these-clinical-notes">Remember these clinical notes:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remember-these-clinical-notes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>ACE inhibitors are used for treatment of hypertension. They block the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II however, they also block the breakdown of bradykinin by the angiotensin converting enzyme. This results in many side effects caused by the bradykinin, including angioedema and irritating cough. For this reason, shifting to angiotensin receptor blockers instead of ACE inhibitors is very important for patients who suffer from these side effects. The receptor blockers block effects of angiotensin II without affecting the converting enzyme, therefore the enzyme inactivates bradykinin.</li>
<li>Congenital or acquired deficiency of one or more of the above defense mechanisms results in certain respiratory problems, for example: deficiency of IgA antibodies causes repeated respiratory infections, deficiency of alpha 1-antitrypsin causes destruction of the lung tissue by proteases (as occurs in emphysema) and impaired muscociliary clearance due to immobile cilia causes repeated respiratory infections (as occurs in primary ciliary dyskinesia, also known as Kartagener's syndrome).</li>
</ul>
<p>270
The costs of medical job casings - 271, 272</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="distribution">DISTRIBUTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#distribution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>Stockholm</strong></p>
<p>Stockholm is the process of getting air into and out of the lungs during packing. It is always adjusted to meet the metabolic demands of the body (i.e. to provide sufficient oxygen and to eliminate excess carbon dioxide).</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>Approximate</strong> refers to ventilation in excess of the metabolic demands of the tissues. It usually results in hypocapnia (low Pos.).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Approximate</strong> refers to ventilation less than the metabolic demands of the tissues. It results in hypercapnia (high Pos.).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Mechanism of ventilation</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Air moves into or out of the lungs due to pressure gradient (when the atmospheric pressure is higher than the intra Pulmonary pressure it gets into the lungs (n. respiration); and when the atmospheric pressure is lower than the intra Pulmonary pressure it gets out of the lungs (n. expiration)).</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Os.T.K. Ventilation</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-ec2d9680.jpeg" alt="img-311.jpeg"></p>
<p>271
The costs of medical job casings - 272</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="distribution">DISTRIBUTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#distribution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>Stockholm</strong></p>
<p>Stockholm is the process of getting air into and out of the lungs during packing. It is always adjusted to meet the metabolic demands of the body (i.e. to provide sufficient oxygen and to eliminate excess carbon dioxide).</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>Approximate</strong> refers to ventilation in excess of the metabolic demands of the tissues. It usually results in hypocapnia (low Pos.).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Approximate</strong> refers to ventilation less than the metabolic demands of the tissues. It results in hypercapnia (high Pos.).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Mechanism of ventilation</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Air moves into or out of the lungs due to pressure gradient (when the atmospheric pressure is higher than the intra Pulmonary pressure it gets into the lungs (n. respiration); and when the atmospheric pressure is lower than the intra Pulmonary pressure it gets out of the lungs (n. expiration)).</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Os.T.K. Ventilation</strong></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-663b89c9.jpeg" alt="img-312.jpeg"></p>
<p>272</p>
<ul>
<li>According to Boyle's law, there is an inverse relationship between pressure of gases and volume. Therefore, there is an inverse relationship between pressure within the lungs and their size.</li>
<li>Inspiration results in inflation of the lungs and therefore reduction in intrapulmonary pressure (IPP) whereas expiration does the reverse.</li>
<li>The following table shows variations in IPP during respiration:</li>
</ul>
<p>Table 7.1: The intrapulmonary pressure</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Phase of respiration (with closed glottis)</th><th>IPP</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>End of normal inspiration</td><td>1 mmHg</td></tr><tr><td>End of normal expiration</td><td>+1 mmHg</td></tr><tr><td>End of maximum inspiration</td><td>-20 mmHg</td></tr><tr><td>End of max expiration (volume maneuver)</td><td>&gt;+50 mmHg</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Remember that:</p>
<ul>
<li>The atmospheric pressure is 760 mmHg. Values of the IPP indicate difference from the atmospheric pressure. A value of -1 mmHg indicates a pressure less than the atmospheric by 1 (i.e. 700 mmHg) whereas +1 indicates a higher pressure (761 mmHg).</li>
<li>Closure of the glottis at the upper part of the larynx includes the respiratory system from the atmosphere. Therefore, there is no equilibration between IPP and atmospheric pressure.</li>
<li>Opening of glottis allows equilibration of IPP with the atmospheric pressure. That's why the IPP reaches -1 during inspiration and then becomes zero at the end of inspiration (i.e. +760 mmHg, similar to the atmospheric pressure).</li>
<li>Opening of the glottis allows IPP to reach zero at the end of all respiratory phases (total inspiration, total expiration, max inspiration &amp; max expiration).</li>
</ul>
<p>Intrapleural pressure (IPLP)</p>
<ul>
<li>The intra pleural pressure (IPLP) undergoes similar changes, however, opening and closure of the glottis do not change its values.</li>
<li>The following table shows variations in IPLP during respiration:</li>
</ul>
<p>Table 7.1: The intrapulmonary pressure</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Phase of respiration (with closed glottis)</th><th>IPP</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>End of normal inspiration</td><td>1 mmHg</td></tr><tr><td>End of normal expiration</td><td>+1 mmHg</td></tr><tr><td>End of maximum inspiration</td><td>+20 mmHg</td></tr><tr><td>End of max expiration (volume maneuver)</td><td>&gt;+50 mmHg</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Remember that:</p>
<ul>
<li>The atmospheric pressure is 760 mmHg. Values of the IPP indicate difference from the atmospheric pressure. A value of -1 mmHg indicates a pressure less than the atmospheric by 1 (i.e. 700 mmHg) whereas +1 indicates a higher pressure (761 mmHg).</li>
<li>Closure of the glottis at the upper part of the larynx includes the respiratory system from the atmosphere. Therefore, there is no equilibration between IPP and atmospheric pressure.</li>
<li>Opening of glottis allows equilibration of IPP with the atmospheric pressure. That's why the IPP reaches -1 during inspiration and then becomes zero at the end of inspiration (i.e. +760 mmHg, similar to the atmospheric pressure).</li>
<li>Opening of the glottis allows IPP to reach zero at the end of all respiratory phases (total inspiration, total expiration, max inspiration &amp; max expiration).</li>
</ul>
<p>Intrapleural pressure (IPLP)</p>
<ul>
<li>The intra pleural pressure (IPLP) undergoes similar changes, however, opening and closure of the glottis do not change its values.</li>
<li>The following table shows variations in IPLP during respiration:</li>
</ul>
<p>Table 7.1: The intrapulmonary pressure</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Phase of respiration (with closed glottis)</th><th>IPP</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>End of normal inspiration</td><td>1 mmHg</td></tr><tr><td>End of normal expiration</td><td>+1 mmHg</td></tr><tr><td>End of maximum inspiration</td><td>+20 mmHg</td></tr><tr><td>End of max expiration (volume maneuver)</td><td>&gt;+50 mmHg</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Remember that:</p>
<ul>
<li>The atmospheric pressure is 760 mmHg. Values of the IPP indicate difference from the atmospheric pressure. A value of -1 mmHg indicates a pressure less than the atmospheric by 1 (i.e. 700 mmHg) whereas +1 indicates a higher pressure (761 mmHg).</li>
<li>Closure of the glottis at the upper part of the larynx includes the respiratory system from the atmosphere. Therefore, there is no equilibration between IPP and atmospheric pressure.</li>
<li>Opening of glottis allows equilibration of IPP with the atmospheric pressure. That's why the IPP reaches -1 during inspiration and then becomes zero at the end of inspiration (i.e. +760 mmHg, similar to the atmospheric pressure).</li>
<li>Opening of the glottis allows IPP to reach zero at the end of all respiratory phases (total inspiration, total expiration, max inspiration &amp; max expiration).</li>
</ul>
<p>Intrapleural pressure (IPLP)</p>
<ul>
<li>The intra pleural pressure (IPLP) undergoes similar changes, however, opening and closure of the glottis do not change its values.</li>
<li>The following table shows variations in IPLP during respiration:</li>
</ul>
<p>Table 7.1: The intrapulmonary pressure</p>
<p>Table 7.2: The intrapleural pressure</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Phase of respiration</th><th>IPLF</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>End of normal respiration</td><td>6 mmHg</td></tr><tr><td>End of normal expiration</td><td>2.5 mmHg</td></tr><tr><td>End of maximum respiration</td><td>40 mmHg</td></tr><tr><td>End of max expiration (cetronel maneuver)</td><td>&gt; 450 mmHg</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><strong>References: Fall</strong></p>
<p>a The intrapleural pressure is subatmospheric (net) during normal respiration and expiration whereas the intrapulmonary pressure is -ve during respiration and +ve during expiration.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Negativity of intrapleural pressure is explained by the tendency of the lung and the chest wall to recoil into opposite directions (the lung tends to recoil inwards, due to its elastic properties, whereas the chest tends to recoil outwards, due to position of the ribs).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The point when recoil of the lung equals recoil of the chest is the end of normal expiration. Here the volume of air within the lungs equals the functional residual capacity (see below).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In the upright position there is difference in intrapleural pressure between apex and base of the lung, because of gravity. The pressure at the apex is lower than that at the base. That's why there is higher tendency of bullae at the apex of an emphysematous lung to rupture more than bullae at the base.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Mechanism of inspiration:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Contraction of inspiratory muscles</li>
<li>Expansion of the chest</li>
<li>Reduction of intrapleural pressure</li>
<li>Expansion of the lungs</li>
<li>Reduction of intrapulmonary pressure</li>
<li>Air moves into the lungs</li>
</ul>
<p>(25)</p>
<p>The term of residual pleura (Fig. 2) is</p>
<p>Table 7.2: The intrapleural pressure</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Phase of respiration</th><th>IPLF</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>End of normal respiration</td><td>6 mmHg</td></tr><tr><td>End of normal expiration</td><td>2.5 mmHg</td></tr><tr><td>End of maximum respiration</td><td>40 mmHg</td></tr><tr><td>End of max expiration (cetronel maneuver)</td><td>&gt; 450 mmHg</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><strong>References: Fall</strong></p>
<p>a The intrapleural pressure is subatmospheric (net) during normal respiration and expiration whereas the intrapulmonary pressure is -ve during respiration and +ve during expiration.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Negativity of intrapleural pressure is explained by the tendency of the lung and the chest wall to recoil into opposite directions (the lung tends to recoil inwards, due to its elastic properties, whereas the chest tends to recoil outwards, due to position of the ribs).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The point when recoil of the lung equals recoil of the chest is the end of normal expiration. Here the volume of air within the lungs equals the functional residual capacity (see below).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In the upright position there is difference in intrapleural pressure between apex and base of the lung, because of gravity. The pressure at the apex is lower than that at the base. That's why there is higher tendency of bullae at the apex of an emphysematous lung to rupture more than bullae at the base.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Mechanism of inspiration:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Contraction of inspiratory muscles</li>
<li>Expansion of the chest</li>
<li>Reduction of intrapleural pressure</li>
<li>Expansion of the lungs</li>
<li>Reduction of intrapulmonary pressure</li>
<li>Air moves into the lungs</li>
</ul>
<p>(26)</p>
<p>The term of residual pleura (Fig. 2) is</p>
<p>Table 7.2: The intrapleural pressure</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Phase of respiration</th><th>IPLF</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>End of normal respiration</td><td>6 mmHg</td></tr><tr><td>End of normal expiration</td><td>2.5 mmHg</td></tr><tr><td>End of maximum respiration</td><td>40 mmHg</td></tr><tr><td>End of max expiration (cetronel maneuver)</td><td>&gt; 450 mmHg</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><strong>References: Fall</strong></p>
<p>a The intrapleural pressure is subatmospheric (net) during normal respiration and expiration whereas the intrapulmonary pressure is -ve during respiration and +ve during expiration.</p>
<p>Negativity of intrapleural pressure is explained by the tendency of the lung and the chest wall to recoil into opposite directions (the lung tends to recoil inwards, due to its elastic properties, whereas the chest tends to recoil outwards, due to position of the ribs).</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The point when recoil of the lung equals recoil of the chest is the end of normal expiration. Here the volume of air within the lungs equals the functional residual capacity (see below).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In the upright position, there is difference in intrapleural pressure between apex and base of the lung, because of gravity. The pressure at the apex is lower than that at the base. That's why there is higher tendency of bullae at the apex of an emphysematous lung to rupture more than bullae at the base.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Mechanism of inspiration:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Contraction of inspiratory muscles</li>
<li>Expansion of the chest</li>
<li>Reduction of intrapleural pressure</li>
<li>Expansion of the lungs</li>
<li>Reduction of intrapulmonary pressure</li>
<li>Air moves into the lungs</li>
</ul>
<p>(28)</p>
<p>The term of residual pleura (Fig. 2) is</p>
<ul>
<li>Inspiration is an active process because it involves contraction of inspiratory muscles. The inspiratory muscles can be grouped into:</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Inspiratory muscles working at rest (and during exercise):</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The diaphragm</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Responsible for about 75% of inspiration</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Descends down during contraction (about 1.5 up to 7cm). This increases the vertical diameter of the chest</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Supplied by the phrenic nerve (C4)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Controls of central tendon, costal fibers and crural fibers</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The external intercostals muscle</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Contraction causes expansion of the chest by increasing the antero-posterior and transverse diameters of the chest.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Aspiratory inspiratory muscles working during forced inspiration only:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Scalene</li>
<li>Sternocleidomastoid</li>
<li>Serratus anterior</li>
<li>Trapezius</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Mechanism of Expiration:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Relaxation of inspiratory muscles</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Increased intrapraval pressure</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Recoil of the lungs to the expiratory position</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Increased intra-alveolar pressure</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Air moves out of the lungs</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Expiration at rest is a passive process since it does not involve contraction of any expiratory muscle. However, forced expiration requires the action of the following expiratory muscles that decrease the size of the chest:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Internal intercostals muscle</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Abdominal muscles</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Inspiration is an active process because it involves contraction of inspiratory muscles. The inspiratory muscles can be grouped into:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Inspiratory muscles working at rest (and during exercise):</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The diaphragm</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Responsible for about 75% of inspiration</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Descends down during contraction (about 1.5 up to 7cm). This increases the vertical diameter of the chest</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Supplied by the phrenic nerve (C4)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Controls of central tendon, costal fibers and crural fibers</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The external intercostals muscle</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Contraction causes expansion of the chest by increasing the antero-posterior and transverse diameters of the chest.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Aspiratory inspiratory muscles working during forced inspiration only:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Scalene</li>
<li>Sternocleidomastoid</li>
<li>Serratus anterior</li>
<li>Trapezius</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Mechanism of Expiration:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Relaxation of inspiratory muscles</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Increased intrapraval pressure</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Recoil of the lungs to the expiratory position</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Increased intra-alveolar pressure</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Air moves out of the lungs</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Expiration at rest is a passive process since it does not involve contraction of any expiratory muscle. However, forced expiration requires the action of the following expiratory muscles that decrease the size of the chest:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Internal intercostals muscle</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Abdominal muscles</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Inspiration is an active process because it involves contraction of inspiratory muscles. The inspiratory muscles can be grouped into:</p>
<p><strong>Inspiratory muscles working at rest (and during exercise):</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The diaphragm</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Responsible for about 75% of inspiration</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Descends down during contraction (about 1.5 up to 7cm). This increases the vertical diameter of the chest</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Supplied by the phrenic nerve (C4)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Controls of central tendon, costal fibers and crural fibers</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The external intercostals muscle</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Contraction causes expansion of the chest by increasing the antero-posterior and transverse diameters of the chest.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Aspiratory inspiratory muscles working during forced inspiration only:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Scalene</li>
<li>Sternocleidomastoid</li>
<li>Serratus anterior</li>
<li>Trapezius</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Mechanism of Expiration:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Relaxation of inspiratory muscles</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Increased intrapraval pressure</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Recoil of the lungs to the expiratory position</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Increased intra-alveolar pressure</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Air moves out of the lungs</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Expiration at rest is a passive process since it does not involve contraction of any expiratory muscle. However, forced expiration requires the action of the following expiratory muscles that decrease the size of the chest:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Internal intercostals muscle</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Abdominal muscles</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Measurement of ventilation</p>
<p>Volumes of air free water or more the large can be measured by special gauges (e.g. the Benedict-Ruth Spinometer).</p>
<p>Fig.7.6. The Benedict-Ruth Spinometer</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-21143929.jpeg" alt="img-313.jpeg"></p>
<p>Volumes and capacities measured by the Spinometer:</p>
<ul>
<li>Total volume (TV)</li>
<li>Volume of air inspired or expired each breath = 0.5L in adult males and females at rest</li>
<li>Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)</li>
<li>Volume of air inspired by maximum inspiratory effort following tidal inspiration = 5L in adult males and 1.5L in adult females</li>
<li>Inspiratory capacity (IC)</li>
<li>Volume of air inspired by maximum inspiratory effort followup tidal expiration = TV + IRV</li>
</ul>
<p>383</p>
<p>The size of method (ft³) = 10⁻³ L/min</p>
<p>Measurement of ventilation</p>
<p>Volumes of air free water or more the large can be measured by special gauges (e.g. the Benedict-Ruth Spinometer).</p>
<p>Fig.7.6. The Benedict-Ruth Spinometer</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-8a8f6e81.jpeg" alt="img-314.jpeg"></p>
<p>Volumes and capacities measured by the Spinometer:</p>
<ul>
<li>Total volume (TV)</li>
<li>Volume of air inspired or expired each breath = 0.5L in adult males and females at rest</li>
<li>Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)</li>
<li>Volume of air inspired by maximum inspiratory effort following tidal expiration = 5L in adult males and 1.5L in adult females</li>
<li>Inspiratory capacity (IC)</li>
<li>Volume of air inspired by maximum inspiratory effort followup tidal expiration = TV + IRV</li>
</ul>
<p>385</p>
<p>The size of method (ft³) = 10⁻³ L/min</p>
<p>Measurement of ventilation</p>
<p>Volumes of air free water or more the large can be measured by special gauges (e.g. the Benedict-Ruth Spinometer).</p>
<p>Fig.7.6. The Benedict-Ruth Spinometer</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-4b1f9c0c.jpeg" alt="img-315.jpeg"></p>
<p>Volumes and capacities measured by the Spinometer:</p>
<ul>
<li>Total volume (TV)</li>
<li>Volume of air inspired or expired each breath = 0.5L in adult males and females at rest</li>
<li>Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)</li>
<li>Volume of air inspired by maximum inspiratory effort following tidal expiration = 5L in adult males and 1.5L in adult females</li>
<li>Inspiratory capacity (IC)</li>
<li>Volume of air inspired by maximum inspiratory effort followup tidal expiration = TV + IRV</li>
</ul>
<p>382</p>
<p>The size of method (ft³) = 10⁻³ L/min</p>
<p>284
The use of medical information</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>Probiotics reserve volume (PRV)</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Volume of air expired by maximum expiratory effort following tidal expiration = 1L in adult males and 0.1L in adult females.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Vital capacity (VC)</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Volume of air expired by maximum expiration following maximum inspiration, (= IPV + TV + EAV or + IC + EAV).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Normal values: About 5L in adult males, 4L in adult females.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Like other lung volumes, it differs according to age, gender, body size (height or weight), position (higher during standing) and ethnic background (higher in Western population than African ones).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is an important index of disease.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For this reason it is usually measured to diagnose certain respiratory problems.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>During measurement, the subject is asked to inspire air maximally and then to expire maximally into the mouth piece of the Spirometer.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When the subject is asked to expire forcefully and as quickly as possible, the measured volume is called forced vital capacity (FVC).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>The forced vital capacity (FVC)</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Volume of air expired forcefully by maximum expiration following maximum inspiration. Since expiration normally takes about 4 s up to 6 s. Forced expiratory time that takes longer than 5 seconds indicates airway obstruction.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The volume of air expired during the first second of the FVC is called the forced expiratory volume in the first second (FEV₁). It equals more than 3 quarters of the FVC (i.e. more than 75%).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For example when the FVC is 5 L, the FEV₁ is about 4 L (i.e. FEV₁/FVC ratio = 80%).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The values of the FEV₁ and the FVC can be measured by a vitalograph. The device provides FVC and FEV₁ values on a graph paper in the Y axis, whereas X axis represents time in seconds.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>285
The use of medical information</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>Cyanogen reserve volume (CRV)</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Volume of air expired by maximum expiratory effort following tidal expiration = 1L in adult males and 0.1L in adult females.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Vital capacity (VC)</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Volume of air expired by maximum expiration following maximum inspiration, (= IPV + TV + EAV or + IC + EAV).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Normal values: About 5L in adult males, 4L in adult females.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Like other lung volumes, it differs according to age, gender, body size (height or weight), position (higher during standing) and ethnic background (higher in Western population than African ones).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is an important index of disease.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For this reason it is usually measured to diagnose certain respiratory problems.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>During measurement, the subject is asked to inspire air maximally and then to expire maximally into the mouth piece of the Spirometer.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When the subject is asked to expire forcefully and as quickly as possible, the measured volume is called forced vital capacity (FVC).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>The forced vital capacity (FVC)</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Volume of air expired forcefully by maximum expiration following maximum inspiration. Since expiration normally takes about 4 s up to 6 s, forced expiratory time that takes longer than 5 seconds indicates airway obstruction.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The volume of air expired during the first second of the FVC is called the forced expiratory volume in the first second (FEV₁). It equals more than 3 quarters of the FVC (i.e. more than 75%).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For example when the FVC is 5 L, the FEV₁ is about 4 L (i.e. FEV₁/FVC ratio = 80%).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The values of the FEV₁ and the FVC can be measured by a vitalograph. The device provides FVC and FEV₁ values on a graph paper in the Y axis, whereas X axis represents time in seconds.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>286
The use of medical information</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-5e7af8ae.jpeg" alt="img-316.jpeg">
Fig.7.6: The xilohamn</p>
<ul>
<li>The FEV/FVC ratio is usually measured to differentiate between obstructive and restrictive lung diseases.</li>
<li>Normal ratio is about 80% (see above).</li>
<li>In obstructive lung diseases (in which FEV₁ is lower than normal) the ratio is less than 70%; e.g. asthma, emphysema and chronic bronchitis (see curve B in fig.7.7).</li>
<li>In restrictive lung diseases (in which both FEV1 and FVC are lower than normal) the ratio is normal or increased (up to 100%), e.g. lung fibrosis and lung collapse (see curve C in fig.7.7).</li>
<li>In combined problems (obstructive and restrictive problems), all the parameters are lower than normal (i.e. low FEV1, low FVC and low FEV1/FVC ratio), e.g. an asthmatic patient with lung fibrosis (see curve B in fig.7.7).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="reminder-list">Reminder list<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reminder-list" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>When the FEV₁ = 0.1, and the FVC = 0.1, the FEV/FVC ratio = 100%. This indicates that the expiratory time is only one second (i.e. wrong maneuver) however, the values indicate normal test.</li>
<li>The use of the vialsograph is replaced by the digital spirometer which gives FEV1, FVC and the FEV1/FVC ratio directly.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-565c40dd.jpeg" alt="img-317.jpeg">
Fig.7.6: The xilohamn</p>
<ul>
<li>The FEV/FVC ratio is usually measured to differentiate between obstructive and restrictive lung diseases.</li>
<li>Normal ratio is about 80% (see above).</li>
<li>In obstructive lung diseases (in which FEV₁ is lower than normal) the ratio is less than 70%, e.g. asthma, emphysema and chronic bronchitis (see curve B in fig.7.7).</li>
<li>In restrictive lung diseases (in which both FEV1 and FVC are lower than normal) the ratio is normal or increased (up to 100%), e.g. lung fibrosis and lung collapse (see curve C in fig.7.7).</li>
<li>In combined problems (obstructive and restrictive problems), all the parameters are lower than normal (i.e. low FEV1, low FVC and low FEV1/FVC ratio), e.g. an asthmatic patient with lung fibrosis (see curve B in fig.7.7).</li>
</ul>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="remember-list">Remember list<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remember-list" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

Fig 7.7: The vitulograph in different cases</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Lung condition</th><th>FEV1</th><th>FVC</th><th>FEV1/FVC ratio</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Normal</td><td>Normal</td><td>Normal</td><td>Normal</td></tr><tr><td>Obstructive diseases</td><td>Low</td><td>Normal</td><td>Low</td></tr><tr><td>Restrictive diseases</td><td>Low</td><td>Low</td><td>Normal</td></tr><tr><td>Obstructive + Restrictive</td><td>Low</td><td>Low</td><td>Low</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Volumes and capacities not measured by the Spirometer:</p>
<ul>
<li>Residual volume (RV)</li>
<li>Volume of air that remains in the lungs after maximum expiration.
= 1.2 L in adult males and 1.1 L in adult females.</li>
<li>Higher volumes are found in obstructive lung diseases (due to difficulty in expiration) and lower volumes in restrictive lung diseases.</li>
<li>The residual volume has the following functions:</li>
<li>Allows easy expansion of the lungs</li>
</ul>

<li>Volume of air that remains in the lungs after maximum expiration.
= 1.2 L in adult males and 1.1 L in adult females.</li>

<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-20bc91f9.jpeg" alt="img-322.jpeg">
Fig 7.7: The vitulograph in different cases</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Lung condition</th><th>FEV1</th><th>FVC</th><th>FEV1/FVC ratio</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Normal</td><td>Normal</td><td>Normal</td><td>Normal</td></tr><tr><td>Obstructive diseases</td><td>Low</td><td>Normal</td><td>Low</td></tr><tr><td>Restrictive diseases</td><td>Low</td><td>Low</td><td>Normal</td></tr><tr><td>Obstructive + Restrictive</td><td>Low</td><td>Low</td><td>Low</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Volumes and capacities not measured by the Spirometer:</p>
<ul>
<li>Residual volume (RV)</li>
<li>Volume of air that remains in the lungs after maximum expiration.
= 1.2 L in adult males and 1.1 L in adult females.</li>
<li>Higher volumes are found in obstructive lung diseases (due to difficulty in expiration) and lower volumes in restrictive lung diseases.</li>
<li>The residual volume has the following functions:</li>
<li>Allows easy expansion of the lungs</li>
</ul>
<p>The term of method (planning) is "subject"</p>
<p>387
The role of medical procedures / 1st edition</p>
<ul>
<li>Above continuous gas exchange throughout the respiratory cycle.</li>
<li>Prevents complete lung collapse.</li>
<li>Functional residual capacity (FRC)</li>
<li>Volume of air that remains in the lungs following tidal expiration.</li>
<li>ENV + RV</li>
<li>Total lung capacity (TLC)</li>
<li>Volume of air accommodated by the lungs at the end of max. inspiration.</li>
<li>(RV + TV + ENV + RV) or (IC + FRC) or (VC + RV)</li>
<li>G. in adult males and SL in adult females.</li>
<li>The RV &amp; FRC are higher in:</li>
<li>Males compared to females</li>
<li>Adults compared to children (i.e. increase with age)</li>
<li>Obstructive lung diseases (asthma, chronic bronchitis and emphysema) compared to restrictive (lung fibrosis).</li>
<li>The above volumes and capacities can be measured by the following methods: Body plethysmography, Helium Dilution Technique or Nitrogen Washout Technique.</li>
<li>Revise the test topic in this chapter (Lung function tests).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pulmonary-ventilation-or-respiratory-minute-volume">Pulmonary ventilation (or respiratory minute volume)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pulmonary-ventilation-or-respiratory-minute-volume" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The volume of air inspired or expired per minute</li>
<li>TV &amp; RR (where TV+ tidal volume &amp; RR+ respiratory rate)</li>
<li>500 X 12+ (6L/min) at rest.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="alveolar-ventilation">Alveolar ventilation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#alveolar-ventilation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The volume of air that verifies the alveoli per minute</li>
<li>(TV-dead space volume) X RR</li>
<li>(500-150) X 12+ (4000 ml/min) or (4.2L/min) at rest.</li>
</ul>
<p>388
The role of medical procedures / 1st edition</p>
<ul>
<li>Above continuous gas exchange throughout the respiratory cycle.</li>
<li>Prevents complete lung collapse.</li>
<li>Functional residual capacity (FRC)</li>
<li>Volume of air that remains in the lungs following tidal expiration.</li>
<li>ENV + RV</li>
<li>Total lung capacity (TLC)</li>
<li>Volume of air accommodated by the lungs at the end of max. inspiration.</li>
<li>(RV + TV + ENV + RV) or (IC + FRC) or (VC + RV)</li>
<li>G. in adult males and SL in adult females.</li>
<li>The RV &amp; FRC are higher in:</li>
<li>Males compared to females</li>
<li>Adults compared to children (i.e. increase with age)</li>
<li>Obstructive lung diseases (asthma, chronic bronchitis and emphysema) compared to restrictive (lung fibrosis).</li>
<li>The above volumes and capacities can be measured by the following methods: Body plethysmography, Helium Dilution Technique or Nitrogen Washout Technique.</li>
<li>Revise the test topic in this chapter (Lung function tests).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pulmonary-ventilation-or-respiratory-minute-volume">Pulmonary ventilation (or respiratory minute volume)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pulmonary-ventilation-or-respiratory-minute-volume" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The volume of air inspired or expired per minute</li>
<li>TV &amp; RR (where TV+ tidal volume &amp; RR+ respiratory rate)</li>
<li>500 X 12+ (6L/min) at rest.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="alveolar-ventilation">Alveolar ventilation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#alveolar-ventilation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The volume of air that verifies the alveoli per minute</li>
<li>(TV-dead space volume) X RR</li>
<li>(500-150) X 12+ (4000 ml/min) or (4.2L/min) at rest.</li>
</ul>
<p>389
The role of medical procedures / 1st edition</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-aa625ac9.jpeg" alt="img-323.jpeg">
Fig 7.8: The equivalent</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-ca496b6b.jpeg" alt="img-324.jpeg">
Fig 7.9: The equivalent</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-d91e865d.jpeg" alt="img-325.jpeg">
Fig 7.8: The subtopism</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="dead-space-volume-ds">Dead space volume (DS)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dead-space-volume-ds" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When a subject smokes 500 ml of air, only 350 ml reaches the alveoli whereas 150 ml is cored or 2 air dead space volume. Therefore, dead space is defined as volume of air that does not participate in gas exchange (the 150 ml).</p>
<p>Includes two types:</p>
<ul>
<li>Anatomical DS: volume of air that occupies the conducting zone.</li>
<li>Physiological DS: volume of air that occupies the conducting zone (anatomical DS) plus volume of air in the respiratory zone but not participating in gas exchange (e.g. for within the upper alveoli that receive the blood supply because of the steady).</li>
<li>The anatomical DS is about 150 ml per average adult male (or roughly it equals the weight of the body of the male).</li>
<li>The physiological DS volume = the anatomical total space volume (150 ml) + any additional alveolar air (e.g. 150 ml per average adult male or roughly it equals the weight of the body of the male).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="dead-space-volume-ds">Dead space volume (DS)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dead-space-volume-ds" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When a subject smokes 500 ml of air, only 350 ml reaches the alveoli whereas 150 ml is cored or 2 air dead space volume. Therefore, dead space is defined as volume of air that does not participate in gas exchange (the 150 ml).</p>
<p>Includes two types:</p>
<ul>
<li>Anatomical DS: volume of air that occupies the conducting zone.</li>
<li>Physiological DS: volume of air that occupies the conducting zone (anatomical DS) plus volume of air in the respiratory zone but not participating in gas exchange (e.g. for within the upper alveoli that receive the blood supply because of the steady).</li>
<li>The anatomical DS is about 150 ml per average adult male (or roughly it equals the weight of the body of the male).</li>
<li>The physiological DS volume = the anatomical total space volume (150 ml) + any additional alveolar air (e.g. 150 ml per average adult male or roughly it equals the weight of the body of the male).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="dead-space-volume-ds">Dead space volume (DS)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dead-space-volume-ds" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When a subject smokes 500 ml of air, only 350 ml reaches the alveoli whereas 150 ml is cored or 2 air dead space volume. Therefore, dead space is defined as volume of air that does not participate in gas exchange (the 150 ml).</p>
<p>Includes two types:</p>
<ul>
<li>Anatomical DS: volume of air that occupies the conducting zone.</li>
<li>Physiological DS: volume of air that occupies the conducting zone (anatomical DS) plus volume of air in the respiratory zone but not participating in gas exchange (e.g. for within the upper alveoli that receive the blood supply because of the steady).</li>
</ul>
<p>The anatomical DS is about 150 ml per average adult male (or roughly it equals the weight of the body of the male).</p>
<p>The physiological DS volume = the anatomical total space volume (150 ml) + any additional alveolar air (e.g. 150 ml per average adult male or roughly it equals the weight of the body of the male).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-e810015d.jpeg" alt="img-326.jpeg"></p>
<p>Therefore, in normal subjects, the physiological is almost equal to the anatomical dead space (the difference being less than 5 ml of air).</p>
<p>The anatomical dead space volume can be measured by the single breath nitrogen test (see lung function tests).</p>
<p>The anatomical (or physiological) dead space volume can be measured by the fibre equation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ba-pas-fasion">BA-PAS FASION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ba-pas-fasion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Where <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>d</mi></msub><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">V_{d} =</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; <p>Another form of the equation for the physiological dead space</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>P</mi><mi>d</mi></msub><mi>C</mi><msub><mi>O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>P</mi><mi>d</mi></msub><mi>C</mi><msub><mi>O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>+</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>P</mi><mi>c</mi></msub><mi>C</mi><msub><mi>O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">P_{d}CO_{2} + V_{1} = P_{d}CO_{2} + (V_{1} - V_{2}) + P_{c}CO_{2} + V_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em;
