margin-left: -0.0278em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">30</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;mmHg</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>P</mi><mi>a</mi></msub><mi>C</mi><msub><mi>O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>40</mn><mtext>&nbsp;mmHg</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">P_{a}CO_{2} = 40 \text{ mmHg}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">P</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.1389em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">a</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0278em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">40</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;mmHg</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>100</mn><mtext>&nbsp;ml</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">V = 100 \text{ ml}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;ml</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="answer">Answer:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#answer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mn>30</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>500</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>40</mn><mo>×</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>500</mn><mo>−</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>d</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">30 \times 500 = 40 \times (500 - V_{d}) + 0</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">30</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">500</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">40</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">500</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3361em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.2222em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">d</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">0</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>d</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>125</mn><mtext>&nbsp;ml</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">V_{d} = 125 \text{ ml}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3361em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.2222em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">d</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">125</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;ml</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>270
The issue of medical physiology 17th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="elastic-properties-surfactant-and-compliance">ELASTIC PROPERTIES: SURFACTANT AND COMPLIANCE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#elastic-properties-surfactant-and-compliance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The elastic properties of the lung are caused by:</p>
<ul>
<li>Elastic fibers in the lung tissue</li>
<li>Surface tension of fluid in the alveoli (see below)</li>
</ul>
<p>These aid against inflation of the lung.</p>
<ul>
<li>For ventilation to take place, it should overcome these two causes. However, the two causes are affected by many factors. These are discussed below.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="surfactant">SURFACTANT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#surfactant" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A phospholipid produced by type II alveolar cells (di-palmitoyl-phosphatidylcholine).</li>
<li>Acts to reduce surface tension of fluid in the alveoli. This is achieved by covering the surface of water, separating it from air (because the surface tension occurs at the waterbar interface).</li>
<li>The surface tension is a physical property of liquids. It arises because the cohesive forces between water molecules attract each other, tending to contrast their surface and eventually cause alveolar collapse.</li>
<li>Reduction of the surface tension with surfactant prevents alveolar collapse and development of pulmonary edema (may occur due to negative interstitial pressure caused by the alveolar collapse).</li>
<li>The presence of surface tension in the lung was first noticed when air and saline were compared during inflation of excised lungs. Irritating lungs with saline was found to be easier than inflating them with air. This is because there is no surface tension acting against inflation when saline was used.</li>
<li>Surfactant effects are mainly exerted on small alveoli, especially during expiration. This is because these small alveoli have higher tendency to collapse. This higher tendency to collapse can be explained by the law of Laplace.</li>
</ul>
<p>P = 270</p>
<p>271
The issue of medical physiology 17th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="elastic-properties-surfactant-and-compliance">ELASTIC PROPERTIES: SURFACTANT AND COMPLIANCE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#elastic-properties-surfactant-and-compliance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The elastic properties of the lung are caused by:</p>
<ul>
<li>Elastic fibers in the lung tissue</li>
<li>Surface tension of fluid in the alveoli (see below)</li>
</ul>
<p>These aid against inflation of the lung.</p>
<ul>
<li>For ventilation to take place, it should overcome these two causes. However, the two causes are affected by many factors. These are discussed below.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="surfactant">SURFACTANT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#surfactant" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A phospholipid produced by type II alveolar cells (di-palmitoyl-phosphatidylcholine).</li>
<li>Acts to reduce surface tension of fluid in the alveoli. This is achieved by covering the surface of water, separating it from air (because the surface tension occurs at the waterbar interface).</li>
<li>The surface tension is a physical property of liquids. It arises because the cohesive forces between water molecules attract each other, tending to contrast their surface and eventually cause alveolar collapse.</li>
<li>Reduction of the surface tension with surfactant prevents alveolar collapse and development of pulmonary edema (may occur due to negative interstitial pressure caused by the alveolar collapse).</li>
<li>The presence of surface tension in the lung was first noticed when air and saline were compared during inflation of excised lungs. Irritating lungs with saline was found to be easier than inflating them with air. This is because there is no surface tension acting against inflation when saline was used.</li>
<li>Surfactant effects are mainly exerted on small alveoli, especially during expiration. This is because these small alveoli have higher tendency to collapse. This higher tendency to collapse can be explained by the law of Laplace.</li>
</ul>
<p>P = 271</p>
<p>272
The issue of medical physiology 17th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="elastic-properties-surfactant-and-compliance">ELASTIC PROPERTIES: SURFACTANT AND COMPLIANCE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#elastic-properties-surfactant-and-compliance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The elastic properties of the lung are caused by:</p>
<ul>
<li>Elastic fibers in the lung tissue</li>
<li>Surface tension of fluid in the alveoli (see below)</li>
</ul>
<p>These aid against inflation of the lung.</p>
<ul>
<li>For ventilation to take place, it should overcome these two causes. However, the two causes are affected by many factors. These are discussed below.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="surfactant">SURFACTANT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#surfactant" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A phospholipid produced by type II alveolar cells (di-palmitoyl-phosphatidylcholine).</li>
<li>Acts to reduce surface tension of fluid in the alveoli. This is achieved by covering the surface of water, separating it from air (because the surface tension occurs at the waterbar interface).</li>
<li>The surface tension is a physical property of liquids. It arises because the cohesive forces between water molecules attract each other, tending to contrast their surface and eventually cause alveolar collapse.</li>
<li>Reduction of the surface tension with surfactant prevents alveolar collapse and development of pulmonary edema (may occur due to negative interstitial pressure caused by the alveolar collapse).</li>
<li>The presence of surface tension in the lung was first noticed when air and saline were compared during inflation of excised lungs. Irritating lungs with saline was found to be easier than inflating them with air. This is because there is no surface tension acting against inflation when saline was used.</li>
<li>Surfactant effects are mainly exerted on small alveoli, especially during expiration. This is because these small alveoli have higher tendency to collapse. This higher tendency to collapse can be explained by the law of Laplace.</li>
</ul>
<p>P = 272</p>
<p>200</p>
<p>What P&gt; pressure inside the alveolus (= distending pressure), T&gt; tension and r= radius of an alveolus.</p>
<ul>
<li>This indicates that the smaller the radius the higher the distending pressure needed to keep it patent.</li>
<li>Production of surfactant starts late in pregnancy (after the 32nd week of pregnancy). Transition it is deficient in pro term babies.</li>
<li>These babies develop cyanosis &amp; difficulty in breathing at birth. A serious condition known as infant respiratory distress syndrome (IRSS) or (hyaline membrane disease), characterized by collapse of alveoli and retention of fluids in the interstitium and alveoli.</li>
<li>Retention of fluid in the alveoli occurs because surfactant is needed for maturation of epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) responsible for absorption of sodium and water from the alveoli after birth. Failure of maturation of these channels due to deficiency of surfactant results in fluid retention.</li>
<li>Treatment of IRSS requires, in addition to high oxygen supply and fluid balance, inhalation of phospholipid or synthetic surfactant.</li>
<li>Surfactant production is increased by Glucocorticoids (that's why pregnant women who develop premature labor contractions are given injections of hydrocortisone, to increase its production).</li>
<li>Surfactant production is decreased by:</li>
<li>Occlusion of the pulmonary artery</li>
<li>Occlusion of a main bronchus</li>
<li>Chronic inhalation of (100%) oxygen</li>
<li>Cigarette smoking</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lung-compliance">LUNG COMPLIANCE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lung-compliance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Compliance is defined as change in volume per unit change in pressure.</li>
<li>Lung compliance is described as the distensibility or sensibility of the lungs (i.e. the capacity of the lungs to expand or stretch).</li>
</ul>
<p>200</p>
<p>Effect of median pressure (32nd weeks)</p>
<p>What P&gt; pressure inside the alveolus (= distending pressure), T&gt; tension and r= radius of an alveolus.</p>
<ul>
<li>This indicates that the smaller the radius the higher the distending pressure needed to keep it patent.</li>
<li>Production of surfactant starts late in pregnancy (after the 32nd week of pregnancy). Transition it is deficient in pro term babies.</li>
<li>These babies develop cyanosis &amp; difficulty in breathing at birth. A serious condition known as infant respiratory distress syndrome (IRSS) or (hyaline membrane disease), characterized by collapse of alveoli and retention of fluids in the interstitium and alveoli.</li>
<li>Retention of fluid in the alveoli occurs because surfactant is needed for maturation of epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) responsible for absorption of sodium and water from the alveoli after birth. Failure of maturation of these channels due to deficiency of surfactant results in fluid retention.</li>
<li>Treatment of IRSS requires, in addition to high oxygen supply and fluid balance, inhalation of phospholipid or synthetic surfactant.</li>
<li>Surfactant production is increased by Glucocorticoids (that's why pregnant women who develop premature labor contractions are given injections of hydrocortisone, to increase its production).</li>
<li>Surfactant production is decreased by:</li>
<li>Occlusion of the pulmonary artery</li>
<li>Occlusion of a main bronchus</li>
<li>Chronic inhalation of (100%) oxygen</li>
<li>Cigarette smoking</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lung-compliance">LUNG COMPLIANCE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lung-compliance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Compliance is defined as change in volume per unit change in pressure.</li>
<li>Lung compliance is described as the distensibility or sensibility of the lungs (i.e. the capacity of the lungs to expand or stretch).</li>
</ul>
<p>201</p>
<p>Effect of median pressure (32nd weeks)</p>
<p>What P&gt; pressure inside the alveolus (= distending pressure), T&gt; tension and r= radius of an alveolus.</p>
<ul>
<li>This indicates that the smaller the radius the higher the distending pressure needed to keep it patent.</li>
<li>Production of surfactant starts late in pregnancy (after the 32nd week of pregnancy). Transition it is deficient in pro term babies.</li>
<li>These babies develop cyanosis &amp; difficulty in breathing at birth. A serious condition known as infant respiratory distress syndrome (IRSS) or (hyaline membrane disease), characterized by collapse of alveoli and retention of fluids in the interstitium and alveoli.</li>
<li>Retention of fluid in the alveoli occurs because surfactant is needed for maturation of epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) responsible for absorption of sodium and water from the alveoli after birth. Failure of maturation of these channels due to deficiency of surfactant results in fluid retention.</li>
<li>Treatment of IRSS requires, in addition to high oxygen supply and fluid balance, inhalation of phospholipid or synthetic surfactant.</li>
<li>Surfactant production is increased by Glucocorticoids (that's why pregnant women who develop premature labor contractions are given injections of hydrocortisone, to increase its production).</li>
<li>Surfactant production is decreased by:</li>
<li>Occlusion of the pulmonary artery</li>
<li>Occlusion of a main bronchus</li>
<li>Chronic inhalation of (100%) oxygen</li>
<li>Cigarette smoking</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lung-compliance">LUNG COMPLIANCE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lung-compliance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Compliance is defined as change in volume per unit change in pressure.</li>
<li>Lung compliance is described as the distensibility or sensibility of the lungs (i.e. the capacity of the lungs to expand or stretch).</li>
</ul>
<p>201</p>
<p>202</p>
<p>The view of natural physiology 2nd edition</p>
<ul>
<li>It differs from elasticity which is the resistance to that stretch (i.e. compliance = Velsability). Therefore when elasticity is decreased, compliance is increased.</li>
<li>It is measured in terms of change in volume per unit change in pressure (i.e. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>W</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>P</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">C = \Delta W / \Delta P</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">Δ</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">W</span><span class="mord">/Δ</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">P</span></span></span></span></span>).</li>
<li>Here a pressure volume curve is used for its measurement. For example the relaxation pressure curve.</li>
<li>To obtain the relaxation pressure curve, a subject breathing through Spirometer is asked to inhale a given amount of air and then to raise his respiratory muscles while both his mouth and nose are shut. During the process, the intrapulmonary pressure is measured by a device in his mouth.</li>
<li>Then the amount of inhaled air is increased and the procedure is repeated until he takes maximum inspiration, followed by maximum expiration.</li>
<li>The intrapulmonary pressure is plotted against volume as appears in the following figure.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-8c85de3a.jpeg" alt="img-327.jpeg">
Fig.7.8: The relaxation pressure curve</p>
<ul>
<li>It differs from elasticity which is the resistance to that stretch (i.e. compliance = Velsability). Therefore when elasticity is decreased, compliance is increased.</li>
<li>It is measured in terms of change in volume per unit change in pressure (i.e. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>W</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>P</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">C = \Delta W / \Delta P</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">Δ</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">W</span><span class="mord">/Δ</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">P</span></span></span></span></span>).</li>
<li>Here a pressure volume curve is used for its measurement. For example the relaxation pressure curve.</li>
<li>To obtain the relaxation pressure curve, a subject breathing through Spirometer is asked to inhale a given amount of air and then to raise his respiratory muscles while both his mouth and nose are shut. During the process, the intrapulmonary pressure is measured by a device in his mouth.</li>
<li>Then the amount of inhaled air is increased and the procedure is repeated until he takes maximum inspiration, followed by maximum expiration.</li>
<li>The intrapulmonary pressure is plotted against volume as appears in the following figure.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-0d3e6017.jpeg" alt="img-328.jpeg">
Fig.7.9: The relaxation pressure curve</p>
<ul>
<li>It differs from elasticity which is the resistance to that stretch (i.e. compliance = Velsability). Therefore when elasticity is decreased, compliance is increased.</li>
<li>It is measured in terms of change in volume per unit change in pressure (i.e. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>W</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>P</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">C = \Delta W / \Delta P</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">Δ</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">W</span><span class="mord">/Δ</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">P</span></span></span></span></span>).</li>
<li>Here a pressure volume curve is used for its measurement. For example the relaxation pressure curve.</li>
<li>To obtain the relaxation pressure curve, a subject breathing through Spirometer is asked to inhale a given amount of air and then to raise his respiratory muscles while both his mouth and nose are shut. During the process, the intrapulmonary pressure is measured by a device in his mouth.</li>
<li>Then the amount of inhaled air is increased and the procedure is repeated until he takes maximum inspiration, followed by maximum expiration.</li>
<li>The intrapulmonary pressure is plotted against volume as appears in the following figure.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-f0af9b64.jpeg" alt="img-329.jpeg">
Fig.7.8: The relaxation pressure curve</p>
<p>203</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Notice that the relaxation pressure equals zero at the end of quiet expiration (i.e. when the lung volume equals the functional residual capacity, the point of equilibrium between the inward recoil of the lungs and the outward recoil of the chest).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The slope of the curve equals compliance. However, it differs in different lung volumes. For this reason the term specific lung compliance is sometimes used. It equals the value of the lung compliance divided by the lung volume</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Specific compliance = Lung compliance / Lung volume</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The compliance obtained in this way is known as static lung compliance.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is important to notice that static lung compliance during inflation is slightly lower than static lung compliance during deflation. Therefore the relaxation pressure curves during inflation and deflation are not the same. This is known as "hysteresis of the lung".</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When the change in lung volume is measured during breathing; the resistance within the airways affects the value of compliance; here the measured compliance is known as the dynamic lung compliance.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Normal values.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Compliance of the lung (<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>C</mi><mi>L</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">C_L</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0715em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">L</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>) = 0.2 L/cm H₂O</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Compliance of the chest (<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>C</mi><mi>C</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">C_C</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0715em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>) = 0.2 L/cm H₂O</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Compliance of both (<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex-error" title="ParseError: KaTeX parse error: Expected '}', got '&amp;' at position 5: C_{L&amp;̲amp;C}" style="color: rgb(204, 0, 0);">C_{L&amp;amp;C}</span></span>) = 0.1 L/cm H₂O</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Notice that: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex-error" title="ParseError: KaTeX parse error: Expected '}', got '&amp;' at position 23: … 1/C_C = 1/C_{L&amp;̲amp;C}" style="color: rgb(204, 0, 0);">1/C_L + 1/C_C = 1/C_{L&amp;amp;C}</span></span> (like resistances connected in parallel).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factors that increase lung compliance:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Emphysema &amp; old age (due to loss of elastic fibers in the lung)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factors that decrease lung compliance:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Lung fibrosis, pulmonary edema, high surface tension of fluid in alveoli (surfactant deficiency) and small lung size (children).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factors that decrease lchest compliance:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stiffness of joints, obesity and deformity of the chest wall (e.g. kyphosis scoliosis).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>293
The core of medical physiology / 4th edition</p>
<p>294
The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<p>Remember that:</p>
<ul>
<li>High lung compliance decreases work of breathing whereas low lung compliance increases work of breathing.</li>
<li>Surfactant decreases work of breathing.</li>
</ul>
<p>Bronchial tone</p>
<ul>
<li>The smooth muscle in the bronchial wall is controlled by the autonomic nervous system. The sympathetic dilates it (e.g. during inspiration) and the parasympathetic constricts it (e.g. during expiration); however, there are multiple irritants, chemicals and hormones that may affect the normal tone of the bronchial tree; these include:</li>
</ul>
<p>Factors causing bronchoconstriction:</p>
<ul>
<li>Irritants &amp; chemicals: e.g. sulfur dioxide</li>
<li>Cool air</li>
<li>Exercise (possibly by the cool air during hyperventilation)</li>
<li>Substance P</li>
<li>Adenosine</li>
<li>Many inflammatory modulators &amp; cytokines involved in the pathogenesis of asthma (e.g. leukotriens); that's why anti-leukotriens are added for treatment of asthma.</li>
</ul>
<p>Factors causing bronchodilation:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Catecholamines</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>VIP (vasoactive intestinal polypeptide)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>There is circadian rhythm in bronchial tone throughout the day, with maximal constriction early in the morning. That's why asthmatic patients usually suffer from symptoms of airway obstruction early in the morning.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Work of breathing</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Consists of two components: Elastic and non-elastic work.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Elastic work is needed for movement of the lung and chest wall. It constitutes two thirds (65%) of the total work.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Non-elastic work is needed for movement of non-elastic tissues (viscous resistance = 7%) &amp; movement of air through the airways (airway resistance = 28%).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pulmonary-circulation">Pulmonary circulation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pulmonary-circulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Each lung receives its blood supply from two sources: the pulmonary artery (which supplies the alveoli) and bronchial arteries (which supply the airways and the pleurae).</li>
<li>The pulmonary artery carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle. It forms an extensive network of capillaries that surround the alveoli to allow gas exchange. Oxygen is taken up into the blood while carbon dioxide diffuses into the alveoli. The oxygenated blood returns through pulmonary veins to the left atrium.</li>
<li>The bronchial arteries carry oxygenated blood from the aorta. They supply the lung parenchyma, airways and pleurae with oxygen and nutrients. They also equilibrate temperature of inspired air with that of the body. Deoxygenated blood is drained through bronchial veins to the azygos vein and therefore to the right atrium via the inferior vena cava; however, there are anastomoses between some bronchial capillaries and pulmonary capillaries. This allows some deoxygenated blood in bronchial capillaries to drain into the pulmonary capillaries and then into the pulmonary vein, resulting in the <strong>physiological shunt</strong> (mixture of oxygenated blood with some deoxygenated blood).</li>
<li>In addition, there is another source for the physiological shunt. It is from small cardiac veins (thebesian veins) that drain deoxygenated blood into the left side of the heart, which contains oxygenated blood.</li>
<li>The physiological shunt results in reduction of arterial PO₂ by 2 mmHg and reduction of arterial oxygen saturation by 0.5% compared to oxygenated blood coming from alveolar capillaries.</li>
</ul>
<p>The core of medical physiology/4th edition</p>
<p>290
The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="gas-exchange-in-the-lungs">GAS EXCHANGE IN THE LUNGS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gas-exchange-in-the-lungs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>There are two sites of gas exchange in the body:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Between alveoli in the lungs &amp; pulmonary capillaries (= external respiration)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Between tissue cells &amp; systemic capillaries (= internal respiration).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Gas exchange in the lungs depends on the following factors:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pressure gradient of the gas</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Surface area of the respiratory membrane</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Thickness of the respiratory membrane</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Physical properties of the gas</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-pressure-gradient">1) Pressure gradient<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-pressure-gradient" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Gases move passively from an area of high pressure to an area of low pressure.</li>
<li>The pressure of a single gas in a container containing mixture of gases is called its partial pressure.</li>
<li>The partial pressure of a gas is calculated by multiplying its fractional concentration times the total pressure of all gases. The following table explains calculation of partial pressures of gases in the atmosphere (dry air):</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Table 7.4: Calculation of partial pressures of gases</strong></p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Gas</th><th>Percentage (%)</th><th>Partial pressure</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Nitrogen</td><td>78.06</td><td>78.06 x 760 = 593.3 mmHg</td></tr><tr><td>Oxygen</td><td>20.98</td><td>20.98 x 760 = 159.4 mmHg</td></tr><tr><td>Carbon dioxide</td><td>0.04</td><td>0.04 x 760 = 0.3 mmHg</td></tr><tr><td>Inert gases (argon &amp; helium)</td><td>0.92</td><td>0.92 x 760 = 7 mmHg</td></tr><tr><td>Total</td><td>100</td><td>760 mmHg</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7160588c">Partial pressure of oxygen (Po₂)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7160588c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>In dry air = 159 mmHg</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In inspired air (after humidification in the airways) = 149 mmHg
20.98% x [760 - 47]; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>P</mi><mrow><mi>H</mi><mn>2</mn><mi>O</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>47</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">P_{H2O} = 47</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">P</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.1389em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="mord mtight">2</span><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">O</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">47</span></span></span></span></span> mmHg at body temperature</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In alveolar air = 100 mmHg (due to rapid diffusion of oxygen into pulmonary capillaries &amp; diffusion of CO₂ into alveoli)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In venous blood (coming to pulmonary capillaries) = 40 mmHg
(Prior to gas exchange)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Po₂ in arterial blood (leaving pulmonary capillaries) = 100 mmHg (After the gas exchange; however, this value is decreased by the physiological shunt).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 7.10</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-0706678d.jpeg" alt="img-330.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="29f1d0b8">Partial pressure of carbon dioxide [Pco₂]<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#29f1d0b8" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>In dry air = 0.3 mmHg</li>
<li>In inspired air = 0.29 mmHg (0.04% × [760 - 47])</li>
<li>In alveolar air = 40 mmHg (due to rapid diffusion of CO₂ from pulmonary capillaries to alveoli)</li>
<li>In venous blood (coming to pulmonary capillaries) = 45 mmHg
(Prior to gas exchange)</li>
<li>Pco₂ in arterial blood (leaving the pulmonary capillaries) = 40 mmHg
(After the gas exchange)</li>
</ul>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-082f9843.jpeg" alt="img-331.jpeg">
Fig 7.11</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-thickness">2) Thickness<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-thickness" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The respiratory membrane consists of the following layers (fig 7.11):</li>
<li>Fluid in the alveoli</li>
<li>Alveolar wall (basement membrane + epithelium)</li>
<li>Vibrational fluid</li>
<li>Capillary wall (basement membrane + endothelium)</li>
<li>Normal thickness = 0.5 micrometer</li>
<li>Gas exchange is inversely proportional to thickness of the respiratory membrane. For example when the thickness is decreased (as occurs during exercise), gas exchange is increased.</li>
<li>It is impaired when the thickness is increased (e.g. due to lung fibrosis or pulmonary edema). This causes hypoxemia (low oxygen in blood); however, thickness of the respiratory membrane is a less common cause of hypoxemia than ventilation: perfusion mismatching (see below).</li>
</ul>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<p>Fig 7.12: The</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-ada823df.jpeg" alt="img-332.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-surface-area">3) Surface Area<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-surface-area" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The available area for gas exchange is called the effective surface area. It indicates well ventilated alveoli in contact with well perfused capillaries.</li>
<li>Gas exchange is directly proportional to the effective surface area.</li>
<li>For example when the surface area is increased (as occurs during exercise), gas exchange is increased.</li>
<li>The effective surface area is increased during exercise because:</li>
<li>More alveoli are ventilated (due to increased ventilation)</li>
<li>More capillaries are perfused (due to increased perfusion)</li>
<li>Total surface area equals about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>70</mn><mtext> </mtext><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">70\,\mathrm{m}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">70</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">m</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> (normal range: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>100</mn><mtext> </mtext><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50-100\,\mathrm{m}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">m</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-diffusion-coefficient">4) Diffusion Coefficient<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-diffusion-coefficient" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Defined as the amount of gas that diffuses across the respiratory membrane per unit pressure difference per unit surface area per unit time. It depends on:</li>
<li>Solubility of the gas (direct relation)</li>
<li>Molecular weight of the gas (inverse relation)</li>
<li>Although molecular weight of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CO}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is larger than <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{O}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, its diffusion coefficient is higher than <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{O}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>. This is due to the high solubility of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CO}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
</ul>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<p>200
The costs of medical physiology of science</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diffusion-capacity-of-the-respiratory-membrane">Diffusion capacity of the respiratory membrane:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diffusion-capacity-of-the-respiratory-membrane" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The volume of gas that crosses the respiratory membrane per unit partial pressure difference per unit time. It is affected by:</li>
<li>Thickness of the membrane (inverse relationship)</li>
<li>Surface area of the membrane (direct relationship)</li>
<li>It is measured by using carbon monoxide which is highly soluble in blood (unlike other gases it is "diffusion limited")</li>
<li>Normal diffusion capacity equals 25 milm/min/mg.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-ventilation-perfusion-ratio-v-q-ratio">The Ventilation - Perfusion Ratio (V/Q ratio):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-ventilation-perfusion-ratio-v-q-ratio" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The ratio of alveolar ventilation to pulmonary blood flow (perfusion).</li>
<li>Alveolar ventilation is about 4 L/min whereas pulmonary blood flow is about 5 L/min. Therefore V/Q ratio = 0.6 (x-1.0).</li>
<li>It is affected by: Gravity and lung diseases</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="effect-of-gravity-on-v-q-ratio">Effect of gravity on V/Q ratio:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effect-of-gravity-on-v-q-ratio" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>In the upright position, the V/Q ratio differs in different parts of the lung due to the effect of gravity.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="at-the-same">At the same:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#at-the-same" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Blood flow (Q) is decreased and ventilation (V) is also decreased but to a lesser extent. Therefore the ratio is increased.</li>
<li>When perfusion is decreased to zero, the ratio is increased to infinity (V/Q = V/Q + infinity).</li>
<li>Since ventilation = perfusion, the extra air = wasted ventilation (or dead space ventilation).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="at-the-same">At the same:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#at-the-same" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Blood flow (Q) is increased and ventilation (V) is also increased but to a lesser extent. Therefore the ratio is decreased.</li>
<li>Since ventilation = perfusion, the extra blood = wasted perfusion (or short flow).</li>
</ul>
<p>201
The costs of medical physiology of science</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diffusion-capacity-of-the-respiratory-membrane">Diffusion capacity of the respiratory membrane:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diffusion-capacity-of-the-respiratory-membrane" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The volume of gas that crosses the respiratory membrane per unit partial pressure difference per unit time. It is affected by:</li>
<li>Thickness of the membrane (inverse relationship)</li>
<li>Surface area of the membrane (direct relationship)</li>
<li>It is measured by using carbon monoxide which is highly soluble in blood (unlike other gases it is "diffusion limited")</li>
<li>Normal diffusion capacity equals 25 milm/min/mg.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-ventilation-perfusion-ratio-v-q-ratio">The Ventilation - Perfusion Ratio (V/Q ratio):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-ventilation-perfusion-ratio-v-q-ratio" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The ratio of alveolar ventilation to pulmonary blood flow (perfusion).</li>
<li>Alveolar ventilation is about 4 L/min whereas pulmonary blood flow is about 5 L/min. Therefore V/Q ratio = 0.6 (x-1.0).</li>
<li>It is affected by: Gravity and lung diseases</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="effect-of-gravity-on-v-q-ratio">Effect of gravity on V/Q ratio:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effect-of-gravity-on-v-q-ratio" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>In the upright position, the V/Q ratio differs in different parts of the lung due to the effect of gravity.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="at-the-same">At the same:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#at-the-same" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Blood flow (Q) is decreased and ventilation (V) is also decreased but to a lesser extent. Therefore the ratio is increased.</li>
<li>When perfusion is decreased to zero, the ratio is increased to infinity (V/Q = V/Q + infinity).</li>
<li>Since ventilation = perfusion, the extra air = wasted ventilation (or dead space ventilation).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="at-the-same">At the same:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#at-the-same" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Blood flow (Q) is increased and ventilation (V) is also increased but to a lesser extent. Therefore the ratio is decreased.</li>
<li>Since ventilation = perfusion, the extra blood = wasted perfusion (or short flow).</li>
</ul>
<p>202
The costs of medical physiology of science</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diffusion-capacity-of-the-respiratory-membrane">Diffusion capacity of the respiratory membrane:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diffusion-capacity-of-the-respiratory-membrane" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The volume of gas that crosses the respiratory membrane per unit partial pressure difference per unit time. It is affected by:</li>
<li>Thickness of the membrane (inverse relationship)</li>
<li>Surface area of the membrane (direct relationship)</li>
<li>It is measured by using carbon monoxide which is highly soluble in blood (unlike other gases it is "diffusion limited")</li>
<li>Normal diffusion capacity equals 20 milm/min/mg.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-ventilation-perfusion-ratio-v-q-ratio">The Ventilation - Perfusion Ratio (V/Q ratio):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-ventilation-perfusion-ratio-v-q-ratio" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The ratio of alveolar ventilation to pulmonary blood flow (perfusion).</li>
<li>Alveolar ventilation is about 4 L/min whereas pulmonary blood flow is about 5 L/min. Therefore V/Q ratio = 0.6 (x-1.0).</li>
<li>It is affected by: Gravity and lung diseases</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="effect-of-gravity-on-v-q-ratio">Effect of gravity on V/Q ratio:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effect-of-gravity-on-v-q-ratio" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>In the upright position, the V/Q ratio differs in different parts of the lung due to the effect of gravity.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="at-the-same">At the same:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#at-the-same" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Blood flow (Q) is decreased and ventilation (V) is also decreased but to a lesser extent. Therefore the ratio is increased.</li>
<li>When perfusion is decreased to zero, the ratio is increased to infinity (V/Q = V/Q + infinity).</li>
<li>Since ventilation = perfusion, the extra air = wasted ventilation (or dead space ventilation).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="at-the-same">At the same:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#at-the-same" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Blood flow (Q) is increased and ventilation (V) is also increased but to a lesser extent. Therefore the ratio is decreased.</li>
<li>Since ventilation = perfusion, the extra blood = wasted perfusion (or short flow).</li>
</ul>
<p>30
The uses of medical physiology. © Wilson</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="effect-of-lung-diseases-on-vig-ratio">Effect of lung diseases on VIG ratio<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effect-of-lung-diseases-on-vig-ratio" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Each lung diseases are characterized by VIG inequality.</li>
<li>There may result in either: wasted ventilation (e.g. pulmonary embolism) or
wasted perfusion (e.g. Lung collapse); the ratio is changed accordingly.</li>
<li>Remember that, VIG inequality is the most common cause of hypoxemia.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="effect-of-vig-mismatching-on-po2-and-pco2-of-alveolar-air">Effect of VIG mismatching on PO2 and PCO2 of alveolar air<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effect-of-vig-mismatching-on-po2-and-pco2-of-alveolar-air" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>If ventilation to an alveolar is reduced relative to its perfusion (i.e. less O₂, which from environment and less CO₂ removal):</li>
<li>PO₂ in alveoli (PAO₂) decreases</li>
<li>PCO₂ in alveoli (PACO₂) increases</li>
<li>This normally occurs in some alveoli at the base of the lung.</li>
<li>If perfusion to an alveolar is reduced relative to its ventilation (i.e. less carbon dioxide reaches the alveoli from blood):</li>
<li>PO₂ in alveoli (PAO₂) increases</li>
<li>PCO₂ in alveoli (PACO₂) decreases</li>
<li>This normally occurs in some alveoli at apex of the lung.</li>
<li>For this reason, the lung apex is the most favorable site of infection for the splenic bacilli (because of the high PAO₂).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="important-point">Important point:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#important-point" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Is the upright position, when comparing volume of air that ventilates the lung base during inspiration with that ventilates the apex, we find that greater volume of air ventilates the base? The explanation is that, the intrapleural pressure (PUP) at the end of expiration is more negative at the apex than at the base (because of gravity and other unknown factors). Therefore the transpumonary pressure (tTSP) is higher at the apex than at the base and that is why alveoli at the lung apex are affected with air. Therefore, during inspiration greater volume of air ventilates the base of the lung while the apex cannot receive large volume of air (because alveoli are already distended).</li>
</ul>
<p>31
The uses of medical physiology. © Wilson</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="effect-of-lung-diseases-on-vig-ratio">Effect of lung diseases on VIG ratio<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effect-of-lung-diseases-on-vig-ratio" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Each lung diseases are characterized by VIG inequality.</li>
<li>There may result in either: wasted ventilation (e.g. pulmonary embolism) or
wasted perfusion (e.g. Lung collapse); the ratio is changed accordingly.</li>
<li>Remember that, VIG inequality is the most common cause of hypoxemia.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="effect-of-vig-mismatching-on-po2-and-pco2-of-alveolar-air">Effect of VIG mismatching on PO2 and PCO2 of alveolar air<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effect-of-vig-mismatching-on-po2-and-pco2-of-alveolar-air" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>If ventilation to an alveolar is reduced relative to its perfusion (i.e. less O₂, which from environment and less CO₂ removal):</li>
<li>PO₂ in alveoli (PAO₂) decreases</li>
<li>PCO₂ in alveoli (PACO₂) increases</li>
<li>This normally occurs in some alveoli at the base of the lung.</li>
<li>If perfusion to an alveolar is reduced relative to its ventilation (i.e. less carbon dioxide reaches the alveoli from blood):</li>
<li>PO₂ in alveoli (PAO₂) increases</li>
<li>PCO₂ in alveoli (PACO₂) decreases</li>
<li>This normally occurs in some alveoli at apex of the lung.</li>
<li>For this reason, the lung apex is the most favorable site of infection for the splenic bacilli (because of the high PAO₂).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="important-point">Important point:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#important-point" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
