<li>Is the upright position, when comparing volume of air that ventilates the lung base during inspiration with that ventilates the apex, we find that greater volume of air ventilates the base? The explanation is that, the intrapleural pressure (PUP) at the end of expiration is more negative at the apex than at the base (because of gravity and other unknown factors). Therefore the transpumonary pressure (tTSP) is higher at the apex than at the base and that is why alveoli at the lung apex are affected with air. Therefore, during expiration greater volume of air ventilates the base of the lung while the apex cannot receive large volume of air (because alveoli are already distended).</li>
</ul>
<p>32
The uses of medical physiology. © Wilson</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="effect-of-lung-diseases-on-vig-ratio">Effect of lung diseases on VIG ratio<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effect-of-lung-diseases-on-vig-ratio" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Each lung diseases are characterized by VIG inequality.</li>
<li>There may result in either: wasted ventilation (e.g. pulmonary embolism) or
wasted perfusion (e.g. Lung collapse); the ratio is changed accordingly.</li>
<li>Remember that, VIG inequality is the most common cause of hypoxemia.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="effect-of-vig-mismatching-on-po2-and-pco2-of-alveolar-air">Effect of VIG mismatching on PO2 and PCO2 of alveolar air<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effect-of-vig-mismatching-on-po2-and-pco2-of-alveolar-air" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>If ventilation to an alveolar is reduced relative to its perfusion (i.e. less O₂, which from environment and less CO₂ removal):</li>
<li>PO₂ in alveoli (PAO₂) decreases</li>
<li>PCO₂ in alveoli (PACO₂) increases</li>
<li>This normally occurs in some alveoli at the base of the lung.</li>
<li>If perfusion to an alveolar is reduced relative to its ventilation (i.e. less carbon dioxide reaches the alveoli from blood):</li>
<li>PO₂ in alveoli (PAO₂) increases</li>
<li>PCO₂ in alveoli (PACO₂) decreases</li>
<li>This normally occurs in some alveoli at apex of the lung.</li>
<li>For this reason, the lung apex is the most favorable site of infection for the splenic bacilli (because of the high PAO₂).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="important-point">Important point:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#important-point" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Is the upright position, when comparing volume of air that ventilates the lung base during inspiration with that ventilates the apex, we find that greater volume of air ventilates the base? The explanation is that, the intrapleural pressure (PUP) at the end of expiration is more negative at the apex than at the base (because of gravity and other unknown factors). Therefore the transpumonary pressure (tTSP) is higher at the apex than at the base and that is why alveoli at the lung apex are affected with air. Therefore, during inspiration greater volume of air ventilates the base of the lung while the apex cannot receive large volume of air (because alveoli are already distended).</li>
</ul>
<p>33
The uses of medical physiology. © Wilson</p>
<p>GAS TRANSPORT IN THE BLOOD</p>
<p>TRANSPORT OF ORTOBIS</p>
<ul>
<li>Oxygen is transported in the blood in two forms:</li>
<li>Dissolved in plasma ... 5%</li>
<li>Bound to hemoglobin ... 98%</li>
</ul>
<p>Dissolved oxygen:</p>
<ul>
<li>Solubility of oxygen + PO₂</li>
<li>Solubility of oxygen = 0.003 ml/100 ml blood/month</li>
<li>PO₂ = 100 mmHg (in arterial blood) and 40 mmHg (in venous blood)</li>
<li>Therefore dissolved oxygen in 100 ml arterial blood</li>
<li>100 x 0.003 = 0.3 ml oxygen/ 100 ml blood</li>
<li>Dissolved oxygen in 100 ml venous blood</li>
<li>40 x 0.003 = 0.12 ml oxygen/ 100 ml blood</li>
</ul>
<p>Remember that PO₂ in arteries (PACs) is actually less than 100 mmHg (= 95 mmHg) because of the physiological shunt.</p>
<p>Oxygen bound to hemoglobin:</p>
<ul>
<li>Oxygen binds to hemoglobin in a rapid reversible oxygenation reaction (excessive in the ferrous state)</li>
<li>The reaction takes less than 0.01 s</li>
<li>Each gram of Hb can carry up to 1.34 ml oxygen (if 100% saturated as in arteries)</li>
<li>Oxygen bound to Hb in arterial blood can be calculated as follows:</li>
<li>O₂ = [Hb] x 1.34 x (% saturation of Hb with oxygen)</li>
<li>[Hb] = 10 g/100 ml blood</li>
<li>There fore O₂ = 15 x 1.34 x 100% = 70 ml O₂ /100 ml blood</li>
<li>Oxygen bound to Hb in venous blood can be calculated as follows:</li>
<li>O₂ = [Hb] x 1.34 x (% saturation of Hb with oxygen)</li>
<li>[Hb] = 10 g/dL</li>
<li>Therefore O₂ = 15 x 1.34 x 75% = 10 ml O₂ /100 ml blood</li>
</ul>
<p>702</p>
<p>GAS TRANSPORT IN THE BLOOD</p>
<p>TRANSPORT OF ORTOBIS</p>
<ul>
<li>Oxygen is transported in the blood in two forms:</li>
<li>Dissolved in plasma ... 2%</li>
<li>Bound to hemoglobin ... 98%</li>
</ul>
<p>Dissolved oxygen:</p>
<ul>
<li>Solubility of oxygen + PO₂</li>
<li>Solubility of oxygen = 0.003 ml/100 ml blood/month</li>
<li>PO₂ = 100 mmHg (in arterial blood) and 40 mmHg (in venous blood)</li>
<li>Therefore dissolved oxygen in 100 ml arterial blood</li>
<li>100 x 0.003 = 0.3 ml oxygen/ 100 ml blood</li>
<li>Dissolved oxygen in 100 ml venous blood</li>
<li>40 x 0.003 = 0.12 ml oxygen/ 100 ml blood</li>
</ul>
<p>Remember that PO₂ in arteries (PACs) is actually less than 100 mmHg (= 95 mmHg) because of the physiological shunt.</p>
<p>Oxygen bound to hemoglobin:</p>
<ul>
<li>Oxygen binds to hemoglobin in a rapid reversible oxygenation reaction (excessive in the ferrous state)</li>
<li>The reaction takes less than 0.01 s</li>
<li>Each gram of Hb can carry up to 1.34 ml oxygen (if 100% saturated as in arteries)</li>
<li>Oxygen bound to Hb in arterial blood can be calculated as follows:</li>
<li>O₂ = [Hb] x 1.34 x (% saturation of Hb with oxygen)</li>
<li>[Hb] = 10 g/100 ml blood</li>
<li>There fore O₂ = 15 x 1.34 x 100% = 20 ml O₂ /100 ml blood</li>
<li>Oxygen bound to Hb in venous blood can be calculated as follows:</li>
<li>O₂ = [Hb] x 1.34 x (% saturation of Hb with oxygen)</li>
<li>[Hb] = 10 g/dL</li>
<li>Therefore O₂ = 15 x 1.34 x 75% = 15 ml O₂ /100 ml blood</li>
</ul>
<p>703</p>
<p>GAS TRANSPORT IN THE BLOOD</p>
<p>TRANSPORT OF ORTOBIS</p>
<ul>
<li>Oxygen is transported in the blood in two forms:</li>
<li>Dissolved in plasma ... 2%</li>
<li>Bound to hemoglobin ... 98%</li>
</ul>
<p>Dissolved oxygen:</p>
<ul>
<li>Solubility of oxygen + PO₂</li>
<li>Solubility of oxygen = 0.003 ml/100 ml blood/month</li>
<li>PO₂ = 100 mmHg (in arterial blood) and 40 mmHg (in venous blood)</li>
<li>Therefore dissolved oxygen in 100 ml arterial blood</li>
<li>100 x 0.003 = 0.3 ml oxygen/ 100 ml blood</li>
<li>Dissolved oxygen in 100 ml venous blood</li>
<li>40 x 0.003 = 0.12 ml oxygen/ 100 ml blood</li>
</ul>
<p>Remember that PO₂ in arteries (PACs) is actually less than 100 mmHg (= 95 mmHg) because of the physiological shunt.</p>
<p>Oxygen bound to hemoglobin:</p>
<ul>
<li>Oxygen binds to hemoglobin in a rapid reversible oxygenation reaction (excessive in the ferrous state)</li>
<li>The reaction takes less than 0.01 s</li>
<li>Each gram of Hb can carry up to 1.34 ml oxygen (if 100% saturated as in arteries)</li>
<li>Oxygen bound to Hb in arterial blood can be calculated as follows:</li>
<li>O₂ = [Hb] x 1.34 x (% saturation of Hb with oxygen)</li>
<li>[Hb] = 10 g/100 ml blood</li>
<li>There fore O₂ = 15 x 1.34 x 100% = 20 ml O₂ /100 ml blood</li>
<li>Oxygen bound to Hb in venous blood can be calculated as follows:</li>
<li>O₂ = [Hb] x 1.34 x (% saturation of Hb with oxygen)</li>
<li>[Hb] = 10 g/dL</li>
<li>Therefore O₂ = 15 x 1.34 x 75% = 15 ml O₂ /100 ml blood</li>
</ul>
<p>702</p>
<ul>
<li>The relation between Po2 &amp; percent saturation of Hb with oxygen is explained by the oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve:</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-oxygen-hemoglobin-dissociation-curve">The Oxygen-Hemoglobin Dissociation Curve<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-oxygen-hemoglobin-dissociation-curve" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Indicates direct relation between PO₂ and % saturation of Hb with oxygen.</li>
<li>Sigmoid shaped. (starts slowly, becomes steep in the middle and then reaches a maximum).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-21c6f6bc.jpeg" alt="img-333.jpeg">
Fig 7.13: The oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve</p>
<ul>
<li>The sigmoid shape can be explained as follows:</li>
<li>Oxygen binds to the subunits of Hb successively (not all of them at the same time).</li>
<li>The binding with the first subunit facilitates binding with the second subunit and this facilitates binding with the third subunit &amp; so on.</li>
<li>The facilitation occurs due to changes in the configuration of Hb from the tense (T) form to the relaxed (R) form.</li>
</ul>
<p>The core of medical physiology. 4th edition</p>
<p>Therefore, binding:</p>
<ul>
<li>Starts slowly indicating low affinity of Hb to oxygen (occurs when oxygen is binding to the first subunits)</li>
<li>Becomes steep in the middle indicating high affinity of Hb to oxygen (occurs when oxygen is binding to the other subunits). The affinity is increased up to 500 kDa.</li>
<li>Reaches maximum at the end (indicating full saturation).</li>
</ul>
<p>Notes to remember from the curve:</p>
<ul>
<li>PO₂ of 65 mmHg gives oxygen saturation of 70% (as in veins)</li>
<li>PO₂ of 65 mmHg gives oxygen saturation of 97% (as in arteries)</li>
<li>PO₂ of 97 mmHg gives oxygen saturation of 97.5% (as in oxygenated blood in pulmonary capillaries). Less saturation in arteries (0.5%) is due to the physiological shunt</li>
<li>PO₂ of 25 mmHg gives oxygen saturation of 93%. This is known as the P₃₀</li>
<li>The P₃₀ is defined as the PO₂ when Hb is 90% saturated with O₂. It is used to describe the affinity of Hb to O₂ (e.g. high P₃₀ indicates low affinity of Hb to O₂ whereas low P₃₀ indicates the reverse.</li>
</ul>
<p>Affinity of hemoglobin to oxygen:</p>
<ul>
<li>The affinity of Hb to oxygen is affected by certain factors. These factors can shift the curve to the right or to the left.</li>
<li>The P₃₀ gives information about affinity of hemoglobin to oxygen. Normal value = 25 mmHg higher values indicate shift to the right (low affinity) &amp; lower values indicate shift to the left (high affinity).</li>
</ul>
<p>Shift to the right:</p>
<ul>
<li>Indicates lower affinity of Hb to oxygen (high P₃₀)</li>
<li>Indicates increased release of oxygen to tissues</li>
<li>Caused by:</li>
</ul>
<p>Therefore, binding:</p>
<ul>
<li>Starts slowly indicating low affinity of Hb to oxygen (occurs when oxygen is binding to the first subunits)</li>
<li>Becomes steep in the middle indicating high affinity of Hb to oxygen (occurs when oxygen is binding to the other subunits). The affinity is increased up to 500 kDa.</li>
<li>Reaches maximum at the end (indicating full saturation).</li>
</ul>
<p>Notes to remember from the curve:</p>
<ul>
<li>PO₂ of 40 mmHg gives oxygen saturation of 75% (as in veins)</li>
<li>PO₂ of 55 mmHg gives oxygen saturation of 97% (as in arteries)</li>
<li>PO₂ of 97 mmHg gives oxygen saturation of 97.5% (as in oxygenated blood in pulmonary capillaries). Less saturation in arteries (0.5%) is due to the physiological shunt</li>
<li>PO₂ of 25 mmHg gives oxygen saturation of 93%. This is known as the P₃₀</li>
<li>The P₃₀ is defined as the PO₂ when Hb is 90% saturated with O₂. It is used to describe the affinity of Hb to O₂ (e.g. high P₃₀ indicates low affinity of Hb to O₂ whereas low P₃₀ indicates the reverse.</li>
</ul>
<p>Affinity of hemoglobin to oxygen:</p>
<ul>
<li>The affinity of Hb to oxygen is affected by certain factors. These factors can shift the curve to the right or to the left.</li>
<li>The P₃₀ gives information about affinity of hemoglobin to oxygen. Normal value = 25 mmHg higher values indicate shift to the right (low affinity) &amp; lower values indicate shift to the left (high affinity).</li>
</ul>
<p>Shift to the right:</p>
<ul>
<li>Indicates lower affinity of Hb to oxygen (high P₃₀)</li>
<li>Indicates increased release of oxygen to tissues</li>
<li>Caused by:</li>
</ul>
<p>Therefore, binding:</p>
<ul>
<li>Starts slowly indicating low affinity of Hb to oxygen (occurs when oxygen is binding to the first subunits)</li>
<li>Becomes steep in the middle indicating high affinity of Hb to oxygen (occurs when oxygen is binding to the other subunits). The affinity is increased up to 500 kDa.</li>
<li>Reaches maximum at the end (indicating full saturation).</li>
</ul>
<p>Notes to remember from the curve:</p>
<ul>
<li>PO₂ of 40 mmHg gives oxygen saturation of 75% (as in veins)</li>
<li>PO₂ of 65 mmHg gives oxygen saturation of 97% (as in arteries)</li>
<li>PO₂ of 97 mmHg gives oxygen saturation of 97.5% (as in oxygenated blood in pulmonary capillaries). Less saturation in arteries (0.5%) is due to the physiological shunt</li>
<li>PO₂ of 25 mmHg gives oxygen saturation of 93%. This is known as the P₃₀</li>
<li>The P₃₀ is defined as the PO₂ when Hb is 90% saturated with O₂. It is used to describe the affinity of Hb to O₂ (e.g. high P₃₀ indicates low affinity of Hb to O₂ whereas low P₃₀ indicates the reverse.</li>
</ul>
<p>Affinity of hemoglobin to oxygen:</p>
<ul>
<li>The affinity of Hb to oxygen is affected by certain factors. These factors can shift the curve to the right or to the left.</li>
<li>The P₃₀ gives information about affinity of hemoglobin to oxygen. Normal value = 25 mmHg higher values indicate shift to the right (low affinity) &amp; lower values indicate shift to the left (high affinity).</li>
</ul>
<p>Shift to the right:</p>
<ul>
<li>Indicates lower affinity of Hb to oxygen (high P₃₀)</li>
<li>Indicates increased release of oxygen to tissues</li>
<li>Caused by:</li>
</ul>
<p>204
The view of medical physiology of science</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>High carbon dioxide,</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>High Hydrogen ions (low pH)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>High 2,3 DPG</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>High temperature</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The 2,0 diphenylsulfonate (2,3 DPG) is a product of glycolysis. It is highly present in RBCs when metabolism is increased. It is also increased in exercise, high altitude and by some hormones like growth hormone, thyroid hormones and androgens. Its binding to the beta chain of Hb decreases the binding of Hb to oxygen.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-cd35b3e8.jpeg" alt="img-334.jpeg">
Fig.1.14: Profile of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve</p>

<li>Indicates increased affinity of Hb to oxygen (low <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>P</mi><mrow><mi>O</mi><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">P_{O2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">P</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.1389em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">O</span><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>)</li>
<li>Indicates decreased release of oxygen to tissues</li>
<li>Caused by:</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="shift-to-the-left">Shift to the left<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#shift-to-the-left" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Indicates increased affinity of Hb to oxygen (low <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>P</mi><mrow><mi>O</mi><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">P_{O2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">P</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.1389em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">O</span><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>)</li>
<li>Indicates decreased release of oxygen to tissues</li>
<li>Caused by:</li>
<li>Low carbon dioxide,</li>
<li>Low hydrogen ions,</li>
</ul>
<p>100</p>
<p>The role of carbon dioxide in the regulation of carbon dioxide</p>
<ul>
<li>Low 2,3 DPG (e.g. due to acidosis or in stored blood)</li>
<li>Low temperature</li>
<li>Myoglobin</li>
<li>Hemoglobin F</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Remember that</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Shift to the right occurs in tissues, where CO₂, H⁺ &amp; temperature are high, whereas shift to the left occurs in the lung where these factors are decreased.</li>
<li>Hb F &amp; Myoglobin have very high affinity to oxygen. They shift the curve to the left.</li>
<li>Hb F binds less easily to 2,3 DPG, this increases its affinity to C2.</li>
<li>Arsenic does not affect the shape of the curve. That's because PO₂ is normal and therefore the % saturation of Hb is normal.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Bake effect</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The affinity of Hb to oxygen is decreased when the pH of the blood falls.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>That's why increase in CO₂ content of the blood decreases the affinity of Hb to O₂ &amp; causes shift of the curve to the right.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Low 2,3 DPG (e.g. due to acidosis or in stored blood)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Low temperature</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Myoglobin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hemoglobin F</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Remember that</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Shift to the right occurs in tissues, where CO₂, H⁺ &amp; temperature are high, whereas shift to the left occurs in the lung where these factors are decreased.</li>
<li>Hb F &amp; Myoglobin have very high affinity to oxygen. They shift the curve to the left.</li>
<li>Hb F binds less easily to 2,3 DPG, this increases its affinity to C2.</li>
<li>Arsenic does not affect the shape of the curve. That's because PO₂ is normal and therefore the % saturation of Hb is normal.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Bake effect</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The affinity of Hb to oxygen is decreased when the pH of the blood falls.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>That's why increase in CO₂ content of the blood decreases the affinity of Hb to O₂ &amp; causes shift of the curve to the right.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Low 2,3 DPG (e.g. due to acidosis or in stored blood)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Low temperature</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Myoglobin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hemoglobin F</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Remember that</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Shift to the right occurs in tissues, where CO₂, H⁺ &amp; temperature are high, whereas shift to the left occurs in the lung where these factors are decreased.</li>
<li>Hb F &amp; Myoglobin have very high affinity to oxygen. They shift the curve to the left.</li>
<li>Hb F binds less easily to 2,3 DPG, this increases its affinity to C2.</li>
<li>Arsenic does not affect the shape of the curve. That's because PO₂ is normal and therefore the % saturation of Hb is normal.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Bake effect</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>The affinity of Hb to oxygen is decreased when the pH of the blood falls.</li>
<li>That's why increase in CO₂ content of the blood decreases the affinity of Hb to O₂ &amp; causes shift of the curve to the right.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="transport-of-carbon-dioxide">TRANSPORT OF CARBON DIOXIDE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transport-of-carbon-dioxide" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Carbon dioxide is transported in 3 forms:</li>
<li>As bicarbonate (the main form of transport)</li>
<li>Bound to proteins (carbamine compounds)</li>
<li>Dissolved</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Dissolved CO₂</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>The solubility of CO₂ is higher than O₂ (up to 20 times).</li>
<li>The dissolved CO₂ constitutes about 5% of total CO₂ in arterial blood and 6% of total CO₂ in venous blood.</li>
<li>Generally there is no reaction between CO₂ &amp; water in the plasma (due to absence of carbonic anhydrase enzyme in the plasma).</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="transport-of-carbon-dioxide">TRANSPORT OF CARBON DIOXIDE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transport-of-carbon-dioxide" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Carbon dioxide is transported in 3 forms:</li>
<li>As bicarbonate (the main form of transport)</li>
<li>Bound to proteins (carbamine compounds)</li>
<li>Dissolved</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Dissolved CO₂</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>The solubility of CO₂ is higher than O₂ (up to 20 times).</li>
<li>The dissolved CO₂ constitutes about 5% of total CO₂ in arterial blood and 6% of total CO₂ in venous blood.</li>
<li>Generally there is no reaction between CO₂ &amp; water in the plasma (due to absence of carbonic anhydrase enzyme in the plasma).</li>
</ul>
<hr>

The role of Cadmium in smoking</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="transport-as-bicarbonate">Transport as Bicarbonate<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transport-as-bicarbonate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>This is the main form of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CO}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> transport in the blood.</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CO}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> diffuses inside RBCs and reacts with water in the presence of carbonic anhydrase enzyme to produce carbonic acid &amp; then bicarbonate &amp; hydrogen ion.</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msubsup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">−</mo></msubsup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CO}_{2} + \mathrm{H}_{2}\mathrm{O} = \mathrm{H}_{2}\mathrm{CO}_{3} = \mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-} + \mathrm{H}^{+} + \mathrm{H}^{+} + \mathrm{H}_{2}\mathrm{O}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0916em; vertical-align: -0.247em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">HCO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -2.453em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.247em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9047em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8213em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9047em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8213em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">O</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<ul>
<li>Hydrogen ions are buffered by hemoglobin.</li>
<li>About 70% of bicarbonate diffuses to the plasma in exchange to chloride (= Chloride shift).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-97635be5.jpeg" alt="img-337.jpeg">
Fig 7.15: Chloride shift</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="remember-that">Remember that:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remember-that" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Due to diffusion of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CO}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> into RBCs, the number of active osmotic particles in RBCs is increased (by either <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">−</mo></msubsup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0916em; vertical-align: -0.247em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">HCO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -2.453em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.247em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> or <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">−</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Cl}^{-}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8557em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Cl</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8557em;"><span style="top: -3.1473em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>)</li>
<li>So, in venous blood water enters RBCs by osmosis, measuring the size of RBCs. Then it passes out in the lungs when chloride leaves out and the RBCs return to their normal size in arteries.</li>
<li>That's why PCV of venous blood is higher than arterial blood by about 3%.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bound-to-proteins">Bound to proteins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bound-to-proteins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CO}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> forms carbamino-compounds by binding to proteins (plasma proteins and hemoglobin in RBCs)</li>
<li>About 11% of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CO}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> in the blood is carried to the lungs as carbamino-</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="haldane-effect">Haldane effect<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#haldane-effect" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Deoxy Hb in venous blood binds CO2 more readily than oxy Hb in arterial blood.</li>
<li>Therefore binding of oxygen to Hb in the lungs facilitates release of CO2 from Hb; this is known as the Haldane effect.</li>
<li>For this reason, arteries (containing oxygenated blood) carry less carbon dioxide than veins (containing deoxygenated blood).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="summary">Summary<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#summary" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>CO2 is transported in plasma as:</li>
<li>Dissolved</li>
<li>Carbamino-CO2</li>
<li>HCO3</li>
<li>CO2 is transported RBCs as:</li>
<li>Dissolved</li>
<li>Carbamino Hb</li>
<li>HCO3</li>
<li>About 70% of the HCO3 enters the venous blood in exchange to chloride (chloride shift).</li>
<li>PCV of venous blood is higher than arterial blood by about 3%.</li>
</ul>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="control-of-respiration">CONTROL OF RESPIRATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-respiration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Can be studied as: Neural control and Chemical control</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="neural-control">Neural Control<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#neural-control" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Two types:</li>
<li>Involuntary control</li>
<li>By the respiratory center</li>
<li>Voluntary control</li>
<li>By the cerebral cortex</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-respiratory-center">The respiratory center<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-respiratory-center" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Collection of neurons in the medulla &amp; pons</li>
<li>Arranged into 4 groups:</li>
<li>Dorsal group</li>
<li>Ventral group</li>
<li>Apneustic center</li>
<li>Pneumotaxic center</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-dorsal-group">The dorsal group<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-dorsal-group" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Found at the dorsal aspect of the medulla.</li>
<li>It contains inspiratory neurons (it is responsible for inspiration). It is called the rhythmicity center because it can discharge impulses rhythmically. However, the rhythmic discharge is initiated in a nearby pacemaker tissue in the medulla known as the pre-Botzinger complex.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-ventral-group">The ventral group<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-ventral-group" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Found in the ventral aspect of the medulla.</li>
<li>Contains expiratory neurons + some inspiratory neurons.</li>
<li>Inactive at rest (that's why expiration occurs passively).</li>
<li>Inactivated when the dorsal group is stimulated &amp; vice versa (reciprocal innervation).</li>
<li>Responsible for forced expiration</li>
</ul>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<p>2.10
The amount of material (dry material) in 1000lbs</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-aprooustic-center">The Aprooustic center<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-aprooustic-center" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Found in the lower part of the pore.</li>
<li>Stimulates the dorsal group to increase depth of inspiration.</li>
<li>Inhibited by: The vagus and the pneumotoxic center.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-pneumotoxic-center">The Pneumotoxic center<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-pneumotoxic-center" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Found in the upper part of the pore.</li>
<li>Its function is unknown, may be switching between inspiration &amp; expiration.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-7-10-the-respiratory-center">Fig 7.10: The respiratory center<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-7-10-the-respiratory-center" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-628546e0.jpeg" alt="img-338.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>Functions of the different groups of the respiratory center are studied in animals by performing sections at various levels in the brain stem.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="section-7-below-the-x-1-100x-1-100x-1-100">Section 7 (below the <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>100</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">x = 1,100</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span></span></span></span></span>)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-7-below-the-x-1-100x-1-100x-1-100" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Results in death if the lesion is above <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>C</mi><mi>x</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">C_x</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0715em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">x</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>. That's because the descending impulses from the respiratory center fail to reach the phrenic nerve which supplies the diaphragm.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="section-7-between-medulla-pons">Section 7 (between medulla &amp; pons)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-7-between-medulla-pons" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Results in gasping (shallow) respiration. That's because the aprostatic center fails to increase depth of inspiration.</li>
</ul>
<p>2.10
The amount of material (dry material) in 1000lbs</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-aprooustic-center">The Aprooustic center<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-aprooustic-center" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Found in the lower part of the pore.</li>
<li>Stimulates the dorsal group to increase depth of inspiration.</li>
<li>Inhibited by: The vagus and the pneumotoxic center.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-pneumotoxic-center">The Pneumotoxic center<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-pneumotoxic-center" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Found in the upper part of the pore.</li>
<li>Its function is unknown, may be switching between inspiration &amp; expiration.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fig-7-10-the-respiratory-center">Fig 7.10: The respiratory center<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fig-7-10-the-respiratory-center" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<li>Results in death if the lesion is above <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>C</mi><mi>x</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">C_x</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0715em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">x</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>. That's because the descending impulses from the respiratory center fail to reach the phrenic nerve which supplies the diaphragm.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="section-1-between-medulla-pons">Section 1 (between medulla &amp; pons)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-1-between-medulla-pons" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-aprooustic-center">The Aprooustic center<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-aprooustic-center" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="section-1-below-the-x-1-100x-1-100x-1-100">Section 1 (below the <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>100</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">x = 1,100</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span></span></span></span></span>)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-1-below-the-x-1-100x-1-100x-1-100" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>

That's because the descending impulses from the respiratory center fail to reach the phrenic nerve which supplies the diaphragm.</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="section-1-between-medulla-pons">Section 1 (between medulla &amp; pons)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-1-between-medulla-pons" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Results in gasping (shallow) respiration. That's because the aprostatic center fails to increase depth of inspiration.</li>
</ul>
<p>The amount of material (dry material) in 1000lbs</p>
<p>Section 3 level positive position + cutting the vessel margin</p>
<ul>
<li>Results in apressatic breathing (dead respiration). That's because the pneumotonic center fails to inhibit the apressatic center.</li>
</ul>
<p>Section 4 relative control</p>
<ul>
<li>No effect on involuntary respiration; however, it impairs the voluntary control of respiration.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-d55a181f.jpeg" alt="img-341.jpeg">
Fig.1.17. Sections below and above the respiratory center</p>

<ul>
<li>Results in apressatic breathing (dead respiration). That's because the pneumotonic center fails to inhibit the apressatic center.</li>
</ul>
<p>Section 5 relative control</p>
<ul>
<li>No effect on involuntary respiration; however, it impairs the voluntary control of respiration.</li>
</ul>

<ul>

</ul>
