<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="higher-centers">Higher centers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#higher-centers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The cerebral cortex</li>
<li>For voluntary modification of respiration</li>
<li>E.g. voluntary hyperventilation or voluntary apnea</li>
<li>The hypothalamus (temperature center)</li>
<li>Stimulates heat loss by increasing respiration</li>
<li>E.g. panting in dogs</li>
<li>The limbic system</li>
<li>Emotions may affect respiration (e.g. fear)</li>
<li>Other brain stem centers</li>
<li>Stimulation or inhibition of the cardiac or the vasomotor centers in the medulla, results also in stimulation or inhibition of the respiratory center (impulses radiate between the centers). That's why hyperventilation is associated with tachycardia and hypoventilation is associated with bradycardia.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-baroreceptors">The Baroreceptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-baroreceptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Stretch receptors found in the aortic &amp; the carotid sinuses, connected to the cardiac &amp; vasomotor centers in the medulla by the cranial nerves 5 &amp; 10, send inhibitory impulses to these centers when stimulated by stretch caused by high blood pressure</li>
<li>The inhibitory impulses decrease the sympathetic discharge from these centers to the heart &amp; blood vessels. This lowers the blood pressure by:</li>
<li>Decreasing the heart rate</li>
<li>Decreasing contractility</li>
<li>Vasorelaxation</li>
</ul>
<p>313
The Journal of Medical Microbiology • 1994</p>
<ul>
<li>Lung stretch receptors</li>
<li>Propricceptors</li>
<li>Other receptors</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="higher-centers">Higher centers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#higher-centers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The cerebral cortex</li>
<li>For voluntary modification of respiration</li>
<li>E.g. voluntary hyperventilation or voluntary apnea</li>
<li>The hypothalamus (temperature center)</li>
<li>Stimulates heat loss by increasing respiration</li>
<li>E.g. panting in dogs</li>
<li>The limbic system</li>
<li>Emotions may affect respiration (e.g. fear)</li>
<li>Other brain stem centers</li>
<li>Stimulation or inhibition of the cardiac or the vasomotor centers in the medulla, results also in stimulation or inhibition of the respiratory center (impulses radiate between the centers). That's why hyperventilation is associated with tachycardia and hypoventilation is associated with bradycardia.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-baroreceptors">The Baroreceptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-baroreceptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Stretch receptors found in the aortic &amp; the carotid sinuses, connected to the cardiac &amp; vasomotor centers in the medulla by the cranial nerves 5 &amp; 10, send inhibitory impulses to these centers when stimulated by stretch caused by high blood pressure</li>
<li>The inhibitory impulses decrease the sympathetic discharge from these centers to the heart &amp; blood vessels. This lowers the blood pressure by:</li>
<li>Decreasing the heart rate</li>
<li>Decreasing contractility</li>
<li>Vasorelaxation</li>
</ul>
<p>312
The Journal of Medical Microbiology • 1994</p>
<p>712
The inhibitory impulses also inhibit the respiratory center. For this reason, hypertension is associated with hypoventilation &amp; hypotension is associated with hyperventilation, but mainly due to activity of the chemoreceptors.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-chemoreceptors">The Chemoreceptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-chemoreceptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>See chemical control of respiration below.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-proprioceptors">The Proprioceptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-proprioceptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Found in the joints, ligaments &amp; tendons of muscles.</li>
<li>Stimulated by movement (even passive movement).</li>
<li>Send impulses directly to the respiratory center to increase respiration.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-long-stretch-receptors">The Long stretch receptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-long-stretch-receptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Stretch receptors found in the smooth muscles of bronchioles.</li>
<li>Stimulated by stretch during inflation of the lung.</li>
<li>Send inhibitory impulses through the vegl to stop further inspiration.</li>
<li>This protective reflex is called resting (breuer inflation reflex).</li>
<li>It is not active in humans (except with very high tidal volume).</li>
<li>There is also resting (breuer deflation reflex stimulated by deflation of the lung.</li>
<li>Here excitatory impulses are carried also through the vegl to restart inspiration.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="other-receptors">Other receptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-receptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(1) receptors</p>
<ul>
<li>Found in upper respiratory tract</li>
<li>Stimulated by infants (dust, smoke,...)</li>
<li>Mediate coughing reflex, sneezing reflex...</li>
</ul>
<p>(2) receptors</p>
<ul>
<li>Found in juxtaposition to pulmonary capillaries</li>
<li>Stimulated when the capillaries become distended with blood</li>
<li>Function unknown, may be mediation of the series of dyspnea</li>
</ul>
<p>713
The role of inhibitory muscles in the respiratory system</p>
<p>714
The inhibitory impulses also inhibit the respiratory center. For this reason, hypertension is associated with hypoventilation &amp; hypotension is associated with hyperventilation, but mainly due to activity of the chemoreceptors.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-choriomeceptors">The Choriomeceptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-choriomeceptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>See chemical control of respiration below.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-proprioceptors">The Proprioceptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-proprioceptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Found in the joints, ligaments &amp; tendons of muscles.</li>
<li>Stimulated by movement (even passive movement).</li>
<li>Send impulses directly to the respiratory center to increase respiration.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-long-stretch-receptors">The Long stretch receptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-long-stretch-receptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Stretch receptors found in the smooth muscles of bronchioles.</li>
<li>Stimulated by stretch during inflation of the lung.</li>
<li>Send inhibitory impulses through the vegl to stop further inspiration.</li>
<li>This protective reflex is called Resting (breuer inflation reflex).</li>
<li>It is not active in humans (except with very high tidal volume).</li>
<li>There is also Resting (breuer deflation reflex stimulated by deflation of the lung.</li>
<li>Here excitatory impulses are carried also through the vegl to restart inspiration.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="other-receptors">Other receptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-receptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(1) receptors</p>
<ul>
<li>Found in upper respiratory tract</li>
<li>Stimulated by infants (dust, smoke,...)</li>
<li>Mediate coughing reflex, sneezing reflex...</li>
</ul>
<p>(2) receptors</p>
<ul>
<li>Found in juxtaposition to pulmonary capillaries</li>
<li>Stimulated when the capillaries become distended with blood</li>
<li>Function unknown, may be mediation of the series of dyspnea</li>
</ul>
<p>715
The role of inhibitory muscles in the respiratory system</p>
<p>The inhibitory impulses also inhibit the respiratory center. For this reason, hypertension is associated with hypoventilation &amp; hypotension is associated with hyperventilation, but mainly due to activity of the chemoreceptors.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-choriomeceptors">The Choriomeceptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-choriomeceptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>See chemical control of respiration below.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-proprioceptors">The Proprioceptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-proprioceptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Found in the joints, ligaments &amp; tendons of muscles.</li>
<li>Stimulated by movement (even passive movement).</li>
<li>Send impulses directly to the respiratory center to increase respiration.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-long-stretch-receptors">The Long stretch receptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-long-stretch-receptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Stretch receptors found in the smooth muscles of bronchioles.</li>
<li>Stimulated by stretch during inflation of the lung.</li>
<li>Send inhibitory impulses through the vegl to stop further inspiration.</li>
<li>This protective reflex is called Resting (breuer deflation reflex).</li>
<li>It is not active in humans (except with very high tidal volume).</li>
<li>There is also Resting (breuer deflation reflex stimulated by deflation of the lung.</li>
<li>Here excitatory impulses are carried also through the vegl to restart inspiration.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="other-receptors">Other receptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-receptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(1) receptors</p>
<ul>
<li>Found in upper respiratory tract</li>
<li>Stimulated by infants (dust, smoke,...)</li>
<li>Mediate coughing reflex, sneezing reflex.</li>
</ul>
<p>(2) receptors</p>
<ul>
<li>Found in juxtaposition to pulmonary capillaries</li>
<li>Stimulated when the capillaries become distended with blood</li>
<li>Function unknown, may be mediation of the series of dyspnea</li>
</ul>
<p>Chemical Control</p>
<ul>
<li>By chemoreceptors that detect chemical changes in blood or CSF</li>
<li>There are two types of chemoreceptors:</li>
<li>Peripheral chemoreceptors</li>
<li>Central chemoreceptors</li>
</ul>
<p>The peripheral chemoreceptors</p>
<ul>
<li>Special receptors found in Aortic bodies and Carotid bodies</li>
<li>Aortic bodies (two or more) are found in the aortic arch and the two carotid bodies are found in the two bifurcations of the carotid artery (one on each side).</li>
<li>The bodies contain two types of cells: type I or glucose cells and type II cells.</li>
<li>Type I cells (= the peripheral chemoreceptors) are stimulated by:</li>
<li>Hypoxia (the main stimulus)</li>
<li>Hypercapnia</li>
<li>Acidosis</li>
<li>They send excitatory impulses through the cranial nerves 9 &amp; 10 to stimulate the respiratory center in the medulla.</li>
<li>This results in hyperventilation to correct the stimulus.</li>
</ul>
<p>Important points:</p>
<ul>
<li>The blood supply per gram tissue to carotid bodies is very high, they receive 2000 ml per 100 gram tissue whereas 100 gram tissue in the kidneys receives 420 ml and in the brain receives 54ml. That's why they can detect minor changes in the chemical composition of the blood.</li>
<li>Glomus cells are chromaffin-like cells. They release dopamine in response to hypoxia which acts on D2 receptors in glossopharyngeal nerve.</li>
<li>Other stimuli to glomus cells include cyanide, nicotine and hyperkalaemia; however, they are not directly stimulated with arsenite.</li>
<li>Type II cells surround type I cells. They are not innervated. Their function is sustenable.</li>
</ul>
<p>The role of medical physiology in animal</p>
<p>Chemical Control</p>
<ul>
<li>By chemoreceptors that detect chemical changes in blood or CSF</li>
<li>There are two types of chemoreceptors:</li>
<li>Peripheral chemoreceptors</li>
<li>Central chemoreceptors</li>
</ul>
<p>The peripheral chemoreceptors</p>
<ul>
<li>Special receptors found in Aortic bodies and Carotid bodies</li>
<li>Aortic bodies (two or more) are found in the aortic arch and the two carotid bodies are found in the two bifurcations of the carotid artery (one on each side).</li>
<li>The bodies contain two types of cells: type I or glucose cells and type II cells.</li>
<li>Type I cells (= the peripheral chemoreceptors) are stimulated by:</li>
<li>Hypoxia (the main stimulus)</li>
<li>Hypercapnia</li>
<li>Acidosis</li>
<li>They send excitatory impulses through the cranial nerves 9 &amp; 10 to stimulate the respiratory center in the medulla.</li>
<li>This results in hyperventilation to correct the stimulus.</li>
</ul>
<p>Important points:</p>
<ul>
<li>The blood supply per gram tissue to carotid bodies is very high, they receive 2000 ml per 100 gram tissue whereas 100 gram tissue in the kidneys receives 420 ml and in the brain receives 54ml. That's why they can detect minor changes in the chemical composition of the blood.</li>
<li>Glomus cells are chromaffin-like cells. They release dopamine in response to hypoxia which acts on D2 receptors in glossopharyngeal nerve.</li>
<li>Other stimuli to glomus cells include cyanide, nicotine and hyperkalaemia; however, they are not directly stimulated with arsenite.</li>
<li>Type II cells surround type I cells. They are not innervated. Their function is sustenable.</li>
</ul>
<p>The role of medical physiology in animal</p>
<p>Chemical Control</p>
<ul>
<li>By chemoreceptors that detect chemical changes in blood or CSF</li>
<li>There are two types of chemoreceptors:</li>
<li>Peripheral chemoreceptors</li>
<li>Central chemoreceptors</li>
</ul>
<p>The peripheral chemoreceptors</p>
<ul>
<li>Special receptors found in Aortic bodies and Carotid bodies</li>
<li>Aortic bodies (two or more) are found in the aortic arch and the two carotid bodies are found in the two bifurcations of the carotid artery (one on each side).</li>
<li>The bodies contain two types of cells: type I or glucose cells and type II cells.</li>
<li>Type I cells (= the peripheral chemoreceptors) are stimulated by:</li>
<li>Hypoxia (the main stimulus)</li>
<li>Hypercapnia</li>
<li>Acidosis</li>
<li>They send excitatory impulses through the cranial nerves 9 &amp; 10 to stimulate the respiratory center in the medulla.</li>
<li>This results in hyperventilation to correct the stimulus.</li>
</ul>
<p>Important points:</p>
<ul>
<li>The blood supply per gram tissue to carotid bodies is very high, they receive 2000 ml per 100 gram tissue whereas 100 gram tissue in the kidneys receives 420 ml and in the brain receives 54ml. That's why they can detect minor changes in the chemical composition of the blood.</li>
<li>Glomus cells are chromaffin-like cells. They release dopamine in response to hypoxia which acts on D2 receptors in glossopharyngeal nerve.</li>
<li>Other stimuli to glomus cells include cyanide, nicotine and hyperkalaemia; however, they are not directly stimulated with arsenite.</li>
<li>Type II cells surround type I cells. They are not innervated. Their function is sustenable.</li>
</ul>
<p>The role of medical physiology in animal</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-central-chemoreceptors">The central chemoreceptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-central-chemoreceptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Found on the international surface of the module, in contact with the CSF.</li>
<li>They are stimulated by:</li>
<li>High carbon dioxide (in blood and therefore in CSF)</li>
<li>High hydrogen ions (in the CSF not that in blood)</li>
<li>Hydrogen ions in the blood cannot cross the blood brain barrier "BBB" easily.</li>
<li>Hydrogen ions in the CSF are formed from carbon dioxide as follows: Carbon dioxide crosses the BBB &amp; reacts with water in the CSF to produce carbonic acid &amp; then dissociates into bicarbonate &amp; hydrogen ions. Then hydrogen ions in the CSF stimulate the central chemoreceptors.</li>
<li>In other words, carbon dioxide stimulates the central chemoreceptors directly (by CO₂ itself) and indirectly (by H⁺).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="part-7-10-the-central-chemoreceptors">Part 7-10: The central chemoreceptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#part-7-10-the-central-chemoreceptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-d00461dd.jpeg" alt="img-344.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="remember-that">Remember that:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remember-that" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>In patients with chronic hypercapnia (e.g. patients with COPD), respiration is stimulated by hypoxia not hypercapnia (because the receptors become used to the high CO₂).</li>
<li>Treatment with high pressure O₂ in these patients corrects hypoxia and stops respiration. That's why they should be treated with low pressure O₂ (e.g. 24% or 28%, not 80% or 100% O₂).</li>
</ul>
<p>The role of carbon dioxide in the brain</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-central-chemoreceptors">The central chemoreceptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-central-chemoreceptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Found on the international surface of the module, in contact with the CSF.</li>
<li>They are stimulated by:</li>
<li>High carbon dioxide (in blood and therefore in CSF)</li>
<li>High hydrogen ions (in the CSF not that in blood)</li>
<li>Hydrogen ions in the blood cannot cross the blood brain barrier "BBB" easily.</li>
<li>Hydrogen ions in the CSF are formed from carbon dioxide as follows: Carbon dioxide crosses the BBB &amp; reacts with water in the CSF to produce carbonic acid &amp; then dissociates into bicarbonate &amp; hydrogen ions. Then hydrogen ions in the CSF stimulate the central chemoreceptors.</li>
<li>In other words, carbon dioxide stimulates the central chemoreceptors directly (by CO₂ itself) and indirectly (by H⁺).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="part-7-10-the-central-chemoreceptors">Part 7-10: The central chemoreceptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#part-7-10-the-central-chemoreceptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-a36f1012.jpeg" alt="img-345.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="remember-that">Remember that:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remember-that" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>In patients with chronic hypercapnia (e.g. patients with COPD), respiration is stimulated by hypoxia not hypercapnia (because the receptors become used to the high CO₂).</li>
<li>Treatment with high pressure O₂ in these patients corrects hypoxia and stops respiration. That's why they should be treated with low pressure O₂ (e.g. 24% or 28%, not 80% or 100% O₂).</li>
</ul>
<p>The role of carbon dioxide in the brain</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-central-chemoreceptors">The central chemoreceptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-central-chemoreceptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Found on the international surface of the module, in contact with the CSF.</li>
<li>They are stimulated by:</li>
<li>High carbon dioxide (in blood and therefore in CSF)</li>
<li>High hydrogen ions (in the CSF not that in blood)</li>
<li>Hydrogen ions in the blood cannot cross the blood brain barrier "BBB" easily.</li>
<li>Hydrogen ions in the CSF are formed from carbon dioxide as follows: Carbon dioxide crosses the BBB &amp; reacts with water in the CSF to produce carbonic acid &amp; then dissociates into bicarbonate &amp; hydrogen ions. Then hydrogen ions in the CSF stimulate the central chemoreceptors.</li>
<li>In other words, carbon dioxide stimulates the central chemoreceptors directly (by CO₂ itself) and indirectly (by H⁺).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="part-7-10-the-central-chemoreceptors">Part 7-10: The central chemoreceptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#part-7-10-the-central-chemoreceptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-8cead974.jpeg" alt="img-346.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="remember-that">Remember that:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remember-that" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>In patients with chronic hypercapnia (e.g. patients with COPD), respiration is stimulated by hypoxia not hypercapnia (because the receptors become used to the high CO₂).</li>
<li>Treatment with high pressure O₂ in these patients corrects hypoxia and stops respiration. That's why they should be treated with low pressure O₂ (e.g. 24% or 28%, not 80% or 100% O₂).</li>
</ul>
<p>The role of carbon dioxide in the brain</p>
<p>510
The case of medical physiology 17th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hypoxia-and-cyanosis">HYPOXIA AND CYANOSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypoxia-and-cyanosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hypoxia">Hypoxia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypoxia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Defined as oxygen deficiency at the level of tissues or low tissue oxygenation (Notice that hypoxemia is reduction of oxygen in the blood).</li>
<li>Classified into 4 types:</li>
<li>Hypoxic hypoxia</li>
<li>Anemic hypoxia</li>
<li>Stagnant hypoxia</li>
<li>Histotoxic hypoxia</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hypoxic-hypoxia">Hypoxic hypoxia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypoxic-hypoxia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Oxygen delivery to tissues is reduced because of low oxygenation of blood.</li>
<li>This is caused by:</li>
<li>High altitude.</li>
<li>Hypoventilation due to:</li>
<li>Lung diseases</li>
<li>Lung collapse</li>
<li>Respiratory center depression</li>
<li>Paralysis of respiratory muscles</li>
<li>Intracerebral shunts</li>
<li>It is characterized by:</li>
<li>Low PO₂ (in arterial blood)</li>
<li>Low % saturation of Hb</li>
<li>Low total oxygen content of the blood</li>
<li>All these parameters are also low in venous blood.</li>
<li>Oxygen therapy is useful in this type of hypoxia; however, when the cause of hypoxia is uncorrected short, oxygen therapy fails to increase oxygen content of the blood. This differentiates uncorrected short from other types of hypoxia.</li>
</ul>
<p>511
The case of medical physiology 17th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hypoxia-and-cyanosis">HYPOXIA AND CYANOSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypoxia-and-cyanosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hypoxia">Hypoxia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypoxia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Defined as oxygen deficiency at the level of tissues or low tissue oxygenation (Notice that hypoxemia is reduction of oxygen in the blood).</li>
<li>Classified into 4 types:</li>
<li>Hypoxic hypoxia</li>
<li>Anemic hypoxia</li>
<li>Stagnant hypoxia</li>
<li>Histotoxic hypoxia</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hypoxic-hypoxia">Hypoxic hypoxia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypoxic-hypoxia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Oxygen delivery to tissues is reduced because of low oxygenation of blood.</li>
<li>This is caused by:</li>
<li>High altitude.</li>
<li>Hypoventilation due to:</li>
<li>Lung diseases</li>
<li>Lung collapse</li>
<li>Respiratory center depression</li>
<li>Paralysis of respiratory muscles</li>
<li>Intracerebral shunts</li>
<li>It is characterized by:</li>
<li>Low PO₂ (in arterial blood)</li>
<li>Low % saturation of Hb</li>
<li>Low total oxygen content of the blood</li>
<li>All these parameters are also low in venous blood.</li>
<li>Oxygen therapy is useful in this type of hypoxia; however, when the cause of hypoxia is uncorrected short, oxygen therapy fails to increase oxygen content of the blood. This differentiates uncorrected short from other types of hypoxia.</li>
</ul>
<p>512
The case of medical physiology 17th edition</p>
<p>1/2
1/3
1/4
1/5
1/6
1/7
1/8
1/9</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="british-hypoxia">British hypoxia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#british-hypoxia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Decreased oxygen carrying capacity of the blood as a result of:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Decreased Hb (e.g. iron deficiency anemia).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Abnormal Hb (e.g. methemoglobinemia).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Unavailable Hb (e.g. carbon monoxide poisoning).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Characterized by:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Normal PO₂ in arterial blood</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Normal % saturation of Hb</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Low total oxygen content of the blood</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>These parameters are lower than normal in venous blood.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Oxygen therapy is slightly useful in this type of hypoxia because it only increases dissolved oxygen.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Heavy smoking in a closed room may cause coma due to carbon monoxide poisoning.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Treatment of carbon monoxide poisoning requires administration of oxygen within a container under high pressure "hypothetic oxygen". That's because the affinity of hemoglobin to CO is higher than oxygen by 250 times.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="histologic-hypoxia">Histologic hypoxia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#histologic-hypoxia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Inability of the tissues to take oxygen as a result of:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Poisoning of the oxidative enzymes (cyanide poisoning)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Long distance between blood &amp; cells (edema)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Characterized by:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Normal PO₂ (in arterial blood)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Normal % saturation of Hb</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Normal total oxygen content of the blood</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>All these parameters are higher than normal in venous blood.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Oxygen therapy is not useful in this type of hypoxia.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="british-hypoxia">British hypoxia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#british-hypoxia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Decreased oxygen carrying capacity of the blood as a result of:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Decreased Hb (e.g. iron deficiency anemia).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Abnormal Hb (e.g. methemoglobinemia).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Unavailable Hb (e.g. carbon monoxide poisoning)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Characterized by:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Normal PO₂ in arterial blood</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Normal % saturation of Hb</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Low total oxygen content of the blood</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>These parameters are lower than normal in venous blood.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Oxygen therapy is slightly useful in this type of hypoxia because it only increases dissolved oxygen.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Heavy smoking in a closed room may cause coma due to carbon monoxide poisoning.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Treatment of carbon monoxide poisoning requires administration of oxygen within a container under high pressure "hypothetic oxygen". That's because the affinity of hemoglobin to CO is higher than oxygen by 250 times.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="metabolic-hypoxia">Metabolic hypoxia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#metabolic-hypoxia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Inability of the tissues to take oxygen as a result of:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Poisoning of the oxidative enzymes (cyanide poisoning)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Long distance between blood &amp; cells (edema)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Characterized by:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Normal PO₂ (in arterial blood)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Normal % saturation of Hb</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Normal total oxygen content of the blood</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>All these parameters are higher than normal in venous blood.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Oxygen therapy is not useful in this type of hypoxia.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="british-hypoxia">British hypoxia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#british-hypoxia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Decreased oxygen carrying capacity of the blood as a result of:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Decreased Hb (e.g. iron deficiency anemia).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Abnormal Hb (e.g. methemoglobinemia).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Unavailable Hb (e.g. carbon monoxide poisoning).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Characterized by:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Normal PO₂ in arterial blood</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Normal % saturation of Hb</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Low total oxygen content of the blood</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>These parameters are lower than normal in venous blood.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Oxygen therapy is slightly useful in this type of hypoxia because it only increases dissolved oxygen.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Heavy smoking in a closed room may cause coma due to carbon monoxide poisoning.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Treatment of carbon monoxide poisoning requires administration of oxygen within a container under high pressure "hypothetic oxygen". That's because the affinity of hemoglobin to CO is higher than oxygen by 250 times.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="metabolic-hypoxia">Metabolic hypoxia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#metabolic-hypoxia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Inability of the tissues to take oxygen as a result of:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Poisoning of the oxidative enzymes (cyanide poisoning)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Long distance between blood &amp; cells (edema)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Characterized by:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Normal PO₂ (in arterial blood)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Normal % saturation of Hb</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Normal total oxygen content of the blood</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>All these parameters are higher than normal in venous blood.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Oxygen therapy is not useful in this type of hypoxia.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>218
The view of medical physiology of cancer</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="steepent-hypoxia">Steepent hypoxia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steepent-hypoxia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Reduced blood flow to tissues as a result of:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Obstruction of a supplying vessel (localized hypoxia)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Heart failure (generalized hypoxia)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Characterized by:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Normal or low PO₂ (in arterial blood)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Normal or low % saturation of Hb</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Normal or low total oxygen of blood</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When heart failure is mild, these parameters are low in venous blood because of high uptake of oxygen in tissues; and then corrected in the lungs to return to normal.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In moderate-severe heart failure, all these parameters are lower than normal in both venous and arterial blood, because the lungs fail to oxygenate blood back to normal.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Oxygen therapy is useful in this type of hypoxia.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="changes">CHANGES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#changes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Strain saturation of the skin &amp; mucus membranes</li>
<li>Appears when the concentration of reduced hemoglobin is more than 5g/dL. For this reason it is rarely seen in anemia and commonly seen in polycythemia.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="types-of-cyanosis">Types of cyanosis:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-cyanosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Peripheral</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Appears at the lips of the fingers</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Due to peripheral vasoconstriction in response to cold</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Central</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Appears in the skin &amp; mucus membranes</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Due to causes of hypoxic hypoxia &amp; stagnant hypoxia</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>219
The view of medical physiology of cancer</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="steepent-hypoxia">Steepent hypoxia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steepent-hypoxia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Reduced blood flow to tissues as a result of:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Obstruction of a supplying vessel (localized hypoxia)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Heart failure (generalized hypoxia)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Characterized by:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Normal or low PO₂ (in arterial blood)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Normal or low % saturation of Hb</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Normal or low total oxygen of blood</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When heart failure is mild, these parameters are low in venous blood because of high uptake of oxygen in tissues; and then corrected in the lungs to return to normal.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In moderate-severe heart failure, all these parameters are lower than normal in both venous and arterial blood, because the lungs fail to oxygenate blood back to normal.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Oxygen therapy is useful in this type of hypoxia.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="changes">CHANGES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#changes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>Strain saturation of the skin &amp; mucus membranes</li>
<li>Appears when the concentration of reduced hemoglobin is more than 5g/dL. For this reason it is rarely seen in anemia and commonly seen in polycythemia.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="types-of-cyanosis">Types of cyanosis:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-cyanosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Peripheral</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Appears at the lips of the fingers</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Due to peripheral vasoconstriction in response to cold</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="steepent-hypoxia">Steepent hypoxia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#steepent-hypoxia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="changes">CHANGES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#changes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="types-of-cyanosis">Types of cyanosis:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-cyanosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Peripheral</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Appears at the lips of the fingers</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Due to peripheral vasoconstriction in response to cold</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Central</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Appears in the skin &amp; mucus membranes</p>

<p>218
The view of medical physiology of cancer</p>
<p>124
The area of medical physiology/1st edition
125
The area of medical physiology/1st edition</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Cyanosis is extremely rare in arsenic hypoxia (arsenic patients may die when &gt; 5g/dL of Hb becomes deoxygenated). It is also extremely rare in CO poisoning (also arsenic hypoxia) because it gives reddish color. No cyanosis occurs in historical hypoxia.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Patients with methemoglobinemia may acquire a dark color that resembles cyanosis.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cyanosis is extremely rare in arsenic hypoxia (arsenic patients may die when &gt; 5g/dL of Hb becomes deoxygenated). It is also extremely rare in CO poisoning (also arsenic hypoxia) because it gives reddish color. No cyanosis occurs in historical hypoxia.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Patients with methemoglobinemia may acquire a dark color that resembles cyanosis.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cyanosis is extremely rare in arsenic hypoxia (arsenic patients may die when &gt; 5g/dL of Hb becomes deoxygenated). It is also extremely rare in CO poisoning (also arsenic hypoxia) because it gives reddish color. No cyanosis occurs in historical hypoxia.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Patients with methemoglobinemia may acquire a dark color that resembles cyanosis.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>220
The uses of medical physiology 17 (2004)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lung-function-tests">LUNG FUNCTION TESTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lung-function-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="regulatory-of-lung-function-tests">Regulatory of lung function tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#regulatory-of-lung-function-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Depending on history and examination to diagnose a respiratory problem, without objective measurement of lung function, may result in wrong diagnosis.</li>
<li>This was confirmed by many studies that recommend the use of lung function tests as objective tools for:</li>
<li>Diagnosis of respiratory diseases</li>
<li>Follow up of respiratory problems</li>
<li>Assessment of fitness for anesthesia</li>
<li>Insurance purposes</li>
<li>Clinical research</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-lung-function-tests">Types of lung function tests:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-lung-function-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Tests of mechanical properties</li>
<li>Gas diffusion</li>
<li>Blood gas interpretation</li>
<li>Puerperal testing</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tests-of-mechanical-properties">Tests of mechanical properties<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tests-of-mechanical-properties" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Lung volumes and capacities</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Spirometry &amp; the flow volume loops</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The peak expiratory flow</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Static compliance</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Airway resistance</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Respiratory muscle power</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This is a brief account about some of the devices and techniques used in lung function tests.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>221
The uses of medical physiology 17 (2004)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lung-function-tests">LUNG FUNCTION TESTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lung-function-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="importance-of-lung-function-tests">Importance of lung function tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#importance-of-lung-function-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
