<li>Depending on history and examination to diagnose a respiratory problem, without objective measurement of lung function, may result in wrong diagnosis.</li>
<li>This was confirmed by many studies that recommend the use of lung function tests as objective tools for:</li>
<li>Diagnosis of respiratory diseases</li>
<li>Follow up of respiratory problems</li>
<li>Assessment of fitness for anesthesia</li>
<li>Insurance purposes</li>
<li>Clinical research</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-lung-function-tests">Types of lung function tests:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-lung-function-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Tests of mechanical properties</li>
<li>Gas diffusion</li>
<li>Blood gas interpretation</li>
<li>Exercise testing</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tests-of-mechanical-properties">Tests of mechanical properties<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tests-of-mechanical-properties" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Lung volumes and capacities</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Spirometry &amp; the flow volume loops</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The peak expiratory flow</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Static compliance</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Airway resistance</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Respiratory muscle power</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This is a brief account about some of the devices and techniques used in lung function tests.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>222
The uses of medical physiology 17 (2004)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lung-function-tests">LUNG FUNCTION TESTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lung-function-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="regulatory-of-lung-function-tests">Regulatory of lung function tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#regulatory-of-lung-function-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Depending on history and examination to diagnose a respiratory problem, without objective measurement of lung function, may result in wrong diagnosis.</li>
<li>This was confirmed by many studies that recommend the use of lung function tests as objective tools for:</li>
<li>Diagnosis of respiratory diseases</li>
<li>Follow up of respiratory problems</li>
<li>Assessment of fitness for anesthesia</li>
<li>Insurance purposes</li>
<li>Clinical research</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-lung-function-tests">Types of lung function tests:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-lung-function-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Tests of mechanical properties</li>
<li>Gas diffusion</li>
<li>Blood gas interpretation</li>
<li>Exercise testing</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tests-of-mechanical-properties">Tests of mechanical properties<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tests-of-mechanical-properties" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Lung volumes and capacities</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Spirometry &amp; the flow volume loops</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The peak expiratory flow</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Static compliance</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Airway resistance</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Respiratory muscle power</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This is a brief account about some of the devices and techniques used in lung function tests.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>10
11</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="measurement-of-lung-volunes-and-capacities">MEASUREMENT OF LUNG VOLUNES AND CAPACITIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#measurement-of-lung-volunes-and-capacities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="schedule-from-statements">Schedule from statements<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#schedule-from-statements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Standards the tidal volume, respiratory reserve volume, expiratory reserve volume and the vital capacity (see above).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-helium-dilution-technique">The helium dilution technique<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-helium-dilution-technique" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>For measurement of many volumes and capacities especially total lung capacity, residual volume and functional residual capacity.</li>
<li>The method depends on the fact that helium does not diffuse through the respiratory membrane into the blood.</li>
<li>The subject is connected to a helium container at the end of:</li>
<li>Maximum expiration (when measuring the residual volume)</li>
<li>Total expiration (when measuring the functional residual capacity)</li>
<li>Maximum respiration (when measuring the total lung capacity)</li>
<li>The subject breathes into a bag containing a known volume and concentration of helium (V1 &amp; C1). This changes the concentration of helium to C2 and expands the volume to V1 + the volume being measured in the lung.</li>
<li>Since C1 = V1 + C2 = V2, V2 can be obtained by calculation.</li>
<li>V2 = V1 + the required volume in the lung.</li>
<li>Therefore the required volume can be obtained.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="body-plethysmography-or-body-loss">Body plethysmography (or body loss)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#body-plethysmography-or-body-loss" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>For measurement of all types of lung volumes and capacities including the total lung capacity, residual volume and functional residual capacity.</li>
<li>Depends on the equation of gases: P(A) = PV</li>
<li>The subject sits within an airtight box. He breathes through a mouthpiece that can be closed electrically (For example when it is closed at the end of normal expiration, the functional residual capacity (FRC) can be measured). Then the subject inhales against the closed shutter. His chest volume is increased while</li>
</ul>
<p>12
13</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="measurement-of-lung-volunes-and-capacities">MEASUREMENT OF LUNG VOLUNES AND CAPACITIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#measurement-of-lung-volunes-and-capacities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="schedule-from-statements">Schedule from statements<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#schedule-from-statements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Standards the tidal volume, respiratory reserve volume, expiratory reserve volume and the vital capacity (see above).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-helium-dilution-technique">The helium dilution technique<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-helium-dilution-technique" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>For measurement of many volumes and capacities especially total lung capacity, residual volume and functional residual capacity.</li>
<li>The method depends on the fact that helium does not diffuse through the respiratory membrane into the blood.</li>
<li>The subject is connected to a helium container at the end of:</li>
<li>Maximum expiration (when measuring the residual volume)</li>
<li>Total expiration (when measuring the functional residual capacity)</li>
<li>Maximum respiration (when measuring the total lung capacity)</li>
<li>The subject breathes into a bag containing a known volume and concentration of helium (V1 &amp; C1). This changes the concentration of helium to C2 and expands the volume to V1 + the volume being measured in the lung.</li>
<li>Since C1 = V1 + C2 = V2, V2 can be obtained by calculation.</li>
<li>V2 = V1 + the required volume in the lung.</li>
<li>Therefore the required volume can be obtained.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="body-plethysmography-or-body-loss">Body plethysmography (or body loss)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#body-plethysmography-or-body-loss" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>For measurement of all types of lung volumes and capacities including the total lung capacity, residual volume and functional residual capacity.</li>
<li>Depends on the equation of gases: P(A) = PV</li>
<li>The subject sits within an airtight box. He breathes through a mouthpiece that can be closed electrically (For example when it is closed at the end of normal expiration, the functional residual capacity (FRC) can be measured). Then the subject inhales against the closed shutter. His chest volume is increased while</li>
</ul>
<p>14
15</p>
<p>the volume within the box is decreased. The pressure within the box can be measured by a device connected to the box. The pressure within the lung can be measured by a device within the mouth.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>At first the change in volume within the box is calculated using the formula <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>P</mi><mi>V</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(P_{1}V_{1} = PV)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">P</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.1389em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.2222em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">P</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">P_{1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">P</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.1389em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is the pressure within the box (known), <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">V_{1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.2222em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is the volume within the box (known), <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">P</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">P</span></span></span></span></span> is the new volume within the box after inspiration (known), and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">V</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span></span></span></span></span> is the new volume within the box after inspiration (unknown). The change in volume within the box <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>V</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>X</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">= V1 - V = X</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span></span></span></span></span>; this equals the change in volume within the lung.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Then the formula <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>P</mi><mi>V</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(P_{1}V_{1} = PV)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">P</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.1389em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.2222em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">P</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> is used again to calculate the lung volume before inspiration (the FRC). P1 is the intrapulmonary pressure before inspiration (known), V1 is the FRC (unknown), P is the new intrapulmonary pressure at the end of inspiration (known), and V is the new volume within the lung at the end of inspiration (= FRC + X). X is known from the previous step; therefore the formula is solved to obtain the FRC.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 7.23: Body plethysmography</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-554cc917.jpeg" alt="img-347.jpeg"></p>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="single-breath-nitrogen-washout-test">Single breath nitrogen washout test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#single-breath-nitrogen-washout-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>For measurement of the residual volume, functional residual capacity, uneven ventilation, anatomical dead space and closing volume.</li>
<li>The subject takes full inspiration of pure oxygen (100% O₂), then he exhales slowly (not more than 0.5 L/5).</li>
<li>A nitrogen analyzer near his mouth detects nitrogen concentration in expired air.</li>
<li>Four phases appear when plotting nitrogen% against lung volume as follows:</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig.7.15</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-0db7507f.jpeg" alt="img-348.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>Phase I = pure oxygen (from the dead space)</li>
<li>Phase II = nitrogen + oxygen (mixture of dead space air + alveolar air)</li>
<li>Phase III = plateau of nitrogen (alveolar air), flat in normal people &amp; has increased slope in uneven ventilation</li>
<li>Phase IV = rapid rise in [N2] from upper alveoli (following closure of the distal airways)</li>
<li>Dead space volume = volume of phase I + mid portion of phase II</li>
<li>Phase III terminates at the closing volume</li>
<li>The closing volume is the volume within the lung when the distal airways begin to close because of less intra-mural pressure</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig.7.16</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="single-breath-nitrogen-washout-test">Single breath nitrogen washout test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#single-breath-nitrogen-washout-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>For measurement of the residual volume, functional residual capacity, uneven ventilation, anatomical dead space and closing volume.</li>
<li>The subject takes full inspiration of pure oxygen (100% O₂), then he exhales slowly (not more than 0.5 L/5).</li>
<li>A nitrogen analyzer near his mouth detects nitrogen concentration in expired air.</li>
<li>Four phases appear when plotting nitrogen% against lung volume as follows:</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig.7.15</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-49ef7a65.jpeg" alt="img-349.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>Phase I = pure oxygen (from the dead space)</li>
<li>Phase II = nitrogen + oxygen (mixture of dead space air + alveolar air)</li>
<li>Phase III = plateau of nitrogen (alveolar air), flat in normal people &amp; has increased slope in uneven ventilation</li>
<li>Phase IV = rapid rise in [N2] from upper alveoli (following closure of the distal airways)</li>
<li>Dead space volume = volume of phase I + mid portion of phase II</li>
<li>Phase III terminates at the closing volume</li>
<li>The closing volume is the volume within the lung when the distal airways begin to close because of less intra-mural pressure</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig.7.17</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="single-breath-nitrogen-washout-test">Single breath nitrogen washout test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#single-breath-nitrogen-washout-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>For measurement of the residual volume, functional residual capacity, uneven ventilation, anatomical dead space and closing volume.</li>
<li>The subject takes full inspiration of pure oxygen (100% O₂), then he exhales slowly (not more than 0.5 L/5).</li>
<li>A nitrogen analyzer near his mouth detects nitrogen concentration in expired air.</li>
<li>Four phases appear when plotting nitrogen% against lung volume as follows:</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig.7.18</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-159ebd29.jpeg" alt="img-350.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>Phase I = pure oxygen (from the dead space)</li>
<li>Phase II = nitrogen + oxygen (mixture of dead space air + alveolar air)</li>
<li>Phase III = plateau of nitrogen (alveolar air), flat in normal people &amp; has increased slope in uneven ventilation</li>
<li>Phase IV = rapid rise in [N2] from upper alveoli (following closure of the distal airways)</li>
<li>Dead space volume = volume of phase I + mid portion of phase II</li>
<li>Phase III terminates at the closing volume</li>
<li>The closing volume is the volume within the lung when the distal airways begin to close because of less intra-mural pressure</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig.7.18</p>
<ul>
<li>The rise in the slope of phase IV and to some extent phase II is due to expiration of air in the upper portions of the lung which contain higher proportion of nitrogen (i.e. less diluted by the inspired oxygen).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spirometry-by-the-vitatograph-or-the-digital-spirometer">Spirometry (by the vitatograph or the digital spirometer)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spirometry-by-the-vitatograph-or-the-digital-spirometer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>For measurement of the forced vital capacity (FVC), the forced expiratory volume in the first second (FEV₁) and the FEV₁/FVC ratio (read the section of volumes and capacities above).</li>
<li>Other parameters and tests that can be measured by spirometry include:</li>
<li>The forced expiratory volume 25-75% (FEV 25-75)</li>
<li>The forced expiratory flow at the middle of the FVC</li>
<li>Normally equals or exceeds 50% of the predicted FVC</li>
<li>Has good correlation with the FEV1 in obstructive lung diseases.</li>
<li>Has the advantage that it avoids the effort dependent first quarter of the FVC.</li>
<li>May diagnose mild airway obstruction while other spirometric parameters are normal.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bronchodilator-studies">Bronchodilator studies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bronchodilator-studies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>See reversibility below</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bronchial-prosecution-testing-challenge-tests">Bronchial Prosecution Testing (challenge tests)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bronchial-prosecution-testing-challenge-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>These tests measure the response of the airways to chemical substances known to cause broncho-constriction.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This determines the extent of airway hyper-responsiveness which is a characteristic of asthma.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>They are used to support the diagnosis of asthma when the results of spirometry are not conclusive.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The subject inhales increasing concentrations of a provocative substance, followed each time by spirometry.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A 25% fall in FEV₁ is considered as a positive test.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The rise in the slope of phase IV and to some extent phase II is due to expiration of air in the upper portions of the lung which contain higher proportion of nitrogen (i.e. less diluted by the inspired oxygen).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spirometry-by-the-vitatograph-or-the-digital-spirometer">Spirometry (by the vitatograph or the digital spirometer)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spirometry-by-the-vitatograph-or-the-digital-spirometer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>For measurement of the forced vital capacity (FVC), the forced expiratory volume in the first second (FEV₁) and the FEV₁/FVC ratio (read the section of volumes and capacities above).</li>
<li>Other parameters and tests that can be measured by spirometry include:</li>
<li>The forced expiratory volume 25-75% (FEV 25-75)</li>
<li>The forced expiratory flow at the middle of the FVC</li>
<li>Normally equals or exceeds 50% of the predicted FVC</li>
<li>Has good correlation with the FEV1 in obstructive lung diseases.</li>
<li>Has the advantage that it avoids the effort dependent first quarter of the FVC.</li>
<li>May diagnose mild airway obstruction while other spirometric parameters are normal.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bronchodilator-studies">Bronchodilator studies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bronchodilator-studies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bronchial-prosecution-testing-challenge-tests">Bronchial Prosecution Testing (challenge tests)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bronchial-prosecution-testing-challenge-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>These tests measure the response of the airways to chemical substances known to cause broncho-constriction.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This determines the extent of airway hyper-responsiveness which is a characteristic of asthma.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>They are used to support the diagnosis of asthma when the results of spirometry are not conclusive.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The subject inhales increasing concentrations of a provocative substance, followed each time by spirometry.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A 25% fall in FEV₁ is considered as a positive test.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The rise in the slope of phase IV and to some extent phase II is due to expiration of air in the upper portions of the lung which contain higher proportion of nitrogen (i.e. less diluted by the inspired oxygen).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spirometry-by-the-vitatograph-or-the-digital-spirometer">Spirometry (by the vitatograph or the digital spirometer)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spirometry-by-the-vitatograph-or-the-digital-spirometer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>For measurement of the forced vital capacity (FVC), the forced expiratory volume in the first second (FEV₁) and the FEV₁/FVC ratio (read the section of volumes and capacities above).</li>
<li>Other parameters and tests that can be measured by spirometry include:</li>
<li>The forced expiratory volume 25-75% (FEV 25-75)</li>
<li>The forced expiratory flow at the middle of the FVC</li>
<li>Normally equals or exceeds 50% of the predicted FVC</li>
<li>Has good correlation with the FEV1 in obstructive lung diseases.</li>
<li>Has the advantage that it avoids the effort dependent first quarter of the FVC.</li>
<li>May diagnose mild airway obstruction while other spirometric parameters are normal.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bronchodilator-studies">Bronchodilator studies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bronchodilator-studies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>See reversibility below</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bronchial-prosecution-testing-challenge-tests">Bronchial Prosecution Testing (challenge tests)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bronchial-prosecution-testing-challenge-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>These tests measure the response of the airways to chemical substances known to cause broncho-constriction.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This determines the extent of airway hyper-responsiveness which is a characteristic of asthma.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>They are used to support the diagnosis of asthma when the results of spirometry are not conclusive.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The subject inhales increasing concentrations of a provocative substance, followed each time by spirometry.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A 25% fall in FEV₁ is considered as a positive test.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>128</p>
<ul>
<li>Complete of provocative substances: histamine &amp; methacholine.</li>
<li>The provocative dose needed to decrease FEV1 by 20% is called P020%.</li>
<li>P020% is lower in patients with bronchial hyper-responsiveness than normal individuals.</li>
<li>Other indirect provocative tests include exercise, adenosine and non isotonic saline.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-salmonella-flow-volume-isolate">The Salmonella Flow Volume Isolate<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-salmonella-flow-volume-isolate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The flow volume loops are a plot of respiratory and expiratory flow against volume. Flow is recorded on the Y-axis while volume is recorded on the X-axis.</li>
<li>When a subject completes his forced expiration during the FVC maneuver, he immediately takes a deep inspiration to obtain a loop as appears in the following figure.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-75d677fd.jpeg" alt="img-351.jpeg">
Fig.7.20: the flow volume loop</p>
<ul>
<li>Examples of provocative substances: histamine &amp; methacholine.</li>
<li>The provocative dose needed to decrease FEV1 by 20% is called P020%.</li>
<li>P020% is lower in patients with bronchial hyper-responsiveness than normal individuals.</li>
<li>Other indirect provocative tests include exercise, adenosine and non isotonic saline.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-salmonella-flow-volume-isolate">The Salmonella Flow Volume Isolate<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-salmonella-flow-volume-isolate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The flow volume loops are a plot of respiratory and expiratory flow against volume. Flow is recorded on the Y-axis while volume is recorded on the X-axis.</li>
<li>When a subject completes his forced expiration during the FVC maneuver, he immediately takes a deep inspiration to obtain a loop as appears in the following figure.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-c993c855.jpeg" alt="img-352.jpeg">
Fig.7.21: the flow volume loop</p>
<ul>
<li>Laxatives of provocative substances: histamine &amp; methacholine.</li>
<li>The provocative dose needed to decrease FEV1 by 20% is called P020%.</li>
<li>P020% is lower in patients with bronchial hyper-responsiveness than normal individuals.</li>
<li>Other indirect provocative tests include exercise, adenosine and non isotonic saline.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-salmonella-flow-volume-isolate">The Salmonella Flow Volume Isolate<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-salmonella-flow-volume-isolate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The flow volume loops are a plot of respiratory and expiratory flow against volume. Flow is recorded on the Y-axis while volume is recorded on the X-axis.</li>
<li>When a subject completes his forced expiration during the FVC maneuver, he immediately takes a deep inspiration to obtain a loop as appears in the following figure.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-09f2c38d.jpeg" alt="img-353.jpeg">
Fig.7.21: the flow volume loop</p>
<ul>
<li>The normal expiratory portion of the flow-volume curve is characterized by a rapid rise to the peak flow rate, followed by a nearly linear fall in flow as the patient exhales towards the residual volume.</li>
<li>Changes in the contour of the loop can aid in the diagnosis of obstructive and restrictive lung diseases. However, it is not the primary diagnostic tool of these disorders.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-peak-expiratory-flow-by-the-peak-flow-meter">The peak expiratory flow (by the Peak Flow Meter)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-peak-expiratory-flow-by-the-peak-flow-meter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The PEF is the highest velocity of air flow achieved transiently during forced expiration from the total lung capacity (i.e. after max inspiration).</li>
<li>The device used (the peak flow meter) is small, portable &amp; inexpensive device. It is manufactured in many designs: Wright peak flow meter, Mini Wright peak flow meter and other designs</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-f390de66.jpeg" alt="img-354.jpeg">
Fig 7.21: The peak flow meter</p>
<ul>
<li>For interpretation of PEF readings (and other lung function test parameters), it should be compared to predicted values (reference values) that vary according to age, sex and body size (height).</li>
</ul>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<p>Normal value in an average adult male is about 600 L/min (or 10 L/s), resulting a value of 300 L/min is low since it is 50% of expected. Values more than or equal 90% of expected are normal.</p>
<p>The PEF readings are used for:</p>
<ol>
<li>Diagnosis of asthma (by variability and/or reversibility)</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>VARIABLE:</strong></p>
<p>The PEF readings are normally variable. Lowest values are obtained early in the morning (see the bronchial tone).</p>
<p>Variability more than 20% indicates asthma. It is detected by measuring and recording the PEF twice daily (morning and evening) for two weeks. [Standard Error: 0.0001]</p>
<p>The PEF variability</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-91edbf03.jpeg" alt="img-355.jpeg"></p>
<p><strong>Reversibility:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>The PEF is measured before and then 15 minutes after administration of salbutamol (bronchodilator).</li>
<li>Refinement of the PEF reading by more than 15% indicates reversible always, which is an important characteristic of asthma.</li>
</ul>
<p>Normal value in an average adult male is about 600 L/min (or 10 L/s), resulting a value of 300 L/min is low since it is 50% of expected. Values more than or equal 80% of expected are normal.</p>
<p>The PEF readings are used for:</p>
<ol>
<li>Diagnosis of asthma (by variability and/or reversibility)</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>VARIABLE:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>The PEF readings are normally variable. Lowest values are obtained early in the morning (see the bronchial tone).</li>
<li>Variability more than 20% indicates asthma. It is detected by measuring and recording the PEF twice daily (morning and evening) for two weeks. [Standard Error: 0.0001]</li>
</ul>
<p>The PEF variability</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-3e4f8de2.jpeg" alt="img-356.jpeg"></p>
<p><strong>Reversibility:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>The PEF is measured before and then 15 minutes after administration of salbutamol (bronchodilator).</li>
<li>Refinement of the PEF reading by more than 15% indicates reversible always, which is an important characteristic of asthma.</li>
</ul>
<p>Normal value in an average adult male is about 600 L/min (or 10 L/s), resulting a value of 300 L/min is low since it is 50% of expected. Values more than or equal 80% of expected are normal.</p>
<p>The PEF readings are used for:</p>
<ol>
<li>Diagnosis of asthma (by variability and/or reversibility)</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>VARIABLE:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>The PEF readings are normally variable. Lowest values are obtained early in the morning (see the bronchial tone).</li>
<li>Variability more than 20% indicates asthma. It is detected by measuring and recording the PEF twice daily (morning and evening) for two weeks. [Standard Error: 0.0001]</li>
</ul>
<p>The PEF variability</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-9f5c376d.jpeg" alt="img-357.jpeg"></p>
<p><strong>Reversibility:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>The PEF is measured before and then 15 minutes after administration of salbutamol (bronchodilator).</li>
<li>Refinement of the PEF reading by more than 15% indicates reversible always, which is an important characteristic of asthma.</li>
</ul>
<p>The text of the text (in writing)</p>
<p>224
The use of various privileges</p>
<ul>
<li>The FEV₁ is used more than the PEF for detection of reversibility because it is more reproducible. Here improvement of the FEV₁ by more than 12% (or 200 ml) indicates reversibility.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-assessment-of-severity-of-asthma">3. Assessment of severity of asthma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-assessment-of-severity-of-asthma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Reduction of PEF is less than 50% of expected indicative acute severe asthma whereas reduction to less than 33% of expected indicative life threatening asthma.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-other-uses-of-the-pef">3. Other uses of the PEF<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-other-uses-of-the-pef" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The PEF is used to guide therapeutic decisions in asthmatic patients. It is also used to measure the degree of response to therapy (i.e. follow up).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lung-compliance">Lung compliance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lung-compliance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Read about compliance above</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="airway-resistance">Airway resistance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#airway-resistance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The force needed to inflate the lungs is greater than that needed to overcome the elastic recoil alone.</li>
<li>The additional impedance is the airway resistance.</li>
<li>The airway resistance is defined as the pressure difference between the alveoli and the mouth per unit of air flow. It is generated from friction between air and mucosa.</li>
<li>Air way resistance = Mouth pressure - alveolar pressure flow of air; (Alveolar pressure is measured by the body plethysmograph).</li>
<li>Airway resistance is higher when the airflow is turbulent than when it is laminar. It is also increased by many other factors, including the factors that increase the bronchial tone.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="respiratory-muscle-power">Respiratory muscle power<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#respiratory-muscle-power" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Investigated by many tests to exclude respiratory muscle weakness. These include the following tests:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The FEV₁ is used more than the PEF for detection of reversibility because it is more reproducible. Here improvement of the FEV₁ by more than 12% (or 200 ml) indicates reversibility.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-assessment-of-severity-of-asthma">3. Assessment of severity of asthma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-assessment-of-severity-of-asthma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="airway-resistance">Airway resistance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#airway-resistance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="respiratory-muscle-power">Respiratory muscle power<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#respiratory-muscle-power" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<p>123
The cost of medical physiology 1st edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-quality">THE QUALITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-quality" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>It is a useful screening test to exclude respiratory muscle weakness. When measured in an erect and then supine posture, the difference is within 5%. This is because the abdominal viscera in supine posture exert more loads on the respiratory muscles.</li>
<li>A difference more than 25% indicates respiratory muscle weakness</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="maximum-inspiratory-pressure">Maximum inspiratory pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#maximum-inspiratory-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Measured during maximum inspiratory effort against an occluded airway at RV or FRC. Normal value varies with age and sex. Values above 80 cm H₂O excludes respiratory muscle weakness</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="maximum-inspiratory-pressure">Maximum inspiratory pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#maximum-inspiratory-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Measures the power of expiratory muscles at TLC.</li>
<li>It is less useful in predicting the ability to breathe.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="transdiaphragmatic-pressure">Transdiaphragmatic pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transdiaphragmatic-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Measures diaphragmatic function.</li>
<li>Estimated from difference between pleural and abdominal pressures (i.e. esophageal and gastric pressures).</li>
<li>Balloon catheters are used for measurement during spontaneous breathing and during phrenic nerve stimulation.</li>
</ul>
<p>124
The cost of medical physiology 1st edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-neurology">THE NEUROLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-neurology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>It is a useful screening test to exclude respiratory muscle weakness. When measured in an erect and then supine posture, the difference is within 5%. This is because the abdominal viscera in supine posture exert more loads on the respiratory muscles.</li>
<li>A difference more than 25% indicates respiratory muscle weakness</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="maximum-inspiratory-pressure">Maximum inspiratory pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#maximum-inspiratory-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Measured during maximum inspiratory effort against an occluded airway at RV or FRC. Normal value varies with age and sex. Values above 80 cm H₂O excludes respiratory muscle weakness</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="maximum-expiratory-pressure">Maximum expiratory pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#maximum-expiratory-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Measures the power of expiratory muscles at TLC.</li>
<li>It is less useful in predicting the ability to breathe.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="transdiaphragmatic-pressure">Transdiaphragmatic pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transdiaphragmatic-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Measures diaphragmatic function.</li>
<li>Estimated from difference between pleural and abdominal pressures (i.e. esophageal and gastric pressures).</li>
<li>Balloon catheters are used for measurement during spontaneous breathing and during phrenic nerve stimulation.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-surgery">THE SURGERY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-surgery" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>A difference more than 25% indicates respiratory muscle weakness</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="maximum-inspiratory-pressure">Maximum inspiratory pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#maximum-inspiratory-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Measured during maximum inspiratory effort against an occluded airway at RV or FRC. Normal value varies with age and sex. Values above 80 cm H₂O excludes respiratory muscle weakness</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="maximum-expiratory-pressure">Maximum expiratory pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#maximum-expiratory-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
