</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="transdiaphragmatic-pressure">Transdiaphragmatic pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transdiaphragmatic-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Measures diaphragmatic function.</li>
<li>Estimated from difference between pleural and abdominal pressures (i.e. esophageal and gastric pressures).</li>
<li>Balloon catheters are used for measurement during spontaneous breathing and during phrenic nerve stimulation.</li>
</ul>
<p>220
The Journal of Medical Microbiology 1997 Volume 136
The Journal of Medical Microbiology 1997 Volume 136
The Journal of Medical Microbiology 1997 Volume 136</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="gas-diffusion-studies">Gas Diffusion studies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gas-diffusion-studies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-transfer-factor">The transfer factor<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-transfer-factor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Measures the transfer of carbon monoxide (CO) across the respiratory membrane, from the alveoli to the RBCs.</li>
<li>It is measured by many techniques. However, the single breath technique is the best. Here the subject exhales maximally and then inspires the test gas (containing 0.5% CO, 10% Helium in addition to oxygen and nitrogen) to the total lung capacity.</li>
<li>After 10 s he exhales into a bag, after discarding the first 0.5 L of expired air.</li>
<li>The sample is analyzed for CO and Helium. The change in concentration of CO and Helium is used to calculate the transfer factor.</li>
<li>The transfer factor obtained by this method is a measure of the diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide (D₂₀). It is also known as (T₂₀), the transfer factor of the lung for CO.</li>
<li>It is affected by diseases that affect the thickness of the respiratory membrane and the IVQ ratio.</li>
<li>For example it is reduced in lung fibrosis, emphysema, pulmonary embolism.</li>
<li>When the D₂₀ is corrected for differences in lung volume, it is known as the transfer coefficient (Kₐₜ). (i.e. Kₐₜ = D₂₀ / alveolar volume).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="gas-diffusion-studies">Gas Diffusion studies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gas-diffusion-studies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-transfer-factor">The transfer factor<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-transfer-factor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Measures the transfer of carbon monoxide (CO) across the respiratory membrane, from the alveoli to the RBCs.</li>
<li>It is measured by many techniques. However, the single breath technique is the best. Here the subject exhales maximally and then inspires the test gas (containing 0.5% CO, 10% Helium in addition to oxygen and nitrogen) to the total lung capacity.</li>
<li>After 10 s he exhales into a bag, after discarding the first 0.5 L of expired air.</li>
<li>The sample is analyzed for CO and Helium. The change in concentration of CO and Helium is used to calculate the transfer factor.</li>
<li>The transfer factor obtained by this method is a measure of the diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide (D₂₀). It is also known as (T₂₀), the transfer factor of the lung for CO.</li>
<li>It is affected by diseases that affect the thickness of the respiratory membrane and the IVQ ratio.</li>
<li>For example it is reduced in lung fibrosis, emphysema, pulmonary embolism.</li>
<li>When the D₂₀ is corrected for differences in lung volume, it is known as the transfer coefficient (Kₐₜ). (i.e. Kₐₜ = D₂₀ / alveolar volume).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="gas-diffusion-studies">Gas Diffusion studies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gas-diffusion-studies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-transfer-factor">The transfer factor<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-transfer-factor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Measures the transfer of carbon monoxide (CO) across the respiratory membrane, from the alveoli to the RBCs.</li>
<li>It is measured by many techniques. However, the single breath technique is the best. Here the subject exhales maximally and then inspires the test gas (containing 0.5% CO, 10% Helium in addition to oxygen and nitrogen) to the total lung capacity.</li>
<li>After 10 s he exhales into a bag, after discarding the first 0.5 L of expired air.</li>
<li>The sample is analyzed for CO and Helium. The change in concentration of CO and Helium is used to calculate the transfer factor.</li>
<li>The transfer factor obtained by this method is a measure of the diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide (D₂₀). It is also known as (T₂₀), the transfer factor of the lung for CO.</li>
<li>It is affected by diseases that affect the thickness of the respiratory membrane and the IVQ ratio.</li>
<li>For example it is reduced in lung fibrosis, emphysema, pulmonary embolism.</li>
<li>When the D₂₀ is corrected for differences in lung volume, it is known as the transfer coefficient (Kₐₜ). (i.e. Kₐₜ = D₂₀ / alveolar volume).</li>
</ul>
<p>211
The rules of medical physiology 1st edition
212
The rules of medical physiology 1st edition
213
The rules of medical physiology 1st edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="blood-gas-interpretation">Blood gas interpretation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-gas-interpretation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A solution to data obtained by the tests that assess mechanical properties of the lung, diagnosis of respiratory problems may need blood gas interpretation.</p>
<ul>
<li>This requires information about:</li>
<li>blood oxygenation (obtained by arterial blood gas analysis)</li>
<li>Oxygen saturation of hemoglobin (see below)</li>
<li>VO distribution (read about VO2 ratio above)</li>
<li>Acid base status (read volume 2)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pulse-oximetry">Pulse oximetry:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pulse-oximetry" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The pulse oximeter probes, placed on fingers or ear lobes are used widely to assess oxygen saturation of Hb (SpO₂).</p>
<ul>
<li>Light originating from the oximeter probe is absorbed by Hb at a degree proportional to its level of oxygenation. This is calculated by a processor to obtain the degree of saturation.</li>
<li>Normal readings are higher than 95%. Readings lower than 88% raises the suspicion of hypoxemia and indicates the need for arterial blood gas analysis (ABG).</li>
<li>There are certain conditions that give false estimation of the oxygen saturation when using the pulse oximeter. For example Carboxyhemoglobin and Methemoglobin give overestimation of O₂ saturation (higher readings) while fingernail polish and motion artifacts underestimate the O₂ saturation (lower readings).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="blood-gas-interpretation">Blood gas interpretation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-gas-interpretation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A solution to data obtained by the tests that assess mechanical properties of the lung, diagnosis of respiratory problems may need blood gas interpretation.</p>
<ul>
<li>This requires information about:</li>
<li>Blood oxygenation (obtained by arterial blood gas analysis)</li>
<li>Oxygen saturation of hemoglobin (see below)</li>
<li>VO distribution (read about VO2 ratio above)</li>
<li>Acid base status (read volume 2)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pulse-oximetry">Pulse oximetry:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pulse-oximetry" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

For example Carboxyhemoglobin and Methemoglobin give overestimation of O₂ saturation (higher readings) while fingernail polish and motion artifacts underestimate the O₂ saturation (lower readings).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="blood-gas-interpretation">Blood gas interpretation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-gas-interpretation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>Blood oxygenation (obtained by arterial blood gas analysis)</li>
<li>Oxygen saturation of hemoglobin (see below)</li>
<li>VO distribution (read about VO2 ratio above)</li>
<li>Acid base status (read volume 2)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pulse-oximetry">Pulse oximetry:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pulse-oximetry" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The pulse oximeter probes, placed on fingers or ear lobes are used widely to assess oxygen saturation of Hb (SpO₂).</p>
<ul>
<li>Light originating from the oximeter probe is absorbed by Hb at a degree proportional to its level of oxygenation. This is calculated by a processor to obtain the degree of saturation.</li>
<li>Normal readings are higher than 95%. Readings lower than 88% raises the suspicion of hypoxemia and indicates the need for arterial blood gas analysis (ABG).</li>
<li>There are certain conditions that give false estimation of the oxygen saturation when using the pulse oximeter. For example Carboxyhemoglobin and Methemoglobin give overestimation of O₂ saturation (higher readings) while fingernail polish and motion artifacts underestimate the O₂ saturation (lower readings).</li>
</ul>
<p>222
The costs of medical processing - 2nd edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="exercise-testing">Exercise testing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#exercise-testing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The cardiopulmonary exercise test is used to assess dyspnea that is explained by other lung function tests. It is also used to assess fitness for anesthesia, disability and response to therapy.</li>
<li>The test assesses the responses of the respiratory, cardiovascular and muscular systems to increasing workload offered by a bicycle ergometer or treadmill.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="exercise-testing">Exercise testing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#exercise-testing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The cardiopulmonary exercise test is used to assess dyspnea that is explained by other lung function tests. It is also used to assess fitness for anesthesia, disability and response to therapy.</li>
<li>The test assesses the responses of the respiratory, cardiovascular and muscular systems to increasing workload offered by a bicycle ergometer or treadmill.</li>
</ul>

<p>1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="section-10-self-association-in-basic-or-fine">SECTION 10: SELF-ASSOCIATION IN (BASIC OR FINE)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-10-self-association-in-basic-or-fine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-reject-of-normal-imagination">1. Reject of normal imagination:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-reject-of-normal-imagination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Apeal/abdominal pressure equals -6 mmHg</li>
<li>Eye/abdominal pressure equals zero when the glottis is open</li>
<li>The transverse diameter of the chest is increased by about 3 cm</li>
<li>The accessory muscles of inspiration are contracted</li>
<li>The abdominal muscles are relaxed</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-surfactant">2. Surfactant:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-surfactant" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A 4-phenanthrin</li>
<li>A produced in the fetus early in pregnancy</li>
<li>Prevent development of pulmonary edema</li>
<li>Add to increase surface tension of fluid in the alveoli</li>
<li>Deficiency causes hypoventilation</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-carbon-dioxide-co2">3. Carbon dioxide (CO2):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-carbon-dioxide-co2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Partial pressure in arterial blood is about 40 mmHg</li>
<li>Partial pressure in arterial blood is about 100 mmHg</li>
<li>A low soluble then oxygen or body fluids</li>
<li>A rat served in hemoglobin</li>
<li>A rat the primary stimulus for hyperventilation in metabolic acidosis</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-hypoxic-hypoxia-is-caused-by">4. Hypoxic hypoxia is caused by:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-hypoxic-hypoxia-is-caused-by" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Heart failure</li>
<li>Cyanide poisoning</li>
<li>Carbon monoxide poisoning</li>
<li>Lung fibrosis</li>
<li>Anemia</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-bronchodilatation-is-caused-by">5. <ul>
<li>Embolism</li>

<li>Sustained P</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-oxygen-hemoglobin-dissociation-curve-is-shifted-to-the-right-by">6. Oxygen - Hemoglobin Dissociation curve is shifted to the right by:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-oxygen-hemoglobin-dissociation-curve-is-shifted-to-the-right-by" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Low CO2</li>
<li>Low 2.5 (UPI)</li>
<li>Low temperature</li>
<li>Low pH</li>
<li>Low metabolism</li>
</ul>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="section-12-self-association-in-basic-or-fine">SECTION 12: SELF-ASSOCIATION IN (BASIC OR FINE)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-12-self-association-in-basic-or-fine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-carbon-dioxide-co2">3. Carbon dioxide (CO2):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-carbon-dioxide-co2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Partial pressure in arterial blood is about 40 mmHg</li>
<li>Partial pressure in arterial blood is about 100 mmHg</li>
<li>A low soluble then oxygen or body fluids</li>
<li>A rat served in hemoglobin</li>
<li>A rat the primary stimulus for hyperventilation in metabolic acidosis</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-hypoxic-hypoxia-is-caused-by">4. Hypoxic hypoxia is caused by:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-hypoxic-hypoxia-is-caused-by" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Heart failure</li>
<li>Cyanide poisoning</li>
<li>Carbon monoxide poisoning</li>
<li>Lung fibrosis</li>
<li>Anemia</li>
</ul>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-oxygen-hemoglobin-dissociation-curve-is-shifted-to-the-right-by">6. Oxygen - Hemoglobin Dissociation curve is shifted to the right by:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-oxygen-hemoglobin-dissociation-curve-is-shifted-to-the-right-by" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-acute-hyperventilation-increases">7. Acute hyperventilation increases:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-acute-hyperventilation-increases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>PCO</li>
<li>PCO2</li>
<li>pH</li>
<li>Hemoglobin concentration</li>
<li>Blood viscosity</li>

<p>1</p>
<p>334
The case of medical job (part 2) - 2 pages</p>
<ol start="8">
<li>The main form of carbon dioxide transport in the blood is:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Bound to hemoglobin</li>
<li>Bound to plasma protein</li>
<li>Dissolved in plasma</li>
<li>Bicarbonate</li>
<li>As carbonic acid</li>
</ul>
<ol start="9">
<li>Volume of air that can be expired by maximum expiration following maximum inspiration is the:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Tidal volume</li>
<li>Inspiratory reserve volume</li>
<li>Vital capacity</li>
<li>Expiratory reserve volume</li>
<li>Residual volume</li>
</ul>
<ol start="10">
<li>Gas exchange in the lungs is increased by:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Increasing thickness of the respiratory membrane</li>
<li>Increasing surface area of the respiratory membrane</li>
<li>Increasing the pressure gradient of a gas between the two sides of the respiratory membrane</li>
<li>decreasing the diffusion coefficient of the gas</li>
<li>Hypoventilation</li>
</ul>
<ol start="11">
<li>Gas exchange in the lungs is increased by:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Increasing thickness of the respiratory membrane</li>
<li>Decreasing surface area of the respiratory membrane</li>
<li>Increasing the pressure gradient across the respiratory membrane</li>
<li>Decreasing the diffusion coefficient of the gas</li>
<li>Hypoventilation</li>
</ul>
<ol start="12">
<li>The diffusing capacity of the respiratory membrane:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Is not affected by thickness of the respiratory membrane</li>
<li>Increase in exercise</li>
<li>Is normal in exercise</li>
<li>Is bed measured using helium</li>
<li>Is bed measured using carbon dioxide</li>
</ul>
<ol start="13">
<li>The partial pressure of oxygen in venous blood is:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>About 60 mmHg</li>
<li>Normal in stagnant hypoxia</li>
<li>Higher than normal in infectious hypoxia</li>
<li>The same in all cases in the body</li>
<li>Does accurate information about gas exchange in the lung</li>
</ul>
<ol start="14">
<li>The functional residual capacity is best measured by:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Helium double method</li>
<li>Methanotography</li>
<li>Challenge test</li>
<li>Spirometry</li>
<li>Mitogen washout method</li>
</ul>

c. Is caused by low pH
d. Induced by high O₂
e. Does not occur without a effect</p>

d. Dead space ventilation is 1.5 L/min

</li>
</ol>
<table><thead><tr><th>Condition</th><th>1</th><th>2</th><th>3</th><th>4</th><th>5</th><th>6</th><th>7</th><th>8</th><th>9</th><th>10</th><th>11</th><th>12</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Arthritis</td><td>a</td><td>c</td><td>a</td><td>d</td><td>a</td><td>c</td><td>b</td><td>c</td><td>c</td><td>c</td><td>c</td><td>b</td></tr><tr><td>Cerebrum</td><td>13</td><td>14</td><td>15</td><td>16</td><td>17</td><td>18</td><td>19</td><td>20</td><td>21</td><td>22</td><td>23</td><td>24</td></tr><tr><td>Kidney</td><td>c</td><td>b</td><td>c</td><td>b</td><td>a</td><td>d</td><td>e</td><td>c</td><td>c</td><td>b</td><td>c</td><td>b</td></tr><tr><td>Ovary</td><td>20</td><td>26</td><td>31</td><td>28</td><td>29</td><td>30</td><td>31</td><td>40</td><td>55</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Stomach</td><td>b</td><td>d</td><td>b</td><td>a</td><td>a</td><td>c</td><td>c</td><td>c</td><td>a</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="34">
<li>
<p>Which of the following is not expected in a patient with anemia:
a. Normal PAO₃
b. Normal PAO₃
c. Normal % of Hb saturation with oxygen
d. Low oxygen carrying capacity of blood
e. High PED of O₂-Hb dissociation curve</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>At an altitude where the atmospheric pressure 600 mm Hg, the partial pressure of O₂ in dry air is approximately:
a. 120 mmHg
b. 120 mmHg
c. 130 mmHg
d. 130 mmHg
e. 150 mmHg</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Carbon dioxide (CO₂):
a. Partial pressure in nervous blood is about 40 mmHg
b. Partial pressure in arterial blood is about 100 mmHg
c. It more soluble than oxygen in body fluids
d. It cannot mainly in hemoglobin
e. Diffuses through biological membranes less easily than oxygen</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Ventilation is most sensitive to changes in:
a. pH of arterial blood
b. PEE in arterial blood
c. Oxygen concentration in arterial blood
d. PCO₂ in arterial blood
e. Norepinephrine</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Regarding the normal oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve, which of the following relations is not correct:
a. PEE 40 - percent saturation 70
b. PEE 50 - percent saturation 80
c. PEE 60 - percent saturation 90
d. PEE 50 - percent saturation 60
e. PEE 100 - percent saturation 120</p>
</li>
</ol>
<table><thead><tr><th>Condition</th><th>1</th><th>2</th><th>3</th><th>4</th><th>5</th><th>6</th><th>7</th><th>8</th><th>9</th><th>10</th><th>11</th><th>12</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Kidney</td><td>a</td><td>c</td><td>a</td><td>a</td><td>c</td><td>a</td><td>b</td><td>a</td><td>a</td><td>c</td><td>c</td><td>b</td></tr><tr><td>Ovary</td><td>20</td><td>26</td><td>31</td><td>28</td><td>29</td><td>30</td><td>31</td><td>40</td><td>55</td><td>56</td><td>57</td><td>58</td></tr><tr><td>Stomach</td><td>b</td><td>d</td><td>b</td><td>a</td><td>a</td><td>c</td><td>c</td><td>c</td><td>c</td><td>b</td><td>c</td><td>b</td></tr><tr><td>Ovary</td><td>20</td><td>26</td><td>31</td><td>28</td><td>29</td><td>30</td><td>31</td><td>40</td><td>55</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Stomach</td><td>b</td><td>d</td><td>b</td><td>a</td><td>a</td><td>c</td><td>c</td><td>c</td><td>a</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>

b. Normal PAO₃

d. Low oxygen carrying capacity of blood

d. 130 mmHg

<p>CHAPTER 8</p>
<p>THE GASTRONITESTINAL TRACT (GIT)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Also known as the digestive tract, alimentary tract, or gut.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions-of-the-gastro-intestinal-tract-git">Functions of the Gastro-intestinal tract (GIT):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-the-gastro-intestinal-tract-git" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Breaks down complex food particles into simpler ones (Digestion).</li>
<li>Transports products of digestion to the blood stream (Absorption).</li>
<li>Expels the remaining waste to outside of the body (Excretion).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="structure-of-the-git">Structure of the GIT:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure-of-the-git" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Organs:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Upper GIT (mouth, pharynx, esophagus and stomach)</li>
<li>Lower GIT (small intestine, large intestine and anus)</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Associated glands:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Salivary glands 2- Pancreas 3- Liver</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-83aae470.jpeg" alt="img-358.jpeg">
Fig 8.1: Structure of the GIT</p>
<p>CHAPTER 8</p>
<p>THE GASTRONITESTINAL TRACT (GIT)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Also known as the digestive tract, alimentary tract, or gut.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions-of-the-gastro-intestinal-tract-git">Functions of the Gastro-intestinal tract (GIT):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-the-gastro-intestinal-tract-git" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Breaks down complex food particles into simpler ones (Digestion).</li>
<li>Transports products of digestion to the blood stream (Absorption).</li>
<li>Expels the remaining waste to outside of the body (Excretion).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="structure-of-the-git">Structure of the GIT:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure-of-the-git" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter-8">CHAPTER 8<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-8" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-gastronitestinal-tract-git">THE GASTRONITESTINAL TRACT (GIT)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-gastronitestinal-tract-git" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Also known as the digestive tract, alimentary tract, or gut.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions-of-the-gastro-intestinal-tract-git">Functions of the Gastro-intestinal tract (GIT):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-the-gastro-intestinal-tract-git" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Breaks down complex food particles into simpler ones (Digestion).</li>
<li>Transports products of digestion to the blood stream (Absorption).</li>
<li>Expels the remaining waste to outside of the body (Excretion).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="structure-of-the-git">Structure of the GIT:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure-of-the-git" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Organs:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Upper GIT (mouth, pharynx, esophagus and stomach)</li>
<li>Lower GIT (small intestine, large intestine and anus)</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Associated glands:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Salivary glands 2- Pancreas 3- Liver</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-b3273767.jpeg" alt="img-360.jpeg">
Fig 8.1: Structure of the GIT</p>
<p>Chapter 1</p>
<p>128
The view of medical psychology of science</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="histories-of-the-git">Histories of the GIT:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#histories-of-the-git" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>the wall of the GIT consists of the following layers:</p>
<ol>
<li>Glucose (epithelium, lamina propria &amp; muscularis mucosae)</li>
<li>Sulimucose</li>
<li>Gluccular layer, (inner circular &amp; outer longitudinal)</li>
<li>Serose (mesohelium)</li>
</ol>
<p>Fig 8.2: Histology of the GIT</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-d93bc7e9.jpeg" alt="img-361.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="control-of-the-git">Control of the GIT:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-the-git" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Neural control by:</li>
<li>Putamen nerves (Autonomic nervous system)</li>
<li>Intrinsic nerves (Enteric nervous system)</li>
<li>Hormonal control by:</li>
<li>Peptide hormones released by endocrine cells scattered throughout the GIT.</li>
<li>These hormones include gastrin, secretin, cholecystokinin-penicerosymin</li>
<li>"CCK-PZ", vasoactive intestinal polypeptide "VIP", somatostatin and other hormones.</li>
</ul>
<p>129
The view of medical psychology of science</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="histories-of-the-git">Histories of the GIT:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#histories-of-the-git" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>the wall of the GIT consists of the following layers:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Glucose (epithelium, lamina propria &amp; muscularis mucosae)</li>
<li>Sulimucose</li>
<li>Gluccular layer, (inner circular &amp; outer longitudinal)</li>
<li>Serose (mesohelium)</li>
</ol>
<p>Fig 8.3: Histology of the GIT</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-97d922eb.jpeg" alt="img-362.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="control-of-the-git">Control of the GIT:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-the-git" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Neural control by:</li>
<li>External nerves (Autonomic nervous system)</li>
<li>Intrinsic nerves (Enteric nervous system)</li>
<li>Hormonal control by:</li>
<li>Peptide hormones released by endocrine cells scattered throughout the GIT.</li>
<li>These hormones include gastrin, secretin, cholecystokinin-penicerosymin</li>
<li>"CCK-PZ", vasoactive intestinal polypeptide "VIP", somatostatin and other hormones.</li>
</ul>
<p>129
The view of medical psychology of science</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="histories-of-the-git">Histories of the GIT:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#histories-of-the-git" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>the wall of the GIT consists of the following layers:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Glucose (epithelium, lamina propria &amp; muscularis mucosae)</li>
<li>Sulimucose</li>
<li>Gluccular layer, (inner circular &amp; outer longitudinal)</li>
<li>Serose (mesohelium)</li>
</ol>
<p>Fig 8.4: Histology of the GIT</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-32820de5.jpeg" alt="img-363.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="control-of-the-git">Control of the GIT:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-the-git" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Neural control by:</li>
<li>External nerves (Autonomic nervous system)</li>
<li>Intrinsic nerves (Enteric nervous system)</li>
<li>Hormonal control by:</li>
<li>Peptide hormones released by endocrine cells scattered throughout the GIT.</li>
<li>These hormones include gastrin, secretin, cholecystokinin-penicerosymin</li>
<li>"CCK-PZ", vasoactive intestinal polypeptide "VIP", somatostatin and other hormones.</li>
</ul>
<p>130
The view of medical psychology of science</p>
<p>340
The Journal of Medical Physiology 17 (2004)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-autonomic-nervous-system-sympathetic-and-parasympathetic">The autonomic nervous system: "Sympathetic and parasympathetic"<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-autonomic-nervous-system-sympathetic-and-parasympathetic" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The sympathetic:</li>
<li>inhibits CIT motility by relaxing walls &amp; contracting sphincters.</li>
<li>inhibits CIT secretion.</li>
<li>The parasympathetic:</li>
<li>Stimulates CIT motility by contracting walls &amp; relaxing sphincters.</li>
<li>Stimulates CIT secretion.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-enteric-nervous-system">The enteric nervous system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-enteric-nervous-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>It is a part of the nervous system consisting of large number of neurons that form networks within the wall of the CIT.</li>
<li>The neurons are distributed into two plecuses (see fig 8.2).</li>
<li>The submucous plexus: Also known as Macerator's plexus. It is found in the submucous layer to control CIT secretion.</li>
<li>The myenteric plexus: Also known as Auerbach's plexus. It is found between the 2 muscular layers to control CIT motility.</li>
</ul>
<p>Remember that, The enteric nervous system (ENS) is connected with the autonomic nervous system. Through this connection, the parasympathetic increases motility &amp; secretion whereas the sympathetic decreases motility &amp; secretion.</p>
<ul>
<li>This connection is not essential for the function of the enteric nervous system because it can act independently after cutting the sympathetic and the parasympathetic innervations.</li>
<li>That is why the enteric nervous system may be regarded as a second brain.</li>
<li>The neurotransmitters released by the neurons of the ENS include vasoactive intestinal polypeptide "VP", substance P, nitric oxide "NO" and others.</li>
</ul>
<p>341
The Journal of Medical Physiology 17 (2004)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-autonomic-nervous-system-sympathetic-and-parasympathetic">The autonomic nervous system: "Sympathetic and parasympathetic"<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-autonomic-nervous-system-sympathetic-and-parasympathetic" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The sympathetic:</li>
<li>inhibits CIT motility by relaxing walls &amp; contracting sphincters.</li>
<li>inhibits CIT secretion.</li>
<li>The parasympathetic:</li>
<li>Stimulates CIT motility by contracting walls &amp; relaxing sphincters.</li>
<li>Stimulates CIT secretion.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-enteric-nervous-system">The enteric nervous system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-enteric-nervous-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>It is a part of the nervous system consisting of large number of neurons that form networks within the wall of the CIT.</li>
<li>The neurons are distributed into two plecuses (see fig 8.2).</li>
<li>The submucous plexus: Also known as Macerator's plexus. It is found in the submucous layer to control CIT secretion.</li>
<li>The myenteric plexus: Also known as Auerbach's plexus. It is found between the 2 muscular layers to control CIT motility.</li>
</ul>
<p>Remember that, The enteric nervous system (ENS) is connected with the autonomic nervous system. Through this connection, the parasympathetic increases motility &amp; secretion whereas the sympathetic decreases motility &amp; secretion.</p>
<ul>
<li>This connection is not essential for the function of the enteric nervous system because it can act independently after cutting the sympathetic and the parasympathetic innervations.</li>
<li>That is why the enteric nervous system may be regarded as a second brain.</li>
<li>The neurotransmitters released by the neurons of the ENS include vasoactive intestinal polypeptide "VP", substance P, nitric oxide "NO" and others.</li>
</ul>

The Journal of Medical Physiology 17 (2004)</p>

<p>^{}[]</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-dfd795aa.jpeg" alt="img-364.jpeg">
Fig 8.3: Major salivary glands</p>
<ul>
<li>Each salivary gland is an exocrine gland consisting of acini and ducts.</li>
<li>The acini have one or two types of cells: Serous cells (secrete water, electrolytes &amp; enzymes) &amp; mucus cells (secrete mucus).</li>
<li>Each acinus may be purely serous, purely mucus or mixed, for example:</li>
<li>Acini of the parotid glands are purely serous</li>
<li>Acini of the submandibular glands are mixed</li>
<li>Acini of the sublingual glands are mixed but mainly mucus</li>
<li>Acini of the minute glands in the mouth &amp; pharynx are purely mucus except Flew's glands in the circumvallate papillae of the tongue, which secrete serous fluid.</li>
<li>The ducts are intercalated ducts that join to form striated ducts and then a main secretory duct that opens in the mouth.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-79f60a25.jpeg" alt="img-365.jpeg">
Fig 8.4: Acini and ducts of an exocrine gland</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-43a93739.jpeg" alt="img-366.jpeg">
Fig 8.5: Major salivary glands</p>
<ul>
<li>Each salivary gland is an exocrine gland consisting of acini and ducts.</li>
<li>The acini have one or two types of cells: Serous cells (secrete water, electrolytes &amp; enzymes) &amp; mucus cells (secrete mucus).</li>
<li>Each acinus may be purely serous, purely mucus or mixed, for example:</li>
<li>Acini of the parotid glands are purely serous</li>
<li>Acini of the submandibular glands are mixed</li>
<li>Acini of the sublingual glands are mixed but mainly mucus</li>
<li>Acini of the minute glands in the mouth &amp; pharynx are purely mucus except Klebs's glands in the circumvallate papillae of the tongue, which secrete serous fluid.</li>
<li>The ducts are intercalated ducts that join to form striated ducts and then a main secretory duct that opens in the mouth.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-2f71e947.jpeg" alt="img-367.jpeg">
Fig 8.6: Acini and ducts of an exocrine gland</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-21ae1c7a.jpeg" alt="img-368.jpeg">
Fig 8.3: Major salivary glands</p>
<ul>
<li>Each salivary gland is an exocrine gland consisting of acini and ducts.</li>
<li>The acini have one or two types of cells: Serous cells (secrete water, electrolytes &amp; enzymes) &amp; mucus cells (secrete mucus).</li>
<li>Each acinus may be purely serous, purely mucus or mixed, for example:</li>
<li>Acini of the parotid glands are purely serous</li>
<li>Acini of the submandibular glands are mixed</li>
<li>Acini of the sublingual glands are mixed but mainly mucus</li>
<li>Acini of the minute glands in the mouth &amp; pharynx are purely mucus except Llover's glands in the circumvallate papillae of the tongue, which secrete serous fluid.</li>
<li>The ducts are intercalated ducts that join to form striated ducts and then a main secretory duct that opens in the mouth.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-5596f095.jpeg" alt="img-369.jpeg">
Fig 8.4: Acini and ducts of an exocrine gland</p>
<p>10
The sum of method (A) ratings: 10² values</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="standardization-of-saliva">Standardization of saliva:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#standardization-of-saliva" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Assume: 0.5 - 1.5 L/day.</li>
<li>(Semideity: hypothesis (due to aldosterone action, see below)</li>
<li>pH: ranges between 6 &amp; 7. It becomes alkaline (class up to 8) in high rates of secretion.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="contents">Contents:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#contents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Water</li>
<li>Isorganic substances</li>
<li>Organic substances</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>The inorganic substances are electrolytes (Na⁺, K⁺, Cl⁻, HCO₃⁻ ...)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The organic substances include the following:</p>
</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Mucus (glycoprotein, lubricates food &amp; protects the oral mucosa)</li>
<li>Immunoglobulins (IgA)</li>
<li>Proline rich proteins (protect tooth enamel)</li>
<li>Lactoferrin (bacteriostatic substance, binds iron)</li>
<li>Lysozyme (bactericidal substance)</li>
<li>Carbonic anhydrase enzyme</li>
<li>Digestive enzymes:</li>
<li>α-amylase (phylline) for digestion of starch</li>
<li>Lingual lipase from Ebrer's glands of the tongue, for digestion of lipids</li>
<li>ABO blood group antigens (antigen H +/- A &amp;/or B)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rejection-that">Rejection that:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rejection-that" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The ABO blood group antigens are present in saliva of about 80% of individuals who are known as "secretion", whereas those who do not secrete these antigens in saliva are known as "non-secretion."</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is worth noting that the non-secretion have higher incidence of oral disease, which ulcer &amp; diabetes than the secretors.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>11
The sum of method (A) ratings: 10² values</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="standardization-of-saliva">Standardization of saliva:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#standardization-of-saliva" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Assume: 0.5 - 1.5 L/day.</li>
<li>(Semideity: hypothesis (due to aldosterone action, see below)</li>
<li>pH: ranges between 6 &amp; 7. It becomes alkaline (class up to 8) in high rates of secretion.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="contents">Contents:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#contents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Water</li>
<li>Inorganic substances</li>
<li>Organic substances</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>The inorganic substances are electrolytes (Na⁺, K⁺, Cl⁻, HCO₃⁻ ...)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The organic substances include the following:</p>
</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Mucus (glycoprotein, lubricates food &amp; protects the oral mucosa)</li>
<li>Immunoglobulins (IgA)</li>
<li>Proline rich proteins (protect tooth enamel)</li>
<li>Lactoferrin (bacteriostatic substance, binds iron)</li>
<li>Lysozyme (bactericidal substance)</li>
<li>Carbonic anhydrase enzyme</li>
<li>Digestive enzymes:</li>
<li>α-amylase (phylline) for digestion of starch</li>
<li>Lingual lipase from Ebrer's glands of the tongue; for digestion of lipids</li>
<li>ABO blood group antigens (antigen H +/- A &amp;/or B)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rejection-that">Rejection that:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rejection-that" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The ABO blood group antigens are present in saliva of about 80% of individuals who are known as "secretion", whereas those who do not secrete these antigens in saliva are known as "non-secretion."</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is worth noting that the non-secretion have higher incidence of oral disease, which ulcer &amp; diabetes than the secretors.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>12
The sum of method (A) ratings: 10² values</p>
<p>Changes in toxic composition of saliva:</p>
<ul>
<li>Saliva is secreted by either cells as isotonic fluid. In the ductile, Na⁺ and Cl⁻ are absorbed whereas K⁺ and HCO₃⁻ are secreted.</li>
<li>Adipoketone stimulates Na⁺ absorption and K⁺ secretion; however, Na⁺ is not followed by water that is why saliva becomes hypotonic.</li>
<li>When the rate of salivary flow through the ducts is very high, there is less time for this exchange to occur, that's why concentrations of Na⁺ &amp; Cl⁻ are increased (Na⁺ &amp; Cl⁻ concentrations in saliva are flow dependent). However, the concentrations of potassium and bicarbonate vary greatly in different species.</li>
<li>The pH of saliva is also flow dependent (the sodium &amp; chloride). It is high in rapid rates of secretion and low in slow rates of secretion (it is thought that as the rate of saliva production increases, more bicarbonate ion is produced as a by-product of cell metabolism).</li>
</ul>
<p>Functions of saliva:</p>
<ol>
<li>Protection against microorganisms by mucus, lysozyme, lactoferrin and IgA antibodies</li>
<li>Digestion of carbohydrates by α amylase and lipids by lingual lipase</li>
<li>Lubrication to facilitate swallowing, speech and taste</li>
<li>Buffer to neutralize gastric acid during vomiting and to relieve heartburn</li>
<li>Excretion of certain substances like mercury, iodate and lead</li>
</ol>
<p>Control of saliva</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Exclusively neural (i.e. there is no hormonal control), by two reflexes:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Conditioned reflex</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Non-conditioned reflex</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The conditioned reflex "or response":</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Here, sight, smell or even thoughts about appetizing food stimulate salivary secretion.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The term "conditioned response" indicates a reaction that has been acquired by learning. It was first described by Pavlov in the 1890s.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>244</p>
<p>Changes in toxic composition of saliva:</p>
<ul>
<li>Saliva is secreted by either cells as isotonic fluid. In the ductile, Na⁺ and Cl⁻ are absorbed whereas K⁺ and HCO₃⁻ are secreted.</li>
<li>Adipoketone stimulates Na⁺ absorption and K⁺ secretion; however, Na⁺ is not followed by water that is why saliva becomes hypotonic.</li>
<li>When the rate of salivary flow through the ducts is very high, there is less time for this exchange to occur, that's why concentrations of Na⁺ &amp; Cl⁻ are increased (Na⁺ &amp; Cl⁻ concentrations in saliva are flow dependent). However, the concentrations of potassium and bicarbonate vary greatly in different species.</li>
<li>The pH of saliva is also flow dependent (the sodium &amp; chloride). It is high in rapid rates of secretion and low in slow rates of secretion (it is thought that as the rate of saliva production increases, more bicarbonate ion is produced as a by-product of cell metabolism).</li>
</ul>
<p>Functions of saliva:</p>
<ol>
<li>Protection against microorganisms by mucus, lysozyme, lactoferrin and IgA antibodies</li>
<li>Digestion of carbohydrates by α amylase and lipids by lingual lipase</li>
<li>Lubrication to facilitate swallowing, speech and taste</li>
<li>Buffer to neutralize gastric acid during vomiting and to relieve heartburn</li>
<li>Excretion of certain substances like mercury, iodate and lead</li>
</ol>
<p>Control of saliva</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Exclusively neural (i.e. there is no hormonal control), by two reflexes:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Conditioned reflex</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Non-conditioned reflex</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The conditioned reflex "or response":</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Here, sight, smell or even thoughts about appetizing food stimulate salivary secretion.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The term "conditioned response" indicates a reaction that has been acquired by learning. It was first described by Pavlov in the 1890s.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>245</p>
<p>Changes in toxic composition of saliva:</p>
<ul>
<li>Saliva is secreted by either cells as isotonic fluid. In the ductile, Na⁺ and Cl⁻ are absorbed whereas K⁺ and HCO₃⁻ are secreted.</li>
<li>Adipoketone stimulates Na⁺ absorption and K⁺ secretion; however, Na⁺ is not followed by water that is why saliva becomes hypotonic.</li>
<li>When the rate of salivary flow through the ducts is very high, there is less time for this exchange to occur, that's why concentrations of Na⁺ &amp; Cl⁻ are increased (Na⁺ &amp; Cl⁻ concentrations in saliva are flow dependent). However, the concentrations of potassium and bicarbonate vary greatly in different species.</li>
<li>The pH of saliva is also flow dependent (the sodium &amp; chloride). It is high in rapid rates of secretion and low in slow rates of secretion (it is thought that as the rate of saliva production increases, more bicarbonate ion is produced as a by-product of cell metabolism).</li>
</ul>
<p>Functions of saliva:</p>
<ol>
<li>Protection against microorganisms by mucus, lysozyme, lactoferrin and IgA antibodies</li>
<li>Digestion of carbohydrates by α amylase and lipids by lingual lipase</li>
<li>Lubrication to facilitate swallowing, speech and taste</li>
<li>Buffer to neutralize gastric acid during vomiting and to relieve heartburn</li>
<li>Excretion of certain substances like mercury, iodate and lead</li>
</ol>
<p>Control of saliva</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Exclusively neural (i.e. there is no hormonal control), by two reflexes:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Conditioned reflex</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Non-conditioned reflex</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The conditioned reflex "or response":</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Here, sight, smell or even thoughts about appetizing food stimulate salivary secretion.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The term "conditioned response" indicates a reaction that has been acquired by learning. It was first described by Pavlov in the 1890s.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>246</p>
<p>The term of medical physiology of saliva</p>
<p>10
The next of medical physiology 17 volume</p>
<p>Is the femoral experiment, Pandox used a bed to call a dog to the meat and, after a few repetitions, the dog learned that the bed sound is followed by food, so it started to activate in response to the bed sound.</p>
<p>The excitatory impulses that travel from the salivary nuclei in the medulla to supply the salivary glands are carried through:</p>
<ul>
<li>The chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve (VR): The proganglionic neurons relay in the submandibular ganglion, then postganglionic supply the submandibular &amp; sublingual glands</li>
<li>The glossopharyngeal nerve (IK): The proganglionic neurons relay in the otic ganglion, then postganglionic supply the parotid gland</li>
</ul>
<p>The non-conditioned reflex:</p>
<p>Presence of food in the mouth stimulates salivary secretion.</p>
<ul>
<li>Components of this neural reflex include:</li>
<li>Afferents from taste receptors in the mouth</li>
<li>Cortex: salivary nuclei in the medulla (superior &amp; inferior)</li>
<li>Efferents: the glossopharyngeal &amp; the facial nerves to the salivary glands</li>
</ul>
<p>Other factors affecting salivary secretion:</p>
<p>1- Sympathetic stimulation: increases secretion (small amount, mainly mucus) and causes vasoconstriction
2- Parasympathetic stimulation: Increases secretion (large amount, watery) and causes vasodilatation. The vasodilatation is mediated by VIP not acetylcholine, that is why it is not blocked by atropine
3- Muscarinic blockers like "atropine": Decreases secretion (results in dry mouth) by blocking acetylcholine. Atropine injection is used before anaesthesia to inhibit salivary secretion and keep the mouth dry. This allows insertion of the endotracheal tube through the mouth with minimal risk of valve aspiration into the respiratory system
4- Dehydration: Decreases secretion
5- Sleep: Decreases secretion to a very low level</p>
<p>11
The next of medical physiology 17 volume</p>
<p>Is the femoral experiment, Pandox used a bed to call a dog to the meat and, after a few repetitions, the dog learned that the bed sound is followed by food, so it started to activate in response to the bed sound.</p>
<p>The excitatory impulses that travel from the salivary nuclei in the medulla to supply the salivary glands are carried through:</p>
<ul>
<li>The chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve (VR): The proganglionic neurons relay in the submandibular ganglion, then postganglionic supply the submandibular &amp; sublingual glands</li>
<li>The glossopharyngeal nerve (IK): The proganglionic neurons relay in the otic ganglion, then postganglionic supply the parotid gland</li>
</ul>
<p>The non-conditioned reflex:</p>
<p>Presence of food in the mouth stimulates salivary secretion.</p>
<ul>
<li>Components of this neural reflex include:</li>
<li>Afferents from taste receptors in the mouth</li>
<li>Cortex: salivary nuclei in the medulla (superior &amp; inferior)</li>
<li>Efferents: the glossopharyngeal &amp; the facial nerves to the salivary glands</li>
</ul>
<p>Other factors affecting salivary secretion:</p>
<p>1- Sympathetic stimulation: Increases secretion (small amount, mainly mucus) and causes vasoconstriction
2- Parasympathetic stimulation: Increases secretion (large amount, watery) and causes vasodilatation. The vasodilatation is mediated by VIP not acetylcholine, that is why it is not blocked by atropine
3- Muscarinic blockers like "atropine": Decreases secretion (results in dry mouth) by blocking acetylcholine. This allows insertion of the endotracheal tube through the mouth with minimal risk of valve aspiration into the respiratory system
4- Dehydration: Decreases secretion
5- Sleep: Decreases secretion to a very low level</p>
