<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abnormal-salivary-secretion">Abnormal salivary secretion:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormal-salivary-secretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sarcoidosis">Sarcoidosis:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sarcoidosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Dry mouth, due to lack of saliva. It results in difficulty in speech and swallowing, halitosis (unpleasant odor exhaled in breathing), dental caries and increased susceptibility to oral infections.</li>
<li>It is caused by:</li>
<li>Dehydration (as in uncontrolled diabetes)</li>
<li>Epigenic syndrome (caused by auto-antibodies directed against the lacrimal and salivary glands resulting in absent tears and dry mouth (primary Epigenic). It may be associated with a connective tissue disease like rheumatoid arthritis (secondary Epigenic). It is more common in females.</li>
<li>Radiation (also destroys the salivary glands)</li>
<li>Drugs (anticholinergics, antidepressants ...)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pityelism">Pityelism:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pityelism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Drooling of saliva to outside the mouth; due to either increased production or decreased swallowing.</li>
<li>Although it may occur normally (e.g. in children due to leathing), it may indicate acute poisoning, tonsillitis retropharyngeal abscess or a neurological problem like Parkinsonism.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abnormal-salivary-secretion">Abnormal salivary secretion:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormal-salivary-secretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sarcoidosis">Sarcoidosis:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sarcoidosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Dry mouth, due to lack of saliva. It results in difficulty in speech and swallowing, halitosis (unpleasant odor exhaled in breathing), dental caries and increased susceptibility to oral infections.</li>
<li>It is caused by:</li>
<li>Dehydration (as in uncontrolled diabetes)</li>
<li>Epigenic syndrome (caused by auto-antibodies directed against the lacrimal and salivary glands resulting in absent tears and dry mouth (primary Epigenic). It may be associated with a connective tissue disease like rheumatoid arthritis (secondary Epigenic). It is more common in females.</li>
<li>Radiation (also destroys the salivary glands)</li>
<li>Drugs (anticholinergics, antidepressants ...)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pityelism">Pityelism:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pityelism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Drooling of saliva to outside the mouth; due to either increased production or decreased swallowing.</li>
<li>Although it may occur normally (e.g. in children due to leathing), it may indicate acute poisoning, tonsillitis retropharyngeal abscess or a neurological problem like Parkinsonism.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abnormal-salivary-secretion">Abnormal salivary secretion:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormal-salivary-secretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sarcoidosis">Sarcoidosis:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sarcoidosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Dry mouth, due to lack of saliva. It results in difficulty in speech and swallowing, halitosis (unpleasant odor exhaled in breathing), dental caries and increased susceptibility to oral infections.</li>
<li>It is caused by:</li>
<li>Dehydration (as in uncontrolled diabetes)</li>
<li>Epigenic syndrome (caused by auto-antibodies directed against the lacrimal and salivary glands resulting in absent tears and dry mouth (primary Epigenic). It may be associated with a connective tissue disease like rheumatoid arthritis (secondary Epigenic). It is more common in females.</li>
<li>Radiation (also destroys the salivary glands)</li>
<li>Drugs (anticholinergics, antidepressants ...)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pityelism">Pityelism:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pityelism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Drooling of saliva to outside the mouth; due to either increased production or decreased swallowing.</li>
<li>Although it may occur normally (e.g. in children due to leathing), it may indicate acute poisoning, tonsillitis retropharyngeal abscess or a neurological problem like Parkinsonism.</li>
</ul>
<p>THE PHARYNX &amp; THE ESOPHAGUS</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-pharynx">THE PHARYNX<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-pharynx" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Lies immediately posterior to the mouth and the nasal cavity</li>
<li>Common route for both air &amp; food</li>
<li>Involved in vocalization and in the swallowing reflex</li>
<li>Divided into three parts: Nasopharynx (posterior to the nasal cavity), Oropharynx (posterior to the oral cavity) and Laryngopharynx (extends down to the larynx and the esophagus).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-96d52b8d.jpeg" alt="img-370.jpeg">
Fig 8.5: The pharynx</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="swallowing-reflex">Swallowing Reflex<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#swallowing-reflex" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Swallowing (or deglutition) is the process by which solids or liquids in the mouth reach the stomach through the pharynx &amp; the esophagus.</li>
<li>It occurs in three stages: Buccal (voluntary), pharyngeal (involuntary) and esophageal (involuntary).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-buccal-stage">The Buccal stage:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-buccal-stage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The tongue moves upwards &amp; backwards to propel the bolus into the pharynx while the soft palate rises to close the nasopharynx.</li>
<li>The larynx starts to rise. The lips &amp; jaw should be closed (swallowing is difficult when they are open).</li>
</ul>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<p>244
The view of medical physiology of children</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-pharyngeal-stage">The Pharyngeal stage:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-pharyngeal-stage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The bolus is pushed backwards by the tongue against the epiglottis.</li>
<li>The epiglottis bends over the larynx to cover its opening; however, this bending is not essential to close the larynx since it is closed by other factors like contraction of the glottis (its upper part) and approximation of the vocal cords (extinction of vocal cords).</li>
<li>The swallowing reflex is initiated. The reflex components include:</li>
<li>Receptors: in the wall of the pharynx</li>
<li>Afferents: cranial nerves (5, 6 &amp; 12)</li>
<li>Center: swallowing center in the medulla</li>
<li>Efferents: cranial nerves (5, 7 &amp; 12)</li>
<li>Effective: muscles of the pharynx, larynx &amp; tongue</li>
<li>Response: coordinated contractions to propel the bolus towards the esophagus, avoiding the larynx with inhibition of respiration.</li>
<li>The upper esophageal sphincter opens for only one second to allow entry of the bolus into the esophagus.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-esophageal-stage">The esophageal stage:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-esophageal-stage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Contraction of the upper esophageal sphincter proceeds down as primary peristalsis. If the bolus is sticky or too large, secondary peristalsis occurs to move the semiants towards the lower esophageal sphincter.</li>
<li>Vagal impulses during swallowing relax the lower esophageal sphincter to allow entry of the bolus into the stomach whereas vagal impulses between meals close the lower esophageal sphincter.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="peristalsis">Peristalsis:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#peristalsis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs in all parts of the GIT starting from the pharynx.</li>
<li>In peristalsis, stretch of the wall of the esophagus results in contraction behind the bolus (by release of acetylcholine and substance P) and relaxation in front of it (by release of NO, VIP or ATP).</li>
</ul>
<p>245
The view of medical physiology of children</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-pharyngeal-stage">The Pharyngeal stage:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-pharyngeal-stage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The bolus is pushed backwards by the tongue against the epiglottis.</li>
<li>The epiglottis bends over the larynx to cover its opening; however, this bending is not essential to close the larynx since it is closed by other factors like contraction of the glottis (its upper part) and approximation of the vocal cords (extinction of vocal cords).</li>
<li>The swallowing reflex is initiated. The reflex components include:</li>
<li>Receptors: in the wall of the pharynx</li>
<li>Afferents: cranial nerves (5, 6 &amp; 12)</li>
<li>Center: swallowing center in the medulla</li>
<li>Efferents: cranial nerves (5, 7 &amp; 12)</li>
<li>Effective: muscles of the pharynx, larynx &amp; tongue</li>
<li>Response: coordinated contractions to propel the bolus towards the esophagus, avoiding the larynx, with inhibition of respiration.</li>
<li>The upper esophageal sphincter opens for only one second to allow entry of the bolus into the esophagus.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-esophageal-stage">The esophageal stage:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-esophageal-stage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Contraction of the upper esophageal sphincter proceeds down as primary peristalsis. If the bolus is sticky or too large, secondary peristalsis occurs to move the semiants towards the lower esophageal sphincter.</li>
<li>Vagal impulses during swallowing relax the lower esophageal sphincter to allow entry of the bolus into the stomach whereas vagal impulses between meals close the lower esophageal sphincter.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="peristalsis">Peristalsis:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#peristalsis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs in all parts of the GIT starting from the pharynx.</li>
<li>In peristalsis, stretch of the wall of the esophagus results in contraction behind the bolus (by release of acetylcholine and substance P) and relaxation in front of it (by release of NO, VIP or ATP).</li>
</ul>
<p>246
The view of medical physiology of children</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-pharyngeal-stage">The Pharyngeal stage:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-pharyngeal-stage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The bolus is pushed backwards by the tongue against the epiglottis.</li>
<li>The epiglottis bends over the larynx to cover its opening; however, this bending is not essential to close the larynx since it is closed by other factors like contraction of the glottis (its upper part) and approximation of the vocal cords (extinction of vocal cords).</li>
<li>The swallowing reflex is initiated. The reflex components include:</li>
<li>Receptors: in the wall of the pharynx</li>
<li>Afferents: cranial nerves (5, 6 &amp; 12)</li>
<li>Center: swallowing center in the medulla</li>
<li>Efferents: cranial nerves (5, 7 &amp; 12)</li>
<li>Effective: muscles of the pharynx, larynx &amp; tongue</li>
<li>Response: coordinated contractions to propel the bolus towards the esophagus, avoiding the larynx, with inhibition of respiration.</li>
<li>The upper esophageal sphincter opens for only one second to allow entry of the bolus into the esophagus.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-esophageal-stage">The esophageal stage:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-esophageal-stage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Contraction of the upper esophageal sphincter proceeds down as primary peristalsis. If the bolus is sticky or too large, secondary peristalsis occurs to move the semiants towards the lower esophageal sphincter.</li>
<li>Vagal impulses during swallowing relax the lower esophageal sphincter to allow entry of the bolus into the stomach whereas vagal impulses between meals close the lower esophageal sphincter.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="peristalsis">Peristalsis:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#peristalsis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs in all parts of the GIT starting from the pharynx.</li>
<li>In peristalsis, stretch of the wall of the esophagus results in contraction behind the bolus (by release of acetylcholine and substance P) and relaxation in front of it (by release of NO, VIP or ATP).</li>
</ul>
<p>247
The view of medical physiology of children</p>
<ul>
<li>This pushes the bolus downwards &amp; then the process repeats itself.</li>
<li>It is integrated in the myenteric plexus, increased by parasympathetic stimulation, and decreased by sympathetic stimulation.</li>
<li>Rate of peristalsis in the esophagus = 4 cm/s.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-esophagus">THE ESOPHAGUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-esophagus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Connects the pharynx to the cardiac part of the stomach.</li>
<li>Ranges from 25 to 35 cm in adults.</li>
<li>Guarded by two sphincters: The upper esophageal sphincter (UES) and the lower esophageal sphincter (LES)</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-b67ad0d4.jpeg" alt="img-371.jpeg">
Fig 8.6: The esophagus</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-upper-esophageal-sphincter-ues">The upper esophageal sphincter (UES):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-upper-esophageal-sphincter-ues" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The upper 3 cm of the esophagus form the UES. Unlike the lower sphincter, it is an "anatomical sphincter" (formed by the cricopharyngeal muscle; and it is known as "the cricopharyngeal sphincter". It is closed at rest at a high pressure (40-100 mmHg). It opens for one second during swallowing.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-lower-esophageal-sphincter-les">The lower esophageal sphincter (LES):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-lower-esophageal-sphincter-les" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The lowest 3 cm of the esophagus form the LES. It is not formed by a definite muscle (= Physiological sphincter). It is an area of high pressure (15-35 mmHg) when compared to the rest of the esophagus, which is sub atmospheric (except at the UES). It is closed at rest and opens for few seconds with swallowing.</li>
</ul>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Factors, which close the lower esophageal sphincter:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hormonal or humoral factors: Gastrin &amp; acetylcholine</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Neural factors: the vagus (between meals)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Factors, which open the lower esophageal sphincter:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hormonal or humoral factors: Secretin, CCK, VIP &amp; NO</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Neural factors: the vagus (during swallowing)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Other factors: Coffee, alcohol, smoking, excess amounts of vitamin C, chocolate, milk &amp; fat</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="competence-of-the-lower-esophageal-sphincter-les">Competence of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#competence-of-the-lower-esophageal-sphincter-les" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Although there is no definite muscle to form the LES, it is competent in preventing reflux of gastric contents into the esophagus.</li>
<li>This competence is due to the following factors:</li>
<li>Its high resting pressure (15-35 mmHg).</li>
<li>The intra-abdominal location which is compressed from outside by high pressure (this is unlike the intra-thoracic part of the esophagus which is surrounded by the negative intrapleural pressure).</li>
<li>The crural fibers of the diaphragm, which act as an external sphincter &amp; cause narrowing of the esophagus.</li>
<li>The mucosal folds of the stomach (act as valves that close the opening of the esophagus).</li>
<li>The oblique entry of the esophagus into the stomach (results in narrowing of its opening).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="abnormalities-of-the-lower-esophageal-sphincter">Abnormalities of the lower esophageal sphincter<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities-of-the-lower-esophageal-sphincter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="achalasia">Achalasia:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#achalasia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Massive dilatation of the esophagus proximal to the LES resulting from failure of the LES to relax during swallowing.</li>
<li>This occurs due to loss of the neurons which release the relaxing factors NO &amp; VIP in the myenteric plexus at the LES whereas acetylcholine and substance P are released causing contraction of the LES.</li>
</ul>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<p>Medical treatment: Botulinum toxin to inhibit release of acetylcholine.</p>
<p>Surgical treatment: Dilatation of the constricted area (Heller myotomy).</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Gastro-esophageal reflux disease (GERD):</strong></li>
<li>Incompetence of the LES due to a defect in the factors that normally close it or due to protrusion of upper part of the stomach into the thorax through a defect in the diaphragm (Hiatus hernia). Theses result in regurgitation of gastric acid into the esophagus causing mucosal damage.</li>
<li>Patients complain of heartburn when they lie down after heavy meals.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Medical treatment:</strong> Lifestyle modifications e.g. weight loss, elevating foot of the bed and avoidance of heavy meals before going to sleep. In addition, some patients may need anti-acid treatment (see peptic ulcer).</p>
<p><strong>Surgical treatment:</strong> Nissen fundoplication (if medical treatment failed as in cases of hiatus hernia)</p>
<p>Fig 8.7: GERD and Achalasia of the esophagus</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-236a194f.jpeg" alt="img-372.jpeg"></p>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<p>THE STOMACH</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The stomach is a "J"-shaped hollow muscular organ of the GIT, acting as a reservoir for food and involved in its digestion.</li>
<li>It is divided into 4 parts:</li>
<li>Cardia: the region where esophageal contents empty into the stomach</li>
<li>Fundus: the upper curvature</li>
<li>Body: the main central region</li>
<li>Pylorus or pyloric antrum: the lower part that facilitates gastric emptying</li>
<li>As in other parts of the GIT, the wall of the stomach consists of mucosa, submucosa, muscular layer, and serosa.</li>
<li>The muscular layer is divided into three layers: Outer longitudinal, middle circular and inner oblique.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-505d57b4.jpeg" alt="img-373.jpeg">
Fig 8.8: Structure of the stomach</p>
<ul>
<li>The mucosa of the stomach contains many deep exocrine glands (gastric glands). Many of the glands open through a common opening (gastric pit).</li>
</ul>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="types-of-cells-in-a-gastric-gland">Types of cells in a gastric gland:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-cells-in-a-gastric-gland" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>1- Mucus cells: At the neck of the glands (in the cardiac &amp; pyloric regions of the stomach)</p>
<ul>
<li>Secrete mucus.</li>
</ul>
<p>2- Parietal cells (oxyptic cells): At the isthmus &amp; body of the gastric gland (in the body &amp; fundus of the stomach)</p>
<ul>
<li>Secrete hydrochloric acid "HCL" &amp; intrinsic factor.</li>
</ul>
<p>3- Chief cells (peptic, zymogen): At the isthmus &amp; body of the gastric gland (in the body &amp; fundus of the stomach)</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Secrete Pepsinogens</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In addition, there are endocrine cells near the gastric glands:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>G cells: Secrete Gastrin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>ECL cells (Enterochromaffin like cells): Secrete histamine</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-9e61643a.jpeg" alt="img-374.jpeg">
Fig 8.9: The gastric gland</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-the-stomach">Functions of the stomach<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-the-stomach" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>1- Storage of food: up to about 4 hours, and controls its release into the duodenum.
2- Digestion of proteins &amp; lipids: by pepsin and gastric lipase enzymes. However, these enzymes are less important than the enzymes of the exocrine pancreas.
3- Protection: by HCL which kills bacteria &amp; vomiting which removes harmful substances.</p>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<p>224
The work of medical physiology of children</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>
<p>Synthesis of the intrinsic factor (IF): this glycoprotein binds vitamin B₁₂ in the stomach and then facilitates its absorption in the terminal ileum.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Facilitates absorption of iron in the intestine, by maintaining iron in the ferrous state.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Absorption: the stomach absorbs small amount of water, ions, alcohol and some drugs.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Endocrine function: produces many hormones like gastrin, glucagon, somatostatin, ghrelin and VIP.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Remember that, Ghrelin is the growth hormone releasing hormones secreted by the hypothalamus. It is also released from fundus of the stomach to give sensation of hunger (opposite to leptin from adipose tissue, which gives sensation of satiety).</p>
<p>225
The work of medical physiology of children</p>
<ol start="6">
<li>
<p>Synthesis of the intrinsic factor (IF): this glycoprotein binds vitamin B₁₂ in the stomach and then facilitates its absorption in the terminal ileum.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Facilitates absorption of iron in the intestine, by maintaining iron in the ferrous state.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Absorption: the stomach absorbs small amount of water, ions, alcohol and some drugs.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Endocrine function: produces many hormones like gastrin, glucagon, somatostatin, ghrelin and VIP.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Remember that, Ghrelin is the growth hormone releasing hormones secreted by the hypothalamus. It is also released from fundus of the stomach to give sensation of hunger (opposite to leptin from adipose tissue, which gives sensation of satiety).</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>
<p>Synthesis of the intrinsic factor (IF): this glycoprotein binds vitamin B₁₂ in the stomach and then facilitates its absorption in the terminal ileum.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Facilitates absorption of iron in the intestine, by maintaining iron in the ferrous state.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Absorption: the stomach absorbs small amount of water, ions, alcohol and some drugs.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Endocrine function: produces many hormones like gastrin, glucagon, somatostatin, ghrelin and VIP.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Remember that, Ghrelin is the growth hormone releasing hormones secreted by the hypothalamus. It is also released from fundus of the stomach to give sensation of hunger (opposite to leptin from adipose tissue, which gives sensation of satiety).</p>
<p>12
The text of medical journal(s) 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="section-1-excitation">SECTION 1: EXCITATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-1-excitation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="section-of-gastric-excretion">Section of gastric excretion:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-of-gastric-excretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Volume: 2-3 L/day</li>
<li>pH: Highly acidic (about 0.9). May increase up to 4 depending on the type of diet, its time and other factors</li>
<li>Osmolarity: Isotonic</li>
<li>Contents:</li>
<li>Water and electrolytes (H⁺ / Cl⁻ / K⁺ / HCO⁻ / Na⁺)</li>
<li>Intrinsic factor</li>
<li>Digestive enzymes (pepsin &amp; gastric lipase)</li>
<li>Mucus</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hydrochloric-acid-hcl">Hydrochloric acid (HCL)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hydrochloric-acid-hcl" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Secreted by parietal cells (which also secrete the intrinsic factor).</li>
<li>Each parietal cell is characterized by the following: It is pyramidal in shape, spiral membrane of the active cell contains canaliculi for secretion of HCL (the canaliculi in an inactive cell are found within the cytoplasm) and its cytoplasm contains large number of mitochondria (to provide energy for the active pumps that secrete hydrogen ions).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="synthesis-of-hcl">Synthesis of HCL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#synthesis-of-hcl" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>HCL is synthesized from hydrogen ions (H⁺) and chloride ions (Cl⁻).</li>
<li>Sources of hydrogen ions (H⁺):</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>From dissociation of H₂O into H⁺ &amp; OH⁻ (H₂O + H⁺ + OH⁻)</li>
<li>From the reaction of CO₂ with water at the presence of carbonic anhydrase enzyme: (CO₂ + H₂O + H₂CO₃ → H⁺ + HCO₂⁻)</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>H⁺ is secreted into the canaliculi against a very high concentration gradient by the H⁺/K⁺ ATPase pump (The proton pump).</li>
<li>HCO₂ enters the blood in exchange to Cl⁻, which enters the parietal cell.</li>
<li>Cl⁻ enters the canaliculi with K⁺.</li>
</ul>
<p>13
The text of medical journal(s) 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="section-2-excitation">SECTION 2: EXCITATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-2-excitation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="section-of-gastric-excretion">Section of gastric excretion:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-of-gastric-excretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Volume: 2-3 L/day</li>
<li>pH: Highly acidic (about 0.9). May increase up to 4 depending on the type of diet, its time and other factors</li>
<li>Osmolarity: Isotonic</li>
<li>Contents:</li>
<li>Water and electrolytes (H⁺ / Cl⁻ / K⁺ / HCO⁻ / Na⁺)</li>
<li>Intrinsic factor</li>
<li>Digestive enzymes (pepsin &amp; gastric lipase)</li>
<li>Mucus</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hydrochloric-acid-hcl">Hydrochloric acid (HCL)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hydrochloric-acid-hcl" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Secreted by parietal cells (which also secrete the intrinsic factor).</li>
<li>Each parietal cell is characterized by the following: It is pyramidal in shape, spiral membrane of the active cell contains canaliculi for secretion of HCL (the canaliculi in an inactive cell are found within the cytoplasm) and its cytoplasm contains large number of mitochondria (to provide energy for the active pumps that secrete hydrogen ions).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="synthesis-of-hcl">Synthesis of HCL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#synthesis-of-hcl" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>HCL is synthesized from hydrogen ions (H⁺) and chloride ions (Cl⁻).</li>
<li>Sources of hydrogen ions (H⁺):</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>From dissociation of H₂O into H⁺ &amp; OH⁻ (H₂O + H⁺ + OH⁻)</li>
<li>From the reaction of CO₂ with water at the presence of carbonic anhydrase enzyme: (CO₂ + H₂O + H₂CO₃ → H⁺ + HCO₂⁻)</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>H⁺ is secreted into the canaliculi against a very high concentration gradient by the H⁺/K⁺ ATPase pump (The proton pump).</li>
<li>HCO₂ enters the blood in exchange to Cl⁻, which enters the parietal cell.</li>
<li>Cl⁻ enters the canaliculi with K⁺.</li>
</ul>
<p>14
The text of medical journal(s) 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="section-3-excitation">SECTION 3: EXCITATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-3-excitation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="section-of-gastric-excretion">Section of gastric excretion:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-of-gastric-excretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Volume: 2-3 L/day</li>
<li>pH: Highly acidic (about 0.9). May increase up to 4 depending on the type of diet, its time and other factors</li>
<li>Osmolarity: Isotonic</li>
<li>Contents:</li>
<li>Water and electrolytes (H⁺ / Cl⁻ / K⁺ / HCO⁻ / Na⁺)</li>
<li>Intrinsic factor</li>
<li>Digestive enzymes (pepsin &amp; gastric lipase)</li>
<li>Mucus</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hydrochloric-acid-hcl">Hydrochloric acid (HCL)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hydrochloric-acid-hcl" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Secreted by parietal cells (which also secrete the intrinsic factor).</li>
<li>Each parietal cell is characterized by the following: It is pyramidal in shape, spiral membrane of the active cell contains canaliculi for secretion of HCL (the canaliculi in an inactive cell are found within the cytoplasm) and its cytoplasm contains large number of mitochondria (to provide energy for the active pumps that secrete hydrogen ions).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="synthesis-of-hcl">Synthesis of HCL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#synthesis-of-hcl" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>HCL is synthesized from hydrogen ions (H⁺) and chloride ions (Cl⁻).</li>
<li>Sources of hydrogen ions (H⁺):</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>From dissociation of H₂O into H⁺ &amp; OH⁻ (H₂O + H⁺ + OH⁻)</li>
<li>From the reaction of CO₂ with water at the presence of carbonic anhydrase enzyme: (CO₂ + H₂O + H₂CO₃ → H⁺ + HCO₂⁻)</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>H⁺ is secreted into the canaliculi against a very high concentration gradient by the H⁺/K⁺ ATPase pump (The proton pump).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>HCO₂ enters the blood in exchange to Cl⁻, which enters the parietal cell.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cl⁻ enters the canaliculi with K⁺.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>K</mi><mo>+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K^+</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> returns back to inside the cell by the <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>H</mi><mo>+</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><msup><mi>K</mi><mo>+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H^+ / K^+</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0213em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ATPase pump (i.e. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>K</mi><mo>+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K^+</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> recycles between the cytoplasm and the cerebrum).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In the cerebrum, HCL is formed as follows: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>H</mi><mo>+</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>C</mi><msup><mi>I</mi><mo>+</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>H</mi><mi>C</mi><mi>L</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(H^+ + CI^+ + HCL)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0213em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8547em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">I</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span><span class="mord mathnormal">L</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>HCL escapes from the cerebrum to the lumen (through the gastric pits).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Remember that, For each <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>H</mi><mo>+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H^+</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ion secreted to the lumen, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>H</mi><mi>C</mi><msubsup><mi>O</mi><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo></msubsup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">HCO_3^-</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0778em; vertical-align: -0.2663em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8115em;"><span style="top: -2.4337em; margin-left: -0.0278em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.1031em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">−</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2663em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> enters the blood.</p>
<ul>
<li>If secretion of HCL is increased e.g. following a meal or due to repeated vomiting, large amount of bicarbonate enters the blood.</li>
<li>This changes pH of the blood to become more alkaline (&gt; a condition known as post-prandial alkaline rate).</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 8 for HCL synthesis in a parietal cell
<img src="assets/images/image-20251216-7ad17c0e.jpeg" alt="img-375.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>Receptors on parietal cells for HCL secretion:</li>
<li>HCL secretion is stimulated through activation of the following receptors, which are found on the basolateral membrane of parietal cells:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Muscarinic receptors (M_L) stimulated by acetylcholine to increase intracellular <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Ca^{2+}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">C</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">a</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">2</span><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, protein kinases and then the proton pump.</li>
</ol>
<p>Fig 8 for HCL synthesis in a parietal cell
<img src="assets/images/image-20251216-915c8b06.jpeg" alt="img-376.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>K</mi><mo>+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K^+</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> returns back to inside the cell by the <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>H</mi><mo>+</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><msup><mi>K</mi><mo>+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H^+ / K^+</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0213em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ATPase pump (i.e. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>K</mi><mo>+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K^+</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> recycles between the cytoplasm and the cerebrum).</li>
<li>In the cerebrum, HCL is formed as follows: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>H</mi><mo>+</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>C</mi><msup><mi>I</mi><mo>+</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>H</mi><mi>C</mi><mi>L</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(H^+ + CI^+ + HCL)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0213em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8547em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">I</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span><span class="mord mathnormal">L</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
<li>HCL escapes from the cerebrum to the lumen (through the gastric pits).</li>
</ul>
<p>Remember that, For each <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>H</mi><mo>+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H^+</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ion secreted to the lumen, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>H</mi><mi>C</mi><msubsup><mi>O</mi><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo></msubsup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">HCO_3^-</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0778em; vertical-align: -0.2663em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8115em;"><span style="top: -2.4337em; margin-left: -0.0278em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.1031em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">−</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2663em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> enters the blood.</p>
<ul>
<li>If secretion of HCL is increased e.g. following a meal or due to repeated vomiting, large amount of bicarbonate enters the blood.</li>
<li>This changes pH of the blood to become more alkaline (&gt; a condition known as post-prandial alkaline rate).</li>
</ul>

<li>In the cerebrum, HCL is formed as follows: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>H</mi><mo>+</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>C</mi><msup><mi>I</mi><mo>+</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>H</mi><mi>C</mi><mi>L</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(H^+ + CI^+ + HCL)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0213em; <li>HCL escapes from the cerebrum to the lumen (through the gastric pits).</li>
</ul>
<p>Remember that, For each <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>H</mi><mo>+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H^+</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; <li>If secretion of HCL is increased e.g. following a meal or due to repeated vomiting, large amount of bicarbonate enters the blood.</li>
<li>This changes pH of the blood to become more alkaline (&gt; a condition known as post-prandial alkaline rate).</li>

<li>In the cerebrum, HCL is formed as follows: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>H</mi><mo>+</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>C</mi><msup><mi>I</mi><mo>+</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>H</mi><mi>C</mi><mi>L</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(H^+ + CI^+ + HCL)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0213em; </ul>
<p>Remember that, For each <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>H</mi><mo>+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H^+</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ion secreted to the lumen, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>H</mi><mi>C</mi><msubsup><mi>O</mi><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo></msubsup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">HCO_3^-</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0778em; vertical-align: -0.2663em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8115em;"><span style="top: -2.4337em; margin-left: -0.0278em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.1031em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">−</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2663em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> enters the blood.</p>
<ul>
<li>If secretion of HCL is increased e.g. following a meal or due to repeated vomiting, large amount of bicarbonate enters the blood.</li>
<li>This changes pH of the blood to become more alkaline (&gt; a condition known as post-prandial alkaline rate).</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 8 for HCL synthesis in a parietal cell</p>
<p>17
The cost of medical knowledge * if &lt;100%</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Q receptors: stimulated by gastrin to increase intracellular Ca2+.
(Rese: gastrin acts mainly on enterochromaffin like cells (ECL) to release histamine).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Q receptors: stimulated by histamine (which is released by the ECL cells) to increase intracellular cAMP, protein kinases and then the proton pump.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Receptors on parietal cells against HCL secretion:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>These are prostaglandin receptors stimulated by prostaglandins; they inhibit HCL secretion.</li>
<li>Prostaglandins also stimulate secretion of mucus, which protects the wall of the stomach from the action of HCL.</li>
<li>Therefore, inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis by aspirin increases HCL synthesis &amp; decreases mucus secretion. This predisposes to peptic ulcer.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Functions of HCL:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>AEs ingested bacteria</li>
<li>Activates peptorogen to pepsin &amp; allows its action</li>
<li>Maintains iron in the ferrous state to facilitate its absorption</li>
<li>Facilitates absorption of calcium</li>
<li>Stimulates flow of bile (by stimulating release of secretin)</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>The hormone which increase HCL secretion:</strong>
<strong>Gastrin:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Characteristics of gastrin:</li>
<li>Peptide hormone (half life: 2-3 min).</li>
</ul>
<ol start="4">
<li>
<p>Q receptors: stimulated by gastrin to increase intracellular Ca2+.
(Rese: gastrin acts mainly on enterochromaffin like cells (ECL) to release histamine).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Q receptors: stimulated by histamine (which is released by the ECL cells) to increase intracellular cAMP, protein kinases and then the proton pump.</p>
</li>
</ol>

<p>238
The role of sodium phytohage in cancer</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Similar to CCK (The gastro family of hormones include gastrin &amp; CCK).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Found in different lengths: (17, 34, 14 aa ...). However, G 17 is the principal form.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Genetic release &amp; catabolism</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Released by:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Grade in the pyloric antrum of the stomach and upper small intestine.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fetal pancreas (this stops gastrin release after delivery).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Some neural structures outside the GIT (e.g. brain, vagus and sciatic nerves).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Catabolism: Kidney and small intestine.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Stress of gastric release</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Gastric distention</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Luminal peptides and amino acids (e.g. tryptophan &amp; phenylalanine)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Vague (through the neurotransmitter "gastrin releasing peptide" (GRP), not acetylcholine; that is why gastrin is not inhibited by atropine).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Calcium ions (hypercalcemia)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Epinephrine</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Inhibitors of gastric release:</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Acid in pyloric antrum (inhibits G cells either directly or through release of somatostatin). This is an example of a negative feedback mechanism.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Somatostatin (also inhibits many other hormones).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Secretin family of GIT hormones (secretin, GR, VIP &amp; glucagon).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Calcitonin (calcium lowering hormone released by the thyroid gland).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Actions of gastric Phytohagic actions:</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stimulates gastric acid secretion</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stimulates pepsin secretion</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Trophic effect on the mucosa of the stomach, intestine and colon</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stimulates gastric motility</p>
</li>
</ul>
