<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="a-large-doses-non-physiologic-actions">a large doses (non-physiologic actions):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-large-doses-non-physiologic-actions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Stimulates pancreatic secretion (the enzymes mainly)</li>
<li>Stimulates water &amp; HCO-secretion from pancreatic ducts and biliary duct</li>
<li>Stimulates insulin secretion (following a protein meal)</li>
<li>Directs the ileo-vocal value</li>
<li>Contacts the lower esophageal sphincter (LES)</li>
<li>Stimulates gastric &amp; intestinal motility &amp; stores gastric emptying</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abnormalities-associated-with-high-gastric-level">abnormalities associated with high gastric level:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities-associated-with-high-gastric-level" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="seminars-softinger-ellison-syndrome">(Seminars = "Softinger Ellison Syndrome" )<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#seminars-softinger-ellison-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A urine (usually in the pancreas) that secretes gastrin excessively</li>
<li>Gastric results in rapid secretion of HCL causing multiple peptic ulcers (in the stomach, esophagus and small intestine)</li>
<li>Modifies of treatment include anti-ulcer treatment plus surgery or chemotherapy</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-portillites-anemia">1. Portillites anemia:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-portillites-anemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This is a severe megakidemic anemia caused by auto-antibodies that result in failure of parietal cells to secrete the intrinsic factor, which is important for absorption of vitamin B₁₂</li>
<li>The parietal cells also fail to secrete HCL; this results in loss of the negative feedback reached by acid on gastrin causing gastrin excess.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-portillites-which-decrease-hcl-secretion">2. Portillites which decrease HCL secretion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-portillites-which-decrease-hcl-secretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Complications: Released from D cells in the pyloric antrum to inhibit gastric acid secretion and gastrin</li>
<li>It is also released from other sites (like intestine, pancreas and hypothalamus)</li>
<li>It limits other hormones (like growth hormone, insulin, glucagon and many other hormones)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-mucosal-two-control-of-pancreatic-secretion">3. Mucosal: Two control of pancreatic secretion.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-mucosal-two-control-of-pancreatic-secretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>11
The cost of medical psychology 12th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="a-large-doses-non-physiologic-actions">a large doses (non-physiologic actions):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-large-doses-non-physiologic-actions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Stimulates pancreatic secretion (the enzymes mainly)</li>
<li>Stimulates water &amp; HCO-secretion from pancreatic ducts and biliary duct</li>
<li>Stimulates insulin secretion (following a protein meal)</li>
<li>Reduces the ileo-vocal value</li>
<li>Contacts the lower esophageal sphincter (LES)</li>
<li>Stimulates gastric &amp; intestinal motility &amp; stores gastric emptying</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abnormalities-associated-with-high-gastric-level">abnormalities associated with high gastric level:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities-associated-with-high-gastric-level" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="seminars-softinger-ellison-syndrome">(Seminars = "Softinger Ellison Syndrome" )<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#seminars-softinger-ellison-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A bone (usually in the pancreas) that secretes gastrin excessively</li>
<li>Gastric results in rapid secretion of HCL causing multiple peptic ulcers (in the stomach, esophagus and small intestine)</li>
<li>Modifies of treatment include anti-ulcer treatment plus surgery or chemotherapy</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-portillites-anemia">1. Portillites anemia:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-portillites-anemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This is a severe megakidemic anemia caused by auto-antibodies that result in failure of parietal cells to secrete the intrinsic factor, which is important for absorption of vitamin B₁₂</li>
<li>The parietal cells also fail to secrete HCL; this results in loss of the negative feedback reached by acid on gastrin causing gastrin excess.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-portillites-which-decrease-hcl-secretion">2. Portillites which decrease HCL secretion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-portillites-which-decrease-hcl-secretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Complications: Released from D cells in the pyloric antrum to inhibit gastric acid secretion and gastrin</li>
<li>It is also released from other sites (like intestine, pancreas and hypothalamus)</li>
<li>It limits other hormones (like growth hormone, insulin, glucagon and many other hormones)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-mucosal-two-control-of-pancreatic-secretion">3. Mucosal: Two control of pancreatic secretion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-mucosal-two-control-of-pancreatic-secretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>12
The cost of medical psychology 12th edition</p>
<p>287
The role of medical physiology in cancer</p>
<p>3- VP: Vasoactive intestinal polypeptide is released from GIT, brain &amp; autonomic nerves. It inhibits gastric old secretion, stimulates intestinal secretion and relieves smooth muscles in the intestine, blood vessels and bronchioles.</p>
<p>4- Glucagon: See the pancreas in the endocrine system.</p>
<p>5- Enterogastrone: Is thought to be the hormone that is released from the intestine to inhibit gastric stimulated acid secretion. Its identity is unsettled (may be the peptide YY).</p>
<p>6- GP: Gastric inhibitory peptide is released by K cells in the duodenum in response to luminal glucose or fat.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Its name refers to its action when administered in high doses (inhibits gastric motility and secretion).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>However, its physiologic role appears to be stimulation of insulin release following ingestion of glucose, that is why it is called the glucose-dependent Na+Inotropic hormone.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="other-factors-that-decrease-hcl-secretion">Other factors that decrease HCL secretion:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-factors-that-decrease-hcl-secretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="vagotomy">Vagotomy:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vagotomy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Cutting the vagus nerve causes loss of the parasympathetic supply to the stomach. This decreases HCL secretion and that is why it is used for treatment of peptic ulcer.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="vagotomy-can-be">-Vagotomy can be:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vagotomy-can-be" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Truncal (cutting the nerve supply to the whole abdomen)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Subciliar (cutting the branch that supply the whole stomach)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Highly selective (cutting the branch that supply the acid secreting area at the proximal part of the stomach).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Vagotomy is usually complicated by decreased gastric emptying; this can be treated by pyloroplasty (surgical widening of the pylorus).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="acute-stress-fear">Acute stress (fear):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-stress-fear" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Associated with reduced HCL secretion due to decreased vagal discharge.</li>
</ul>
<p>288
The role of medical physiology in cancer</p>
<p>3- VP: Vasoactive intestinal polypeptide is released from GIT, brain &amp; autonomic nerves. It inhibits gastric old secretion, stimulates intestinal secretion and relieves smooth muscles in the intestine, blood vessels and bronchioles.</p>
<p>4- Glucagon: See the pancreas in the endocrine system.</p>
<p>5- Enterogastrone: Is thought to be the hormone that is released from the intestine to inhibit gastric stimulated acid secretion. Its identity is unsettled (may be the peptide YY).</p>
<p>6- GP: Gastric inhibitory peptide is released by K cells in the duodenum in response to luminal glucose or fat.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Its name refers to its action when administered in high doses (inhibits gastric motility and secretion).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>However, its physiologic role appears to be stimulation of insulin release following ingestion of glucose, that is why it is called the glucose-dependent Na+Inotropic hormone.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="other-factors-that-decrease-hcl-secretion">Other factors that decrease HCL secretion:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-factors-that-decrease-hcl-secretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="vagotomy">Vagotomy:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vagotomy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="gastric-lipase">GASTRIC LIPASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gastric-lipase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The enzyme is released by mucosa of the fundus.</li>
<li>It causes hydrolysis of triglycerides into monoglycerides and fatty acids.</li>
<li>Not important except in the absence of pancreatic lipase (its activity &gt; 1/5th of pancreatic lipase activity).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pepen">PEPEN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pepen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The enzyme is secreted by peptic cells as pepsinogens (inactive enzymes). Pepsinogens are activated by HCL to pepsin &amp; then by pepsin itself which activates other pepsinogens (auto-activation or auto-caterpals).</li>
<li>It causes protein digestion (acts in acidic pH (1.2-3.0) - i.e. HCL activates it and provides for it a suitable pH). It is worth noting that pepsin is not essential for protein digestion, unlike proteolytic enzymes of the pancreas.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="remain-enzyme">REMAIN ENZYME<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remain-enzyme" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The enzyme is not found in humans, it is found in calf stomach.</li>
<li>It causes digestion of proteins.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="mucus">MUCUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mucus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Glycoprotein.</li>
<li>Protects the stomach from auto-digestion by HCL &amp; pepsin.</li>
<li>For this reason, the mucus layer (aided by bicarbonate ions) are known as "the mucosal barrier."</li>
<li>Mucus is stimulated by: i) Mechanical &amp; chemical irritation ii) Sympathetic &amp; parasympathetic stimulation iii) Prostaglandins.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="nitrinsic-factor">NITRINSIC FACTOR<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nitrinsic-factor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Glycoprotein secreted by parietal cells to facilitate absorption of vitamin B₁₂ at the femoral ileum. It is lost in pernicious anemia (due to autoantibodies affecting parietal cells or the intrinsic factor).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="gastric-lipase">GASTRIC LIPASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gastric-lipase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The enzyme is released by mucosa of the fundus.</li>
<li>It causes hydrolysis of triglycerides into monoglycerides and fatty acids.</li>
<li>Not important except in the absence of pancreatic lipase (its activity &gt; 1/5th of pancreatic lipase activity).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pepse">PEPSE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pepse" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The enzyme is secreted by peptic cells as pepsinogens (inactive enzymes). Pepsinogens are activated by HCL to pepsin &amp; then by pepsin itself which activates other pepsinogens (auto-activation or auto-caterpals).</li>
<li>It causes protein digestion (acts in acidic pH (1.5-3.5) - i.e. HCL activates it and provides for it a suitable pH). It is worth noting that pepsin is not essential for protein digestion, unlike proteolytic enzymes of the pancreas.</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="remain-enzyme">REMAIN ENZYME<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remain-enzyme" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The enzyme is not found in humans, it is found in calf stomach.</li>
<li>It causes digestion of proteins.</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="mucus">MUCUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mucus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>Glycoprotein.</li>
<li>Protects the stomach from auto-digestion by HCL &amp; pepsin.</li>
<li>For this reason, the mucus layer (aided by bicarbonate ions) are known as "the mucosal barrier."</li>
<li>Mucus is stimulated by: i) Mechanical &amp; chemical irritation ii) Sympathetic &amp; parasympathetic stimulation iii) Prostaglandins.</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="nitrinsic-factor">NITRINSIC FACTOR<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nitrinsic-factor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="gastric-lipase">GASTRIC LIPASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gastric-lipase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The enzyme is released by mucous of the fundus.</li>
<li>It causes hydrolysis of triglycerides into monoglycerides and fatty acids.</li>
<li>Not important except in the absence of pancreatic lipase (its activity &gt; 1/5th of pancreatic lipase activity).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pepse">PEPSE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pepse" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The enzyme is secreted by peptic cells as pepsinogens (inactive enzymes). Pepsinogens are activated by HCL to pepsin &amp; then by pepsin itself which activates other pepsinogens (auto-activation or auto-caterpals).</li>
<li>It causes protein digestion (acts in acidic pH (1.5-3.5) - i.e. HCL activates it and provides for it a suitable pH). It is worth noting that pepsin is not essential for protein digestion, unlike proteolytic enzymes of the pancreas.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="remain-enzyme">REMAIN ENZYME<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#remain-enzyme" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The enzyme is not found in humans, it is found in calf stomach.</li>
<li>It causes digestion of proteins.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="mucus">MUCUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mucus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Glycoprotein.</li>
<li>Protects the stomach from auto-digestion by HCL &amp; pepsin.</li>
<li>For this reason, the mucus layer (aided by bicarbonate ions) are known as "the mucosal barrier."</li>
<li>Mucus is stimulated by: i) Mechanical &amp; chemical irritation ii) Sympathetic &amp; parasympathetic stimulation iii) Prostaglandins.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="nitrinsic-factor">NITRINSIC FACTOR<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nitrinsic-factor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Glycoprotein secreted by parietal cells to facilitate absorption of vitamin B₁₂ at the femoral ileum. It is lost in pernicious anemia (due to autoantibodies affecting parietal cells or the intrinsic factor).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id=""><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"></span></h1></div>
<p>162
The cost of medical physiology: 1st edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="control-of-gastric-secretion">CONTROL OF GASTRIC SECRETION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-gastric-secretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Controlled by neural &amp; hormonal mechanisms. These mechanisms are activated during the following phases: Cephalic phase, gastric phase and intestinal phase.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Cephalic phase</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When food is in front or within the mouth (not in the stomach).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Two neural reflexes are activated:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Conditioned reflex (activated by sight, smell, or thought about food)</li>
<li>Non-conditioned reflex (activated by food in the mouth)
Both reflexes are mediated through the vagus nerve.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Cutting the vagus nerve abolishes this reflex.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Gastric Phase</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is the phase when food reaches the stomach.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Here gastric secretion is mediated by both neural &amp; hormonal mechanisms.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>The neural mechanism: Distention of the stomach stimulates gastric secretion by long and short reflexes as follows:</p>
<ul>
<li>Vagovagal reflex (long reflex mediated by the vagus &amp; integrated in the brain stem. It can be abolished by vagotomy).</li>
<li>Intramural reflex (short reflex integrated in the submucus plexus within the wall of the stomach).</li>
</ul>
<p>Hormonal mechanism: Food in the stomach stimulates release of gastric, which stimulates gastric secretion. Gastric stimuli include: Gastric distention &amp; L-amino acids.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Intestinal phase</strong></li>
<li>Activated when chyme reaches the intestine.</li>
<li>Here gastric secretion is initially inhibited (due to stimulation of an intestinal hormone that inhibits HCL secretion; this hormone is known as enterogastrone). Then after 1-2 hours, HCL secretion may increase (due to release of gastric from the intestine).</li>
</ul>
<p>163
The cost of medical physiology: 1st edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="control-of-gastric-secretion">CONTROL OF GASTRIC SECRETION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-gastric-secretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Controlled by neural &amp; hormonal mechanisms. These mechanisms are activated during the following phases: Cephalic phase, gastric phase and intestinal phase.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Cephalic phase</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When food is in front or within the mouth (not in the stomach).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Two neural reflexes are activated:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Conditioned reflex (activated by sight, smell, or thought about food)</li>
<li>Non-conditioned reflex (activated by food in the mouth)
Both reflexes are mediated through the vagus nerve.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Cutting the vagus nerve abolishes this reflex.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Gastric Phase</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is the phase when food reaches the stomach.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Here gastric secretion is mediated by both neural &amp; hormonal mechanisms.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>The neural mechanism: Distention of the stomach stimulates gastric secretion by long and short reflexes as follows:</p>
<ul>
<li>Vagovagal reflex (long reflex mediated by the vagus &amp; integrated in the brain stem. It can be abolished by vagotomy).</li>
<li>Intramural reflex (short reflex integrated in the submucus plexus within the wall of the stomach).</li>
</ul>
<p>Hormonal mechanism: Food in the stomach stimulates release of gastric, which stimulates gastric secretion. Gastric stimuli include: Gastric distention &amp; L-amino acids.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Intestinal phase</strong></li>
<li>Activated when chyme reaches the intestine.</li>
<li>Here gastric secretion is initially inhibited (due to stimulation of an intestinal hormone that inhibits HCL secretion; this hormone is known as enterogastrone). Then after 1-2 hours, HCL secretion may increase (due to release of gastric from the intestine).</li>
</ul>
<p>164
The cost of medical physiology: 1st edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="control-of-gastric-secretion">CONTROL OF GASTRIC SECRETION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-gastric-secretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Controlled by neural &amp; hormonal mechanisms. These mechanisms are activated during the following phases: Cephalic phase, gastric phase and intestinal phase.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Cephalic phase</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When food is in front or within the mouth (not in the stomach).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Two neural reflexes are activated:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Conditioned reflex (activated by sight, smell, or thought about food)</li>
<li>Non-conditioned reflex (activated by food in the mouth)
Both reflexes are mediated through the vagus nerve.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Cutting the vagus nerve abolishes this reflex.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Gastric Phase</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is the phase when food reaches the stomach.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Here gastric secretion is mediated by both neural &amp; hormonal mechanisms.</p>
</li>
</ul>

<ul>
<li>Vagovagal reflex (long reflex mediated by the vagus &amp; integrated in the brain stem. It can be abolished by vagotomy).</li>

<li>Here gastric secretion is initially inhibited (due to stimulation of an intestinal hormone that inhibits HCL secretion; this hormone is known as enterogastrone). Then after 1-2 hours, HCL secretion may increase (due to release of gastric from the intestine).</li>

<p>165
The cost of medical physiology: 1st edition</p>
<p>30
The use of medical physiology 17 others</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sample-ulcide">SAMPLE ULCIDE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sample-ulcide" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Defect in the mucosa of the stomach or intestine caused by gastric secretion.</li>
<li>Inabests of peptic ulcer suffer from severe epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting and bicarbonate gastric bleeding.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causes-of-peptic-ulcer">Causes of peptic ulcer:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-of-peptic-ulcer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-infection-of-the-gastric-mucosa-with-helicobacter-pylori-bacteria">1. Infection of the gastric mucosa with Helicobacter pylori bacteria.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-infection-of-the-gastric-mucosa-with-helicobacter-pylori-bacteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>This is the main cause of peptic ulcer in most cases.</li>
<li>The bacteria lives within the mucus layer, it protects itself from the effect of the gastric acid resulting it by releasing the enzyme unease, this enzyme converts urea into ammonia and bicarbonate, both of which are basic substances that neutralize the acid.</li>
<li>On the other hand, its presence within the mucus layer protects it from the immune system of the body.</li>
<li>Ammonia and the products of leucocytes which attack the bacteria result in disruption of the mucosal barrier or direct damage to the gastric mucosa causing peptic ulcer.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="2-non-steroidal-anti-inflammatory-drugs-nsaid-like-aspirin">2. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAID) like aspirin.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-non-steroidal-anti-inflammatory-drugs-nsaid-like-aspirin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>These inhibit synthesis of prostaglandins from arachidonic acid.</li>
<li>Since prostaglandins inhibit HCL synthesis and increase mucus secretion, then chloric use of aspirin, which inhibits its formation from arachidonic acid, results in increased HCL secretion and decreased mucus production causing peptic ulcer.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="3-zollinger-ellison-syndrome">3. Zollinger Ellison Syndrome.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-zollinger-ellison-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Described by Zollinger and Ellison in 1955.</li>
<li>Caused by a tumor in the pancreas or other part in the GIT.</li>
<li>The tumor cells release gastrin (= gastrinome). This causes excessive secretion of HCL resulting in multiple peptic ulcers.</li>
</ul>
<p>31
The use of medical physiology 17 others</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sample-ulcide">SAMPLE ULCIDE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sample-ulcide" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Defect in the mucosa of the stomach or intestine caused by gastric secretion.</li>
<li>Haberts of peptic ulcer suffer from severe epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting and bicarbonate gastric bleeding.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causes-of-peptic-ulcer">Causes of peptic ulcer:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-of-peptic-ulcer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-infection-of-the-gastric-mucosa-with-helicobacter-pylori-bacteria">1. Infection of the gastric mucosa with Helicobacter pylori bacteria.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-infection-of-the-gastric-mucosa-with-helicobacter-pylori-bacteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>This is the main cause of peptic ulcer in most cases.</li>
<li>The bacteria lives within the mucus layer, it protects itself from the effect of the gastric acid resulting it by releasing the enzyme unease, this enzyme converts urea into ammonia and bicarbonate, both of which are basic substances that neutralize the acid.</li>
<li>On the other hand, its presence within the mucus layer protects it from the immune system of the body.</li>
<li>Ammonia and the products of leucocytes which attack the bacteria result in disruption of the mucosal barrier or direct damage to the gastric mucosa causing peptic ulcer.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="2-non-steroidal-anti-inflammatory-drugs-nsaid-like-aspirin">2. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAID) like aspirin.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-non-steroidal-anti-inflammatory-drugs-nsaid-like-aspirin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>These inhibit synthesis of prostaglandins from arachidonic acid.</li>
<li>Since prostaglandins inhibit HCL synthesis and increase mucus secretion, then chloric use of aspirin, which inhibits its formation from arachidonic acid, results in increased HCL secretion and decreased mucus production causing peptic ulcer.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="3-zollinger-ellison-syndrome">3. Zollinger Ellison Syndrome.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-zollinger-ellison-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Described by Zollinger and Ellison in 1955.</li>
<li>Caused by a tumor in the pancreas or other part in the GIT.</li>
<li>The tumor cells release gastrin (= gastrinome). This causes excessive secretion of HCL resulting in multiple peptic ulcers.</li>
</ul>
<p>10
The use of medical physiology 17 others</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sample-ulcide">SAMPLE ULCIDE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sample-ulcide" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Defect in the mucosa of the stomach or intestine caused by gastric secretion.</li>
<li>Haberts of peptic ulcer suffer from severe epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting and bicarbonate gastric bleeding.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causes-of-peptic-ulcer">Causes of peptic ulcer:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-of-peptic-ulcer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-infection-of-the-gastric-mucosa-with-helicobacter-pylori-bacteria">1. Infection of the gastric mucosa with Helicobacter pylori bacteria.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-infection-of-the-gastric-mucosa-with-helicobacter-pylori-bacteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>This is the main cause of peptic ulcer in most cases.</li>
<li>The bacteria lives within the mucus layer, it protects itself from the effect of the gastric acid resulting it by releasing the enzyme unease, this enzyme converts urea into ammonia and bicarbonate, both of which are basic substances that neutralize the acid.</li>
<li>On the other hand, its presence within the mucus layer protects it from the immune system of the body.</li>
<li>Ammonia and the products of leucocytes which attack the bacteria result in disruption of the mucosal barrier or direct damage to the gastric mucosa causing peptic ulcer.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="2-non-steroidal-anti-inflammatory-drugs-nsaid-like-aspirin">2. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAID) like aspirin.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-non-steroidal-anti-inflammatory-drugs-nsaid-like-aspirin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>These inhibit synthesis of prostaglandins from arachidonic acid.</li>
<li>Since prostaglandins inhibit HCL synthesis and increase mucus secretion, then chloric use of aspirin, which inhibits its formation from arachidonic acid, results in increased HCL secretion and decreased mucus production causing peptic ulcer.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="3-zollinger-ellison-syndrome">3. Zollinger Ellison Syndrome.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-zollinger-ellison-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Described by Zollinger and Ellison in 1955.</li>
<li>Caused by a tumor in the pancreas or other part in the GIT.</li>
<li>The tumor cells release gastrin (= gastrinome). This causes excessive secretion of HCL resulting in multiple peptic ulcers.</li>
</ul>
<p>104
The role of medical physiology in medicine</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="medical-treatment-of-peptic-ulcer">Medical treatment of peptic ulcer:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-treatment-of-peptic-ulcer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Treatment starts by eradication of the primary cause (e.g. antibiotics against Helicobacter pylori and cessation of NSAID).</li>
<li>In addition, some of the following drugs should be used for at least 4-6 weeks to allow the ulcer to heal:</li>
<li>Drugs that inhibit HCL secretion allow the ulcer to heal:</li>
<li>Proton pump inhibitors: Effective drugs in treatment of peptic ulcers. They block the proton pump (the H⁺/K⁺ ATPase pump).</li>
<li>Example: omeprazole.</li>
<li>H₂ blockers: Block histamine receptors type 2 (H2 receptors). Examples: cimetidine, ranitidine and famotidine.</li>
<li>Muscarinic blockers: Block the effect of acetylcholine at the muscarinic receptors. However, they are less effective than other drugs.</li>
<li>Example: pramipexole.</li>
<li>Prostaglandin analogues: Inhibit HCL secretion and induce mucus and bicarbonate secretion.</li>
<li>Example: Misoprostol.</li>
<li>Drugs that neutralize HCL+ relative symptoms:</li>
<li>Antacids: Are used to neutralize existing acid in the stomach. They are used mainly to relief symptoms.</li>
<li>Drugs that cover the ulcer+ prevent further digestion of the ulcer:</li>
<li>Sucralfate: This sucrose octasulphate compound binds to proteins in the ulcer trough, protecting it from further digestion.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="surgical-treatment-of-peptic-ulcer">Surgical treatment of peptic ulcer<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#surgical-treatment-of-peptic-ulcer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vegetative">Vegetative:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vegetative" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Indicated when there is failure of all types of medical treatment.</li>
<li>Negatively blocks the cephalic phase &amp; part of the gastric phase.</li>
<li>This decreases HCL secretion, giving chance for the ulcer to heal.</li>
</ul>
<p>105
The role of medical physiology in medicine</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="medical-treatment-of-peptic-ulcer">Medical treatment of peptic ulcer:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-treatment-of-peptic-ulcer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Treatment starts by eradication of the primary cause (e.g. antibiotics against Helicobacter pylori and cessation of NSAID).</li>
<li>In addition, some of the following drugs should be used for at least 4-6 weeks to allow the ulcer to heal:</li>
<li>Drugs that inhibit HCL secretion+ allow the ulcer to heal:</li>
<li>Proton pump inhibitors: Effective drugs in treatment of peptic ulcers. They block the proton pump (the H⁺/K⁺ ATPase pump).</li>
<li>Example: omeprazole.</li>
<li>H₂ blockers: Block histamine receptors type 2 (H2 receptors). Examples: cimetidine, ranitidine and famotidine.</li>
<li>Muscarinic blockers: Block the effect of acetylcholine at the muscarinic receptors. However, they are less effective than other drugs.</li>
<li>Example: pramipexole.</li>
<li>Prostaglandin analogues: Inhibit HCL secretion and induce mucus and bicarbonate secretion.</li>
<li>Example: Misoprostol.</li>
<li>Drugs that neutralize HCL+ relative symptoms:</li>
<li>Antacids: Are used to neutralize existing acid in the stomach. They are used mainly to relief symptoms.</li>
<li>Drugs that cover the ulcer+ prevent further digestion of the ulcer:</li>

</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="surgical-treatment-of-peptic-ulcer">Surgical treatment of peptic ulcer<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#surgical-treatment-of-peptic-ulcer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diarrhoea">Diarrhoea:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diarrhoea" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="medical-treatment-of-peptic-ulcer">Medical treatment of peptic ulcer:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-treatment-of-peptic-ulcer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<p>60
The case of medical physiology: P' address
61
The case of medical physiology: P' address
62
The case of medical physiology: P' address</p>
<p>The problem with vagotomy is the impairment of gastric emptying (see above). That is why pylompilasty (dilatation of the pylorus) is usually done with the procedure.</p>
<p>Vagotomy can be tested by insulin injection to induce hypoglycemia because hypoglycemia stimulates the vagus nerve, which increases gastric secretion. Therefore, any increase in gastric secretion following the injection indicates that vagotomy is not successful.</p>
<p>The problem with vagotomy is the impairment of gastric emptying (see above). That is why pylompilasty (dilatation of the pylorus) is usually done with the procedure.</p>
<p>Vagotomy can be tested by insulin injection to induce hypoglycemia because hypoglycemia stimulates the vagus nerve, which increases gastric secretion. Therefore, any increase in gastric secretion following the injection indicates that vagotomy is not successful.</p>
<p>The problem with vagotomy is the impairment of gastric emptying (see above). That is why pylompilasty (dilatation of the pylorus) is usually done with the procedure.</p>
<p>Vagotomy can be tested by insulin injection to induce hypoglycemia because hypoglycemia stimulates the vagus nerve, which increases gastric secretion. Therefore, any increase in gastric secretion following the injection indicates that vagotomy is not successful.</p>
<p>550
The view of medical physiology 17 APRIL</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="gastric-mutility">GASTRIC MUTILITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gastric-mutility" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Many types of movement appear in the stomach as food enters it. These movements allow storage of food for some time with minimal rise in intra-gastric pressure and facilitate gradual gastric emptying. They include:</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-receptive-relaxation">1. Receptive relaxation:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-receptive-relaxation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs at the upper part of the stomach to accommodate food with minimal increase in pressure (Laplace law). It is mediated by the vagus.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-peristalsis">2. Peristalsis:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-peristalsis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Sweeps down towards the lower part of the stomach to allow chyme to pass through the pylorus. Its frequency is about 3-4 times per min. It is controlled by the basic electrical rhythm (see below).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-migrating-motor-complex-mmc">3. Migrating Motor Complex (MMC):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-migrating-motor-complex-mmc" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Also known as hunger contractions. These are peristalsis waves that occur every 60 minutes during the fasting state (between meals) and disappear upon eating. They pass from the empty stomach through the small intestine, to reach the ileocecal valve.</li>
<li>Their exact function is unknown. However, they remove remnants of food &amp; therefore prevent growth of bacteria.</li>
<li>The hormone "mobile" which is secreted by upper small intestine during the interdigestive period may be responsible for initiation of MMC.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-basic-electrical-rhythm-ber">The basic electrical rhythm (BER):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-basic-electrical-rhythm-ber" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>These spontaneous rhythmic fluctuations in the membrane potential vary between (-45 &amp; -65 mv). It occurs in smooth muscle of all parts of the GIT except the esophagus and the proximal part of the stomach.</li>
<li>It is recorded in form of slow waves &amp; spikes. Depolarization in each spike is caused by Ca++ influx &amp; repolarization is caused by K+ efflux.</li>
<li>The frequency of slow waves (i.e. rate of BER) is 4/min in stomach, 12/min in duodenum, 6/min in ileum, 5/min in cecum and 16/min in sigmoid colon.</li>
</ul>
<p>551
The view of medical physiology 17 APRIL</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="gastric-mutility">GASTRIC MUTILITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gastric-mutility" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Many types of movement appear in the stomach as food enters it. These movements allow storage of food for some time with minimal rise in intra-gastric pressure and facilitate gradual gastric emptying. They include:</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-receptive-relaxation">1. Receptive relaxation:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-receptive-relaxation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs at the upper part of the stomach to accommodate food with minimal increase in pressure (Laplace law). It is mediated by the vagus.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-peristalsis">2. Peristalsis:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-peristalsis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Sweeps down towards the lower part of the stomach to allow chyme to pass through the pylorus. Its frequency is about 3-4 times per min. It is controlled by the basic electrical rhythm (see below).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-migrating-motor-complex-mmc">3. Migrating Motor Complex (MMC):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-migrating-motor-complex-mmc" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Also known as hunger contractions. These are peristalsis waves that occur every 60 minutes during the fasting state (between meals) and disappear upon eating. They pass from the empty stomach through the small intestine, to reach the ileocecal valve.</li>
<li>Their exact function is unknown. However, they remove remnants of food &amp; therefore prevent growth of bacteria.</li>
<li>The hormone "mobile" which is secreted by upper small intestine during the interdigestive period may be responsible for initiation of MMC.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-basic-electrical-rhythm-ber">The basic electrical rhythm (BER):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-basic-electrical-rhythm-ber" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>These spontaneous rhythmic fluctuations in the membrane potential vary between (-45 &amp; -65 mv). It occurs in smooth muscle of all parts of the GIT except the esophagus and the proximal part of the stomach.</li>
<li>It is recorded in form of slow waves &amp; spikes. Depolarization in each spike is caused by Ca++ influx &amp; repolarization is caused by K+ efflux.</li>
<li>The frequency of slow waves (i.e. rate of BER) is 4/min in stomach, 12/min in duodenum, 6/min in ileum, 9/min in cecum and 16/min in sigmoid colon.</li>
</ul>
<p>552
The view of medical physiology 17 APRIL</p>
<p>The number of spikes per each wave is increased by acetylcholine and decreased by norepinephrine.</p>
<p>The function of the BER is co-ordination of peristalsis &amp; other types of GIT quality (This is confirmed by the finding that in its absence peristalsis becomes popular).</p>
<p>Fig. 6.11: The basic electrical rhythm</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-dbf19e01.jpeg" alt="img-379.jpeg"></p>
<p>The pyloric sphincter</p>
<p>An atypical sphincter (since it is open except when peristalsis reaches it).</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>It acts with the duodenum and the antral part of the stomach to control gastric emptying.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When peristalsis reaches the lower part of the stomach, it causes sequential contraction of the antrum followed by the pylorus and then the duodenum.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The pylorus takes slightly longer time in contraction; this prevents reflux of duodenal contents into the stomach and allows grinding and mixing of solid particles in the stomach.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Factors affecting gastric emptying</p>
<ul>
<li>Longitudinal mucosal folds in the stomach. Allow rapid emptying of liquids.</li>
<li>Amount of food: Emptying is faster with higher intra-gastric volume.</li>
<li>Type of food: Emptying of liquids is faster than solids &amp; emptying of CHO is faster than protein and proteins faster than lipids.</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig. 6.11: The basic electrical rhythm</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-27c4d382.jpeg" alt="img-380.jpeg"></p>
<p>The number of spikes per each wave is increased by acetylcholine and decreased by norepinephrine.</p>
<p>The function of the BER is co-ordination of peristalsis &amp; other types of GIT quality (This is confirmed by the finding that in its absence peristalsis becomes popular).</p>
<p>Fig. 6.11: The basic electrical rhythm</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-e9acf3d4.jpeg" alt="img-381.jpeg"></p>
<p>The pyloric sphincter</p>
<p>An atypical sphincter (since it is open except when peristalsis reaches it).</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>It acts with the duodenum and the antral part of the stomach to control gastric emptying.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When peristalsis reaches the lower part of the stomach, it causes sequential contraction of the antrum followed by the pylorus and then the duodenum.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The pylorus takes slightly longer time in contraction; this prevents reflux of duodenal contents into the stomach and allows grinding and mixing of solid particles in the stomach.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Factors affecting gastric emptying</p>
<ul>
<li>Longitudinal mucosal folds in the stomach. Allow rapid emptying of liquids.</li>
<li>Amount of food: Emptying is faster with higher intra-gastric volume.</li>
<li>Type of food: Emptying of liquids is faster than solids &amp; emptying of CHO is faster than protein and proteins faster than lipids.</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig. 6.11: The basic electrical rhythm</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-e9acf3d4.jpeg" alt="img-382.jpeg"></p>
<p>The number of spikes per each wave is increased by acetylcholine and increased by norepinephrine.</p>
<p>The function of the BER is co-ordination of peristalsis &amp; other types of GIT quality (This is confirmed by the finding that in its absence peristalsis becomes popular).</p>
<p>Fig. 6.11: The basic electrical rhythm</p>
<p>248
The Journal of Medical Microbiology 17 (2007)
249
The Journal of Medical Microbiology 17 (2007)</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Osmolarity of chymo: Emptying of hypotonic chyme is faster than hypertonic chyme (this is due to a neural mechanism stimulated by distortion or shrinkage of osmoreceptors in duodenum).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>pH of chymo: Emptying of alkaline chyme is faster than acidic (due to a neural mechanism stimulated by chemoreceptors in the duodenum).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hormones: Secretin, CCK &amp; GIP decrease gastric emptying. Concerning gastric, it increases gastric motility; however, it also increases intestinal motility. This increases resistance in the intestine against evacuation of gastric contents. Therefore, the overall effect is reduction in gastric emptying.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Other factors that decrease emptying include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Distention of the duodenum</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Vagotomy</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Emotions like "feel" (unlike excitement, which increases gastric emptying).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Osmolarity of chyme: Emptying of hypotonic chyme is faster than hypertonic chyme (this is due to a neural mechanism stimulated by distortion or shrinkage of osmoreceptors in duodenum).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>pH of chyme: Emptying of alkaline chyme is faster than acidic (due to a neural mechanism stimulated by chemoreceptors in the duodenum).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hormones: Secretin, CCK &amp; GIP decrease gastric emptying. Concerning gastric, it increases gastric motility; however, it also increases intestinal motility. This increases resistance in the intestine against evacuation of gastric contents. Therefore, the overall effect is reduction in gastric emptying.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Other factors that decrease emptying include:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Distention of the duodenum</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Vagotomy</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Emotions like "feel" (unlike excitement, which increases gastric emptying).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Osmolarity of chyme: Emptying of hypotonic chyme is faster than hypertonic chyme (this is due to a neural mechanism stimulated by distortion or shrinkage of osmoreceptors in duodenum).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>pH of chyme: Emptying of alkaline chyme is faster than acidic (due to a neural mechanism stimulated by chemoreceptors in the duodenum).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hormones: Secretin, CCK &amp; GIP decrease gastric emptying. Concerning gastric, it increases gastric motility; however, it also increases intestinal motility. This increases resistance in the intestine against evacuation of gastric contents. Therefore, the overall effect is reduction in gastric emptying.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Other factors that decrease emptying include:</p>
</li>

<p>Distention of the duodenum</p>

<p>Vagotomy</p>
</li>
