</ul>
<p>107</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="continued-on-emergency">CONTINUED ON EMERGENCY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#continued-on-emergency" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>This is a protective reflex for expulsion of harmful materials in the stomach, carefully through the mouth.</li>
<li>It consists of the following components:</li>
<li>Receptors (and their stimuli "situation")</li>
<li>Some of the receptors that induce vomiting are situated in the GIT (pharynx, stomach, &amp; duodenum).</li>
<li>They are stimulated by chemical irritation, mechanical irritation or over-detection.</li>
<li>Other sites that can be stimulated to cause vomiting.</li>
<li>The bile ducts, peritoneum, heart and many other organs. Signals from these organs reach the vomiting center in response to certain diseases affecting them for example, myocardial infarction and obstructive jaundice.</li>
<li>Vestibular system: stimulated by motion sickness.</li>
<li>The Chemoreceptor trigger zone (CRTZ) on lateral wall of the fourth ventricle in the medulla. It discharges directly to the vomiting center.</li>
<li>It is stimulated by circulating chemicals (including drugs). The effects of these chemicals on the CRTZ can be inhibited by serotonin antagonists or dopamine antagonists.</li>
<li>It is also stimulated by vestibular stimulation (motion sickness).</li>
<li>Frontal lobe: stimulated by psychic stimuli "like shocking sites or smells."
(Note: the last 3 stimuli are known as central receptors).</li>
<li>Afferents from the stomach:</li>
<li>Autonomic nerves (sympathetic &amp; vagus)</li>
<li>Vomiting center:</li>
<li>Present bilaterally in the medulla oblongata</li>
<li>Effecents:</li>
<li>The frontal nerves and the spinal nerves that supply the effectors</li>
<li>Effectors:</li>
</ul>
<p>108</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="continued-on-emergency">CONTINUED ON EMERGENCY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#continued-on-emergency" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>This is a protective reflex for expulsion of harmful materials in the stomach, carefully through the mouth.</li>
<li>It consists of the following components:</li>
<li>Receptors (and their stimuli "situation")</li>
<li>Some of the receptors that induce vomiting are situated in the GIT (pharynx, stomach, &amp; duodenum).</li>
<li>They are stimulated by chemical irritation, mechanical irritation or over-detection.</li>
<li>Other sites that can be stimulated to cause vomiting.</li>
<li>The bile ducts, peritoneum, heart and many other organs. Signals from these organs reach the vomiting center in response to certain diseases affecting them for example, myocardial infarction and obstructive jaundice.</li>
<li>Vestibular system: stimulated by motion sickness.</li>
<li>The Chemoreceptor trigger zone (CRTZ) on lateral wall of the fourth ventricle in the medulla. It discharges directly to the vomiting center.</li>
<li>It is stimulated by circulating chemicals (including drugs). The effects of these chemicals on the CRTZ can be inhibited by serotonin antagonists or dopamine antagonists.</li>
<li>It is also stimulated by vestibular stimulation (motion sickness).</li>
<li>Frontal lobe: stimulated by psychic stimuli "like shocking sites or smells."
(Note: the last 3 stimuli are known as central receptors).</li>
<li>Afferents from the stomach:</li>
<li>Autonomic nerves (sympathetic &amp; vagus)</li>
<li>Vomiting center:</li>
<li>Present bilaterally in the medulla oblongata</li>
<li>Effectors:</li>
<li>The frontal nerves and the spinal nerves that supply the effectors</li>
<li>Effectors:</li>
</ul>
<p>109</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="continued-on-emergency">CONTINUED ON EMERGENCY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#continued-on-emergency" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>This is a protective reflex for expulsion of harmful materials in the stomach, carefully through the mouth.</li>
<li>It consists of the following components:</li>
<li>Receptors (and their stimuli "situation")</li>
<li>Some of the receptors that induce vomiting are situated in the GIT (pharynx, stomach, &amp; duodenum).</li>
<li>They are stimulated by chemical irritation, mechanical irritation or over-detection.</li>
<li>Other sites that can be stimulated to cause vomiting.</li>
<li>The bile ducts, peritoneum, heart and many other organs. Signals from these organs reach the vomiting center in response to certain diseases affecting them for example, myocardial infarction and obstructive jaundice.</li>
<li>Vestibular system: stimulated by motion sickness.</li>
<li>The Chemoreceptor trigger zone (CRTZ) on lateral wall of the fourth ventricle in the medulla. It discharges directly to the vomiting center.</li>
<li>It is stimulated by circulating chemicals (including drugs). The effects of these chemicals on the CRTZ can be inhibited by serotonin antagonists or dopamine antagonists.</li>
<li>It is also stimulated by vestibular stimulation (motion sickness).</li>
<li>Frontal lobe: stimulated by psychic stimuli "like shocking sites or smells."
(Note: the last 3 stimuli are known as central receptors).</li>
<li>Afferents from the stomach:</li>
<li>Autonomic nerves (sympathetic &amp; vagus)</li>
<li>Vomiting center:</li>
<li>Present bilaterally in the medulla oblongata</li>
<li>Effectors:</li>
<li>The frontal nerves and the spinal nerves that supply the effectors</li>
<li>Effectors:</li>
</ul>
<p>110</p>
<ul>
<li>All the following effectors participate in the act of vomiting: Abdominal muscles, diaphragm, intestine, stomach, esophagus &amp; mouth.</li>
</ul>
<p>The act of vomiting:</p>
<ul>
<li>Vomiting starts with cessation of respiration at mid inspiration (= closure of the glottis &amp; nasopharynx).</li>
<li>Violent contractions of abdominal muscles &amp; diaphragm occur to squeeze the stomach and increase its pressure.</li>
<li>Reverse peristalsis occurs to evacuate the upper intestine into the stomach.</li>
<li>In the mean time, the wall of the stomach relaxes, the lower esophageal sphincter open and the upper esophageal sphincter suddenly open.</li>
<li>The high intra-gastric pressure allows gastric contents to be expected through the esophagus to the outside.</li>
</ul>
<p>Associated with vomiting:</p>
<ul>
<li>Salivation</li>
<li>Nausea</li>
<li>Sweating</li>
<li>Skin vasoconstriction</li>
<li>Slowing of the heart rate</li>
</ul>
<p>Remember that: Because vomiting causes slowing of the heart rate, induction of vomiting is used sometimes for treatment of supraventricular tachycardia.</p>
<ul>
<li>All the following effectors participate in the act of vomiting: Abdominal muscles, diaphragm, intestine, stomach, esophagus &amp; mouth.</li>
</ul>
<p>The act of vomiting:</p>
<ul>
<li>Vomiting starts with cessation of respiration at mid inspiration (= closure of the glottis &amp; nasopharynx).</li>
<li>Violent contractions of abdominal muscles &amp; diaphragm occur to squeeze the stomach and increase its pressure.</li>
<li>Reverse peristalsis occurs to evacuate the upper intestine into the stomach.</li>
<li>In the mean time, the wall of the stomach relaxes, the lower esophageal sphincter open and the upper esophageal sphincter suddenly open.</li>
<li>The high intra-gastric pressure allows gastric contents to be expected through the esophagus to the outside.</li>
</ul>

<li>Sweating</li>
<li>Skin vasoconstriction</li>
<li>Slowing of the heart rate</li>
</ul>

</ul>

<li>Violent contractions of abdominal muscles &amp; diaphragm occur to squeeze the stomach and increase its pressure.</li>
<li>Reverse peristalsis occurs to evacuate the upper intestine into the stomach.</li>
<li>In the mean time, the wall of the stomach relaxes, the lower esophageal sphincter open and the upper esophageal sphincter suddenly open.</li>
<li>The high intra-gastric pressure allows gastric contents to be expected through the esophagus to the outside.</li>
</ul>

<li>Nausea</li>
<li>Sweating</li>

<li>Slowing of the heart rate</li>

<p>12</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="section-10-self-assessment-bottles">SECTION 10: SELF ASSESSMENT - (Bottles)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-10-self-assessment-bottles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-describe-situation-of-the-stomach-is-identified-by">1. Describe situation of the stomach is identified by:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-describe-situation-of-the-stomach-is-identified-by" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a. Ingestion of a heavy meal
b. Parasympathetic stimulation
c. Sympathetic stimulation
d. Regulatory
e. Administration of COX-PZ</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-sales-is-characterized-by">2. Sales is characterized by:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-sales-is-characterized-by" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a. HCO₃ concentration lower than plasma
b. Presence of proteolytic enzymes
c. Absence of glucose
d. pH similar to that of plasma
e. Hepatobody relative to plasma</p>

Peptic ulcer:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-peptic-ulcer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a. Is required primarily by excessive secretion of HCI
b. Can be treated with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs like aspirin
c. Is stimulated with histolytically type I infection in the majority of patients
d. Treatment involves reduction of cAMP within the cell</p>

<p>THE EXCERINE PANCREAS</p>
<p>STRUCTURE</p>
<ul>
<li>Consists of lobules. Each lobule consists of acini &amp; ducts.</li>
<li>The ducts are joined together to form the main pancreatic duct. This opera together with the common bile duct into the duodenum at the ampulla of Vater.</li>
<li>The opening at the ampulla is guarded by the sphincter of Oddi (choleibrachy-duodenal sphincter).</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 6.12: The pancreas</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-c749c677.jpeg" alt="img-383.jpeg"></p>
<p>PANCREATIC SECRETION</p>
<p>Characteristics:</p>
<ul>
<li>Volume: 1.0 L</li>
<li>Osmolarity: bottoms</li>
<li>pH: Alkaline (B) to neutralize gastric acid (together with bile and intestinal secretion)</li>
<li>Contents: Water, electrolytes (secreted by ductular &amp; centroacinar cells) &amp; digestive enzymes (secreted by acinar cells)</li>
</ul>
<p>214</p>
<p>The text of method [Appendix] is "other"</p>

<p>17
The uses of medical physiology: 6th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-paramedic-enzymes">The paramedic enzymes:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-paramedic-enzymes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The main digestive enzymes in the GIT. These enzymes are essential for digestion (i.e. absence of these enzymes impairs digestion and consequently absorption is also impaired).</li>
<li>The enzymes include:</li>
<li>Enzymes for protein digestion</li>
<li>Acidicant in an inactive form.</li>
<li>Soluble: Trypanogen, chymotrypsinogen, prostastase and proarboxypeptidase.</li>
<li>Activation occurs as follows: fat trypanogen is activated to trypsin in the bacterium by enteropeptidase enzyme (also known as enterokinase), and then trypsin activates the other enzymes (autocatalysis) as follows:</li>
<li>Other trypanogen is activated to trypsin.</li>
<li>Chymotrypsinogen is activated to chymotrypsin.</li>
<li>Prostastase is activated to elastase.</li>
<li>Procarboxypeptidase is activated to carboxypeptidase.</li>
<li>Ketamine that: These enzymes are secreted in inactive form to prevent subdigestion of the pancreas. They are activated within the intestinal lumen, not in the pancreatic duct. Activation within the pancreatic duct is inhibited by a trypsin inhibitor found in the pancreatic juice.</li>
<li>Enzymes for carbohydrate digestion</li>
<li>Pancreatic α-amylase: Acts on starch.</li>
<li>Enzymes for lipid digestion</li>
<li>Pancreatic lipase: For triglycerides.</li>
<li>Ox lipase: Bound to lipase to increase its activity. It needs activation by trypsin.</li>
<li>Cholesterol esterase: For cholesterol esters.</li>
<li>Phospholipase A₂: For phospholipids. It also needs activation by trypsin.</li>
<li>Enzymes for nucleic acid digestion</li>
<li>Ribonuclease: For RNA digestion</li>
</ul>
<p>18
The uses of medical physiology: 6th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-paramedic-enzymes">The paramedic enzymes:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-paramedic-enzymes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The main digestive enzymes in the GIT. These enzymes are essential for digestion (i.e. absence of these enzymes impairs digestion and consequently absorption is also impaired).</li>
<li>The enzymes include:</li>
<li>Enzymes for protein digestion</li>
<li>Acidicant in an inactive form.</li>
<li>Soluble: Trypanogen, chymotrypsinogen, prostastase and proarboxypeptidase.</li>
<li>Activation occurs as follows: fat trypanogen is activated to trypsin in the bacterium by enteropeptidase enzyme (also known as enterokinase), and then trypsin activates the other enzymes (autocatalysis) as follows:</li>
<li>Other trypanogen is activated to trypsin.</li>
<li>Chymotrypsinogen is activated to chymotrypsin.</li>
<li>Prostastase is activated to elastase.</li>
<li>Procarboxypeptidase is activated to carboxypeptidase.</li>
<li>Ketamine that: These enzymes are secreted in inactive form to prevent subdigestion of the pancreas. They are activated within the intestinal lumen, not in the pancreatic duct. Activation within the pancreatic duct is inhibited by a trypsin inhibitor found in the pancreatic juice.</li>
<li>Enzymes for carbohydrate digestion</li>
<li>Pancreatic α-amylase: Acts on starch.</li>
<li>Enzymes for lipid digestion</li>
<li>Pancreatic lipase: For triglycerides.</li>
<li>Ox lipase: Bound to lipase to increase its activity. It needs activation by trypsin.</li>
<li>Cholesterol esterase: For cholesterol esters.</li>
<li>Phospholipase A₂: For phospholipids. It also needs activation by trypsin.</li>
<li>Enzymes for nucleic acid digestion</li>
<li>Ribonuclease: For RNA digestion</li>
</ul>
<p>19
The uses of medical physiology: 6th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-paramedic-enzymes">The paramedic enzymes:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-paramedic-enzymes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The main digestive enzymes in the GIT. These enzymes are essential for digestion (i.e. absence of these enzymes impairs digestion and consequently absorption is also impaired).</li>
<li>The enzymes include:</li>
<li>Enzymes for protein digestion</li>
<li>Acidicant in an inactive form.</li>
<li>Soluble: Trypanogen, chymotrypsinogen, prostastase and proarboxypeptidase.</li>
<li>Activation occurs as follows: fat trypanogen is activated to trypsin in the bacterium by enteropeptidase enzyme (also known as enterokinase), and then trypsin activates the other enzymes (autocatalysis) as follows:</li>
<li>Other trypanogen is activated to trypsin.</li>
<li>Chymotrypsinogen is activated to chymotrypsin.</li>
<li>Prostastase is activated to elastase.</li>
<li>Procarboxypeptidase is activated to carboxypeptidase.</li>
<li>Ketamine that: These enzymes are secreted in inactive form to prevent subdigestion of the pancreas. They are activated within the intestinal lumen, not in the pancreatic duct. Activation within the pancreatic duct is inhibited by a trypsin inhibitor found in the pancreatic juice.</li>
<li>Enzymes for carbohydrate digestion</li>
<li>Pancreatic α-amylase: Acts on starch.</li>
<li>Enzymes for lipid digestion</li>
<li>Pancreatic lipase: For triglycerides.</li>
<li>Ox lipase: Bound to lipase to increase its activity. It needs activation by trypsin.</li>
<li>Cholesterol esterase: For cholesterol esters.</li>
<li>Phospholipase A₂: For phospholipids. It also needs activation by trypsin.</li>
<li>Enzymes for nucleic acid digestion</li>
<li>Ribonuclease: For RNA digestion</li>
</ul>
<p>The uses of medical physiology: 6th edition</p>
<p>-Deoxyribonuclease: For DNA digestion</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="changes-in-toxic-composition-of-pancreatic-secretion">Changes in toxic composition of pancreatic secretion:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#changes-in-toxic-composition-of-pancreatic-secretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>After secretion into the duct lumen, bicarbonate is maltearbed back in exchange to chloride which is secreted. Therefore high flow rate decreases this exchange resulting in more bicarbonate and less chloride in pancreatic secretion (i.e. bicarbonate &amp; chloride are flow dependent).</li>
<li>Sodium &amp; potassium concentrations remain constant without difference in concentrations between high or slow rates of secretion (i.e. sodium &amp; potassium are flow independent).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="control-of-pancreatic-secretion">CONTROL OF PANCREATIC SECRETION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-pancreatic-secretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>By neural &amp; hormonal mechanisms.</li>
<li>These mechanisms are activated during the following phases: Cephalic phase, gastric phase &amp; intestinal phase.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="cephalic-phase">Cephalic phase<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cephalic-phase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>It is the phase when food is in front or within the mouth (not in the stomach).</li>
<li>Two neural reflexes are activated:</li>
<li>Conditioned reflex (activated by sight, smell or thoughts about appetizing food).</li>
<li>Non-conditioned reflex (activated by presence of food in the mouth).</li>
<li>Both reflexes are mediated through the vagus nerve.</li>
<li>The vagus acts on acinar cells to release pancreatic enzymes by two ways. Directly by acting on acinar cells &amp; indirectly by stimulating gastrin release from the stomach (see above).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="gastric-phase">Gastric Phase<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gastric-phase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>It is the phase when food reaches the stomach.</li>
<li>Here pancreatic secretion "rich in enzymes" is mediated by both neural &amp; hormonal mechanisms.</li>
</ul>
<p>276</p>
<p>-Deoxyribonuclease: For DNA digestion</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="changes-in-toxic-composition-of-pancreatic-secretion">Changes in toxic composition of pancreatic secretion:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#changes-in-toxic-composition-of-pancreatic-secretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="cephalic-phase">Cephalic phase<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cephalic-phase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="control-of-pancreatic-secretion">CONTROL OF PANCREATIC SECRETION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-pancreatic-secretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>By neural &amp; hormonal mechanisms.</li>
<li>These mechanisms are activated during the following phases: Cephalic phase, gastric phase &amp; intestinal phase.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="cephalic-phase">Cephalic phase<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cephalic-phase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>It is the phase when food is in front or within the mouth (not in the stomach).</li>
<li>Two neural reflexes are activated:</li>
<li>Conditioned reflex (activated by sight, smell or thoughts about appetizing food).</li>
<li>Non-conditioned reflex (activated by presence of food in the mouth).</li>
<li>Both reflexes are mediated through the vagus nerve.</li>
<li>The vagus acts on acinar cells to release pancreatic enzymes by two ways. Directly by acting on acinar cells &amp; indirectly by stimulating gastrin release from the stomach (see above).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="gastric-phase">Gastric Phase<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gastric-phase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>It is the phase when food reaches the stomach.</li>
<li>Here pancreatic secretion "rich in enzymes" is mediated by both neural &amp; hormonal mechanisms.</li>
</ul>
<p>276</p>
<p>The work of Leichard, Joplin &amp; Kapp - 277</p>
<p>The neural mechanism. Distention of the stomach stimulates pancreatic secretion by a vaginvagal reflex.</p>
<p>Hemoral mechanism: Food in the stomach stimulates release of gastrin through gastric distention (Lar L-amino acids). Gastrin stimulates pancreatic secretion rich in enzymes.</p>
<p>Intestinal phase:</p>
<ul>
<li>This is the main phase for pancreatic secretion. It is mediated through hormonal mechanisms. The hormones are released when chyme reaches the small intestine; they are two hormones: Secretin &amp; COX-P2.</li>
</ul>
<p>SECRETIN:</p>
<ul>
<li>Peptide hormone (27aa), released by 5 cells in the duodenum.</li>
<li>Similar in structure to VIP, GIP &amp; Glucagon (these hormones constitute the Secretin family).</li>
</ul>
<p>History: Bayliss and Sterling in 1922 suggested that a chemical substance released by the small intestine into the blood stimulates pancreatic secretion. This led to the identification of secretin, the first hormone to be discovered.</p>
<p>Stimuli:</p>
<ul>
<li>Low pH (mainly)</li>
<li>Amino &amp; fatty acids</li>
</ul>
<p>Mechanism of action:</p>
<ul>
<li>Secretin has cell membrane receptors.</li>
<li>Its effects are mediated via the second messenger "vAMP".</li>
</ul>
<p>Actions:</p>
<ul>
<li>Acts on ductular &amp; centrosolar cells of the pancreas to release water &amp; electrolytes (especially bicarbonate).</li>
<li>Acts on the biliary tract to release water &amp; electrolytes (it increases flow of bile, i.e. it is cholesterol).</li>
<li>Inhibits gastrin and gastric acid secretion.</li>
<li>Inhibits intestinal motility.</li>
</ul>
<p>The neural mechanism. Distention of the stomach stimulates pancreatic secretion by a vaginvagal reflex.</p>
<p>Hemoral mechanism: Food in the stomach stimulates release of gastrin through gastric distention (Lar L-amino acids). Gastrin stimulates pancreatic secretion rich in enzymes.</p>
<p>Intestinal phase:</p>
<ul>
<li>This is the main phase for pancreatic secretion. It is mediated through hormonal mechanisms. The hormones are released when chyme reaches the small intestine; they are two hormones: Secretin &amp; COX-P2.</li>
</ul>
<p>SECRETIN:</p>
<ul>
<li>Peptide hormone (27aa), released by 5 cells in the duodenum.</li>
<li>Similar in structure to VIP, GIP &amp; Glucagon (these hormones constitute the Secretin family).</li>
</ul>

<li>Amino &amp; fatty acids</li>
</ul>

<li>Its effects are mediated via the second messenger "vAMP".</li>
</ul>

<li>Acts on ductular &amp; centrosolar cells of the pancreas to release water &amp; electrolytes (especially bicarbonate).</li>
<li>Acts on the biliary tract to release water &amp; electrolytes (it increases flow of bile, i.e. it is cholesterol).</li>
<li>Inhibits gastrin and gastric acid secretion.</li>
<li>Inhibits intestinal motility.</li>
</ul>

<p>Hemoral mechanism: Food in the stomach stimulates release of gastrin through gastric distention (Lar L-amino acids). Gastrin stimulates pancreatic secretion rich in enzymes.</p>

<li>Peptide hormone (27aa), released by 5 cells in the duodenum.</li>
<li>Similar in structure to VIP, GIP &amp; Glucagon (these hormones constitute the Secretin family).</li>
</ul>

<li>Amino &amp; fatty acids</li>
</ul>

<li>Its effects are mediated via the second messenger "vAMP".</li>
</ul>
<p>Actions:</p>
<ul>
<li>Acts on ductular &amp; centrosolar cells of the pancreas to release water &amp; electrolytes (especially bicarbonate).</li>
<li>Acts on the biliary tract to release water &amp; electrolytes (it increases flow of bile, i.e. it is cholesterol).</li>
<li>Inhibits gastrin and gastric acid secretion.</li>
<li>Inhibits intestinal motility.</li>
</ul>
<p>The neural mechanism. Distention of the stomach stimulates pancreatic secretion by a vaginvagal reflex.</p>
<p>378
The role of various physiology 17 of 24</p>
<ul>
<li>Releases the lower esophageal sphincter &amp; contracts the ileo-caecal valve.</li>
<li>Contracts the pyloric sphincter and decreases gastric emptying.</li>
<li>Augments actions of COX on the pancreas.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cox-pz-cholecystokinin-pancregzywin">COX-PZ (CHOLECYSTOKININ-PANCREGZYWIN)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cox-pz-cholecystokinin-pancregzywin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Peptide hormone, similar in structure to gastrin (both hormones constitute the gastrin family).</li>
<li>Produced by: I cells of the duodenum and by some neurons in the brain and GIT</li>
<li>Like gastrin it is found in many forms (5, 12, 30, 39, 58 amino acids)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="stimuli">Stimuli:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stimuli" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Luminal amino &amp; fatty acids (mainly)</li>
<li>Like pH in the duodenum</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanism-of-action">Mechanism of action:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanism-of-action" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Has cell membrane receptors.</li>
<li>Its effects are mediated via 'phospholipase C'.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="actions">Actions:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#actions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Acts on pancreatic acinar cells to stimulate secretion of enzymes.</li>
<li>Contracts the gall bladder (chicagogue) &amp; relaxes the Oddi sphincter.</li>
<li>Augments actions of secretion on the pancreas.</li>
<li>Inhibits gastric emptying.</li>
<li>Inhibits gastrin and gastric acid secretion (in large doses).</li>
<li>Releases the lower esophageal sphincter &amp; contracts the ileo-caecal valve.</li>
<li>Contracts the pyloric sphincter (decreases gastric emptying).</li>
<li>Stimulates intestinal motility.</li>
</ul>
<p>379
The role of various physiology 17 of 24</p>
<p>270
The uses of medical physiology of medicine</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abnormalities-of-the-pancreas">ABNORMALITIES OF THE PANCREAS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities-of-the-pancreas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acute-pancreatitis">Acute pancreatitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-pancreatitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs due to activation of pancreatic enzymes within the pancreatic duct, resulting in autodigestion of the pancreas; as occurs when the common bile duct is obstructed by gallstones.</li>
<li>Symptoms include severe upper abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting.</li>
<li>High amount of pancreatic enzymes may enter the blood (e.g. amylase &amp; lipase). Presence of high concentration of these enzymes in the plasma can be used for diagnosis.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chronic-pancreatitis">Chronic pancreatitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chronic-pancreatitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Characterized by release of the amount of pancreatic enzymes in the duodenum, resulting in maldigestion &amp; malabsorption of protein and fat.</li>
<li>Large amounts of fat (&gt; 5 grams/day) appear in stool (&gt; fatty stool or steatorhose).</li>
</ul>
<p>271
The uses of medical physiology of medicine</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abnormalities-of-the-pancreas">ABNORMALITIES OF THE PANCREAS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities-of-the-pancreas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acute-pancreatitis">Acute pancreatitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-pancreatitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs due to activation of pancreatic enzymes within the pancreatic duct, resulting in autodigestion of the pancreas; as occurs when the common bile duct is obstructed by gallstones.</li>
<li>Symptoms include severe upper abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting.</li>
<li>High amount of pancreatic enzymes may enter the blood (e.g. amylase &amp; lipase). Presence of high concentration of these enzymes in the plasma can be used for diagnosis.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chronic-pancreatitis">Chronic pancreatitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chronic-pancreatitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Characterized by release of the amount of pancreatic enzymes in the duodenum, resulting in maldigestion &amp; malabsorption of protein and fat.</li>
<li>Large amounts of fat (&gt; 5 grams/day) appear in stool (&gt; fatty stool or steatorhose).</li>
</ul>
<p>272
The uses of medical physiology of medicine</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abnormalities-of-the-pancreas">ABNORMALITIES OF THE PANCREAS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities-of-the-pancreas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acute-pancreatitis">Acute pancreatitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-pancreatitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs due to activation of pancreatic enzymes within the pancreatic duct, resulting in autodigestion of the pancreas; as occurs when the common bile duct is obstructed by gallstones.</li>
<li>Symptoms include severe upper abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting.</li>
<li>High amount of pancreatic enzymes may enter the blood (e.g. amylase &amp; lipase). Presence of high concentration of these enzymes in the plasma can be used for diagnosis.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chronic-pancreatitis">Chronic pancreatitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chronic-pancreatitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Characterized by release of the amount of pancreatic enzymes in the duodenum, resulting in maldigestion &amp; malabsorption of protein and fat.</li>
<li>Large amounts of fat (&gt; 5 grams/day) appear in stool (&gt; fatty stool or steatorhose).</li>
</ul>
<p>THE LIVER AND BILE</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-liver">THE LIVER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-liver" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="anatomy">Anatomy:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anatomy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Weight: about 1.5 Kg.</li>
<li>Consists of lobules, each lobule consists of many cellular plates radiating between a central vein &amp; a portal tract.</li>
<li>Between the cellular columns in each plate are bile canaliculi.</li>
<li>Between the cellular plates are hepatic sinusoids (lined by endothelial cells &amp; kupffer cells).</li>
<li>The hepatic sinusoids receive blood supply from both hepatic artery and portal vein (the total liver blood flow = 1.5 L/min; 1L/min from the portal vein &amp; 0.5 L/min from the hepatic artery. Then blood drains to central veins, which drain to hepatic veins and then to the inferior vena cava (IVC).</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig 8.13: Histology of the Liver</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-8668592a.jpeg" alt="img-386.jpeg"></p>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<ul>
<li>Between the sinusoids &amp; cellular plates there are spaces of Disse.</li>
<li>These spaces drain lymph to lymphatic vessels (The liver produces one half of all lymph formed in the body; lymphatic flow = 1 ml/min).</li>
<li>Because of the large pores in the hepatic sinusoids, they are permeable to both fluid and protein. Therefore large quantities of protein move into the spaces of Disse (Protein concentration in the lymph is only slightly lower than that of the plasma).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-functional-unit">The functional unit:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-functional-unit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The functional unit of the liver is the <strong>hepatic acinus</strong>. It represents the hepatocytes that lie more near to afferent vessels (i.e. vessels in the portal triads, away from central veins).</li>
<li>Each acinus can be divided into 3 zones: 1, 2 and 3.</li>
<li>Zone 1 is the nearest zone to afferent vessels (hepatic arterioles carrying well oxygenated blood). For this reason interruption of hepatic blood flow results in necrosis of cells at zone 3 rather than zone 1 (anoxic damage).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-76c1c7bb.jpeg" alt="img-387.jpeg">
Fig 8.14: Hepatic acinus</p>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-the-liver">Functions of the Liver<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-the-liver" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Synthesis of plasma proteins (albumin, globulins &amp; fibrinogen).</li>
<li>Note that the liver forms α and β globulins (most of which are clotting factors). However, gamma globulins (= the immunoglobulins) are not synthesized by the liver.</li>
<li>Synthesis &amp; secretion of bile (see functions of bile).</li>
<li>Metabolism of CHO, proteins, fats and hormones (especially steroid hormones).</li>
<li>Excretion of end products of metabolism (excreted through bile).</li>
<li>Storage of glycogen, iron and vitamins (vitamin A, D &amp; B₁₂).</li>
<li>Detoxification of toxic substances, drugs and ammonia.</li>
<li>Note that the liver converts ammonia, which is toxic, to urea, which is non-toxic except in very high levels as in renal failure.</li>
<li>Immunity by Kupffer cells (phagocytic cells derived from monocytes).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bile">BILE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bile" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Yellowish to greenish fluid secreted continuously by hepatocytes into the biliary system.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="characteristics-of-bile">Characteristics of bile:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#characteristics-of-bile" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Color: Golden yellow or greenish fluid</li>
<li>Taste: Bitter taste</li>
<li>Osmolarity: Isotonic</li>
<li>pH: Slightly alkaline</li>
<li>Contents:</li>
<li>Water &amp; electrolytes (K⁺/Na⁺/Ca⁺/HCO₃⁻/Cl⁻…)</li>
<li>Bile salts</li>
<li>Bile pigments (bilirubin)</li>
<li>Cholesterol/Phospholipids</li>
<li>Alkaline phosphatase enzyme</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-gall-bladder-cholecyst">The gall bladder (Cholecyst)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-gall-bladder-cholecyst" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="characteristics-of-the-gall-bladder">Characteristics of the gall bladder:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#characteristics-of-the-gall-bladder" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A pear shaped structure, dark green in color.</li>
<li>About 10-12 cm in length.</li>
<li>Connected to the liver and duodenum by the biliary system.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions-of-the-gall-bladder">Functions of the gall bladder:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-the-gall-bladder" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Storage of bile (Between meals bile is stored in the gall bladder. The full capacity of the gall bladder is about 50 ml. This is released into the duodenum up to 10 times per day (i.e. volume of bile released into the intestine = 0.5 L/day)).</li>
<li>Concentration of bile (the mucosa of the gall bladder absorbs water).</li>
<li>Acidification of bile (the mucosa also absorbs bicarbonate).</li>
<li>Note: The gall bladder also controls release of bile through the cystic &amp; common bile ducts into the duodenum (in response to CCK).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="differences-between-hepatic-bile-gall-bladder-bile">Differences between hepatic bile &amp; gall bladder bile:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differences-between-hepatic-bile-gall-bladder-bile" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The gall bladder absorbs Na⁺, Cl⁻ &amp; HCO₃⁻ actively, followed by passive water absorption.</li>
<li>This results in less water, [Na⁺], [Cl⁻], [HCO₃⁻] and pH in bile of the gall bladder compared to hepatic bile; but higher concentrations of the other substances (e.g. bile salts, bile pigment, cholesterol and phospholipids).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-bile">Functions of bile:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-bile" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-neutralization-of-acid-chyme">1- Neutralization of acid chyme<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-neutralization-of-acid-chyme" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>By the high bicarbonate content in bile (alkaline pH).</li>
<li>Note that bile, pancreatic secretion and duodenal secretion all act together to neutralize acid in the duodenum.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-fat-digestion-absorption">2- Fat digestion &amp; absorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-fat-digestion-absorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>By the Bile salts; the bile salts result in: Emulsification (for fat digestion) &amp; Micelle formation (for fat absorption).</li>
</ul>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Emulsification = Breakdown of large fat droplets into smaller ones. This facilitates digestion by increasing surface area of fat droplets for the action of pancreatic lipase.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Micelles = Cylindrical structures formed by bile salts and phospholipids in bile. Bile salts are arranged in away that their hydrophilic parts project to the outside and their hydrophobic parts project to the center inside. Large lipid molecules are enclosed in the center of these micelles. This makes lipids soluble in water &amp; facilitates their transport to the intestinal wall for absorption.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-excretion">3- Excretion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-excretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Bile is an important excretory route for bile pigment (bilirubin), cholesterol, some drugs, some dyes and some inorganic substances.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-b2a00222.jpeg" alt="img-388.jpeg">
Fig 8.15: Emulsification &amp; micelle formation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bile-salts">Bile Salts<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bile-salts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Bile salts are sodium &amp; potassium salts of bile acids.</li>
<li>Bile acids are formed in the liver from cholesterol as two primary bile acids: Cholic acid &amp; chenodeoxycholic acid.</li>
<li>They are found conjugated to the amino acids glycine and taurine.</li>
</ul>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<p>10</p>
<p>In the small intestine, bile salts exert the following effects:</p>
<ol>
<li>Participate in fat digestion &amp; absorption.</li>
<li>Reduce surface tension of fluid in the small intestine.</li>
<li>Stimulate CCK (intimicity, by the products of lipid digestion).</li>
<li>Most of the bile acids (90-95%) are absorbed in the terminal ileum actively to the enterohepatic circulation (they return to the liver and then re-secreted again in bile). The recycling occurs about 6-10 times every day (helozebes). The amount of bile acids that recycles is about 2-4g.</li>
</ol>
<p>In the large intestine, bacteria deconjugate the primary bile acids &amp; convert them into secondary bile acids as follows:</p>
<ol>
<li>Cholic acid to deoxycholic acid.</li>
<li>Chenodeoxycholic acid to lithocholic acid.</li>
<li>Deoxycholic acid is absorbed back to the liver for re-conjugation or secretion whereas most lithocholic acid is excreted in stool.</li>
<li>The amount of bile acids lost daily in stool is about 0.2-0.4g, this is replaced daily by the liver (i.e. the liver forms only 0.2-0.4 g/day).
Note: Intestinal bacteria also deconjugate bile pigments into undolinogens (see RBC destruction in volume 1).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="control-of-bile">CONTROL OF BILE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-bile" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>By two types of factors:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-choleration">1. Choleration:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-choleration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Factors that increase secretion of bile from the liver and its flow within the bile ducts.</li>
<li>They include: Bile salts, secretin, vagus, gastrin &amp; glucagon.</li>
<li>Note that bile salts recycle through the enterohepatic circulation. This recycling increases flow of bile &amp; decreases synthesis of bile acids.</li>
<li>Therefore it is the most important choleretic factor. It is responsible for about 30% of bile flow.</li>
</ul>
<p>101</p>
<p>The use of sodium phosphate 145</p>
<p>In the small intestine, bile salts exert the following effects:</p>
<ol>
<li>Participate in fat digestion &amp; absorption.</li>
<li>Reduce surface tension of fluid in the small intestine.</li>
<li>Stimulate CCK (intimicity, by the products of lipid digestion).</li>
<li>Most of the bile acids (90-95%) are absorbed in the terminal ileum actively to the enterohepatic circulation (they return to the liver and then re-secreted again in bile). The recycling occurs about 6-10 times every day (helozebes). The amount of bile acids that recycles is about 2-4g.</li>
</ol>
<p>In the large intestine, bacteria deconjugate the primary bile acids &amp; convert them into secondary bile acids as follows:</p>
<ol>
<li>Cholic acid to deoxycholic acid.</li>
<li>Chenodeoxycholic acid to lithocholic acid.</li>
<li>Deoxycholic acid is absorbed back to the liver for re-conjugation or secretion whereas most lithocholic acid is excreted in stool.</li>
<li>The amount of bile acids lost daily in stool is about 0.2-0.4g, this is replaced daily by the liver (i.e. the liver forms only 0.2-0.4 g/day).
Note: Intestinal bacteria also deconjugate bile pigments into undolinogens (see RBC destruction in volume 1).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="control-of-bile">CONTROL OF BILE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-bile" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>By two types of factors:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-choleration">1. Choleration:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-choleration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Factors that increase secretion of bile from the liver and its flow within the bile ducts.</li>
<li>They include: Bile salts, secretin, vagus, gastrin &amp; glucagon.</li>
<li>Note that bile salts recycle through the enterohepatic circulation. This recycling increases flow of bile &amp; decreases synthesis of bile acids.</li>
<li>Therefore it is the most important choleretic factor. It is responsible for about 30% of bile flow.</li>
</ul>
<p>102</p>
<p>The use of sodium phosphate 145</p>
<p>In the small intestine, bile salts exert the following effects:</p>
<ol>
<li>Participate in fat digestion &amp; absorption.</li>
<li>Reduce surface tension of fluid in the small intestine.</li>
<li>Stimulate CCK (intimicity, by the products of lipid digestion).</li>
<li>Most of the bile acids (90-95%) are absorbed in the terminal ileum actively to the enterohepatic circulation (they return to the liver and then re-secreted again in bile). The recycling occurs about 6-10 times every day (helozebes). The amount of bile acids that recycles is about 2-4g.</li>
</ol>
<p>In the large intestine, bacteria deconjugate the primary bile acids &amp; convert them into secondary bile acids as follows:</p>

<li>The amount of bile acids lost daily in stool is about 0.2-0.4g, this is replaced daily by the liver (i.e. the liver forms only 0.2-0.4 g/day).
Note: Intestinal bacteria also deconjugate bile pigments into undolinogens (see RBC destruction in volume 1).</li>
