<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abnormalities-of-intestinal-motility">ABNORMALITIES OF INTESTINAL MOTILITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities-of-intestinal-motility" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="intestinal-obstruction">Intestinal obstruction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intestinal-obstruction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Two types</li>
<li>Mechanical obstruction</li>
<li>Paralytic obstruction (adynamic ileus)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="meningoidal-obstruction">Meningoidal obstruction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#meningoidal-obstruction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Caused by stool impaction, tumor, stricture, or hernia.</li>
<li>Characterized by increased peristalsis and distortion of bowel proximal to the site of obstruction. This causes severe solidity abdominal pain.</li>
<li>Blood supply in the distended area is reduced with a risk of perforation.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="treatment-surgery">Treatment Surgery<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#treatment-surgery" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="paralytic-adynamic-ileus">Paralytic (adynamic) ileus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paralytic-adynamic-ileus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs following abdominal operations, peritonitis or due to hypokalemia.</li>
<li>These result in either direct inhibition of smooth muscle or indirect inhibition through increased noradrenergic discharge.</li>
<li>It is characterized by:</li>
<li>Inhibition of peristalsis — no pain</li>
<li>Abdominal distention</li>
<li>Vomiting</li>
<li>Electrolyte disturbance</li>
<li>Following abdominal operations, peristalsis usually returns after 6-8 h (in the small intestine &amp; then the stomach) and after 2-3 days (in the large intestine).</li>
<li>Treatment (Medical treatment). Patients should take nothing per mouth, should have nasogastric tube suction of gastric contents and their electrolyte disturbances should be corrected.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abnormalities-of-intestinal-motility">ABNORMALITIES OF INTESTINAL MOTILITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities-of-intestinal-motility" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="intestinal-obstruction">Intestinal obstruction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intestinal-obstruction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Two types</li>
<li>Mechanical obstruction</li>
<li>Paralytic obstruction (adynamic ileus)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanical-obstruction">Mechanical obstruction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanical-obstruction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Caused by stool impaction, tumor, stricture, or hernia.</li>
<li>Characterized by increased peristalsis and distortion of bowel proximal to the site of obstruction. This causes severe solidity abdominal pain.</li>
<li>Blood supply in the distended area is reduced with a risk of perforation.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="treatment-surgery">Treatment Surgery<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#treatment-surgery" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="paralytic-adynamic-ileus">Paralytic (adynamic) ileus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paralytic-adynamic-ileus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs following abdominal operations, peritonitis or due to hypokalemia.</li>
<li>These result in either direct inhibition of smooth muscle or indirect inhibition through increased noradrenergic discharge.</li>
<li>It is characterized by:</li>
<li>Inhibition of peristalsis — no pain</li>
<li>Abdominal distention</li>
<li>Vomiting</li>
<li>Electrolyte disturbance</li>
<li>Following abdominal operations, peristalsis usually returns after 6-8 h (in the small intestine &amp; then the stomach) and after 2-3 days (in the large intestine).</li>
<li>Treatment (Medical treatment). Patients should take nothing per mouth, should have nasogastric tube suction of gastric contents and their electrolyte disturbances should be corrected.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abnormalities-of-intestinal-motility">ABNORMALITIES OF INTESTINAL MOTILITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities-of-intestinal-motility" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="intestinal-obstruction">Intestinal obstruction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intestinal-obstruction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Two types</li>
<li>Mechanical obstruction</li>
<li>Paralytic obstruction (adynamic ileus)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanical-obstruction">Mechanical obstruction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanical-obstruction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Caused by stool impaction, tumor, stricture, or hernia.</li>
<li>Characterized by increased peristalsis and distortion of bowel proximal to the site of obstruction. This causes severe solidity abdominal pain.</li>
<li>Blood supply in the distended area is reduced with a risk of perforation.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="treatment-surgery">Treatment Surgery<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#treatment-surgery" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="paralytic-adynamic-ileus">Paralytic (adynamic) ileus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paralytic-adynamic-ileus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs following abdominal operations, peritonitis or due to hypokalemia.</li>
<li>These result in either direct inhibition of smooth muscle or indirect inhibition through increased noradrenergic discharge.</li>
<li>It is characterized by:</li>
<li>Inhibition of peristalsis — no pain</li>
<li>Abdominal distention</li>
<li>Vomiting</li>
<li>Electrolyte disturbance</li>
<li>Following abdominal operations, peristalsis usually returns after 6-8 h (in the small intestine &amp; then the stomach) and after 2-3 days (in the large intestine).</li>
<li>Treatment (Medical treatment). Patients should take nothing per mouth, should have nasogastric tube suction of gastric contents and their electrolyte disturbances should be corrected.</li>
</ul>
<p>270
The costs of medical physiology 17th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="definition">DEFINITION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Spring varies initiated by definition of the rectum with focus.</li>
<li>A results in contraction of the rectum and relaxation of the internal and sphincter (in response to parasympathetic stimulation).</li>
<li>This reflex can be facilitated or inhibited by relaxing or contracting the external and sphincter (Skeletal muscle under voluntary control through the pudendal nerve).</li>
<li>The pudendal nerve is a somatic nerve originating from the sacral segments S₄, 184.</li>
<li>The components of this reflex are:
<strong>Reception</strong>: Smooth receptors in the wall of the rectum, stimulated when the rectum is full and its pressure reaches 10 mmHg (e.g. following mass action contraction).
<strong>Afterwards</strong>: Parasympathetic nerves (pelvic splenchitic nerve).
<strong>Center</strong>: Sacral segments (S₄, 184).
<strong>Efferents</strong>: Parasympathetic nerves (pelvic splenchitic nerve).
<strong>Efficiency</strong>: Smooth muscle in the wall of the rectum and smooth muscle of the internal sphincter.</li>
<li>The response of the reflex is contraction of the wall of the rectum and relaxation of the internal sphincter to allow defecation.</li>
<li>This is facilitated (in suitable conditions) by relaxing the external sphincter voluntarily. In unsuitable conditions, the subject contracts the external sphincter to inhibit defecation.</li>
<li>When the pressure in the rectum reaches 55 mmHg, the stool is forced out through the external sphincter in spite of its resistance.</li>
<li>Note that the sympathetic neurons contract the internal sphincter and relax the wall of the rectum, however, they are not part of the defecation reflex.</li>
</ul>
<p>271
The costs of medical physiology 17th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="definition">DEFINITION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Spring varies initiated by definition of the rectum with focus.</li>
<li>A results in contraction of the rectum and relaxation of the internal and sphincter (in response to parasympathetic stimulation).</li>
<li>This reflex can be facilitated or inhibited by relaxing or contracting the external and sphincter (Skeletal muscle under voluntary control through the pudendal nerve).</li>
<li>The pudendal nerve is a somatic nerve originating from the sacral segments S₄, 184.</li>
<li>The components of this reflex are:
<strong>Reception</strong>: Smooth receptors in the wall of the rectum, stimulated when the rectum is full and its pressure reaches 10 mmHg (e.g. following mass action contraction).
<strong>Afterwards</strong>: Parasympathetic nerves (pelvic splenchitic nerve).
<strong>Center</strong>: Sacral segments (S₄, 184).
<strong>Efferents</strong>: Parasympathetic nerves (pelvic splenchitic nerve).
<strong>Efficiency</strong>: Smooth muscle in the wall of the rectum and smooth muscle of the internal sphincter.</li>
<li>The response of the reflex is contraction of the wall of the rectum and relaxation of the internal sphincter to allow defecation.</li>
<li>This is facilitated (in suitable conditions) by relaxing the external sphincter voluntarily. In unsuitable conditions, the subject contracts the external sphincter to inhibit defecation.</li>
<li>When the pressure in the rectum reaches 55 mmHg, the stool is forced out through the external sphincter in spite of its resistance.</li>
<li>Note that the sympathetic neurons contract the internal sphincter and relax the wall of the rectum, however, they are not part of the defecation reflex.</li>
</ul>
<p>272
The costs of medical physiology 17th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abnormalities-of-defecation">Abnormalities of defecation:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities-of-defecation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Transection of the spinal cord above the sacral segments impairs the descending orders from the brain to the external sphincter (resulting in loss of the voluntary control). However, since the external sphincter is in state of contraction, stool is not evacuated until the rectal pressure reaches 55mm Hg. Here it forces its way out.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251216-5e9c636f.jpeg" alt="img-393.jpeg">
Fig 8.20: The defecation reflex</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-gastro-colic-reflex">The gastro-colic reflex<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-gastro-colic-reflex" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>When food enters the stomach, the rectum contracts to allow defecation.</li>
<li>This reflex occurs mainly in children who defecate after meals.</li>
<li>It is not mediated by a neural mechanism.</li>
<li>The hormone gastrin may be responsible for his reflex.</li>
</ul>
<p>The core of medical physiology/ 4th edition</p>
<p>246
The case of random placement of letters</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="digestion-absorption">DIGESTION &amp; ABSORPTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#digestion-absorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Complete substations are known down into absorbable units in the small intestine.</li>
<li>The absorbable units enter either the portal blood or the lymphatic system.</li>
<li>Non-digestible &amp; absorbable units like cellulose &amp; lignin (dietary fiber) are excreted in stool.</li>
<li>These vegetable products add bulk to stool.</li>
<li>When they are present in high amount in food (high fiber diet), they decrease incidence of colonic cancers, diabetes mellitus, ischemic heart disease and other problems.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="carbohydrates">CARBOHYDRATES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#carbohydrates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cho-digestion">CHO Digestion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cho-digestion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Types of CHO in diet:</li>
<li>Monosaccharides:</li>
<li>Glucose</li>
<li>Fructose</li>
<li>Disaccharides:</li>
<li>Maltose (2 glucose)</li>
<li>Trehalose (2 glucose)</li>
<li>Sucrose (glucose + fructose)</li>
<li>Lactose (glucose + galactose)</li>
<li>Polyaccharides (glucose polymers):</li>
<li>Starch</li>
<li>Derivatives of starch (Amylose, amylopectin)</li>
<li>Glycogen</li>
<li>Digestive enzymes:
In the mouth: Salivary is amylose (acts on polysaccharides "starch")</li>
</ul>

The case of random placement of letters</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="digestion-absorption">DIGESTION &amp; ABSORPTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#digestion-absorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="carbohydrates">CARBOHYDRATES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#carbohydrates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cho-digestion">CHO Digestion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cho-digestion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Types of CHO in diet:</li>
<li>Monosaccharides:</li>
<li>Glucose</li>
<li>Fructose</li>
<li>Disaccharides:</li>
<li>Maltose (2 glucose)</li>
<li>Trehalose (2 glucose)</li>
<li>Sucrose (glucose + fructose)</li>
<li>Lactose (glucose + galactose)</li>
<li>Polyaccharides (glucose polymers):</li>
<li>Starch</li>
<li>Derivatives of starch (Amylose, amylopectin)</li>
<li>Glycogen</li>
<li>Digestive enzymes:
In the mouth: Salivary is amylose (acts on polysaccharides "starch")</li>
</ul>
<p>200</p>
<p>In the stomach. No specific enzyme. Delivery is amylase is inhibited (by the low pH).</p>
<p>In the intestine. Pancreatic is amylase (also acts on starch).</p>
<p>able. Salivary is amylase may resume its activity in the intestine (suitable pH)</p>
<p>. Products of starch digestion by is amylase enzymes.</p>
<p>1- Disaccharides: maltose
2- Trisaccharides: maltotriose
3- Short polymers: is dextrose</p>
<p>. Further digestion requires the following intestinal enzymes found in the brush border:</p>
<ul>
<li>α dextinase: Acts on alpha dextinase, maltose &amp; maltotriose</li>
<li>Maltase: Acts on maltose to give glucose + glucose</li>
<li>Sucrose: Acts on sucrose to give glucose + fructose</li>
<li>Lactase: Acts on lactose to give glucose + galactose</li>
<li>Trehalase: Acts on trehalose to give glucose + glucose</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cho-absorption">CHO Absorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cho-absorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>. Only occurs for the monosaccharides (e.g. glucose, galactose ...)</p>
<p>. Absorption is almost 100%</p>
<p>. The absorbed units enter portal circulation</p>
<p>Glucose absorption</p>
<ul>
<li>Co-transported with sodium</li>
<li>Na⁺ facilitates glucose absorption &amp; vice versa.</li>
<li>Water follows sodium; that is why oral rehydration solutions (ORS) are used for treatment of diarrhea. These solutions contain salt and sugar.</li>
<li>Transporters of glucose and sodium:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>On luminal membrane (carriers for co-transport to inside the cell):</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Sodium-glucose transporters 1 &amp; 2 (SGLT1 &amp; SGLT2)</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>On basolateral membrane (carriers for facilitated diffusion to the IBP):</li>
</ol>
<p>Glucose transporters 1 &amp; 2 (SGLT1 &amp; SGLT2)</p>
<p>200</p>
<p>In the stomach. No specific enzyme. Delivery is amylase is inhibited (by the low pH).</p>
<p>In the intestine. Pancreatic is amylase (also acts on starch).</p>
<p>able. Salivary is amylase may resume its activity in the intestine (suitable pH)</p>
<p>. Products of starch digestion by is amylase enzymes:</p>
<p>1- Disaccharides: maltose
2- Trisaccharides: maltotriose
3- Short polymers: is dextrose</p>
<p>. Further digestion requires the following intestinal enzymes found in the brush border:</p>
<ul>
<li>α dextinase: Acts on alpha dextinase, maltose &amp; maltotriose</li>
<li>Maltase: Acts on maltose to give glucose + glucose</li>
<li>Sucrose: Acts on sucrose to give glucose + fructose</li>
<li>Lactase: Acts on lactose to give glucose + galactose</li>
<li>Trehalase: Acts on trehalose to give glucose + glucose</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cho-absorption">CHO Absorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cho-absorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>. Only occurs for the monosaccharides (e.g. glucose, galactose ...)</p>
<p>. Absorption is almost 100%</p>
<p>. The absorbed units enter portal circulation</p>
<p>Glucose absorption</p>
<ul>
<li>Co-transported with sodium</li>
<li>Na⁺ facilitates glucose absorption &amp; vice versa.</li>
<li>Water follows sodium; that is why oral rehydration solutions (ORS) are used for treatment of diarrhea. These solutions contain salt and sugar.</li>
<li>Transporters of glucose and sodium:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>On luminal membrane (carriers for co-transport to inside the cell):</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Sodium-glucose transporters 1 &amp; 2 (SGLT1 &amp; SGLT2)</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>On basolateral membrane (carriers for facilitated diffusion to the IBP):</li>
</ol>
<p>Glucose transporters 1 &amp; 2 (SGLT1 &amp; SGLT2)</p>
<p>200</p>
<p>In the stomach. No specific enzyme. Delivery is amylase is inhibited (by the low pH).</p>
<p>In the intestine. Pancreatic is amylase (also acts on starch).</p>
<p>able. Salivary is amylase may resume its activity in the intestine (suitable pH)</p>
<p>. Products of starch digestion by is amylase enzymes:</p>
<p>1- Disaccharides: maltose
2- Trisaccharides: maltotriose
3- Short polymers: is dextrose</p>
<p>. Further digestion requires the following intestinal enzymes found in the brush border:</p>
<ul>
<li>α dextinase: Acts on alpha dextinase, maltose &amp; maltotriose</li>
<li>Maltase: Acts on maltose to give glucose + glucose</li>
<li>Sucrose: Acts on sucrose to give glucose + fructose</li>
<li>Lactase: Acts on lactose to give glucose + galactose</li>
<li>Trehalase: Acts on trehalose to give glucose + glucose</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cho-absorption">CHO Absorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cho-absorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>. Only occurs for the monosaccharides (e.g. glucose, galactose ...)</p>
<p>. Absorption is almost 100%</p>
<p>. The absorbed units enter portal circulation</p>
<p>Glucose absorption</p>
<ul>
<li>Co-transported with sodium</li>
<li>Na⁺ facilitates glucose absorption &amp; vice versa.</li>
<li>Water follows sodium; that is why oral rehydration solutions (ORS) are used for treatment of diarrhea. These solutions contain salt and sugar.</li>
<li>Transporters of glucose and sodium:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>On luminal membrane (carriers for co-transport to inside the cell):</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Sodium-glucose transporters 1 &amp; 2 (SGLT1 &amp; SGLT2)</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>On basolateral membrane (carriers for facilitated diffusion to the IBP):</li>
</ol>
<p>Glucose transporters 1 &amp; 2 (SGLT1 &amp; SGLT2)</p>
<p>200</p>
<ul>
<li>Remember that: Glucose transporters are also found in the cells of the proximal convoluted tubules in the kidney for reabsorption of sodium and glucose (see chapter 8).</li>
<li>Glucose transporters are also found in other cells in the body. They are seven types, among these types, only GLUT-4 is sensitive to insulin (found in fat &amp; muscle cells).</li>
<li>(Intestinal absorption: Similar to glucose (i.e. so transported with sodium "secondary active transport")</li>
<li>Fructose absorption: Facilitated diffusion</li>
<li>Pantoan absorption: Produced from metabolism of nucleic acids. Absorbed by simple diffusion.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="abnormalities-of-cho-digestion-absorption">Abnormalities of CHO digestion &amp; absorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities-of-cho-digestion-absorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Deficiency of the digestive enzymes in the intestinal brush border (by a congenital or acquired cause) results in diarrhea, abdominal distention and flatulence. This usually follows ingestion of a carbohydrate meal and its breakdown by the intestinal bacteria resulting in increased number of narcotic particles (causing diarrhea) and excessive release of gases (causing abdominal distention &amp; flatulence).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A good example is lactose intolerance due to deficiency of lactose enzymes. Have symptoms follow ingestion of milk.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The condition is caused by avoidance of milk and use of yogurt, which contains bacterial lactase.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Remember that: Glucose transporters are also found in the cells of the proximal convoluted tubules in the kidney for reabsorption of sodium and glucose (see chapter 9).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Glucose transporters are also found in other cells in the body. They are seven types, among these types, only GLUT-4 is sensitive to insulin (found in fat &amp; muscle cells).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>(Intestinal absorption: Similar to glucose (i.e. so transported with sodium "secondary active transport")</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pantoan absorption: Facilitated diffusion</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pantoan absorption: Produced from metabolism of nucleic acids. Absorbed by simple diffusion.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="abnormalities-of-cho-digestion-absorption">Abnormalities of CHO digestion &amp; absorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities-of-cho-digestion-absorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Deficiency of the digestive enzymes in the intestinal brush border (by a congenital or acquired cause) results in diarrhea, abdominal distention and flatulence. This usually follows ingestion of a carbohydrate meal and its breakdown by the intestinal bacteria resulting in increased number of narcotic particles (causing diarrhea) and excessive release of gases (causing abdominal distention &amp; flatulence).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A good example is lactose intolerance due to deficiency of lactose enzymes. Have symptoms follow ingestion of milk.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The condition is caused by avoidance of milk and use of yogurt, which contains bacterial lactase.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Remember that: Glucose transporters are also found in the cells of the proximal convoluted tubules in the kidney for reabsorption of sodium and glucose (see chapter 9).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Glucose transporters are also found in other cells in the body. They are seven types, among these types, only GLUT-4 is sensitive to insulin (found in fat &amp; muscle cells).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>(Intestinal absorption: Similar to glucose (i.e. so transported with sodium "secondary active transport")</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pantoan absorption: Facilitated diffusion</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pantoan absorption: Produced from metabolism of nucleic acids. Absorbed by simple diffusion.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="abnormalities-of-cho-digestion-absorption">Abnormalities of CHO digestion &amp; absorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities-of-cho-digestion-absorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Deficiency of the digestive enzymes in the intestinal brush border (by a congenital or acquired cause) results in diarrhea, abdominal distention and flatulence. This usually follows ingestion of a carbohydrate meal and its breakdown by the intestinal bacteria resulting in increased number of narcotic particles (causing diarrhea) and excessive release of gases (causing abdominal distention &amp; flatulence).</li>
<li>A good example is lactose intolerance due to deficiency of lactose enzymes. Have symptoms follow ingestion of milk.</li>
<li>The condition is caused by avoidance of milk and use of yogurt, which contains bacterial lactase.</li>
</ul>
<p>400
The Journal of Infectious Diseases 2007, Vol. 12, No. 1, pp. 100-104
401
The Journal of Infectious Diseases 2007, Vol. 12, No. 1, pp. 100-104</p>
<p>401
The Journal of Medical Microbiology, 4th Edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="section">Section<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="health-digestion">Health Digestion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-digestion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Sources of protein:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Diet</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Off secretions &amp; desquamated cells.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Digestive enzymes:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In the mouth: No enzyme for digestion.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In the stomach: Protein, gelatinase and mucin (See gastric secretion).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In the intestine: Pancreatic endopeptidases (Trypsin, chymotrypsin, and elastase) and pancreatic exopeptidase (Carboxypeptidases (A &amp; B)). Then further digestion occurs by proteolytic enzymes found in the brush border (aminopeptidase, carboxypeptidase, endopeptidase and dipeptidase).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Products of protein digestion:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Free amino acids</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Dipeptides and tripeptides</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>These are further digested by peptidases in the cytoplasm of cells.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="protein-absorption">Protein Absorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#protein-absorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>About 85-90% of proteins are digested &amp; absorbed.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The absorbed units enter portal circulation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Absorption of free amino acids</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Co-transport with sodium (mainly)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Absorption of dipeptides &amp; tripeptides</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>By a mechanism involving hydrogen ions.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Contains proteins (undigested):</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Occurs in infants for IgA antibodies in milk by endocytosis.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>402
The Journal of Medical Microbiology, 4th Edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="section">Section<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="protein-digestion">Protein Digestion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#protein-digestion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Sources of protein:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Diet</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Off secretions &amp; desquamated cells.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Digestive enzymes:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In the mouth: No enzyme for digestion.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In the stomach: Protein, gelatinase and mucin (See gastric secretion).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In the intestine: Pancreatic endopeptidases (Trypsin, chymotrypsin, and elastase) and pancreatic exopeptidase (Carboxypeptidases (A &amp; B)). Then further digestion occurs by proteolytic enzymes found in the brush border (aminopeptidase, carboxypeptidase, endopeptidase and dipeptidase).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Products of protein digestion:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Free amino acids</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Dipeptides and tripeptides</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>These are further digested by peptidases in the cytoplasm of cells.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="protein-absorption">Protein Absorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#protein-absorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>About 95-69% of proteins are digested &amp; absorbed.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The absorbed units enter portal circulation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Absorption of free amino acids</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Co-transport with sodium (mainly)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Absorption of dipeptides &amp; tripeptides</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>By a mechanism involving hydrogen ions.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Contains proteins (undigested):</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Occurs in infants for IgA antibodies in milk by endocytosis.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>403
The Journal of Medical Microbiology, 4th Edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sections">Sections<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="protein-digestion">Protein Digestion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#protein-digestion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Sources of protein:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Diet</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Off secretions &amp; desquamated cells.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Digestive enzymes:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In the mouth: No enzyme for digestion.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In the stomach: Protein, gelatinase and mucin (See gastric secretion).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In the intestine: Pancreatic endopeptidases (Trypsin, chymotrypsin, and elastase) and pancreatic exopeptidase (Carboxypeptidases (A &amp; B)). Then further digestion occurs by proteolytic enzymes found in the brush border (aminopeptidase, carboxypeptidase, endopeptidase and dipeptidase).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Products of protein digestion:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Free amino acids</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Dipeptides and tripeptides</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>These are further digested by peptidases in the cytoplasm of cells.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="protein-absorption">Protein Absorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#protein-absorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>About 95-56% of proteins are digested &amp; absorbed.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The absorbed units enter portal circulation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Absorption of free amino acids</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Co-transport with sodium (mainly)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Absorption of dipeptides &amp; tripeptides</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>By a mechanism involving hydrogen ions.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Contains proteins (undigested):</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Occurs in infants for IgA antibodies in milk by endocytosis.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>402
The view of medical physiology 17 (2004)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abnormalities-of-protein-digestion-absorption">Abnormalities of protein digestion &amp; absorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities-of-protein-digestion-absorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Absorption of foreign proteins induces antibody formation; this explains allergy to certain types of food.</p>
<ul>
<li>Congenital defects in the mechanisms of amino acid absorption result in injury, errors of metabolism. Examples include: Hartrup disease &amp; Cyclinuria.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abnormalities-of-protein-digestion-absorption">Abnormalities of protein digestion &amp; absorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities-of-protein-digestion-absorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Absorption of foreign proteins induces antibody formation; this explains allergy to certain types of food.</p>
<ul>
<li>Congenital defects in the mechanisms of amino acid absorption result in injury, errors of metabolism. Examples include: Hartrup disease &amp; Cyclinuria.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lipids">LIPIDS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lipids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lipid-digestion">Lipid Digestion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lipid-digestion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Lipids in diet:</li>
<li>Triglycerides &amp; cholesteryl esters</li>
<li>Digestive enzymes:</li>
<li>In the mouth:</li>
<li>Lingual lipase (acts on triglycerides)</li>
<li>In the stomach:</li>
<li>Gastric lipase</li>
<li>In the intestine: (from the pancreas and from the liver)</li>
<li>From the pancreas:</li>
<li>Pancreatic lipase &amp; Colipase (revise contents of pancreatic secretory)</li>
<li>Bile salt activated lipase</li>
<li>Cholesteryl ester hydrolase</li>
<li>From the liver:</li>
<li>Bile salts, which cause emulsification and muscle formation (see functions of bile).</li>
</ul>
<p>403
The view of medical physiology 17 (2004)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lipois">LIPOIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lipois" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lipid-digestion">Lipid Digestion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lipid-digestion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Lipids in diet:</li>
<li>Triglycerides &amp; cholesteryl esters</li>
<li>Digestive enzymes:</li>
<li>In the mouth:</li>
<li>Lingual lipase (acts on triglycerides)</li>
<li>In the stomach:</li>
<li>Gastric lipase</li>
<li>In the intestine: (from the pancreas and from the liver)</li>
<li>From the pancreas:</li>
<li>Pancreatic lipase &amp; Colipase (revise contents of pancreatic secretory)</li>
<li>Bile salt activated lipase</li>
<li>Cholesteryl ester hydrolase</li>
<li>From the liver:</li>
<li>Bile salts, which cause emulsification and muscle formation (see functions of bile).</li>
</ul>
<p>404
The view of medical physiology 17 (2004)</p>
<p>4-2
The costs of medical informational 4th edition
4-3
The costs of medical informational 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lipid-absorption">Lipid Absorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lipid-absorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>More than 90% of fats are absorbed in adults, but less than that in infants.</li>
<li>Most fats are absorbed by passive diffusion. However, carriers may be packed.</li>
<li>Be absorbed units either enter portal circulation or lymphatics as follows:</li>
<li>Fats entering the portal blood have carbons = (10-12) e.g. short chain free fatty acids (FFAs).</li>
<li>Fats entering the lymphatics have carbons = (10-17) e.g. long chain free fatty acids and cholesterol.</li>
<li>Before entering the lymphatics, the long chain fatty acids and cholesterol are transmitted within the cytoplasm of intestinal cells and become coated with protein &amp; phospholipids to form chylomicrons.</li>
<li>Chylomicrons are released to lymphatics by exocytosis.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abnormalities-of-fat-digestion-absorption">Abnormalities of fat digestion &amp; absorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities-of-fat-digestion-absorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="deuteronose-fatty-stool">Deuteronose (fatty stool)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#deuteronose-fatty-stool" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Use of more than 5 grams of fat in stool per day.</li>
<li>Deuteronose is caused by conditions that impair release of pancreatic lipase or bile salts into the small intestine.</li>
<li>For example: Chronic pancreatitis &amp; obstruction of the common bile duct.</li>
<li>Stool is usually bulky, offensive and difficult to flush, because of fats.</li>
<li>Note that the total weight of normal stool is about 60-200 g/day but 75% of this amount is water, also there are other constituents not dietary in origin like bacteria &amp; desquamated cells.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lipid-absorption">Lipid Absorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lipid-absorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>More than 90% of fats are absorbed in adults, but less than that in infants.</li>
<li>Most fats are absorbed by passive diffusion. However, carriers may be packed.</li>
<li>Be absorbed units either enter portal circulation or lymphatics as follows:</li>
<li>Fats entering the portal blood have carbons = (10-17) e.g. short chain free fatty acids (FFAs).</li>
<li>Fats entering the lymphatics have carbons = (10-12) e.g. long chain free fatty acids and cholesterol.</li>
<li>Before entering the lymphatics, the long chain fatty acids and cholesterol are transmitted within the cytoplasm of intestinal cells and become coated with protein &amp; phospholipids to form chylomicrons.</li>
<li>Chylomicrons are released to lymphatics by exocytosis.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abnormalities-of-fat-digestion-absorption">Abnormalities of fat digestion &amp; absorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities-of-fat-digestion-absorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="deuteronose-fatty-stool">Deuteronose (fatty stool)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#deuteronose-fatty-stool" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Use of more than 5 grams of fat in stool per day.</li>
<li>Deuteronose is caused by conditions that impair release of pancreatic lipase or bile salts into the small intestine.</li>
<li>For example: Chronic pancreatitis &amp; obstruction of the common bile duct.</li>
<li>Stool is usually bulky, offensive and difficult to flush, because of fats.</li>
<li>Note that the total weight of normal stool is about 60-200 g/day but 75% of this amount is water, also there are other constituents not dietary in origin like bacteria &amp; desquamated cells.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lipid-absorption">Lipid Absorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lipid-absorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>More than 90% of fats are absorbed in adults, but less than that in infants.</li>
<li>Most fats are absorbed by passive diffusion. However, carriers may be packed.</li>
<li>Be absorbed units either enter portal circulation or lymphatics as follows:</li>
<li>Fats entering the portal blood have carbons = (10-12) e.g. short chain free fatty acids (FFAs).</li>
<li>Fats entering the lymphatics have carbons = (10-12) e.g. long chain free fatty acids and cholesterol.</li>
<li>Before entering the lymphatics, the long chain fatty acids and cholesterol are transmitted within the cytoplasm of intestinal cells and become coated with protein &amp; phospholipids to form chylomicrons.</li>
<li>Chylomicrons are released to lymphatics by exocytosis.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abnormalities-of-fat-digestion-absorption">Abnormalities of fat digestion &amp; absorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abnormalities-of-fat-digestion-absorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="deuteronose-fatty-stool">Deuteronose (fatty stool)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#deuteronose-fatty-stool" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Use of more than 5 grams of fat in stool per day.</li>
<li>Deuteronose is caused by conditions that impair release of pancreatic lipase or bile salts into the small intestine.</li>
<li>For example: Chronic pancreatitis &amp; obstruction of the common bile duct.</li>
<li>Stool is usually bulky, offensive and difficult to flush, because of fats.</li>
<li>Note that the total weight of normal stool is about 60-200 g/day but 75% of this amount is water, also there are other constituents not dietary in origin like bacteria &amp; desquamated cells.</li>
</ul>
<p>404
The issue of mechanical engineering / 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="absorption-of-electrolytes">ABSORPTION OF ELECTROLYTES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#absorption-of-electrolytes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sodium">Sodium:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sodium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Absorbed throughout the small &amp; large intestines, actively by the action of the Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase pumps on the basolateral membranes of intestinal cells.</li>
<li>Glucose facilitates absorption of sodium on the apical membranes (through the SOLTs, less above).</li>
<li>Other substances that are co-transported with sodium on the apical membranes include: galactose, mannose, amino acids, lactate, iodide, bile acids and some short chain fatty acids.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chloride">Chloride:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chloride" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Absorbed passively with sodium and possibly actively in exchange laboratories.</li>
<li>Recorded to the intestinal lumen through chloride channels.</li>
<li>Enters enterocytes from 60⁻ by (Na-K₂CO) co-transporters on the basolateral membranes.</li>
<li>Part of the cholera toxin enters enterocytes &amp; increases cAMP. This results in activation of the chloride channels through a protein kinase.</li>
<li>The activation causes severe watery diarrhea because it increases chloride secretion, decreases NaCl absorption and increases water loss.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="potassium">Potassium:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#potassium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Recorded into the intestinal lumen by diffusion or active secretion.</li>
<li>Aldosterone increases K⁺ secretion in the colon (by increasing Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase pump activity in the basolateral membranes of intestinal cells).</li>
<li>In the distal colon some K⁺ is absorbed back by H⁺/K⁺ ATPase pump in the luminal membrane.</li>
<li>Chronic diarrhea decreases the absorption resulting in loss of K⁺ (= hypokalemia + periodic ileus).</li>
<li>See iron absorption in volume 1 &amp; calcium absorption below in the endocrine system.</li>
</ul>
<p>405
The issue of mechanical engineering / 4th edition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="absorption-of-electrolytes">ABSORPTION OF ELECTROLYTES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#absorption-of-electrolytes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sodium">Sodium:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sodium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Absorbed throughout the small &amp; large intestines, actively by the action of the Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase pumps on the basolateral membranes of intestinal cells.</li>
<li>Glucose facilitates absorption of sodium on the apical membranes (through the SOLTs, less above).</li>
<li>Other substances that are co-transported with sodium on the apical membranes include: galactose, mannose, amino acids, lactate, iodide, bile acids and some short chain fatty acids.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chloride">Chloride:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chloride" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Absorbed passively with sodium and possibly actively in exchange laboratories.</li>
<li>Recorded to the intestinal lumen through chloride channels.</li>
<li>Enters enterocytes from 60⁻ by (Na-K₂CO) co-transporters on the basolateral membranes.</li>
<li>Part of the cholera toxin enters enterocytes &amp; increases cAMP. This results in activation of the chloride channels through a protein kinase.</li>
<li>The activation causes severe watery diarrhea because it increases chloride secretion, decreases NaCl absorption and increases water loss.</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-the-large-intestine-differs-from-the-small-intestine-because">1. The large intestine: differs from the small intestine because:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-the-large-intestine-differs-from-the-small-intestine-because" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<li>It is a plant's absorption in water and electrolytes</li>
<li>It invests its own contents by peroxides</li>
<li>It has lower number of genes cells</li>
<li>Its longitudinal muscle layer is incomplete</li>
<li>It is not supplied by the vagus nerve</li>
</ul>

<li>Decreased water content of feces</li>
<li>Decreased water content of feces</li>
<li>Prolonged constipation</li>
</ul>
<ol start="11">
<li>Bile</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>A transition to the gall bladder</li>
<li>Contains lipase for digestion of lipids</li>
<li>A waste due to bile acids</li>
<li>Releases in the blood for CCU</li>
<li>Decrease surface tension of intestinal fluid</li>
<li>Decreased water content of feces</li>
<li>Increased water content of feces</li>
<li>Prolonged constipation</li>
</ul>
<p>16- The following enzyme is essential for protein digestion:</p>
<p>a- Alpha amylase
b- Lingual lipase
c- Pepsin
d- Trypsin
e- Alkaline phosphatase</p>
<p>17- Water and electrolyte in the GI tract are:</p>
<p>a- Derived mainly from ingested fluids
b- Absorbed mainly in the large intestine
c- Equilibrated with GI secretions at the stomach
d- Absorbed mainly in the jejunum
e- Absorbed in response to activity of GI hormones</p>
<p>18- The following vitamin is absorbed primarily by diffusion:</p>
<p>a- Vitamin C
b- Folic acid
c- Vitamin D
d- Vitamin B12
e- Niacin</p>
<p>19- Pancreatic secretion rich in bicarbonate is released in response to:</p>
<p>a- CCK
b- Vagal stimulation
c- Glucagon
d- Gastrin
e- Secretin</p>
<p>20- Which of the following is directly activated by trypsin:</p>
<p>a- Enterokinase
b- Co-lipase
c- Pepsinogen
d- Pancreatic lipase
e- Alpha amylase</p>
<p>21- Bile salts are</p>
<p>a- Synthesized from hemoglobin
b- Absorbed in terminal ileum
c- Form chilomicrons within the enterocytes
d- Responsible for the color of stool</p>
<p>50% are absorbed to the enterohepatic circulation</p>
